superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter j j
The fifth letter of the alphabet: called jiymN, which is one of the names of letters of the fem. gender, but which it is allowable to make masc.: it is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only]: and of the number of the letters termed maHoquwrap, and Huruwfu Alqaloqalapi, because it cannot be uttered in a case of pause without a strong compression, and a strong sound: and it is also one of those termed $ajoriy~ap, from Al$~ajoru, which is the place of opening of the mouth. (TA.) ― -b2- It is sometimes substituted for Y, when the latter letter is doubled, (K,) or is so substituted by some of the Arabs; (AA, S;) as in fuqayomij~N, for fuqayomiY~N; (AA, S, K;) and mur~ij~N, for mur~iY~N. (AA, S.) An Arab of the desert recited to Khalaf El-Ahmar,
AlomuToEimaAni Al~aHoma biA@loEa$ij~i xaAliY EuwayofN waA^abuw Ealij~i
[My maternal uncle is 'Oweyf, and Aboo-'Alijj, who feed with flesh-meat at nightfall]; meaning EaliY~ and Ea$iY~. (S.) It is also sometimes substituted for a single Y. (S, K.) AZ gives the following ex.:
yaA rab~i A_ino kunota qabilota Huj~atijo
falaA yazaAlu $aAHijN yaA^otiyka bijo
[O my Lord, if Thou accept my plea, a brayer (or mule) shall not cease to bring me to Thee (i. e. to thy temple)]; (S;) meaning Huj~atiY (K) [and biY]. A^amosajato and A^amosajaA are also mentioned as occurring in a verse, for A^amosato and A^amosaY [because originally A^amosayato and A^amosaYa]. (S.) But all these substitutions are abominable, (S, Ibn-'Osfoor,) and only allowable in cases of poetical necessity. (Ibn- 'Osfoor.) It is further said that some of the Arabs, among whom were the tribe of Kudá'ah, changed Y, when occurring immediately after E, into j; and said, for raAEK, [originally raAEiYN,] raAEijN: this is what is termed EajoEajapN: Fr attributes the substitution of j for Y to the tribe of Teiyi, and some of the tribe of Asad. (TA.) ― -b3- Some of the Arabs also changed it into Y; saying $ayarapN for $ajarapN, and javoyaAvN for javojaAvN, and yaS~aSa for jaS~aSa. (AZ, S in art. yS.) ＝ -A2- [As a numeral, j denotes Three; and, as such, is generally written without the dot, but thus H, or thus H, to distinguish it from H, which denotes eight.]

juw^ojuw^N *
The breast (Sador, Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán, ” S, K, TA) of a human being, (TA,) and of a bird, and (tropical:) of a ship: (S, TA:) or the sternum, or breast-bone: or the middle of the breast: or the part where the heads of the bones of the breast come together; as in the Nh and M: (TA:) pl. jaA=jiy^u. (S, K.) An Arab is related to have said, maA A^aToyaba juw*aAba AlA^aruz~i bijaA=jiy^i AlA_iwaz~i [How delicious is jw*Ab of rice (i. e. rice prepared with sugar and flesh-meat) with the breasts of geese!]. (TA.) And you say, $aq~ati Als~afiynapu bijuw^ojuw^ihaA (tropical:) [The ship clave the water with her breast]. (TA.)

1 jaA^aba *
, aor.
jaAa^a
, (S, K,) inf. n. jaA^obN, (S,) He gained, earned, or acquired, (S, K,) wealth, or property: (K:) but [SM says,] I have not seen that any of the leading lexicologists has mentioned this addition of wealth, or property. (TA. [See, however, jaA^~=bN, below.]) The rájiz (Ru-beh Ibn-El-'Ajjáj, TA) says,
waA@ll~`hu raAEiY EamaliY wajaA^obiY
[And God is mindful of my work and my earning]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also He sold jaA^obi, i. e. magorap [red ochre]; (IAar, K;) and so jabaA^a. (IAar, TA.)

jaA^obN *
Thick, gross, big, or bulky: (S, K:) or strong: (A:) applied to an ass, (A, K,) or to a wild ass: (S, K:) as also jaAbN, without ': (S:) pl. juw^uwbN. (TA.) Accord. to the K [and the A], it signifies also Whatever is rude, or coarse; thick, gross, big, or bulky: (kul~u jaAfK galiyZK:) but in the L, we find kaAhilN jaA^obN galiyZN [meaning that jaA^obN applied to the part of the back termed kAhl signifies thick, or big]: and xaloqN jaA^obN as meaning a thick, gross, big, or bulky, make. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AljaA^obu The lion. (A, Sgh, K.) ― -b3- And jaA^obapu AlmidoraY, (S, A, K,) or, accord. to AO (S) and the Mj (TA) and Sh, (TA in art. jwb q. v.,) without ', (S, TA,) A doe-gazelle having her horn just come forth; because the horn when it first comes forth is thick, and afterwards becomes slender; (S, K;) thus showing her to be young: (S:) or a doe-gazelle, and a cow, strong in the horn. (A.) [See also art. jwb.] ― -b4- You say also, fulaAnN $axotu AlA=li jaA^obu AlS~abori (assumed tropical:) Such a one is slender in body, or person, [but] great in patience. (S.) ＝ -A2- The navel. (K.) ＝ -A3- Red ochre; syn. magorap [read by Golius mEzp]; (Mj, K;) with and without ', (Mj, TA.)

jaA^obapu AlbaToni *
, (Ibn-Buzurj, K,) as also jaboA^apu AlbaToni, (Ibn-Buzurj, TA,) i. q. maA^onapu AlbaToni, (K,) i. e. The part of the belly that is between the navel and the pubes. (TA.)

juw^obapN *
: see what next follows.

juw^uwbapN *
(K) and juw^obapN↓ (K accord. to some copies, but not in others nor in the TA) A grinning, and frowning, or contracting, of the face; or looking sternly, austerely, or morosely. (K.)

jaA^~=bN *
A gainer, an earner, or an acquirer, of wealth, or property. (TA voce jaw~aAbN.)

jaAvaliyqN jAvlyq jvlyq
[an arabicized word, from the Greek καθολικὸς, The catholicos; i. e.] the primate of the Christians in the country of El- Islám, [residing] in the [chief] city of El-Islám: under him is the biToriyq [or biToriyk, or baTorak, i. e. patriarch] of Antioch: then, under him, is the maToraAn [or metropolitan]; under whom is the A^usoquf~ [or bishop], in every province: then, the qis~iys [or priest]: then, the $am~aAs [or deacon]: (K:) accord. to Sgh, a judge, or ruler: in the Tekmileh, a wise man, or sage. (TA.) j and q do not occur in any one word, unless it is arabicized or a word imitative of a sound: (S and K * at the beginning of the section in which this word is mentioned:) accord. to El-Jawáleekee, they do not occur in any Arabic word unless separated, as in jalawobaqN and jaranodaqN: accord. to Lth, they occur in many words, most of which are arabicized. (TA ib.)

1 jaA^ara *
, aor.
jaAa^a
, inf. n. juw^aArN (S, A, K) and jaA^or (K,) He, (a bull, S and K, or a calf, A,) and jaA^orato she, (a cow, K,) lowed. (S, A, K.) juw^aArN is like xuwaArN; and is substituted for the latter in a reading of the Kur vii. 146 and xx. 90. (Akh, S.) ― -b2- Also, (S, A, K,) inf. ns. as above, (K,) He (a man praying, A and TA) raised his voice in prayer, or supplication: (Th, K:) he cried out: (Es-Suddee, TA:) he cried out, calling for aid, or succour; humbled, or abased, himself, and raised his voice: (A:) he humbled, or abased, himself, with earnest supplication; (S, K;) AilaY A@ll~`hi
to God; (S;) and cried out, or called, for aid, or succour. (K.) [Accord. to Katádeh, yajoA^aruwna in the Kur xxiii. 66 signifies yaxoraEuwna, as written in the TA; but this is app. a mistranscription for yajozaEuwna, They manifest grief and agitation; &c.] ― -b3- Also (tropical:) It (a plant) grew tall; (A, K;) like as one says, SaAHati Al$~ajarapu. (A.) And jaA^arati AlA^aroDu (tropical:) The plants, or herbage, of the land grew tall. (A, K.)

jaA^orN *
, applied to herbage, (Az, A, K,) (tropical:) Fresh, juicy, or sappy: (K, * TA:) or tall, and fullgrown: (Az, TA:) and abundant. (A, K.) ― -b2- gayovN jaA^orN, (K,) and juw^arN↓, (As, S, A, K,) and, accord. to As, juw^aArN↓, (TA voce jawar~N,) as also jiwar~N, (K,) (tropical:) A copious rain; (As, S, A, K;) that makes the plants, or herbage, to grow tall: (A:) or the second, a rain that makes a sound, or noise. (TA.)

juw^~rN *
: see jaA^orN.

juw^aArN *
: see jaA^orN.

huwa jaA^~rN biAll~ayoli *
[He is one who cries out, calling for aid, or succour; who humbles, or abases, himself, and raises his voice; much, or often, by night]. (A, TA.)

1 jaA^a$ato nafosuhu *
, aor.
jaAa^a
, His soul rose, or heaved, by reason of grief or fear; (As, K;) a dial. var. of jaA$ato, aor. tajiy$u. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, both of these, His (a coward's) soul purposed flight: or was frightened. (TA in art. jy$.) ― -b3- jaA^a$a A_ilayohi, aor.
jaAa^a
, He came, came forward, or advanced, towards him. (K.)

jaA^o$o *
The return to its place, (ruwaAE, Lth, S, K,) or the fright, (rawoE, as in a copy of the A, [which latter is agreeable with explanations of the verb given above,]) of the heart, when in a state of commotion on an occasion of fright. (Lth, S, A, K.) ＝ -A2- The soul (nafos) of a man: (IDrd, A, K:) or his heart: or firmness, or constancy, of heart: or strength of heart when one hears a thing and knows not what it is: (TA:) sometimes, [jaA$N,] without ': (K:) pl. juw^uw$N (K) and jiy^aA$N. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN raAbiTu AljaA^o$i Such a one restrains his soul, or himself, from flight, by reason of his courage; (S A; *) is strong in heart; as also rabiyTu AljaA^o$i: (S in art. rbT:) or both signify is courageous. (K in art. rbT, q. v.) And waAhiY AljaA^o$i [Infirm, or weak, in soul, or heart]. (A, TA.) And rabaTa li*`lika AlA^amori jaA^o$FA, (A,) or jaA$FA only, [without ',] (ISk, TA,) see art. rbT. And rabaTa jaA^o$uhu His heart became strong. (K in art. rbT q. v.) ― -b2- See also juw^o$uw$N.

juw^o$N *
: see what follows.

juw^o$uw$N *
The breast, or chest; (S, A, K;) as also jaA^o$N↓ and juw^o$N↓: (A:) or its Hayozuwm, q. v. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- The forepart (Sador) of the night; accord. to which explanation it is tropical: or what is between the beginning and the third thereof: or a while thereof: (TA:) or a portion thereof; (Lh, K;) and of people. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also A thick, or gross, or coarse, man. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

jayoA^alu *
The DabuE [or female hyena]; (S, K;) a name thereof, of the measure fayoEalu, determinate without Al (S,) imperfectly decl.; (K;) as also jayoA^alapu↓, (S, K,) accord. to Ks; (S;) and jayalu, without ', (S, K,) the Y not being changed into A as in naAbN and the like because the ', though literally suppressed, is considered as though meant to be retained, and because the Y is considered as though meant to be quiescent; (Aboo-'Alee the grammarian, S, TA;) and AljayoA^alu, (K,) like the first, but with Al. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, AljayoA^alu, accord. to Ibn-Es-Seed, The wolf: but MF deems this strange. (TA.)

jayoA^alapu *
: see above.

jaAmN jAm
: see art. jwm.

jaAmuwsN jAmws
: see art. jys.

juw^onapN *
A receptacle of the kind termed safaT, covered with skin, for the perfumes of the seller of perfumes; as also juwnapN: originally with ': pl. like SuradN [i. e. juwanN: thus in the TA, without ']. (K.) See also art. jwn.

jaAhN jAh jAp
: see art. jwh.

jaAwarosN jAwrs
: see art. jrs.

superEntry.head: Quasi jA^y
superEntry.entry:
3 jaAA=niY jAA=nY jAA=ny
: see 3 in art. jyA^.

1 jab~ahu jb jbh jbp
, aor.
jabu3a
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. jab~N (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and jibaAbN, (A, K, MF,) He cut it; or cut it off; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also Ajtbahu↓. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- jab~a xuSaAhu, inf. n. jab~N and jibaAbN, He cut off entirely, or extirpated, his testicles; (TA;) [as also Aijotab~ahaA↓; for] jab~N (A, K) and jibaAbN and AijotibaAbN (TA) signify the cutting off entirely, or extirpating, (A, K, TA,) of the testicle, (K, TA,) or of the genitals: (A:) [or] jibaAbN signifies [or signifies also, as inf. n. of jub~a,] the having the testicles, (S, TA,) or genitals, (Msb,) entirely cut off. (S, * Msb, TA.) You say also, jababotuhu, meaning I cut off entirely, or extirpated, his genitals; (Msb;) [or his testicles; or his penis; as is implied in the TA:] and jub~a, inf. n. jab~N, (Mgh, TA,) [or jibaAbN,] he had his penis and his testicles [or either of these] cut off entirely, or extirpated. (Mgh, TA. *) ― -b3- jab~a Als~anaAma, aor.
jabu3a
, inf. n. jab~N; and Ajtb~hu↓; He cut off the hump of the camel: accord. to Lth, jab~N signifies the cutting off entirely, or extirpating, of the hump. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jab~a Aln~axola, (As, S, Msb, TA,) [aor.
jabu3a
,] inf. n. jab~N, (A, K,) or jibaAbN, (S, TA,) or jabaAbN, (A,) or both the second and last, (Msb, [the first is disallowed by MF,]) He fecundated the palmtrees [with the pollen of the male tree]. (As, S, A, Msb, TA.) You say, jaA='a zamanu AljibaAbi, (S,) or AljabaAbi, with fet-h, (A,) or both, (Msb,) [The time of the fecundating of the palm-trees came]. ＝ -A3- jab~a Alqawoma, (S,) aor.
jabu3a
, (TA,) inf. n. jab~N, (K,) He surpassed, or overcome, the people, or company of men; (S, K, * TA;) accord. to some, in grounds of pretension to respect or honour, or in beauty, and in any or every manner. (TA.) And jab~ati Aln~isaA='a She surpassed the [other] women in her beauty. (TA.) The saying
jab~ato nisaA='a AlEaAlamiyna biAls~ababo
[She overcame the women of the whole world by means of the string] relates to a woman who measured round her hinder parts with a string, and then threw it to the women of the tribe, that they might do with it the like; but they found it to be much exceeding their measures. (TA.) See 3, in three places. ＝ -A4- See also 2.

2 tajobiybN tjbyb
The reaching of the [whiteness termed] taHojiyl, in a horse, to the knee and the hock: (S:) or the rising of the whiteness to [the extent of] what is termed Aljababu. (K.) You say of a horse, fiyhi tajobiybN [In him is a rising of the tHjyl to the knee and the hock]: and in this case, the horse is said to be mujab~abN: and the subst. is jababN↓ [meaning a whiteness of the legs rising to the knee and the hock]. (S.) [See mujab~abN.] ＝ -A2- The act of shrinking [from a thing]; or the being averse [from it]; or the act of withdrawing; (S, K, TA;) outwardly or inwardly. (TA.) You say of a man, jab~aba fa*ahaba [He shrank, or was averse, or withdrew, and went away]. (S.) And jay~aba Aln~aAsu Eano TaAEapi A@ll~`hi The people forsook, or relinquished, the obeying of God. (TA from a trad.) ― -b2- The act of fleeing. (K.) You say of a man, jbab He fled. (TA.) El-Hotei-ah says,
wanaHonu A_i*aA jab~abotumu Eano nisaAy^ikumo
kamaA jab~abato mino Einodi A^awolaAdihaA AlHumuro
[And we, when ye flee from your women, like as the wild asses have fled from the presence of their young ones]. (TA.) And jab~a↓, said of a man, [if not a mistranscription for jab~aba,] signifies He went quickly, fleeing from a thing. (TA.) ＝ -A3- The act of satisfying with water (K, TA) the earth, (Aljabuwb, TA,) or cattle. (K, TA.)

3 jibaAb jb jbAb jbp
The act of vying, or contending for superiority, in goodliness, or beauty, &c., (K,) as, for instance, in grounds of pretension to respect or honour, and in lineage: (TA:) and mujaAb~apN the vying, or contending for superiority, in goodliness, or beauty, (K,) &c., (TA,) and in food: (K:) but [SM says,] I know not whence this addition, respecting food, is derived. (TA. [See, however, what follows, from the A.]) You say, jaAb~aniY fajababotuhu↓ He vied with me, or contended with me for superiority, and I overcame him. (TA.) And jaAb~ati AlmaroA^apu SaAHibatahaA HusonFA fajab~atohaA↓ The woman vied, or contended for superiority, with her fellow, and surpassed her in beauty. (TA.) And jaAb~ahu fiY AlqiraY fajab~ahu↓ He vied with him, or contended with him for superiority, in the entertainment of guests, and he overcame him therein. (A.)

4 Ajb~ A^jAb A^jb Ajb jAb jb jbY wjb
It (camels' milk) had, or produced, what is termed jubaAb [q. v.]. (K.)

5 tjb~b jb tjbb
He clad himself with a jub~ap [q. v.]. (MA.) [And so, app., Ajtb~↓, explained by Golius, on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof, as signifying He put on a vest, or tunic.]

8 A_ijotaba3a
see 1, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see also 5.

R. Q. 1 jabojaba jbjb
He dealt, or trafficked, in jabaAjib [pl. of jubojubapN, q. v.]. (TA.)

R. Q. 2 tajabojaba tjbjb
i. q. Ait~a$aqa; (S, TA;) i. e. He prepared what is called jubojubap: (TA:) or he put what is called xaloE into a jubojubap [q. v.]. (AZ, TA.)

jub~N jb
A well: (A, K:) or a well not cased with stone or the like: (S, A, Msb, K:) or a well containing much water: or a deep well: (A, K:) or of some other description: (A:) or a well in a good situation with respect to pasture: or one that people have found; not one that they have dug: (K:) or a well that is not deep: (Lth, TA:) or a well that is wide, or ample: (ElKilábeeyeh, TA:) or a well that is cut through rock, or smooth rock, or stones, or smooth stones, or hard and smooth and large stones: (Aboo- Habeeb, TA:) of the masc. gender; (Msb, TA;) [not fem. like biy^orN;] or masc. and fem.: (Fr, Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajobaAbN (Msb, K.) and [of mult.] jibaAbN and jibabapN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- A well that is dug wherein a grape — vine is planted; like as one is dug for the shoot of a palm — tree: pl. jibaAbN. (ISh, TA.) ― -b3- The inside of a well, from its bottom to its top, whether cased with stone or the like or not. (Sh, TA.) ― -b4- The juron of a well [app. meaning A hollowed stone, or stone basin, for water, placed at the mouth of a well: or, perhaps, a hollowed stone placed over the mouth; for many a well has such a stone, forming a kind of parapet]. (Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh, TA.) ＝ -A2- [A kind of leathern bag;] a mazaAdap of which one part is sewed to another, (K, TA,) wherein they used to prepare the beverage termed nabiy*, until, by use, it acquired strength for that purpose; mentioned in a trad., forbidding the use of it; and also called majobuwbapN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A3- The spathe, or envelope, of the spadix, or flowers, of the palmtree; also called juf~N: the former word was unknown to A'Obeyd: both occur, accord. to different readings, in a trad., where it is said that a charm contrived to bewitch Mohammad was put into the jub~, or juf~, of a TaloEap: accord. to Sh, (TA,) it means the inside of a TaloEap [which latter here app. signifies, as it does in some other instances, the spathe, not the spadix, of a palmtree]; (K, TA;) in like manner as the inside of a well, from its bottom to its top, is called jub~: the pl. is jibaAbN. (TA.) Hence the well-known prov., jibaAbN falaA taEan~a A^aborFA [They are merely envelopes of the flowers of palm-trees; therefore weary not thyself to effect fecundation]; applied to a man in whom is little or no good; meaning he is like the spathes of the palm-tree in which are no flowers; therefore weary not thyself by attempting to make him good; laA taEan~a being for laA tataEan~a. (MF.)

jub~apN jb jbh jbp
A well-known garment [or coat], (Msb, K, TA,) of the kind of those called muqaT~aEaAt: (TA:) accord. to ' Iyád, a garment cut out and sewed: accord. to Ibn-Hajar and others, a double garment quilted with cotton; or, sometimes, if of wool, a single garment, not quilted with anything: (MF:) [most probably not so much resembling the modern garment more generally known by the same name (for a description and representation of which see my “ Modern Egyptians, ” ch. i.,) as a kind of jub~ap still worn in Northern Africa, described in this Lexicon voce midoraEapN: accord. to Golius, “ tunica ex panno gossipino, cui pallium seu toga imponitur, cum subductitio panno et intercedente gossipio punctim consuta: Italis consona voce giuppa: si ita cum gossipio consuta non sit, dur~aAEapN tunica illa gossipina dicitur: ”] pl. jubabN (Msb, K) and jibaAbN. (S, K.) ― -b2- I. q. diroEN [A coat of mail; or any coat of defence]: (K:) pl. jubabN. (TA.) Er-Rá'ee says,
lanaA jubabN waA^aromaAHN TiwaAlN
bihin~a numaArisu AlHaroba Al$~aTuwnaA
[We have coats of mail, or of defence, and long spears: with them we ply distant war]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- The part of a spear-head into which the shaft enters: (S, K:) and the vaEolab is the part of the spear-shaft that enters into the head. (TA.) ― -b2- [In the TA, jub~apu Alr~umoHi is also explained as meaning mA dxl mn AlsnAn fyh The part of the spearhead that enters into the shaft: but it seems that mn has been inserted here by a mistake of the copyist; and that the true meaning intended is the part of the spear-shaft into which the head enters; though in general the shaft enters into the head.] ― -b3- The part in which is the mu$aA$ap [q. v.] of a horn. (Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh, TA.) ― -b4- The HijaAj [or bone that surrounds the cavity (see art. Hj)] of the eye. (K.) ― -b5- The contents (Ha$ow) of the solid hoof: or the horny box (qaron) of the solid hoof: or the joint between the sAq [which seems to mean here, as it does in many other instances, the hind shank,] and the thigh: (K:) or the shank-joint of a horse or the like (mawoSilu AlwaZiyfi [commonly applied, as in the S and K voce rusog, to the upper extremity of the pastern, i. e. the fetlock-joint, which seems to be the meaning intended in this instance,]) in the *iraAE [which here app. means the fore leg, not the arm]: or, accord. to As, the part where the wZyf [or shank] is set into the hoof: (S:) or the part of the rsg [or pastern], of a horse, where the wZyf [or shank] joins upon the Hawo$ab [which seems here to mean the upper pasternbone]: or, as AO says, the part where a horse's wZyf joins to the upper part of the Hw$b: or, as he says in another place, the place where each tibia and hind shank, of a horse, meet; [the hockjoint;] expl. by mltqY sAqyh wwZyfY rjlyh: and the place of junction of any two bones, except in the back-bone. (TA.) ― -b6- Accord. to Lth, Whiteness of the bTAnyp [a word which I have not found anywhere but in this instance] of a horse or similar beast, extending to the hairs that surround the hoof. (TA.)

jababN jbb jbp
A cutting off of the hump of a camel: (K:) or a cutting in the hump of a camel: (TA:) [or the state of having the hump cut off; as seems to be indicated in the S:] or an erosion of the hump of a camel, by the saddle, so that it does not grow large. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 2.

jubabN jbb jbp
Butter, or what is produced by churning, of camels' milk; like as zubod is what is produced by churning of cows' or sheep's or goats' milk: (Msb in art. zbd:) what rises upon the surface, (T, S,) or what has collected together [or coagulated], (K,) of the milk of camels, resembling zubod, (T, S, K,) which camels' milk has not: (S, K:) when a camel shakes about a skin of camels' milk, suspended to him, what is termed jbAb collects at the mouth of the skin. (T.)

jabuwbN jbwb
The earth, (Lh, K,) in general; (Lh;) sometimes written jabuwbu, as a proper name, without the article, and imperfectly decl., like $aEuwbu: (TA:) so called because it is cut, i. e. dug; or because it cuts, i. e. dissunders, the bodies of those buried in it: (Suh, TA:) and hence jab~aAnN↓ and jab~aAnapN↓, signifying a burial-ground; from Aljab~u and Aljabuwbu; accord. to Kh; but others derive these two words from jbn: (TA:) or rugged land: (As, S, K:) or hard or rugged land, composed of rock, not of soil: (IAar, TA:) or earth, or dust: (Lh, K:) or the surface of the earth; (ISh, S, K;) whether plain or rugged or mountainous: (ISh:) a word without a pl.: (S:) also coarse, or big, lumps or clods of clay or mud; or of dry, or tough, or cohesive, clay or mud; plucked from the surface of the ground: (TA:) or crumbled clods of clay or mud; or of dry, or tough, or cohesive, clay or mud: (IAar, TA:) and with p, a lump, or clod, of clay or mud; or of dry, or tough, or cohesive, clay or mud. (K.)

jibaAbiY~N jb jbAbY jbAby jbp
: see what next follows.

jub~iY~N jb jbY jby jbyy
[app. a contraction of jubabiY~N], or jibaAbiY~N↓ A seller of jibaAb [pl. of jub~apN, q. v.]. (K.)

jab~aAnN jb jbAn
: see jabuwbN; and see art. jbn.

jab~aAnapN jbAn jbAnh jbAnp
: see jabuwbN; and see art. jbn.

jabojabapN jbjbh jbjbp
: see what next follows, in two places.

jubojubapN jbjbh jbjbp
, (S,) or jabojabapN↓, (A,) or both, (K,) and jabaAjibu [which is the pl.], (L, TA,) The stomach of a ruminant animal * (S, A, K, TA) in which xaloE [q. v.] is put, (S, TA,) i. e., (TA,) in which is put flesh-meat cut in pieces; (K, TA;) or in which is put flesh-meat to be used as provision in travelling; (TA;) or in which melted grease (S, K) is collected (S) or put: (K:) or the skin of the side of a camel, cut out in a round form, in which is prepared flesh-meat, (K, TA,) such as is called wa$iyqap, (TA,) which is flesh-meat that is boiled once, and then cut into strips, and dried, or salted and sun-dried; the most lasting of all provision [of the kind]: (S, TA:) or the first and second both signify tripe; in Persian, $knbh or A_i$okanobah. (MA.) A coward is likened to a jbjbp in which xlE is put; because of his turgidness and his little profitableness. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the first, A vessel, or receptacle, made of skin, in which water is given to camels, and in which one macerates habiyd [i. e. colocynths, or the pulp thereof, or the seeds thereof]. (TA.) ― -b3- And A basket, (S, K, TA,) of small size, (TA,) made of skins, (S, K, TA,) in which dust, or earth, is removed: (S, TA:) or, accord. to Kt, it is [jabojabapN↓,] with fet-h: (TA:) pl. jabaAjibu. (S.) ― -b4- And A drum: pl. jabaAjibu [which is explained in the K as meaning “ a drum ” instead of “ drums ”]: as in the saying, Duribato EalaY baAbihi AljabaAjibu [The drums were beaten at his door]. (A.)

jubojubiY~N jbjbY jbjby
A tripe-seller. (Golius from Meyd. [See jubojubapN.])

jubojubiy~apN jbjbyh jbjbyp
Food made with tripe; in Persian, $ikanobaho waA; (Golius from Meyd;) in Turkish, suxotuw $wrbAsY. (MA.)

A^ajab~u *
A camel having his hump cut off: (S, K:) or having his hump cut off: (S, K:) or having his hump eroded by the saddle, so that it does not grow large: (K:) or having no hump: (A, TA:) fem. jab~aA='u. (A, K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] the fem., (tropical:) A woman not having [prominent] buttocks: (K:) or i. q. rasoHaA='u [i. e. having small buttocks sticking together; or having little flesh in her posteriors and things]: (ISh, TA:) or whose bosom and breasts have not become large: (K:) or whose breast has not become large: (Sh, TA:) or small in the breast; from the same epithet applied to a she-camel; (A;) for a woman having small breasts is like the camel that has no hump: (TA:) or having no thighs; (K;) i. e. having lean thighs; as though having no thighs. (TA.) Also, the masc., (assumed tropical:) A pubes having little flesh. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] AlA^ajab~u i. q. Alfaroju [as meaning The pudendum muliebre]; (K;) from the same word as applied to a camel [having no hump]. (TA.)

majab~apu mjbh mjbp
The middle, or main part, (jaAd~p,) of a road. (S.)

mujab~abN mjbb
A horse in which the [whiteness termed] taHojiyl reaches to the knee and the hock; (S;) [i. e.] in which the whiteness [of the lower part of the leg] reaches to the knee and the hock or the knees and the hocks: (TA:) or in which the tHjyl reaches to his knees: (Lth, TA:) or in which the whiteness rises to [the extent of] what is termed Aljababu; (K, TA;) or more than this, [perhaps a mistake of a copyist for less than this,] so as not to reach to the knees: or in which the whiteness reaches to the hairs that surround his hoof. (TA.) ― -b2- biy^orN mujab~abapN Aljawofi A well having in the middle a part wider than the rest, hollowed out like a cupola. (Fr, TA.)

majobuwbN mjbwb
Having the genitals, (Msb,) or the testicles (S, * Mgh, TA) and the penis, (Mgh,) cut off entirely, or extirpated: (S, * Mgh, Msb, TA:) or having the penis cut off. (TA.)

majobuwbapN 1
: see jub~u.

1 jabaA^a * and jabiy^a
, aor.
jabaAa
, He restrained, or withheld, himself; refrained, forbore, or abstained; or turned back, or reverted. (K, TA.) You say, jabaA^a Eanohu, and jabiy^a, meaning He restrained, or withheld, himself, &c., from him, or it; and regarded him, or it, with reverence, veneration, dread, awe, or fear: (TA:) [or,] accord. to AZ, jabaA^otu Eani Alr~ajuli, inf. n. jabo'N and jubuwo'N, [to which Golius adds jubuw^N and jibaA='N, but, I suspect, from incorrect MSS.,] means I drew, or held, or hung, back from the man; or remained behind him; or shrank from him; or shrank from him and hid myself: and he cites (from Nuseyb Ibn-Mihjen, TA)
fahalo A^ana A_il~a mivolu say~iqapi AlEidaY
A_ini A@sotaqodamato naHorN waA_ino jabaA^ato EaqorN
[And am I otherwise than like the beasts driven away by the enemy? If they go before, slaughter befalls them; and if they remain behind, hocking]. (S, TA.) You say also, maA jabaA^a Eano $atomiY He did not draw back from reviling me; did not desist, or abstain, therefrom. (TA.) ― -b2- It (a sword) recoiled, or reverted, without penetrating, or without effect: (K:) or so the former verb [only]. (TA.) ― -b3- It (the sight, or the eye,) recoiled, or reverted: (K:) or so the former verb [only]; and disliked, or disapproved, or hated, the thing [that was before it]. (TA.) You say, jabaA^ato EayoniY Eani Al$~aYo'i My eye recoiled, or reverted, from the thing. (S.) And of a woman of displeasing aspect you say, A_in~a AlEayoni latajobaA^u EanohaA [Verily the eye recoils from her with dislike]. (As, TA.) ― -b4- He disliked, disapproved, or hated: (K:) or so the former verb [only]. (TA.) You say, jabaA^a Al$~aYo'a He disliked, &c., the thing. (TA.) ― -b5- He inclined his neck: (K:) or so the former verb [only]. (TA.) ― -b6- He hid himself; (K, TA;) [app. from fear;] as, for instance, a Dab~ [q. v.] in its hole. (TA.) ― -b7- He, or it, came, or went, forth, or out: (K:) [or so the former verb only.] You say of a serpent, jabaA^a Ealayohi It came forth upon him from its hole (S, TA) so as to frighten him; and in like manner one says of a hyena, and a Dab~, and a jerboa. (TA.) And jabaA^a EalaY Alqawomi He came forth unexpectedly upon the people, or company of men. (TA.) And jabaA^a AljaraAdu The locusts invaded, or came suddenly upon, the country. (TA.)

4 A^ajobaA^ato *
said of a land, (S,) or AjbA^ said of a place, (K,) It abounded with [the kind of truffles called] kamoA^ap, (S,) or kamo', (so in some copies of the K,) or [rather] jibaA^ap [a pl. or quasi-pl. n. of jabo'. (So in other copies of the K.) ＝ -A2- AjbA^ He hid a thing. (K.) And hence, He hid his camels from the collector of the poor-rate. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- He sold seed-produce before it showed itself to be in a good state, (S, K, TA,) or before it came to maturity. (TA.) Hence, in a trad., mano A^ajobaY faqado A^arobaY [He who sells seed-produce before it shows itself to be in a good state, or before it has come to maturity, practices the like of usury]: (S, TA:) originally with ', (S,) which is suppressed for the purpose of assimilation [to ArbY]. (TA. [See 4 in art. jbw and jbY.] ＝ -A3- AjbA^ EalaY Alqawomi He overlooked the people, or company of men; or commanded, or had, a view of them; or came in sight of them; syn. A^a$orafa. (K.)

jabo'N jb'
sing. of jibaA^apN, like as faqoEN is of fiqaEapN, and garodN of giradapN: (S:) or i. q. kamoA^apN: (K:) or n. un. of jaboA^apN↓, which is a coll. gen. n., like kamoA^apN: (MF and TA, voce qaEobN:) [J says,] jibaA^apN signifies Red kamoA^ap [or truffles]: or, accord. to El-Ahmar, those [truffles] that incline to redness; kamoA^apN signifying those that incline to dust-colour and blackness; and fiqaEapN, the white; and banaAtu A^awobara, the small: (S:) accord. to AHn, jaboA^apN↓ signifies a white thing resembling a kamo', of which no use is made: but accord. to IAar, the black kamoA^ap; which, he says, are the best of kmA^p: (TA:) the pl. of jabo'N is A^ajobuw^N, (S, K,) a pl. of pauc., (S,) and jibaA^apN, [as mentioned above,] or, accord. to Sb, this is a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) and jabaA^N↓, (K,) or this also is a quasi-pl. n. (TA.) ― -b2- I. q. A^akamapN [q. v., i. e. A hill, or mound, &c.]: pls. as above. (K.) ― -b3- A hollow, or cavity, (T, K,) in a mountain, (TA,) in which the water (T, K) of the rain (TA) stagnates, (T,) or collects: (K:) pl. as above. (K.)

jabaA^N *
: see the next preceding paragraph.

jaboA^apN *
: see jabo'N, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A shoemaker's board, (S, K,) on which he cuts his leather; also called qurozuwmN. (S.) ＝ -A3- And The place where the false ribs of the camel end, and thence as far as the navel and udder. (K.) ― -b2- And The part of the belly called the maA^onapN thereof; as also jaA^obapN; (Ibn-Buzurj, TA;) i. e. the part between the navel and the pubes. (TA in art. jA^b.)

jub~aA^N *
(S, K) and jub~aA'Na↓ (Sb, K) Fearful, or cowardly: (S, K:) fem. with p: and therefore the pl. is formed by the addition of w and n.
(Sb, TA.) Mafrook Ibn-' Amr Esh-Sheybánee says,
famaA A^ana mino rayobi Almanuwni bijub~aA^K
walaA A^anaA mino sayobi AlA_il`hi biA=yisi
[But I am not fearful of the vicissitudes of fortune, nor despairing of the favour of God]. (S, TA.)

jub~aA='N jbA='
: see what next precedes.

jaAbiy^N *
The locust, or locusts: (S, K:) so called because of the coming forth thereof [suddenly or unexpectedly: see 1, last two sentences]: (S, TA:) as also jaAbK [q. v.]. (TA.)

A^aroDN majobaA^apN *
A land abounding with [the truffles called] jibaA^ap. (S.)

Aljibotu Aljbt
, not a pure Arabic word, because it comprises the letters j and t without any of the letters of the kind called *awolaqiY~ [which are r and l and n]; (S;) The idol: (S, K:) or idols: (Ksh in iv. 54:) or the name of a certain idol, (Bd and Jel on that verse,) belonging to Kureysh; as also AlT~aAguwtu: (Jel:) and that which is worshipped instead, or to the exclusion, of God; whatever it be: (Ksh, Bd, K:) said to be originally Aljibosu, i. e., (Bd,) he, or that, wherein is no good: (Bd, K:) and the diviner: (S, K:) and the enchanter: (S, K, Kull:) and the like thereof: (S:) or the Devil; Satan: (Kull:) and enchantment. (Esh-Shaabee, K.) Accord. to Esh-Shaabee, yuw^ominuwna biAljiboti waAlT~aAguwti, in the Kur [iv. 54], means They believe in enchantment and the Devil: or, accord. to I' Ab, by Aljbt is meant Hoyeí Ibn-Akhtab; and by AlTAgwt, Kaab Ibn-El-Ashraf: (TA:) or the words relate to these two men, Jews, who, in order to induce Kureysh to join with them in a league against Mohammad, prostrated themselves to the gods of Kureysh: (Ksh, Bd:) or to certain Jews, who said that the worship of idols is more pleasing to God than that to which Mohammad invited. (Bd.) It is said in a trad. that what are termed AlT~iyarapu and AlEiyaAfapu and AlT~aroqu are mina Aljiboti [app. meaning of things wherein is no good: or kinds of divination: or from the Devil]. (S.)

1 jaba*ahu *
, (S, A, Mgh, * L, Msb, K, *) aor.
jabi*a
, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. jabo*N, (T, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) i. q. ja*abahu (T, * S, A, Mgh, * L, Msb, K, * &c.) i. e. He drew it; &c.: (T, TA:) formed by transposition from the latter; (A 'Obeyd, S, A;) accord. to some: (Msb:) or it is a dial. var. of the latter; (M, L, K, &c.;) of the dial. of Temeem; (T, Msb;) not formed from the latter by transposition, (Ibn-Es-Sarráj, IJ, M, L, K,) for both are equally conjugated: (Ibn-EsSarráj, IJ, L, Msb:) and AijotibaA*N [inf. n. of Ajtb*↓] signifies the same as jabo*N. (K.) jaba*aniY rajulN mino xalofiY, meaning A man pulled me from behind me, occurs in a trad. (L.) ― -b2- You say also, jaba*atohu and ja*abatohu, meaning, (tropical:) She repelled him, or rejected him; namely, a man who sought her in marriage. (T and TA in art. j*b.)

7 AinojibaA*N *
[inf. n. of Anjb*] i. q. Ainoji*aAbN, (K,) meaning Quick going or journeying or travelling. (TA.)

8 A_ijotaba*a
see 1.

1 jabara jbr
, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
jabura
, (Msb,) inf. n. jaborN (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) and jubuwrN, (M, K,) which latter, accord. to MF, is an inf. n. of the intrans. verb only, but it has been heard as an inf. n. of the trans. verb also, (TA,) and jibaArapN, (Lh, K,) He set a bone; reduced it from a fractured state; (S, A, Msb, K, &c.;) as also jb~r↓, (A, IAmb, K,) inf. n. tajobiyrN; (TA;) and Ajbr↓, (Ibn-Talhah, MF, TA,) but this is extremely strange, and not found in the lexicons of celebrity, (MF,) and not heard by AO; (TA;) [and Ajtbr↓.] One says also, yadahu jb~r↓, (A, IAmb,) or jabarahaA, (Msb,) He (a bone-setter) set his arm, or reduced it from a fractured state: (A:) or put upon it the jabiyrap [or splints]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) jabara, (AAF, M, K, &c.,) inf. n. jaborN (S, A, K) and jubuwrN [but respecting this latter see above] and jibaArapN; (K;) and jb~r↓, (K,) inf. n. tajobiyrN; (TA;) and Ajbr↓; (Ibn- Talhah, MF, TA; [but respecting this form see above;]) and Ajtbr↓; (K;) (tropical:) He restored a man from a state of poverty to wealth, or competence, or sufficiency: (AAF, S, A, K, &c.:) or he benefited a poor man; conferred a benefit, or benefits, upon him: (M, K:) but the former is the more appropriate explanation: (AAF, TA:) and this signification is tropical; (IDrst, MF, TA;) the poor man being likened to one who has a broken bone, and his restoration to wealth, or competence, being likened to the setting of the bone; wherefore he is called faqiyrN, as though the vertebræ of his back were broken: (IDrst, TA:) in the A it is mentioned as proper, not tropical; but the author of the A afterwards mentions jabarotu fulaAnFA as tropical in the sense of naEa$otuhu (tropical:) [I recovered such a one from his embarrassment, &c.; repaired his broken fortune, or his condition]. (TA.) One says also, jabarotu faAqapa Alr~ajuli (tropical:) [I repaired the broken fortune of the man;] I restored the man to wealth, or competence, or sufficiency. (A Heyth, TA.) And jabarotu Alyatiyma (assumed tropical:) [I put the affairs of the orphan into a right, or good, state: or] I gave to the orphan. (Msb.) And jabara (tropical:) He restored anything to a sound, right, or good, state. (IDrst, TA.) And jabarahu A@ll~`hu (assumed tropical:) [May God render him sound, and strong]: said in relation to a child. (S and K in art. zrE.) And jabarotu niSaAba Alz~akaApi bika*aA (assumed tropical:) I made the amount of the property equal to that which renders it incumbent on the possessor to pay the poor-rate, by [adding] such a thing: the name of that thing is jbrAn [app. juboraAnN↓]: and the person who does this is termed jaAbirN↓. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- jabara also signifies He compelled, or constrained, another. (B.) You say, jabarahu EalaY AlA^amori, (Lh, Az, Msb, K,) aor.
jabura
, inf. n. jaborN and jubuwrN, (Msb,) a chaste form of the verb, of the dial. of El- Hijáz, (Az, TA,) or of the Benoo-Temeem and of many of the people of El-Hijáz, (Msb,) or of Temeem alone; (Lh, TA;) [but said in the Mgh to be of weak authority;] and Ajbrhu↓; (Th, S, Msb, K, &c.;) both these forms of the verb mentioned by AZ, Fr, A 'Obeyd, and others, (Msb,) but the latter is the form used by the generality of the Arabs, (Lh, TA,) and by the grammarians [in general]; (TA;) He compelled him, against his will, to do the thing: (Lh, Th, Az, S, Msb, K:) A_ijobaArN↓ originally signifying the inciting, urging, or inducing, another to restore a thing to a sound, right, or good, state. (B.) And EalaY AlHukomi Ajbrhu↓ He (a judge) compelled him to submit to, or to perform, the sentence. (L.) ＝ -A3- Also jabara, [aor.
jabura
,] inf. n. jubuwrN (S, Msb, K) and jaborN, (Msb, K,) which latter, accord. to MF [and the Mgh], is an inf. n. of the trans. verb only, but it has been heard as an inf. n. of the intrans. verb also; (TA;) and Anjbr↓, (T, S, K,) and Ajtbr↓, (T, S,) and tjb~r↓; (K;) It (a bone) became set, or reduced from a fractured state. (T, S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] the first of these verbs, with the same inf. ns.; (K;) and Ajtbr↓, (S, * K,) and Anjbr↓, and tjb~r↓, and Astjbr↓; (K;) (tropical:) He (a poor man, K, and an orphan, TA) became restored from a state of poverty to wealth, or competence, or sufficiency: (S, * K:) or received a benefit, or benefits: (K:) Ajtbr↓ is syn. with AntE$ (tropical:) [he recovered, or became recovered, from his embarrassment, &c.]. (A.) [And (assumed tropical:) It (anything) became restored to a sound, right, or good, state.] El-' Ajjáj has used jabara transitively and intransitively in the same sentence, saying,
qado jabara Ald~iyna AlA_ilaAhu fajabaro
[(assumed tropical:) God hath restored the religion to a sound, right, or good, state, and it hath become restored thereto]: (S:) or, accord. to some, the second verb is corroborative of the first; the meaning being, God hath desired, or purposed, to restore the religion, &c., and hath completed its restoration. (B.)

2 jab~ara
see 1, in three places.

4 A^ajobara
see 1, in five places. ＝ -A2- Ajbrhu also signifies He imputed to him [the tenet of] Aljabor; (S, * L, K; *) he called him a jabariY~: (L:) like as Akfrhu signifies “ he imputed to him infidelity. ” (S.)

5 tjb~r A^jbr jbr tjbr
: see 1, latter part, in two places. Also (tropical:) What had gone from him (a man) returned to him: (K:) or some of his property that had gone from him returned to him. (T, TA.) (assumed tropical:) He (a sick man) became in a good state. (K.) (assumed tropical:) It (a plant, TA, and a tree, K) became green, and put forth leaves (K, TA) and fresh green twigs, when dry: produced fresh shoots in its dry parts: (TA:) it (herbage) became somewhat restored to a good state after having been eaten: (K, * TA:) or grew after having been eaten. (S.) ― -b2- He (a man, S) magnified himself; behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently. (S, A, K.) ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) obtained wealth, or property: (K:) but
Lh explains it as meaning, intransitively, he obtained wealth, or property. (TA.)

7 A_inojabara
see 1, latter part, in two places.

8 A_ijotabara
see 1, in five places. You say also, A^aSaAbatohu muSiybapN laA yajotabiruhaA [(assumed tropical:) A calamity befell him from which he will not recover]; i. e. minohaA laA majobara↓ [(assumed tropical:) there is no recovering from it]. (TA.)

10 A_isotajobara
see 1, latter part. ＝ -A2- Astjbrhu (tropical:) He exerted himself much, or exceedingly, or to the utmost, in paying frequent attention to him, taking care of him, or putting his affairs into a right, or proper, state. (A.)

jaborN jbr
, in computation, (assumed tropical:) The addition of something for the purpose of reparation. (TA.) [Hence, Aljaboru (assumed tropical:) Algebra; more commonly called Aljaboru waAlmuqaAbalapu perfective addition and compensative subtraction; or restoration and compensation; because of the frequency of these operations in the reduction of equations.] ＝ -A2- The contr. of qadarN: (S, Msb, K:) it is the assertion that God compels his servants, or mankind, to commit acts of disobedience; (Msb;) the virtual denial that actions proceed from man, and attributing them to God; the sect that hold the tenet thus termed asserting that man, with respect to his actions, is like the feather suspended in the air; whereas qadarN signifies the “ virtual attributing of optional, or voluntary, actions to man; asserting that man creates his own optional, or voluntary, actions: ” (IbrD:) A 'Obeyd says that it is a post-classical term. (S.) ＝ -A3- A king; (AA, T, M, K;) of uncertain derivation: (M:) and a slave, or servant: (A 'Obeyd, Kr, K, &c.:) thus bearing two contr. significations: (K:) and a man: (AA, A 'Obeyd, K, &c.:) [see jaboray^iylu:] and a young man: and [a] courageous [man]. (K.) ＝ -A4- [Also, app., Aloes-wood: Aljaboru is explained in the K as signifying AlEuwdu, which means wood in general, as well as aloes-wood in particular; and to this is added in the TA, Al*Y yujobaru bihi, as though the meaning were the wood with which one sets bones; but I think that yujobaru is a mistranscription for yujam~aru; and that the meaning is aloes-wood with which one fumigates.]

jabariY~N jbr jbrY jbry
or jaboriY~N: see jabariy~apN.

jabaruw~apN jbr jbrwh jbrwp
and jaboruw~apN and jabaruwtN &c.: see what next follows.

jabariy~apN jbry jbryh jbryp
(S, K) and jaboriy~apN and jiboriy~apN and jibiriy~apN and jiboriyaA='u↓ (K) and jabariy~aA='u↓ (Aboo-Nasr, TA) and jabaruw~apN↓ (S, K) and jaboruw~apN↓ (K) and jabaruwtN↓ (S, Msb, K, one of the forms most known, of the measure faEaluwtN, like malakuwtN and rahabuwtN and ragabuwtN and raHamuwtN, said to be the only other words of this measure, though, as MF says, this requires consideration, TA) and juboruwtN↓ (K) and jaboraw^uwtN↓ (Et-Tedmuree, TA) and jabaruwtaY↓ (K, like raHamuwtaY, [&c.], TA) and jab~uwrapN↓ (S, K) and jab~uwrN↓ (Lh, Kr) and jub~uwrN↓ (Lh, TA) and jubuwrapN↓ and tajobaArN↓, (K,) all inf. ns., (TA,) [or simple substs.,] meaning The quality denoted by the epithet jab~aArN; (K;) i. e. self-magnification, pride, haughtiness, or insolence; or proud, haughty, or insolent, behaviour; (S, Msb, K;) &c. (K, TA.) Hence, maA kaAnato nubuw~apN A_il~aA tanaAsaxahaA mulokN jabariy~apF [There has been no prophetic office but a kingly office has succeeded in its place through some one's selfmagnification, pride, haughtiness, or insolence]; i. e., but kings have magnified themselves, or behaved proudly or haughtily or insolently, after it. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- Aljabariy~apu (S, K) and Aljaboriy~apu, (Th, Msb,) or the latter is a mispronunciation, or is the correct form, (K,) and the former is so pronounced in order to assimilate it to Alqadariy~apu; (Msb, K; *) the latter is the pronunciation of the scholastic theologians of the persuasion of EshSháfi'ee (El-Háfidh in the “ Tabseer, ” B) in old times, but the term used in the conventional language of the modern scholastic theologians is Almujobarapu↓; (B;) and Aljbry~p, also, is a postclassical term; (TA;) The contr. of Alqadariy~apu; (S, K;) the sect who hold the tenet termed jaborN [q. v.]; (Msb;) a sect of those who follow their own natural desires, whose founder was El- Hoseyn Ibn-Mohammad En-Nejjár El-Basree, who assert that man has no power; that [what are termed] voluntary motions are of the same predicament as a tremour; though this does not oblige them to deny the imposition of duties; (Lb, TA;) a sect who assert that God compels his servants, or mankind, to commit sins: (AHeyth, TA:) n. un. jabariY~N↓ or jaboriY~N. (Msb.)

jaboraAlu jbrAl
and jiboraAlu: see jaboray^iylu.

juboraAnN jbrAn
: see 1.

jiboriylu jbry^yl jbryl
and jaboriylu &c: see jaboray^iylu.

jiboriynu jbryn
and jaboriynu: see jaboray^iylu.

jiboriyaA='u jbryA='
and jabariy~aA='u: see jabariy~apN.

jaboray^iylu *
, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) imperfectly decl., because having the quality of a proper name and that of a foreign word, or being a compound regarded as forming a single word, as some say, (TA,) originally Syriac, or Hebrew, [???,] (Esh-Shiháb [El-Khafájee],) A proper name of an angel; (TA;) [Gabriel: and also, of a man:] signifying the servant of God: (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K, TA:) or (rather, TA) the man of God: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) being said to be composed of jaborN, (S, Msb, TA,) signifying “ servant, ” or “ slave, ” (Msb, TA,) or rather “ man, ” (TA,) and A_iylN, (S, Msb, TA,) signifying “ God: ” (Msb, TA:) or both together signify the servant of the Compassionate: or the servant of the Mighty, or Glorious: (TA:) this form of the word is of the dialects of Keys and Temeem: (TA:) and there are other dial. vars.; namely, jaborayiylu↓, without ' , and jaboraAy^iylu ↓, (S, K,) and jaboraAyiylu ↓, and jaboray^ilu ↓, and jaboraAy^iylu ↓, (K,) and jaboraAyiylu ↓, (Es-Suyootee, TA,) and jaboraAy^ilu ↓, (K,) and jaboraAyilu ↓, (Es-Suyootee, TA,) and jiboriylu↓, (S, Msb, K, which is the form most known and most chaste, and is of the dial. of El-Hijáz, TA,) and jaboriylu↓, (Msb, K, reckoned of weak authority by Fr, because the measure faE~iyl [or faEoliyl] does not exist in the language, for as to samowiyl, mentioned by Esh-Shiháb as against the objection of Fr, it is of the measure faEowiyl, MF, TA,) and jaborayolu↓, and jaboraAlu↓, and jiboraAlu↓, (K,) and jiboriynu↓, and jaboriynu↓, (S, K,) and jaboraAy^iynu↓. (Es-Suyootee, MF.)

jaborayiylu jbryyl
: see jaboray^iylu.

jaboraAy^ilu *
and jaboraAyilu: see jaboray^iylu.

jaboraAy^iylu *
and jaboraAyiylu: see jaboray^iylu.

jaboraAy^iyna *
: see jaboray^iylu.

jubaArN jbAr
A thing of which no account, or for which no revenge or retaliation or mulct, is taken. (S, A, Msb, K, TA.) You say, *ahaba damahu jubaArFA His blood went unrevenged, unretaliated, or unexpiated by a mulct. (S, A.) And juroHN jubaArN A wound for which is no retaliation, nor any expiatory mulct. (A, TA.) And HarobN jubaArN A war in which is no retaliation, (K, TA,) nor any expiatory mulct. (TA.) And AlmaEodinu jubaArN [The mine is a thing for which no mulct is exacted]: i. e., if the mine fall in upon him who is working in it, and he perish, his hirer is not to be punished for it. (S and Msb from a trad.) And Albiy^oru jubaArN [The well is a thing for which no mulct is exacted]: i. e., if a man fall into an ancient well, and perish, his blood is not to be expiated by a mulct: (TA:) or, as some say, it relates to a hired man's descending into a well to cleanse it, or to take forth something from it, if he fall into it and die. (TA in art. bA^r.) And jurHu AlEajumaA='i jubaArN The wound of the speechless beast, if it get loose and wound a man or other thing while loose, is a thing for which no retaliation or expiatory mulct is exacted. (T, A, * Msb. *) ― -b2- Clear, or quit, of a thing: so in the saying, A^anaA minohu xalaAwapN wujubaArN [I am clear, or quit, of it]. (K. [See also faAlijN.]) ＝ -A2- A torrent. (K.) ― -b2- Anything that corrupts, or mars, and destroys; (so accord. to some copies of the K, and the TA;) as the torrent, &c.: (TA:) or anything that is corrupted, or marred, and destroyed. (So accord. to other copies of the K.) ＝ -A3- Tuesday; (S, K;) an ancient name thereof, (S,) used in the Time of Ignorance; (TA;) as also jibaArN↓. (K.)

jibaArN jbAr
: see what next precedes.

jibaArapN jbAr jbArh jbArp
and jabiyrapN↓ Splints; pieces of wood with which bones are set, or reduced from a fractured state: (S, K:) or bones which are put upon a diseased part of the person, to reduce it to a sound state: pl. jabaAy^iru. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, both words, A wide bracelet; syn. yaAraqN: (S, K:) a bracelet (siwaAr) of gold or silver: pl. jabaAy^irapN [or jabaAy^iru, as above?]. (A 'Obeyd, TA.)

jubuwrapN jbwr jbwrh jbwrp
: see jabariy~apN.

jabiyrapN jbyr jbyrh jbyrp
: see jibaArapN.

jab~aArN jbAr
One who magnifies himself, or behaves
proudly or haughtily or insolently, and does not hold any one to have any claim upon him, or to deserve anything of him: (K:) one who slays when in anger: (S, A:) one who slays unjustly: (K:) imperious, or domineering, by absolute force and power; overbearing; tyrannical; a tyrant: (TA:) any one who exalts himself, or is insolent and audacious, in pride and in acts of rebellion or disobedience; who is bold, or audacious, and immoderate, inordinate, or exorbitant; or excessively, immoderately, or inordinately, proud, or corrupt, or unbelieving, or disobedient, or rebel-lious; or who exalts himself and is inordinate in infidelity; or who is extravagant in acts of disobedience and in wrongdoing; or who is refractory, or averse from obedience; (K, * TA;) as also jib~iyrN↓: (K:) or this latter signifies one who magnifies himself much, or behaves very proudly or haughtily or insolently: (S:) and the former, one who proudly, haughtily, or insolently, disdains the service of God: (Lh, TA:) fem. with p: pl. masc. jab~aAruwna and jabaAbirapN. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Aljab~aArN [A name of] God; so called because of his magnifying Himself [above every other being], (K,) and his highness: (TA:) meaning the Compeller of his creatures to do whatsoever He willeth: (Bd and Jel in lix. 23:) or the Compeller of his creatures to obey the commands and prohibitions which He pleaseth to impose upon them: (Msb, TA:) accord. to Fr, from A^ajobara, and the only instance known to him of an epithet of the measure faE~aAlN from a verb of the measure A^afoEala except dar~aAkN [q. v.] from A^adoraka: (Az, TA:) or, accord. to Fr, from jabara as syn. with A^ajobara: (Msb:) it is also explained as meaning the Supreme; the High above his creatures: (Az, TA:) or the Unattainable; and hence applied to the palm-tree [of which the branches cannot be reached by the hand]: (IAmb, TA:) or it may signify (tropical:) the Restorer of the poor to wealth or competence or sufficiency. (Az, TA.) [God is also called] jab~aAru Alquluwbi EalaY fiTaraAtihaA (assumed tropical:) The Establisher of hearts according to their natural constitutions which He hath given them in the mothers' wombs, disposing them to know Him and to confess Him, both the unfortunate of them and the fortunate. (TA from a trad. of 'Alee.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) A name of AljawozaA='u [the constel-lation Orion]; (A, K;) because it is [represented] in the form of a crowned king upon a throne. (A.) ― -b4- *iraAEu Aljab~aAri (assumed tropical:) The cubit of the king: (A, TA:) or the long cubit: or, as Kt thinks, by Aljb~Ar is here meant a certain foreign king whose fore arm was of full length. (TA.) ― -b5- qalobN jab~aArN (tropical:) A heart that receives not admonition: (A:) or that admits not compassion. (K.) ― -b6- jab~aArN, (Seer, K,) without p, (Seer, TA,) applied to a palm-tree (naxolapN), signifies (tropical:) Tall and young; (Seer, K, TA;) as also jub~aArN↓: (K:) or is applied to palmtrees collectively (naxolN), and signifies tall, and above the reach of the hand; (T, S;) and the epithet applied to a single palm-tree is with p; (S, A;) in this sense; meaning less than saHuwqN: (A:) or, with p, it signifies a young palm-tree, that has attained its utmost height and has borne fruit: (M:) or that has been ascended [for the purpose of cutting off its fruit], and retains its excellence, surpassing therein other palm-trees. (AHn, TA.) ― -b7- Also, hence, as Az thinks, (TA,) (tropical:) Huge, tall, and strong; a giant. (T, A, * K.) ― -b8- And, with p, (S, A,) and also without p, (A,) applied to a she-camel, (tropical:) Great (S, A) and fat. (S.)

jub~aArN jbAr
: see jab~aArN.

jab~uwrN jbwr
and jub~uwrN: see jabariy~apN.

jib~iyrN jbyr
: see jab~aArN.

jab~uwrapN jbwr jbwrh jbwrp
: see jabariy~apN.

jaAbirN jAbr
, (S,) and jaAbiru bonu Hab~apa, (S, A, K,) names of (tropical:) Bread; (S, A, K;) and A^abuw jaAbirK is a surname thereof; (S, K;) and so A^um~u jaAbirK: which last also signifies the ear of corn: (T in art. Am:) and i. q. Alhariysapu [grain, or wheat, bruised, or brayed, and then cooked]. (Har p. 227.) ― -b2- fulaAnN jaAbirN liY i. q. musotajobirN↓ (tropical:) [Such a one exerts himself much, or exceedingly, or to the utmost, in paying frequent attention to me, taking care of me, or putting my affairs into a right, or proper, state]. (A.) ― -b3- See also 1.

tajobaArN tjbAr
: see jabariy~apN.

majobarN mjbr
[an inf. n. of 1]: see 8.

Almujobarapu Almjbrh Almjbrp mjbr
: see jabariy~apN.

mujab~irN mjbr
One who sets bones, or reduces them from a fractured state; a bone-setter. (S, A, K.)

majobuwrapN mjbwr mjbwrh mjbwrp
A woman possessed by a jinnee, or genie; syn. majonuwnapN; but this is held to be of weak authority. (Mgh.)

Almutajab~iru Almtjbr mtjbr
The lion. (K.)

musotajobirN mstjbr
: see jaAbirN.

jaboray^iylu *
and its vars.: see art. jbr.

jibosN jbs
[Gypsum;] i. q. jiS~N, or jaS~N, (K,) with which one builds. (Kr, TA. *)

jab~aAsapN jbAsh jbAsp
The place of jibos; [i. e., in which gypsum is found, or prepared;] as also mjb~asp [i. e. mujab~asapN↓, or, more probably, it is a mistranscription, for majobasapN↓, like maHoSaApN (originally maHaSayapN) and maboqalapN &c.]. (TA.)

majobasapN mjbsh mjbsp
or mujab~asapN: see jab~aAsapN.

1 jabalahu jbl jblh jblp
, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jabula
(Msb, K) and
jabila
, (K,) inf. n. jabolN, (KL.) He (God) created him. (S, Msb, K, KL.) So in the phrase, jabalahu EalaY ka*aA, (Msb,) or ElY Al$~aYo'i, (K,) He (God) created him with an adaptation, or a disposition, to such a thing, or to the thing; adapted him, or disposed him, by nature thereto. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., jubilati Alquluwbu EalaY Hub~i mano A^aHosana A_ilayohaA wabugoDi mano A^asaA='a A_ilayohaA [Hearts are created with a disposition to the love of him who does good to them, and the hatred of him who does evil to them]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) i. q. jabarahu [evidently as meaning He compelled him, against his will, EalaY AlA^amori to do the thing; for he who is created with a disposition to do a thing is as though he were compelled to do it]; and so Ajblhu↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. A_ijobaAlN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jabila (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became like a mountain (jabal) in bigness, thickness, coarseness, or roughness. (TA.) ― -b2- jabila Hadiyduhumo (K, TA; in the CK, jabala; and in a MS. copy of the K, without any vowels;) (assumed tropical:) Their iron was, or became, blunt, such as would not penetrate. (K, * TA.)

3 jAbl jAbl
He (a man) alighted, or descended and abode, or sojourned, or settled, in a mountain. (AA, TA.)

4 Ajbl A^jbl Ajbl jbl
He came, or went, or betook himself, to the mountain. (ISk, S, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He (a digger) reached a hard place, (S, K,) or stone, (Mgh,) in his digging. (TA. [AlHaAfir, meaning “ the digger, ” Golius seems to have misunderstood as meaning “ the hoof ” of a horse.]) ― -b3- [Hence,] (tropical:) He (a poet) experienced difficulty in diction, (K, TA,) so that he said nothing original, nor anything in the way of repetition. (TA.) ― -b4- And Talaba HaAjapF faA^ajobala (assumed tropical:) He sought a thing that he wanted, and failed of attaining it. (TA.) ― -b5- And saA^alonaAhumo faA^ajobaluwA (tropical:) We asked them, and they refused, and did not give. (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, TA.) ― -b6- And A^ajobaluwA (tropical:) Their iron became blunt, so that it would not penetrate. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- Ajblhu (tropical:) He found him to be a jabal, i. e. a niggard: (K, TA:) it is considered as implying fixedness. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.

5 tjb~lwA jbl tjblwA
They entered a mountain: (K:) or, accord. to the O, you say, tjb~l Alqawomu AljibaAla, meaning, the people, or company of men, entered the mountains. (TA.)

jabolN jbl
(assumed tropical:) Big, thick, coarse, or rough; (TA;) as also jabilN ↓, applied to a thing (S, O, K) of any kind: (K:) or this latter is applied to an arrow, signifying (assumed tropical:) coarsely, roughly, or rudely, pared. (K.) You say rajulN jabolu Alr~aA^osi , (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, jabalu AlrA^s ,]) and Alwajohi, (TA,) (tropical:) A man having a big, thick, coarse, or rough, head, and face; (TA;) having little sweetness. (K, TA.) [See also jabiylN.] And rajulN mijobaAlN↓ (assumed tropical:) A big, thick, coarse, or rough, and heavy, man. (Ham p. 818.) And AimoraA^apN jabolapN (K [in one place in the CK jabalapN and jibolapN, but only jabolapN accord. to the TA,]) and mijobaAlN↓ (S, K) (tropical:) A woman big, thick, coarse, or rough, (S, K, TA,) in make; (S;) large in make. (TA.) And xiloqapN jabolapN (assumed tropical:) A big, thick, coarse, or rough, make. (Ham p. 821.) And naAqapN jabolapu Als~anaAmi (tropical:) A she-camel having an increasing hump. (TA.) And sayofN jabolN and mijobaAlN↓ (assumed tropical:) A sword not made thin. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also (K, TA, [in the CK, jabal,]) A court [of a house]; syn. saAHapN. (K.)

jubolN jbl
: see jibolN: ― -b2- and jibil~N. ＝ -A2- Also Dry trees. (K.)

jibolN jbl
Much; or numerous; (S, K;) as also jubolN↓ (K.) So in the phrases maAlN jibolN [Much property; or numerous cattle]; and HaY~N jibolN A numerous tribe. (S.) ― -b2- See also jibil~N, in two places.

jabalN jbl
[A mountain: or] any of the mountains (A^awotaAd [lit. “pegs,” or “stakes,” a term applied to the mountains because they are supposed to make the earth firm, or fast,]) of the earth, that is great and long; (Mgh, K;) or, as some say, only such as is long; (Msb;) such as is isolated being called A^akamapN, or qun~apN: (K:) [and also applied to a rocky tract; any rocky elevation, however little elevated:] and sometimes it means stone; [or rock;] such, for instance, as is reached by the digger: and hence it is applied to Es-Safà and El-Marweh: (Mgh:) pl. [of mult.] jibaAlN (S, Msb, K) and (of pauc., Msb) A^ajobulN (Msb, K) and A^ajobaAlN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A man who does not remove from his place: you say of such a one, huwa jabalN. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A niggard. (K, TA.) [See 4.] ― -b4- (tropical:) The lord, or chief, of a people, or company of men: and their learned man. (Fr, K, TA.) ― -b5- Abonapu Aljabal (assumed tropical:) The serpent: (K:) because it keeps to the jabal. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) Calamity, or misfortune. (K.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) The bow that is made from the tree called naboE; (K, TA;) because this is one of the trees of the jabal. (TA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) The echo. (Har p. 472.)

jabulN jbl
: see jibil~N.

jabilN jbl
: see jabolN. ― -b2- Also, applied to the iron head, or blade, of an arrow, or of a spear, or of a sword, &c., (tropical:) Blunt; that will not penetrate into a thing: (Ibn-' Abbád, K, * TA:) and so, with p, applied to a faA^os. (TA.)

jubulN jbl
: see jibil~N.

jabolapN jbl jblh jblp
(K, TA, [in the CK jabalapN,]) and jibolapN↓ The face: or the ba$arap [or external skin] thereof: or the part thereof that is turned towards one. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, (K,) or the former, (TA,) A vice, fault, defect, or blemish. (K.) ＝ -A3- And Strength. (K.) ― -b2- And Hardness of the earth, or ground. (Lth, K.) ＝ -A4- See also jubolapN: ＝ -A5- and see jibolaPN.

jubolapN jbl jblh jblp
A camel's hump; (S, K;) as also jabolapN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also jibil~N: ＝ -A3- and see jibil~apN, in two places.

jibolapN jbl jblh jblp
: see jibil~apN. ― -b2- Also The origin, or stock, (K, TA,) of any created thing; (TA;) and so jubul~apN↓. (K, TA.) ― -b3- The fundamental nature, or composition, of a mountain. (TA.) ― -b4- vawobN jay~idu Aljibolapi (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, good in respect of the thread (K, TA) and the weaving. (TA.) ― -b5- rajulN *uw jibolapK (assumed tropical:) A big, thick, coarse, or rough, man. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also jibil~N, in two places: ＝ -A3- and see jabolapN.

jabalapN jbl jblh jblp
: see jibil~apN.

jubul~N jbl
: see what next follows.

jibil~N jbl
and jubul~N↓ and jibolN↓ [accord. to the CK like EadolN, but correctly like EidolN,] and jubolN↓ and jubulN↓, (S, K,) accord. to different readings of the instance occurring in the Kur xxxvi. 62, the first being the reading of the people of ElMedeeneh, (S,) [and the most common,] A great company of men; as also jibil~apN↓ and jabiylN↓: (K:) or [simply] a company of men; (S;) as also jabulN↓, accord. to Kh; (Sgh, TA;) and so jabolapN↓ and jubolapN↓ and jibil~apN↓: which last three signify also the same as A^um~apN [a nation, or people, &c.]: (K:) it is said [by some] that jibil~N is pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of jibil~apN↓ meaning a numerous company: (TA:) jibalapN is pl. of jibolN↓: one says, qabaHa A@ll~`hu jibalatakumo [May God remove far from prosperity, or success,] your companies: (Fr, TA:) and jibalN is pl. of jibolapN↓. (Bd in xxxvi. 62.)

jubul~apN jbl jblh jblp
Much, or an abundance, or a large quantity or number, or anything; as also jibil~apN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also jibolapN: ＝ -A3- and see what next follows, in two places.

jibil~apN jbl jblh jblp
(S, Msb, K) and jubul~apN↓ and jabiylapN↓ (Sgh, MF) and jibolapN↓ (AA, S, K) and jubolapN↓ and jabolapN↓ and jabalapN↓, (K,) but this last, accord. to MF, is unknown, (TA,) Nature; or natural, native, innate, or original, constitution, disposition, temper, or other quality or property; idiosyncrasy; syn. xiloqapN (AA, S, Sgh, Msb, K) and TabiyEapN (Msb, K) and gariyzapN; all these signifying the same: (Msb:) pl. of the first jibil~aAtN. (S.) Hence, in the Kur [xxvi. 184], waAljibil~apa AlA^aw~aliyna, (S,) meaning Alxaliyqapa, (Jel,) or *awiy Aljibil~api, i. e. And the preceding created beings: (Bd:) El- Hasan read with damm [i. e. Aljubul~apa↓ or Aljvbolapa↓]. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also jibil~N, in three places: ― -b2- and see jubul~apN.

jabaliY~N jbl jblY jbly jblyy
Of, or relating to, a mountain or mountains; contr. of suholiY~N. (The Lexicons &c. passim.)

jibil~Y~N jbl jblY jbly jblyy
Natural; i. e. of, or relating to, the natural, native, innate, or original, constitution, disposition, temper, or other quality or property; like TabiyEiY~N; i. e. essential; resulting from the Creator's ordering of the natural disposition in the body. (Msb.)

jibaAlN jbAl jbl
(tropical:) The body, with, or without, the members; syn. jasadN and badanN; (K, TA;) as being likened to a mountain in bigness [?]. (TA.) One says, A^aHosana A@ll~`hu jibaAlahu, meaning, (tropical:) [May God render beautiful] his body (jasadahu): and [render good] his created xuluq [or mind, with its qualities and attributes: but I rather think that xuluq is here a mistranscription for xaloq, meaning make]. (Ibn-' Abbád, TA.)

jabiylN jbyl
: see jibil~N. ＝ -A2- jabiylu Alwajohi (tropical:) A man having a bad, or an ugly, face. (K, TA.) [See also jabolN.]

jabiylapN jbyl jbylh jbylp
: see jibil~apN.

mijobaAlN mjbAl
: see jabolN, in three places.

majobuwlN mjbwl
, applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Great, large, or big, (K, TA,) in make; as though he were a mountain. (TA.)

1 jabuna jAb jbn jbnn
, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jabuna
, inf. n. jubonN (Msb, K) and jubunN (K) and jabaAnapN; (Msb, K;) and jabana, (S, ISd, Msb,) aor.
jabuna
; (Msb, TA;) He (a man) was, or became, such as is termed jabaAn (S, Msb, K) and jabiyn; (S, K;) i. e. cowardly, (K,) or weak hearted. (Msb.) And jabuna Eanohu He held back, or refrained, from him, or it, through cowardice. (TA in art. Ers.)

2 jbanhu jAb jbn jbnh jbnnh jbnp
, inf. n. tajobiynN, He attributed to him cowardice (jubon). (S.) And huwa yujab~anu, inf. n. as above, He is accused of cowardice. (K.)

4 Ajbnhu A^jAb A^jbn A^jbnh A^jbnp Ajbnh Ajbnp jbn
He found him to be such as is termed jabaAn; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. a coward, or cowardly, (K,) or weak-hearted: (Msb:) or he reckoned him a coward; (M, K;) as also Ajtbnhu↓. (K.)

5 tjb~n A^jAb jAb jbn tjbn tjbnn wjb
It (milk) became like jubon [i. e. cheese]. (K.) ― -b2- And hence, perhaps, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became thick, gross, coarse, or big. (S, TA.)

8 Ajtbnhu Ajtbnh Ajtbnp
He made cheese of it; i. e. of milk. (T, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 4.

jubonN jAb jbn jbnn
and jubunN↓ and jubun~N↓, (S, Msb, K,) the first of which is the most approved, and the last the most rare, and said by some to be used only in a case of necessity in poetry, (Lth, Msb,) [Cheese;] a certain thing that is eaten, (S, Msb,) well known: (K:) n. un. jubonapN, (TA,) a word having a more particular signification than jubonN, (S,) meaning a qurS [or round, flattened, loaf] thereof, (Mgh,) [or a cheese, or piece of cheese,] as also jubunapN (TA) and jubun~apN. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also jubonN and jubunN↓, [inf. ns. of jabuna, used as simple substs.,] Cowardice; weak-heartedness;] the quality denoted by jabaAnN. (S.)

jubunN jAb jbn jbnn
: see jubonN, in two places.

jubun~N jAb jbn jbnn
: see jubonN.

juboniY~N jb jbn jbnY jbny
A seller of jubon [i. e. cheese]. (TA.) ― -b2- And a rel. n. from suwqu Aljuboni [The cheesemarket] in Damascus. (K.)

jabaAnN jb jbAn
, (S, Msb, K,) an epithet from jabana, (S,) applied to a man and to a woman, (S, Msb, K,) in the latter case like HaSaAnN and razaAnN, (Ibn-EsSarráj, S,) and with p also applied to a woman; (M, Msb, K;) and jabynN↓, (S, K,) from jabuna, (S,) applied to a man and to a woman; and jab~aAnN↓; (K;) A coward; or cowardly; i. e. wont to dread things, so as not to venture upon them boldly, (K, TA,) by night or by day; (TA;) weak-hearted: (Msb:) jabaAnN is contr. of $ujaAEN: (Msb in art. $jE:) pl. masc. jubanaA='u, (Msb, K,)
[properly of jabiynN] and fem. jabaAnaAtN. (Lth, Msb, TA.) huwa jabaAnu Alkalobi [He is one whose dog is cowardly,] means (tropical:) he is extremely generous: (K, TA:) because, by reason of guests' coming to him, his dog does not growl. (TA.) And you say, fulaAnN $ujaAEu Alqalobi jabaAnu Alwajohi (tropical:) [app. meaning Such a one is courageous in heart, mild in face]. (TA. [Expl. by AjnY Alwjh, which seems to be a mistranscription.])

jabiynN jb jbY jbyn
: see jabaAnN. ＝ -A2- Also The part above the temple, on the right of the forehead, and on the left thereof; the two being called jabiynaAni: (S:) the side of the forehead, [so Bd in xxxvii. 103,] from the part over against the place where the hair falls off, to the temple, on the right of the forehead, and on the left thereof: so say Az and IF and others: the forehead (Aljabotap) is between the jabiynaAni: (Msb:) or the jabiynaAni are the two borders of the forehead, on either side thereof, in the part between the two eyebrows (fiymaA bayona AlHaAjibayoni [so in the copies of the K, a mistake for fymA yaliY AlHAjbyn in the part next to the two eyebrows]), rising to the place where the growth of the hair terminates: (K:) or between the place where the growth of the hair terminates and the eyebrows: (TA:) or the jbyn is the borders (in the T, the border, TA) of the forehead, between the two temples, uniting with the naASiyap [or place where the hair grows in the fore part of the head, or the hair of that part]: (K, TA:) and it sometimes occurs as meaning the forehead: (MF, TA:) [see an ex. voce tariba, where it is used in this last sense, and is fem., perhaps because syn. with jabohap, for] Lh says that it is always masc.: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] jubunN and [of pauc.] A^ajobinapN (Msb, K) and A^ajobunN. (K.)

jab~aAnN jb jbAn
: see jabaAnN. ＝ -A2- Also One who keeps, or guards, the produce of land in the desert. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also what next follows.

jab~aAnapN jbAn jbAnh jbAnp
(S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jab~aAnN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the former of which is the more common, (Msb,) A place of prayer, (Msb,) or common place of prayer, (Mgh,) in a SaHoraA=' [or desert tract]. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- A burial-ground: (K:) this is sometimes called jb~Anp because the place of prayer is generally in the burial-ground: (Msb:) accord. to Kh, these two words, in this sense, are from Aljab~u and Aljabuwbu; but others derive them from jbn. (TA in art. jb.) ― -b3- A [desert tract such as is termed] SaHoraA='. (S, K.) ― -b4- A place that produces much herbage: and level, elevated land: (AHn, K:) or the latter, level, elevated land, that produces much herbage: (Aboo-Kheyreh, TA:) accord. to ISh, it is smooth, without trees; but it may have in it hills, and a tract abounding with trees: and sometimes the jb~Anp is level, without hills and without any tract abounding with trees; but it is not in sand nor in mountains, though it may be in [high grounds such as are termed] qifaAf [pl. of quf~N] and in [what are termed] $aqaAy^iq [pl. of $aqiyqapN]. (TA.)

jab~AniY~N jb jbAn jbAnY jbAny jbAnyy jbY
A dweller in the jab~aAn, meaning SaHoraA='. (TA.)

A^ajobanu *
[More, and most, cowardly, or weakhearted]. (TA.) You say A^ajobanu mino SaAfirK, i. e. [More cowardly] than a whistling bird: (S in art. Sfr:) or, as some say, than a thief. (TA in that art. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 326.])

majobanapN mjbnh mjbnp
[A cause of cowardice, or weak-heartedness]. One says, Alwaladu majobanapN maboxalapN [Children are a cause of cowardice and a cause of niggardliness]; because one loves continuance of life, and property, on account of them. (S, TA.)

1 jabahahu jbh jbhh jbhp
, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jabaha
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jabohN, (Ham p. 355,) He slapped, (S,) or struck, (K,) or hit, (Msb,) or struck him on, (Ham ubi suprà,) his jabohap [or forehead]. (S, Msb, K, and Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b2- And [hence], (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He turned him back (K, TA) from the thing that he wanted: (TA:) or (tropical:) he met him, or encountered him, with, or he said to him, or did to him, a thing disliked, or hated: (K, TA, TK:) or (tropical:) he encountered him, or confronted him, with speech in which was roughness: (JK, M, TA:) or (tropical:) he encountered him with that which he disliked, or hated; or he accused him thereof to his face; (M, TA, and Ham ubi suprà;) or so jabahahu biAlmakoruwhi. (S, TA.) ― -b3- jabaha AlmaA='a, (JK, S, K,) inf. n. as above, (JK, S,) (tropical:) He came to the water, (JK, S, K,) when there was at it no apparatus for drawing, (S,) i. e. no pulley &c., (JK, TA,) or having no means of drawing, so that he only looked at the surface of the water. (Z, K.) [See also jabiyhapN.] ― -b4- jabaha Alqawoma (tropical:) It (winter) came upon the people unprepared for it. (A, K.)

2 tajobiyhN jb jbY tjbyh tjbyp
The mounting a fornicator, or an adulterer, upon an ass, and turning his face towards the tail; whence the trad. of the Jews respecting the adulterer, yuHum~amu wayujab~ahu wyujoladu [He shall have his face blackened with charcoal, and be mounted on an ass with his face towards the tail, and be flogged]: (Mgh:) or the mounting two fornicators, or adulterers, upon an ass, and turning the backs of their heads towards each other, (JK, Mgh,) and parading them round about; thus accord. to the Tekmileh: (Mgh:) or the blackening [with charcoal] the faces of two fornicators, or adulterers, (A^ano yuHam~ara in the K being a mistake for A^ano yuHum~ama, i. e. yusaw~ada, TA,) and mounting them upon a camel or an ass, and turning their faces in contrary directions: accord. to analogy, it should mean turning their faces towards each other; for it is from Aljabotapu: tajobiyhN also signifies the bending, inclining, lowering, or hanging down, the head towards the ground: and it may be hence; (i. e. it may be hence that it is applied to him who is mounted on a beast in the manner described above; TA;) because he to whom this is done bends down his head in shame and confusion: or it may be from jabahahu meaning "he did to him a thing disliked, or hated." (K.)

8 AijotibaAhN AjtbAh AjtbAp {jtbAh {jtbY
The deeming [one] rude, coarse, unkind, hard, or churlish. (JK.) ― -b2- And The fearing [a person or thing]. (JK.) ― -b3- And Ajtbhhu He disliked, or hated, and feared, it, or him; namely, a country, or town, and a man. (JK.) ― -b4- He disapproved it, or disliked it, and did not find it wholesome; namely, water, (En-Nawádir, K,) &c. (K.)

jabahN jb jbh jbp
Largeness, (S,) or width (JK, M, K) and beauty, (M, K,) of the jabohap [or forehead]: (JK, S, M, K:) or protuberance, or prominence, thereof. (M, K.)

waradonaA maA='F lahu jabiyhapN wrdnA mA=' lh jbyhh wrdnA mA=' lh jbyhp
We came to a water that was salt, so that the drinking thereof did not take away the thirst of our cattle: (ISk, JK, S:) or that was altered for the worse in taste and colour, from some such cause as long standing, though still drinkable; or covered with the green substance called TuHolub and with leaves: or that was deep in the bottom, difficult to give to drink. (ISk, S.) [See also 1, last meaning but one.]

jub~ahN jb jbh jbp
i. q. jub~aA^N, (K,) i. e. A fearful, or cowardly, man. (TA.)

jaAbihN jAb jAbh jAbp
, applied to a gazelle, (JK,) or to a bird or a wild animal, (K,) That meets one with its face or forehead; and such is of evil omen: (K:) contr. of qaEiydN. (JK.) ― -b2- Coming to water: so in a saying cited and explained in art. A*n, conj. 2. (IAar, TA.)

A^ajobahu *
, applied to a man, Large, (S,) or wide (JK, M, K) and beautiful, (M, K,) in the jabohap [or forehead]: (JK, S, M, K:) or protuberant, or prominent, therein: (M, K:) applied to a horse, having a protuberant, or prominent, forehead, rising beyond the bone of the nose: (TA:) fem. jabohaA='u; (S, K;) of which the dim. is jubayohaA='u. (S.) ― -b2- AlA^ajobahu The lion; (K;) because of the width of his jabohap. (TA.)

div1.superEntry:
jbw and jbY [The words belonging to the former of these two arts. cannot well be classed by themselves, being intimately connected with those of the latter, which are the more numerous and common, and from which they are generally easily distinguishable.]
1 jabaY jb jbY jby jbyy
, (K,) first pers. jabayotu, (Ks, S, Er-Rághib,) aor.
1a2i3a
; (K;) and jabaY, aor.
1a2a3a
, (K,) said by MF to be unknown, and also, because neither the second nor the third radical is a faucial letter, unreasonable, but mentioned by Sb, though held by him to be of weak authority, and mentioned also by IAar, as extr., like A^abaY, aor. yaA^obaY; (TA;) and jabaA, (TA,) first pers. jabawotu, (Ks, S, TA,) aor.
1a2u3a
; (TA;) inf. n. [of the first and second] jaboYN (Sh, K) and [probably of the last only] jabFA and jibFA and jubFA and [of the last, but whether in the first or the second of the senses here following is not shown,] jibowapN; (K; [or this last has a different application, explained below;]) He collected water in a trough or tank for beasts &c. [Ks, S, K, Er-Rághib.) ― -b2- And (hence, metaphorically, Er-Rághib, TA) the first of these verbs, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, Er-Rághib,) and the second, (K,) and the third; (S, Msb, TA;) inf. n. (of the first, S, Msb) jibaAyapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, Er-Rághib) and (of the last, S, Msb) jibaAwapN (S, Msb, K) and jabowN (TA) [and probably jibowapN also, which see above]; (tropical:) He collected the [tax called] xaraAj, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, Er-Rághib,) and [other] property. (Msb, TA.) The last of these verbs is said in the S to be originally with ', though pronounced without '; but IB says that this is not the case, and that it has not been heard with '. (TA.) You say also, jabaAhu Alqawoma (assumed tropical:) [He collected it from the people, or company of men]; (M, K, * TA;) and jabaY minohumo (assumed tropical:) [He collected from them]. (M, K, TA.) ― -b3- Also jabaA [or jabaY], (TA,) first pers. jabayotu, (Zj, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He appropriated a thing purely to himself, exclusively of any partner; chose it, or took it in preference, for himself. (Zj, TA.) And hence, (Zj, TA,) AjtbAhu↓ (assumed tropical:) He chose it, or selected it, (Zj, S, K) linafosihi for himself. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And jabaY and jabaA, [originally jabaA^a,] He returned, receded, retreated, or went back. (TA.)
2 jb~Y jb jbY jby jbyy
, inf. n. tajobiyapN, He placed his hands upon his knees, (K, TA,) in prayer; (TA;) or upon the ground: or he fell prostrate; or fell upon his face: (K:) or he lowered his body and his hands, and raised his buttocks: (Ham p. 801:) [or] tjbyp signifies a man's standing [with the hands upon the knees] in the manner of the raAkiE: (S, K: *) accord. to A'Obeyd, what is thus termed is of two kinds: one is the placing the hands upon the knees, while standing: the other, the prostrating oneself, or falling upon the face, lying down; which is sujuwdN: (S:) or the bending down, and placing the hands upon the knees; because it is a bringing-together of the limbs. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- jb~Ahu, inf. n. as above, meaning He gave to him, is vulgar. (TA.)
4 AjbY A^jbY A^jby AjbY Ajby jbY
in the trad. mano A^ajobaY faqado A^arobaY is originally A^ajobaA^a [q. v.]: (S:) accord. to IAth, it is a corruption of the relater, or the ' is suppressed to assimilate the verb to ArbY (TA.) The inf. n., A_ijobaA='N, is variously explained, as follows: (TA:) The selling seed-produce before it shows itself to be in a good state: (A'Obeyd, Th, S, K:) and a man's hiding his camels from the collector of the poor-rate: (IAar, A'Obeyd, K:) and i. q. EiynapN; i. e. the selling to a man a commodity for a certain price to be paid at a certain period, then buying it of him with ready money for a less price than that for which it was sold. (TA.)
8 AijotibaA='N AjtbA='
(assumed tropical:) The drawing forth property from the places in which it is known, or presumed, or accustomed, to be. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The collecting in the way of choice, or selection. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, last sentence but one. ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) God's particular, or peculiar, distinguishing of men by abundant bounty, from which various blessings result to them without their labour; as happens to prophets and some others. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b5- Also AjtbAhu, (assumed tropical:) He forged it: and he extemporized it. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [vii. 202], qaAluwA lawolaA A@jotabayotahaA (assumed tropical:) They say, Wherefore hast thou not forged it, (Fr, TA,) or produced it, (Th, TA,) or invented it, (Jel,) or put it together by forgery, (Bd,) of thyself? (Fr, Th, Bd, Jel, TA:) or wherefore hast thou not sought it, or demanded it, of God? (Bd.)
jabFA jb jbA
