, or jabFY, (as in different copies of the K,) written with A and with Y, (TA,) The camel-waterer's going in advance of the camels a day before their coming to the water, and collecting for them water in the drinking-trough, and then bringing them to it (IAar, K, TA) on the morrow. (IAar, TA.) [App. an inf. n., of which, in this sense, the verb is not mentioned.] So in the verse,
biAlr~ayovi maA A^arowayotuhaA laA biAlEajalo
wabiAljabaA A^arowayotuhaA laA biAlqabalo
[Slowly I satisfied their thirst; not hastily: and by going in advance of them a day, and collecting for them water in the trough, and bringing them to it on the morrow, I satisfied their thirst; not by pouring the water into the trough while they were drinking, without having prepared any for them beforehand]. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also the former, Water collected [in a trough]; and so jubowapN↓, with damm. (TA. [See jibFA.]) ― -b2- A wateringtrough (K, TA) in which water is collected: (TA:) or the station of the drawer of water, upon the [upper part of the] casing. (K.) ― -b3- The place where a well is dug: (K:) in this sense, and in the next, also written jabFY (TA.) ― -b4- The brink, or margin, of a well. (A boo-Leylà, K.) The earth that is around a well, that is seen from afar; (S;) originally jabaA^N: (TA:) what is around a well: (K:) and what is around a wateringtrough: (TA:) pl. A^ajobaA='N. (K.) ＝ -A3- jabaA meaning A gift without compensation is a vulgar word. (TA.)
jibFA jb jbA
Water collected (T, S, K) in a trough, (T, K,) being drawn from a well, (T, TA,) for camels; (S;) [like jabFA;] as also jibowapN↓, (K, TA, and so in a copy of the S, but omitted in the CK,) or jabowapN↓, (so in two copies of the S,) and jubowapN↓ also, (so in a copy of the S, [see jabFA,]) and jabaAwapN↓, (K, TA, and so in a copy of the S,) and jabaAwapN↓, (K, TA, and so in another copy of the S, but omitted in the CK,) and jibaA='apN↓: (TA as from the K, but not in the CK: [perhaps a mistranscription for jibaAyapN↓:]) but accord. to IAmb, jibFA is pl. of jiboyapN↓. (TA.)
jabowapN jb jbY jbwh jbwp
; see jibFA.
jubowapN jb jbY jbwh jbwp
: see jabFA and jibFA.
jibowapN jb jbY jbwh jbwp
: see jibFA. ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) A mode, or manner, of collecting the [tax called] xaraAj; and so jiboyapN↓, which Lh calls an inf. n. (TA.)
jiboyapN jb jbyh jbyp
: see what next precedes: ― -b2- and see jibFA.
jibaA='apN jbA='h jbA='p
: see jibFA.
jabaAwapN jbAwh jbAwp
and jibaAwapN: see jibFA.
jibaAyapN jbAyh jbAyp
: see jibFA. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The tax called A_itaAwap [or xaraAj]. (TA in art. Atw.) [Originally an inf. n.]
jabaAyaA jbAyA
[a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Wells which are dug, and in which the shoots of grape-vines are set. (AHn, K.)
jaAbK jAb jAby
A collector of water for camels: belonging to arts. jbw and jbY. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The locust (K) that collects everything by eating it; as also jaAbiY'N [q. v.]. (TA.) The Arabs say, A_i*aA jaA='ati Als~anapu jaA='a maEahaA AljaAbiY waAljaAniY, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [When the year of drought comes,] the locust and the wolf [come with it]. (IAar, TA.)
jaAbiyapN jAby jAbyh jAbyp
A watering-trough, (S,) or large wateringtrough, (K,) in which water is collected (S) for camels: (TA:) or a watering-trough that collects water: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. jawaAbK. (S.) Hence, in the Kur [xxxiv. 12], wajafaAnK kaAljawaAbiY [And bowls like watering-troughs, or great wateringtroughs]. (S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A company of men. (K, * TA.)
luw^oluw^apN mujab~aApN *
A hollowed pearl: (Ibn-Wahb, TA:) the latter word thought by El-Khattábee to be formed by transposition from mujaw~bapN. (TA.)

superEntry.entry:
1 jav~ahu jv jvh jvp
, (S, Msb, TA,) aor.
javu3a
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. jav~N, (A, K,) He pulled it up, or out; as also Ajtv~hu↓; (S, Msb;) or the latter denotes a quicker action than the former; and properly signifies he took its whole juv~ap [or body]: (TA:) or the former, he cut it; or cut it off: (A, L, K:) or he cut it off from its root: (L:) or he pulled it up, or out, by the root; namely, a tree: (A, K;) he uprooted it, or eradicated it. (A.) ＝ -A2- jav~a said of a collector of honey, He took the honey with its jav~ and its maHaAriyn, i. e., the bees that had died in it. (IAar, TA.)

7 Ainojav~a Anjv
(M, L, TA) and Aujotuv~a↓ (M, A, L, TA) It was, or became, pulled up, or out: properly, its whole juv~ap [or body] was taken; said of a tree: (TA in explanation of the latter:) it was, or became, cut, or cut off; (A, L;) or cut off from its root; (L;) pulled up, or out, by the root; uprooted, or eradicated: said of a tree. (A.)

8 A_ijotava3a
see 1 and 7.

jav~N jv
, so in the S [and L] and other lexicons, but in the K it is implied that it is juv~N↓, (TA,) Bees' wax: or any particles, of the wings of the bees, (S, K,) and of their bodies, (S,) intermixed with the honey: (S, K:) [or] the xiro$aA=' of honey; (K;) i. e. the young bees, or the wings, that are upon honey; as in the M and L &c.: (TA:) or the bees that have died in the honey. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- Also Dead locusts. (IAar, K.)

juv~N jv
: see jav~N. ＝ -A2- Also Elevated ground (S, TA, but not in all the copies of the former) such as has a form visible from a distance: (TA:) or ground that is elevated so as to be like a small [hill of the kind called]A^akamap. (K.) ＝ -A3- The envelope of fruit; (K;) [or of the spadix of a palm-tree;] like juf~N; the v being a substitute for f. (TA.)

juv~apN jv jvh jvp
The body, or corporeal form or figure, ($axoS.) of a man, (S, A, Msb, K,) [absolutely, or] sitting, (S, A, Msb,) or sleeping, [by which is meant, as in many other instances, lying down,] (S, Msb,) or reclining, or lying on the side: (TA:) that of a man standing erect being termed TalalN (Msb) or qaAmapN; (TA;) and $xS applying in common to what is termed jvap and what is termed Tll, in relation to a man: (Msb:) or jvap is used only in relation to a man upon a horse's or camel's saddle, wearing a turban: so says IDrd on the authority of Abu-l-Khattáb ElAkhfash; but he adds that this has not been heard from any other: (TA:) pl. [of mult.]

juvavN jvp jvv
(A, TA) and [of pauc.] A^ajovaAvN; the latter as though formed from juv~N, without regard to the augmentative letter [p]; or it may be pl. of juvavN, and thus a pl. pl. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A body; [a corpse;] syn. jasadN; as in the saying, in a trad., Aall~hum~a jaAfi AlA^aroDa Eano juv~atihi [O God, remove the earth from his body, or corpse: i. e., let it not press against his sides in the grave]. (TA.) ― -b3- [And The body of a tree: see 7.]

javiyvN jvyv
[a coll. gen. n.] Young palm-trees, or shoots of palm-trees, that are cut off from the mother-trees, or plucked forth from the ground, and planted: n. un. with p: it is thus called until it yields fruit; when it is called naxalapN: (S:) or what are planted, of the shoots of palm-trees; (AHn, K;) not what are set, of the stones: (AHn, TA:) or shoots of palm-trees when they are first pulled off from the mother-trees: (As, TA: [as also qavayvN:]) or, with p, it signifies a palm-tree produced from a date-stone, for which a hole is dug, and which is transplanted with the earth adhering to its root: (AA, TA:) or what falls in succession from [app. a mistake for at] the roots, or lower parts, of palm-trees. (Abu-lKhattáb, TA.) ― -b2- And Grapes that fall at the roots, or lower parts, of the vine. (ISd, TA.)

mijav~apN mjvh mjvp
and mijovaAvN↓ A thing with which javiyv [q. v.] are uprooted: (M, K:) an iron implement with which young palm-trees, or shoots of palmtrees, are pulled up or off. (S.)

mijovaAvN mjvAv
: see what next precedes.

$ajarapN mujotav~apN *
A tree [pulled up or out, by the root: or] that has no root in the ground. (A.) ― -b2- baHoru Almujotav~i The fourteenth metre of verse; as though it were cut off from the xafiyf; (TA;) the metre consisting of
musotafoEiluno faAEilaAtuno faAEilaAtuno
(K. [So originally; but in usage, the last of the three feet is cut off. Accord. to the TA, the first foot is properly written musotafoEi luno, as in some copies of the K.])

1 javula jvl
, aor.
javula
; (Lth, Msb, K;) and javila, aor.
javala
; (K;) inf. n. juvuwlapN and javaAlapN; (Msb, K;) both of the former verb; (Msb, TA;) [but both mentioned in the S as simple substs.;] It was, or became, such as is termed javolN, explained below. (Msb, K.)

Q. Q. 4 AijovaA^al~a *
He (a bird) ruffled his feathers (S, K) by reason of the cold. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became angry, and prepared himself for fighting. (S, K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (a plant, or herbage,) became tall, and tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense: (Z, K:) or became tall (Aihotaz~a, q. v.), and such as might be grasped with the hand. (AZ, S, K.) ― -b4- It (the plumage of a bird) became ruffled. (K.)

javolN jvl
(AZ, S, Msb, K) and javiylN↓ (K) A thing, (Msb,) or hair, (AZ, S, K,) and (tropical:) trees ($ajarN), (K, TA,) much, or abundant, (AZ, S, Msb, K,) and thick, or abundant, (AZ, S, Msb, K,) and thick, or coarse, or rough, (Msb,) or tangled, or luxuriant and dense, (K,) and soft: (TA:) or thick, or coarse, or rough, and short: or dense and black: (K:) or the blackest hair: or the thickest, or coarsest, or roughest: (Lth, TA:) or anything large, big, or bulky, and dense, and tangled, or luxuriant. (K.) You say liHoyapN An abundant, thick, or coarse, or rough, beard. (Msb:) or a thick, or dense, beard. (TA.) And naASiyapN javolapN A horse's forelock moderate in respect of quantity and length: such is approved. (S.) And $ajarapN javolapN (tropical:) A many-leaved, big, tree. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- javolN A species of ant, large and black; as also jafolN: (IDrd, TA:) or javolapN signifies a black ant: (S:) or a large and: and javolN is its pl. [or coll. gen. n.]. (K.)

javaylN jvyl
: see javolN.

juvaAlapN jvAlh jvAlp
Leaves that have become gradually scattered, or strewn. (K.)

mujovay^il~N *
Brood, or wide. (K.) ― -b2- Standing erect. (S, K.)

1 javama jAvm jvm
, aor.
javima
(S, Mgh, Msb, K) and
javuma
, (S, K,) inf. juvuwmN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and javomN, (K,) said of a bird, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and of a hare, and sometimes of a gazelle, (Msb,) or of a [young gazelle such as is termed] xa$of, (K,) and of a camel, (Msb, K,) and a jerboa, (K,) and a man, (S, K,) He clave to the ground: (S, K:) or kept to his place, not quitting it: (K:) or fell upon his breast: (Msb, * K:) juvuwmN in the case of a bird and a hare is like buruwkN in the case of a camel: (Msb:) or in the case of a bird it is like juluwsN in the case of a man [so that the verb means he sat]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) aor.
javima
, (TA,) said of seed-produce, It rose a little from the ground. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- Also, (AHn, K,) aor.
javuma
, (AHn, TA,) inf. n. juvuwmN, said of a raceme of a palm-tree, Its unripe, or ripening, dates became somewhat large: (AHn, K: *) or it became large, and kept its place. (T, TA.) ― -b4- Also, inf. n. juvuwmN, said of the night, (assumed tropical:) It became half spent. (Th, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- javama also signifies He collected clay, or mould, and earth, or dust, and ashes. (K.)

2 jv~m jAvm jvm
, (S, Mgh,) inf. n. tajoviymN, (KL,) [He made a bird, and a hare, and the like, to cleave to the ground, then to be shot at, or cast at, and so killed: see mujav~apN:] he kept, or held, a bird confined, that it might [be shot at, or cast at, and] die: (KL:) he turned an animal on his side to be slaughtered. (Golius, as from the KL, but not in my copy of that work.)

5 tjv~m jvm tjvm
He (a bird) mounted his female for the purpose of copulation. (TA.)

javomN jAvm jvm
Seed-produce rising a little from the ground; as also javamN↓. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- A raceme of a palm-tree having its unripe, or ripening, dates becoming somewhat large. (K, * TA.)

javamN jAvm jvm
: see the next preceding paragraph.

juvamN jAvm jvm
: see jav~aAmapN: ― -b2- and juvaAmN.

javomapN jAvm jvm jvmh jvmp
: see juvuwmN.

juvomapN jAvm jvm jvmh jvmp
Clay, or mould, and earth, or dust, and ashes, collected. (K.)

javamapN jAvm jvm jvmh jvmp
: see juvuwmN.

juvamapN jAvm jvm jvmh jvmp
: see jav~aAmapN: ― -b2- and juvaAmN.

juvomaAnN jvmAn
The body, with the limbs or members; syn. jisomN: and i. q. $axoSN [app. as meaning a person; not, as J seems to have held, a corporeal, or material, form or thing or substance, such as is seen from a distance; see jisomN]: (K:) or, accord. to As, it has the latter meaning, i. q. $axoSN; and jusomaAnN has the former meaning, that of jisomN (S, Msb) and jasadN: (Msb:) or, accord. to AZ, juvomaAnN is syn. with jusomaAnN, (S, Msb,) i. e. jasadN. (S.) One says, maA A^aHosana juvomaAna Alr~ajuli and jusomaAnahu, meaning [How goodly, or beautiful, is] the body, or person, of the man! (AZ, S.) J cites, as an ex. of this word in the sense of $xS, from a verse of Bishr,
sanaAmN kajuvomaAni Albaniy~ipi A^atolaEaA
observing that by Albny~p is meant the Kaabeh: but IB says that the right reading, as found in his poetry, is Albaliy~api, and A^atolaEu; and that the meaning is, A [long] hump like the jvmAn [or body] of the she-camel that is placed [and confined without food or water until she dies] at the grave of a dead man. (TA.) One says also, jaA='anaA bivariydK kajuvomaAni AlmaA='i [He brought us crumbled bread moistened with broth and piled up, like the body of the bird of the kind called qaTFA]. (S.)

juvomaAniy~apu AlmaA='i jvmAnyp AlmA='
, as used in the saying of ElFarajeeyeh, (K,) so in the copies of the K, [or El-Faraheeyeh, accord. to the CK,] but correctly of El-Farezdak, (TA,)
wabaAtato bijuvomaAniy~api AlmaA='i niybuhaA
A_ilaY *aAti raHolK kaA@lomaA=timi Hus~araA
means The water itself: or the middle thereof: or the place where it collected. (K TA.) [The poet says, And her aged she-camels passed the night in the water, &c.,.... like the companies of mourning women having the head, or the face, &c., uncovered: but what is meant by Aly *At rHl, unless it be with one having a saddle upon her, A_ilaY being sometimes used in the sense of maEa I am unable to conjecture. In the CK, nayobahA and kAlm`Avimi are erroneously put for niybuhaA and kaAlmaA=timi.]

juvaAmN jvAm
Incubus, or nightmare; (T, K;) what comes upon a man when he is sleeping; (T, TA;) what comes upon a man in the night, preventing him from speaking; i. q. nayodulaAnN; (IAar, TA;) as also jaAvuwmN↓ (T, K) and jav~aAmapN↓ and juvamN↓ and juvamapN↓. (T, TA.)

javuwmN jvwm
: see jaAvimN. ― -b2- Hence, (assumed tropical:) A hare. (TA.)

juvuwmN jvwm
pl. of jAvimN [q. v.]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A hill such as is called A^akamapN; and so javamapN↓ (K) and javomapN↓ (TA.)

jav~aAmN jvAm
: see jaAvimN.

jav~aAmapN jvAm jvAmh jvAmp
: see jaAvimN. ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) A man who keeps to the region of cities, towns, villages, or cultivated land, and does not travel: (Msb:) a man who sleeps much, and does not travel; as also juvamapN↓ (S, K) and juvamN↓ and jaAvuwmN↓: (K:) [see also jaAvimapN:] stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence; or not penetrating, sharp, vigorous, or effective, in the performing of affairs: and a forbearing, or clement, personage, chief, or man of rank or quality. (K.) ― -b3- See also juvaAmN.

jaAvimN jAvm
A bird, (Msb, K,) and a hare, and sometimes a gazelle, (Msb,) or a [young gazelle such as is termed] xi$of, (K,) and a camel, (Msb, K,) and a jerboa, and a man, (K,) cleaving to the ground: or keeping to his place, not quitting it: (K:) or falling upon his breast: (Msb, * K:) as also javuwmN↓: (K:) [or the latter] and jav~aAmN↓ doing so much, or often: and jav~aAmapN↓ doing so very much, or very often: (Msb:) and the first, also, sitting upon his legs like a bird: pl. juvuwmN (TA) [and juv~amN, accord. to Freytag].

faA^aSobaHuwA fiY daArihimo jaAvimiyna *
, in the Kur [vii. 76, &c.], means [And they became, in their abode,] bodies cast upon the ground: (TA:) or extinct, or motionless; and dead. (Bd.) ― -b2- Aljuvvwmu (tropical:) The stars composing the constellation of the Scorpion; also called Alburuku: see baroko. (L and TA in art. brk.)

jaAvimapN jAvm jAvmh jAvmp
One who does not quit his house, or tent. (Lth, TA.) [See also jav~aAmapN.]

jaAvuwumN jAvwm jvAm
: see jav~aAmapN: ― -b2- and juvaAmN.

majovamN mjvm
[and majovimN A place where a bird, &c., cleaves to the ground: or to which it keeps: or where it falls upon its breast. And particularly,] The seat, or form, of a hare: (TA:) [pl. majaAvimu.]

mujav~amapN 1
A bird, and a hare, and the like, that is confined or set up, to be killed; (A'Obeyd, S, Mgh;) that is made to cleave to the ground (tujav~amu), and then shot at, or cast at, until it is killed; (S, Mgh;) which manner of killing is forbidden: (S:) or any animal that is set up and shot at, or cast at, and [so] killed: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or a sheep, or goat, that is shot at with arrows: ('Ikrimeh, Mgh:) or a sheep, or goat, that is stoned (Sh, Mgh, TA) until it dies, and is then eaten. (TA.)

superEntry.head: jvw and jvY
superEntry.entry:
1 javaA * and javaY
(S, Msb, K) EalaY rukobatayohi, (S, Msb,) aor.
1a2u3a
and
1a2i3a
, inf. n. juvuw~u and juviY~u, (S, Msb, K,) He sat upon his knees; (K, TA;) for the purpose of contention or disputation, or the like: (TA:) or jvA [and jvY] he kneeled; put himself in a kneeling posture; which is the mode of sitting of him who is contending or disputing: (AZ, Har p. 512:) [or he put down his knees upon the ground and raised his buttocks; i. e. he kneeled with his body and thighs erect, or nearly so: see jaAvK:] and javaA lirukobatihi he fell [upon his knee]; and javawoA lilr~ukabi [they fell upon the knees, and sank backwards so as to rest the body upon the keels or upon the left foot bent sideways beneath; for] juvuw~N is the manner of sitting of the muta$ah~id [in prayer]: (Ham p. 287:) or javaA, (K, TA,) inf. n. javowN and juvuwN, (TA,) he stood upon the extremities of his toes; (K;) like ja*aA; from which AO reckons it to be formed by substitution [of v for *]; but IJ says that they are two dial. vars. (TA.) Aboo-Thumámeh says,
A^uxaASimuhumo mar~aPF qaAy^imFA waA^ajovuw A_i*aA maA javawoA lilr~ukabo
[I contending, or disputing, with them one time standing, and falling upon my knees when they fell upon their knees]. (Ham p. 287.) ＝ -A2- javawotu, (Sgh, K,) inf. n. javowN; (TA;) and javayotu, (Sgh, K,) inf. n. javoYN; (TA;) I collected camels, and sheep or goats. (Sgh, K.)

3 jaAuayotu rukobatiY A_ilaY rukobatihi mjvmh mjvmp
, (K, and so in some copies of the S,) or jaAvayotuhu rukobatiY A_ilaY rukobatihi, (so in other copies of the S,) [I sat, or sat with him, with my knee to his knee, each of us sitting upon his knees, in contending or disputing: see 1]: and jaAvayotuhu alone, (S voce HaADarotuhu,) [signifies the same,] inf. n. mujaAvaApN (K and TA voce muHaAaDrapN) [and jivaA='N: see also 6].

4 AjvAhu AjvAh AjvAp
(S, K) He made him to sit upon his knees: [see 1:] or he made him to stand upon the extremities of his toes. (K.)

6 tajaAvawoA EalaY Alr~ukab tjAvwA Ely Alrkb
[They sat together upon their knees], (S, K,) in contending or disputing; inf. n. mujaAvaApN and jivaA='N, which are [properly inf. ns. of 3, but are] thus used as inf. ns. of a verb to which they do not conform. (TA.) ― -b2- Alt~ajaAviY fiY A_i$aAlapi AlHajari is like Alt~ajaA*i Y [The vying, one with another, in lifting the stone, for trial of strength]. (TA.)

juvFA jvA
, or juvFY, [pl. of juvowapN, q. v. ＝ -A2- Also] A company, or congregated body, of men; (TA;) or so javowapN↓ (Bd in xlv. 27) [or juvowapN↓]: and companies, or congregated bodies, thereof. (TA.) It has the former meaning in a trad., where it is said, yaSiyruwna yawoma AlqiyaAmapi juvFA kul~u A^um~apK tatobaEu nabiy~ahaA [They shall become, on the day of resurrection, a company, or congregated body, each people following its prophet: or here the pl. meaning is more reasonable]: and the latter in the trad., fulaAnN mino juvaY jahan~ama [Such a one is of the companies, or congregated bodies, of Hell, or Hellfire], accord. to one recital: otherwise, mino juviY~i↓ jahan~ama of those that sit upon the knees therein. (TA.) ＝ -A3- AljuvaA is also said to have been A certain idol, to which sacrifices were performed. (TA.)

javowapN jv jvA jvw jvwh jvwp
: see what next follows, in two places: ― -b2- and see juvFA.

juvowapN jv jvA jvw jvwh jvwp
and jivowapN↓ and javowapN↓ Stones collected together: (S, K:) or the stones of earth collected together like the [mound over a] grave: and the first, a hillock: or a heap of earth: (TA:) or collected earth: (Ham p. 399:) or a quantity collected of earth &c.: (Ham p. 381:) and (hence, Ham p. 381) a grave: (TA, Ham pp. 381 and 399:) pl. juvFA, (TA, Ham p. 399,) or juvoY. (Ham ib.) It is said in a trad., raA^ayotu qubuwra Al$~uhadaA='i juvFA I saw the tombs of the martyrs [to be] collections of earth. (TA.) And juvaY AlHarami (pl. of juvowapN, TA) and jivaY AlHarami (pl. of jivowapN↓, TA) signify What are collected, in the sacred territory, of the stones of the jimaAr [or pebbles cast at Minè]: (S:) or this is a mistake; (K;) pointed out by Sgh in the TS: (TA:) the meaning is, what are collected together of the stones that are set [in heaps] at the limits of the sacred territory: or the A^anoSaAb [or stones set up around the Kaabeh] upon which victims were slain in sacrifice. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. ja*owapN [A live coal; or piece of fire; &c.]: (K:) or so javowapN↓ and javowapN↓: (TA:) or jvwpN mino naArK: (Fr, TA:) asserted by Yaakoob to be formed by substitution [of v for *]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And The middle [of a thing]. (IAar, K, TA: but omitted in the CK and in a MS. copy of the K.) ＝ -A4- And The body, with the limbs or members; syn. jasadN: (K:) or so juvowapN: pl. juvFY. (Sh, TA.) ― -b2- And juvowapN, A great, or large, man. (ISh, TA.) ＝ -A5- See also juvFA.

jivowapN jv jvA jvw jvwh jvwp
: see juvowapN, in three places.

javaA='N jvA='
i. q. $axoSN [app. as meaning A person; or the body of a man, like juvowapN and juv~apN]; as also juvaA='N↓. (Sgh, K.) ― -b2- [And hence, perhaps,] Incubus, or nightmare. (TA. [But in this sense it is written in the TA jvA, without ', and without any syll. sign.]) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. jazaA='N [Requital, or compensation]. (K.) ― -b2- And Quantity, measure, size, bulk, or extent; and amount, sum, or number, (K, TA,) as, for instance, of a people, or company of men. (TA.)

juvaA='N jvA='
: see the next preceding paragraph.

jaAvK jAv jAvy
Sitting upon his knees: or standing upon the extremities of his toes: (K:) and [simply] sitting: or [kneeling with his body and thighs erect, or nearly so; i. e.] putting down his knees [upon the ground] and raising his buttocks: (TA:) [see also 1, of which it is the part. n.:] pl. juviYN and jiviY~N; (K;) or these may be pls., like bukY~N and bkYN, pls. of baAk; or inf. ns. used as epithets [as is indicated in the S]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say qawomN juviY~N [A company of men sitting upon their knees]; (S, Msb;) like as you say jalasa juluwsFA and qawomN juluwsN. (S.) And hence, in the Kur [xix. 73], wana*aru AlZ~aAlimiyna fiyhaA juviy~FA, and jiviy~FA also, with kesr to the j because of the kesr of the letter following it, [And we will leave the wrongdoers therein, sitting upon their knees.] (S.) And fulaAnN mino juviY~i jahan~ama: see juvFA. (TA.) And, in the Kur [xlv. 27], wataray kul~a A^um~apK jaAviyapF (TA) And thou shalt see every people sitting upon the knees, (Bd, Jel,) in an upright posture, not at ease: (Bd:) or congregated; (Bd, Jel;) from javowapN signifying “ a company, ” or “ congregated body. ” (Bd.) Whence, (TA,) suwrapu AljaAviyapi The [forty-fifth] chapter, of the Kur-án, next after that called Ald~uxaAn. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [AljaAviY, or AljaAviY EalaY rukobatayohi, (assumed tropical:) The constellation Hercules.]

[
majovFY mjvY mjvy
A place of sitting upon the knees.]

R. Q. 1 jaHojaHa jHjH
He mentioned a jaHojaAH [or chief, &c.] of his people. (TA.) ― -b2- jaHojaHato She gave birth to a jHjAj. (TA.) And jHjHt biwaladihaA She brought forth her child a jHjAH. (A.)

jaHojaHN jHjH
: see the following paragraph. ― -b2- Also A low, an ignoble, a vile, a mean, or a sordid, man; possessing no manly qualities. (AA, T, K.) [Thus it bears two contr. significations.]

jaHojaAHN jHjAH
(S, A, K) and jaHojaHN↓ (K) A chief, lord, master, or man of rank or quality or distinction: (S, A, K:) or one who is liberal, bountiful, or munificent; or one who is noble, or generous: (TA:) and one who hastens [to render aid] in cases of evil: (A:) pl. (of the former, S, A, TA, [or of the latter accord. to analogy,]) jaHaAjiHu (S, A, K) and (of the same, A, TA) jaHaAjiHapN (A, K) and jaHaAjiyHu: (K:) it is said in the S that these two are pls. of the first pl.; the p in the former of them being substituted for the Y in the latter of them, which is rejected; for one of these two letters must be retained, but both cannot be together: this assertion in the S, however, is well refuted by MF. (TA.)

1 jaHada jHd
, aor.
Hada3a
, inf. n. jaHodN and juHuwdN, He denied a thing; disacknowledged it; (L, MF;) in an absolute sense, whether knowing it to be otherwise than as he represented it to be or not. (MF.) [It is used by grammarians, and often by others, as relating to something past, or supposed or asserted to be past; and thus, in a more restricted sense than nafaY.] You say, jaHadahu Haq~ahu, and biHaq~ihi, inf. ns. as above; [and jAHdhu↓; (see 3 in art. kbr, where jAHadahu is used in explaining kaAbarahu; and see what follows;)] He denied, or disacknowledged, his right, or due, knowing it to be such, (S, A, * Msb, K, MF,) and also, not knowing it; (MF;) the doing of which is also termed mukaAbarapN: (TA:) but accord. to some, it is made trans. by means of b only by its being made to imply the meaning of kafara. (MF.) ＝ -A2- Also jaHadahu, He found him to be niggardly, or avaricious: (K:) or he found him to possess little good; i. e., to be either niggardly or poor. (TA.) ＝ -A3- jaHida, (S, K,) aor.
Hadi3a
, (K,) inf. n. jaHodN, (S,) He (a man) was, or became, niggardly, or avaricious; (S;) possessed little good; (S, K;) as also AjHd↓: (S:) or his property became dissipated or dispersed, and passed away; and so ↓the latter verb. (AA, TA.) ― -b2- It (anything, TA) was, or became, little in quantity, or scanty. (K, TA.) ― -b3- It (a person's life, TA) was, or became, strait, and difficult. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- It (a plant) was, or became, scanty; (S;) did not grow tall. (S, K.) ― -b5- jaHidati AlA^aroDu The land became dry, and of no good. (L.) ― -b6- jaHada EaAmunaA [Our year was, or became, one of little rain: see jaHidN]. (A.)

3 HaAoda3a
see 1.

4 A^aHoda3a
see 1, in two places.

jaHodN jHd
and juHodN↓ and jaHadN↓ Paucity, or scantiness, of good; (S, K;) which means both niggardliness and poverty: (A:) straitness of the means of subsistence; as also juHuwdN↓. (TA.) One says, nakadFA lahu wajaHadFA↓ (S) and nukodFA lahu wajuHodFA↓ (L in art. nkd) [May God decree straitness, or difficulty, to him, and poverty]: a form of imprecation. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jaHodN as an epithet, fem. with p: see jaHodN, in three places.

juHodN jHd
: see jaHodN, in four places.

jaHadN jHd
: see jajodN, in four places.

jaHidN jHd
(S, K) and jajodN↓ and A^ajoHadu↓ (K) A man niggardly, or avaricious; (S;) possessing little good. (S, K.) [Hence,] A^aroDN jaHodapN↓ Dry land, in which is no good. (L.) And EaAmN jaHidN, (S,) or jaHodN↓, (A,) A year in which is little rain. (S.) ― -b2- Also jaHidN, A thick and short horse: fem. with p: pl. jiHaAdN. (K.)

juHuwdN jHwd
: see jaHodN.

jaH~aAdN jHAd
(applied to a man, TA) Slow in emitting his seminal fluid; syn. baTYo'u AlA_inozaAli. (K.)

A^ajoHadu *
: see jaHidN.

1 jaHara jHr
, (A, K,) aor.
jaHara
; (K;) and AnjHr↓, (S, Msb, K,) and tjH~r↓, (K,) and AstjHr↓, (A,) said of a [lizard of the kind called] Dab~, (A, Msb, K,) and of a jerboa, and of a serpent, (Msb,) [&c., (see juHorN,)] It entered its burrow, or hole; (S, A, K;) betook itself to it for refuge; or resorted to it. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jaHarato Eayonuhu [and tjH~rt↓ or AnjHrt↓ (see jaHoraA='u)] (tropical:) His eye sank, or became depressed, in his head. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- jaHarati Al$~amosu liloguyuwbi (assumed tropical:) [The sun set, or became near to setting]. (TA.) ― -b4- And jaHarati Al$~amosu (assumed tropical:) The sun rose high, (K,) so that the shade receded and contracted. (TA.) ― -b5- Hajara said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He retreated, or retired; remained behind; or held back. (S, TA.) ― -b6- jaHara Alr~abiyEu (tropical:) The [rain called] rbyE withheld itself: (A:) [or] the [season called] rbyE did not give us rain. (K.) ― -b7- And jaHara Ean~aA Alxayoru (assumed tropical:) Good, or prosperity, kept back from us, (K, * TA,) and did not betide us. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4.

5 tajaH~ara
see 1; each in two places.

7 A_inojaHara
see 1; each in two places.

8 AjtHr linafosihi juHorFA AjtHr lnfsh jHrA
It [a Dab~ &c.] made for itself a burrow, or hole. (S, K.)

10 A_isotajoHara
see 1.

jaHorN jHr
A deep-bottomed cavern. (K.)

juHorN jHr
(S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and juHoraAnN↓ (S, K) The burrow, or hole, (M, K,) of a [lizard of the kind called] Dab~, (A, Mgh, Msb, MF,) and (tropical:) of a jerboa, and (tropical:) of a serpent, (Mgh, Msb, MF, *) and (assumed tropical:) of any venomous reptile or the like, and wild beast, (M, K,) or of any creature that is not of a large size; (TA;) and [the den] of a hyena: (K in art. wjr:) pl. [of mult.] of the former, jiHarapN (S, Msb, K [in the CK jaHarapN]) and [of pauc.] A^ajoHaArN. (S, K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] the former, (A,) or ↓the latter, or both, (IAth, TA,) (tropical:) The vulva of a woman; the pudendum muliebre: and (tropical:) the anus. (IAth, TA.) ― -b3- You say, HaS~iniY juHoraki (tropical:) [Protect thou (O woman) thy pudendum]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., (by 'Áïsheh, A,) A_i*aA HaADati AlmaroA^apu Haruma AljuHoraAnu↓ (S, TA) (tropical:) When a woman has the menstrual discharge, the vulva is forbidden: (TA:) or, (accord. to one reading, TA,) Haruma AljuHoraAn, i. e. both (A) the vulva and the anus (TA) are forbidden; (A, TA;) one having been forbidden before. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence likewise,] the former signifies also (assumed tropical:) A hole, or aperture, (vaEolabN,) whence rainwater flows. (K and TA in art. vElb.)

jaHorapN jHr jHrh jHrp
(S, K) and jaHarapN (K) (assumed tropical:) A severe, hard, or distressful, year; (S, K;) one of drought, dearth, or unfruitfulness, (K,) and of little rain; because it drives the people into the tents, or houses. (TA.)

EayonN jaHoraA='u Eyn jHrA='
i. q. mutajaH~irapN↓ or munojaHirapN↓, (accord. to different copies of the K,) i. e. (tropical:) An eye deep, or depressed, in its socket. (TA.) It occurs in a trad., in a description of Ed-Dejjál; but Az says that [in this instance] it is correctly jaxoraA=', with x. (TA.)

juHoraAnN jHr jHrAn
: see juHorN, in three places.

jaAHirN jAHr
[Entering a burrow, or hole: and also] (assumed tropical:) remaining behind, not having come up to others; (K, TA;) applied to a horse or the like, &c. (TA.)

jawaAHiru jwAHr
[is its pl., signifying] Entering into burrows, or holes, (S, K,) and hiding-places: (S:) entering secretly into [their] habitations: (KL:) and also (assumed tropical:) remaining behind; applied to wild animals &c. (TA.)

majoHarN mjHr
, (K,) pl. majaAHiru, (S, A,) (tropical:) A hidingplace; (S, A, K;) a place of refuge. (K.)

EayonN mutajaH~irapN Eyn mtjHrh Eyn mtjHrp
or munojaHirapN: see jaHoraA='u.

1 jaHa$ahu *
, (Ks, S, Mgh, K, *) aor.
jaHa$a
, (Mgh, K,) inf. n. jaHo$N, (S, K,) It scratched it, or the like, (namely the skin, S, Mgh, K, or a man's side, Ks,) so as to abrade the surface, (Mgh, K,) or so as to abrade the skin; (Ks;) syn. saHajahu, (Ks, K,) and qa$arahu: (Mgh, K:) or i. q. xada$ahu: or it signifies more than this last: (Ks, K:) or less than this last: (Lth, K:) and it (an arrow) made a mark upon it; [or grazed it;] namely, a wall. (Mgh.) You say, A^aSaAbahu $aYo'N fajaHa$a wajohahu [A thing struck him, and abraded the surface of the skin of his face]: and bihi jaHo$N [in him, or it, is an abrasion of the skin]: (S, TA:) or jaHo$N is not in the face, nor [anywhere] in the body [except in the side]. (L, TA.) It is said in a trad., respecting Mohammad, saqaTa mino farasK fajuHi$a $iq~ahu He fell from a horse, and the skin of his side was scratched, or lacerated, or abraded. (Mgh, * TA.) [See also majoHuw$N.]

jaHo$N *
A young ass; (S, Msb, K;) domestic and wild: or before it becomes big: (TA:) or from the time when it is brought forth until it becomes big from sucking: when it has completed the year, it is called tawolabN: (As:) [or the latter is applied to a wild ass of that age:] pl. [of pauc.] A^ajoHaA$N (so in a copy of the S) and [of mult.] jiHaA$N and jiHo$aAnN (S, Msb, K) and juHuw$N (Msb) and jiHa$apN: (As, TA:) [dim. juHayo$N:] and fem. jaHo$apN. (S, K.) It is said in a prov., AljaHo$a lam~aA ba*~aka AlA^aEoyaAru, (A, TA,) i. e., Seek thou, or pursue thou, the young ass when the full-grown asses outstrip thee: applied to him who seeks much, and it escapes him; so one says to him, Seek thou less than that. (TA.) [Meyd gives faAtaka in the place of ba*~aka.] ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A mare's colt; (A, K;) as being likened to a young ass. (TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A gazelle; (Ibn- 'Abbád, K;) in the dial. of Hudheyl: (TA:) or a young gazelle; (A, TA;) in that dial.; occurring in a poem of Aboo-Dhu-eyb; but accord. to one relation, the word there is x$of. (TA.)

jaHiy$N *
The side, (K, TA,) of a man: (TA:) and a lateral, or an adjacent, part, or place, or tract. (Sh, K.) You say, A^uSiyba jaHiy$uhu His side was hit, or hurt. (TA.) And nazala fulaAnN AljaHiy$a Such a one alighted in the adjacent part or tract. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A man who retires to a distance, apart from others: (S:) who alights apart from others, and does not mix with them: (IDrd, K:) who lives alone, with none to incommode him in his house. (AHn.) You say, nazala fulaAnN jaHiy$FA Such a one alighted alone; apart from others. (TA.)

juHayo$N *
[dim. of jaHo$N]. You say, huwa juHayo$u waHodihi (tropical:) He is one who follows his own opinion only, (S, A, K,) who has his gain to himself exclusively, (TA,) and does not consult others, nor mix with them; (K, TA;) as also Euyayoru waHodihi; [q. v.;] meaning dispraise; (S, A, TA;) the man being thereby likened to a [little] young ass. (TA.)

bayotN jaAHi$N *
[A tent] apart from the tribe. (TA.)

majoHuw$N *
One whose side (jaHiy$uhu, TA) is hit, or hurt. (K, TA.)

1 jaHaZato Eayonuhu jHZt Eynh jHZt Eynp
, aor.
jaHaZa
, (S, K,) inf. n. juHuwZN (T, S, TA) and jiHaAZN, (M, TA,) His eyeball, the globe of his eye, was prominent (T, M, K, TA) and apparent: (TA:) or was large (S, K, TA) and prominent; (S, TA;) as though a large pearl came forth from the eyelids. (Jm, TA.) ＝ -A2- jaHaZa A_ilayohi Eamalahu (tropical:) He looked into, or examined, his deed, and saw the evil that he had done: (K:) and it may mean he looked into his face, and reminded him of the evil of his deed. (Az, TA.) The Arabs also say, laA^ajoHaZan~a A_ilayoka A^avara yadika, meaning (assumed tropical:) I will assuredly show thee the evil of the effect of thy hand. (Az, TA)

2 jH~Z jHZ
, inf. n. tajoHiyZN, He looked sharply, or intently. (K.)

jaHZtAni jHZtAn
: see `jaAHiZataAni.

jiHaAZN jHAZ
: see jaAHiZN.

jiHaAZN jHAZ
The part [which is next below, or around, the eye, and] which is called the maHojir of the eye. (IDrd, Az, L, K.) ― -b2- And, (Az, K,) in one copy [of the work of IDrd, i. e. the Jm,] (Az,) The edge of the gland of the penis. (Az, K.) ― -b3- jiHaAZAni: see jaAHiZataAni.

jiHaAZataAni jHAZtAn
: see jaAHiZataAni.

jaAHiZN jAHZ
A man having the eyeball, or globe of the eye, prominent and apparent; (TA;) or large and prominent; (S, TA;) as also jaHoZamN↓, in which the m is augmentative. (S, TA.) And jaAHZu AlEayonayoni A man whose blacks of his eyes are prominent. (TA.) You say also, fulaAnN jaAHiZN A_ilaY~a biEayonihi, and mujaH~iZN↓, meaning Such a one is looking at me intently. (T, TA in art. znr.) And juH~aZN and juHuZN, [which are pls. of jaAHiZN,] applied to men, signify Raising the eyes, and looking fixedly; or stretching and raising the sight; or opening the eyes and not moving the eyelids. (L, TA.)

jaAHiZataAni jAHZtAn
, (so in copies of the S, and in the L,) or jiHaAZataAni↓, (so in a copy of the S, and so accord. to a copy of the KL, in which the sing. is written jiHaAZapN, though Golius, on the authority of that work, writes it jaHaAZapN,) or jaHaAZaAni↓, accord. to Lth, (TA,) or jaHZtAni↓, (as written in one copy of the S,) The two blacks
of the eye [or rather of the two eyes]. (Lth, S, L, TA.)

mujaH~iZN mjHZ
: see jaAHiZN.

1 jaHafahu jHf jHfh jHfp
, aor.
jaHafa
, (K,) inf. n. jaHofN, (TA,) He, or it, stripped off, scraped off, or otherwise removed, its superficial part; (K;) [and so AjtHfhu↓; for you say,] AjtHf Als~ayolu AlwaAdiy The torrent stripped off [or swept away] the superficial parts of the valley. (TA.) ― -b2- He, or it, took away, carried away, or removed, the whole of it, or the greater part of it, or much of it; or swept it away: (K, TA:) or, as some say, vehemently. (TA.) And mujaAHafapN [an inf. n. of jAHf↓] signifies The taking a thing, taking it away, removing it, or sweeping it away. (TA.) ― -b3- He, or it, destroyed, and extirpated, him, or it; as also AjtHfhu↓ and bh AjHf↓. (Mgh.) ― -b4- It (a bucket) took it and bore it away; namely, water. (S, K.) ― -b5- He collected it, lanafosh for himself. (K.) ― -b6- He laded it out with his hand or with a ladle, namely, food, (IAar, K,) and beverage, (TA,) lahu for him. (IAar, K.) ― -b7- He threw it (a thing, IDrd) by kicking it with his foot. (IDrd, K.) ― -b8- jaHafa Alkurapa (K) and AjtHfhA↓ (TA) He snatched away the ball (K, TA) from the ground. (TA in explanation of the former. See also jaHofapN.) ― -b9- [The inf. n.] jaHofN also signifies The act of eating (AA, S, TA) what is called variyd, (S, * TA,) or butter with dates, or with dried dates. (AA, S.) ― -b10- And The act of striking, or smiting, with the sword. (AA, S, TA.) ― -b11- And The act of ejecting, or expelling. (KL.) ― -b12- And The doing damage, or an injury. (KL. [See also 4.]) ― -b13- And jaHafa maEahu He inclined with him, (K, TA,) EalaY gayorihi against another: and in like manner, jaHafa lahu [he inclined to him]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jaHifa He (a man) was affected with the flux of the belly termed juHaAf. (TA.)

3 jAHf jAHf
, inf. n. mujaAHafapN: see 1. ― -b2- jAHfhu, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) also signifies He pushed, or pressed, against, or upon, him, or it; (S, K, TA;) and so jAHf bihi: (TA:) and clave to him, or it: (Ham p. 62:) and jiHaAfN [which is also an inf. n. of the same verb] signifies the pushing, or pressing, one against another, or one upon another, in war: and the striving, struggling, contending, or conflicting, in an affair. (AA, TA.) Hence the saying of El-Ahnaf, A_in~amaA A^anaA bayona tamiymK kaEulobapi Alr~aAEiY yujaAHifuwna bihaA yawoma Alwirodi, i. e. [I am, among Temeem, only like the milkingvessel of the pastor,] upon which they press, or crowd, together [on the day of coming to water]. (TA.) ― -b3- He was, or became, near to him, or it. (S, IF, K.) So in the phrase jAHf Al*~anoba [He was, or became, near to committing the crime, or sin, or act of disobedience]. (IF, TA.) [See also 4.] ― -b4- jAHf Eanohu He repelled from him. (TA.) ― -b5- [The inf. n.] jiHaAfN also signifies The act of fighting, or combating: (K:) and slaying. (TA.) ― -b6- And A bucket's striking against the mouth of the well, so that its water pours out, and sometimes it becomes rent. (S, K.)

4 AjHf bihi AjHf bh AjHf bp
, (inf. n. A_ijoHaAfN, Msb,) He, or it, took away, carried away, or removed, him, or it; (S, Msb, K;) said, in this sense, of a torrent: (Msb:) and extirpated him, or it; (S, Mgh, Msb;) said of a torrent, (S, Msb,) and of time, or fortune, and of a calamity. (TA.) See also 1. ― -b2- He, or it, did damage, or an injury, to him. (KL, * MA.) [See also 1.] It is said by one of the sages, mano A=vara Ald~unoyaA A^ajoHafa biA=xiratihi [He who prefers the enjoyments of the present life mars his enjoyments of the life to come]. (TA.) And you say, A^ajoHafato bihi AlfaAqahu Want reduced him to poverty, (K, TA,) and caused his property to pass away. (TA.) And A^ajoHafati Als~anapu The year was, or became, one of drought, and dearth, or sterility. (Msb.) [Accord. to Fei,] A_ijoHaAfN is met. used as meaning (tropical:) The making to suffer excessive loss or detriment. (Msb.) [It is also used as a simple subst., meaning Damage, harm, or injury: pl. A_ijoHaAfaAtN.] ― -b3- He imposed upon him, or tasked him with, (namely, his slave, Msb,) that which he was unable to do. (Msb, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence, perhaps, (assumed tropical:) He strained it, or wrested it; namely, a word, or an expression.] ― -b5- He approached him, or it; was, or became, near to him, or it. (S, K.) [See also 3.] ― -b6- He approached it, or drew near to it, (namely, a road,) but did not enter it. (TA.) And AjHf bihimo, said of an enemy, and of a torrent, or rain, He, or it, approached them, or drew near to them, but missed them. (TA.) ― -b7- He was near to falling short of accomplishing it, namely, an affair, or of doing what was requisite therein; or was near to being remiss therein. (TA.)

6 tjAHfwA jAHf tjAHfwA
They reached, or hit, one another with staves, (K, TA,) in the O, with bows, (TA,) and swords, (K, TA,) in fighting. (TA.) Hence the phrase, in a trad., A_i*aA tajaAHafato quray$N Almuloka bayonahumo, i. e., When Kureysh shall contend together in fight for dominion. (TA.) ― -b2- tjAHfwA Alkurapa bayonahumo They contended together in snatching away the ball (taxaATafuwhaA) with the goff-sticks, (K, * TA,) after rolling it along. (TA.)

8 AjtHfhu AjtHfh AjtHfp
: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- Also He seized it, took it, or carried it off, by force. (K, TA.) ― -b3- He took it up, namely, the food called varyd, with the three fingers. (Sgh, K.) ― -b4- He exhausted it, namely, the water of a well, (K, TA,) with the hand or with a vessel. (TA.)

jaHofN jHf
: see the next paragraph.

jaHofapN jHf jHfh jHfp
A portion of clarified butter. (Sgh, K.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph. ＝ -A2- An affection resembling magaS [or pain and griping] in the belly, (K, TA,) arising from indigestion. (TA.) [See also jaHaAfN.] ＝ -A3- The playing with the ball; as also jaHofN↓ [inf. n. of jaHafa, q. v.]. (K.)

juHofapN jHf jHfh jHfp
A portion of water remaining in the sides of a watering-trough or tank; as also jaHofapN↓. (Kr, K.) ― -b2- The water that is exhausted from a well: or, that remains in the well after the exhausting [of the rest]. (K.) ― -b3- A small quantity of the food called variyd, in a vessel, not filling it. (K.) ― -b4- The quantity that is laded out at once, of food: or a handful: (IAar, K:) pl. juHafN. (TA.) ― -b5- A portion of scattered herbage in the qawoz (a mistake for qaron, meaning the most elevated part, TA) of a desert, (K, TA,) resembling waters on all its sides, such as that the seeker of water knows not which of the waters is the nearest to the extremity thereof. (TA.)

juHaAfN jHAf
That carries away everything; applied to a torrent; (S, K;) as also jaAHifN↓; (TA;) and to death. (S, K.) ― -b2- Death [itself]. (S, K.) ― -b3- A flux of the belly, arising from indigestion: (S, K:) or a pain that attacks in consequence of eating flesh-meat without bread. (TA.) [See also jaHofapN.]

jaHuwfN jHwf
A bucket (dalowN) that takes and bears away water. (S, K.) ― -b2- Food of the kind called variyd remaining in the middle of a bowl. (IAar, K.)

jaAHifN jAHf
: see juHaAfN

mar~a Al$~aYo'u muDir~FA wamujoHifFA *
The thing passed by approaching, or coming near. (S.) ― -b2- sanapN mujoHifapN A year that renders the cattle lean: or a year that destroys people, or impoverishes them, or injures them, (tujoHifu bihimo,) by slaughter, or by marring, or destroying, the cattle. (TA.) ― -b3- And mujoHifapN, alone, A calamity; (K;) because it extirminates people. (TA.)

majoHuwfN mjHwf
A man affected with the flux of the belly termed juHaAfN. (S, K.)

Q. 1 jaHofalahu jHfl jHflh jHflp
, (S, K,) inf. n. jaHofalapN, (TA,) He prostrated him on the ground; threw him down: (S, K:) and sometimes they said, jaEofalahu. (S.) ＝ -A2- He reproved, chid, or reproached, him for his deed; or did so severely. (Sgh, K.)

Q.2 tajaHofaluwA tjHfl tjHflwA
They congregated; collected themselves together. (S, K.)

jaHofalN jHfl
An army: (S:) or a numerous army. (K.) MF holds it to be formed, with an augmentative l, from AljaHofu, meaning “ the taking, ” or “ carrying, ” a thing “ away. ” (TA.) ＝ -A2- A great man: (K:) or a man of great estimation or dignity. (S.) ― -b2- A generous, noble, or high-born, chief or lord. (K.) ― -b3- Great in the sides. (IAar, K.)

jaHofalapN jHfl jHflh jHflp
The lip (S, K) of a solid-hoofed animal, (Sudot;,) [i. e.,] of a horse, a mule, and an ass: (K:) and metaphorically applied to that of a man, which is properly termed $afapN: (TA:) not, as some assert, peculiarly the upper lip: (MF:) pl. jaHaAfilu. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) jaHofalataAni, (TA,) Two callosities (raqomataAni) in the two arms of the horse, (K,) resembling two marks made with a hot iron, facing each other, in the inner side of each arm. (TA.)

jaHanofalN jHnfl
(with an augmentative n S) Thicklipped. (S, K.)

1 jHumati Aln~aAru jHmt AlnAr
, aor.
jaHufa
, inf. n. juHuwmN; and jaHimat, aor.
jaHafa
, inf. n. jaHomN and jaHamN [accord. to the CK juHomN] and juHuwmN; The fire burned, burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed; (K, TA;) and had many live coals, and much flame: (TA in explanation of the latter verb; and so the former or the latter is explained in a copy of the S, in which it is imperfectly written:) or the former signifies it became great: (TA:) and AjHmt↓ it became vehement; said of fire, and also of war. (Ham p. 810.) ＝ -A2- jaHama, aor.
jaHafa
, He kindled fire; made it to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame. (K.)

4 AjHm Eanohu AjHm Enh AjHm Enp
, (S, K,) inf.n. A^ijoHaAmN, (TA,) He refrained, forbore, abstained, or desisted, from it; (S, K;) namely, a thing; like AHjm: (S:) but the former is a rare dial. var. (Har p. 95.) Both these verbs bear contr. significations; being used as meaning He advanced, or went forward: and also he receded, or drew back. (MF.) ＝ -A2- AjHm fulaAnFA He, or it, was near to destroying, or killing, such a one. (K.) ＝ -A3- See also 1.

5 tjHum tjHm
He burned with vehemence of desire, or covetousnsss, and niggardliness; (K;) as also tjAHm↓: from jaAHimu AlHarobi. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, also, (TA,) i. q. taDaAyaqa [app. meaning He became straitened in disposition]. (K.) You say also, EalayonaA huwa yatajaAHamu↓, i. e., yataDaAyaqu [app., He becomes straitened in disposition against us]: a phrase mentioned by El-Mundhiree on the authority of Aboo-Tálib. (TA.)

6 tajaAoHafa
see 5, in two places.

jaHomapN jHmh jHmp
The burning, burning brightly or fiercely, blazing, or flaming, of fire; (Ham p. 77;) as also jaAHimN↓: (TA:) or vehemence of burning or blazing or flaming: (Bd in xxxvii. 95:) or it is an epithet applied to fire because of its redness [or as meaning red]. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b2- See also jaHiymN.

juHomapN jHmh jHmp
: see jaHiymN.

jaHiymN jHym
A fire burning, or blazing, or flaming, vehemently; (K;) as also jaAHimN↓: (Ham p. 810:) and any fire having one part above another; as also jaHomapN↓ and juHomapN↓; (K;) of which last the pl. is juHamN: (TA:) or having many live coals, and flaming much: (so in a copy of the S:) and any great fire in a pit or the like; (S, K;) from the saying in the Kur [xxxvii. 95], qaAluwA A@bonuwA lahu bunoyaAnFA faA^aloquwhu fiY AljaHiymi [They said, Build ye for him a building, and cast him into the great fire therein]. (S.) And AljaHiymu is one of the names of The fire [of Hell]; (S, TA;) from which may God preserve us. (TA.) See also jaAHimN.

jaH~aAmN jHAm
Niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious: (K:) from jaAHimu AlHarobi, meaning “ the straitness, and vehemence, of war.” (TA.)

jaAHimN jAHm
: see jaHiymN. Also Live coals (jamorN) vehemently burning or blazing or flaming. (K.) And a place vehemently hot; (S, K;) as also jaHiymN↓. (K.) El-Aashà says, Almawotu jaAHimN [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) Death is like a burning, or fiercelyburning, fire]. (S.) See also jaHomapN. ― -b2- jaAHimu Aljarobi The main part [or the thick] of the war or battle: (K:) or the straitness thereof: (TA:) and the vehemence of the fight or slaughter, in the scene thereof. (K.) You say, AiSoTalaY bijaAHimi AlHarobi (tropical:) [He warmed himself with the heat, or vehemence, of the battle]. (TA.) ― -b3- AljaAHimapu Fire: (TA:) or, [as an epithet,] fire burning, burning brightly or fiercely, blazing, or flaming. (Ham p. 77.)

1 jad~ahu jd jdh jdp
, aor.
jadu3a
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. jad~N, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He cut it, or cut it off. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) This is the primary signification. (Mgh.) You say of a weaver, jad~a vawobFA He cut off a piece of cloth [sufficient for a garment or the like, from the web]. (S, K.) And jad~a Aln~axola, (S, Mgh, L,) aor,
jadu3a
, (S, L,) inf. n. jad~N (S, L, K) and jadaAdN (Lh, Mgh, L) and jidaAdN; (Lh, L; [in the L, the last two forms are mentioned as inf. ns., and the former of them is mentioned as inf. n. in the Mgh; but in the K, they are only mentioned as syn. with jad~N; and in the S, it seems to be implied that they are simple substs., or quasiinf. ns.;]) i. q. Saramahu; (Lh, S, Mgh, K; *) [like ja*~ahu and jaz~ahu;] i.e., He cut off the fruit of the palm-trees. (Mgh, L. [See also jadaAdN.]) And jud~ato A^axolaAfu Aln~aAqapi The she-camel's teats were cut off by some accident that befell her: (As, TA:) or, in consequence of injury occasioned to her by the SiraAr [q. v.]. (S.) And tajodiydN [inf. n. of jd~d↓] signifies The cutting off the teat of a camel. (KL.) You say also, jud~a vadoyaA A^um~ika May thy mother's breasts be cut off: a form of imprecation against a man; and implying a wish for his separation. (As, L, from a trad.) ― -b2- See also 5. ＝ -A2- jad~a, aor.
jadi3a
, inf. n. jid~apN, It (a garment, TA, or a thing, S, Msb, TA) was new; (S, L, Msb, K;) [as though newly cut off from the web;] from jad~a as signifying “ he cut, ” or “ cut off. ” (L.) [See also 5.] ＝ -A3- jad~a, like taEiba, (Msb,) see. pers. jadidNta, [like its syn. HaZiZota,] (L, Msb,) aor. yajad~u; (Msb;) or jud~a, with damm, (Mgh,) see. pers. judidota, (S,) [aor. yujad~u;] inf. n. jad~N; (S, * Mgh, L, Msb;) He was, or became, fortunate, or possessed of good fortune, (S, Mgh, L, Msb,) or of good worldly fortune; (TA;) he advanced in the world, or in worldly circumstances; (Mgh;) biAlA^amori by the affair, or event, whether good or evil; (L;) or biAl$~aYo'i by the thing. (Msb.) And humo yujad~uwna bihimo, as also yuHaZ~uwna bhm, They become possessed of good fortune, and riches, or competence, or sufficiency. (Ibn-Buzurj, L.) [You say also, jad~a jad~uhu (tropical:): so in a copy of the A: probably a mistranscription for jad~a jid~uhu, which see below: if not, meaning His fortune became good; or his good fortune increased in goodness: or, perhaps, his dignity became great; from what next follows]. ＝ -A4- jad~ fiY EayoniY, (S, A,) or fiY Euyuwni Aln~aAsi, and Suduwrihimo, (Mgh,) aor.
jadi3a
, inf. n. jad~N, (S,) He was, or became, great, or of great dignity or estimation, in my eye, or in the eyes of men, and their minds. (S, A, Mgh.) It is said in a trad. of Anas, kaAna Alr~ajulu min~aA A_i*aA qaraA^a Albaqarapa waA=la EimoraAna jad~a fiynaA, i. e., [A man of us, when he recited the chapter of the Cow and that of the Family of 'Imrán (the second and third chapters of the Kur-án),] used to be great in our eyes. (S.) ＝ -A5- jad~a fiY AlA^amori, (S, A, K,) or fiY A^amorihi, (L,) or fiY kalaAmihi, (Msb,) aor.
jadi3a
(S, L, Msb, K) and
jadu3a
, (L, K,) inf. n. jid~N, (S, K,) or jad~N, (L, Msb,) jid~N being a simple subst.; (Msb;) and fiyhi Ajd~↓; (L, K;) He was serious, or in earnest, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) in the affair, (S, A, K,) or in his affair, (L,) or in his speech; (Msb;) syn. Haq~aqa; (L;) contr. of hazala. (L, Msb. [In the S and A and K, the inf. n. is said to signify the contr. of hazolN; and in the K, it is also said to be syn. with taHoqiyqN.]) ― -b2- And jad~a fiY AlA^amori, (As, S, L, Msb, K,) aor.
jadi3a
and
jadu3a
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. jid~N, (S, * K, * TA,) or this is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is jad~N; (Msb;) and fyh Ajd~↓; (As, S, L, K;) signify also He strove, laboured, or toiled; exerted himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability; employed himself vigorously, strenuously, laboriously, diligently, studiously, sedulously, earnestly, or with energy; was diligent, or studious; took pains, or extraordinary pains; in the affair. (As, S, L, Msb, K.) And jad~afiY Als~ayori He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, in going, or journeying, or in his course, or pace; (tropical:) he hastened therein: and in like manner, Als~ayora Ajd~↓ (assumed tropical:) he hastened his course, or pace. (L.) And jad~a jid~uhu, [meaning His labour, or exertion, or energy, was, or became, great, or extraordinary: or] meaning AizodaAda jid~uhu jid~FA [his labour, &c., increased in labour, &c.]: or it may mean what was not [his] jid~, became jid~; wherefore, i. e. because it would be so eventually, it is here so called. (Ham p. 33. [See also jad~a jad~uhu, above.] ― -b3- jad~a bihi AlA^amoru (A, L) (tropical:) The affair, or event, distressed, or afflicted, him. (L.) So in the saying of Aboo-Sahm,
A^axaAlidu laA yaroDaY Eani AlEabodi rab~uhu
A_i*aA jad~a biAl$~ayoxi AlEuquwqu AlmuSam~imu
[O Khálid, his Lord will not approve of the servant, or man, (meaning the son,) when cutting, or biting, disobedience to a parent distresses the old man]. (L.) ＝ -A6- jad~a, aor,
jadi3a
inf. n. jad~N and jid~N, It (a house, or tent, bayot) dripped, or let fall drops. (K.)

2 jd~d jdd jdyd
, inf. n. tajodiydN: see 1. ＝ -A2- See also 4, in three places. ＝ -A3- tjdyd also signifies The making [or weaving] stripes of different colours in a garment. (KL.)

3 jAd~hu fiY AlA^amori *
, (S, L, K, *) inf. n. mujaAd~apN, (L,) i. q. HaAq~ahN (S, L) or HaAqaqahu (K) [He contended with him respecting a thing, each of them asserting his right therein: so accord. to explanations of HAq~hu in the lexicons: but I think that the meaning intended here is, he acted seriously, or in earnest, with him in the affair; and this is confirmed by its being immediately added in the TA, after HAqqh, “ and A^ajad~a ” signifies “ Haq~aqa, as above mentioned: ” see jad~afiY AlA^amori expl. by Haq~aqa as contr. of hazala]. Also He exerted his full effort, or endeavour, or energy, with him in the affair. (So accord. to an explanation of the inf. n., mjAdap, in the KL.)

4 Ajd~ Aln~axolu Ajd Alnxl
The palm-trees attained to the time for the cutting off of the fruit. (S, A, * L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] A^ajad~ato qaruniY minohu I (myself, TA) relinquished, or forsook, him, or it. (K.) ＝ -A2- Ajd~hu, and Astjd~hu↓, (S, A, L, K,) and jd~dhu↓, (S, L, K,) He made it new; (S, A, L, K;) namely, a thing, (S,) or a garment: (A, TA:) or he put it on, or wore it, new; namely, a garment. (TA.) One says to him who puts on a new garment, A^aboli waA^ajid~a waA@Homadi AlkaAsiY [Wear out, and make, or put on, new, and praise the Clother, meaning God]. (S.) And you say, bahiYa bayotu fulaAnK faA^ajad~a bayotFA mino $aEarK [The tent of such a one was, or became, rent, or pierced with holes; therefore he made a new tent of haircloth]. (S.) And AlA^amora jd~d↓, and Ajd~hu, and Astjd~hu↓, He originated, or innovated, the thing, or affair; or did it newly, or for the first time (Msb.) And AlwuDuwo'a jd~d↓ (tropical:) [He renewed the ablution termed wDw'], and AlEahoda (tropical:) [the compact, or contract, or covenant, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Ajd~ fulaAnN A^amorahu bi*`lika Such a one established, or settled, firmly his affair, or case, thereby, or therein: so says As, and he cites the following verse:
A^ajad~a bihaA A^amorFA waA^ayoqana A^an~ahu
lahaA A^awoxoray kaAlT~aHiyna turaAbuhaA
[He established, or settled, firmly his case thereby, or therein, and knew certainly that he was for it, (app. meaning a war, or battle, Harob, which is fem.,) or for another whereof the dust would be like flour]: Aboo-Nasr says, It has been related to me that he said, Ajda bhA AmrFA means Ajd~ A^amorahu bihaA; [and so this phrase is explained in the K;] but the former explanation I heard from himself: (L:) or this phrase means A^ajad~a A^amoruhu bihaA [so in two copies of the S, app., (assumed tropical:) his affair, or case, became easy, or practicable, thereby, like ground termed jadad, which is easy to walk, or travel, upon; see the next sentence]; Amr being put in the accus. case as a specificative, like EayonFA in the phrase qarirotu bihi EayonFA, meaning qar~ato bihi EayoniY. (S.) ＝ -A3- Ajd~ also signifies It (a road) was, or became, what is termed jadad [i. e. hard, or level, &c.]. (S, K.) And Ajd~t laka AlA^aroDu The ground hath become to thee free from soft places, and clear to thy view. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He walked along, or traversed, what is termed jadad. (K.) And Ajd~ Alqawomu The people, or company of men, came to what is so termed: (S:) and ascended upon the surface (jadiyd) of the ground: or went upon sand such as is termed jadad. (TA.) ＝ -A4- See also 1, in three places.

5 tjd~d A^jd jd jdd tjdd
[originally It became cut, or cut off. ― -b2- And hence,] It (an udder) lost, or became devoid of, its milk: (S, K:) and [in like manner] jud~a↓, aor. yujad~u, inf. n. jadadN, it, (a breast, and an udder,) became dry. (A Heyth, TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, [It was newly made; as though newly cut off from the web;] said of a garment: (TA:) and it (a thing, S, A) became new: (S, A, K:) and it (a thing, or an affair,) originated; was originated, or innovated; or was done newly, or for the first time: and sometimes Astjd~↓ is used intransitively [in the same senses]. (Msb.) [Also (assumed tropical:) It (an action, as, for instance, ablution, and a compact, or the like,) was renewed. See jad~ada as syn. with A^ajad~a.]

10 A_isotajoda3a
see 4, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also 5.

jad~N jd
Fortune, or particularly good fortune, syn. HaZ~N, (S, A, Mgh, L, K,) and baxotN, (S, A, L, K,) in the world, or in wordly circumstances; (TA;) advance in the world, or in worldly circumstances: (Mgh:) pl. [of mult.] juduwdN (S) and [of pauc.] A^ajodaAdN and A^ajud~N. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN *uw jad~K fiY ka*aA Such a one is possessed of good fortune in such a thing. (L.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the day of resurrection, waA_i*aA A^aSoHaAbu Aljad~i maHobuwsuwna And lo, the people who were possessed of good fortune and riches in the world were imprisoned. (L.) And in a prayer, (L,) laA yanofaEu *aA Aljad~i minoka Aljad~u The good worldly fortune of him who is possessed of such fortune will not profit him, (Mgh, L,) in the world to come, (L,) in lieu of Thee; (Mgh, L; *) i. e., of obedience to Thee: (Mgh, and Mughnee in art. mino:) or in lieu of the good fortune that cometh from Thee: or, as some say, will not defend him from Thee. (Mughnee ubi suprà. [See also another explanation below.]) Hence, A^ajad~aka laA tafoEalo [or A^ajad~ika]; and, accord. to some, wajad~ika: see jid~N. ― -b2- One's lot in life; and the means of subsistence that one receives from the bounty of God. (L, K.) One says, lifulaAnK fiY h`*aA AlA^amori jad~N Such a one has in this thing, or state of affairs, means of subsistence. (A'Obeyd, L.) ― -b3- Richness; competence, or sufficiency; or the state of being in no need, or of having no wants, or of having few wants. (S, L, Msb.) lA ynfE *A Aljd~ mnk Aljd~, [explained above, is said to mean] Riches, &c., will not profit the possessor thereof with Thee; for nothing will profit him but acting in obedience to Thee: mnk here signifies Einodaka. (S, Msb.) ― -b4- Greatness, or majesty; (Mujáhid, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) accord. to some, specially of God: (TA:) so in the Kur lxxii. 3: (S, TA:) or his freedom from all wants or the like; syn. ginFY. (S.) Hence, taEaAlaY jad~uka, (Mgh, TA,) in a trad. respecting prayer, (TA,) Exalted be thy greatness, or majesty. (Mgh, * TA.) ― -b5- See also A^ajad~aka, as an interrogative phrase, voce jid~N. ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) and majoduwdN↓, (S, A, Mgh, K,) and jadiydN↓, (S, Msb, K,) and jad~iy~N↓, (S,) and jud~N↓, and jud~iy~N↓, the last two with damm, (K,) applied to a man, Fortunate; or possessed of good fortune; (S, A, Mgh, Msb;) or possessed of good worldly fortune: (TA:) or possessing great fortune, or great good fortune: (K:) [the words here given from the S are there coupled with synonyms of the same form, thus; jadiydN↓ HaZiyZN, and maHoZuwZN majoduwdq↓, and jad~N HaZ~u, and HaZ~iY~N jad~iy~N↓; on the authority of ISk:] jud~N↓, with damm, as an epithet applied to a man, is said by Sb to be syn. with majoduwdN; and its pl. is jud~Nwna only. (L.) ＝ -A3- Also jad~u, A grandfather; the father's father, and the mother's father: (S, Msb, K:) and (assumed tropical:) a higher ascendant; an ancestor: (Msb:) and jad~apN↓ a grandmother; the father's mother, and the mother's mother: (K:) [and (assumed tropical:) a female ancestor:] pl. of the former, A^ajodaAdN [a pl. of pauc.] and juduwdN and juduwdapN: (K:) and of the latter, jad~aAtN. (TA.) Hence, accord. to some, wajad~ika laA tafoEalo: see jid~N. ＝ -A4- See also jud~apN: ― -b2- and see jadiydN.

jud~N jd
: see jad~N, in two places. ＝ -A2- See also jud~apN. ― -b2- Also The side (jaAnib) of anything. (K.) ＝ -A3- And A well in a place where is much herbage, or pasture: (S, Msb, K:) a well abounding with water; (K;) [and] so judojudN↓; (KL;) but A'Obeyd says that this is not known: (L:) and, contr., a well containing little water: a scanty water, or water little in quantity: a water at the extremity of a [desert such as is called] falaAp: (K:) an old water: (Th, K:) an old well: (KL:) pl. (in all these senses, TA) A^ajodaAdN. (Msb, TA.)

jid~N jd
[accord. to some an inf. n., but accord. to others a simple subst., (see jad~a,)] Seriousness, or earnestness, contr. of hazolN, (S, A, Msb, K,) in speech. (Msb.) Hence, valaAvN jid~uhun~a jid~N wahazoluhun~a jid~N [There are three things in relation to which what is serious is serious and what is jesting is serious]: a saying of Mohammad, whereby he forbade a man's divorcing and emancipating and marrying and then retracting, saying “ I was jesting; ” as was customary in the time of paganism. (Msb.) A^ajid~aka and A^ajad~aka↓ signify the same; (S;) but the former is the more chaste; (TA;) jid~ and jad~ being thus used only as prefixed nouns: (S, K:) As says that the meaning is, A^abijid~K minoka h`*aA [Does this proceed from thee in seriousness, or in earnest?]; and that jid~ is put in the accus. case because of the rejection of the [prep.] b: AA says that the meaning is, maA laka A^ajid~FA minoka [What aileth thee? Doth it proceed from thee in seriousness, or in earnest?]; and that jd~ is put in the accus. case as an inf. n.: Th says that the phrase as it occurs in poetry is A^ajid~aka, with kesr: (S:) but when it occurs with wa [in the place of A^a, or with A^a in the sense of wa, as a particle denoting an oath,] it is
wajad~ika↓ [or A^ajad~ika], with fet-h: (S, K:) yon say, wajad~ika laA tafoEalo, (K, in the CK wajad~aka,) meaning, By thy grandfather, do not [such a thing]: or by thy fortune, or good fortune, do not: (TA:) also, when you say, A^ajid~aka laA tafoEalo, [or A^ajid~ika, for A^a (q. v.) is substituted for a particle of swearing, as in A^all~`hi laA^afoEalan~a,] the meaning is, I adjure thee by thy truth, (Lth, K,) and by thy seriousness, or earnestness, (Lth, TA,) do not: and when you say, laA tafoEalo A^ajad~aka↓, [or A^ajad~ika,] the meaning is, I adjure thee by thy fortune, or good fortune, do not: (Lth, K:) Aboo- 'Alee Esh-Shalowbeenee asserts that it implies the signification of an oath. (MF.) In the phrase Ajd~k lA tafoEalu, AAF says, we may consider lA tfEl as put in the place of a denotative of state; or the phrase may be originally Ajd~k A^ano laA tafoEala, An being suppressed, and its government annulled: [therefore it may be rendered, in the former case, Is it with seriousness on thy part, thou doing such a thing? and in the latter case, Is it with seriousness on thy part that thou will not do such a thing? i. e. dost thou mean seriously that thou will not do it? or in this case, Ajd~k may be used as a form of adjuration in one of the senses explained above, and laA tafoEalu may mean, that thou do not such a thing; or Ajd~k may mean wajad~aka, (explained above, and so in the three exs. below,) and laA tafoEalu, thou wilt not do it:] and, as AHei says, there is here a nice point, which is this; that the noun [meaning the pronoun] to which jd~ is prefixed should agree in person with the verb which follows it; so that one should say, Ajd~iY laA A^ukorimuka, and Ajd~ka laA tafoEalu, and Ajd~hu laA yazuwrunaA; because jd~ is an inf. n. corroborating the proposition that follows it. (MF.) ― -b2- Also, [and in this case, likewise, accord. to some an inf. n., but accord. to others a simple subst., (see, again, jad~a,)] A striving, labour, or toil; exertion of one's self, or of one's power or efforts or endeavours or ability; vigorousness, strenuousness, laboriousness, diligence, studiousness, sedulousness, earnestness, or energy; painstaking, or extraordinary painstaking; (S, L, Msb, K;) in affairs, (S,) or in an affair. (Msb, K.) Hence, jid~FA [meaning In a great, or an extraordinary, degree; greatly, much, exceedingly, or extraordinarily; very; very greatly, or very much; extremely]; as in the phrase, (Msb,) fulaAnN muHosinN jid~FA [Such a one is beneficent in a great, or an extraordinary, degree; very, exceedingly, or extremely, beneficent]: you should not say jad~FA. (S, Msb. * [In my copy of the Msb, it is mHsn jd~A bAlftH: but the context shows that there is an omission here, and that, after jd~A, we should read, as in the S, walaA taqulo jad~FA.]) jid~FA [in a phrase of this kind] is put in the accus. case as an inf. n. [of which the verb is understood; so that, in the ex. given above, the proper meaning is, yajid~u fiY AlA_iHosaAni jid~FA striving in beneficence with a great striving]; because it is not from the same root as the preceding word, nor is it identical with it [in meaning]. (L.) You say also, fiY h`*aA xaTarN jid~a EaZiymK, meaning EaZiymN jid~FA [(assumed tropical:) In this is a very, or an extremely, great danger, or risk]. (S.) And h`*A AlEaAlimu jid~a AlEaAlimi This is the learned man, the extremely [or the very] learned man. (L.) And h`*aA EaAlimN jid~a EaAlimK This is a learned man, an extremely [or a very] learned man. (L, * K.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) Haste. (S, L, K, TA.) So in the phrase fulaAnN EalaY jid~i A^amorK (tropical:) Such a one is in haste in an affair. (S, L, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Executed seriously, or in earnest, [in which there is no jesting,] and excessive; syn. muHaq~aqN mubaAlagN fiyhi [meaning muHaq~aqN fiyhi wamubaAlagN fiyhi; (see jad~a fiY A^amorihi;) jid~N thus used as an epithet having an intensive signification because it is originally an inf. n., or as some say, a simple subst.]: (L, K:) applied in this sense to a punishment: (L:) and also applied to a pace. (K in art. nS.) ＝ -A3- See also jud~apN: ― -b2- and see jadiydN.

jad~apN jd jdh jdp
: see jad~N, near the end of the paragraph.

jud~apN jd jdh jdp
The bank, or side, or a river; as also jid~apN and jid~N↓ (IAth, L, K) and jud~N↓ (IAth, Mgh, L) and jad~N↓, (Mgh, L, K,) accord. to some, but correctly jud~N; so called because cut off from the river, or because cut by the water, in like manner as it is called saAHilN because it is abraded by the water: (Mgh:) or the part of a river that is near the land; as also jid~apN↓: (L:) and the shore of the sea: (MF:) accord. to As, jd~p is an arabicized word from the Nabathean kd~. (L.) ― -b2- The stripe, or streak, that is on the back of the ass, differing from his general colour. (S, A, * K.) And (tropical:) A streak (Fr, S, K, TA) in anything, (TA,) as in a mountain, (Fr, S,) differing in colour from the rest of the mountain, (S,) white and black and red; (Fr, TA;) as also in the sky: (A, TA:) pl. judadN, (Fr, S,) occurring in the Kur xxxv. 25; (S;) where some read jududN, pl. of jdydp↓ [app. jadiydapN], which is syn. with jud~apN; and some, jadadN [q. v.]. (Bd.) ― -b3- A sign, or mark, syn. EalaAmapN, (Th, K,) of, or in, anything. (Th, TA.) ― -b4- A beaten way, marked with lines [cut by the feet of the men and beasts that have travelled along it]: (Az, L:) or a road, or way: pl. judadN: (Msb:) and juduwdN, also, [app. another pl. of jud~apN,] signifies paths, or tracks, forming lines upon the ground. (Az, L.) See also jaAd~apN. ― -b5- [Hence, app., but accord. to the S from the same word as signifying “a streak,”] rakiba jud~apF mina AlA^amori, (S, A, TA,) or jud~apa AlA^amori, (K,) (tropical:) He set upon a way, or manner, of performing the affair: (A:) or he formed an opinion respecting the affair, or case. (Zj, S, A, K.) ― -b6- See also jid~apN.

jid~apN jd jdh jdp
: see jud~apN, in two places: ― -b2- and see jadiydN. ― -b3- Also A rag; or piece torn off from a garment; and so jud~apN↓: thus in the saying, maA Ealayohi jid~apN and jud~apN [There is not upon him a rag]. (K.) ― -b4- A collar upon the neck of a dog: (Th, L, K:) pl. judadN [like luHFY pl. of liHoyapN, or perhaps a mistake for jidadN]. (L.)

jadadN jdd jdyd
Hard ground: (S:) or hard level ground: (Har p. 522:) [see also jadojadN:] or rough level ground: (K:) or rough ground: or level ground: (TA:) or a level and spacious tract of land; a tract such as is called SaHoraA=', and such as is called faDaA=', containing no soft place in which the feet sink, nor any mountain, nor any [hill such as is called] A^akamap; sometimes wide, and sometimes of little width: (ISh:) [and] a conspicuous road: (Bd in xxxv. 25:) pl. A^ajodaAdN. (ISh.) It is said in a prov., mano salaka Aljadada A^amina AlEivaAra [He who walks along hard, or hard and level, ground is secure from stumbling]; (S, TA;) meaning, he who pursues the course marked out by common consent is secure from stumbling. (TA.) And makaAnN jadadN occurs in a trad., meaning Level ground. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jadiydN. ― -b3- Also Sand that is thin, or fine, (K, TA,) and sloping down. (TA.) ― -b4- And A thing resembling a siloEap [or ganglion] in the neck of a camel. (K.)

jadaAdN jdAd
and jidaAdN↓ The cutting off of the fruit of palm-trees. (S, * A, * L, Msb, * K. *) You say, h`*aA zamanu AljadaAdi and AljidaAdi [This is the time, or season, of the cutting off of the fruit of the palmtrees]. (S, A, Msb. *) Some say that jdAd signifies particularly [as above,] the cutting off [of the fruit] of palm-trees; and j*A*, the cutting off of all fruits, in a general sense: others say that they signify the same. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The time, or season, of the cutting off of the fruit of palm-trees. (S, * L.) You say jadaAdN and jidaAdN, like SaraAmN and SiraAmN, and qaTaAfN and qiTaAfN; (Ks, S;) whence it seems as though the measures faEaAlN and fiEaAlN were uniformly applicable to every noun signifying the time of the action; such nouns being likened to A^awaAnN and A_iwaAnN. (S.)

jidaAdN jdAd
: see jadaAdN, and jaAd~N.

jaduwdN jd jdwd
, (ISk, S, A, K,) or jaduwdapN, (L,) Having little milk, (ISk, S,) or not from any imperfection; (L;) applied to a ewe, (ISk, S, K,) but not to a she-goat; the epithet maSuwrN being used in the latter case: (ISk, S:) or a ewe or she-goat having no milk; as also jad~aA='u↓: (A:) pl. jadaAy^idu (S, L) and jidaAdN. (L.) ― -b2- Also A fat she-ass: pl. jidaAdN. (AZ, K.)

jadiydN jdyd
, of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, [i. e. majoduwdN↓,] Cut, or cut off. (S, Msb.) A poet says,
A^abiY Hub~iY sulayomaY A^ano yabiydaA
waA^amosaY HaboluhaA xalaqFA jadiydaA
[My love of Suleymà hath refused to perish; but her cord (i. e. her tie of affection to me) hath become worn out and cut]: (S:) [as jdyd signifies “new” more commonly than "cut,"] this verse appears as though it involved a contradiction. (MF.) ― -b2- Applied to a garment, or a piece
of cloth [sufficient for a garment or the like], Newly cut off [from the web] by the weaver: (S, K:) and so (without p, S) applied to a miloHafap; (S, A;) thus applied to a fem. n. because syn. with majoduwdapN↓; (S, ISd;) or, accord. to Sb, because by mlHfp in this case is meant A_izaAr, and for a like reason in like cases; (Ham p. 555;) but one also says jadiydapN; (ISd;) and accord. to some, jdyd is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN, and therefore the p is regularly affixed to it: (Ham ubi suprà:) the pl. is jududN (Mbr, Th, S, A, K) and judadN; (AZ, A'Obeyd, Mbr;) but the former is the more common. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (L,) applied to a garment, (L, TA,) or a thing, (S, Msb,) New; contr. of qadiymN, (Msb,) or contr. of xalaqN; (S, L;) from jid~apN as contr. of bilFY: (K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajid~apN and [of mult.] jududN and judadN. (L.) You say, A^aSobaHato xalaquhumo jududFA, a phrase mentioned by Lh, meaning xuloqaAnuhumo jududFA [i. e. Their old worn-out garments became replaced by new]: or jududFA may be here put for jadiydFA. (L.) ― -b4- And hence, (TA,) AljadiydaAni and AlA^ajad~aAni↓ The night and the day; (S, Msb, K;) because they never become impaired by time. (TA.) You say, laA A^afoEaluhu maA A@xotalafa AljadiydaAni and AlA^ajad~aAni↓ [I will not do it while the day and the night succeed each other]: (S:) or maA kar~a AljadiydaAni and AlA^ajad~aAni [while the day and the night return time after time: i. e., ever]. (A.) ― -b5- Hence likewise, jadiydN also signifies A thing of which one has had no knowledge. (L.) ― -b6- And hence, (L,) Aljadiydu signifies Death: (K:) or is applied as an epithet to death, in the dial. of Hudheyl. (L.) Accord. to Akh and El-Mugháfis El-Báhilee, jadiydu Almawoti means The commencement of death. (L.) ＝ -A2- Also The face, or surface, of the earth, or ground; [as though it were cut;] (S, K, TA;) and so jadadN↓, and jid~apN↓, and jad~N↓, (K,) and jid~N↓. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also jad~N, in two places.

judaAdapN jdAdh jdAdp
What is cut off from the roots, or eradicated, of, or from, palm-trees &c. (Lh, TA.)

jadiydapN jdyd jdydh jdydp
The kind of pad, or stuffed thing, (rifaAdapN,) and the felt, stuck, or attached, beneath the two boards of a horse's saddle: there are two such things, called jadiydataAni: (S:) or the jdydtAn consist of the felt that is stuck, or attached, in the inner side of a horse's and of a camel's saddle: (L:) but jdydp thus applied is a post-classical word: the [classical] Arabs say jadoyapN, (S,) or, as in J's own handwriting, jadiy~apN. (So in the margin of a copy of the S.) ＝ -A2- See also jud~apN.

jad~iY~N jd jdY jdy jdyy
: see jad~N, in two places.

jud~iY~N jd jdY jdy jdyy
: see jad~N.

jadojadN jdjd
Hard level ground: (S, K:) [see also jadadN:] smooth ground: and rough ground: (TA:) a smooth tract such as is called fayof. (AA, TA.)

judojudN jdjd
[The cricket;] i. q. Sar~aAru All~ayoli, (S, M,) a small flying thing, (K,) that leaps, or springs, or bounds, much, (S, M,) and creaks by night, (TA,) and bears a resemblance to the jaraAd [or locust]: (S, M, K:) and a certain insect like the junodab, (M, L, K,) except that it is generally blackish, and short, but in some instances inclining to white; also called SaroSarN: (M, L:) or i. q. SadFY and junodabN: (El-'Adebbes:) pl. jadaAjidu. (S.) Accord. to IAar, A certain insect that clings to a skin, or hide, and eats it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jud~N.

jaAd~N jAd
act. part. n. of jad~a; (Mgh, L;) Cutting, or cutting off. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- A^ajaAd~u A^anota A^amo haAzilN Art thou serious or jesting? (A.) It is said in a trad., laA yaA^oxu*an~a A^aHadukumo mataAEa A^axiyhi laAEibFA jaAd~FA [By no means shall any one of you take the property of his brother in play and in earnest]; by which is meant taking a thing without meaning to steal it, but meaning to vex and anger the owner, so that the taker is in play with respect to theft, but in earnest in annoying. (TA in art. lEb.) ― -b2- fulaAnN jaAd~N Such a one is striving, labouring, or toiling; exerting himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability; &c. (TA.) And fulaAnN jaAd~N mujid~N↓, thus with the two similar words together, (As, S, L,) signifies the same [in an intensive degree]. (L, TA.) ＝ -A3- jaAd~u miAy^api wasoqK Land, or palm-trees, of which the produce, cut therefrom, is a hundred camel-loads: jaAd~N being here used in the sense of majoduwdN↓. (L.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Bekr, Ei$oriyna wasoqFA nahala EaAy^i$apa jidaAda↓, meaning He gave to 'Áïsheh palm-trees of which the quantity of the dates cut therefrom was a hundred camel-loads; but the phrase heard from the Arabs is jaAd~a Ei$oriyna: the former is like the saying h`*ihi Ald~araAhimu Darobu AlA^amiyri; and the latter, like Eiy$apN raADiyapN. (Mgh.)

jaAd~apN jAd jAdh jAdp
The main part of a road; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) its middle: (Mgh, Msb, and M voce jarajap:) or its even part: or the beaten track, or part along which one walks, or travels; the conspicuous part thereof: or a main road that comprises other roads, or tracks, and upon which one must pass: (TA:) or a road, or way, absolutely; as also jud~apN↓: (Zj, MF:) or a road leading to water: (AHn, TA:) it is so called because it is marked with tracks, forming lines: (T, TA:) pl. jawaAd~N, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) occurring in poetry without teshdeed, but disapproved by As. (L.) fulaAnN EalaY AljaAd~api means (assumed tropical:) Such a one is following the right course of action or the like. (Mgh.) You say also, huwa EalaY jaAd~api AlHaq~i (assumed tropical:) [He is on the road, or main road, of truth]: not, however, EalaY jaAd~api AlbaATili, but ElY mazal~api AlbaATili, and mazolaqatihi, and maholakatihi. (MF.)

A^ajad~u *
[Having some part, or parts, cut, or cut off: fem. jad~aA='u]. ― -b2- [Hence,] jad~aA='u A ewe, or she-goat, or she-camel, (TA,) having her ear cut off. (K, TA.) ― -b3- A ewe, or she-goat, having her teats cut off; (Sh, TA;) as also mujad~adapN↓ [q. v.], applied to a she-camel: (As, TA:) or having her udder cut off. (Khálid, TA.) ― -b4- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) A milch animal (TA [in the S app. restricted to a ewe]) whose milk has passed away, (ISk, S, K,) by reason of some fault, or imperfection: (ISk, S:) see also jaduwdN: or a ewe, or she-camel, or she-ass, having little milk; having a dry udder: or having dry teats, being hurt by the SiraAr [q. v.]: (L:) and A^ajad~u (assumed tropical:) a breast that has become dry. (AHeyth.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A woman small in the breast: (S, K:) or having short breasts. (TA from a trad.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A desert, (falaAp, S, K,) or land, (A^aroD, A,) in which is no water: (S, A, K:) a desert (mafaAzap) that is dry. (TA.) ― -b7- EaAmN A^ajad~u and sanapN jad~aA='u (assumed tropical:) A year of drought, and of dryness o the earth. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AlA^ajad~aAni: see jadiydN, in two places. ＝ -A3- A^ajad~u also signifies More [and most] easy to walk or ride upon, and more [and most] plain or level; applied to a road. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And More [and most] fortunate; applied to a man. (ISd, A, L.)

mujad~adapN AlA^axolaAfi *
A she-camel having her teats cut off in consequence of injury occasioned to her by the SiraAr [q. v.]. (S.) See also A^ajad~u. ＝ -A2- And mujad~adN A [garment of the kind called] kisaA=' having stripes of different colours. (S.)

mujid~N mjd mjdy
