: see jaAd~N. ― -b2- A_in~ahaA lmjd~p biAlr~ajuli, a phrase mentioned by As, said of a she-camel, meaning, Verily she is quick in her pace with the man: but Az says, I know not whether he said mijad~apN↓ or mujid~apN: the former would be from jad~a; and the latter, from A^ajad~a. (L.)

mijad~apN mjd mjdh mjdp
: see what next precedes.

majoduwdN mjdwd
: see jadiydN, in two places; and jaAd~N. ＝ -A2- See also jad~N, in two places.

1 jaduba jdb
, (A, Msb, K,) aor.
jaduba
, (K,) inf. n. juduwbapN, (S, A, Msb, K,) It (a place, S, A, K, or a country, or region, Msb,) was, or became, affected with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also jadiba, (A,) inf. n. jadabN; (KL;) or jadaba; (K;) and Ajdb↓; (A, K;) or jadibat, aor.
jadaba
; and A^ajodabat↓; both said of the earth or land (AlA^aroD): (Msb:) and A^ajodabati↓ AlbilaAdu the countries, or regions, were affected with drought, and the prices became high [therein]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jadabahu, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
jadiba
(M, Msb, K) and
jaduba
, (K,) inf. n. jadobN, (Msb,) He found fault with it; dispraised it; expressed disapprobation of it. (S, M, A, Msb, K.) So in the saying (S, A) relating to 'Omar, (A, TA,) in a trad., (S,) jadaba Als~amara baEoda AlEi$aA='i (S) or baEoda AlEatamapi (A) [He expressed disapprobation of night-discourse after nightfall, or after the first third of the night reckoned from the disappearance of the redness of the twilight].

3 jaAdabati AlA_ibilu AlEaAma jAdbt AlAbl AlEAm
, (ISk, S, A, TA,) inf. n. mujaAdabapN, (TA,) The camels experienced, or have experienced, drought, and barrenness, or dryness
of the earth, this year, and have become in such a state as not to eat anything but dry and black herbage, dry vumaAm [or panic grass]: (ISk, S, TA:) or have not met with, or found, anything but what was bad, by reason of drought, and barrenness, or dryness of the earth, this year. (A.)

4 A^ajodaba
see 1, in three places. ― -b2- A^ajodabati Als~anapu The year became one of drought, barrenness, or dearth; or drought, and dryness of the earth. (A, * TA.) ― -b3- Ajdb Alqawomu The people, or company of men, experienced drought, barrenness, or death; or drought, and dryness of the earth. (S, A, Msb, K.) ― -b4- [Hence,] nazalonaA bibaniY fulaAnK faA^ajodabonaA (tropical:) We alighted as guests at the abode of the sons of such a one, and found not entertainment with them, though they were in the enjoyment of plenty: (A:) [or] nazalonaA fulaAnFA faA^ajoabonaAhu (assumed tropical:) we alighted as guests at the abode of such a one, and [found that] he did not entertain us. (TA.) [The latter, if correct, is from what next follows.] ＝ -A2- Ajdb AlA^aroDa He found the land to be affected with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth. (S, A, K.)

5 maA A^atajad~abu A^ano A^aSoHabaka *
(assumed tropical:) I do not deem it disagreeable, or unsuitable, to accompany thee; syn. maA A^asotawoximu. (K.)

jadobN jdb
Drought, barrenness, or dearth; contr. of xiSobN; (S;) i. q. maHolN, (A, Msb, K,) i. e. drought, or suspension of rain, and dryness of the earth; (Msb;) dryness and barrenness of the earth: (Har p. 576:) and jidab~N↓ is a name, or subst., for AljadobN, (K, TA,) meaning AlmaHolu; as in the saying of the rájiz, cited by Sb,
laqado xa$iytu A^ano A^araY jidab~aA
fiY EaAminaA baEoda maA A^axoSab~aA
[Verily I feared to see drought, or barrenness, &c., in this our year, after it had been abundant in herbage]; jidab~aA being used for AljadobaA; or, accord. to one reading, it is jadobab~aA↓, with a doubled b added; the change being made for the sake of the metre. (M, TA. [Respecting A^axoSab~aA, see 4 in art. xSb.]) ― -b2- Also A place, (S, A, K,) or a country, or region, (Msb,) affected with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth; and so jadiybN↓ (S, A, Msb, K) and jaduwbN↓ and majoduwbN↓, (K,) the last derived from judiba though this verb has not been used, (TA,) and mujodibN↓, (M, A,) of which the pl. is majaAdiybu. (A.) You say also A^aroDN jadobN [in which jdb is an inf. n. (though app. obsolete as such) and therefore applicable to a fem. subst.] (ISd, TA) and jadobapN (S, A, Msb, K) and jadibapN↓ (A, Msb) and jadiybN↓ (Msb) and jaduwbN↓ (Lh, M, Msb) and mujodibapN↓, of which last the pl. is majaAdiybu, (Msb,) A land affected with drought, &c.: (S, M, A, &c.:) and A^aroDuwna juduwbN, (S, K,) as though to each part were applied the term jadobN [used as a subst.] from which is formed the pl. juduwbN, (TA,) and jadobN, (K,) which is here an inf. n. used as an epithet [and therefore applicable to a pl. subst.], (TA,) lands affected with drought, &c. (S, K.) And falaApN jadobaA='u↓ [fem. of A^ajodabu] (M, K) A desert affected with drought, &c.; (K;) in which is neither little nor much, neither pasture nor herbage. (M, TA.) And fulaAnN jadiybu↓ AljanaAbi Such a one is environed by a tract affected with drought, &c. (S. [But this phrase is generally used tropically, as meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one is ungenerous or illiberal or inhospitable. See art. jnb.]) And sanapN jadobapN (K in art. jrz) and EaAmN jaduwbN↓ (M, TA) [A year of drought, &c.]. See also A^ajaAdibu, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also i. q. EayobN [A vice, fault, defect, &c.]; (S, A, K;) a signification which may be either proper or tropical. (Er-Rághib, MF.)

A^aroDN jadibapN *
: see jadobN.

A^axa*a fiY waAdiY jadabaAtK *
: see ja*abaAt, in art. j*b.

jidab~N jdb
and jadobab~N: see jadobN.

jaduwbN jdwb
: see jadobN, in three places.

jadiybN jdyb
: see jadobN, in three places.

jaAdibN jAdb
Finding fault, dispraising, expressing disapprobation: whence the saying of Dhu-rRummeh,
fayaA laka mino xad~K A^asiylK w manoTiqK
raxiymK wamino xaloqK taEal~ala jaAdibuho
meaning [O thou smooth and even cheek, and gentle speech, and make] whereof he who dispraises it occupies himself vainly, finding no defect in it. (S, TA.) ― -b2- It is also said [as in the K &c.] to signify Lying; and the author of the 'Eyn says that it has no verb belonging to it [in this sense]; but this is a mistranscription [for xaAdibN]: AZ says that jaAdibN, with j, has the signification here first given. (M, TA.)

junodabN jndb
and junodubN (S, K, &c.) and jinodabN, like dirohamN, (Sb, M, K,) the last of which is of weakest authority, because of a rare measure, whereof it has been said that there are only four examples: (TA:) in all of them the n is said by some to be radical; but others, with more reason, hold it to be augmentative: (MF:) Sb says that it is augmentative: (S:) A species of locust, (S, K,) well known: (K:) or the male locust: or small locust: or, accord. to Seer, i. q. SadFY [a kind of cricket], that creaks by night, and hops and flies: [but see SadFY:] or, accord. to the M, it is smaller than the SdY, and is found in the deserts: pl. janaAdibu. (TA.) Sr~ Aljndb [i. e. Sar~a Aljunodabu The jndb creaked] is a saying of the Arabs, used as a proverb; alluding to a difficult affair by which a person is troubled in mind; originating from the fact that the jndb, when its feet are scorched by the heated ground, does not keep them steadily upon it, and a creaking sound is consequently heard, produced by its legs. (TA.) ― -b2- A^um~u junodabK The sand; because the locust [or jndb] deposits its eggs therein: and the walker therein falls into evil [or encounters difficulty]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence it signifies also] Misfortune: (S, M, K:) and perfidy, or faithlessness, or treachery: (M, K:) and wrong, or injury: (S, M, K:) and evil conduct, or ill treatment. (S.) You say, waqaEa fulaAnN fiY A^um~i junodabK Such a one fell into misfortune: or into perfidy. (TA.) And waqaEuwA fiY A^um~i junodabK They suffered wrong, or injury. (AZ, S, K.) And waqaEa Alqawomu junodabK The people, or company of men, committed wrong, or injury, and slew him who was not a slayer: (TA:) [as though they came with violence upon sand in which eggs of the jndb were deposited, and so destroyed the eggs, which had occasioned them no harm.] And rakiba A^um~a junodabK He committed wrong, or injury. (TA.)

[
A^ajodabu *
i. q. jadobN as syn. with jadiybN: fem. jadoyaA='u. Hence,] falaApN jadoyaA='u: see jadobN. ― -b2- [Hence also,] sanapN jadobaA='u A year of much snow. (L in art. $hb.) ― -b3- A^ajodabu is [also] said in the M to be [used as] a subst. applied to what is termed mujodib [i. e. as syn. with the latter word used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; app. meaning A place, or the like, affected with drought, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b4- [Also, as a comparative and superlative epithet, meaning More, and most, affected with drought, &c.; contr. of A^axoSabu.]

A^ajaAdibu *
, in a trad., where it is said, wakaAnato fiyhi A^ajaAdibu A^amosakati AlmaA='i, (K, * TA,) or wkAnt fiyhaA, (TA,) [And there were in it AjAdb that retained the water], is said to be pl. of A^ajodubN, which is pl. of jadobN↓, (K, TA,) like as A^akaAlibu is pl. of A^akolubN, which is pl. of kalobN; (TA;) and signifies hard parts of the ground, that retain water, and do not imbibe it quickly; or, as some say, land having no plants or herbage, from jadobN↓ meaning “ drought ” &c: the word is thus written in the two Saheehs, of El-Bukháree and Muslim: (IAth, TA:) but some say that it is an anomalous pl. of jadobN, like as maHaAsinu is of HusonN: and there are other readings; namely, A^ajaA*ibu and A^aHaAdibu and A^aHaAzibu and A^ajaAridu, pl. of A^ajoradu, and A_ixaA*aAtN, pl. of A_ixaA*apN. (MF, TA.)

mujodibN mjdb
, and its fem., with p: see jadobN.

mijodaAbN mjdAb
Land scarely ever, or never, abundant in herbage, or in the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; scarcely ever, or never, fruitful, or plentiful. (K.)

majoduwbN mjdwb
: see jadobN.

8 Ajtdv Ajtdv
He made, or prepared, a jadav, i. e., a grave, or sepulchre; or did so for himself. (S, K, TA.)

jadavN jdv
A grave; a sepulchre; pl. A^ajodaAvN (S, Msb, K) and A^ajoduvN; (S, K;) of which latter, J cites an ex., but in this instance it is the proper name of a place. (TA.) It is of the dial. of Tihámeh: the people of Nejd say jadafN: (Msb:) or [as some say] the f in the latter is a substitute for the v in the former; for AjdAv is used as a
pl. by common consent, and AjdAf is not used: (TA:) but Suh affirms, in the R, that the latter pl. is used by Ru-beh. (TA in art. jdf.)

1 jadaHa jdH
, aor.
jadaHa
, inf. n. jadoHN, He mixed anything. (L.) jadaHa Als~awiyqu, (S, A, Mgh, L, K,) wanaHowahu, aor. and inf. n. as above; and jd~Hhu↓, inf. n. tajodiyHN; (L;) and AjtdHhu↓, (S, L, K,) and AjdHhu↓; (K;) He stirred about the swyq [or meal made of parched barley or wheat], and the like, with water, [or milk, (see what follows,) or clarified butter, or fat of a sheep's tail, &c., (see lat~a,)] until the whole became of a uniform consistence: (L:) or he stirred it about with a mijodaH: (A, L:) or he stirred about the swyq in milk, and the like, with a mjdH, until it became mixed: (Lth, TA:) or he beat and mixed the swyq with a mjdH: (Mgh:) i. q. lat~ahu: (S, K:) and jd~Hhu↓, inf. n. tajodiyHN, he mixed it; in the K, laTaxahu; but the right reading is xalaTahu, as in the L and other lexicons: (TA:) and AjtdHhu↓ he drank it ($rbh [but this is perhaps a mistranscription for Darabahu he beat it]) with the mjdH. (L, TA.)

2 jad~aHa
see 1, in two places.

4 A^ajodaHa
see 1. ― -b2- AHdH AlA_ibila He branded the camels on their thighs with the mark called mijodaH. (K.)

8 A_ijotadaHa
see 1, in two places.

AlmujodaHu AlmjdH
: see the next paragraph.

mijodaHN mjdH
The instrument with which sawiyq is stirred about with water &c.; (S, A, K, &c.;) which is a piece of wood the end whereof has several sides; (S, L;) or a piece of wood at the head of which are two cross pieces of wood; (A, Mgh, L;) and sometimes having three prongs: (IAth, TA:) pl. majaAdiHu. (L.) ― -b2- It is sometimes used tropically, as relating to evil, or mischief. (L.) [Thus it means (tropical:) A stirrer-up of evil or mischief; or a thing that stirs up, or whereby one stirs up, evil or mischief.] ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Any one of the majaAdiyHu Als~amaA='i [or stirrers-up of the sky, or of rain]; (L;) these being the A^anowaA='N [or stars, or asterisms, which, by their auroral settings or risings, were believed by the Pagan Arabs to bring rain &c.]; (S, L, K;) of those AnwA' that seldom or never failed [to bring rain], accord. to the Arabs: (Mgh:) the Y in the pl. is added to give fulness to the sound of the kesreh; for the regular pl. is majaAdiHu, and the sing. of mjAdyH should by rule be mijodaAHN. (A, IAth, Mgh.) One says, Arosalati Als~amaA='a majaAdiyHuhaA (L) or majaAdiyHu Algayovi (A) (assumed tropical:) [Its stirrers-up, or the stirrers-up of rain, or the stars or asterisms which were the bringers of it, sent forth rain]. It is related of 'Omar, that he ascended the pulpit to pray for rain, and, having only offered a prayer for forgiveness, descended; whereupon it was said to him, “ Thou hast not prayed for rain; ” and he replied, laqadi A@sotasoqayotu bimajaAdiyHi Als~amaA='i (assumed tropical:) [I have indeed prayed for rain by words which are the stirrers-up of rain]; making the prayer for forgiveness to be a prayer for rain, in allusion to a passage in the Kur, lxxi. 9 and 10; and meaning thereby to deny the efficacy of the AnwA'. (A, * Mgh, * L.) AlmijodaHu, also pronounced AlmujodaHu↓, (S, K,) thus pronounced by El-Umawee, (S,) is moreover the name of (assumed tropical:) A particular star or asterism, one of those which the Pagan Arabs asserted to be bringers of rain: (L:) said to be Ald~abaraAnu [the Hyades; or the five chief stars thereof; or the brightest star thereof, a of Taurus]; (S, A, L, K;) [which is called by this name of AldbrAn] because it rises latterly [with respect to the Pleiades], (S,) or because it follows (yadoburu, i. e. yatobaEu,) the Pleiades: (T in art. dbr:) [whence] it is also called HaAdiY Aln~ujuwmi [“ the urger of the stars, ” properly, “ with singing ”], (S,) or HaAdiY Aln~ajomi [“ the urger of the asterism, ” meaning, “ of the Pleiades ”], and taAliY Aln~ajomi [“ the follower of the asterism, ” or, “ of the Pleiades ”], (Kzw,) and Alt~aAliY and Alt~aAbiEu [“ the follower ”]: (Sh:) or it is a small star or asterism, between AldbrAn and Alv~uray~aA [or the Pleiades]: (IAar, K:) [perhaps meaning the four stars that are the chief stars of the Hyades exclusively of a Tauri:] or three stars, (Mgh, TA,) like the three stones upon which a cooking-pot rests, (TA,) likened to a three-pronged mijodaH; (Mgh, TA;) on the [auroral] rising of which, heat is expected: (TA:) the Arabs regarded it as one of the AnwA' which [by their auroral setting] foretokened rain. (IAth.) AlmijodaHaAni is a name by which some of the Arabs called (assumed tropical:) The two wings of AljawozaA=' [or Orion]. (Sh, TA.) ― -b4- mijodaHN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain mark made with a hot iron upon the thighs of camels. (K.)

mujad~aHN mjdH
Beverage, or wine, ($araAb,) stirred about: (S, K:) and in like manner, blood, when it is stirred about in the body of a gored animal by the goring horn. (L.)

majoduwHN mjdwH
Blood drawn from a vein, used in times of dearth, or drought, (S, K,) in the Time of Ignorance: (S:) or blood which was mixed with something else, and eaten in times of dearth: (TA:) or a kind of food of the Pagan Arabs, being blood obtained by opening a vein of a she-camel, which blood was received in a vessel, and drunk. (T, TA.)

1 jadara jdr
, (K,) aor.
jadura
, (TA,) He made a jidaAr [app. here meaning a wall of enclosure]; syn. Haw~aTa: (K:) or he built a jdAr: and he founded it. (Ham p. 818.) ＝ -A2- He concealed himself by means of a jidAr [or wall]. (Th, K.) ＝ -A3- judira, (A, K,) inf. n. jadorN; (TA;) and jadara, (Lh, K,) aor.
jadura
, inf. n. jadorN; (Lh, TA;) and jud~ira↓, (S, (A, K,) which last some disallow, because this form denotes repetition, and the verb signifies the having a disease that befalls but once in a man's life; (MF;) He (a man, S, or a child, A) had, or became attacked by, judariY~ [or small-pox]. (S, A, K.) [And jadara AljudariY~u The small-pox came forth, or broke out; as in the TK: for its inf. n.] jadorN signifies the coming forth, or breaking out, of the judariY~. (K.) ＝ -A4- jadura, aor.
jadura
, inf. n. jadaArapN, He, or it, was, or became, adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, proper, or worthy. (K.) You say, jadura bihi [and lahu ] He was, or became, adapted, disposed, apt, &c., for it. (A.) [And jadura A^ano yafoEala ka*aA He was, or became, adapted, disposed, apt, &c., for doing such a thing. See jadiyrN .] ＝ -A5- jadarahu He made, or called, (jaEala,) him, or it, adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, proper, or worthy. (K.)

2 jad~ara binaA='ahu jdr bnA='h jdr bnA='p
: see 8. ＝ -A2- jud~ira: see 1.

4 maA A^ajodarahu biAlxayori *
[and liloxayori] How well adapted or disposed, or how apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, or proper, is he for what is good! or how worthy is he of what is good! (A.) And maA A^ajodarahu A^ano yafoEala *`lika, and A^ajodiro bihi, How well adapted or disposed, or how apt, meet, &c., is he for doing that! or how worthy is he to do that! (TA.) The usage of jadura, signifying “ he was, or became, adapted, &c., ” refutes the assertion of certain grammarians that these two forms of the verb deviate from general rule. (MF.)

8 Ajtdr binaA='ahu Ajtdr bnA='h Ajtdr bnA='p
; and jd~rhu↓, inf. n. tajodiyrN (K) and mujad~arN; (TA;) He raised his building high; or constructed it firmly and strongly, and raised it high; syn. $ay~adahu. (K, TA.) [In the CK, we read Aijtadara binaAhu, as though the pronoun h referred to the word jidaAr, which precedes; and thus the verb signified “ he built a wall; ” but it is shown in the TA that the right reading is that given above.]

Q. Q. 1 janodara AlkitaAba jndr AlktAb
He passed the pen over what had become obliterated, of the writing, (S, K,) in order that it might become distinct. (S.) And jndr Alv~awoba He renewed the variegated, or figured, work of the garment, or piece of cloth, after it had gone. (S, K.) [J says,] I think it to be an arabicized word. (S)

jadorN jdr
A wall; or a wall of enclosure; syn. HaAy^iTN; as also jidaArN↓, [which is the more common]: (S, A, Msb, K:) pl. of the former, judurN, (S, Msb, K,) sometimes used as a pl. of pauc., (Sb, TA,) and judorN; (K;) and of the latter, judoraAnN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- The basis, or foundation, of a wall: (K:) and the side of a wall: (Lh, K:) pl., in both these senses, juduwrN. (TA.) Aljadoru is applied to The [wall called the] HaTiym (A, K) of the Kaabeh; (K;) because in it is a part of the [original] foundations of the house: (TA:) and it is also called AlHijoru. (A.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A fence, or dam, raised of branches, to retain water; likened to a wall: (Az, Msb:) or
a fence, or dam, to confine water: pl. juduwrN: (Suh, Msb:) and judurN, [which is also a pl.,] signifies fences, or dams, between houses, which retain water. (TA.) ― -b4- [The pl.] juduwrN also signifies Gardens, or walled gardens, (HawaAy^iT,) of grapes. (TA.)

jadarapN jdr jdrh jdrp
: see jadiyrapN

judariY~N jdrY jdry
and jadariY~N (S, Msb, K) [Small-pox;] certain pustules (Msb, K) in the body, (K,) which break forth (Msb, K) from the skin, full of water, and afterwards opening, (Msb,) and generating thick purulent matter; (K;) a well-known disease, that attacks people once during life. (TA.) ― -b2- judariY~u AlA^aroDi (tropical:) an appellation applied to Truffles (kamoA^ap), denoting disapprobation. (TA from a trad.)

jidaArN jdAr
: see jadorN: and see also jadiyrapN.

jadiyrN jdyr
A place having a wall built around it; a walled place. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also mujad~arN. ＝ -A3- Also Adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, competent, or worthy; syn. xaliyqN (S, A, Msb, K) and HaqiyqN: (Msb:) fem. with p: (TA:) pl. mase. jadiyruwna and judaraA='u: (S, K:) pl. fem. jadiyraAtN and jadaAy^iru. (TA.) You say, huwa jadiyrN bika*aA (S, A, Msb) and lika*aA (TA) He is adapted, disposed, apt, meet, &c., for such a thing; (S, A, Msb;) and [naturally] drawn to it. (Ham p. 707.) And A^anota jadiyrN A^ano tafoEala ka*aA Thou art adapted, disposed, apt, meet, &c., for doing such a thing; or worthy to do it. (S.) And A^ano yafoEala A_in~ahu lamajodarapN↓, (K,) and in like manner you say of two persons, and of more, (TA,) and majoduwrN↓, (K.) Verily he is one who is adapted, disposed, apt, meet, &c., for doing [such a thing]; or worthy to do [it]; syn. maxolaqapN. (K.) [majodarapN↓ properly signifies A place, and hence a thing, an affair, and a person, adapted, disposed, apt, meet, &c.; like maxolaqapN and maHoraApN: and majoduwrN↓, Made, or called, adapted or disposed &c., though said by Aboo-Jaafar Er-Ru- ásee to be a pass. part. n. having no verb.] Also bi*`lika A_in~ahaA lamajodarapN↓ Verily she is one who is adapted, disposed, apt, &c., for that: and biA^ano tafoEala *`lika for doing that: and in like manner you say of two persons, and of more. (TA.) And li*aAka h`*aA AlA^amoru majodarapN↓ This affair, or thing, is one that is adapted, apt, meet, &c., for that; syn. maHoraApN. (S.) And h`*aA AlA^amoru majodarapN↓ minohu This affair, or thing, is one that is adapted, apt, meet, &c., for him to do; i. e. he is adapted, apt, meet, &c., for doing it. (TA.)

jadiyrapN jdyr jdyrh jdyrp
An enclosure for camels, (AZ, S, K,) and for lambs and kids and calves &c., (TA,) made of masses of stone; (AZ, S;) as also jadarapN↓: (TA:) if of mud, or clay, it is called jidaArN↓: (AZ, TA:) or an enclosure (zarob ) for sheep or goats. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Nature; or natural, or native, disposition, temper, or other property. (K)

huwa A^ajodaru bihi *
He, or it, is more, or most, adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, or proper, for it, or him; or he is more, or most, worthy of it. (A.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce xuT~apN.]

A^aroDN majodarapN *
A land in which is HudariY~ [or small-pox]: (Lh, S:) or a land in which is much thereof. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also jadiyrN, in five places.

mujad~arN mjdr
(S, Mgh, Msb, K) and majoduwrN↓ (Mgh, K) and jadiyrN↓ (Msb, TA) Having the judariY~ [or small-pox]. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) And majoduwrN↓ Alwajohi [Having the face marked with the smallpox]. (A.)

majoduwrN mjdwr
: see mujad~arN: ＝ -A2- and see also jadiyrN, in two places.

1 jadaEa AlA^anofa *
, (S, * Msb, K, *) aor.
jadaEa
, (Msb,) inf. n. jadoEN, (S, Msb, K,) He cut off the nose; and in like manner, the ear; and the hand, or arm; and the lip; (S, Msb, K;) and a similar part: (TA:) and A^anofahu A^ajodaEotu↓ signifies the same as jadaEotu [I cut off his nose]: or jadoEN signifies [absolutely] the cutting off; or cutting so as to separate. (TA.) In the following saying of a poet, the verb is used metaphorically,
waA^aSobaHa Ald~ahoru *uw AlEironiyni qado judiEaA
[lit. And nosed fortune became mutilated in the nose; meaning, (assumed tropical:) became marred]. (TA.) And in the following phrase, occurring in a verse, kaA^an~a A@ll~`ha yajodaEu A^anofahu waEayonayohi, the poet means, [As though God cut off his nose] and put out his eyes: see a similar saying in art. qld, voce taqal~ada. (TA.) ― -b2- jadaEahu, (S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He mutilated him, or maimed him, by cutting off his nose, or his ear, or his hand or arm, or his lip, (S, K, TA,) or the like; (TA;) as also jd~Ehu↓ (S, TA.) [Hence the phrase,] lahu jadoEFA↓ (S, K) [(May God decree) to him mutilation, or maining, by the cutting off of his nose, or the like; or cause it to befall him: or] meaning A^alozamahu A@ll~`hu AljadoEa [(assumed tropical:) may God make injury, or diminution of what is good, to cleave to him]: (K:) said in imprecating a curse upon a man: similar to EaqorFA lahu, q. v.: the first word being governed in the accus. case by a verb understood. (TA.) One says also, AijodaEohumo biAlA^amori Hat~aY ya*il~uwA, a phrase mentioned by IAar, but not explained by him; thought by ISd to mean, (tropical:) Act thou, in commanding, as though thou mutilatedst them by cutting off their noses [until they become submissive]. (TA.) In the phrase Sawotu AlHimaAri Alyujad~aEu↓ [The voice of the ass that has his ear, or ears, cut off, (see mujad~aEN, below,)], occurring in a verse of Dhu-l-Khirak Et-Tuhawee, (S,) accord. to J, but not found by Sgh in the verses of that poet, and said to be in the Book [of Sb], though IB denies this, asserting it to be in the Nawádir of AZ, (TA,) Akh says, the poet means Al~a*iY yujad~aEu, like as you say, huwaA@loyaDoribuka, meaning Al~a*iY yaDoribuka: Aboo-Bekr Ibn-es-Sarráj says, the poet, requiring refa for the rhyme, has changed the noun into a verb; and this is one of the worst of poetic licences. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence,] Als~anapu tajodaEu Aln~abaAta (tropical:) [The year of drought cuts off, or destroys, the herbage]: (A, TA:) and tajodaEu biAlmaAli destroys the camels or the like. (S, O, K.) And AlqaHoTu Alnab~aAti jad~aEa↓ (tropical:) The drought prevented the growth, or increase, of the herbage. (K, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] jadaEa EiyaAlahu, inf. n. jad~aEN, (assumed tropical:) He withheld good things from his family, or household. (TA.) And jadaEatohu A^um~uhu, aor.
jadaEa
, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) His mother fed him with bad food; (Zj, K;) as also A^ajodaEatohu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. A_ijodaAEN; (TA;) and jad~aEatohu↓, (K,) inf. n. tajodiyEN: (TA:) and jd~Ehu↓ and AjdEhu↓ (tropical:) He (a pastor) confined him [a beast] to bad pasture. (TA.) jadaEotuhu, (S,) inf. n. as above, (K,) also signifies (assumed tropical:) I confined him, restricted him, or the like; syn. Habasotuhu: and (assumed tropical:) I imprisoned him: (S, K: *) and so with *: (S:) or jadoEN and ja*oEN both signify (assumed tropical:) the confining, or restricting, a person with evil management, and with contemptuous treatment, and want of good care. (A Heyth.) ＝ -A2- jadiEa, aor.
jadaEa
, (Msb,) inf. n. jadaEN, (S, Msb, K,) He (a man) was, or became, mutilated, or maimed, by the cutting off of his nose, or his ear, (S, * Msb, K, *) or his hand or arm, or his lip, (S, K,) or the like: (TA:) or, accord. to some, you do not say jadiEa, but judiEa: (TA:) and jadiEati Al$~aApu The sheep, or goat, was, or became, mutilated by having its ears entirely cut off. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] also, (S, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (S,) [as though meaning (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, injured;] (tropical:) he (a child) had bad food: (S, K, TA:) and he (a young weaned camel) had bad food: or was ridden while [too] young, and in consequence became weak. (TA.)

2 jd~Ehu jdE jdEh jdEp
, inf. n. tajodiyEN: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- jad~aEahu wa$ar~aAhu (tropical:) He made him to experience evil treatment, and derided him; as when one cuts off the ear of his slave, and sells him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also He said to him jadoEFA laka [explained above; see 1]. (S, K. *) [See also Eaq~arahu.]

3 jAdE jAdE
, inf. n. mujaAdaEapN (S, K) and jidaAEN (K,) (tropical:) He reviled, being reviled by another, (K, * TA,) saying jadoEFA laka; as though each of them cut off the nose of the other: (TA:) and, (K,) or accord. to some, (TA,) (tropical:) he contended in an altercation; as also tjAdE↓; (S, K, TA;) [but the latter is said of a number of persons &c.] You say, A^afaAEiyhaA tarakotu AlbilaAda tajaAdaEu↓, (Th, S,) and tajad~aEu↓ also, (Th,) (tropical:) I left the countries with their vipers eating one another; (Th, S;) not meaning eating in reality, but rending in pieces, or mangling, one another: (Th:) and A^afaAEiyhaA EaAmN tajad~aEu↓, and tajaAdaEu↓, (tropical:) A year in which the vipers eat one another, by reason of its severity. (Th.)

4 A^ajodaEa
see 1, in three places.

5 tajad~aEa
see 3, in two places.

6 tajaAodaEa
see 3, in three places.

jadoEN jdE
What is cut off of the anterior parts of the nose, to its furthest, or uttermost, part: (As,
TA:) an inf. n. used as a [proper] subst. (TA.) ― -b2- jadoEFA lahu : see 1. ＝ -A2- (tropical:) Unwholesomeness in herbage. (K.)

jadiEN *
(tropical:) A child having bad food; or fed on bad food: (S, K, TA:) pronounced by El-Mufaddal with *; but As repudiated to him this pronunciation; (S, TA:) and his objection was confirmed by a young man of the Benoo-Asad called in as an umpire. (TA.)

jadaEapN jdE jdEh jdEp
What remains, of the nose, ear, hand or arm, or lip, after the cutting off [of the rest]: (S, K:) the place of the cutting off thereof; like EarajapN from AlA^aEoraju, and qaTaEapN from AlA^aqoTaEu. (TA.)

jadaAEi jdAE
(S, A, K, &c.) and jadaAEN (K, TA) (tropical:) A year of drought; because it cuts off, or destroys, (tajodaEu,) the herbage, and abases men: (A, TA:) or a severe, or calamitous, year, that destroys the camels or the like; (S, O, K;) or that destroys everything; as though it cut off its nose or the like. (L.) ― -b2- See also judaAEN.

judaAEN jdAE
(tropical:) Withered herbage: (S:) or herbage that is unwholesome to the feeder upon it: (K:) or tall, unwholesome, and withered. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, AljudaAEu signifies (tropical:) Death: (K, TA:) written by some AljadaAEu↓. (TA.)

A^ajodaEu *
Mutilated, or maimed, by having his nose cut off, or his ear, (S, Msb, K,) or his hand or arm, or his lip, (S, K,) or the like: (TA:) fem. jadoEaA='u: (S, Msb:) and the latter, applied to a she-camel, having the sixth part of her ear, or the fourth part of it, or more than that, to the half, cut off; and to a she-goat, having a third part, or more, of her ear cut off; or, accord. to IAmb, any ewe or she-goat having the ear lopped; (TA;) or a ewe or she-goat having her ear entirely cut off: (Mgh, Msb:) and mujad~aEN↓ an ass having the ear cut off, (S,) or having the ears cut off. (K.) It is said in a prov., A^anofuka minoka wa A_ino kaAna A^ajodaEa [Thy nose is a part of thee though it be cut off]: applied with reference to him whose good and evil attaches to thee though he be not firmly connected with thee by relationship. (TA.) ― -b2- AlA^ajodaEu one of the appellations applied to The devil. (Fr, K. *)

mujad~aEN mjdE
: see A^ajodaEN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A plant, or herbage, of which the upper part has been eaten: (S:) or of which the upper part and the sides have been partly cut off or eaten. (AHn.)

1 jadafahu jdf jdfh jdfp
, aor.
jadifa
, (IDrd, K,) inf. n. jadofN, (TA,) He cut it; or cut it off: (IDrd, K:) and so ja*afahu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jadafa, (Ks, S, K,) aor.
jadifa
, (Ks, IDrd, S,) inf. n. juduwfN, (Ks, S, K,) or jadofN, (L as on the authority of Ks,) He (a bird) flew [with his wings] clipped, appearing as though he turned his wings backward: (Ks, S, K:) or contracted his wing somewhat, in order to descend in his flight, and then inclined, or declined, in fear of the hawk: (TA:) and he (a bird) went quickly, (K in art. j*f,) with his wings; generally when one of the wings had been shortened; (TA;) as also Ajdf↓ and Anjdf↓: and so, all, with *. (K ib.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jadafa Almal~aAHu biAlmijodaAfi [The sailor rowed, or paddled, with the oar, or paddle]. (AA, TA.) And jadafa biAls~afiynapi, (TA,) or jadafa Als~afiynapa, aor.
jadifa
, inf. n. jadofN, (Mgh,) [He rowed, or paddled, the ship, or boat;] he put the ship, or boat, in motion with the mijodaf [or mijodaAf]. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also jadafa He (a man) swung the arms; (K, expl. by Daraba biAlyadayoni; in the O, biAlyadi, as is said in the TA;) as a man does in walking, moving them about: and the meaning seems to be, he walked quickly: (TA:) you say, jadafa fiY mi$oyatihi he (a man) was quick in his manner of walking; (AAF, TA;) and so with *: (S in art. j*f:) or jadofN signifies a repeated interrupting of the voice (taqoTiyEu AlS~awoti) in singing to camels to urge or excite them. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- Also, (K,) inf. n. jadofN, (TA,) He (a gazelle) went, or walked, with short steps. (K, * TA.) And jadafato She (a woman) walked like those that are short: and she (a gazelle, and a woman, TA) went with short steps; as also Ajdft↓: and so, both, with *. (K in art. j*f.) ― -b5- jadafati Als~amaA='u biAlv~aloji The sky cast down snow: (K:) and so with *. (TA.)

2 jd~f jdf
, (S,) inf. n. tajodiyfN, (S, K,) He denied, or disacknowledged, favours, or benefits; or was ungrateful, or unthankful, for them: (As, S, K:) or he deemed the gifts of God small: (ElUmawee, S, K:) or he said that he was in an evil state when he was in a good state: (TA:) or he said, layosa liY walayosa EinodiY [app. meaning There is nothing due to me nor by me]; (K;) thus explained by Mohammad on his saying that the worst of deeds is Alt~ajodiyf: (TA:) [accord. to Golius, he blasphemed; and identified by him, in this sense, with the Hebr. ???.] It is said in a trad., laA tujad~ifuwA biniEomapi A@ll~`hi (S, TA) Deny not ye, or disacknowledge not, or be not ungrateful or unthankful for, the bounty of God, and deem it not small. (TA.)

4 A^ajodafa
see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- AjdfwA They raised cries, shouts, noises, a clamour, or confused cries or shouts or noises. (K, TA.)

7 A_inojadafa
see 1.

jadafN jdf
A grave; a sepulchre; (S, Msb, K;) like jadavN; for the Arabs made f and v interchangeable: (Fr, S:) the former is of the dial. of Nejd; and the latter, of the dial. of Tihámeh: (Msb in art. jdv:) [accord. to some,] the former is formed from the latter by substitution [of f for v]: (S:) IJ argues that this is the case because the former has not A^ajodaAfN for pl.: (TA:) but it has this pl., (Fr, S, R, TA,) used by Ru-beh. (R, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, said in a trad. to be the beverage of the jinn, or genii, (S, TA,) Beverage that has not been covered [at night according to a precept of the Prophet]: (Katádeh, S, K:) or of which the mouth of the skin containing it has not been tied [at night]: (K:) or a certain plant of El-Yemen, the eater of which needs not to drink after it: (S, K:) or a certain plant of El-Yemen, eaten by camels, which thereby become in no need of water: (M, TA:) or the froth, or floating particles, cast up by beverage; (El-'Otbee, Hr, K;) as though it were cut off from the beverage. (El-'Otbee, Hr, TA.)

jadafapN jdf jdfh jdfp
Cries, shouts, noises, clamour, or a confusion of cries or shouts or noises: and the sound made in running. (Sgh, K.)

jawaAdifu jwAdf
[pl. of jaAdifapN,] Gazelles going with short steps. (Sgh, K.)

A^ajodafu *
Short: (Lth, K:) applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b2- And [the fem.] jadofaA='u A ewe, or she-goat, having somewhat cut off from her ear. (K.)

mijodafN mjdf
: see mijodaAfN.

mujad~afN mjdf
Straitened: so in the saying, A_in~ahu lamujad~afN Ealayohi AlEayo$u [Verily the means of living are rendered strait to him]: (K:) but in the L, lamajoduwfN↓. (TA.)

mijodaAfN mjdAf
The wing of a bird: (S, Msb, K:) sometimes with *. (Msb.) ― -b2- And hence, (K,) [An oar; a paddle;] a certain appertenance of a ship or boat; (As, S, Msb, K;) a piece of wood at the head of which is a broad board, with which one propels a ship or boat; (M, TA;) and mijodafN↓ [signifies the same;] a certain thing with which a ship, or boat, is put in motion: (Mgh:) pl. majaAdiyfu: (Msb:) from jadafa said of a bird: (As, S, M:) also called mijo*aAfN (IDrd, S, Msb) and miqo*afN and miqo*aAfN. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, as being likened thereto, (tropical:) A whip: and so with *. (TA in this art, and in art. j*f.) ― -b4- And for a similar reason, (tropical:) The neck. (TA.)

majoduwfN mjdwf
A [skin of the kind called] ziq~ having the legs cut off: and so with *. (K, * TA.) And majoduwfu Alyadayoni A man having the arms, or hands, cut off. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] the latter, (assumed tropical:) A niggardly man. (TA.) ― -b3- And majoduwfu Alkum~ayoni, (K, TA,) and Alyadi, and AlqamiySi, and AlA_izaAri, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) Short in respect of the sleeves, (K, TA,) and of the arm, and of the shirt, and of the waistwrapper. (TA.) ― -b4- See also mujad~afN.

1 jadalahu jdl jdlh jdlp
, aor.
jadula
(S, K) and
jadila
, (K,) inf. n. jadolN, (S,) He twisted it firmly; (S, K;) namely, a rope. (S.) ― -b2- He made it firm, strong, or compact. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] jaAriyapN HasanapN Aljadoli (assumed tropical:) [A girl of beautiful compacture; of beautiful, compact make]. (S.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] Eamila EalaY $aAkilatihi Al~atiY judila EalayohaA (assumed tropical:) [He did according to his own particular way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, to which he was strongly disposed by nature]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 2. ＝ -A3- jadala, inf. n. juduwlN, It (a thing) was, or became, hard, and strong. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- jadala AlHab~u fiY Als~unobuli The grain became strong in the ears: (S. O, TA:) or accord. to the K, it means waqaEa [i. e., came into the ears]. (TA.) ― -b3- jadala said of a
young gazelle, &c., He became strong, and followed his mother. (K.) [See also jaAdilN.] ＝ -A4- jadila, aor.
jadala
, inf. n. jadalN, [said in the S to be a subst. from 3, q. v.,] He contended in an altercation, disputed, or litigated, vehemently, or violently. (Msb.)

2 jd~lhu jdl jdlh jdlp
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tajodiylN, (Msb,) He threw him down (S, Msb, K) upon the jadaAlap, (Msb, K,) i. e., (TA,) upon the ground; (S, TA;) as also jadalahu↓, (K,) inf. n. jadolN: (TA:) or the former signifies he did so much, or often. (TA.) You say, TaEanahu fajad~alahu [He thrust him, or pierced him, with a spear or the like, and threw him down &c.]. (S, Msb.) [See also 3.]

3 jAdlhu jAdl jAdlh jAdlp
, inf. n. mujaAdalapN and jidaAlN, (S, Mgh, K,) He contended in an altercation, or disputed, or litigated, with him: (S, TA:) or did so vehemently, or violently, (Mgh, K,) and ably, or powerfully: (K:) [or he did so obstinately, or merely for the purpose of convincing him; for] mjAdlp signifies the disputing respecting a question of science for the purpose of convincing the opponent, whether what he says be wrong in itself or not: (Kull p. 342:) [he wrangled with him:] or jAdl, inf. n. mjAdlp and jdAl, as above, signifies originally he contended in an altercation, or disputed, or litigated, by advancing what might divert the mind from the appearance of the truth and of what was right: and accord. to a later usage, of the lawyers, he compared evidences [in a discussion with another person, or other persons,] in order that it might appear which of those evidences was preponderant: and the doing this is commendable if for the purpose of ascertaining the truth; but otherwise it is blameable: (Msb:) accord. to Er-Rághib, jdAl signifies the competing in disputation or contention, and in striving to overcome [thereby]; from jadalotu AlHabola, meaning, “ I twisted the rope firmly; ” as though each of the two parties twisted the other from his opinion: or, as some say, it originally means the act of wrestling, and throwing down another upon the jadaAlap [or ground]: accord. to Ibn-El-Kemál, a disputing that has for its object the manifesting and establishing of tenets or opinions. (TA.) [See also jadila.]

4 Ajdlt Ajdlt
She (a gazelle) had her young one [sufficiently grown to be] walking with her. (Zj, K.)

5 tajad~ala
see 7.

6 tjAdlwA jAdl tjAdl tjAdlwA
The contended in an altercation, disputed, or litigated, [or did so vehemently, or violently, &c., (see 3,)] one with another. (KL, MA, &c.,)

7 Anjdl Anjdl
He fell down upon the ground: (S:) he became thrown down upon the jadaAlap, i. e., the ground; and in like manner tjd~l↓, he became thrown down, &c., much, or often. (TA.)

8 AijotidaAlN AjtdAl
The act of building, or constructing. (TA.) El-Kumeyt says,
majaAdila $ad~a Alr~aASifuwna A@jotidaAlahaA
(S, TA) i. e. [Pavilions of which the masons have made strong] the building, or construction. (TA.)

[ Q. Q. 1 jadowala jdwl
He ruled a book with lines; such as are ruled round a page, &c. See jadowalN.]

jadolN jdl
Hard, and strong; as also jadilN↓. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- Also, and jidolN↓, A strong, firm, or compact, penis. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or the former, (S, TA,) Any member, or limb: (S, K:) pl. juduwlN. (S, TA.) ― -b4- Also, (K,) or the former, (TA,) Any complete bone, [app. with its flesh,] not broken, nor mixed with aught beside: pl. [of pauc.] A^ajodaAlN and [of mult.] juduwlN. (K, TA.) ― -b5- Also, (K,) or [the pl.] juduwlN , (Lth, TA,) The bones of the arms and legs (Lth, K, TA) of a man: (Lth, TA:) and of the fore and hind legs of the victim termed Eaqiyqap. (TA from a trad.)

jidolN jdl
: see jadolN.

jadalN jdl
Vehemence, or violence, in altercation or disputation or litigation; (S, K;) and ability, or power, to practise it: (K:) [or simply contention in an altercation; disputation; or litigation:] a subst. from jaAdalahu: (S:) or inf. n. of jadila [q. v.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, as a term of logic, A syllogism composed of things well known, or conceded; the object of which is to convince the opponent, and to make him to understand who fails to apprehend the premises of the demonstration. (TA.)

jadilN jdl
: see jadolN. ＝ -A2- Also One who contends in an altercation, disputes, or litigates, vehemently, or violently, (Msb, K,) and ably, or powerfully; and so mijodalN↓ and mijodaAlN↓. (K.)

jadolaA='u jdlA='
fem. of A^ajodalu. ＝ -A2- Also syn., in two senses, with jadiylapN, which see, in two places.

jadowalN jdwl
A rivulet; a streamlet; (S, Msb, K;) [whether natural, or formed artificially for irrigation; being often applied to a streamlet for irrigation, in the form of a trench, or gutter;] it is less than a saAqiyap; and this is less than a nahor: (Mgh in art. saqY:) as also jidowalN: (K:) pl. jadaAwilu. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, AisotaqaAma jadowaluhumo (tropical:) Their affair, or case, was, or became, in a right, a regular, or an orderly, state; like the jdwl when its flow is uniform and uninterrupted. (TA.) And AisotaqaAma jadowalu AlHaAj~i (assumed tropical:) The caravan of the pilgrims formed an uninterrupted line. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also jadowalN as meaning (assumed tropical:) A kind of small vein. (Golius from Ibn-Seenà.)] ― -b4- Hence also jadowalu kitaAbK (assumed tropical:) [A ruled line, (such as is ruled round a page, &c.,) and a column, and a table, of a book]. (TA.)

jadiylN jdyl
applied to a rope, Firmly twisted; as also majoduwlN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- A camel's nose-rein (S, K) of hide, or leather, (S,) firmly twisted: (S, K:) and a cord of hide, or leather, or of [goats'] hair, [that is put] upon the neck of the camel: (K:) and the [kind of women's ornament termed] wi$aAH (S, K) is sometimes thus called: (S:) pl. judulN. (K.)

jadaAlapN jdAl jdAlh jdAlp
The ground: (S, Msb, K:) or hard ground: (TA:) or ground having fine sand. (K.)

jadiylapN jdylh jdylp
A rahoT, [q. v.,] i. e., (TA,) a thing like an A_itob, of hide, or leather, which boys, and menstruous women, wear round the waist in the manner of an A_izaAr. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- A [tribe, such as is termed] qabiylap: and a region, quarter, or tract; syn. naAHiyapN: (S, K:) and so jadolaA='u↓, in both these senses, as used in the phrase, h`*aA EalaY jadolaAy^ihi [This is according to the way of his region, and of his tribe]. (TA.) You say also, *ahaba EalaY jadolaAy^ihi↓, in the K, erroneously, jadolaAnihi, (TA,) i. e., ElY wajohihi [He went his own way], (K, TA,) and naAHiyatihi [towards his region, or quarter, or tract]. (K.) ― -b2- A state, or condition. (K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A particular way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct; syn. $aAkilapN, (S, K,) and TariyqapN. (K.) You say, Eamila EalaY jadiylatihi, i. e. [He did according to his own particular way, &c.; or] Eamila EalaY $aAkilatihi Al~atiY judila EalayohaA [explained above: see 1]. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A determination of the mind. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) The management, or ordering, of a people's affairs; the exercise of the office of Eariyf. (AA, TA.)

jaAdilN jAdl
A boy becoming, or become, strong; vigorous, or robust. (S.) ― -b2- A she-camel's young one above such as is termed raA$iH, which is such as has become strong, and walks with his mother- (As, S.) [See also jadala.]

janodalN jndl
: and junodalN: &c.: see art. jndl.

A^ajodalu *
; fem. jadolaA='u: see majoduwlN, in three places ＝ -A2- Also, [accord. to most of the grammarians A^ajodalN, but accord. to some A^ajodalu,] The hawk; syn. SaqorN; (S, K;) as also A^ajodaliY~N↓: (K:) or an epithet applied to the hawk [and therefore without tenween]: (TA:) pl. A^ajaAdilu. (K.)

A^ajodaliY~N *
: see what next precedes.

mijodalN mjdl
A qaSor [or palace, or pavilion, &c.,] (S, K, TA [in the CK AlqaSiyru is erroneously put for AlqaSoru]) strongly constructed: (TA:) pl. majaAdilu. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also jadilN.

mijodaAlN mjdAl
A piece of rock or stone: [an oblong roofing-stone, of those which, placed side by side, form the roof of a subterranean passage, &c.:] pl. majaAdiylu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jadilN.

majoduwlN mjdwl
: see jadiylN. [Hence,] diroEN majoduwlapN (tropical:) A compact coat of mail; (S, TA;) as also jadolaA='u↓: (S, K:) pl. [of the latter] judolN. (K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A man (K, TA) of slender make, (TA,) slender in the (bones called] qaSab, of firm, or compact, make (muHokamu Alfatoli [as though firmly twisted]): (K, TA:) or slender, slim, thin, spare, lean, or light of flesh; not from emaciation: (S:) and majoduwlu Alxaloqi, as some say, of firm, or compact, make. (TA.) And majoduwlapN (assumed tropical:) A woman small in the belly, and compact in flesh:
(A in art. fyD:) or majoduwlapu Alxaloqi a girl of beautiful compacture; of beautiful, compact make; syn. Hasanapu Aljadoli. (S.) Also saAEidN A^ajodalu↓ (assumed tropical:) [A fore arm, or an upper arm,] of firm, or compact, make. (K, * TA.) And saAqN majoduwlapN and jadolaA='u↓ (tropical:) [A shank of beautiful compacture;] well rounded; well turned; syn. Hasanapu AlT~aY~i. (K, TA.)

1 jadaA Ealayohi jdA Elyh jdA Elyp
, (Msb, K,) and jadaAhu, first pers. jadawotu, (IB, TA,) aor.
jaduwa
, (K,) inf. n. jadowN (Msb, TA) and jadFA; (Msb;) and Ealayohi AjdY↓, (Msb, K,) and AjdAhu↓, (S,) the prep. in the former of these two being suppressed in the latter; (TA;) and AjtdAhu↓; (TA;) He gave him a gift. (S, IB, Msb, K, * TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jadaA Ealayohi $uw^omahu (assumed tropical:) He drew his evil fortune, or ill luck, upon him: an ironical expression; [for it literally means he gave him, or bestowed upon him, his evil fortune.] (TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, Ealayoka AjdY↓ (tropical:) It (a thing) sufficed thee. (Msb.) fiEoluhu $ayoy^FA maA A^ajodaY↓ (tropical:) His deed, or act, did not profit him, or avail him, aught. (Msb.) And Eanoka h`*aA maA yujodiY↓ (assumed tropical:) This does not stand thee in any stead; does not profit thee, or avail thee. (S.) ＝ -A2- jadawotuhu, (S, IB, Msb, K, *) [aor.
jaduwa
,] inf. n. jadowN; (K;) and jadayotuhu; (K in art. jdY;) and Aijotadayotuhu↓, (S, Msb, K, *) and Aisotajodayotuhu↓; I sought, or demanded, (S,) or asked, (IB, Msb, K,) of him (S, IB, Msb, K) a gift, (S,) or a thing wanted. (K.) [See an ex. of the last of these verbs in a verse cited in art. tA.] Hence, mujaAdaApN [inf. n. of jAdY↓]: whence, in a trad., waqado EarafuwA A^an~ahu layosa Einoda marowaAna maAlN yujaAduwnahu Ealayohi, meaning yasoA^aluwnahu Ealayohi [i. e. And they knew that there was not, in the possession of Marwán, property for which they should ask as owed by him]. (TA.)

3 jaAodawa
see 1.

4 A^ajodawa
see 1, in five places. ＝ -A2- Also AjdY, He obtained a gift. (S, Msb.)

8 A_ijotadawa
see 1, in two places.

10 A_isotajodawa
see 1.

jadFA jd jdA
i. q. jadowaY, q. v. ― -b2- Hence, (Har p. 32,) jadFA, (K,) also written jadFY, (ISk, TA,) or maTarN jadFA, (S,) and, accord. to the K, jadowaY↓, but this latter is not known except as signifying “ a gift, ” (TA,) A common, or general, rain; (S, K, TA;) of wide extent: (TA:) or of which the uttermost is not known. (K.) One says also samaA='N jadFA, meaning A rain having a rain following it; making the latter word masc. because it has the force of an inf. n. (TA.) And Aal~`hum~a A@soqinaA gadaqFA wajadFA TabaqFA [O God, water us with a copious rain, and a rain that shall cover the land]: (S, TA:) occurring in a trad. respecting prayer for rain. (TA.) ― -b3- And xayorN jadFA Ample good; (K;) of wide extent to men. (TA.) ＝ -A2- laA A=tiyka jadaA Ald~ahori (S, * K, * TA) i. e. [I will not come to thee] ever, like yada Ald~ahori; (S, TA;) or to the end of time. (K, TA.)

jadowaY jdwY jdwy
A gift; (S, Msb, K;) as also jadFA↓: (S, K:) dual (of the former, TA) jadowaAni and jadoyaAni; (Lh, M, K;) the former, regular; (M, TA;) the latter, anomalous, (M, K, TA,) formed by commutation. (M, TA.) You say, maA A^aSabotu mino fulaAnK jadowaY qaT~u [I have not obtained from such a one a gift ever]. (TA.) And hence the prov., $agalato $iEaAbiY jadowaAYa: see art. $Eb. (S in that art.) ― -b2- See also jadFA.

jadaA='N *
profit, utility, or avail. (S, TA.) So in the saying, fulaAnN qaliylu AljadaA='i Eanoka [Such a one is of little profit, utility, or avail, to thee; will stand thee in little stead]. (S.)

jadiY~N jd jdY jdy jdyy
[originally jadiywN] Munificent, or bountiful. (TA.)

jaAdK jAd
Asking, seeking, or demanding, (S, K,) a bounty, or benefit, (S,) or gift: (K:) pl. judaApN. (TA.)

A^ajodaY *
[More, and most, profitable, useful, or availing]. It is said in a prov., A^ajodaY mina Algayovi fiY A^awaAnihi [More profitable than rain in its season]. (Meyd.)

1 jadayotuhu jdy jdyp jdyth jdytp
: see 1 in art. jdw. ― -b2- One says of the locust, yajodiY kul~a $aYo'K, meaning It eats everything. (TA.) ＝ -A2- lamo A^ajodi mino *`lika bud~FA I found no means of avoiding, or escaping, that, is sometimes said for lamo A^ajido Alx The text appears to have a medial خ in the terminal position. . (Kz, TA in art. wjd.)

2 jd~Y Alr~aHoli jdy AlrHl
, inf. n. tajodiyapN, He made, or put, to the camel's saddle a [jadoyap or] jadiy~ap. (TA.)

4 AjdY A^jd A^jdY A^jdy A^jdyy AjdY Ajdy jdA
It (a wound) flowed [with blood: see jadiy~apN]. (K.)

jadoYN jdy
A kid: (S:) or a male kid; (IAmb, Msb, K;) the female being called EanaAqN: (IAmb, Msb:) or a kid in his first year; (Mgh, Msb;) not yet a year old: (TA:) one should not say jidoYN; (S;) this being a bad dial. var.: (Msb:) pl. (of pauc., TA, applied to three, S) A^ajodK (S, Msb, K) and (of mult., TA, applied to more than three, S) jidaA='N (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jidoyaAnN: (K:) jadaAyaA [as pl. of jadoY] is not allowable. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened thereto, (M, TA,) AljadoYu (assumed tropical:) A certain star, (S, Msb, K,) [the star a of Ursa Minor, commonly called the pole-star,] that revolves with banaAtu naEo$K, (K,) by the side of the [north] pole, by which the kibleh is known, (S,) or according to which the kibleh is turned; (Msb;) the bright star at the extremity of the tail of the Lesser Bear; (Kzw;) the star of the kibleh; (Mgh;) also called jadoYu Alfaroqadi; (Mgh, Msb;) and called by the astronomers AljudaY~u↓, in the dim. form, to distinguish it from what next follows. (Mgh, MF.) [See also AlquTobu.] ― -b3- Hence also, (M, TA,) A certain sign of the Zodiac; (S, K;) [namely, Capricornus;] the tenth of the signs of the Zodiac; (Mgh;) that next to the dalow; unknown to the Arabs [of the classical times]. (K.) This and the former together are called [the] jadoyaAni. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jadoyaAni is also an anomalous dual of jadowaY, q. v. (Lh, M, K.) ＝ -A3- See also what next follows.

jadoyapN jd jdy jdyh jdyp
and jadiy~apN↓, (S, K,) but not jadiydapN, which is used by the vulgar, (S,) [A kind of pad, or] a stuffed thing, (S,) or a stuffed piece (K, TA) of a kisaA=', (TA,) that is put beneath a horse's saddle, (K,) or beneath the two boards (Ald~af~ataAni) of a horse's and of a camel's saddle; [one on either side; for] there are two of such stuffed things: (S:) the pl. of the former is jadayaAtN, (Sb, S,) which may be used as a pl. of mult., (TA,) or jadoyaAtN, so in [some of] the copies of the K, [but omitted in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K,] following the TS, as on the authority of A'Obeyd and AA and En-Nadr, (TA,) and jadoYN↓; (S, IB, [in some copies of the S jadFA, but the former (which I find in two copies of the S) is said by IB to be the right; or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,]) like as $aroYN is of $aroyapN: (IB, TA:) the pl. of jadiy~apN↓ is jadaAyaA. (S.) [See also jadiydapN, and rifaAdapN.]

judaA='N jdA='
, (K in this art.,) or ju*aA='N, (A in art. j*r, and K in art. brj,) [the latter is the term commonly known, An arithmetical square;] the product of multiplication [of a number by itself]; as when you say, the jdA' [or j*A'] of three [in some copies of the K, of three multiplied by three,] is nine; (K, * TA;) also called maAlN. (Msb in art. j*r.) [See ja*orN.]

Aljuday~u AljdY Aljdy jdy
: see jadoYN.

jadaAyapN jdAyh jdAyp
and jidaAyapN A young gazelle; syn. gazaAlN: (K, and so in a copy of the S:) or a young doegazelle; syn. gazaAlapN: (so in another copy of the S:) said by As to be like the EanaAq of goats: (S:) or the male, and the female, of the young of gazelles, when it has attained the age of six months, or seven, and has run, and become strong: or, as some say, the male thereof: pl. jadaAyaA. (M, TA.)

jadiy~apN jd jdy jdyh jdyp
: see jadoyapN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also Flowing blood; (Lh, K;) blood not flowing being termed baSiyrapN: (Lh, TA:) or the former, blood adhering to the body; and the latter, blood upon the ground: (AZ, S:) or the former, a streak of blood: (S:) or the first quantity that flows at once, of blood: (TA:) pl. jadaAyaA. (S.) ― -b2- A piece of musk. (K.) ― -b3- The colour of the face. (K, TA.) You say, AiSofar~ato jadiy~apN wajohihi [The colour of his face became yellow]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- I. q. naAHiyapN [A side; a lateral, or an outward or adjacent, part or portion, region, quarter, or tract; &c.]. (K.) So in the saying, huwa EalaY jadiy~atihi [app. meaning He is keeping to his own side: he is following his own course; like the phrase huwa EalaY Tariyqatihi: or he is by himself; like huwa EalaY waHodihi and Hidatihi]. (TA.)

jaAdK jAd
The locust; because it eats (yajodiY, i. e. yaA^okulu) everything: but the appellation [more] commonly known is jaAbiy^u. (TA.)

jaAdiY~N jAd jAdY jAdy jAdyy
[erroneously written in the CK, in this art. and in art. jwd, without the sheddeh to the Y] Saffron; (Az, IF, K;) as also jaAdiyaA='u↓: (Sgh, K:) the former a rel. n. from AljaAdiyap, or jaAdiyap, a town of AlbaloqaA=', in Syria, said to produce saffron: it is mentioned by Az and IF in this art., being held by them to be of the measure faAEuwlN [originally jaAduwYN]: by J, in art. jwd, as being of the measure faEoliY~N. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Wine; (K, TA;) as resembling saffron in colour. (TA.)

jaAdiyaA='u jAdyA='
: see what next precedes.

1 ja*~ahu *
, (S, A, L, Msb,) aor.
ja*u3a
, (L, Msb,) inf. n. ja*~N, (L, Msb, K,) He cut it, or cut it off; (S, A, L, Msb;) namely, a thing; (S, Msb;) as, for instance, a rope: (L:) or he cut it off utterly; (L, K;) and ja*oja*apN [inf. n. of ja*oja*a↓] signifies the same as ja*~N, i. e. the cutting off utterly: (K:) and Aijoti*aA*N [inf. n. of Ajt*~↓], the act of cutting: (KL:) or ja*~ahu signifies he cut it off utterly and quickly; and in like manner j*~*hu↓ [applied to many objects, or as meaning he cut it, &c., repeatedly, or many times, or in many pieces, or much]. (L.) [Hence,] ja*~a Aln~axola, aor.
ja*u3a
, inf. n. ja*~N and ja*aA*N and ji*aA*N, He cut off the fruit of the palm-trees; syn. Sarama: (Lh, L:) or, accord. to some, j*A* signifies the cutting off of all fruits, and jdAd relates particularly to palmtrees. (TA in art. jd.) [Hence also,] ju*~uwhumo ja*~FA, in a trad. relating to the battle of Honeyn, (assumed tropical:) Cut ye them off utterly; exterminate them by slaughter. (L.) ― -b2- Also, (S, A, L, Msb,) aor.
ja*u3a
, (L,) inf. n. ja*~N, (L, K,) He broke it; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) namely, a thing, (S, Msb,) or a hard thing: (M, L:) and Aijoti*aA*N [inf. n. of Ajt*~↓], also, signifies the act of breaking. (KL.) ― -b3- Also, (L,) inf. n. ja*~N, (L, K,) He hastened it; or hastened to it. (L, K. *) It is said in a prov., respecting one who boldly ventures upon taking a false oath, ja*~ahaA ja*~a AlEayori AlS~il~iyaAnapa He hastened to it as the ass hastens to the plant called Sl~yAnp. (L.)

2 ja*~a3a
see 1.

5 taja*~a3a
see 7.

7 Anj*~ *
It became cut, or cut off: (S, L, Msb, K:) or cut off utterly: or cut off utterly and quickly: and in like manner, tj*~*↓ [said of a number of things, or used in a frequentative or an intensive sense; being quasi-pass. of 2]. (L.)

8 A_ijota*a3a
see 1, in two places.

R. Q. 1 ja*oja*a *
, inf. n. ja*oja*apN: see 1.

ja*~N *
A piece broken off; a fragment: pl. A^ajo*aA*N: so in the phrase, kasarotuhu A^ajo*aA*FA [I broke it in pieces, or fragments]; occurring in a trad., relating to an idol. (L.) [See also ju*aA*N.]

maA Ealayohi ju*~apN *
There is not upon him a piece of rag; i. e., any garment to cover him: (L:) or anything (S, L, K) of clothing: (S, L:) pl. ju*a*N. (Bd in xxi. 59.)

ji*a*N *
: see ju*aA*N.

ja*aA*N *
, with fet-h, The act of separating a thing from another thing (faSolu $aYo'K Eano $aYo'K, accord. to some copies of the K and the TA; [see 1;] accord. to other copies of the K, [probably by mistranscription,] the superiority of a thing over another thing, faDolu $Y'K EalaY $Y'K); as also ja*aA*apN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

ju*aA*N *
and ji*aA*N↓, (S, L, K,) the former of which is the more chaste, (S, L,) and ja*aA*N↓, (L, K,) substs. from ja*~N the act of “ breaking; “ (K;) What is broken, of, or from, a thing: (S, L:) or what is broken, or cut, in pieces: or broken pieces: so in the Kur xxi. 59, in which the word is read in these three different forms: (L:) some also read ju*u*FA, which is pl. of ja*iy*N↓; and some, ju*a*FA, pl. of ju*~apN: (Bd:) or the first signifies fragments of a thing much broken; [as a coll. gen. n.;] and the n. un. is ju*aA*apN↓: (Lth, L:) [or] it is an extr. pl. of ja*iy*N↓; (L;) or i. q. majo*uw*N; and ji*aA*N↓ is a dial. var.; or is pl. of ja*iy*N↓. (Bd.) [See also ja*~N.] ― -b2- Also the first, Small pieces, or particles, of silver: and ju*aA*aAtN↓, pieces of silver: (L:) or the latter, cuttings, or clippings, (S, L, K,) of silver. (M and L in art. q*.) ― -b3- Also Stones containing gold; (Ks, S, L, K;) so called because they are broken: (Ks, S, L:) or stones containing gold &c. which are broken; as also ji*aA*N↓. (Msb.) ― -b4- And j*A* [app. ju*aA*N or ji*aA*N↓], (L,) or ji*a*N↓, (TA,) i. q. firaqN [Distinct parties, or portions, &c., of men or things]. (L, TA.)

ji*aA*N *
: see ju*aA*N, in four places.

ja*iy*N *
and majo*uw*N↓ Cut; or cut off: or cut off utterly: or cut off utterly and quickly: and also broken: (L:) pl. of the former, ju*u*N and ji*aA*N (Bd in xxi. 59) and ju*aA*N, which last is extr. (L. See the paragraph headed ju*aA*N, in three places.) ― -b2- Also the former, (A, K,) and $araAbN ja*iy*N, (A,) and ja*iy*apN↓, (S, L, K,) Meal of parched barley or wheat; syn. sawiyqN; (S, A, L, K;) so prepared [by being moistened with water or with clarified butter &c.] as to be drunk: (A:) and j*y*p↓ is [a mess of the kind called] ja$iy$ap made of coarse swyq; so called because it is broken and made into coarse particles: and a quantity of swyq, or the like, such as a man eats or drinks at one time. (L.)

ja*aA*apN *
: see ja*aA*N.

ju*aA*apN *
and its pl. ju*aA*atN: see ju*aA*N, in two places.

ja*iy*apN *
: see ja*iy*N, in two places.

yado ja*~aA='u *
[fem. of A^aja*~u] (tropical:) An amputated arm or hand: used figuratively: see A^aHa*~u, in art. H*. (L.) ― -b2- raHimN ja*~aA='u (assumed tropical:) A bond of relationship [cut, or severed, or] not made close by affection; expl. by A_i*aA lamo tuwSalo [a well-known phrase: erroneously explained by Golius as meaning “ uterus infœcundus vel interruptæ conceptionis ”]: (Fr, S, L, K:) as also Ha*~aA='u. (Fr, S, L.) ― -b3- yamiynN ja*~aA='u: see Ha*~aA='u. ― -b4- sin~N ja*~aA='u A tooth much broken; or broken in pieces. (K, TA.)

ja*~aAnN *
(As, L, and so in some copies of the K: in other copies of the K, and in the TA, ju*~aAnN:) Soft stones: (As, L, K:) as also ka*~aAnN [q. v.]: (As, L:) n. un. (of both, As, L) with p. (As, L, K.)

majo*uw*N *
: see ja*iy*N. ＝ -A2- EaTaA='N gayoru majo*uw*K [A gift, or stipend,] not cut short, or not interrupted; syn. gayoru maqoTuwEK. (A'Obeyd, S, L.)

1 ja*abahu *
, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
ja*iba
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. ja*obN; (S, Msb;) as also jaba*ahu, (S, TA,) inf. n. jabo*N, of the dial. of Temeem, (TA,) or formed by transposition; (S, TA; [but see art. jb*;]) and Ajt*bhu↓; (S, A, K;) He drew it; dragged it; pulled it; tugged it; strained it; extended it by drawing, or pulling or tugging; stretched it; extended, lengthened, or protracted, it; (S, A, K;) namely, a thing; and sometimes relating to an ideal object. (TA.) ― -b2- ja*aba mina AlA_inaA='i, (S,) or ja*aba mina AlmaA='i, (K,) or ja*aba AlmaA='a, (A, Msb,) nafasFA, (S, A, Msb, K,) or nafasayoni, (S, A, Msb,) (tropical:) He drank (S, K) from the vessel, (S,) or of the water, (K,) by putting his mouth into it, [a draught, or two draughts:] (S, K:) or he conveyed [or drew up] into the innermost parts of his nose [a draught, or two draughts, of the water]. (Msb.) And ja*abato labanahaA (tropical:) She (a camel) drank her milk when she was milked. (A. [But see what next follows: and see also 5.]) ― -b3- ja*abato, said of a she-camel, (S, K,) and of a she-ass also, aor.
ja*iba
, inf. n. ji*aAbN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) She became scant of milk; (S, K;) she drew her milk (ja*abato labanahaA) from her udder so that it went away upwards. (TA.) ― -b4- ja*abahu, (K,) or ja*abahu Eano A^um~ihi, (S, A,) aor.
ja*iba
, inf. n. ja*obN, (TA,) (tropical:) He weaned him; namely, a colt, (S, A, K,) and a young camel, and a lamb. (TA.) And one says of a mother, ja*abato waladahaA (tropical:) She weaned her young one: so accord. to Lh, who does not specify the kind. (ISd, TA.) And accord. to the T, ju*iba is said of a child, or of a lamb or kid, meaning (tropical:) He was weaned. (TA.) ― -b5- ja*abahu and jaA*abahu↓ He transferred, or removed, it (a thing) from its place. (K.) ― -b6- ja*abatohu (tropical:) She repelled him, or rejected him; namely, a man who sought her in marriage; (T, A, TA;) as though from the saying jaA*abotuhu faja*abotuhu [which see below]; (T, TA;) [i. e.] as though she contended with him and overcame him, and thus he became separated from her; (T, A, TA;) as also jaba*atohu. (T, TA.) [Accord. to the TA, jaA*abatohu↓ has the same meaning; but I think that this is a mistake of a copyist.] ― -b7- ja*aba fulaAnN Habola fulaAnihi (assumed tropical:) Such a one severed the bond of his union. (M, TA.) And ja*aba fulaAnN AlHabola bayonanaA (tropical:) Such a one severed the bond of union between us. (A, TA.) ― -b8- ja*aba Aln~axolapa, aor.
ja*iba
,
(AHn, K,) inf. n. ja*obN, (AHn, TA,) He cut off the ja*ab [q. v.] of the palm-tree, (AHn, K,) to eat it. (AHn, TA.) ― -b9- ja*aba AlEadowa (assumed tropical:) He ran quickly. (L in art. mEd.) See also 7. ― -b10- ja*ab Al$~ahoru, (S, A, K,) aor.
ja*iba
, inf. n. ja*obN, (TA,) (tropical:) The greater part of the month (EaAm~atuhu, S, A, K, i. e. A^akovaruhu, TA) passed. (S, A, K.) ＝ -A2- ja*abahu, aor.
ja*uba
, He overcame him in AlmujaA*abap (K) [lit. drawing, dragging, pulling, &c.; (see 3;) but also] used figuratively [as meaning (tropical:) he overcame him in contention]. (TA.) You say, jaA*abotuhu↓ faja*abotuhu [I contended with him in drawing, dragging, &c., and I overcame him therein: and also] (tropical:) I contended with him and I overcame him. (T, A, * TA.)

3 jA*bhu *
He contended with him in drawing, dragging, pulling or tugging, straining, or stretching, &c. (L in art. md.) And jA*bhu AlHabola [He contended with him in pulling the rope]. (Mgh in art. nzE .) And jA*bhu Alv~awob He contended with him in pulling the garment, or piece of cloth. (A.) And jA*bwA Al$~aYo'a, inf. n. mujaA*abapN, They pulled the thing, every one of them to himself. (Msb.) And jaA*abotuhu faja*abotuhu: see 1, last sentence: [a phrase having two meanings: for] you say, jaA*abaA, (K, TA,) inf. n. mujaA*abapN (TA) and ji*aAbN, (Har p. 636,) meaning (assumed tropical:) They two contended [in any manner], each with the other: (K, TA:) and [in like manner,] tjA*bA↓, (K,) inf. n. tajaA*abN, (S,) (assumed tropical:) They two contended together. (S, * K.) You say also, kaAnato bayonahumo mujaA*abaAtN vum~a A@t~afaquwA (tropical:) [There were contentions between them: then they agreed]. (A, TA.) And jaA*abotuhu Al$~aYo'a (assumed tropical:) I contended with him for the thing. (S.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places, beside the instance in the last sentence.

5 tj*~bhu *
(tropical:) He drank it; (A, K;) namely, milk: said of a pastor. (A.)

6 tjA*bwA Alv~awoba *
They contended together in pulling the garment, or piece of cloth. (A.) [Hence,] tjA*bwA A^aToraAfa AlkalaAmi (tropical:) [They contended together in discourse, talk, or conversation]. (A.) See also 3. ― -b2- And see 7.

7 Anj*b *
It (a thing) was, or became, drawn, dragged, pulled, tugged, strained, extended by drawing or pulling or tugging, or stretched, &c.; it dragged, or trailed along; syn. Anjr~. (S and K in art. jr.) ― -b2- It was, or became, transferred, or removed, from its place; and so tjA*b↓. (K.) ― -b3- Ainoji*aAbN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Quick going or journeying or travelling. (S.) [You say, Anj*b, and Als~ayora ja*aba↓, (the latter occurring in the TA in art. xlj, &c., like ja*aba AlEadowa, mentioned above, see 1,) (assumed tropical:) He went, or journeyed, or travelled, quickly.] And Anj*bwA fiY Als~ayori and Anj*b bihimu Als~ayoru (tropical:) They brought, or purveyed, wheat, or corn, or provisions, from afar. (A, TA.)

8 Ajt*bhu *
: see 1. ― -b2- Also He seized it, or took it, or carried it off, by force. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) He called, summoned, or invited, him. (Ham p. 645.)

ja*obN *
(assumed tropical:) Quick journeying or travelling. (ISd, K.) ― -b2- And The stopping, or a stoppage, of the flow of saliva (AinoqiTaAEu Alr~iyqi). (S.)

ja*abN *
The pith that is at the head of the palmtree, from which the [fibres called] liyf are pulled off, and which is then eaten; as though so called because pulled off [or cut] from the tree; (TA;) the heart, pith, or cerebrum, (jum~aAr,) of the palm-tree; (AHn, S, TA;) so in some copies of the K; (TA;) i. e. the $aHom of the palm-tree: (S:) or, as in some copies of the K, and in the M and L, only such as is coarse: (TA:) as also ji*aAbN↓: (K:) n. un. ja*abapN. (S, K.) [See also ja*amapN.]

ja*obapN mino gazolK *
A portion that is drawn by a single pull of spun thread, or yarn. (S.) [Hence,] maA A^aEoTaAhu ja*obapa gazolK (tropical:) He gave him not aught. (A, TA.) ― -b2- bayoniY wabayona Almanozili ja*obapN (assumed tropical:) Between me and the place of alighting is a piece [of land or country, or a tract], meaning a distance: (S:) or a far-extending piece [of land or country]. (K.) And bayonanaA wabayona baniY fulaAnK ja*obapN, and nabo*apN, (assumed tropical:) Between us and the sons of such a one is a small space, or short distance; i. e., they are near to us. (ISh, TA.)

A^axa*a fiY waAdiY ja*abaAtK *
[He took his way into the valley of Jedhebát]: (K:) or, as given by Meyd, [and in the A,] waqaEuwA [they fell into the valley of Jedhebát]: a celebrated prov.: (TA:) applied to a man who has missed the object of his aim or pursuit; (K, * TA;) j*bAt being said to be derived from ja*aba AlS~abiY~a “ he weaned the boy; ” because, in weaning, a child sometimes dies: or from Ainoja*abuwA fiY Als~ayori, or Ainoja*aba bihimu Als~ayoru, explained above: or, accord. to some, the right reading is jadabaAtK: or, as Az says, on the authority of As, the most correct reading is xadibaAtK, from xadabatohu AlHay~apu “ the serpent bit him; ” and the prov. is applied to him who falls into perdition, and to him who wanders in perplexity from the object of his aim or desire. (TA.) [See also another reading in art. xrb.]

ji*ib~aAnN *
The sandal-thong that is between the great and second toes. (K, TA.) You say, maA A^agonaY EaniY ji*ib~aAnFA He did not stand me in stead of, or avail me as much as, a sandal-thong that is between the great and second toes. (AA, TA.)

ja*aAbi *
, indecl., [as a proper name, changed in form from AljaA*ibu,] (TA,) Death: (ISd, K:) so called because it draws away the soul. (ISd, TA.)

ji*aAbN *
: see ja*abN.

ja*uwbN *
: see jaA*ibN.

ja*~aAbapN *
Hairs, (TA,) or coarse hairs, or a coarse hair, (K,) tied, and made into a snare, (TA,) for catching larks. (K, TA.)

jaA*ibN *
(tropical:) A she-camel that has exceeded the usual time of pregnancy, and passed beyond the time [of the year] when she had been covered: (Lh, TA:) or a she-camel that has extended, or protracted, the period of her pregnancy to eleven months. (A, TA.) (assumed tropical:) A she-camel, (S, K,) and a she-ass, (TA,) scant of milk; (S, K, TA;) as also jaA*ibapN and ja*uwbN↓: (K:) pl. [of the first and second] jawaA*ibu and ji*aAbN. (S, K.)

juw*aAbN *
(M, K) and *uwbaAjN, the latter formed by transposition, (L and TA in art. *bj,) A kind of food, prepared with sugar and rice and flesh-meat: (M, K:) [from the Persian kuw*aAbo, as observed by Golius:] it might be hastily imagined to be arabicized from juwzaho A=bo; but this is not the case: (TA:) [n. un. with p: or] juw*aAbapN is a cake of bread (xubozapN) put into the oven (tan~uwr), and having suspended over it a bird or some flesh-meat, the gravy of which flows upon it as long as it is cooking; also called A^um~u Alfaraji, because it removes one's anxiety for seasoning, or condiment. (Har p. 227.)

1 ja*ara *
, (A, TA,) aor.
ja*ura
, (TK,) inf. n. ja*orN, (A, K,) He cut, or cut off, or severed, (K, TA,) a thing: (TA:) and (K) he extirpated, or cut off entirely, (A, K,) a thing; (A;) as also j*~r↓; (S;) and Aj*r↓, inf. n. A_ijo*aArN. (AZ, K.)

2 ja*~ara
see 1.

4 A^ajo*ara
see 1.

7 Anj*r *
It became cut, or cut off, or severed. (K, TA.)

ja*orN *
(As, IAar, S, A, Msb, K) and ji*orN↓ (AA, S, K) The root, or lower part, (As, S, A, Msb, K,) of anything: (As, S, A:) or (so in the K, but in other lexicons “ and ”) particularly, of the tongue: (Sh, A, Msb, K:) and of the penis: (Sh, K:) and of a horn (S, * A) of a cow (S) or of a bull; (A;) or the horn [itself] of a cow: (TA:) and the latter word, the root, or foot, or lowest part, of a tree: (TA:) and the former word, the base of the neck: (El-Hejeree, K:) pl. ju*uwrN. (K.) Hence, nazalati AlmaHab~apu fiY ja*ori qalobihi Love took up its abode in the bottom (A^aSol) of his heart. (A.) And [hence] it is said in a trad., A_in~a AlA^amaAnapa nazalato fiY ja*ori quluwbi Alr~ijaAli [app. meaning, Verily reason, or intellect, or rather conscience, each of which is a trust committed by God to man, and a faculty which renders him responsible for his faith and works, (see, in art. Amn, an explanation of A^amaAnapN as used in the Kur xxxiii. 72,) hath taken up its abode in the bottom of the hearts of men]. (S.) ― -b2- Also, both words, The origin, or stock, from which one springs. (TA.) ― -b3- And the former, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and the latter, or the latter only, (K,) or the former only, (IAar, TA,) A root of a number; (A;) an arithmetical root; (Mgh, K;) [a square root;] a number that is multiplied by itself; (Msb;) as when you say that ten multiplied by ten is a hundred; (Mgh, Msb;) and three multiplied by three is nine; (A;) in the former of which cases, ten is the j*r, (Mgh, Msb,) i. e., the j*r of a hundred; (Mgh;) and in the latter, three; (A;) and in each case, the [square or] product of the multiplication is called the maAl, (Msb,) or the ju*aA=', (A,)
or the maj*uwr↓: (Mgh:) [pl. of pauc. A^jo*aArN, and of mult. ju*uwrN.] It is of two kinds, naATiqN [i. e. rational], and A^aSam~u [i. e. surd, or irrational]: the latter known only to God, accord. to a saying of 'Áïsheh. (Mgh.)

ji*orN *
: see ja*orN.

juw^o*arN *
and juw^o*urN (S, K) and juw*arN and jawo*arN and jaw^o*arN and jiy*arN↓, (K, TA,) the last of which is written in some copies of the K [and in the CK] jayo*arN, (TA,) The young one of a wild cow: (S, K:) pl. of the first and second, jaA=*iru. (S.) ISd thinks that jawodarN and jiy*arN are Arabic, and that juw^o*arN and juw^o*urN are Persian. (TA.) See also mujo*irN.

jiy*arN *
or jayo*arN: see what next precedes.

mujo*irN *
A wild cow having a young one. (ISd, K.) Hence we decide that the ' in jw^*r↓ is augmentative; and because it often occurs as an augmentative in the second place. (ISd, TA.) [In the S it is regarded as a radical.]

majo*uwrN *
: see Ha*orN.

4 Aj*E *
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_ijo*aAEN, (Mgh, Msb,) He (a beast) became such as is denoted by the term ja*aEN; (TA;) said of the offspring of the sheep or goat, he became in his second year; of that of the cow, and of a solidhoofed beast, he became in his third year; and of that of the camel, he became in his fifth year: (S, Msb, K:) but sometimes, when said of the offspring of the ewe, it means he became six months old, or nine months old; and such is allowable as a victim for sacrifice: (S:) IAar says, it denotes a time, not a tooth (Mgh, Msb) growing or falling out: (Msb:) and said of a she-goat, Aj*Et means she became a year old, and sometimes, less than a year, by reason of plenty of food; and of a sheep, Aj*E means, when from young parents, he became from six months old to seven; and when from very old parents, from eight months old to ten. (Mgh, Msb.) [See ja*aEN, below.]

6 tjA*E *
(tropical:) He (a man) pretended to be a ja*aE [or youth]. (TA.)

ji*oEN *
The trunk of a palm-tree: (S, * Msb, K:) or, accord to some, only after it has become dry: or, accord. to some, only after it has been cut: (TA:) or the trunk of a tree when the head has gone: (Ham p. 656:) in the Kur, xix. 23, it is applied to the trunk of a palm-tree which had become dry and was without a head; (Bd;) therefore this does not indicate any restriction nor the contrary: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^jo*aAEN (Msb) and [of mult.] ju*uwEN. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- The beam of a roof. (Msb, TA.)

ja*aEN *
A beast (Lth, Mgh) before the vaniY~ [q. v.], (Lth, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) by one year; when it may for the first time be ridden and used: (Lth:) fem. with p: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. masc. [of pauc.] A^jo*aAEN (Yoo, O) and [of mult.] ju*oEaAnN (Yoo, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ji*oEaAnN (L, Msb) and ji*aAEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ju*aAEN; (Yoo, O;) and pl. fem. ja*aEaAtN: (S, Msb:) it is a name applied to the beast in a particular time, not denoting a tooth growing or falling out: (S, K:) but it differs in its application to different kinds of beasts: (Az:) applied to a sheep or goat, it means a year old; (IAar;) in his second year: (Mgh:) or, applied to a sheep, a year old; and sometimes less than a year, by reason of plenty of food; (IAar;) or eight months old, (Az, Mgh, TA,) or nine; (TA;) or, when from young parents, from six months old to seven; and when from very old parents from eight months old to ten; (IAar, Mgh;) and the sheep thus called is a satisfactory victim for sacrifice: (Mgh, TA:) and applied to a goat, a year old; (Az, Mgh;) or in its second year; (AZ;) but the goat thus called is not a satisfactory victim for sacrifice: (Mgh:) applied to a bull, it means in like manner in his second year; (Mgh;) or in his third year; and the bull thus called is not a satisfactory victim for sacrifice: (TA:) applied to a horse, it means in his third year; (IAar;) or in his fourth year: (Mgh:) [but see qaAriHN:] and applied to a camel, in his fifth year; (Az, Mgh;) fem. with p; and this (a j*Ep) is what must be given for the poor-rate when the camels are more than sixty. (Az, TA.) [See also $aSarN.] ― -b2- A youth, or young man. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) One who is light-witted, or weak and stupid, like a youth: opposed in this sense to baAzilN as meaning “ old: ” (IAar, TA:) or one whose teeth have fallen out, here and there, [as though likened to a beast thus termed that has shed some of his first teeth,] because he has drawn near to his appointed term of life. (TA: [but it is not quite clear whether this explanation relate to j*E or to bAzl.]) ― -b4- (tropical:) [A novice, or recent beginner.] You say, fulaAnN fiY h`*aA AlA^amori ja*aEN (tropical:) [Such a one, in this affair, is a novice, or recent beginner,] when he has begun it recently. (S, Z.) ― -b5- Ald~ahoru ja*aEN A^abadFA (tropical:) Time, or fortune, is ever new, like a youth. (K, * TA.) ― -b6- Hence, (TA,) AlA^azolamu Alja*aEu (tropical:) Time, or fortune; (S, K;) as in the saying, A^aholakahumu AlA^azolamu Alja*aEu (tropical:) Time, or fortune, destroyed them; and laA A=tiyka AlA^azolama Alja*aEa (tropical:) I will not come to thee ever. (TA.) [See also art. zlm.] And accord. to some, (S,) The lion: (S, K:) but this is a mistake. (IB, L.) ― -b7- And hence, (TA,) A^um~u Alja*aEi (tropical:) Calamity, or misfortune. (K, TA.) ― -b8- A^aEadotu AlA^amora ja*aEFA (tropical:) I renewed the thing, or affair, as it was at the first: as, for instance, a war which had been extinguished. (TA.) And far~a AlA^amora ja*aEFA [signifies, in like manner, (tropical:) He recommenced the thing: or] he commenced the thing. (TA.) And fur~a AlA^amoru ja*aEFA (tropical:) The thing was commenced: (TA:) or the thing returned to its first state; it recommenced. (K in art. fr.) ― -b9- ju*oEaAnu AljibaAli (assumed tropical:) Small mountains. (K.)

ju*uwEapN *
[The state of being what is denoted by the term ja*aEN;] a subst. from A_ijo*aAEN [inf. n. of Aj*E]. (TA.)

ja*oEamapN *
Young; (S, K, * TA;) not arrived at puberty: (TA:) originally ja*oEapN; (S, K;) the m being augmentative: (S:) the p is either to give intensiveness to the meaning, or to denote the fem. gender; the word being considered as implying the meaning of nafosN or juv~apN. (TA.)

xaruwfN mutajaA*iEN *
[A lamb approaching the age in which the term ja*aEN is applied to him: expl. in some copies of the K by daAnK: in others, by waAnK:] in the copies of the O, expl. by waAnK mina AlA_ijo*aAEi: in the TS and in the A, by daAnK, which is probably the right reading. (TA.)

superEntry.head: Quasi j*Em
superEntry.entry:
ja*oEamapN *
: see art. j*E.

1 ja*afahu *
, (AA, S, K,) aor.
ja*ifa
, (K,) inf. n. ja*ofN, (AA, S,) He cut it; or cut it off: (AA, S, K:) and so with d. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jadafa said of a bird, a dial. var. of jadafa: (S:) both signify He (a bird) went quickly (K, TA) with his wings; generally, when one of the wings had been shortened; (TA;) as also Aj*f↓ and Anj*f↓: and so, both of these, with d. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence, ja*afa biAlmijo*aAfi; and ja*afa biAls~afiynapi, or Als~afiynapa; i. q. jadafa, q. v.] ― -b3- ja*afa fiY mi$oyatihi He (a man) was quick in his manner of walking: (AO, S:) and so with d: (AAF, TA in art. jdf:) as also tj*~f↓. (TA.) And ja*afato She (a woman) walked like those that are short: and she (a gazelle, and a woman, TA) went with short steps; as also Aj*ft↓: and so, both, with d. (K.) ― -b4- ja*afati Als~amaA='u biAlv~aloji The sky cast down snow: and so with d. (TA.) ＝ -A3- ja*afa Al$~aYo'a i. q. ja*abahu. (TA.)

4 A^ajo*afa
see 1, in two places.

5 taja*~afa
see 1.

7 A_inoja*afa
see 1.

mijo*aAfN *
, (S, TA,) in the K mijo*aAfapN↓, but the former is the more proper, (TA,) i. q. mijodaAfN; (S;) The wing of a bird: and so with d. (Msb in art. jdf.) ― -b2- And [hence, An oar; a paddle;] a certain thing with which a ship, or boat, is propelled. (S, * TA.) ― -b3- And hence, as being likened thereto, A whip: (Abu-l-Ghowth, S:) and so with d. (TA in art. jdf.)

majo*uwfN *
A [skin of the kind called] ziq~ having the legs cut off: and so with d. (K * and TA in this art. and in art. jdf.)

mijo*aAfapN *
: see mijo*aAfN.

1 ja*ala *
, (aor.
ja*ula
