, TK,) inf. n. ju*uwlN, It stood erect, and was firm, (K, TA,) like the ji*ol of a tree. (TA.) And He set himself up as an antagonist to others, in fight. (TA in art. Hk.)
And said of a chameleon, It became erect; as also Astj*↓. (TA.) You say also, baAta yasotajo*ilu↓ EalaY Zahori daAb~atihi (tropical:) He slept [during the night] erect, without commotion, upon the back of his beast. (TA.) ＝ -A2- ja*ila, (S, K,) aor.
ja*ala
, (K,) inf. n. ja*alN, (S,) He was, or became, joyful, glad, or happy; as also Ajt*l↓. (S, K.)

4 Aj*lhu *
He made him joyful, glad, or happy. (S, K.)

8 A_ijota*ala
see 1.

10 A_isotajo*ala
see 1, in two places.

ja*olN *
: see what next follows, in two places.

ji*olN *
(S, K) and ja*olN↓ (K) The trunk, stem, stump, or lower part, (A^aSol) of a tree &c., after the branch or the like has gone; pl. [of pauc.] A^ajo*aAlN and [of mult.] ji*aAlN and ju*uwlN and ju*uwlapN, (K,) which last is pl. of ja*olN: (TA:) or a large trunk, or lower portion, of a tree; (S, * K;) pl. A^ajo*aAlN: (S:) and a branch, or piece of wood, like the fruit-stalk of the raceme of a palm-tree. (K.) [Hence,] EaAda A_ilaY ja*olihi↓ [or ji*olihi] (assumed tropical:) He returned to his original state, or condition. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the former, A post, or piece of wood, that is set up (S, K) in the place where camels lie down, at their watering-place, (S,) for the mangy camels to rub themselves against it. (S, K. *) Hence, (S, K,) the saying of El- Hobáb Ibn-El-Mundhir, (S,) AlmuHak~aku A^anaA ju*ayoluhaA↓ waEu*ayoquhaA Almuraj~abu (assumed tropical:) [I am their much-rubbed little rubbing-post, and their propped little palm-tree loaded with fruit, or their honoured little palmtree &c.: see art. rjb]: (S, * K, * TA:) i. e., I am of those by means of whose counsel, or advice, people seek relief, like as the mangy camels seek relief from their mange by rubbing themselves against the post above mentioned, (TA,) and one having a family that will aid and defend me: (TA in art. rjb:) the dim. is here used for the purpose of aggrandizement. (K. [See also art. Hk.]) And hence, (TA,) huwa ji*olu maAlK (tropical:) He is a gentle manager of cattle: (S, * K, * TA:) likened to the ji*ol that is set up. (TA.) One says also, A_in~ahu ji*olu rihaAnK, i. e., SaAHibuhu [app. meaning, (assumed tropical:) Verily he is one who is constantly engaged in contending for stakes, or wagers; rhAn being here an inf. n. of raAhana; not a pl. of rahonN; for if it were the latter, the explanation would be SaAHibuhaA]. (K.) ― -b3- A small quantum of property, or a small number of cattle; (K;) as though it were the original stock thereof. (TA.) ― -b4- The summit, or head, of a mountain; and a prominent portion thereof: pl. A^jo*aAlN. (K.) ― -b5- The side of a sandal. (K.)

ja*ilN *
: see what next follows.

ja*olaAnu *
[in copies of the K with tenween, but correctly without tenween, for the fem. is ja*olaA='u,] Joyful, glad, or happy; (S, K;) as also ja*ilN↓; (K;) and jaA*ilN↓ occurs in poetry: (IDrd, K:) pl. ju*olaAnN. (K.) You say, nafosuhu ja*olaA='u bi*`lika His soul is joyful, glad, or happy, by means of that. (TA.)

ju*ayolN *
dim. of ji*olN, q. v.

jaA*ilN *
[part. n. of ja*ala] (assumed tropical:) Erect, in his place, not moving therefrom; likened to the ji*ol that is set up in the place where camels lie down, at their watering-place, for the mangy camels to rub themselves against it. (S.) You say, baAta jaA*ilFA EalaY Zahori daAb~atihi (tropical:) He slept [during the night] erect, without commotion, upon the back of his beast. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also ja*olaAnu.

1 ja*amahu *
, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ja*ima
(Msb, K, TA) and
ja*uma
also, (accord. to some copies of the K,) inf. n. ja*omN, (S, Msb, K,) He cut it off; (S, Msb, K;) and so j*~mhu↓: (K:) or j*~m signifies he cut off many things; or cut off much, or frequently: and ja*omN signifies also the cutting off quickly. (TA.) [It is like xa*amahu.] You say, ja*ama yadahi, (Msb, K,) aor.
ja*ima
, inf. n. as above, (Msb,) He cut off, or amputated, his arm, or hand; (Msb, K;) as also Aji*mihA↓, (K,) inf. n. A_ijo*aAmN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ja*ama fulaAnN Habola wiSaAlihi (tropical:) Such a one severed the bond of his union; as also ja*abahu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- ja*ima, (S, Msb,) aor.
ja*ama
, (Msb,) inf. n. ja*amN , He (a man) had his arm, or hand, cut off, or amputated; was maimed of it. (S, Msb.) You say, Hat~aY maA Al~a*iY A^jo*amahu↓ j~*ima [What is it that has maimed him of his arm, or hand, so that he has become maimed of it?] (TA.) ― -b2- And ja*imiti Alyadu, aor.
ja*ama
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. ja*amN, (Msb,) The arm, or hand, was cut off, or amputated. (Msb, K.) ＝ -A3- ju*ima He (a man, S, Msb) was, or became, affected, or smitten, with the disease termed ju*aAm. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.)

2 ja*~ama
see 1.

4 A^ajo*ama
see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- A_ijo*aAmN also signifies The being quick in pace, or going. (Lth, TA.) You say, Aj*m fiY sayorihi, (S,) or Aj*m Als~ayora, (K,) He (a camel, S) hastened, or was quick, in his pace, or going. (S, K.) And Aj*m said of a horse, (Lh, K,) and the like, of such as run, (Lh, TA,) He ran vehemently. (Lh, K.) ― -b2- Aj*m Eani Al$~aYo'i He abstained, or desisted, from the thing. (S, * K.) ― -b3- Aj*m He decided, determined, or resolved, upon it. (K.)

5 taja*~ama
see 7.

7 Anj*m *
It was, or became, cut off; (S, K;) as also tj*~m↓: (K:) [or the latter is said of a number of things; or implies muchness, or frequency:] the two verbs are syn. [respectively] with AinoqaTaEa and taqaT~aEa. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence] you say, Anj*m Eani Alr~akobi (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, cut off from the company of riders upon camels. (TA.) And En-Nábighah says,
Sad~ato sulayomaY waA^amosaY HaboluhaA A@noja*amaA
[Suleymà has turned away, and the bond of her union with me has become severed]. (S.)

ja*omN *
: see the next paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also A cessation of the supply of corn or other provision. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A rope cut off, or severed. (TA.) ― -b2- A man whose extremities have fallen off in pieces, piece after piece, in consequence of the disease termed ju*aAm. (TA; but in this last sense, the word is there written without any syll. signs.)

ji*omN *
The root, source, origin, or original, or the fundamental or essential or principal part, syn. A^aSol, (S, Msb, K,) of a thing, (S, Msb, TA,) whatever that thing be; (TA;) as also ja*omN↓: (S, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajo*aAmN and [of mult.] ju*uwmN. (K.) ― -b2- The family of a people; their kinsfolk: whence the saying, in a trad., lamo yakono rajulN mino qurayo$K A_il~aA lahu ji*omN bimak~apa [There was not a man of Kureysh but he had kinsfolk in Mekkeh]. (TA.) [And app. The main stock from which tribes are derived: for,] accord. to some, it ranks before $aEobN. (TA voce baTonN.) ― -b3- The places [or place] of growth of the teeth. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, El-Hárith Ibn-Waaleh, (TA,)
AaloA=na lam~aA A@boyaD~a masorubatiY
waEaDiDotu mino naAbiY EalaY ji*omi
(S, TA,) [Now, when the hair in the middle of my bosom, extending downwards to my navel, has become white, and I have bitten upon the place of growth of my canine tooth]: i. e., I have become old, and eaten upon the j*m of my nAb. (TA.) ― -b4- The lower, or lowest, part, or the foundation, of a wall: (Mgh from a trad.:) or the remains thereof: or a portion thereof. (TA.) ― -b5- See also ji*omapN.

ja*imN *
Quick; swift. (K.)

ja*omapN *
The place of the arm, or hand, where it is cut off, or amputated; as also ja*amapN↓. (K.)

ju*omapN *
The defect, or deficiency, of him who has had his arm, or hand, amputated, or who has lost the end-joints of his fingers: so accord. to the copies of the K: but in the L, the defect, or deficiency [resulting] from the amputation of the arm or hand (mina AlA_ijo*aAmi.) (TA.) ＝ -A2- maA samiEotu lahu ju*omapF, with damm, meaning [I heard him not utter] a word, is not of established authority. (ISd, TA.)

ji*omapN *
A piece cut off (S, K) of a rope &c., (S,) or of a thing of which the extremity has been cut off, the lower, or principal, part remaining; (K;) as also ji*omN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- A whip: (S, K:) because it becomes cut by that which is beaten with it. (TA.) ― -b3- The part of a whip of which the slender extremity has become much cut [by use], the lower, or principal, part remaining; pl. ji*amN: (L, TA:) or the remaining part of a whip; its lower, or principal, portion. (As, TA.) ― -b4- A thick piece of wood, having fire at the end of it or not; [i. e. a brand, or fire-brand;] like ji*owapN. (AO, S and TA in art. j*w.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A company of men [as though cut off from others]. (TA.)

ja*amapN *
: see ja*omahN. ― -b2- Also The uppermost pith of the palm-tree; which is the best; (K;) like ja*abapN. (TA.) ― -b3- And Dates that come forth upon one base. (TA.)

ju*aAmN *
[Elephantiasis; a species of leprosy; the leprosy that pervaded Europe in the latter part of the Middle Ages;] a certain disease, (S, K,) arising from the spreading of the black bile throughout the whole person, so that it corrupts the temperament of the members, and the external condition thereof; and sometimes ending in the dissundering, or corrosion, (so accord. to different copies of the K, TA,) of the members, and their falling off, in consequence of ulceration; (K, TA;) so called because it dissunders the flesh, and causes it to fall off; (Msb;) or because the fingers, or toes, become cut off: (TA:) it is a cracking of the skin, and a dissundering, and gradual falling off, of the flesh. (Mgh.)

nawFYja*uwmN *
A tract towards which one journeys separating lovers or objects of love. (TA.)

ja*iwmN *
Cut off; amputated. (S, Msb, TA.) [See also A^ajo*amu.]

ju*aAmapN *
What remains, of seed-produce, after the reaping. (S.) ― -b2- [See also juraAmapN, in two places.]

jaAmN jAm
[an epithet] of the measure faE~aAlN from Alja*omu meaning AlqaToEu: so in the phrase ja*~aAmu Haboli AlhawaY [Wont to sever the bond of love], in a verse of Ows Ibn-Thaalabeh. (Ham p. 334.)

A^ajo*amu *
Having his arm, or hand, cut off, or amputated: (S, Msb, K:) or having lost the endjoints of his fingers: (K:) fem. ja*omaA='u: (Msb:) pl. ja*omaY. (S.) It is said in a trad., mano taEal~ama AlquroA=na vum~a nasiyahu laqiYa A@ll~`ha yawoma AlqiyaAmapi wahuwa A^ajo*amu, (A 'Obeyd, S, *) i. e., [He who learns the Kur-án and then forgets it shall meet God on the day of resurrection] having his arm, or hand, cut off: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or having lost all his limbs, or members: (Kt, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) having his plea cut off; having no tongue with which to speak, nor any plea in his hand: (IAth, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) having his means of access cut off: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) with his hand devoid of good and of recompense. (IAar, El-Khattábee, TA.) And in another trad., kul~u xuTobapK layosa fiyhaA $ahaAdapN kaA@loyadi Alja*omaA='i [Every oration from the pulpit in which there is not an acknowledgment of the unity of God and of the mission of Mohammad is like the arm of which the hand is amputated]. (TA.) ― -b2- Alk~f~u Alja*omaA='u [The amputated hand;] (assumed tropical:) a name of the star a of Cetus; (so in the Egyptian Almanacs;) [i. e.] the star that is in the head of Cetus: so called because it is less extended [from the Pleiades] than that called Alkaf~a AlxaDiybu. (Kzw. [See Alkaf~u AlxaDiybu in art.xDb.]) ― -b3- naEolN ja*omaA='u (assumed tropical:) A sandal of which the [thong called] qibaAl [which is between two of the toes] is cut, or cut off, or severed. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also majo*uwmN.

muja*~amN *
: see majo*uwmN. ＝ -A2- Also A man tried, or proved, and strengthened by experience in affairs. (TA.)

rajulN mijo*aAmN *
and mijo*aAmapN↓, [the latter of a very rare measure, (see miEozaAbapN,)] (assumed tropical:) A man who decides affairs. (K.) (tropical:) A man who, loving and being loved, when he is sensible of evil treatment quickly cuts the tie of affection: (A, TA:) or the latter, (tropical:) a man who quickly cuts the tie of love, or affection. (S, K, TA.) rajulN mijo*aAmu Alr~akoDi fiY AlHarobi (assumed tropical:) A man quick in running, or fleeing, in war. (TA.) And rajulN mijo*aAmapN↓ liloHarobi, and lils~ayori, and lilohawaY, (assumed tropical:) A man who desists from, and relinquishes, war, and journeying, and love, or natural desire. (Lh, TA.)

majo*uwmN *
A man (S, Msb) affected, or smitten, with the disease termed ju*aAm; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also muja*~amN↓ (K) and A^ajo*amu↓, (Kr, K,) which J erroneously disallows: (K:) J says, one does not say A^jo*amu: (TA:) [and Fei,] they say that A^ajo*amu, of the measure of A^aHomaru, is not said in this sense. (Msb.)

mijo*aAmapN *
: see mijo*aAmN, in two places.

ja*omaArN *
or jidomaArN: see what follows, in two places.

ju*omuwrN *
The root, or lowest part, of a thing: or the first thereof; (K;) the beginning, or commencement, and fresh state, thereof; its first and fresh state. (TA.) ― -b2- A piece, or portion, (S, K,) of the lowest part (S) of a palm-branch, (S, K,) [i. e. a stump thereof,] remaining upon the trunk when the [rest of the] branch has been cut off; (S, K;) as also ja*omaArN↓, (S,) or ji*omaArN. (K.) [Accord. to the S, the m is an augmentative letter.] ― -b3- The stump of a [tree of the kind called] naboEap, remaining when the tree has been cut down. (TA.) ― -b4- The stump of a hand of which the greater part has been cut off; (TA;) what remains of a hand that has been amputated, at the extremity of the two bones of the fore arm. (T, TA.) One says, Darabahu biju*omuwrihi and biqaTaEatihi [He struck him with the stump of his amputated hand]. (TA.) ― -b5- What remains of anything that has been cut off. (IAar, TA.) ― -b6- [Pl. ja*aAmiyru.] ― -b7- You say, A^xa*ahu biju*omuwrihi (assumed tropical:) He took it altogether; (K;) as also Ax*h bija*aAmiyrihi: (Ks, S, K:) or he took it in its first and fresh state: and Fr also mentions the phrases Ax*h biji*omiyrihi↓ and biji*omaArihi↓. (TA.)

A^axa*ahu biji*omiyrihi *
: see what next precedes.

1 ja*aA *
, (S, K,) aor.
ja*uwa
, (TA,) inf. n. ja*owN and ju*uw~N, (K,) It (a thing, TA) stood firmly; as also Aj*Y↓. (S, K.) You say also, ja*aA EalaY $aYo'K He [or it, for instance, a stone of those (three in number) upon which a cooking-pot is places, as is implied in the S, (see jaA*K,)] remained firm upon a thing. (S.) And ja*aA AlquraAdu fiY janobi AlbaEiyr The ticks stuck, and clave, to the side of the camel: (ISd, K, TA:) and j*A biAljamali clung to the camel. (TA.) ― -b2- I. q. javFA [He sat upon his knees; &c.]; (AA, Fr, S, K;) as also Aijo*awaY↓, [in form] like AiroEawaY; (TA;) except that j*A is more indicative of keeping to a place: (Kh, TA:) or he stood upon the extremities of his toes: (As, K:) accord. to Th, ju*uw~N is [the standing] upon the extremities of the toes; and juvuw~N is [the sitting] upon the knees: (TA:) and accord. to IAar, jaA*K↓ means [a man standing] upon his feet; and jaAvK, [one sitting] upon his knees. (S, TA.) Accord. to El-Hasan Ibn-'AbdAllah El-Kátib El-Isbahánee, ja*aA, inf. n. ju*uw~N, said of a bird, means He stood upon the extremities of his toes, and warbled, and went round in his warbling; which he does only when seeking the female: and said of a horse, it means he stood upon his toes; and in like manner when said of a man, whether for dancing or for some other purpose. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, En-Noamán Ibn-Nadleh, (TA,)
A_i*aA $iy^otu gan~atoniY dahaAqiynu qaroyapK
waSan~aAjapN tajo*uw EalaY Harofi manosimi
[When I will, the husbandmen of a village sing to me, and a female player with the cymbals, standing upon the extremity of a toe]. (S, TA: but in the latter, EalaY kul~i manosimi [upon every toe].) ― -b3- Also, inf. n. ju*uw~N, He, or it, was, or became, erect, and straight; (TA;) and so Aijo*awo*aY↓, inf. n. Aijo*iy*aA='N. (Az, TA.) See jawaA*i as applied to she-camels, in two places, voce jaA*K. ― -b4- It (a camel's hump) bore fat [so that it became elevated]. (K.) ― -b5- ja*aA manoxiraAhu His nostrils were, or became, raised and extended. (TA.) ― -b6- Er-Rá'ee, describing a strong, or sturdy, she-camel, says,
lamo yajo*u mirofaquhaA fiY Ald~afi mino zawari
meaning Her elbow did not stand out far from the side by reason of [the distortion termed] zawar. (TA.)

4 Aj*Y *
: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also He (a young camel) bore fat in his hump. (Ks, S, K.) El-Khansà says,
yujo*iyna nay~FA walaA yjo*iyna qirodaAnaA
They bear fat [in their humps], and have not ticks clinging to them. (IB, TA.) ＝ -A2- He lifted a stone, (AA, S, TA,) in order that he might know thereby his strength. (TA.) One says, humo yujo*uwna HajarFA wayatajaA*awonahu↓ [They lift a stone, in order to prove their strength, and vie, one with another, in lifting it, for that purpose]. (TA.) tajaA*K↓, in the lifting of a stone, is like tajaAv: (S, TA:) tajaA*awoA meaning taraAbaEuwA liyarofaEuwhu [They vied, one with another, to lift the stone, for trial of strength]. (TA.) ― -b2- Aj*Y Tarofahu [in the CK, erroneously, Tarafahu,] He raised his eye, or sight, and cast it before him. (K, TA.)

6 tajaAo*awa
see 4, in two places.

9 Aijo*awaY *
: see 1.

12 Aijo*awo*aY *
: see 1.

ji*owapN *
and ju*owapN and ja*owapN (S, Msb, K) [A brand, or fire-brand;] i. q. ji*omapN, (AO, S, K,)
i. e. a thick piece of wood, having fire at the end of it or not: (AO, S, in explanation of the first:) or a thick piece of fire-wood, not flaming: (AO, TA, in explanation of ji*owapN mina Aln~aAri:) or a thick stick, one end of which is a live coal: (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA:) or a thick stick upon which fire is taken [by kindling one end]: (ISk, TA:) and a piece (qabosapN, K, or qiToEapN, Har p. 471) of fire: (K, Har:) or a portion of fire-wood that remains after flaming: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and a live coal: (S, K:) or a flaming live coal: (Msb:) or ji*owapN mina Aln~aAri means a piece of live coal; so in the language of all the Arabs: (Mujáhid, S, TA:) pl. [of the first] ji*FY and [of the second] ju*FY (S, Msb, K) and (of the third, TA) ja*FY (Msb, TA, and so in a copy of the S) and ji*aA='N, (AAF, K,) which is held by ISd to be a pl. of the third. (TA.)

ju*aA='N *
: see judaA='N, in art. jdY.

jaA*K *
[part. n. of 1; fem. jaA*iyapN: pl. masc. ji*aA='N; pl. fem. jaA*iyaAtN and jawaA*K]. A rájiz says, (S,) namely, 'Amr Ibn-Jebel-El-Asadee, (TA,)
lamo yuboqi minohaA sabalu Alr~a*aA*i
gayora A^avaAfiY mirojalK jawaA*iY
i. e. [The continual fine rain left not thereof save the three stones that were the supports of a cooking-pot] remaining firm. (S, TA.) ― -b2- I. q. jaAvK [Sitting upon his knees; &c.]: (Fr, TA:) or sitting upon his heels, with his feet upright, [resting] upon the extremities of his toes: (S:) or standing upon the extremities of the toes: (AA, S:) see also 1: pl. [masc.] ja*aA='N. (S) Aboo-Duwád describes mares as jaA*iyaAtN EalaY Als~anaAbiki, i. e. Standing upon the toes. (AA, S, * TA.) ― -b3- jawaA*K, (K,) applied to she-camels, (TA,) means That bear themselves erect (tajo*uw↓) in their course, or pace, as though they lifted their feet clear from the ground; (K, TA;) on the authority of Aboo-Leylà: (TA:) [the last words of the explanation in the K are kaA^an~ahaA taqolaEu: in the TA, kAnhA tqlE Als~ayora: I suppose that Als~ayora is for fiY Als~ayori; and that the pret. of the aor. here used is qaliEa; for qaliEN, which is of the regular form of a part. n. of such a verb as qaliEa, means “ raising the feet clear from the ground in walking &c.: ” but in one copy of the K, I find tuqal~Eu: and another reading in some work seems to be tuqoliEu; for] ISd says, I know not ja*aA with the meaning of A^asoraEa nor of A^aqolaEa: and As says that jawaA*K means quick, or swift, camels, that do not stretch themselves forth in their course, or pace, but bear themselves erect (wayanotaSibona yajo*uwna↓). (TA.)

mujo*K *
[act. part. n. of 4]. mivolu AlA^arozapi Almujo*iyapi EalaY AlA^aroDi, (S,) or kaAlA^arozapi Almj*yp ElY wajohi AlArD, (TA,) occurring in a trad., (S, TA,) describing the unbeliever, (TA,) means [Like the pine-tree] that is firm (S, TA) and erect [upon the ground]. (TA.)

mujo*awo*K *
[in the CK, erroneously, Almajo*uwo*iY~u,] Keeping constantly to the dwelling, or to the camel's saddle and the dwelling, (Alr~aHol and Almanozil, AA, S, K,) not quitting it: (AA, S:) like mujo*awo*K EalaY Alr~aHoli. (AA, S) ― -b2- And A man who lowers, or abases, himself; (El-Hejeree, ISd, TA;) as though he clave to the ground by reason of his abjectness; from ja*aA AlquraAdu fiY janobi AlbaEiyri [q. v.]. (ISd, TA.)

1 jar~a jr
, aor.
jaru3a
, (S, A, Msb,) inf. n. jar~N; (S K;) and jr~r↓, inf. n. tajoriyrN (S K) [and app. tajir~apN, said in the TA to be of the measure tafoEilapN from Aljar~u], with teshdeed to denote repetition or frequency of the action, or its relation to many objects, or intensiveness; (S;) and Ajtr~↓, inf. n. AijotiraArN; (S, L, K;) and Aijdr~↓, inf. n. AijodiraArN; (L, K;) in which the t is changed into d, though you do not say AijodaraA^a for AijotaraA^a, nor AijodaraHa for AijotaraHa; (L;) and Astjr~↓; (K;) He dragged, drew, pulled, tugged, strained, extended by drawing or pulling or tugging, or stretched, (A, L, Msb, K,) a thing, (A,) or a rope, (S, Msb,) and the like. (Msb.) You say, jar~uwA A^a*oyaAlahumo They dragged along their hinder skirts. (A.) And Alr~umoHa AjAr~↓ He dragged, or drew along, the spear. (TA.) And AlHadiyva mino A^abaAEidi A^aToraAfihi fulaAnN yasotajir~u↓ (assumed tropical:) [Such a one draws forth talk, or discourse, or news, or the like, from its most remote sources]. (A in art. bEd.) And maA Al~a*iY jar~aka A_ilaY h`*aA AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) [What drew thee, led thee, induced thee, or caused thee, to do this thing]. (TA in art. dEw.) ― -b2- Also jar~a, aor.
jaru3a
, (TA,) inf. n. jar~N, (K,) (tropical:) He drove (camels and sheep or goats, TA) gently, (K, TA,) letting them pasture as they went along. (TA.) And jar~a AlA_ibila EalaY A^afowaAhihaA (tropical:) He drove the camels gently, they eating the while. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence,] halum~a jar~FA↓ (tropical:) At thine ease. (TA.) ElMundhiree explains halhm~a jur~uwA as meaning (tropical:) Come ye at your ease; from Aljar~u in driving camels and sheep or goats, as rendered above. (TA.) You say also, kaAna *aAka EaAma ka*aA wahalum~a jar~FA A_ilaY Alyawomi (S, A, Msb, * TA) (tropical:) That was in such a year, and has continued to this day: (Msb, TA:) from Aljar~u meaning the act of “ dragging, ” &c.: (TA:) or from A^ajorarotuhu Ald~ayona, or from A^ajorarotuhu Alr~umoHa. (Msb.) jr~A is here in the accus. case as an inf. n., or as a denotative of state: but it is disputed whether this expression be classical or postclassical. (TA.) [See also art. hlm] ― -b4- jar~a AlA^avara, said of a numerous army, means (assumed tropical:) [It made a continuous track, so that] it left no distinct footprints, or intervening [untrodden] spaces. (TA.) ― -b5- jar~ati Alxayolu AlA^aroDa bisanaAbikihaA (tropical:) The horses furrowed the ground with their hoofs. (As, A, TA.) ― -b6- jar~a jariyrapF, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
jaru3a
and
jara3a
, (K,) but the latter form is disallowed by MF as not authorised by usage nor by analogy, (TA,) inf. n. jar~N, (K,) He committed a crime, or an offence for which he should be punished, or an injurious action, (S, Msb, K, *) against (EaliY [and A_ilaY, as in the K voce janaY,]) another or others, (S, K,) or himself; (A, K;) [as though he drew it upon the object thereof;] syn. janaY jinaAyapF. (S, TA.) It is said in a trad., baAyaEahu EalaY A^ano laA yajur~a Ealayohi A_il~aA nafosahu [He promised, or swore, allegiance to him on the condition that he should not inflict an injury, meaning a punishment, upon him but for an offence committed by himself;] i. e., that he should not be punished for the crime of another, of his children or parent or family. (TA.) ― -b7- jar~a AlfaSiyla: see 4, in two places. ― -b8- [jar~a AlHarofa fiY AlA_iEoraAbi, aor.
jaru3a
, inf. n. jar~N, (assumed tropical:) He made the final letter to have kesreh, in inflection; i. q. xafaDa, q. v.:] Aljar~u is used in the conventional language of the Basrees; and AlxafoDu, in that of the Koofees. (Kull p. 145.) ＝ -A2- jar~N, (S, A,) inf. n. jaruwrN, (K,) (tropical:) She exceeded the [usual] time of pregnancy. (A.) (tropical:) She (a camel) arrived at the time [of the year] in which she had been covered, and then went beyond it some days without bringing forth: (S, TA:) or withheld her fœtus in her womb after the completion of the year, a month, or two months, or forty days only: (K, * TA:) Th says that she sometimes withholds her fœtus [beyond the usual time] a month. (TA. [See also jar~ato.]) (tropical:) She (a mare) exceeded eleven months and did not foal: (K, TA:) the more she exceeds the usual term, the stronger is her foal; and the longest time of excess after eleven months is fifteen nights: accord. to AO, the time of a mare's gestation, after she has ceased to be covered, to the time of her foaling, is eleven months; and if she exceed that time at all, they say of her, All~ayolapu. (TA.) (tropical:) She (a woman) went beyond nine months without bringing forth, (K, TA,) exceeding that term by four days, or three. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) It (the night, kbd,) was, or became, long. (L in art. kbd.) ― -b3- jar~a, aor.
jaru3a
, (TA,) inf. n. jar~N; (K;) and Anjr~↓; (K;) (assumed tropical:) He (a camel) pastured as he went along: (IAar. K: [if so, the aor. is contr. to analogy:]) or he rode a she-camel and let her pasture [while going along]. (Kudot;.) ― -b4- jar~a Aln~awo'u biAlmakaAni (assumed tropical:) The nw' [or auroral setting or rising of a star or asterism supposed to occasion rain] caused lasting rain in the place. (TA.)

2 jar~a3a
see 1, first sentence.

3 jArahu jAr jArh jArp
, (S, K,) inf. n. mujaArarapN, (TA,) or mujaAr~apN, (TK,) He delayed, or deferred, with him, or put him off, by promising him payment time after time; syn. TaAwalahu, (S,) or maA Tilahu: (K:) or he put off giving him his due, and drew him from his place to another: (TA:) or i. q. jaAnaAhu, (so in copies of the K,) meaning, he committed a crime against him: (TK:) or HaAbaAhu. (TA, as from the K. [But this seems to be a mistranscription.]) It is said in a trad., laA tujaAr~ A^axaAka walaA tu$aAr~ihi, i. e. Delay not, or defer not, with thy brother, &c.: [and do not act towards him in an evil, or inimical, manner; or do not evil to him, obliging him to do the like in return; or do not contend, or dispute, with him:] or bring not an injury upon him: but accord. to one reading, it is
laA tujaArihi, without teshdeed, from AljaroYu, and meaning, contend not with him for superiority. (TA.)

4 Ajr~hu A^jAr A^jr A^jrY A^jrh A^jrp Ajrh Ajrp jAr jr jrY |jr |jrh
He pierced him with the spear and left it in him so that he dragged it along: (S, K:) or so Ajr~hu Alr~umoHa: (A, Msb:) as though [meaning] he made him to drag along the spear. (TA.) ― -b2- He put the jariyr, i. e. the rope, upon his neck. (Har p. 308.) ― -b3- Ajr~hu jariyrahu [lit. He made him to drag along his rope; meaning,] (tropical:) he left him to pasture by himself, where he pleased: a prov. (L.) And Ajr~hu rasanahu [lit. He made him to drag along his halter; meaning,] (tropical:) he left him to do as he would: (S, K, TA:) he left him to his affair. (A, TA.) ― -b4- Ajr~hu Ald~ayona (tropical:) He deferred for him the payment of the debt: (S, A, K:) he left the debt to remain owed by him. (Msb.) ― -b5- Ajr~hu A^agaAniY~a (tropical:) He sang songs to him consecutively, successively, or uninterruptedly; syn. taAbaEahaA: (S, K, TA:) or (tropical:) he sang to him a song and then followed it up with consecutive songs. (A, TA.) ― -b6- Ajr~ lisaAna AlfaSiyli, (S,) or Ajr~ AlfaSiyla, (As, K, *) inf. n. A_ijoraArN; (K;) and AlfaSiyla jar~a↓, (As K, *) inf. n. jar~N; (K;) (tropical:) He slit the tongue of the young weaned camel, that it might not suck the teat: (S, K, TA:) or A_ijoraAru AlfaSiyli signifies (tropical:) the slitting the tongue of the young weaned camel, and tying upon it a piece of stick, that it may not suck the teat; because it drags along the piece of stick with its tongue: or AlA_ijoraAru is like Alt~afoliyku, signifying (assumed tropical:) a pastor's making, of coarse hair, a thing like the whirl, or hemispherical head, of a spindle, and then boring the tongue of the [young] camel, and inserting it therein, that it may not suck the teat: so say some: (ISk, TA:) the animal upon which the operation has been performed is said to be majoruwrN↓ and mujar~N↓. (TA.) [But sometimes jar~a↓ signifies merely He drew away a young camel from its mother: see xaliy~apN voce xaliY~N, in three places.] ― -b7- Hence, Ajr~ lisaAnahu (tropical:) He prevented him from speaking. (A.) 'Amr Ibn-MaadeeKerib Ez-Zubeydee says,
falawo A^an~a qawomiY A^anoTaqatoniY rimaAHuhumo
naTaqotu wal`kin~a Alr~imaAHa A^jar~ati
[And if the spears of my people had made me to speak, I had spoken; but the spears have prevented speech]: i. e., had they fought, and shown their valour, I had mentioned that, and gloried in it, (S,) or in them; (TA;) but their spears have prevented my tongue from speaking, by their flight. (S, * TA.) ＝ -A2- Ajr~ as an intrans. verb: see 8. ― -b2- Ajr~t Albiy^oru (tropical:) The well was, or became, such as is termed jaruwr. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.)

7 Anjr~ 8
It (a thing, S) was, or became, dragged, drawn, pulled, tugged, strained, extended by drawing or pulling or tugging, or stretched; it dragged, or trailed along; syn. Ainoja*aba. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence but one.

8 AHtr~ * and Ajdr~
: see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- Ajtr~ said of a camel, (S, Msb, K,) and any other animal having a kari$, (S, TA,) [i. e.] any clovenhoofed animal, (Msb,) He ejected the cud from his stomach and ate it again; ruminated; chewed the cud; (S, * Msb, * K * TA;) as also Ajr~↓. (Lh, K.)

10 A_isotajora3a
see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- Aisotajorarotu lahu (tropical:) I made him to have authority and power over me, (K, TA,) and submitted myself, or became submissive or tractable, to him; (A, K, TA;) as though I became to him one that was dragged, or drawn along. (TA.) ― -b2- Astjr~ Eani Alr~aDaAEi (assumed tropical:) He (a young camel) refrained from sucking in consequence of a purulent pustule, or an ulcer, in his mouth or some other part. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 jarojara A^njr Anjr njr {njr
, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. jarojarapN, (S, * K, * TA,) He (a stallion-camel) reiterated his voice, or cry, (S, * Mgh, Msb, K, *) or his braying, (TA,) in his windpipe. (S, * Mgh, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- He, or it, made, or uttered, a noise, sound, cry, or cries; he cried out; vociferated; raised a cry, or clamour. (TA.) It (beverage, or wine,) sounded, or made a sound or sounds, (K, TA,) in the fauces. (TA.) And jarojarati Aln~aAru (assumed tropical:) The fire sounded, or made a sound or sounds. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- Also, (A, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He poured water down his throat; as also tajarojara↓: (K:) or he swallowed it in consecutive gulps, so that it sounded, or made a sound or sounds; (A, Msb, TA;) as also ↓the latter verb. (K, * TA.) It is said in a trad., (of him who drinks from a vessel of gold or silver, Mgh, TA,) yujarojiru fiY baTonihi naAra jahan~ama He shall drink down into his belly the fire of Hell (Az, A, Mgh, Msb) in consecutive gulps, so that it shall make a sound or sounds: (A:) or he shall make the fire of Hell to gurgle reiteratedly in his belly; from jarojara said of a stallion-camel. (Mgh.) Most read AlnAra, as above; but accord. to one reading, it is AlnAru, (Z, Msb,) and the meaning is, (tropical:) The fire of Hell shall produce sounds in his belly like those which a camel makes in his windpipe: the verb is here tropically used; and is masc., with Y, because of the separation between it and AlnAr: (Z, TA:) but this reading and explanation are not right. (Mgh.) ― -b2- You say also, jarojarahu AlmaA='a He poured water down his throat so that it made a sound or sounds. (K, * TA.)

R. Q. 2
see R. Q. 1, in two places.

laA jara lA jr
and laA *aA jara, for laA jarama and laA *aA jarama: see art. jrm.

jar~N jr
(tropical:) The foot, bottom, base, or lowest part, of a mountain; (S, A, K;) like *ayolN: (A, TA:) or the place where it rises from the plain to the rugged part: (IDrd, TA:) or Alj~r~u A^aSolu Aljabali is a mistranscription of Fr, and is correctly AljuraASilu Aljabalu [i. e. jurASilN signifies “a mountain”]: (K:) but juraASilN is not mentioned [elsewhere] in the K, nor by any one of the writers on strange words; and [SM says,] there is evidently no mistranscription: jar~u Aljabali occurs in a trad., meaning the foot, &c., of the mountain: and its pl. is jiraArN. (TA.) ― -b2- halom~a jar~FA: see 1. ＝ -A2- See also jar~apN. ＝ -A3- laA jar~a i. q. laA jarama: see art. jrm. (TA.)

jar~apN jr jrh jrp
[A jar;] a well-known vessel; (Msb;) an earthen vessel; a vessel made of potters' clay: (T, IDrd, * S, * K: *) or anything made of clay: (Mgh:) dim. jurayorapN: (TA:) pl. jiraArN (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jar~aAtN (Msb) and jar~N↓, (T, S, Msb, K,) [or this last is rather a coll. gen. n., signifying pottery, or jars, &c.,] like tamorN in relation to tamorapN; or, accord. to some, this is a dial. var. of jar~apN. (Msb.) Beverage of the kind called nabiy* made in such a vessel is forbidden in a trad.: (Mgh, TA:) but accord. to IAth, the trad. means a vessel of this kind glazed within, because the beverage acquires strength, and ferments, more quickly in a glazed earthen vessel. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jir~apN: ＝ -A3- and see what here next follows.

jur~apN jr jrh jrp
(S, K) and jar~apN↓ (K) A small piece of wood, (K,) or a piece of wood about a cubit long, (S,) having a snare at the head, (S, K,) and a cord at the middle, (S,) with which gazelles are caught: (S, K:) when the gazelle is caught in it, he strives with it awhile, and struggles in it, and labours at it, to escape; and when it has overcome him, and he is wearied by it, he becomes still, and remains in it; and this is what is termed [in a prov. mentioned below] his becoming at peace with it: (S, * TA:) or it is a staff, or stick, tied to a snare, which is hidden in the earth, for catching the gazelle; having cords of sinew; when his fore leg enters the snare, the cords of sinew become tied in knots upon that leg; and when he leaps to escape, and stretches out his fore leg, he strikes with that staff, or stick, his other fore leg and his hind leg, and breaks them. (AHeyth, TA.) naAwaSa Aljur~apa vum~a saAlamahaA He struggled with the jr~p and then became at peace with it [see above] is a prov. applied to him who opposes the counsel, or opinion, of a people, and then is obliged to agree: (S, * TA:) or to him who falls into a case, and struggles in it, and then becomes still. (TA.) And it is said in another prov., huwa kaAlbaAHivi Eani Aljur~api [He is like him who searches in the earth for the]. (AHeyth, TA.) In the phrase A_i*aA A^afolatato mino jur~atayohaA , in a saying of Ibn-Lisán-el-Hummarah, referring to sheep, [app. meaning When they escape from their two states of danger,] by jr~tyhA he means their place of pasture (Almajar~) in a severe season [when they are liable to perish], and when they are scattered, or dispersed, by night, and [liable to be] attacked, or destroyed, by the beasts of prey: so says ISk: Az says that he calls their mjr two snares, into which they might fall, and perish. (TA.)

jir~apN jr jrh jrp
A mode, or manner, of dragging, drawing, pulling, tugging, straining, or stretching. (K.) ＝ -A2- The stomach of the camel, and of a clovenhoofed animal: this is the primary signification: by extension of its meaning, it has the signification next following. (Msb.) ― -b2- The cud which a camel [or cloven-hoofed animal] ejects from its stomach, (Az, S, * IAth, Mgh, Msb, K, *) and eats again, (K,) or chews, or ruminates, (Az, IAth, Msb,) or to chew, or ruminate; (S;) as also
jar~apN↓: (K:) it is said to belong to the same predicament as baEor. (Mgh.) Hence the saying, laA A^afoEalu *`lika maA A@xotalafati Ald~ir~apu waAljir~apu I will not do that as long as the flow of milk and the cud go [the former] downwards and [the latter] upwards. (S, A. * [See also dir~apN.]) And Aujotulibati Ald~ir~apu biAljir~api [The flow of milk was procured by the cud]: alluding to the beasts' becoming full of food, and then lying down and not ceasing to ruminate until the time of milking. (IAar, TA.) And laA yaHonaqu EalaY jir~atihi (assumed tropical:) He will not bear rancour, or malice, against his subjects:: or, as some say, cross he will not conceal a secret: (TA:) and maA yaHonaqu EalaY jir~apK and maA yakoZimu ElY jir~apK (assumed tropical:) he does not speak when affected with rancour, or malice: (TA in art. Hnq:) [or the last has the contr. signification: for] laA yakoZimu EalaY jir~atihi means (tropical:) he will not be silent respecting that which is in his bosom, but will speak of it. (TA in art. kZm.) ― -b3- Also The mouthful with which the camel diverts and occupies himself until the time when his fodder is brought to him. (K.)

jaruwrN jrwr
(tropical:) A female that exceeds the [usual] time of pregnancy. (A.) (tropical:) A she-camel that withholds her fœtus in her womb, after the completion of the year, a month, or two months, or forty days only; (K, * TA;) or, three months after the year: they are the most generous of camels that do so: none do so but those that usually bring forth in the season called Alr~abiyE (AlmaraAbiyE); not those that usually bring forth in the season called AlS~ayof (AlmaSaAyiyf): and only those do so that are red [or brown], and such as are of a white hue intermixed with red (AlS~uhob), and such as are ash-coloured: never, or scarcely ever, such as are of a dark gray colour without any admixture of white, because of the thickness of their skins, and the narrowness of their insides, and the hardness of their flesh. (IAar, TA. [See also 1: and see xaSuwfN.]) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that is made to incline to, and to suckle, a young one not her own; her own being about to die, they bound its fore legs to its neck, and put upon it a piece of rag, in order that she might know this piece of rag, which they then put upon another young one; after which they stopped up her nostrils, and did not unclose them until the latter young one had sucked her, and she perceived from it the odour of her milk. (L.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a horse, (S, A, K,) and a camel, (K,) (tropical:) That refuses to be led; refractory: (S, A, K:) of the measure faEuwlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; or it may be in the sense of the measure faAEilN: (Az, TA:) or a slow horse, either from fatigue or from shortness of step: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) pl. jururN. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A woman crippled; or affected by a disease that deprives her of the power of walking: (Sh, K:) because she is dragged upon the ground. (Sh, TA.) ― -b5- biy^orN jaruwrN (tropical:) A deep well; (Sh, S, K;) from which the water is drawn by means of the saAniyap [q. v.], (S, A,) and by means of the pulley and the hands; like matuwHN and nazuwEN: (A:) or a well from which the water is drawn [by a man] upon a camel [to the saddle of which one end of the wellrope is attached]; so called because its bucket is drawn upon the edge of the mouth thereof, by reason of its depth. (As, L.)

jariyrN jryr
A rope: pl. A^ajir~apN. (Sh, TA.) A rope for a camel, corresponding to the Ei*aAr of a horse, (S, K,) different from the zimaAm. (S.) Also The nose-rein of a camel; syn. zimaAmN: (K:) or a cord of leather, that is put upon the neck of a she-camel: (Msb:) or a cord of leather, like a zmAm: and applied also to one of other kinds of plaited cords: or, accord. to El-Hawázinee, [a string] of softened leather, folded over the nose of an excellent camel or a horse. (TA.) [See also xiTaAmN.]

jiraArapN jrAr jrArh jrArp jrp
The art of pottery: the art of making jars, or earthen vessels. (TA. [See jar~apN.])

jariyrapN jryrh jryrp
A crime; a sin; an offence which a man commits, and for which he should be punished; an injurious action: (S, * Msb, * K, * TA:) syn. *anobN, (Msb, K,) and jinaAyapN: (S:) of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: (Msb:) pl. jaraAy^iru. (A.) See also what next follows.

faEalotu ka*aA mino jar~aAka *
, (S, A, * K, *) and mn jar~aAy^ika, (K,) and mn jaraAk, and mn jaraAy^ika, (S, K,) and mn jariyratika↓, (K,) means mn A^ajolika, (S, A, K,) i. e., [originally, I did so] in consequence of thy committing it, namely, a crime: and then, by extension of its application, [because of thee, or of thine act &c.; on thine account; for thy sake;] indicating any causation. (Bd in v. 35, in explanation of mn jar~aAka and mn A^ajolika.) One should not say mijoraAka, (S,) or bijoraAka. (A.)

jir~iY~N jr jrY jry
(written in the Towsheeh with fet-h to the j also, TA,) [The eel;] a kind of fish, (S, K,) long and smooth, (K,) resembling the serpent, and called in Persian maAro maAhiY; said to be a dial. var. of jir~iyvN; (TA;) not eaten by the Jews, (K,) and forbidden to be eaten by 'Alee; (TA;) having no scales: (K:) or any fish having no scales. (Towsheeh, TA.)

jir~iy~apN jry jryh jryp
The stomach, or triple stomach, or the crop, or craw, of a bird; syn. HawoSalapN; (S, K;) as also jir~iyoy^apN [q. v.] (K) and qir~iy~apN. (AZ, TA.) You say, A^loqaAhu fiY jir~iy~atihi, meaning, (tropical:) He ate it. (A, TA.) See also art. jrY.

jar~aArN jrAr jrp
A man who leads a thousand. (T, end of art. Hfz.) ― -b2- jayo$N jar~aArN, (S, A,) and katiybapN jar~aArapN, (S, K,) (tropical:) An army, and a troop of horse or the like, that marches heavily, by reason of its numbers: (As, S, K:) or dragging along the apparatus of war: (A:) or numerous. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A potter; a maker of jars, or earthen vessels. (TA. [See jar~apN.])

jar~aArapN jrAr jrArh jrArp jrp
A small, (S, A, K, TA,) yellow, (A, TA,) female (TA) scorpion, (S, A, K, TA,) like a piece of straw, (TA, [thus I render ElY $kl Altbnp, but I think that there must be here some mistranscription, as the words seem to be descriptive of form,]) that drags its tail; (S, K;) for which reason it is thus called; one of the most deadly of scorpions to him whom it stings: (TA:) pl. jar~aAraAtN. (A, TA.)

jar~aAnu jrAn
: see jaAr~N, last sentence.

jarojarN jrjr
The thing [or machine] of iron with which the reaped corn collected together is thrashed. (K.) [See naworajN and midowasN.] ＝ -A2- See also jirojirN.

jirojirN jrjr
: see jarojaArN. ＝ -A2- Also The bean; or beans; syn. fuwlN; (S, K;) and so jarojarN: (K:) of the dial. of the people of El-'Irák. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jirojiyrN.

jarojarpN jrjr jrjrh jrjrp
, an onomatopœia: (Msb:) A sound which a camel reiterates in his windpipe: (S, K:) the sound made by a camel when disquieted, or vexed: (TA:) the sound of pouring water into the throat: (TA:) or the sound of the descent of water into the belly: (IAth, TA:) or the sound of water in the throat when drunk in consecutive gulps. (Msb.) [See R. Q. 1.]

jarojaArN jrjAr
A camel that reiterates sounds in his windpipe: (S:) or a camel that makes much noise [or braying]; as also jirojirN↓ and juraAjirN↓. (K.) ― -b2- The sound of thunder. (K.) ＝ -A2- A certain plant, (S, K,) of sweet odour; (S;) a certain herb having a yellow flower. (AHn, TA.)

jurojuwrN jrjwr
A large, or bulky, camel: (K:) pl. jaraAjiru, (Kr, K,) without Y [before the final letter], though by rule it should be with Y, except in a case of poetic necessity. (TA.) And, as a pl., Large, or bulky, camels; as also [its pl.] jaraAjiru: (S:) or large-bellied camels: (TA:) and generous, or excellent, camels: (K, TA:) and a herd, or collected number, (K, TA,) of camels: (TA:) and maAy^apN jurojuwrN a complete hundred (K, TA) of camels. (TA.)

jirojiyrN jrjyr
(S, K) and jirojirN↓ (K) [The herb eruca, or rocket;] a certain leguminous plant, (S, K,) well known: (K;) a plant of which there are two kinds; namely, bar~aY~ [i. e. eruca sylvestris, or wild rocket], and busotaAniY~ [i. e. eruca sativa, or garden-rocket]; whereof the latter is the better: its water, or juice, removes scars, and causes milk to flow, and digests food: (TA:) AHn says that the jirojiyr is the baAqil~aY [q. v.]; and that the jirjiyr miSoriY~ is the turomus: [but see this last word.] (TA in art. trms.)

jarojaArapN jrjArh jrjArp
A mill, or mill-stone; syn. raHFY: (K:) because of its sound. (TA.)

juraAjirN jrAjr
: see jarojaArN. ― -b2- Also That drinks much; (K; [in the CK misplaced;]) applied to a camel: you say A_ibilN juraAjirapN. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) Water that makes a noise. (K.)

jaAr~N jAr jAry
[act. part. n. of 1; Dragging, drawing, &c.]. ― -b2- jaAr~u AlD~abuEi (tropical:) Rain that draws the hyena from its hole by its violence: or the most violent rain; as though it left nothing without dragging it along: (TA:) or rain that leaves nothing without making it to flow, and dragging it along:
(IAar, TA:) or the torrent that draws forth the hyena from its hole: (A:) and in like manner, AlD~abuEi majar~u↓ the torrent that has torn up the ground; as though the hyena were dragged along in it. (IAar, Sh, TA.) You say also maTarN jaAr~u AlD~abuEi, and maTorapN jaAr~apu AlD~abuEi. (A.) ― -b3- A_ibilN jaAr~apN (tropical:) Working camels; because they drag along burdens; (A, Mgh;) or tropically so called because they are dragged along by their nose-reins: (Mgh:) or camels that are dragged along by their nosereins: (S, K, TA: [but in the copies of the S, and in those of the K, in my possession, tajur~u is put for tujar~u, though the latter is evidently meant, as is shown by what here follows:]) jAr~p is of the measure faAEilapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: it is like as when you say Eiy$apN raADayapN in the sense of maroDiy~apN, and maA='N daAfiqN in the sense of madofuwqN: (S:) or it means such as carry goods, or furniture and utensils, and wheat, or food. (AZ, TA voce HaAn~N, q. v.) It is said in a trad. that there is no poor-rate (Sadaqap) in the case of such camels, (S, Mgh,) because they are the ridingcamels of the people; for the poor-rate is in the case of pasturing camels, exclusively of the working. (S.) ― -b4- laA jaAr~a liY fiY h`*aA (tropical:) There is no profit for me in this to attract me to it. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- HaAr~N jaAr~N is an expression in which the latter word is an imitative sequent to the former; (S, K;) but accord. to A 'Obeyd, it was more common to say HaAr~N yaAr~N, with Y: (S:) and one says also Har~aAnu yar~aAnu jar~aAnu↓. (TA in art. Hr.)

jiwar~N jwr jwrp
is mentioned by Az in this art., meaning Rain that draws along everything: and rain that occasions the herbage to grow tall: and a large and heavy [bucket of the kind called] garob; explained in this sense by AO: and a bulky camel; and, with p, in like manner applied to a ewe: Fr says that the w in this word may be considered as augmentative or as radical. (TA.) [See also art. w.]

jaAr~apN jAr jArh jArp
[fem. of jaAr~N, q. v.: and, as a subst.,] A road to water. (K.)

jaAruwrN jArwr
A river, or rivulet, of which the bed is formed but a torrent. (S, * K, * TA.)

AlA^ajar~aAni *
The jinn, or genii, and mankind. (IAar, K.)

majar~N mjr
[The place, or track, along which a thing is, or has been, dragged, or drawn]. You say, raA^ayotu majar~a *ayolihi [I saw the track along which his hinder skirt had been dragged]. (A.) See also Almajar~apu: and jaAr~N. ― -b2- A place of pasture. (TA.) ― -b3- The jaAy^iz [or beam] upon which are placed the extremities of the EawaAriD [or rafters]. (K)

mujar~N mjr
: see 4, in the latter portion of the paragraph.

Almajar~apu Almjrh Almjrp
(tropical:) [The Milky Way in the sky;] the $araj of the sky; (K;) the whiteness that lies across in the sky, by the two sides of which are the nasoraAni [or two constellations called Aln~asoru AlT~aAy^iru and Aln~asoru AlwaAqiEu]: or [the tract called] AlT~ariyqu AlmaHosuwspu [which is probably the same; or the tract], in the sky, along which (minohaA) the [wandering] stars [or planets] take their ways: (TA:) or the gate of Heaven: (K:) so called because it is like the trace of the majar~ [or place along which a thing has been dragged, or drawn]. (S.) Hence the prov., turoTibo hajaro siTiY majaro↓ (tropical:) Reach the middle of the sky, O milky way, (mjr being for mjr~p,) and the palm-trees of Hejer will have ripe dates. (A, * TA.)

majoruwrN mjrwr
[pass. part. n. of 1]: see 4, latter portion.

1 jaruw^a *
, aor.
jaruAa
, inf. n. jaraA='apN (S, Msb, K) and jaraAy^iyapN and jaraAyapN, with Y [in the place of '], which is extr., (K,) and juroA^apN and jurapN, (S, K,) thus sometimes, without ', like as one says maroA^apN and juroA^apN, (S,) [all mentioned as inf. ns. in the TK, and app. as such in the K, but only the first is explicitly mentioned as an inf. n. in the S and Msb, and AstjrA^↓ is said in the Msb to be a simple subst.,] He was, or became, bold, daring, brave, or courageous; (S, Msb, * K, TA;) so as to attempt, or venture upon, a thing without consideration or hesitation: (TA:) [said of a brute and the like, as well as of a man:] and AstjrA^↓ is syn. therewith. (IJ, W p. 146.)

2 jar~aA^otuhu Ealayohi *
, (inf. n. tajoriYo'N, K,) I emboldened him, or encouraged him, against him. (S, Msb, * K, TA.)

5 tajar~aAa
see 8.

8 AjtrA^ Ealayohi *
, (S, K,) or tjr~A^↓, (Msb,) He became emboldened or encouraged, or he emboldened or encouraged himself, against him. (S, Msb, * K, TA.) ― -b2- AjtrA^ EalaY Alqawoli He ventured upon the saying hastily and unhesitatingly. (Msb.)

10 A_isotajoraAa
see 1.

juroA^apN *
Boldness, daringness, bravery, or courage; as also jurapN: (S: see 1:) the quality of venturing upon a saying [&c.] hastily and unhesitatingly. (Msb.)

jariYo'N jrY' jry' jry^
Bold, daring, brave, or courageous: (S, Msb, * K, TA:) pl. A^ajoraA='N, accord. to a MS. copy of the K; [and so in the CK;] but in the M, A^ajoriy^aA='u, with two hemzehs, on the authority of Lh; and so in some copies of the K; and sometimes juraA^='u, like HulamaA='u, occurring in a trad., as some relate it; but the reading commonly known is HuraA^=', with the unpointed H. (TA.) ― -b2- jariYo'u Almuqodami Bold, daring, brave, or courageous, in venturing [against an adversary, or upon an undertaking]. (S.) ― -b3- AljariYo'u The lion; as also AlmujotariY'u↓. (O, K.)

jariyoy^apN *
A chamber (K, TA) constructed of stones, with a stone placed over its entrance, (TA,) for the purpose of entrapping wild beasts: (K, TA:) the piece of flesh-meat for the wild beast is put in the hinder part of the chamber; and when he enters to take the piece of meat, the stone falls upon the entrance, and closes it: (TA:) pl. jaraAy^iYu (accord. to some copies of the K,) or jaraAy^iY'u, (accord. to others,) mentioned by AZ as one of the forms of pl. repudiated by the Arabic grammarians except in some anomalous instances. (TA.)

Aljir~iyoy^apu *
The qaAniSap [here app. meaning the stomach, or triple stomach, or the crop, or craw, of a bird], and the Huloquwm [here app. meaning the gullet of a bird]; like Aljir~iy~apu; (K;) i. e. the HawoSalap [meaning the stomach, or the crop, of a bird]: it is said in the T, on the authority of AZ, that Alqir~iy~apu and Aljir~iy~apu and Aln~awoTapu signify the HawoSalap of a bird. (TA.)

AlmujotariY'u AlmjtrY' Almjtry' Almjtry^ mjtry^
: see jariYo'N.

1 jariba A^jrb jrAb jrb
, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
jaraba
, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. jarabN, (Msb, TA,) He (a camel, S, A, Msb, K, and a man, S, or other animal, Msb,) was, or became, affected with what is termed jarab [i. e. the mange, or scab]. (S, Msb, K.) maA lahu jariba waHariba is a form of imprecation against a man [meaning What aileth him? may he have the scab, and be despoiled of all his wealth, or property: or may he have his camels affected with the mange, or scab, and be despoiled &c.: or may his camels be affected with the mange, or scab, &c.]: it may express a wish that he may be affected with jarab: or jariba may be put for A^ajoraba, to assimilate it to Hariba: or it may be for jaribato A_ibluhu. (L.) ― -b2- See 4. ― -b3- Also (tropical:) i. q. halakato A^aroDuhu [meaning His land had its herbage dried up by drought; or became such as is termed jarobaA=', fem. of A^ajorabu, q. v.]. (K.)

2 jr~bhu A^jrb jrAb jrb jrbh jrbp
, (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. tajoribapN, (M, A, K,) or tajoriybN, the former, which see also below, being a simple subst., (Msb,) or both, but the former is irreg., are inf. ns., (TA,) He tried, made trial of, made experiment of, tested, proved, assayed, proved by trial or experiment or experience, him, or it: (A, K:) or he tried it, made trial of it, &c., namely, a thing, time after time. (Msb.) [You say also jar~aba, for jar~aba AlA^umuwra, meaning He tried affairs: and hence, i. q.] jur~iba fiY AlA^umuwr [He became experienced, or expert, in affairs]. (T, TA.) And jar~abatohu AlA^umuwru [Affairs, or events, tried him. &c.: and thus, rendered him experienced, or expert]. (S, TA.) And maA jur~ibto Ealayohi faEolapN qabiyHapN qaT~u [A foul action was never found to be chargeable upon him]. (S voce nugobapN.)

4 Ajrb A^jrb Ajrb jrb
He had his camels [or found them to be] affected with what is termed jarab [i. e. the mange, or scab]; (S, A, L, K;) as also jariba↓, (L, K,) which may be for jaribato A_ibiluhu; or used for A^ajoraba, to assimilate it to Hariba in a saying mentioned above; see 1. (L.)

Q. Q. 1 jaworabahu jwrb jwrbh jwrbp
He put on him [i. e., on his
(another's) foot or feet,] jaworab [i. e. a sock or stocking, or a pair of socks or stockings]. (S, K.)

Q. Q. 2 tajaworaba tjwrb
He put on [i. e., on his own foot or feet,] jaworab [i. e. a sock or stocking, or a pair of socks or stockings]. (S, K.) And in like manner, tjwrb jaworabayoni [He put on a pair of socks or stockings]. (TA.)

jirobN A^jrb jrAb jrb
: see jirobapN.

jarabN A^jrb jrAb jrb
[The mange, or scab;] a certain disease, (A,) well known; (S, A, K;) accord. to the medical books, (Msb,) a gross humour, arising beneath the skin, from the mixture of the salt phlegm, (Msb, MF,) or the phlegm of the flesh, (so in a copy of the Msb,) with the blood, accompanied with pustules, and sometimes with emaciation, in consequence of its abundance; (Msb, MF;) or [an eruption consisting of] pustules upon the bodies of men and camels. (M, TA.) You say, A^EodaY mina Aljarabi Einoda AlEarabi [More transitive, or catching, than the mange, or scab, among the Arabs]: (A, TA:) a proverb. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Rust upon a sword. (K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A resemblance of rust upon the inner side of the jafon [or eyelid], (M, K,) sometimes covering the whole of it, and sometimes part of it. (M.) You say, biA^ajofaAnihi jarabN (tropical:) [In his eyelids is] a resemblance of rust upon their inner sides. (A.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A vice, a fault, a defect, an imperfection, or a blemish. (IAar, K.)

jaribN A^jrb jrAb jrb
: see A^ajorabu.

jirobapN A^jrb jrAb jrb jrbh jrbp
A place of seed-produce; (S, K;) as also jariybN↓: (K:) and a tract of land such as is termed qaraAH [i. e. a field, or land, sown or for sowing, without any building or trees in it; or land cleared for sowing and planting; or a separate piece of land in which palm-trees &c. grow; &c.]: (K:) metaphorically applied by Imra-el-Keys to [a grove of] palm-trees, where he says
kajirobapi naxolK A^awo kajan~api yavoriba
[Like a grove of palm-trees, or like the plantation of Yethrib]: (AHn, TA:) or land prepared for sowing or planting: (AHn, K:) or a piece of land differing in condition from the land adjoining it, [i. e. a patch of land,] producing good plants or herbage: (Lth, TA:) the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] is jirobN↓, (Lth, AHn,) like as tibonN is of tibonapN, and sidorN of sidorapN: (AHn:) or jirobN signifies a qaraAH; and its pl. is jirabapN. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- A skin, or a mat, which is placed upon the brink of a well, lest the water should be scattered into the well [app. in falling from the bucket into the channel of the tank or cistern &c.]: or (a skin, TA,) that is placed in a rivulet or streamlet jadowal [which is applied in the present day to an artificial streamlet for irrigation, in the form of a trench or gutter,]) that the water may flow down over it [app. from the well to the tank or cistern &c.]. (M, K.)

jaribapu A^jrb jrAb jrb jrbh jrbp
: see A^ajorabu, last sentence but one.

jarobaAnu A^jrb jrb jrbAn
or jarobaAnN: see A^ajorabu: ＝ -A2- and for the latter, see jurub~aAnN.

jurobaAnN A^jrb jrb jrbAn
and jirobaAnN: see jurub~aAnN, in five places.

jurub~aA=' jrbA='
and jirib~aA=': see what next follows.

jurub~aAnN A^jrb jrb jrbAn
(S, MF, TA) and jirib~aAnN, (Mj, MF, TA,) which are the two forms commonly known, (MF, TA,) or, accord. to the K, jirobaAnN↓ and jurobaAnN↓, or, accord. to the L, jarobaAnN↓, and sometimes jurobaAnN↓, or, accord. to some copies of the K, [and so in the CK,] jirib~aA='↓ and jurub~aA='↓, which are evident mistranscriptions, or, accord. to the 'Ináyeh of El-Khafájee, jarib~aAnN, which is more strange, (MF,) but this last accords [most nearly] with its original, (TA,) [for it is] a Persian word arabicized, (S, TA,) originally GariybaAno; (TA;) The jayob [or opening at the neck and bosom] of a shirt: (K, TA:) or the part around the neck, upon which are sewed the buttons: (IB and TA in art. bnq:) or the [part called] libonap [q. v.] of a shirt. (S, TA.) ― -b2- jurub~aAnu sayofK (Fr, S, K) and jurobaAnuhu↓, (K, TA,) or jirobAnhu↓, (CK,) The edge (Had~) of a sword: (K:) or a thing [i. e. a case] (K, TA) of sewed leather (TA) in which are put a sword and its scabbard with the cords or belts by which it is suspended: (K, TA;) i. q. qiraAbuhu: (S: [see also jiraAbN:]) or a large sword-case in which are a man's sword and his whip and what else he requires: (Fr, TA: [also called julub~aAn and jilib~aAn and julobaAn:]) in the L, the first is [also] said to signify the scabbard of a sword. (TA.)

jirobiyaA='u jrbyA='
[a word of a very rare form, (see kiboriyaA='u,)] The north-west wind; a wind of the kind termed nakobaA='u, that blows in a direction between that of the [north wind, or northerly wind, called] $amaAl and that of the [west wind, or westerly wind, called] dabuwr, and that dispels the clouds: (S, TA:) it is a cold wind, and is sometimes attended by a little rain: (TA in art. nkb, q. v.:) or the [north wind, or northerly wind, called] $mAl: or the cold of that wind: (K, TA:) or, (K,) as also A^azoyabu, (TA,) the south east wind; the wind that blows in a direction between that of the [south wind, or southerly wind, called] januwb and that of the [east wind, or easterly wind, called] SabaA. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also, with the article Al, a name of The seventh earth: corresponding to AlEirobiyaA='u, a name of “the seventh heaven.” (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A weak man. (K.)

jiraAbN jrAb
, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) not jaraAbN, (ISk, Msb, K,) or this latter is of weak authority, (K, TA,) or peculiar to the vulgar, (S, L,) A provisionbag for travellers: (K, Har p. 174:) or a bag, or receptacle, for travelling-provisions and for goods or utensils &c.,; syn. wiEaA='N: (K, TA:) or such a receptacle made of sheep-skin, in which nothing is kept but what is dry: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] jurubN (S, Msb, K) and jurobN, (S, K,) the latter a contraction of the former, (TA,) and [of pauc.] A^ajoribapN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A sword-case; or a case, or receptacle, in which a sword is put with its scabbard and its suspensory belt or cord; syn. qiraAbu sayofK. (TA. [See also jurub~aAnN.]) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The scrotum. (K.) ― -b4- jiraAbu Alqalobi (assumed tropical:) [The pericardium, or heart-purse]. (K in art. vht, &c.) ― -b5- jiraAbu Albiy^ori (assumed tropical:) The cavity of the well; (M, K;) or (tropical:) its interior, (Lth, S, M, A,) from top to bottom. (Lth, S, M.) You say, AiTowi jiraAbahaA biAlHijaArapi Case thou its interior with stones. (A.)

jariybN jryb
A certain measure, (M, A, Mgh, K,) or quantity, of wheat, (S, Msb,) consisting of four A^aqofizap [pl. of qafiyzN]: (M, A, Msb, K:) or ten Aqfzp; each qfyz thereof consisting of ten A^aEo$iraA=' [pl. of Ea$iyrN]; so that the E$yr is the hundredth part of the whole: (TA:) or, as some say, a measure differing in different countries; as is the case of the rTol and mud~ and *iraAE &c. (MF, TA.) For the pl., see what follows. ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh,) (assumed tropical:) A certain quantity of land; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as much as is sown with the measure of seed so called; (A, Mgh;) like as mules and the space that they travel are termed bariydN: (A, Mgh: *) it is sixty cubits by sixty cubits; accord. to Kudámeh, the extent termed A^a$ol multiplied by itself; the A$l being sixty cubits; the cubit being six qabaDaAt; and the qaboDap, four A^aSaAbiE: the tenth part of the jryb is called qfyz, and the tenth of the qfyz is called E$yr; so that the qfyz is ten AE$rA': (Mgh:) it is a distinct portion of land, differing according to the different conventional usages of the people of different provinces: it is said that the width of six moderate-sized barleycorns is called A_iSobaEN; the qbDp is four ASAbE; the *iraAE is six qbDAt; ten A^a*oruE are called qaSabapN; ten qaSabaAt are called A$l; and the jryb is the extent termed A$l multiplied by itself: the A$l multiplied by the qSbp is called qfyz; and the A$l multiplied by the *rAE is called E$yr: so the jiryb is ten thousand cubits: or, accord. to Kudámeh the Scribe, it is three thousand and six hundred cubits: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajoribapN and [of mult.] jurobaAnN (S, Msb, K) and juruwbN. (R, TA.) See also jirobapN. ― -b3- Also A valley; (Lth, Msb, K; [accord. to the second of which, this is the primary signification;]) i. e., in an absolute sense; and, with the article Al, the name of a particular valley in the territory of Keys: (TA:) pl. A^ajoribapN. (Lth, TA.)

jaworabN jwrb
[A sock or stocking, or a pair of socks or stockings;] the wrapper of the foot or leg: (K:) or a pair of woollen envelopes for the feet, used for warmth: (TA:) an arabicized word, (S, Msb,) from the Persian Guwrabo, originally Guwro, i. e. “tomb of the foot:” (TA:) pl. jawaAribapN and jawaAribu; (S, A, Msb, K;) in the former of which, the p is added because it is originally a foreign word. (S, TA.) You say, huwa A^anotanu mino riyHi Aljaworabi [He, or it, is more stinking than the smell of socks, or stockings]. (A, TA.)

jawaAribiY~N jwArbY jwArby jwrb
A maker of jawaArib [i. e. socks or stockings]. (TA.)

A^jorabu *
(S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and jaribN↓ (A, Mgh, K) and jarobaAnu↓ or jarobaAnN (K accord. to different copies) [Mangy, or scabby;] affected with what is termed jarab: (S, A, Msb, K:) applied to a camel, (A, Msb,) and to a man: (S, A:) fem. (of the first, Msb) jarobaA='u (A, Msb) and [of the second] jaribapN: (A:) pl. (of the first, S, Msb) jurobN (S, A, Msb, K) and (of the first, S, Mgh, TA, or of the second, Mgh, or of the third agreeably with analogy, TA) jarobaY (S, Mgh, K) and [of the first] A^ajaAribu, which is like certain pls. of substantives, as A^ajaAdilu and A^anaAmilu, (TA,) and (of the first contrary to rule, like EijaAfN and biTaAHN and EiSaAlN which are pls. of A^aEojafu and A^aboTaHu and A^aEoSalu, Msb, or of the second, IB, K, or of jurobN, which is pl. of the first, S) jiraAbN: (S, IB, Msb, K:) this last occurs in the following verse [of ‘Amr, or’ Omeyr, Ibn-El-Hobáb, or El-Khabbáb; these variations being in different copies of the K; but in the TA art. n$r, and in a copy of the S in that art. and in the present one, ‘Omeyr Ibn-El-Khabbáb]:
wafiynaA waA_ino qiyla A@SoTalaHonaA taDaAgunN
kamaA Tar~a A^awobaAru AljiraAbi EalaY Aln~a$ori
(S, K *) Within us, though it be said that we have made peace, one with another, and we are on good terms outwardly, is mutual rancour: as the soft wool of the mangy camels (while disease lurks beneath, within them, TA) grows by reason of [eating] the n$r [or herbage] that becomes green at the and of summer (in consequence of rain falling upon it, TA) and is injurious to animals that pasture upon it: (K, TA:) and it is said by IB, and in the K, that jrAb, here, is pl. of jaribN, not, as J says, of jurobN: but MF observes that fiEaAlN is the pl. measure of several words of the measure fuEolN, as rumoHN and duhonN, and is even said by IHsh and Ibn-Málik and AHei to be regularly applicable to sings. of this latter measure; whereas no grammarian nor Arabic scholar asserts that a word of the measure faEilN assumes fiEaAlN as the measure of its pl. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] sayofN A^ajorabu (tropical:) A sword reddened by much rust, which cannot be removed from it unless with a file. (A.) ― -b3- And A^aroDN jarobaA='u (tropical:) Land affected with. drought: (S, A, Msb, K: *) or salt land, affected with drought, and containing nothing. (ISd, TA.) ― -b4- And AljarobaA='u (tropical:) The sky; (S, M, A, K;) so called because of the stars (S, TA) and the milky way, (TA,) as though it were scabbed with stars; (S, IF, ISd;) its stars being likened to the marks of jarab; (A;) like as the sea is called A^ajoradu, and like as the sky is also called raqiyE because [as it were] patched with stars: (AAF, ISd:) or that tract of the sky in which the sun and moon revolve: (M, K:) or the lowest heaven: (AHeyth, TA:) and accord. to the M, jrbp [so in the TA, app. jaribapu↓,] is applied as a determinate [proper] name to the sky. (TA.) ― -b5- And jarobaA='u (assumed tropical:) A beautiful girl; (IAar, K;) so called because the women separate themselves from her, seeing that their goodly qualities are rendered foul by comparison with hers. (IAar, TA.)

tajoribapN jrb tjrbh tjrbp
is a subst. from jar~aba: (Msb:) or it is an inf. n. of that verb, (M, A, K,) and is one of the inf. ns. from which pls. are formed: (M, TA:) its pl. is tajaArbu (M, Msb, TA) and tajaAriybu, (M, TA.) En-Nábighah says,
A_ilaY Alyawomi qado jur~ibona kul~a Alt~ajaAribi
[To this day, they (referring to females) have been tried with every kind of tryings]: and El-Aashà says,
kamo jar~abuwhu famaA zaAdato tajaAribuhumo
A^abaA qudaAmapa A_il~aA Almajoda waAlqanaEaA
[How often have they tried him, and their tryings of Aboo-Kudámeh have not increased aught save his glory and contentment!]; tjArb being here a pluralized inf. n. made to govern an objective complement; which is a strange fact. (M, TA.) [But in this latter instance, we may consider AbA qdAmp as a first objective complement of rAdt, and $ayoy^aA, understood before Al~A, as a second objective complement of the same verb.]

mujoribN mjrb
A man who has his camels affected with what is termed jarab [i. e. the mange, or scab]: whence the prov., laA A_ilaAha limujoribK [There is no god to one who has his camels affected with the mange]; as though he renounced his god by frequently swearing falsely by him that he had no pitch when it was demanded of him [for the purpose of curing other camels]: (A:) or laA A^aliy~apa limojoribK [There is no oath to one who has his camels affected with the mange; for the reason above mentioned, or because he is likely to deny that he has mangy camels lest his camels should be prevented from coming to water: and hence also,] A^akodabu mino mujoribK [More lying than one who has his camels affected with the mange]; another prov. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 382.])

mujar~abN mjrb
One who has been tried, or proved, in affairs, and whose qualities have become known: (T, TA:) or one who has been tried, or proved, and strengthened by experience in affairs: (S:) [experienced, or expert, in affairs:] or one whose qualities have been tried, or proved. (K, TA.) And mujar~ibN↓ One having experience in affairs. (K, TA.) In general, but not always, (MF,) the Arabs used the former of these two epithets [which are virtually synonymous]. (S, MF.) ― -b2- daraAhimu mujar~abapN Weighed money. (Kr, K.) ― -b3- Almujar~abu The lion. (Sgh, K.) ＝ -A2- [It is also employed as an inf. n. of 2, in accordance with a usage of which there are many other instances; as in the saying,] A^anota EalaY Almujar~abi [Thou art about to have the proof, or experience]: a prov., mentioned by AZ: said to him who asks respecting a thing which he is about to know of himself: originally said by a woman to a man who asked her an indecent question which he was himself about to resolve. (TA.)

mujar~ibN mjrb
: see mujar~abN.

jir~iyvN jryv
A kind of fish, (S, Mgh, K,) well known, (TA,) also called jir~iY~N and Sil~aworN, (Mgh, TA,) resembling a serpent, called in Persian maAro maAhiY [snake-fish, or eel]; forbidden to be eaten by the Jews: whether it be lawful to the Muslims is disputed: (TA:) qir~iyvN is a dial. var. (S in art. qrv.)

Q. 2 tajarovama tjrvm
: see 3, in two places. ＝ -A2- tjrvm Al$~aYo'a He took the greater, main, or chief, part of the thing. (K.)

Q. 3 Aijoranovama Ajrnvm
He, or it, drew himself, or itself, together; contracted; or shrank: (TA, Har p. 297:) from jurovuwmapN signifying the “earth collected around a tree.” (Har ib.) Also, and tjrvm↓, It (a thing, S) collected itself together, or became collected, (S, K,) and kept to a place. (K.) Hence, in a trad., waEaAda lahaA Aln~iqAdu mujoranovimFA↓ And the lambs, by reason of it, namely, the vehement drought, became collected, or drawn, together [in one place, and kept to it]. (TA.) ― -b2- He (a man, TA) fell from a high, or higher, to a low, or lower, place; as also tjrvm↓. (K, TA.)

jurovumapN jrvmh jrvmp
: see what next follows.

jurovuwmapN jrvwm jrvwmh jrvwmp
[and accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the S, jurovuwmN, but this I have. not found in any Lexicon but his and that of Freytag,] The root, lowest part, base, stock, or source, syn. A^aSolN, of a thing; (S, Mgh, K;) whatever the thing be; (Mgh;) as also jurovumapN↓: (TA:) and the place of collection thereof: (Mgh, TA:) or the earth that is collected at the roots, or lower parts, of trees: (K:) or the earth collected around a tree: (Har p. 297:) or the root of a tree to which the earth is collected: (Lth, TA:) pl. jaraAviymu. (Mgh.) One is related to have said, AlA^asodu jurovuwmapu AlEarabi famano A^aDal~a nasabahu faliyaA^otihimo [ElAsd are those, of the Arabs, to whom most others congregate: therefore whoever loses his genealogy, let him come to them]: meaning AlA^azodu. (TA.) And jaraAviymu jahan~ama means The greater, main, or chief, degrees of the punishment of Hell. (Mgh.) ― -b2- The base (A^aSol) of a sandhill overlooking what surrounds it. (Har p. 99.) And the pl. (jrAvym), Places elevated above the ground, composed of clay and earth collected together. (TA.) ― -b3- The earth collected by ants; (TA;) an ant-hill: (K:) or jurovuwmapu Aln~amoli signifies the ant-hill. (S.) ― -b4- The earth, or dust, that the wind raises, or sweeps up and scatters. (K.) ― -b5- The galoSamap [or epiglottis]. (K.)

mujoranovimN mjrnvm
: see 3. ― -b2- rakabN mujoranovamN [in the CK, erroneously, rakobN mujoranovamN,] i. q. musotahodifN, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, musotahodafN,]) i. e., A wide, elevated pubes. (TA in art. hdf.)

1 jaraHahu jrH jrHh jrHp
, (S, A, K, &c.,) aor.
jaraHa
, (K, Msb, &c.,) inf. n. jaroHN, (S, Msb, &c.,) He wounded him;
produced an effect, or made an impression, upon him with a weapon: (L:) he cut him: (A, MF:) or clave, or rent, some part of his body: (MF:) syn. kalamahu: (K:) and jr~Hhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. tajoriyHN, (TA,) signifies the same (K) in an intensive sense, or as applying to several objects; (S;) or he wounded him much. (L.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or jaraHahu bilisaAnihi, (A, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (Msb,) [lit. He wounded him with his tongue; meaning] (tropical:) he reviled him, or vilified him; (A, K;) he imputed to him a vice, or fault, or the like; or spoke against him. (Msb.) And jaraHuwhu biA^anoyaAb waA^aDoraAsK [lit. They wounded him with dog-teeth and grinders; meaning] (tropical:) they reviled him, or vilified him, and imputed to him vices or the like. (A.) And hence, (Msb,) jaraHa Al$~iAhida (A, L, Msb, K) [and jr~Hhu↓, as in many of the law-books,] said of a judge, (A, L,) or other person, (I.,) (tropical:) He annulled the witness's claim to be legally credible, (L, K,) by happening to discover in him a falsehood &c.; (L;) he evinced in the witness something that caused his testimony to be rejected: (Msb:) he censured the witness, and rejected what he said. (L.) And jaraHa Alr~ajula (tropical:) He invalidated the man's testimony. (L.) And jaraHa Al$~ahaAdapa (tropical:) [He, or it, invalidated the testimony; or annulled its claim to be legally credible]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Also jaraHa, and AjtrH↓, (tropical:) He gained, acquired, or earned; (S, Mgh, K, TA;) or applied himself with art and diligence to get, obtain, gain, acquire, or earn; (S, K, TA;) a thing: (TA:) he worked, or wrought, with his hand, and gained, acquired, or earned; &c.: (Msb:) from jiraAHapN. (Mgh.) You say, fulaAnN yajoraHu liEiyaAlihi, and yajotariHu↓, (tropical:) Such a one [works, and earns sustenance, or] gains, acquires, or earns, and collects, for his family, or household. (TA) And biy^osa maA jaraHato yadaAka, and A@jotaraHato↓, (tropical:) Very evil is that which thy hands have done, or wrought, or effected: a metaphor taken from the signification of “cutting,” or “wounding;” (A, TA;) accord. to El-Khafájee, a metaphorical meaning conventionally regarded as proper. (TA.) Als~ay~aA=ti A@jotaraHuwA↓, in the Kur [xlv. 20], means (tropical:) Have committed crimes, sins, or evil actions. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jariHa, aor. as above, He (a man, TA) received a wound. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) He had his testimony rejected as not legally entitled to credit: (K, * TA:) and so his relation. (TA.)

2 jar~aHa
see 1, in two places.

8 A_ijotaraHa
see 1, in four places.

10 AstjrH AstjrH
(tropical:) He deserved that his claim to be legally credible should be annulled. (A, TA.) And (tropical:) It (a tradition, or narrative, A, or a thing, Msb) deserved to be rejected [as unworthy of credit or regard]. (A, Msb.) AisotajoraHato h`*ihi AlA^aHaAdiyvu means (tropical:) These traditions deserved to be rejected on account of their great number and the fewness of such as were true: (A:) or, by reason of their great number, obliged those who were acquainted with them to annul the claim of some one or other of their relaters to be credited, and to reject his relation: (L:) or were corrupt: (T, S, * TA:) [for] AisotijoraAHN signifies [also] the being faulty, defective, and corrupt. (S, K.) One says, qado waEaZotukumo falamo tazodaAduwA A_il~aA A@sotijoraAHFA: (S, A:) these words are from a xuTobap of ‘AbdEl-Melik; and the meaning is, [I have admonished you and ye have not increased save] in corrupt conduct: or in what gaineth for you censure. (TA.)

jaroHN jrH
: see the next paragraph.

juroHN jrH
a subst. from jaraHa; (S, L, K;) A wound; (L;) and so jaroHN↓, in its original acceptation; but some of those skilled in the science of lexicology say that the former is employed to denote the effect produced upon bodies by iron instruments and the like; and the latter, that produced upon objects of the mind by the tongue: (MF:) the pl. of the former is juruwHN and A^ajoraAHN [which is a pl. of pauc.] (S, L, K) and jiraAHN; (T, A, L;) but the second of these is of rare occurrence, (K,) only used in poetry: (S, L:) [respecting the third, see what follows:] jiraAHapN↓ also signifies the same as juroHN; (Msb;) and its pl. is jiraAHN (S, Msb, K) and jiraAHaAtN (A, Msb) and jaraAy^iHu; (A;) or jiraAHN is a coll. gen. n., of which jiraAHapN is the n. un.; or, accord. to Az, this last has not a sing. sense, as Lth asserts it to have, but is a pl. of juroHN, like as HijaArapN is of HajarN, and jimaAlapN of jamalN, and HibaAlapN of HabolN. (L.)

juroHapN jrH jrHh jrHp
(tropical:) A thing whereby testimony is invalidated, or its claim to be legally credible annulled: as in the saying, halo laka juroHapN (tropical:) [Hast thou anything to adduce whereby to invalidate the testimony?]. (A, TA.) A^aqoSaSotuka AljuroHapa faA_ino kaAna Einodaka maA tajoraHu bihi AlHuj~apa fahalum~ahaA, said by the judge of El-Medeeneh to one of the parties in a lawsuit, when about to give judgment against him, means (tropical:) I authorize thee to adduce anything whereby to invalidate the testimony: [therefore, if thou have anything whereby thou mayest invalidate the allegation, adduce it.] (A, * TA.)

jariyHN jryH
; pl. jaroHaY; (S, A, Msb, K;) each of which is mase. and fem.; (S, K;) Wounded. (Msb.) The pl. is not formed by the addition of w and n because the fem. is not formed by the addition of p. (TA.)

jiraAHapN jrAH jrAHh jrAHp jrH
: see juroHN.

jaraAy^iHiY~N *
: see what next follows.

jar~aAHN jrAH jrH
A surgeon that dresses wounds. (Golius on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof; and so in the present day; as also jaraAy^iHiY~N↓.)

jaAriHapN jArH jArHh jArHp
sing. of jawaAriHu. (Mgh, L, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- The latter signifies (tropical:) Beasts, and birds, of prey; or that catch game; (S, A, * Mgh, L, Msb, K:) thus the falcon is a jArHp, and so is the dog trained for hunting, because it gains for its owner: (L:) and this appellation is applied alike to the male and the female, like raAHilapN and raAwiyapN. (Msb.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The members, or limbs, of a man, with which things are gained or earned; (S, K, TA;) or with which one works; (A;) as the hands or arms, and the feet or legs: (S, A, K, TA:) because they gain, or earn, or do, good and evil. (TA.) ― -b4- [And (tropical:) The organs of the body: thus, for instance, jArHp is applied (in the Msb, art. bSr,) to the eye, which is termed (in the TA in that art.) the seeing jArHp (AljaAriHapu Aln~aAZirapu).] ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) Mares: [and the like:] because they bring gain to their owners by their breeding. (AA, T.) You say, maA lahu jaAriHapN (assumed tropical:) He possesses not a female beast that bears young: he possesses not that which makes gain. (TA.) And h`*ihi Aln~aAqapu mino jawaAriHi AlmaAli, and h*h AlA^ataAnu, (K,) and h*h Alfarasu, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) This she-camel, and this she-ass, and this mare, is young, unimpaired by age (muqobilapN [i. q. muqotabalapN]) in the womb, (K, TA,) and in youthful vigour, and one of which the offspring is wished for. (TA.)

1 jarada jrd
, aor.
jaruda
, inf. n. jarodN: see 2, in nine places. ― -b2- jarada AljaraAdu AlA^aroDa, (A, L, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (L,) (tropical:) The locusts stripped the land of all its herbage; (A, * L;) ate what was upon the land. (Msb.) ― -b3- jaradahumu AljaAruwdu (tropical:) [The year of drought destroyed them]. (A.) ＝ -A2- juridati AlA^aroDu (assumed tropical:) The land had its herbage eaten by locusts; (S;) was smitten by locusts. (Msb.) ― -b2- jurida said of seed-produce, (assumed tropical:) It was smitten [or eaten] by locusts. (K.) ― -b3- And said of a man, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He had a complaint of his belly from having eaten locusts. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- jarida, aor.
jarada
, (K,) inf. n. jaradN, (TA,) (tropical:) It (a place) was, or became, destitute of herbage. (K, TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) had no hair upon him [i. e. upon his body, or, except in certain parts: see A^ajoradu]. (S: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He (a horse, K, TA, or similar beast, TA) had short hair: (TA:) or had short and fine hair: as also Anjrd↓. (K, TA.) [See A^ajoradu.] ― -b4- See also 7. ― -b5- Also, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, S) became affected with the cutaneous eruption termed $arFY, from having eaten locusts. (S, K.)

2 jr~d jrd
, (A, L,) inf. n. tajoriydN, (S, A, L,) He stripped, divested, bared, or denuded, of garments, or clothes. (S, A, L.)
