, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (T, S, K,) and to a skin for water or milk, &c., (T, TA,) Old, and worn out: (T, TA:) or threadbare, or worn, and soft, or smooth: and in like manner applied to a coat of mail: (S, K:) as also jariynN↓: (TA:) or, applied to a coat of mail (diroE), in which case it is with p, that has become smooth from much use: (Ham p. 656:) pl. jawaArinu: (S, TA:) and, applied to a commodity, or utensil, or an article of furniture, used, and worn out: and to a skin for water or milk, dried up, and rough, or coarse, from use: (TA:) and to a road, worn, or effaced. (Abu-l-Jarráh, S, K.) ― -b2- Also The young one of a serpent: (S, K:) or of a viper, (Lth, M, TA,) such as is smooth. (Lth, TA.)

majoranN mjrn
: see jariynN.

mijoranN mjrn
: see jariynN. ＝ -A2- Also Very voracious: (K:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.)

mujar~anN mjrn
A whip of which the thong has become soft, or smooth. (K.) Az says, I have seen them make their whips from the jurun [pl. of jiraAnN q. v.] of camels such as are termed buzol [i. e. in the ninth year, or nine years old], because of the thickness thereof. (TA.)

4 A^ajorato *
[in its primary sense app. signifies She (a bitch, and any female beast of prey,) whelped; or had a whelp, or whelps: see mujorK. (Accord. to Golius, as on the authority of J, Cum fœtu abiit vel asportavit eum fera: but I have not found it in any copy of the S, nor in any other lexicon.) ― -b2- And hence,] said of a tree ($ajarapN), It had upon it [fruits such as are termed] jiraA=' [pl. of jirowN]; (As, TA;) said [for instance] of a mawozap [or banana-tree]: (AHn, TA in art. mwz:) and [in like manner] said of a herb,
or leguminous plant, (baqolapN,) it had jiraA='; (K in art. jrY; [in the CK, erroneously, jarA';]) belonging to the present art., not to art. jrY. (TA.)

jirowN jrw
and jurowN and jarowN (of which the first is the most chaste, Msb) The whelp, or young one, of the dog, (S, Msb, K,) [and so, app., jirowapN↓, q. v.,] and of the lion, (K,) and of any beast of prey: (S, Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajorK, (S, K,) originally A^ajoruwN, (S,) and A^ajoriyapN (Lh, K) and A^ajoraA='N (K) and [of mult.] jiraA='N; (S, K;) A^ajoriyapN, as pl. of jrw, being anomalous; (TA;) or it is pl. of jiraA='N [and therefore not anomalous]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And the same, (K,) or the first of these, (S, El-Bári', Msb, TA,) only, (TA,) (tropical:) The small of anything, (El-Bári', Msb, K, TA,) as also jirowapN↓; (TA;) even, (K,) of the colocynth, (As, S, K,) and of the melon, and the like; (K;) as, for instance, (TA,) of the pomegranate, (S, TA,) and of the poppy, (AHn, TA in art. Etr,) and of the baA*anojaAn, (TA,) and of the cucumber, (S, TA,) as also jirowapN↓, (S, Msb,) likened to the whelps of dogs, because of their softness and smoothness: (Msb:) or what is round of the fruits of trees; as the colocynth and the like: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^jorK (Msb, K, TA [in the CK, erroneously, Aajoruw^N]) and [of mult.] jiraA='N. (As, Msb, K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Fruit when it first grows forth, (AHn, K,) in its fresh, juicy, state. (AHn, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The seeds, (M, TA,) or envelope, or receptacle, of the seeds, (K,) of the kaEaAbiyr [app. meaning the round and compact pericarps (in some of the copies of the K, erroneously, as is observed in the TA, EkAbyr,)] that are at the heads of branches. (M, K.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A tumour in a camel's hump; and in the withers; so called by way of comparison [to a whelp]: (TA:) and in the fauces. (K.) ― -b6- See also what next follows, last sentence.

jirowapN jr jrY jrwh jrwp
: see jirowN, in three places. A huntsman beat, or disciplined, or trained, his dog for the purpose of the chase (Darabahu EalaY AlS~ayodi); and thereupon it was said, Daraba jirowatahu [app. meaning He beat, or disciplined, or trained, his whelp]: and hence this phrase became proverbially used, in instances here following. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- I. q. nafosN [as meaning Self]. (TA.) You say, Daraba Ealayohi jirowatahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He disposed and subjected himself to it; (S, TA;) namely, a thing, an affair, or a case: and he endured it with patience: and in like manner, Daraba jirowapa nafosihi: (TA:) and A^aloqaY fulaAnN jrowatahu he endured the thing with patience. (S, TA.) Also Darabotu jirowatiY Eanohu (assumed tropical:) I endured with patience the want, or loss, of it: (TA:) or my mind became at ease [respecting it]. (AA, IB, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also (K, TA, [in the CK jirowN↓,]) (tropical:) A short she-camel. (K, TA.)

mujorK mjr
and mujoriyapN applied to a bitch, (S, K,) and a female beast of prey, (TA,) Having a whelp, or young one: (K:) or having with her her whelps, or young ones. (S.) El-Aalam says,
laHomiY A_ilaY A^ajorK HawaA$ibo
watajur~u mujoriyapN lahaA
And a hyena having young ones shall drag for her my flesh to young ones with swollen bellies, and short. (Skr p. 57.)

1 jaraY jr jrY jry
, said of water (S, Mgh, Msb) &c., (S,) or of water and the like, (K,) more properly thus, as in the K, aor.
jariYa
, (TA,) inf. n. jaroYN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jarayaAnN (S, K) and jiroyapN, (S, * Msb, K,) [which last see below,] It ran, or passed along quickly; originally said of water: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it flowed;; syn. saAla; contr. of waqafa and sakana. (Msb.) ― -b2- Said also of farina, in the phrase jaraY Ald~aqiyqu fiY Als~unobuli [The farina pervaded the ears of wheat]. (L in art. qmH.) ― -b3- And of a horse (Mgh, Msb, K) and the like, (Msb, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. jaroYN (Msb, K) and jarayaAnN (Msb) and jiraA='N (Lth, K) and majorFY, (S,) [He ran;] from the same verb said of water. (Mgh) ― -b4- And of a ship: you say, jarati Als~afiynapN, (S, TA,) inf. n. jaroYN (TA) and majorFY, (S, K,) [The ship ran.] ― -b5- And of the sun, and a star: you say, jarati Al$~amosu, aor.
jariYa
, inf. n. jaroYN, [The sun pursued its course:] and jarati Aln~ujuwmu The stars travelled, or passed along, from east to west. (TA.) ― -b6- jaraY A_ilaY ka*aA, (Msb, and Har p. 152,) inf. n. jaroYN and jiraA='N; (Msb;) and A_ilayohi AjrY↓, inf. n. A_ijoraA='N; (Ham p. 224, and Har p. 152;) He betook, or directed, himself to such a thing; made it his object; aimed at it; intended, or purposed, it: (Msb, and Har ubi suprà:) and he hastened to it: (Msb:) but in the latter phrase, an objective complement is understood; and it is used in relation to something disapproved, or disliked; (Ham and Har;) properly, AjrY fiEolahu A_ilayoh, (Ham,) or AjrY fiEolahu biAlqaSodi A_ilayohi. (Har.) ― -b7- Hence, perhaps, the saying, jaraY AlxilaAfu fiY ka*aA (tropical:) [frequently used as meaning A controversy ran, or ran on, respecting such a thing between such and such persons]. (Msb.) ― -b8- jaraY lahu Al$~aYo'u, (Sh, TA,) and jaraY Ealayohi, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The thing was permanent, or continued, to him. (Sh, TA.) [And, more commonly, (assumed tropical:) The thing happened, or occurred, to him. Whence, maAjarayaAtN↓, as pl. of maAjaraY, used as a single word, by late writers, meaning (assumed tropical:) Events, or occurrences.] ― -b9- huwa yajoriY majoraAhu (assumed tropical:) It is like it, or similar to it, in state, condition, case, or predicament. (TA.) [It (a word or phrase) follows the same rule or rules, or occupies the same grammatical place, as it (another word or phrase). And similar to this is the saying,] mujaAraApa AlmabiyEi Ald~ayonu waAlr~ahonu yatajaArayaAni↓ wAlv~amani (assumed tropical:) [The debt and the pledge are subject to the same laws as the thing sold and the price]. (Mgh.) ― -b10- [Also (assumed tropical:) It acts as, or in a similar manner to, it: and (assumed tropical:) he acts in his stead: see jariY~N. Hence the phrase, jaraY minohu majoraY ka*aA (assumed tropical:) It acted upon him, or affected him, like, or in a similar manner to, such a thing: as in the prov.,] jaraY minohu majoraY All~aduwdi (assumed tropical:) [It acted upon him, or affected him, like, or similarly to, the medicine, or draught, called ldwd: mnh here having the meaning of fiyhi]. (ISk, S in art. ld.) ― -b11- [One says, also, of an inf. n., and of a part. n., that is regularly formed, yajoriY EalaY AlfiEoli, meaning (assumed tropical:) It is conformable to the verb.]

2 jr~Y jr jrY jry
He sent a deputy, or commissioned agent; as also AjirY↓. (K.) And jr~Y jariy~FA He made, or appointed, a deputy, or commissioned agent; (ISk, S, * TA;) as also AstjrAhu↓. (S, * TA.) Hence the trad., (TA,) laA yasotajoriyan~akumu↓ Al$~ayoTiAnu (S, TA) By no means let the Devil make you his followers and his commissioned agents. (TA.) You say also, fiY HaAjatihi AjrAhu↓ [He sent him to accomplish his needful affair]. (TA.)

3 jArAhu jAr jArAh jArAp jArY
, inf. n. mujaAraApN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jiraA='N, (S, K,) He ran with him. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, jaArayotuhu Hat~aY fut~uhu I ran with him until I passed beyond him, or outwent him. (TA in art. fwt.) ― -b2- [He vied, contended, or competed, with him in running: and hence, (assumed tropical:) in any affair; like saAyarahu.] You say, jArAhu fiY ka*aA wafaEala mivola fiEolihi (assumed tropical:) [He vied, contended, or competed, with him in such an affair, and did like as he did]. (Mgh in art. fwD.) And jArAhu fiY AlHadiyvi (assumed tropical:) [He vied, contended, or competed, with him in discourse]. (S.) And jaArawoA fiY AlHadiyvi (TA) and tajaArawoA↓ fiyhi (S, TA) (assumed tropical:) [They vied, contended, or competed, one with another, in discourse]. And it is said in a trad., mano Talaba AlEiloma liyujaAriYa bihi AlEulamaA='a (assumed tropical:) He who seeks knowledge in order that he may run [i. e. vie] with the learned in discussion and disputation, to show his knowledge to others, to be seen and heard. (TA.) And in another trad., laA tujaAri A^axaAka walaA tu$aArihi walaA tumaArihi (assumed tropical:) [Contend not for superiority with thy brother, (so explained in the TA, voce jaAr~a, in art. jr,) nor dispute with him, nor wrangle with him]: (El-Jámi'-es- Sagheer:) or, as some relate it, laA tujaAr~i A^axaAka walaA tu$aAr~ihi. (TA in art. jr, q. v.)

4 AjrAhu A^jr A^jrAh A^jrY AjrAh AjrAp |jr |jrAh
He made it to run; (S, K, * TA;) said of water &c., (S,) or of water and the like. (K, * TA.) [Hence, AjrY damoEFA, or dumuwEFA, He shed tears.] ― -b2- Also He made him to run; namely, a horse (Mgh, Msb, K *) and the like: (Msb, K: *) in which sense mujorFY [as well as A_ijoraA='N] is used as an inf. n. (S.) ― -b3- AjrY Als~afiynapa [He made the ship to run]: (S:) in this sense, also, mujorFY [as well as A_ijoraA='N] is used as an inf. n. (S, K.) ― -b4- AjrY as syn. with jr~Y; and AjrAhu fiY HaAjatihi: see 2. ― -b5- AjrY A_ilayohi: see 1. ― -b6- A^ajorayotu Ealayohi [and lahu] (assumed tropical:) I made a thing permanent, or continual, to him. (IAar, TA.) [And hence, both of these phrases, in the present day, (assumed tropical:) I made him, or appointed him, a permanent, or regular, allowance of bread &c.; I provided for him, or maintained him.] ― -b7- [AjrAhu mujoraY ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He made it to be like, or similar to, such a thing in state, condition, case, or predicament. (assumed tropical:) He made it (a word or phrase) to follow the same rule or rules, or to occupy the same grammatical place, as such another. (assumed tropical:) He made it to act as, or in a
similar manner to, such a thing.] ― -b8- [Hence,] AisomN laA yajoraY i. q. laA yanoSarifu (assumed tropical:) [A noun that is imperfectly declinable]. (TA in art. Smt, &c.) ＝ -A2- A^ajorato said of a herb, or leguminous plant, (baqolapN,) mentioned in this art. in the K: see art. jrw.

6 tajaArawoA fiY AlHadiyvi tjArwA fy AlHdyv
: see 3. Hence, in a trad., tatajaAraY bihimu AlA^ahowaA='u (assumed tropical:) [Natural desires, or blamable inclinations, or erroneous opinions, contend with them for the mastery: or] they vie, or compete, one with another, in natural desires, &c. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1.

10 AstjrAhu AstjrAh AstjrAp
He demanded, or desired, that he should run. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 2, in two places.

laA jara lA jr
and laA *aA jara, for laA jarama and laA *aA jarama: see art. jrm.

jurapN jr jrh jrp
and jaraAyapN↓: see 1 in art. jrA_.

jarFY jr jrY jry
: see jaraA^'N ＝ -A2- faEalotuhu mino jaraAka, and mn jaraAy^ika↓, I did it because of thee, or of thine act; on thine account; or for thy sake; i. q. mn A^ajolika; like mn jar~aAka [which see in art. jr]. (S, K.)

jiroyapN jry jryh jryp
i. q. jaroYN as inf. n. of jaraY said of water (Msb, K) and the like: (K:) and also A mode, or manner, of running [thereof]. (TA.) You say, maA A^a$ad~a jiroyapa h`*aA AlmaA='i [How vehement is the running, or manner of running, of this water!]. (S.)

jaraA='N jrA='
and jiraA='N↓ (S, K) and jarFY↓ (K) and jaraAyapN↓ (S, K) and jaraAy^iyapN↓ (IAar, K, TA, [in the CK jiraAyapN]) Girlhood; the state of a jaAriyap. (S, K.) One says, kaAna *`lika fiY A^ay~aAmi jaraAy^ihaA That was in the days of her girlhood. (S.) ＝ -A2- faEalotuhu mino jaraAy^ika: see jaraY.

jiraA='N jrA='
: see the next preceding paragraph.

jariY~N jr jrY jry
A commissioned agent; a factor; a deputy: (S, Mgh, K:) because he runs in the affairs of him who appoints him, (Mgh,) or acts in his stead (yajoriY majoraAhu): (S, Mgh:) [in this and other senses following] used alike as sing. and pl., and also as [masc. and] fem.: (K:) but sometimes, though rarely, jariy~apN is used for the fem., accord. to AHát; and accord. to J [in the S, and Mtr in the Mgh], it has A^ajoriyaA='u for its pl. (TA.) And A messenger, or person sent, (S, K,) that runs in an affair. (TA.) But accord. to Er-Rághib, it is weaker [in signification, or in point of chasteness,] than rasuwlN and wakiylN [which are given as its syns. in the S and K]. (TA.) ― -b2- A servant. (TA.) ― -b3- A hired man; a hireling. (Kr, K.) ― -b4- A surety; a guarantee; one who is responsible, accountable, or answerable, for another. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A2- The word signifying “ bold, ” or “ daring, ” is jariYo'N, with '. (S.)

jaraAyapN jrAyh jrAyp
: see jiraAyapN: ＝ -A2- and jaraA='N: ＝ -A3- and jurapN.

jiraAyapN jrAyh jrAyp
The office of a jariY~, i. e. a commissioned agent, factor, or deputy; (S, K;) and of a messenger: (S:) as also jaraAyapN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A running [or permanent] daily allowance of food or the like. (S, TA.) [Hence, in the present day, xubozu jiraAyapK Bread made of inferior flour, for servants and other dependants.]

jaraAy^iyapN *
: see jaraA='N

jiriy~aA='u jryA='
: see A_ijoriy~aA

jir~iY~N jr jrY jry
[The eel;] a certain fish, well known. (K: mentioned also in art. jr, q. v.)

jir~iy~apN jry jryh jryp
, like qir~iy~apN, (S,) The stomach, or triple stomach, or the crop, or craw, of a bird; syn. HawoSalapN: (S, K: mentioned also in art. jr, q. v.:) so called because the food at the last runs into it, or because it is the channel through which the food runs: (Er-Rághib, TA:) thus pronounced by Fr, and by Th on the authority of Ibn-Nejdeh, without ': by Ibn-Háni, [jir~iyoy^apN,] with ', on the authority of AZ. (TA.)

jaArK jAr jAry
applied to water [and the like], [Running, or flowing, or] pressing forward, in a downward and in a level course. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, [as meaning Running,] applied to a horse and the like. (Msb.) ― -b3- SadaqapN jaAriyapN (assumed tropical:) A permanent, continuous, charitable donation; such as the unalienable legacies provided for various benevolent purposes. (TA.)

jaAriyapN jAr jAry jAryh jAryp
A ship; (S, Msb, K;) because of its running upon the sea: (Msb:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: pl. jawaArK (TA.) ― -b2- The sun; (K;) because of its running from region to region: (TA:) or the sun's disk in the sky. (T, TA.) And AljawaAriY Alkun~asu The stars. (TA. [But see art. kns.]) ― -b3- The wind: pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b4- A girl, or young woman; (S, * Mgh, Msb, * K;) a female of which the male is termed gulaAmN; so called because of her activity and running; opposed to EajuwzN: (Mgh:) and (tropical:) a female slave; (Mgh voce gulaAmN;) [in this sense] applied even to one who is an old woman, unable to work, or to employ herself actively; alluding to what she was: (Msb:) pl. as above. (Msb, K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) The eye of any animal. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A benefit, favour, boon, or blessing, bestowed by God (K, TA) upon his servants. (TA.)

A_ijoriY~N A^jr A^jrY A^jrp A^jry A^jryy AjrY Ajry jrY
A kind of running: pl. A^ajaAriY~u. (TA.) You say farasN *uwA^ajaAriY~a A horse that has several kinds of running. (TA.) ― -b2- See also A_ijoriy~aA.

A_ijoriy~apN A^jr A^jrY A^jry A^jryh A^jryp Ajryh Ajryp jrY
: see what next follows.

A_ijoriyaAhu A^jrY A^jry A^jryAh AjryAh AjryAp
: see what next follows.

A_ijoriy~aA A^jrY A^jry A^jryA AjryA
The act of running: (S, and so in some copies of the K: [in this sense, erroneously said in the TA to be btxfyf:]) or A_ijoriY~N↓. (So in this sense in some copies of the K.) ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) and A_ijoriy~aA='u↓, (K,) (assumed tropical:) A custom, or habit, (S,) or manner, (K,) that one adopts (S, K) and follows; (K;) [like hijoriy~aA &c.;] and so A_ijoriyaA='u↓ without teshdeed: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) nature, constitution, or natural disposition; [in the CK, Alxaloqu is erroneously put for Alxuluqu;] as also jiriy~aA='u↓ and A_ijoriy~apN↓. (K.) One says, Alkaramu mino A_ijriy~aAhu and mn A_ijoriy~aAy^ihi↓ (assumed tropical:) Generosity is [a quality] of his nature, &c. (Lh, TA.)

A_ijoriy~aA='u AjryA='
: see what next precedes, in two places.

majorFY mjr mjrY mjry mjryy
[A place, and a time, of running, &c.]. The channel of a river [and of a torrent &c.: a conduit; a duct; any passage through which a fluid runs: pl. majaArK]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, K, &c.)

mujorK mjr
[Making to run]. It is said in a prov., kul~u mujorK fiY AlxalaA='i yusar~u [Every one who makes his horse to run in the solitary place rejoices, because no one can contradict his account of his horse's fleetness]. (Mgh.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 315 and 316, where two other readings are added: kl~ mjr bixalaA='K mujiydN, i. e., is possessor of a fleet horse; and kl~ mjr bixalaA='K saAbiqN, i. e., is one who outstrips.]

maAjarayaAtN mAjryAt
: see 1.

1 jaz~a jz
, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
jazu3a
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. jaz~N, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and jaz~apN↓, (K,) [but the latter seems to be an inf. n. of un.,] He cut (Mgh, Msb, K) wool, (IDrd, S, Mgh, Msb,) [see Halaqa,] and, as some say, other things, (Msb,) or a dense thing, (Mgh,) or hair, (A, K,) and dry herbage, (K,) and seed-produce, (A,) and wheat, (S,) and palm-trees, (S, ISd, A, Mgh,) meaning their fruit; (Mgh;) as also Ajtz~↓. (K.) You say, Al$~iyHa wagayorahu Aijotazazotu↓, and Aijodazazotuhu↓, in the sense of jazazotuhu [I cut the sheeh, a species of wormwood, &c.]. (S.) You say also, jazazotu Alkabo$a wAln~aEojapa, [I shore, or sheared, the ram and the ewe]; but of the she-goat and he-goat you say, HalaqotuhumaA. (TA.) And jaz~a Aln~axolapa, (Lh, A, Mgh,) aor.
jazu3a
, inf. n. jaz~N and jazaAzN and jizaAzN, (Lh, TA,) [like ja*~a and jad~a,] He cut off the fruit of the palm-tree. (Mgh, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in four places.

2 jz~r jzr jzyrp
, inf.n. tajoziyzN, He dried dates. (Msb.)

4 Ajz~ 8
It attained to the proper time for being cut; (S, Msb, TA;) said [app. of wool, and] of hair, and of herbage, (A,) and wheat, (AZ, S, Msb,) and barley; (AZ, Msb;) as also Astjz~↓, (S, Msb, K,) said of wool, (Msb,) and of wheat; (S, K;) and jaz~a↓, [aor., app.,
jazi3a
, as below,] said of wheat. (TA.) ― -b2- Ajz~ Ali$~yHu The sheeh [a species of wormwood] attained to the proper time for being cut: (L, TA:) or Ajz~ Al$~ayoxu (assumed tropical:) The old man attained to the proper time for dying. (K.) [SM says,] Al$~ayoxu seems to be a mistranscription, for Al$~iyHu: if not, it is a tropical expression. (TA.) [But see 4 in art. jzr, and 8 in art. xDr.] ― -b3- Ajz~ Alganamu The sheep attained to the proper time for being shorn; (S, TA;) as also jaz~a↓. (TA.) ― -b4- Ajz~ Aln~axolu The palm-trees attained to the proper time for having their fruit cut off;
(S, K, TA;) as also jaz~a↓. (K.) ― -b5- [Hence, app.,] Ajz~ Alt~amoru The dates dried; (S, K;) as also jaz~a↓, aor.
jazi3a
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. juzuwzN, (S, K,) or jaz~N: (Msb:) you say tamorN fiyhi juzuwzN Dates in which is dryness. (S, TA.) ― -b6- Ajz~ Alqawomu The people attained to the proper time for the shearing of their sheep: (K:) or had their sheep shorn: or had their seed-produce cut. (S, L.) ＝ -A2- Ajz~ Alr~ajula He assigned to the man the jiz~ap [or wool, &c.,] of a sheep. (K.)

8 Ajtz~ * and Aj*z~
: see 1, in three places.

10 A_isotajoza3a
see 4.

juz~N A^jAz A^jz A^jzY Ajz jAz jz jzY wjz
i. q. juzo'N. (Bd in xv. 44.)

jaz~apN jz jzh jzp
[A single cutting, or shearing, or the like.]. (K.) See 1.

jiz~apN jz jzh jzp
[A mode, or manner, of cutting, or shearing, or the like]. You say, jaz~ahu jz~apF HasanapF [He cut it, or sheared it, &c., in a good manner]. (K, TA.) [in the CK, wajiz~apF is omitted after wajaz~apF; so that the reading there is jaz~apF HasanapF.] ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) and jazazN↓ and juzaAzN↓ and juzaAzapN↓, (K,) What is cut, of dates: (K:) or [a fleece; i. e.,] the wool of a sheep [shorn] in one year: (S, K:) [and the hair of a goat, and of a camel, (see tim~apN,) when shorn; a shorn crop of wool, and of goat's hair, and of camel's hair:] or the wool of a ewe, (K, TA,) or of a ram, (TA,) when shorn, and not mixed with any other: (K, TA:) so accord. to AHát: (TA:) or wool not used after being shorn; (K;) in which last sense you say also SuwfN jazazN↓: (TA:) pl. jizazN and jazaAy^izu: (Lh, K:) the latter like DaraAy^iru as pl. of A^aqoriDoniY jiz~apF, without regard to the difference of the vowels [in the sing.]. (TA.) One says to another, A^awo jiz~atayoni kaA^an~ahu EaAD~N EalaY jiz~apK [Lend thou me the wool of a sheep, or of two sheep]; and the latter gives him the wool of a sheep, or of two sheep. (S.) And one says of a man with a large beard, EalaY jaz~apK [As though he were biting] the wool of a shorn sheep. (K, TA: in the CK, jazazN.)

jazazN jzp jzz
: see jiz~apN, in two places.

jazaAzN jzAz
and jizaAzN↓ The act of cutting, or shearing, wool, (Mgh, * Msb,) and hair; (Mgh;) and of reaping; (Fr, S, K;) and of cutting seed-produce (Mgh, K) before it has attained to maturity; (K;) and of cutting off the fruit of palm-trees: (Fr, S, Mgh:) and the time, or season, of shearing sheep [and the like]. (TA.) You say, h`*aA zamanu AljazaAzi, and AljizaAzi, This is the time of cutting, or shearing, wool: (Msb:) and of reaping: and of cutting off the fruit of palm-trees. (S.)

juzaAzN jzAz
What one cuts, or cuts off, of anything; (K;) the cuttings of wool or any other thing: n. un. with p: (TA:) [as, for instance,] what is redundant of a skin or hide when it is cut: (K:) or juzaAzapN↓ signifies what falls from a skin or hide (S, A) or other thing (S) when it is cut. (S, A.) See also jiz~apN.

jizaAzN jzAz
: see jazaAzN

jazuwzN jzwz
What is cut, or shorn; a masc. n.; and, as also jazuwzapN↓, fem.: (K:) or the latter signifies sheep of which the wool is shorn; (S, A;) and is similar to rakuwabpN, and HaluwbapN and EaluwfapN: (S:) Th says that a subst. of this class is only with p, like the three words just mentioned: Lh says that it may be with p and without p; and that the pl. in both cases is of the measures fuEulN and faEaAy^ilu: [in this instance, juzuzN and jazaAy^izu:] but ISd says, I hold that fuEulN is the measure of the pl. of a subst. of this class without p, such as rakuwbN, of which the pl. is rukubN; and faEaAy^ilu, of that which is with rakaAy^ibu, such as rakuwbapN, of which the pl. is rakaAy^ibu. (TA.)

jaziyzN jzyz
and majozuwzN↓ Cut, or shorn. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also jaziyzapN.

juzaAzapN jzAz jzAzh jzAzp
: see jiz~apN: ― -b2- and juzaAzN.

jazuwzapN jzwzh jzwzp
: see jazuwzN.

jaziyzapN jzyzh jzyzp
A flock, or tuft, of wool; as also jizojizapN↓; (S, K;) which [latter] is a tuft of wool, or of wool dyed of various colours, (EihonapN,) that is hung upon a woman's camel-vehicle (hawodaj): (S:) or the latter signifies a tuft of wool tied with threads or strings, with which the woman's camel-vehicle (hwdj) is ornamented: and jazaAy^izu [pl. of the former] and jazaAjizu [pl. of the latter] signify tufts of dyed wool which are hung upon the camel-vehicles (hawaAdij) of women on the day of going forth on a journey; also called vukanN: or jazaAy^izu, (TA,) or jaziyzN↓, (L,) signifies a kind of beads (xaraz) with which the girls, or slave-girls, (jawaArK,) of the Arabs of the desert are adorned, resembling jazoE: or tufts of wool, or of wool dyed of various colours, (EihonN,) which were used in the place of anklets. (TA.)

jizojizapN jzjzh jzjzp
: see jaziyzapN.

mijaz~N mjz
An instrument for cutting or shearing. (S.)

majozuwzN mjzwz
: see jaziyzN.

1 jazaA^ahu *
, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jazaAa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jazo'N, (S,) He divided it (a thing, S) into parts, or portions; (S, K;) made it to consist of parts, or portions; (S, Msb;) as also jz~A^hu↓, (S, * Msb, K,) inf. n. tajoziy^apN, (S,) or tajoziYo'N: (Msb:) when that which is divided is property, as, for instance, slaves, only this latter form of the verb, with teshdeed, is used. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, aor. and inf.n. as above, He took a part, or portion, of it; namely, a thing. (Ham p. 117.) And jazaA^a Al$~iEora, inf. n. as above; and jz~A^hu↓; He curtailed the poetry of two feet in each verse: or he made the poetry to consist of two feet in each verse. (TA. [See majozuwo'N.]) ＝ -A2- Also He made it firm, fast, or strong; or he bound it firmly, fast, or strongly; ($ad~ahu;) namely, a thing. (K.) ＝ -A3- jazaA^a bihi, (S, K,) aor.
jazaAa
, (TA,) inf. n. jazo'N, (S,) [and app. juzo'N also,] He was, or became, satisfied, or content, with it; namely, a thing; (S, K;) as also jaziY'a, a dial. var. mentioned by IAar; (TA;) and bh AjtzA^↓, (S, Msb, K,) and bh tjz~A^↓. (S, K.) A poet says,
waA_in~a Almaro'a yajozaA^u biAlkuraAEi
[And verily the man is satisfied, or content, with the shank of the sheep or goat &c.]. (TA.) And you say TaEaAmN laA jazo'a lahu Food whereof one is not satisfied with a little. (TA.) And lahu fiY h`*aA ganaA='N wajuzo'N [He has, in this, competence and] sufficiency. (Mgh.) And jazaA^ati AlA_ibilu biAlr~uTobi Eani AlmaA='i, (S, Mgh, K,) or [simply] jazaA^ati AlA_ibilu, (Har p. 475,) inf. n. juzo'N, with damm, (S, TA,) and juzuwo'N; (TA;) and jaziy^at, (IAar, K,) and AjtzA^t↓; (Mgh, and Har ubi suprà;) The camels were satisfied, or content, with green, or fresh, pasture or herbage [so as to be in no need of water]. (S, Mgh, K, TA.) And Eani A@moraA^atihi AjtzA^↓ [He was content to abstain from, or be without, conjugal intercourse with his wife]. (M in art. Abl.)

2 jaz~aAa
see 1, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also 4.

4 AjzA^hu *
It (a thing) satisfied, sufficed, or contented, him. (S, Mgh, K.) [Hence,] AjzA^ mujozaY gayorihi [or mujozaA^a gayorihi] It (a thing) satisfied, sufficed, or contented, in lieu of another thing or other things; stood, or served, in stead thereof. (Msb.) And A^ajozaA^otu Eanoka mujozaA^a fulaAnK (S, Mgh, K) and majozaA^a flAn and mujozaA^apa flAn and majozaA^apa flAn, (S, K,) as also mujozaY flAn and mujozaApa flAn without ' and with damm, and majozaY flAn and majozaApa flAn, (K in art. jzY,) I satisfied, sufficed, or con tented, thee as such a one; I stood thee, or served thee, in stead of such a one. (S, Mgh, K.) And AjzA^ AlA_ibila biAlr~uTobi Eani AlmaA='i, (S, K,) inf. n. A_ijozaA='N; (TA;) and jz~A^hA↓, (S, K,) inf. n. tajoziy^apN, (S,) or tajoziYo'N; (TA;) He satisfied, or contented, the camels with green, or fresh, pasture or hesrbage [so that they were in no need of water]. (S, K.) ― -b2- AjzA^ is also syn. with jazaY; the former being of the dial. of Temeem, and the latter of the dial. of El-Hijáz; (Akh, Msb;) and one may suppress the ', and say A^ajozaY: (Mgh, Msb:) this last is used by some of the lawyers in the sense of [jazaY, i. e.] qaDaY. (Az, Mgh, Msb.) One says, A^ajozaA^atN Eanoka $aApN A sheep, or goat, made satisfaction for thee (S, Msb, * K, TA) as a sacrifice; (TA;) syn. qaDato; (S, Msb, K;) the verb being here a dial. var. of jazato. (S, K.) And Albadanapu tajoziy^u Eano saboEapK The camel, or cow, makes satisfaction for seven: or serves in stead of seven. (Mgh.) And h`*aA yujoziy^ uEano h`*aA [This will make satisfaction, for this: or this will serve in stead of this]: and, accord. to 'Alee Ibn-'Eesà, yujoziY also, suppressing the ' (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also, said of pasture, or herbage, (K, TA,) and of a meadow, (TA,) (tropical:) It was, or became, luxuriant: (K, TA:) because satisfying the beasts that feed upon it. (TA.) ― -b4- And, said of a company of men, They had their camels satisfied with green, or fresh, pasture or herbage [so that they were in no need of water]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A^ajozaA^ato She (a woman) brought forth
females. (K. [But see juzo'N, from which it is derived.]) ＝ -A3- AjzA^ He furnished an awl (mixoSaf, S, K, or A_i$ofaY, S), (S, K,) or a knife, (Msb,) with a juzoA^ap, i. e. handle; (S, Msb, K;) as also AjzY. (Msb.) ― -b2- AjzA^ AlxaAtama fiYA_iSobaEihi He put the ring upon his finger. (K.)

5 tjz~A^ *
It became divided into parts, or portions. (Msb, KL.) ＝ -A2- See also 1.

8 A_ijotazaAa
see 1, in three places.

jazo'N jz'
: see juzo'N. ＝ -A2- It is said by El-Khattábee to be a name for ruTb [app. meaning ruTobN, i. e. Green, or fresh, pasture or herbage, (see 1 and 4,)], with the people of El-Medeeneh; and occurs in a trad.; but the reading commonly known is jrw. (TA.)

juzo'N jz'
A part, or portion, (Msb, K, TA,) or division, (TA,) of a thing; (Msb, TA;) properly and conventionally; (TA;) as also jazo'N↓; (K;) a constituent part of a thing, as of a ship, and of a house or tent, and of a sum in reckoning; (B, TA;) [an ingredient of any compound or mixture;] a share, or lot: (TA:) pl. A^ajozaA='N: (S, Msb, K, &c.:) it has no other pl. (Sb, TA.) ― -b2- [A volume of a book.] ― -b3- A foot of a verse. (TA.) ― -b4- In the Kur [xliii. 14], where it is said, wajaEaluwA lahu mino EibaAdihi juzo'FA, (K, TA,) or, as some read, juzu'FA, (Bd,) it means Females; (K, TA;;) i. e., they asserted the angels to be the daughters of God: so says Th: and Aboo-Is-hák says that it means, they asserted God's share of offspring to be the females; but that he had not found this in old poetry, nor had persons worthy of confidence related it on the authority of the Arabs [of the classical times]: Z disallows it, asserting it to be a lie against the Arabs; and Bd follows him: El-Khafájee says that the word may be used figuratively; for, as Eve was created of a part (juzo') of Adam, the word jz' may be applied to denote the female. (MF, TA.)

juzoA^apN *
The handle of the [kind of awl called] mixoSaf, (S, K,) and of the A_i$ofiY: (S:) AZ says that it is not [the handle, or hilt,] of the sword, nor of the dagger; but is the handle of the miy^ovarap with which camels' feet are branded. (TA.) [See also Dab~apN.] ― -b2- A vine-prop; (K, TA;) a piece of wood with which a vine is raised from the ground. (TA.) ― -b3- In the dial. of the tribe of Sheybán, The hinder, or hindermost, $uq~ap [or oblong piece of cloth] of a tent. (TA.)

[
juzoy^iY~N *
Relating to a part or portion or division; partial; particular; contr. of kul~iY~N. ― -b2- And, as a subst., A particular: pl. juzoy^iy~aAtN.]

[
juzoy^iy~apN *
The quality of relating to a part or portion or division; relation to a part &c.; particularity.]

jaziYo'N jzY' jzy' jzy^
Satisfying food; as also mujoziy^N↓; (Fr, K;) like $abiyEN and mu$obiEN. (Fr, TA.)

jaAziy^N *
[act. part. n. of 1]. ― -b2- h`*aA rajulN jaAziy^uka mino rajulK This is a man sufficing thee as a man. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- ZaboyapN jaAziy^apN A doe-gazelle that is satisfied with green, or fresh, pasture or herbage [so as to be in no need of water]: pl. jawaAziy^u. (S.) The pl. is explained by IKt as meaning Gazelles: (TA:) [or] it signifies [or signifies also] Wild bulls or cows; (K, TA;) because they are satisfied with green, or fresh, pasture or herbage so as to be in no need of water. (TA.) Also, the pl., Palm-trees; as not needing irrigation. (TA.)

A^ajozaA^u *
More [and most] satisfying or sufficing or satisfactory: hence, AlfaArisu A^ajozaA^u mina Alr~aAjili [The horseman is more satisfactory than the footman]. (Mgh.)

majozaA^N *
and mujozaA^N are used as inf. ns. of 4 [q. v.]. (TA.)

mujoziy^N *
: see jaziYo'N. ― -b2- Also A strong, fat, camel; because sufficing for the wants of the rider and carrier. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, and mujoziy^apN, A woman who brings forth females. (TA. [But see juzo'N, from which the verb is derived.])

majozaA^apN *
and mujozaA^apN are used as inf. ns. of 4 [q. v.]. (TA.)

majozuwo'N mjz mjzw'
Divided into parts, or portions. (TA.) ― -b2- [Having a part, or portion, taken from it: see 1.] ― -b3- A verse curtailed of two [of the original] feet: [like the hazaj and muDaAriE &c., which were originally of six feet each, but of which every known example is of four only:] or a verse consisting of two feet only: [as a kind of the rajaz, and two kinds of the munosariH: to each of which, or, accord. to some, to the former of which only, when thus consisting of only two feet, the term manohuwkN is also applied:] the former is said to be EalaY Als~alobi; and the latter, EalaY Alwujuwbi. (TA.)

1 jazara jzr jzyrp
, aor.
jazira
and sometimes
jazura
, (K,) inf. n. jazorN, (Mgh, K,) He cut, or cut off, (Mgh, K,) a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- jazara, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
jazura
, (S, Msb,) [inf. n. as above,] He slaughtered a camel (S, Mgh, Msb) or other animal, (Msb,) and skinned it; (S;) as also Ajtzr↓. (S, TA.) You say also, jazara lahumo, meaning He slaughtered for them a camel. (A.) And Alqawoma jazuwrFA Ajtzr↓ He slaughtered and skinned for the people a camel. (TA.) ― -b3- jazara Aln~axola, aor.
jazira
(S, K) and
jazura
, (K,) inf. n. jazorN (S, K) and jazaArN and jizaArN, (Lh, K,) He cut off the fruit of the palm-trees: (Lh, S, K:) or, as some say, he spoiled the palm-trees in fecundating them. (TA.) ― -b4- And jazara, (TA,) inf. n. jazorN, (K,) He gathered honey from the hive. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- jazara, aor.
jazira
and
jazura
, inf. n. jazorN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) (tropical:) It (water) sank, and disappeared; became low; or became remote; (S, K;) decreased; went away; (TA;) flowed away, or retired, (A, Mgh, * Msb,) from the earth, or land: (A, Mgh:) it (the sea, and a river, Lth, ISd) ebbed; contr. of mad~a; (S, ISd, K; [but in this last sense, only
jazira
is authorized by the K, and app. by ISd also, as the aor.;]) i. e., retreated, or went back; (S. Msb; *) as also Anjzr↓; (ISd, TA;) or ceased to increase. (Lth, Mgh.)

4 Ajzrhu A^jzrh Ajzrh Ajzrp jzr
, (K,) or Ajzr Alqawoma, (ISk, S,) He gave to him, or to the people, a sheep or a goat, for him, or for them, to slaughter; (ISk, S, K;) meaning a ewe or a ram or a she-goat; (ISk, S;) or a sheep, or goat, fit for slaughter: (TA:) and A^ajozarotuhu $aApF I gave to him a ewe or a ram or a she-goat, and he slaughtered it: (ISk, TA:) and A^ajozarotuka baEiyrFA, or $aApF, I gave to thee a camel, or a sheep or goat, that thou mightest slaughter it: (A:) [but] accord. to ISk, one does not say A^ajozarotuhumo naAqapF, because a she-camel is fit for other purposes than that of slaughter: (S:) and accord. to some, one should not say Ajzrhu jazuwrFA, but Ajzrhu jazarapF. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Ajzr He (a camel) attained to the fit time for his being slaughtered. (S, K.) ― -b2- Ajzr Aln~axolu The palm-trees attained to the fit time for the cutting off of the fruit. (S, K.) ― -b3- [And hence,] Ajzr Al$ayoxu (tropical:) The old man attained to the fit time for his dying; (K, TA;) being aged, and near to his perishing; like as the palm-tree attains to the fit time for having its fruit cut off. (TA.) Youths used to say to an old man A^ajozarota yaA $ayoxu, meaning, Thou hast attained to the fit time for thy dying, O old man: and he would say, A^aYo baniY~a watuHotaDaruwna, i. e., “ [O my sons, and] ye shall die youths: ” but accord. to one way of relation, it is A^ajozazota; from A^ajaz~a Albur~u “ the wheat attained to the proper time for being out. ” (S.) ― -b4- Ajzr Alqawomu The people attained to the fit time for the cutting off of the fruit of the palm-trees. (Yz, TA.)

5 tajaz~ara
see 8.

6 tajaAzaraA tjAzrA
(assumed tropical:) They reviled each other (K, TA) vehemently, or excessively. (TA.)

7 A_inojazara
see 1.

8 Ajtzr Ajtzr
: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- AjtzrwA fiY AlqitaAli and tjz~rwA↓ (K, TA) They fought one another [app. so that they cut one another in pieces]. (TA.) [In the K, this is immediately followed, as though for the purpose of explanation, by the words tarakuwhumo jazarFA lils~ibaAEi A^aYo qiTaEFA: but there is evidently an omission in this place, at least of the conjunction wa.] ― -b3- And AjtzrwA They had a camel slaughtered for them. (A.)

jazorN jzr jzyrp
inf. n. of 1. (S, K, &c.) ＝ -A2- And also (assumed tropical:) The sea (K, TA) itself. (TA.)

jazarN jzr jzyrp
, (not jizarN↓, Fr, S, [but see what follows,]) [a coll. gen. n.,] Fat sheep or goats: (S, K, TA:) n. un. jazarapN: (S, K:) or sheep, or goats, that are slaughtered; (M;) as also jazuwrN↓: (K:) n. un. as above: (M: in the K jazorapN:) or jazarapN signifies a sheep, or goat, fit for slaughter: or a sheep, or goat, to which the owners betake themselves and which they slaughter: and anything that is lawful to be slaughtered; n. un. of jazarN, which is sometimes [written jizarN↓,] with fet-h to the z. (TA.) ― -b2- jazaru Als~ibaAEi The flesh which beasts or birds of prey eat. (S, Mgh.) One says, tarakuwhumo jazarFA (S, K) They slew them: (S:) or they left them cut
in pieces lils~ibaAEi [for the beasts or birds of prey]. (K.) And SaAruwA jazarFA liloEaduw~i [They became a prey to the enemy, cut in pieces]. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- See also jaziyrapN. ＝ -A3- Also, and jiz~rN↓, (Fr, S, Msb, K,) the latter with kesr to the j, (Msb, K,) arabicized, (K,) from the Persian [Gazaro], (AHn,) [coll. gen. ns., meaning Carrots, or the carrot;] a certain root, (A^aruwmap,) which is eaten, (S, K,) well known: (TA:) n. un. with p; (K;) or jazarapN: (As, S, Msb:) the best kind is the red and sweet, which grows in winter: it is hot in the extreme of the second degree; moist in the first degree; (TA;) diuretic; (K, TA;) lenitive; emollient; (TA;) strengthening to the venereal faculty; emmenagogue: the putting of its pounded leaves upon festering ulcers is advantageous: (K, TA:) it is difficult of digestion; and engenders bad blood; but is made wholesome with vinegar and mustard. (TA.) ― -b2- [See also HinozaAbN, in art. Hzb.]

jizarN jzr jzyrp
: see jazarN, in three places.

jizaArN jzAr
The time of the cutting off of the fruit of palm-trees. (Yz, TA.) [See also 1.]

jazuwrN jzwr
A camel [that is slaughtered, or to be slaughtered]; (K;) applied to the male and the female: (S, Msb:) or (as some say, Sgh, Msb) properly a she-camel that is slaughtered: (Sgh, Msb, K:) but the former is the correct assertion; (TA;) though the word is fem., (IAmb, S, Msb, TA,) on the authority of hearsay; (TA;) therefore you say, raEati Aljazuwr' [the camel for slaughter pastured]: (IAmb, Msb:) or when used alone, it is fem., because what are slaughtered are mostly she-camels: (TA:) and when used as a common term, it implies the like of predominance [of the fem. gender]: (Háshiyeh of Esh-Shiháb, TA:) [the shares into which the jzwr is divided in the game called Almayosir are described voce bado'N:] pl. juzurN (S, Msb, K) and jazaAy^iru and juzuraAtN, (Msb, K,) the last of which is pl. of juzurN, like as TuruqaAtN is of TuruqN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jazarN.

juzaArapN jzAr jzArh jzArp
, of a camel, The extremities; (S, A;) namely, (S,) the fore and kind legs, (AlyadaAni waAlr~ijolaAni, S, K,) and the head, (S,) or neck: (A, K:) because the slaughterer receives them; (S;) they being his hire, (S, K,) or right, (A,) not being included among the shares in the game called Almayosir. (TA.) But when a horse is said to be Eabolu AljuzaArapi, (S,) or Daxomu AljuzaArapi, (M,) what is meant is thickness of the fore and hind legs, and abundance of sinews; and the head is not included, because largeness of the head, in a horse, is a fault. (S, M.)

jizaArapN jzAr jzArh jzArp
The trade of him who slaughters camels (Mgh, Msb, K, * TA) and other animals. (Msb.)

jaziyrapN jzyrh jzyrp
(tropical:) An island; land in the sea [or in a river], from which the water has flowed away, so that it appears; (Az, Mgh;) and in like manner, land which a torrent does not overflow, but which it surrounds; (Az, TA;) land from which the tide retires; as also jazarN↓: (K:) so called because cut off from the main land: (S:) or because of the retiring of the water from it: (Msb:) pl. jazaAy^iru: (S, Mgh:) [also, a peninsula:] and a piece of ground or land. (Kr, TA.)

jaz~aArN jzAr
(S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and jiz~iyrN↓ (K) and jaAzirN↓ (A) One who slaughters camels (A, Mgh, Msb, K) and other animals. (Msb.)

jiz~iyrN jzyr
: see what next precedes.

jaAzirN jAzr
: see what next precedes.

majozarN mjzr
, (Msb, K,) or majozirN, with kesr to the z, (S, Ibn-Málik,) contr to rule, as the aor. of the verb is with damm, (Ibn-Málik, TA,) and sometimes majozarapN↓ [or majozirapN], (Msb,) A place where camels are slaughtered, (S, Msb, K,) and other animals, (Msb,) namely, bulls and cows and sheep and goats, and where their flesh is sold: pl. majaAziru. (TA.) In a trad. of 'Omar, persons are enjoined to avoid majaAzir, (S, TA,) meaning as above; because of their uncleanness; (TA;) or because the witnessing of the slaughter of animals hardens the heart and dispels mercy: (IAth, TA:) or the meaning is, places of assembly; because a camel is slaughtered only where people are collected together: (S, TA:) the majozarap↓ is one of the places in which it is forbidden to perform the usual prayers. (Mgh.)

majozarapN mjzr mjzrh mjzrp
or majozirapN: see majozarN, in two places.

1 jazoEN jzE
[inf. n. of jazaEa] signifies The act of cutting; or cutting off. (TA.) [See also 8.] ― -b2- [Hence,] jzaEa lahu jizoEapF mina AlmaAli He cut off for him a portion of the property. (S.) ― -b3- And jazaEa AlwaAdiY, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jazaEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jazoEN, (S, Msb, K,) He passed the valley to the other side: (Msb:) or he passed the valley [in any manner]: (K:) or he passed across it; i. e., crossed it: (S, K:) and in like manner, AlA^aroDa the land: (K:) and AlmafaAzapa the desert: and AlmawoDiEa the place. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jaziEa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jazaEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jazaEN (S, Msb, K) and juzwEN, (K,) He was, or became, impatient, (S, K,) mina Al$~aYo'i [of the thing]; (S;) and EalaY fulaAnK [on account of such a one]; (S and K in art. Alh, &c.;) jazaEN being the contr. of SaborN: (S, K:) or he had not sufficient strength to bear what befell him, (O, Msb,) and found not patience: (Msb:) or he manifested grief and agitation: (TK:) or he was, or became, affected with grief: or he was, or became, affected with most violent grief, such as prevented him and turned him from that to which he was directing himself, or from his object, and cut him off therefrom: this meaning of cutting off being said by 'Abd-el-Kádir El-Baghdádee to be the primary signification. (TA.)

2 jz~E jzE
, inf. n. tajoziyEN, It (a full-grown unripe date) became ripe to the extent of two thirds of it: (S:) or to the extent of half of it; (K, TA;) from the bottom: (TA:) or became partly ripe: and in like manner one says of a grape. (TA.) ― -b2- It (a watering-trough, or tank,) had but little remaining in it. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- He put a little water into a skin. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jz~E fulaAnFA, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He caused the impatience (jazaE) of such a one to cease: (K:) he said to him that which comforted him, or consoled him, and which caused his grief and fear to cease. (IAth.)

4 AjzE jizoEapF AjzE jzEh AjzE jzEp
, and juzoEapF, He left, or caused to remain, a remainder: (O, K:) or less than half. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AjzEhu He caused him to be impatient: (S, K:) or he caused him to want sufficient strength to bear what befell him, and to be impatient. (Msb.)

5 tajaz~aEa
see 7, in two places. ＝ -A2- tjz~EwA Alganiymapa They divided among themselves the spoil. (TA.)

7 AnjzE AnjzE
It (a rope) broke, (K, TA,) in any manner: (TA:) or broke in halves; (K, TA;) but if it have broken at its extremity, one does not say AnjzE. (TA.) And AnjzEt AlEaSaA, and tjz~Et↓, The staff, or stick, broke (K, TA) in halves. (TA.) tjz~E↓ is also said of a spear, and of an arrow, &c., meaning It broke in pieces. (TA.)

8 AjtzEhu AjtzEh AjtzEp
He broke it, and cut it off: (K:) or he broke it off, and cut it off, for himself; namely, a branch, rod, or piece of wood, from a tree. (S.)

jazoEN jzE
(S, Msb, K) and jizoEN↓, (Kr, K,) but IDrd ascribes the latter to the vulgar, (TA,) [The onyx; so called in the present day;] certain beads, or gems, (xarazN,) (Msb,) the beads, or gems, (xaraz, [here rendered by Golius “ Murœna seu concha Veneris, ” though he also gives what I regard as the only correct signification, namely “ onyx, ”]) of El-Yemen (S, K) [and] of China, (K) in which are whiteness and blackness, (S, Msb, K,) and to which eyes are likened, (S, K,) and in particular, by Imra-el-Keys, the eyes of wild animals, because their eyes, while they are alive, are black, but when they die, their whiteness appears; (TA;) a kind of stone having many colours, brought from El-Yemen and China; (Kzw;) so called because interrupted by various colours; its blackness being interrupted by its whiteness and its yellowness: (IB:) 'Áïsheh's necklace [which she lost on the occasion that subjected her to the accusation of adultery] was of jazoE of Dhafári: (TA:) the wearing it in a signet induces anxiety, or disquietude of mind, and grief, and terrifying dreams, and altercation with men; and if the hair of one who experiences difficulty in bringing forth be wound upon it, she brings forth at once: (K: [and Kzw says the like, and more of a similar kind:]) n. un. jazoEapN (Msb, K, * TA) and jizoEapN. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

jizoEN jzE
, (S, O, L, Msb, K,) but AO says that it should be with fet-h, [jazoEN↓,] (K) The place of bending, or turning, (munoEaTaf, S, Msb, K, or munoHanFY, As, K,) of a valley: (As, S, Msb, K:) or the middle thereof: or the place where it ends: (IDrd, K:) or its side: (Msb:) or the place of
passing, or crossing, of a valley: or a widening part, of the narrow places, thereof, whether it produce plants &c. or do not produce them: (TA:) or it is not so called unless [it be a part] having width, and producing trees &c.: (Msb, K:) or it may be without plants, or herbage, or the like: (TA:) or a place, in a valley, in which are no trees: (IAar, K:) or a place, of a valley, taking a round and wide form: (TA:) pl. A^ajozaAEN. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- A place of alighting, or abiding, of a people. (K.) ― -b3- Elevated land, or ground, by the side of which is a low, or depressed, part. (K.) ＝ -A2- A bee-hive: pl. as above. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A3- See also jazoEN.

jazuEN jzE
: see what next follows.

jaziEN jzE
(Msb, K) and jaAziEN↓ and jazuEN↓ (K) and jazuwEN↓ (Msb, K) and juzaAEN↓ (K) part. ns. of jaziEa; [Impatient; &c.;] (Msb, K;) but the last two have an intensive signification [very impatient, or having much impatience; &c.]. (IAar.)

juzoEapN jzE jzEh jzEp
: see what next follows, in two places.

jizoEapN jzE jzEh jzEp
A little, or small quantity, of property, or wealth; and of water, (S, K,) remaining in a skin, (Lh, IDrd,) and in a leathern bottle, or other vessel, (IDrd,) and in a pool left by a torrent, but not in a well, (TA,) as also juzoEapN↓ (IDrd, K) and [the dim.] juzayoEapN↓, (IDrd,) and of milk, in a skin; (Lh;) or a third part, or nearly that quantity, of water, in a trough, or tank; (ISh;) or a quantity of water, and of milk, less than the half of the skin or other vessel, and of the trough; (TA;) and, as also juzoEapN↓, somewhat remaining; (O, K;) or the latter, particularly, of milk; (IAar;) or both, accord. to some, [a remainder consisting of] less than half; (TA;) and the former, a portion [not defined] of property, or wealth; (S;) and particularly a portion of a flock of sheep or goats; (Aboo-Leylà, K;) as also juzayoEapN↓; (S;) thus in the handwriting of Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee; but in the Mj of IF, jaziyEapN↓, of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: (TA:) the pl. of jizoEapN is jizaEN. (ISh.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (tropical:) A part, or portion, of the night, (S, O, K,) past or to come, (TA,) less than half, (O, K,) of the former part thereof or of the latter part. (K.) ＝ -A2- A place in which is a collection of trees (K, TA) among which the camels or other beasts are made to rest at night from the cold, and are confined when they are hungry, or returning from water, or under rain. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also n. un. of jizoEN as syn. with jazoEN. (TA.)

juzaAEN jzAE
: see jaziEN.

jazuwEN jzE jzwE
: see jaziEN.

jaziyEapN jzyEh jzyEp
and juzayoEapN: see jizoEapN, in three places.

jaAziEN jAzE
: see jaziEN. ＝ -A2- Also The piece of wood which is placed in the trellis of a grape-vine, crosswise, upon which are laid the branches of the vine; (S, K) not known to Aboo-Sa'eed; (S;) it is thus placed for the purpose of raising the branches from the ground; and this piece of wood is also called xa$abapN jaAziEapN; the latter word being thus used as an epithet. (TA.) Also Any piece of wood that is put crosswise between two things for a thing to be borne upon it (K, TA) is called its jAzE. (TA.)

mujaz~aEN mjzE
Interrupted by various colours [like the jazoE or onyx]: (IB:) or anything in which are blackness and whiteness; as also mujaz~iEN↓: (K:) and flesh-meat in which are whiteness and redness. (TA.) [Hence,] nuwFY mujaz~aEN and mujaz~iEN↓ Datestones of which some, or some parts, have been scraped, or abraded, so as to have become white, the rest being left of their [original] colour: (K:) likened to the jazoE. (TA.) And busorN majaz~iEN↓ (S, K) and mujaz~aEN; (K;) the former, says Sh, accord. to El-Ma'arree, but he adds that he himself held the latter to be the right; Az says that he heard the former from the people of Hejer, and it has the authority of A' Obeyd; (TA;) Full-grown dates that have ripened to the half; (K, TA;) from the bottom: (TA:) or to the extent of two thirds: (S:) or that have become partly ripe: (TA:) fem. with p: (S, K:) and in like manner you say tamorN mutajaz~iEN↓ dates that have ripened to the half. (TA.)

mujaz~iEN mjzE
: see mujaz~aEN, in three places. ― -b2- HawoDN mujaz~iEN A watering-trough, or tank, having but little water remaining in it. (K.)

mutajaz~iEN mtjzE

1 jazofN jzf
[inf. n. of jazafa] signifies The taking a thing [in the manner termed] majaAzafapF and jizaAfFA [i. e. by conjecture, not knowing the measure nor the weight]: (S, TA:) or the taking largely, or copiously: (IF, Msb, TA:) and it is [from] a Persian word. (Msb. [See juzaAfN, below.]) And you say, jazafa fiY Alkayoli, inf. n. jazofN, He gave large measure: (IKtt, Msb:) and jazafa lahu fiY Alkayoli He gave him large measure. (Jm, TA.)

, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. mujaAzafapN (S, Msb, K, TA) and jizaAfN, (S, TA,) He sold, or bought, a thing not knowing its measure nor its weight: (Msb:) or he conjectured in selling and buying. (K.) ― -b2- He acted in an easy, or a facile, manner, (Msb, TA,) in selling or buying. (Msb.) ― -b3- And hence, jAzf binafosihi (tropical:) He perilled, endangered, jeoparded, hazarded, or risked, himself; as though he acted in an easy manner with himself. (TA.)

jazofN jzf

juzaAfN jzAf
, accord. to the 'Eyn, in selling and buying, is [The selling, and buying,] by conjecture, without measuring and without weighing; and by rule should be jizaAfN↓, with kesr; i. e., if formed in accordance to the verb [which is jaAzafa]: (Mgh:) or the selling or buying a thing not knowing its measure nor its weight: (Msb:) or conjecture in selling and buying; as also jizaAfN↓ and jazaAfN↓ and juzaAfapN↓ and jizaAfapN↓ and jazaAfapN↓: (K, TA:) arabicized, from GuzaAfo, (Msb, K, TA,) which is Persian: (Msb, TA:) they say laAfo wGazaAfo, meaning “ excess in speech, by conjecture: ” accord. to the Jm, its primary signification is muchness, or copiousness: (TA:) some say that the most chaste form of jzAf is jizaAfN↓, with kesr; [because this is a regular inf. n. of jaAzafa;] (MF, TA;) and some, that the triple vocalization of the j in jzAf is a kind of jzAf [i. e. conjecture], since all assert it to be a Persian word arabicized, and it cannot be so and be also an inf. n., conformable to the verb and to rule: it seems that, when they arabicized it, its original was gradually forgotten, so they formed from it a verb, and derived from it, and made it analogous. (TA.) ― -b2- bayoEN juzaAfN and jizaAfN↓ and jazaAfN↓ and jaziyfN↓ (K) and mujotazafN↓ (TA) A thing sold, or bought, of unknown quantity, whether measured or weighed. (TA.) [See also jazofN.]

, (K,) inf. n. jazolN, (S,) He cut it (a thing, S) in two pieces, (S, K,) with a sword. (K.) ― -b2- jazaluwA naAqapF They cut the base of the neck of a she-camel, that was slaughtered and dead, in the part between the two shoulder-joints, in order that the neck might become relaxed; not cutting the whole of it; previously to skinning. (Ham p. 689.) ― -b3- jazalahu Alqatabu, (K, * TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above; and Ajzlhu↓; The saddle cut it; namely, the withers of a camel. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- jazila, aor.
jazala
, (K.) inf. n. jazalN, (S, K,) He (a camel) had a gall, or sore, in the withers, in consequence of which a bone came forth from it, and the place thereof became depressed: (S, K:) or he had his withers cut by the saddle: (K:) or he had a gall, or sore, in the withers, penetrating into the interior, and killing him. (TA.) The epithet applied to a camel in this case is A^ajozlu↓; (S, K;) fem. jazolaA='u: pl. juzolN (K.) See also A^axozalu ＝ -A3- jazula,
aor.

, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jazaAlapN, (Msb,) said of firewood, (Msb, TA,) &c., (TA,) It was thick and large. jazolN jzl
Large and dry firewood: (S:) or dry firewood: (K:) or thick, large firewood. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Much of a thing; as also jaziylN↓: (K:) or the latter, great, or large; [and so the former:] you say EaTaA='N jazolN and jaziylN↓ (tropical:) [a great, or large, gift]: (S, TA:*) and vawaAbN jaziylN↓ (tropical:) [a great, or large, recompense]: (TA:) pl. jizaAlN; (S, K;) either of the former or of the latter. (TA.) And [the fem.] jazolapN (tropical:) [A woman] large in the posteriors. (K, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Generous; munificent. (K, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Intelligent; firm, or sound, in judgment. And when this is said to you, and you desire to deny it, say, Alr~aA^oYi balo jazilu↓(tropical:) Nay, unsound in judgment; from jazalN, [inf. n. of jazila,] relating to a gall, or sore, in the withers [of a camel]. (TA.) ― -b5- Applied to a word, or an expression, (S, K, &c.,) (tropical:) Strong, (PS,) sound, correct; (PS, TK;) contr. of rakiykN (S, K.) And applied to language, (assumed tropical:) Chaste, clear, or eloquent, and comprehensive. (TA.)

1 jazamahu jzm jzmh jzmp
, (S, Msb, K,) aor
jazima
(Msb, K,) inf. n. jazomN, (Msb,) He cut it, or cut it off; (S, Msb, K) namely, a thing: (Msb:) [like jaramahu &c.] ― -b2- jazama Aln~axola He cut off the fruit of the palmtrees: (Msb:) [like jarama Alnxl: but see another explanation, below.] And jazama mina Aln~axolapi jizomFA [He cut off a portion of the fruit from the palmtree]. (TA.) ― -b3- jazama AlHarofa, (S, ISd, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (S,) He made the letter quiescent; (S, ISd, Msb, K;) i.e., the final letter of a declinable word; (S, ISd, Msb;) he cut it off from motion: (Msb:) or as though he cut off from it declinability: (Mbr, TA:) from jazama in the first of the senses explained above: jazomN in a declinable word being like sukuwnN in an indeclinable word. (S.) It is said in a trad. of En-Nakha'ee, Alt~akobiyru jazomN wAlt~asoliymu jazomN, meaning that neither should be prolonged in utterance, and that the last letter in each should be without a case-ending, i.e., be quiescent; so that one should not say [in prayer] Aall~`hu A^akobaru [nor Als~alaAmu Ealayokumo waraHomapu A@ll~`hi, but A^akobaro in the former instance, and A@ll~`ho in the latter]: or, accord. to Z, that one should not exceed the due bounds in the pronunciation of the hemzeh and the medd: (TA:) or that one should abstain from giving fulness and depth to the sound of the vowel, and should elide it entirely in the places of pausing, and avoid excess in the pronunciation of the hemzeh and the medd. (Mgh.) ― -b4- jazama EalaY fulaAnK ka*aA waka*aA, He made such and such things to be binding, or obligatory, on such a one. (K.) And jazama Alyamiyna, (K,) inf.n. as above, (TA,) i. q. A^amoDaAhaA; (K) i. e., He made the oath to be unconditional, without exception, absolutely or decidedly or irreversibly binding; (TK;) A^amoDaAhaA Albat~apa. (TA.) One says also, Halafa yamiynFA HatomFA jazomFA [He swore an oath in an absolute, a decided, or an irreversible, manner]. (TA.) And jazama AlA^amora, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He decided the affair irreversibly. (K.) And jazamotu maA bayoniY wabayonahu I decided the matter between me and him. (TA.) And A^afoEalu *`lika jazomFA I will do that decidedly; without any indulgence therein. (Msb.) And jazama bihi [He asserted it decisively]. (TA passim.) And jazama EalaY AlA^amori He decided, or determined, upon, or upon doing, the thing, or affair. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, this last phrase, He was silent respecting the affair; and so jz~m↓. (K,* TA.) ― -b6- And jazama Eanohu He held back, or refrained, from it through cowardice; and was unable to do it; and so jz~m↓: (K:) or Alqawomu jz~m↓ the people lacked power or ability. (S) ― -b7- jazama AlbaEiyru famaA yaboraHu [app., The camel stopped, and would not quit his place]. (TA: but the verb jzm is there without any syll. sign.) ＝ -A2- jazama Aln~axola, (A'Obeyd, S, K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and Ajtzmhu↓; (K; and the act. part. n. of the latter is also mentioned in the S;) like jaramahu (S) [and Ajtrmhu]; He computed by conjecture the quantity of fruit upon the palm-trees. (A'Obeyd, S, K.) ― -b2- And jazomN also signifies The selling, or buying, fruit [by conjecture, while yet in a rudimental state,] in its calyxes, for money. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also jazama (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He filled a skin; (S, K;) and so jz~m↓, (S, *K,) inf. n. tajoziymN (S.) ― -b2- jazamati AlA_ibilu, (Fr, K,) inf. n. as above, (Fr, TA,) The camels satisfied their thirst [as though they filled themselves] with water. (Fr, K.) ― -b3- And jazama, (IAar, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (IAar, TA,) He ate one meal and was filled thereby: (IAar, K) or he ate one meal in every day and night. (Th, K.) ＝ -A4- jazama AlqiraA='apa, (Lth, K,) inf. n. as above, (Lth, TA,) He performed the reading, or recitation, so as to put the letters in their proper places, in a distinct, or perspicuous, and leisurely, manner. (Lth, K.) ― -b2- And jazomN in writing means The making the letters even. (K.) ＝ -A5- jazama bisaloHihi He voided part of his excrement, part thereof remaining: or he cast forth his excrement. (K.)

[an inf.n. (see 1) used as an epithet]. You say HukomN jazomN An indissoluble and irreversible decree or ordinance, or sentence; like qaDaA='N HatomN. jaAzimN jAzm

1 jazaY jzY jzy jzyp
, aor
jaziYa
(Msb, K,) inf. n. jazaA='N, (Msb,) It (a thing) paid; gave, or rendered, as a satisfaction; or made, gave, or rendered, satisfaction: (Msb:) or satisfied; sufficed; or contented. (K.) And jazayotu Ald~ayona I paid the debt. (Msb.) And jazayotu fulaAnFA Haq~ahu I paid such a one his right, or due. (TA.) And maA yajoziyniY h`*aA Alv~awobu This garment does not suffice me. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) jazaY Eanohu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (Mgh,) It (a thing) paid for him; gave, or rendered, [a thing] as a satisfaction for him; made, gave, or rendered, satisfaction for him; (S, Mgh, Msb,* K;) and some of the lawyers use AjzY↓ in this sense, like AjzA^: (Az, Mgh, Msb:) jazaY is of the dial. of El-Hijáz, and AjzA^ of the dial. of Temeem. (Akh, Msb.) Hence, in the Kur [ii. 45], laA tajoziY nafosN Eano nafosK $ayoy^FA [A soul shall not give anything as a satisfaction for a soul, i. e. for another soul: or a soul shall not make satisfaction for a soul at all; accord. to the latter rendering, $yy^A being put in the accus. case after the manner of an inf. n.]. (S, Msb.) You say also, jazato Eanoka $aApN A sheep, or goat, made satisfaction for thee [as a sacrifice]; (S, TA;) as also A^ajozato↓: (TA:) Benoo-Temeem say A^ajozaA^ato, with ': (S, TA:) this last, thus explained, is a dial, var. mentioned by IKtt (Msb.) And ka*aA Eano ka*aA AjzY↓ Such a thing stood, or served, in lieu, in the place, or in stead, of such a thing, without sufficing. (Zj, K.) And qaliylN mino kaviyrKyujoziY↓; and h`*aAmino h`*aA; A little stands, or serves, in lieu of much; and this, of this. (IAar, TA.) And Eanohu mujozaY AjzY↓ fulaAnK and mujozaApa fulaAnK and (as though the augmentative letter [A in AjzY] were imagined to be rejected, TA) majozaY flAn and majozaApa flAn He satisfied, sufficed, or contented, him as such a one; he stood, or served, him in stead of such a one; a dial. var. of AjzA^. (K.) And AjzY↓ mujozaY gayorihi It (a thing) satisfied, sufficed, or contented, as another thing; it stood, or served, in stead of another thing. (Msb.) And AjzAka↓, with the [second] objective complement suppressed, It was sufficient for thee. (Mgh.) ― -b3- jazaAha ka*aA (Msb,* TA,) and jazaAhu bihi (K,) or bimaA SanaEa, (S,) and Ealayohi, (K,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He repaid, requited, compensated, or recompensed, him (Msb, K TA) [for such a thing, for it, or for what he had done]; as also jAzAhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. mujaAzaApN and jizaA='N: (K:) or, accord. to Fr, [contr. to many instances in the Kur,] the former verb relates only to good; and the latter, to good and to evil: but accord. to others, the former may relate to good and to evil; and the latter, to evil. (TA.) [See also jazaA='N, below.] One says, in praying for another, jazaAhu A@ll~`hu xayorFA May God repay him good: and requite, or recompense, him for good [that he has done]. (Msb.) And bi*anobihi jaAzayotuhu↓ I punished him for his crime, or sin, or act of disobedience. (Msb.) And jazaY Eanohu fulaAnFA He requited, compensated, or recompensed, for him, such a one. (TA.) ― -b4- jaAzayotuhu fajazayotuhu: see 3.

3 jaAozaYa
see 1, latter part, in two places. ― -b2- [jAzAhu xayorFA He prayed for a reward for him from God: or said to him, May God reward thee. (Golius, on the authority of Z.) ― -b3- jAzY biHarofK and biZarofK, He employed a particle, and an adverbial noun, as conditional; to denote that, with what follows, it expresses a condition with its complement. For instance, in the S, voce Hayovu, it is said,Hayovu mina AlZ~uruwfi Al~atiY laA yujaAzaY bihaA A_il~aA maEa maA, i. e. Hyv is one of the adverbial nouns that are not employed conditionally, or to denote that, with what follows, they express a condition with its complement, unless with mA affixed thereto. See jazaA='N, below.] ― -b4- jaAzayotuhu fajazayotuhu↓ [I vied, or contended, with him in repaying, requiting, compensating, or recompensing, and] I overcame him [therein]. (S.)

jizoyapN jzyh jzyp
The tax that is taken from the free nonMuslim subjects of a Muslim government; (S, IAth, Mgh,* Msb, K;) whereby they ratify the compact that ensures them protection: (IAth:) [from jazaY;] as though it were a compensation for their not being slain: (IAth, Mgh:) [or from the Persian Gizoyaho:] and also, (metaphorically, Mgh,) (tropical:) a land-tax; (Mgh, K;) a tax that is paid by the owner of land: (TA:) pl. jizFY (S,) or jizoYN↓, (Msb,) or both, (K,) [but the latter is, properly speaking, a coll. gen. n.,] and jizaA='N, (K, [in the CK, erroneously, jazA'N,]) like kitaAbN. (TA.)

jazaA='N jzA='
Repayment, requital, compensation, or recompense, for a thing; as also ↓; jaAziyapN(K;) a satisfaction, good for good, and evil for evil; (Er-Rághib, TA;) sometimes a reward, and sometimes a punishment: (AHeyth, TA:) [the former word is an inf. n.; see 1;] the latter, a quasi-inf. n.: jawaAzK is pl. of the latter, or of the former, or of jaAzK↓, accord. to different writers explaining the saying of El-Hoteí-ah,
mano yafoEali Alxayora laA yaEodamo jawaAziyahu
[Whoso doth good, he will not want his rewards, or his rewarders]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jazaA='a AlEuTaAsi In the time between the complimentary prayer addressed to a sneezer (called Alt~a$omiyt) and the sneeze; [or as soon as one can compliment a sneezer by repeating the usual prayer of yaroHamuka A@ll~`hu (God have mercy on thee).] (TA voce muEaAqibN) ― -b3- [And jazaA='u $aroTK An apodosis; the complement, or correlative, of a condition; also called jawaAbu $aroTK, q.v. in art. jwb ― -b4- And Harofu jazaA='K A particle denoting compensation, or the complement of a condition. And A conditional particle; as A_ino; also termed HarofN lilojazaA='i, and jazaA='N alone, and Harofu $aroTK.] ― -b5- huwa *uw jazaA='K He is possessed of sufficiency, or competence, or wealth. (TA.)

jaAzK jAz
[act. part. n. of 1, q. v.]: see jazaA='N ― -b2- h`*aA rajulN jaAziyka mino rajulK This is a man sufficient for thee as a man. (S.)
