, (A, Mgh, K,*) or jas~ahu biyadihi, (S Msb,) aor
jasu3a
, (Mgh, Msb,) inf.n. jas~N, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) He felt it with his hand (S, A, Mgh, K) for the purpose of testing it, that he might form a judgment of it; (Mgh, Msb;) as also Ajts~hu↓. (S, Msb, K.) You say, jas~ahu AlT~abiybu, (Mgh,) and jas~a yadahu, (A,) The physician felt him, (Mgh,) and felt his arm, or hand, (A,) to know if he were hot or cold. (Mgh.) And jas~a Al$~aApa He felt the sheep, or goat, to know if it were fat or lean. (A, Mgh.) ― -b2- jas~N is also, sometimes, with the eye. (IDrd, S, Msb. *) You say, jas~ahu biEayonihi (IDrd, S, A, K) (tropical:) He looked sharply, or intently, or attentively, at him, or it, for the purpose of investigation and clear perception. (K, TA.) IDrd cites as an ex. a verse (of 'Obeyd, or 'Abeed, [for I find it written without any syll. signs,] the son of Eiyoob El-'Amberee, TA,) in which occurs
the expression jas~uwhu biA^aEoyunihimo: (S:) but Sgh says that the right reading is Has~uwhu. (TA.) ― -b3- jas~a AlA^aroDa (assumed tropical:) He traversed the land. (Aboo-Sa'eed El-Yeshkuree, TA.) ― -b4- jas~a AlA^axobaAra, (S, Msb, K,) and tajas~asahaA↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) (tropical:) He searched, or sought, for, or after, news or tidings; inquired, or sought for information, respecting news or tidings; searched or inquired or spied into, investigated, scrutinized, or examined, news or tidings: (S, K:) he searched, or sought, repeatedly, or leisurely and by degrees, for news or tidings. (Msb.) You say also, fulaAnFA tjs~s↓, and mino fulaAnK (tropical:) He inquired, or sought for information, respecting such a one; as also tHs~s, which latter verb occurs in an extr. reading of verse 87 of ch. xii. of the Kur: or the former signifies he sought after him for another; and the latter, "he sought after him for himself:" or tjs~s↓ signifies [he acted as a spy;] he inquired respecting, or searched or inquired or spied into, things which others veiled or concealed by reason of disdainful pride or of shame or pudency; and tHs~s, "he listened:" (TA:) in the last of the senses here assigned to it, the former verb is used in the Kur, xlix. 12, where it is said, walaA tajas~asuwA↓, for tatajas~asuwA; (Mujáhid, Bd, K;) ↓or the meaning here is, and do not ye inquire respecting, or search or inquire or spy into, private circumstances: or take ye what appeareth, and leave ye what God hath concealed. (Mujáhid, K.) You also say, lahumo A^amori Alqawomi Ajts~↓ He examined or spied into, and sought out, for them, the circumstances of the people. (Mgh.)

5 tajas~a3a
see 1, in five places.

8 A_ijotasa3a
see 1, first and last sentences. ― -b2- Ajt~st AlA_ibilu AlbaAriDu, (A,) or AlkalaA^a, (K,) (tropical:) The camels sought out the first sprouts of the herbage with their mouths: (A:) or cropped the herbage with their majaAs~, (K,) i. e., their mouths. (TA.)

jasiysN jsys
: see jaAsuwsN

jas~aAsN jsAs
: see jaAsuwsN ― -b2- (tropical:) The lion that marks his prey with his claws: (K, TA:) or one that traverses a land. (Aboo-Sa'eed El-Yeshkuree, TA.) ― -b3- Aljas~aAsapN A certain beast, that will be in the islands, that will search after news, or tidings, and bring them to Ed-Dejjál [or Antichrist]. (Lth, L, K.)

jaAs~apN jAs jAsh jAsp
a dial. var. of HaAs~apN, (Msb,) and sing. of jawaAs~N, (Msb, TA,) which is syn. with HawaAs~N, (Kh, S, A, K,) signifying The five senses. (TA.) See HaAs~apN.

jaAsuwsN jAsws
(tropical:) A spy, who searches for, and brings, information, news, or tidings: (S, * Msb, * TA:) or one who is acquainted with private affairs of an evil nature: as also jasiysN↓ (K) [and jas~aAsN↓:] and naAmuwsN signifies one who is acquainted with private affairs of a good nature: (TA:) pl. jawaAsiysu. (A.)

majas~N mjs
(A, TA) and majas~apN↓ (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) The place which one feels with his hand, (A,* Mgh, K, TA,) for the purpose of testing it, that he may form a judgment of it: (Mgh:) and ↓the latter, the place which the physician feels [to know if a patient be hot or cold]: (S, Msb:) pl. majaAs~u. (S, A, Msb, K.) You say, majas~atuhu↓ HaAr~apN [The place in which one feels him is hot]. (A, TA.) And kayofa taraY majas~ahaA [How dost thou find the place in which one feels her?]; referring to a sheep or goat; to which one answers, "Indicative of fatness." (A.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) Anything external which indicates the internal condition.] It is said in a prov., (S, A, Msb, K,) relating to camels, (Msb,) A^afowaAhuhaA majaAs~uhaA, (S, A, K,) or majaAs~uhaA A^afowaAhuhaA, (Msb,) or A^aHonaAkuhaA majaAs~uhaA, (A, K,) (assumed tropical:) [Their mouths, or their palates, are the things which indicate their internal condition:] for if they eat well, he who looks at them sufficiently knows their fatness, (S, Msb, K,) without feeling them: (S, K:) if one see them eat well, it is as though he felt them: (A, TA:) or, accord. to AZ, they feel the herbage, to test it, with their heads [or mouths] and their palates: so that, accord. to his explanation, the term mjAs~ is tropically applied to these parts. (TA.) The prov. relates to external evidences of things explaining their internal qualities. (K) [And hence,] raEati AlA_ibilu AlkalaA^a bimajaAs~ihaA, (K) (tropical:) The camels cropped the herbage with their mouths. (TA.) ― -b3- You say also, fulaAnN waAsiEu Almajas~i, like as you say raHobu Al*~iraAEi (tropical:) [app. meaning Such a one is liberal, munificent, or generous]: and in the contrary case, Day~iqu Almajas~i, (A,) or Almajas~api↓, (K,) or both, (TA,) signifying gayoru raHobi AlS~adori (tropical:) [app., not liberal]; (K, TA;) and not waAsiEu Als~arobi [which is explained as meaning of ample bosom, and judgment, and love; and of ample way, or course of proceeding: but I rather incline to think that the right reading is waAsiEu Als~irobi, and the meaning, of ample, or large, mind, or heart]. (TA.) You also say, laDiyqFA A_in~a fiY majas~atika↓ (A) or majas~ika (TA) (tropical:) [app,. Verily in thy bosom, or mind, or heart, is narrowness; or in thee is illiberality.]

majas~ahu mjs mjsh mjsp
: see, majas~N, throughout. ― -b2- It may also be used as an inf. n. of jas~ahu in the first of the senses assigned to it above. (Mgh.)

1 jasaA^a *
, aor
jasaAa
inf. n. jusuwo'N and jusoA^apN, (K,) thus in the corrected copies of the K, but in some copies the latter inf. n. is written jusaA='apN, (TA,) It (a thing, TA) was, or became, hard, tough, rigid, or stiff; (K, TA;) as also jasaA, aor
jasuAa
(Msb and K in art. jsw.) ― -b2- jasaA^ato yaduhu, aor
jasaAa
inf. n. jaso'N, His hand became hard, tough, callous, (S, TA,) coarse, or rough, (TA,) from work. (S, TA.) ― -b3- jasaA^ato mafaASiluhu His joints became rigid, or stiff. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jusiy^ati AlA^aroDu The ground became hard, or hard and level, and rough: from jaso'N, explained below. (Ks, K.)

Haso'N Hs'
Hard, or hard and level, and rough, ground, (jaladN xa$inN, Ks, K, TA,) resembling small pebbles. (TA.) [Accord. to some copies of the K, Rough skin (jilodN xa$inN).] ― -b2- Frozen water, (K, TA,) resembling hail [strewed on the ground], (TA.)

jusoA^apN *
Hardness, toughness, callousness, [coarseness, or roughness,] of the hand, from work. (S.) ― -b2- Rigidity, or stiffness, of the neck, (S, K, TA,) in a horse or the like. (S, TA.)

yadN jasoA='N yd jsA='
A hard, tough, callous, coarse, or rough, hand. (K, TA.)

jaAsiy^N *
[Hard, tough, rigid, or stiff: see 1]. You say jabalN jaAsiy^N [A hard, or hard and rugged, mountain]. (TA.) And SxuwrN jaAsiy^apN [Hard, or hard and rugged, rocks]. (TA.) And nabotN jaAsiy^N A rigid, or tough, plant. (TA.) And A^aroDN jaAsiy^apN Hard, or hard and level, and rough, ground; (TA;) as also majosuwo'apN↓. (Ks, K.) And makaAnN jaAsiy^N A rugged place; as also $aAsiy^N. (TA.) And daAb~apN jaAsiy^apN AlqawaAy^imi A beast, or horse or the like, having rigid, or stiff, legs, that will hardly bend. (TA.)

jaAsiy^aA='u *
[in the CKjA siyA'] Hardness, toughness, rigidness, or stiffness; and ruggedness, or roughness. (K,* TA.)

majosuwo'apN mjsh mjsp mjsw'h mjsw'p
: see jaAsiy^N

1 jasida jsd
, aor
jasada
(S, K,) inf.n. jasadN. (S, KL,) It (blood) stuck, or adhere, (S K, KL,) bihi [to him, or it]: (S, K:) and it (blood) became dry. (KL.)

4 A^ujosida *
It (a garment) was made to stick, or adhere, to the jasad [or body]. (Fr, S.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. A_ijosaAdN, It (a garment) was dyed so that it stood up by reason of [the thickness of] the dye. (ISK, S.) [See mujosadN.]

5 tjs~d jsd tjsd
from Aljasadu is like tjs~m from Aljisomu: (S:) [apparently signifying He became, or assumed, a jasad, or body; or became corporeal, or incarnate; and thus it is used by late writers, and in the present day: but tjs~m generally signifies he became corpulent: accord. to the TA, tjs~d, said of a man, is like tjs~m: accord, to the KL, the former signifies he became possessed of a body: accord. to the PS, he became corporeal, or corpulent.]

jasadN jsd
The body, with the limbs or members, [or whole person,] of a human being, and of a jinnee (or genie), and of an angel: (El-Bári', L, Msb, K:) it is thus applied only to the body of a rational animal; (El-Bári', Msb;) to no body that is nourished with food except that of a human being; but to the body of every rational creature that neither eats nor drinks, such as the genii and the angels: (L:) [the genii, however, are commonly believed to eat and drink:] or, accord. to ISd, it seems to be applied to a body other than that of a human being tropically: (TA:) the [golden] calf of the Children of Israel cried, but did not eat nor drink; [wherefore it is termed
jsd;] and in the Kur [vii. 146 and xx. 90], jasadFA is a substitute for EijolFA, or it may be meant for *aA jasadK: (L:) [but see another explanation of jsdA, as there used, below:] or jasadN is syn. with badanN [which is generally held to signify the body without the head and arms and legs]: (S, A:) the pl. is A^ajosaAdN. (Lh, Msb, TA.) Lh mentions the saying, A_in~ahaA laHasanapu AlA^ajosaAdi [Verily she is beautiful in respect of body]; as though the sing. of which the pl. is thus used were applied to every separate part. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Saffron; (S, Msb, K) as also jisaAdN↓: (Lth, IAar, ISk, S, A, Msb, K:) or a similar dye: (S:) and ↓the latter signifies also a similar dye; (Lth, Msb,) red, or intensely yellow: (Lth, TA:) or bastard saffron; syn. EuSofurN; (Msb;) and so the former word. (L.) ― -b2- Also, (S, L, Msb, K,) and jasidN↓ (L, K) and jaAsidN↓ (L, Msb, K) and jasiydN↓ (L, K) and jisaAdN↓, (R,) (assumed tropical:) Blood; (S;) as also mujosadN↓, as being likened to saffron: (Ham p. 215:) or dry blood: (R, L, Msb, K:) pl. of the first as above. (Ham p. 127.) ― -b3- Some say that EijolFA jasadFA, in the Kur, [in two verses referred to above,] means A red golden calf. (S.)

jasidN jsd
: see jasadN: ＝ -A2- and see also jaAsidN.

jisaAdN jsAd
: see jasadN, in three places.

jasiydN jsyd
: see jasadN.

jaAsidN jAsd
Blood sticking to (bi) a person; as also ↓. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also jasadN.

jalosadN jlsd
(L, K in art. jlsd) and Aljalosadu (S, L, K, TA, in the CK Aljal~asadu) the name of A certain idol, (S, L, K,) which was worshipped in the time of paganism: (L:) the l is an augmentative letter accord. to J and most of the leading lexicologists; but F disapproves of the mention of the word in this art. (TA.)

mujosadN mjsd
Red. (S.) ― -b2- Also, (S, Msb, K,) and sometimes mijosadN↓, (IF, Msb,) and mujas~adN↓, (K,) A garment dyed with saffron: (K:) or with bastard saffron: (IAth, TA:) dyed with jisaAd: (IF, Msb:) or saturated with dye: (S:) or one says, EalaY fulaAnK vawobN mu$obaEN mina AlSibogi [Upon such a one is a garment saturated with dye]; and Ealayohi vawobN mufodamN [Upon him is a garment saturated with red dye]; and when it is standing up by reason of [the thickness of] the dye, it is termed mujosadN: (ISK, S:) the pl. of this word is majaAsidu. (S.) ― -b3- See also what next follows: ― -b4- and see jasadN.

mijosadN mjsd
, (S, A, K,) or mujosadN↓, (A,) the latter is the original form, because it is from A^ujosida, meaning, "it was made to stick, or adhere, to the body,” (Fr, S,) like miTorafN and muTorafN, and miSoHafN and muSoHafN, (Fr, TA,) A garment worn next the body (IAar, S, A, K) by a woman, so that she sweats in it: (TA:) and a garment worn next the body dyed with saffron: (A:) pl. majaAsidu. (IAar, A.) [Hence,] laA yaxorujan~a A_ilaY AlmasaAjidi fiY AlmajaAsidi (IAar, A) They (women) shall by no means go forth to the mosques in the shirts that are next the body. (IAar.) ― -b2- See also mujosadN.

mujas~adN mjsd
: see mujosadN.

1 jasara jsr
, (K,) aor.
jasura
, (TA,) inf. n. jasaArapN (A, K, KL) and jusuwrN, said of a man, (K,) He was daring, courageous, or bold: (A, KL:) he acted with penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness; syn. maDaY and nafa*a. (K.) You say, jasara EalaY ka*aA, aor.
jasura
, inf. n. jasaArapN, He ventured upon such a thing daringly, courageously, or boldly; (S, A;) as also tjAsr↓: (S:) and Ealayohi tjAsr↓ he emboldened himself against it, or him. (A, K.) And jasara EalaY Eaduw~ihi, (A, Msb,) aor.
jasura
, inf. n. jusuwrN and jasaArapN, (Msb,) He acted daringly, conrageously, or boldly, against his enemy. (A.) And laA yajosuru A^ano yafoEala ka*aA He dares not to do such a thing. (A.) ＝ -A2- jasara, (K,) inf. n. jasorN, (TA,) He (a man) arched, or vaulted, a jisor [or bridge]. (K.) ― -b2- It is said of [the giant] 'Ooj (Euwj), in a trad., waqaEa EalaY niyli miSora fajasarahumo sanapF, i. e., (tropical:) [He fell down upon the Nile of Egypt, and] became a bridge to them [for the space of a year]. (A.) ― -b3- And one says, jasarati Alr~ikaAbu AlmafaAzapa, and AijotasaratohaA↓, (tropical:) The travellingcamels crossed, or passed over, the desert, (A, K,) as by a bridge: (A:) and Als~afiynapu AlbaHora Ajtsrti↓ (tropical:) The ship crossed, or passed over, the sea: (A:) or rode upon, and passed through, the sea. (K.)

2 js~rhu jsr jsrh jsrp
, (A, K,) inf. n. tajosiyrN; (K;) [and Ajsrhu↓; (see A^agar~ahu;)] He encouraged him; emboldened him. (A, K.)

4 A^ajosara
see 2.

6 tjAsr tjAsr
: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also He stretched himself up, and raised his head. (K.) ― -b3- tjAsr lahu biAlEaSaA He put himself in motion to him (En-Nawádir, K) with the staff, or stick. (K.) ― -b4- tjAsrwA They acted with mutual daring or courage or boldness. (KL.) ― -b5- They journeyed [app. with boldness, or emulating one another in boldness]. (TA.) ― -b6- Alxayolu tajaAsaru biAlkumaApi [for tatajaAsaru] (tropical:) The horses convey the brave armed men away, or along, or across. (A.)

8 A_ijotasara
see 1, last sentence, in two places.

jasorN jsr
: see jasuwrN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, applied to a he-camel, Sharp, spirited, or vigorous; syn. maADK [as contr. of baliydN]; as also jasorapN and mutajaAsirapN↓ applied to a she-camel: or (so in the K accord. to the TA; but in the CK, “ and ”) tall: (K:) or tall and bulky: and with p, applied to a she-camel, it has this last signification; (TA;) or signifies strong, and bold to endure travel: (A, TA:) the masc. epithet applied to a he-camel is rare. (Lth, TA.) ― -b3- Also Large, or bulky; applied to a camel, (S, K,) &c., (S,) or to anything, (K,) or to any limb, or member: (TA:) fem. with p. (S, K.) ― -b4- jasorapu Als~awaAEidi, and Almuxad~ami, Full or plump [in the fore arms, and in the place of the anklet]; applied to a girl, or young woman. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

jisorN jsr
and jasorN↓ [A bridge; and a dyke, or causeway:] that on which one crosses over a river or the like; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as a qanoTarap and the like; (TA;) whether built or not built: (Mgh, Msb:) and a bridge of boats; boats bound together, and tied to stakes in the bank, being over a river; see qanoTarapN: (TA:) pl. (of pauc., TA) A^ajosurN (K) and (of mult., TA) jusuwrN. (S, Msb, K.) [Hence,] Almawotu jisorN yuwaS~ilu AlHabiyba A_ilaY AlHabiybi (tropical:) [Death is a bridge that conveys the friend to the friend]. (TA.) And jaEala TaAEatahu jisorFA A_ilaY najaAtihi (tropical:) [He made his obedience a bridge to his safety]. (A, TA.)

jasuwrN jsr jswr
Daring, courageous, or bold: (S, A:) or courageous and tall; as also jasorN↓: (K:) or courageous; and also tall and bulky; applied to a man; and so jasorN↓: (TA:) fem. of the former without, and sometimes with, p: (Msb:) and of the latter with p: (TA:) pl. of the former jusurN and jusorN. (K, TA.) It is not applied to a hecamel; but with p is applied to a she-camel, meaning Bold to traverse rugged, or difficult, tracts. (Msb.)

jas~aArN jsAr
Very daring or courageous or bold. (TA.)

mutajaAsirapN mtjAsr mtjAsrh mtjAsrp
: see jasorN.

1 jasuma jsm
, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
jasuma
, (K,) inf. n. jasaAmapN, (Msb, TA,) He, or it, (a thing, S,) was, or became, great, or large: (S, K:) or so jasima, aor.
jasama
, inf. n. jasamN: and the former, it (a thing) was, or it, was, or became, great, big, or bulky: (Msb:) or he, or it, was, or became, great, or large, in body: (KL:) or he, or it, was, or became, corpulent; or corporeal, or bodied; as also tjs~m↓. (MA, PS.)

2 js~m jsm
, inf. n. tajosiymN, He, or it, made, or rendered, corporeal; or great, large, big, or bulky. (KL.) ― -b2- [He made to be solid, or to have length and breadth and thickness.]

5 tajas~ama
see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] tjs~m fiY EayoniY ka*aA (tropical:) Such a thing assumed a form, or shape, [or an embodiment,] in my eye. (TA.) And tjs~m fulaAnN mina Alkarami (tropical:) [app. Such a one was, or became, an embodiment of generosity]. (TA.) And kaA^an~ahu karamN qado tajas~ama (tropical:) [app. As though he were generosity embodied]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- tjs~m fulaAnFA (tropical:) He chose such a one (S, K, TA) mino bayoni Alqawomi [from among the people, or party], (S,) or mina AlEa$iyrapi faA^arosalahu [from the kinsfolk, or tribe, &c., and sent him]: (TA:) as though he directed his course, or aim, to, or towards, his jisom [or body]; like as you say, taA^ay~ayotuhu, meaning “ I directed my course, or aim, to, or towards, his A=yap, and his $axoS. ” (S.) [See also 5 in art. j$m.] One says also, tajas~amohaA naAqapF mina AlA_ibili qaA@noHarohaA [Choose thou her, a she-camel from among the camels, and stick her]. (TA.) ― -b2- tjs~m AlA^aroDa (assumed tropical:) He betook himself towards the land, or country, (S, K,) desiring
to go thither. (S.) ― -b3- tjs~m Alr~amola, (S, K,) and Aljabala, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He mounted, or ascended, the greater part of the sand, (S, K,) and of the mountain. (S.) [See also 5 in art. j$m.] ― -b4- tjs~m AlA^amora (tropical:) i. q. rakiba muEoZamahu; (S, K, TA;) i. e., He ventured upon, embarked in, or undertook, the main part, or bulk, of the affair: (TK:) or he constrained himself to do it, or perform it; as also tj$~mhu: (Aboo-Mihjen, Aboo-Turáb, TA:) or both these verbs signify he took it, or imposed it, upon himself, or he undertook it, in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience. (Aboo-Turáb, TA in art. j$m.) You say also, fulaAnN yatajas~ama AlmajaAsima↓ and yataja$~amu AlmajaA$ima (tropical:) [app. meaning Such a one undertakes, in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience, those things, or affairs, that are causes of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience; i. e., difficult, or troublesome, or inconvenient things or affairs: supposing the two nouns to be pls. of which the sings. are majosamapN and majo$amapN, of the measure mafoEalapN, like maboxalapN and majobanapN and ma$~aqapN (originally ma$oqaqapN) &c.]. (TA.)

jisomN jsm
The body, with the limbs or members; syn. jasadN; (AZ, S, Msb;) as also jusomaAnN↓ and juvomaAnN: (AZ, S, Msb: *) or jisomN and jusomaAnN↓ are syn. with jasadN; (As, S;) or signify the whole body and limbs or members of a man, (K, and T and Msb in explanation of jsm,) and of a beast, a camel, and the like, (T, Msb,) and of any other species, (K,) of large make; (T, Msb, K;) and juvomaAnN is syn. with $axoSN [app. as meaning “ a person ”]; and jusomaAnN↓ signifies the whole jisom of a man: (As, S:) or jisomN signifies [a body, or material substance; a solid;] a thing having length and breadth and thickness; so that, when it is cut and divided, no portion thereof ceases to be a jisom; whereas a $axoS [meaning “ a person ”] ceases to be a $axoS by its being divided: (Er-Rághib, TA:) a thing that is capable of being divided in length and breadth and thickness is called jisomN TabiyEiY~N, and also, because it is a subject of investigation, or inquiry, in instruction in the mathematical studies, jisomN taEoliymiY~N: (KT:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajosaAmN and [of mult] jusuwmN. (K.) You say, vaAba jisomuhu, (M, A, K, in art. vwb,) and A^avaAba jisomuhu, (IKt, M, ib.,) and vaAba A_ilayohi jisomuhu, (T, M, A, ib.,) (tropical:) He became fat, after leanness; (A;) his good state of body returned to him; (M, K; *) his condition of body became good, after extenuation; and health, or soundness, thereof returned to him. (T.) And A_in~ahu laHaniyfu AljusomaAni↓ [Verily he is slender, spare, or lean, of body]. (TA.) ― -b2- AlA^ajosaAmu Almuxotalifapu AlT~abaAy^iEi [The material substances of different natures; also called AlA^ajosaAmu Als~aboEapu the seven material substances, and Alfili*aAtu; namely,] the EanaASir [which are the four elements, fire, air, earth, and water,] and the three products composed of these, (KT,) which are minerals, vegetables, and animals. (Note in a copy of the KT.) AlA^ajosaAmu AlT~abiyEiy~ahu, as used by those who study to discover occult things, signifies The Earo$ and the kurosiY~: and AlA^ajosaAmu AlEunoSuriy~apu, everything beside these two, of the heavens and the [elements termed] A^usoTuqusaAt therein. (KT.)

[
jisomiY~N jsm jsmY jsmy jsmyy
Bodily, or corporeal.]

[
jisomiy~apN jsm jsmy jsmyh jsmyp
Bodiliness, or corporeity.]

jusomaAnN jsm jsmAn
: see jisomN, in four places.

jusomaAniY~N jsm jsmAn jsmAnY jsmAny
: see jasiymN.

jusaAmN jsAm jsym
: see what next follows

jasiymN jsym
Great; large; (S, Msb, K;) as also jusaAmN↓: (S, K:) big; bulky: (Msb:) fem. with p: (K:) pl. jisaAmN (S, Msb) [and jusumN also, like as jududN is pl. of jadiydN]: and corpulent, large in body, or big-bodied; (K, * TA;) as also jusomaAniY~N↓, applied to a man. (TA.) You say, huwa mino jisaAmi AlA^umuwri [It is one of great affairs or events]: and mino jasiymaAti AlxuTuwbi [meaning the same, or of great afflictions or calamities]. (TA.) And jusumN [likewise, or A^umuwrN jusumN,] signifies Great affairs or events. (TA.) jasiymu AlA^amori signifies [also] The bulk, or the greater, main, principal, or chief, part, of the affair; and so AlA^amori A^ajosamu↓. (S.) ― -b2- [The pl.] jusumN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Intelligent men. (TA.) ― -b3- jasiymu AlA^aroDi Elevated land over which water has risen: (K, * TA:) pl. jisaAmN. (K.)

A^ajosamu *
Greater, larger, bigger, or bulkier; or greatest, largest, biggest, or bulkiest. (S, K.) See also jasiymN.

majaAsimu mjAsm
: see 5, last sentence.

jsw jsw
: omitted in some copies of the S.

1 jasaA js jsA
, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
jasuma
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. jasowN (M, K) and jusuw~N, (M, TA,) He, or it, (a man, M, TA, or a thing, Msb,) was, or became, hard, tough, rigid, or stiff: (M, Msb, K:) [see also jasaA^a: or, said of a man,] he was, or became, hard, rough, harsh, or ungentle; contr. of laTufa. (S.) And jasati Alyadu, inf. n. jusuw~N and jasFA, The hand, or arm, was, or became, dry, or tough, or hard, (S, TA,) in the bones, with little flesh; (TA;) and in the same sense the verb is said of other things. (S.) ― -b2- It (water) congealed, or froze. (S, TA.) ― -b3- Also, inf. n. jusuw~N, He (an old man) attained the utmost age [so that his limbs became rigid]. (S, TA.)

3 jAsAhu jAs jAsAh jAsAp
, (K,) inf. n. mujaAsaApN, (TA.) He treated him, or regarded him, with enmity, or hostility. (K, TA.)

yadN jaAsiyapN yd jAsyh yd jAsyp
A hand, or an arm, dry, or tough, or hard, in the bones, with little flesh. (TA.) And daAb~apN jaAsiyapN AlqawaAy^imi A beast having tough, or hard, legs. (TA.) And rimaAHN jaAsiyapN Stiff, rigid, or tough, and hard, spears. (TA.) [See also jaAsiy^N, in art. jsA^.]

1 ja$~ahu *
, (S, A, K,) aor.
ja$u3a
, inf. n. ja$~N, (S,) He ground it (namely wheat, S, or grain, A) coarsely; (S, A;) as also A^aja$~ahu↓. (S.) ― -b2- He bruised, brayed, or pounded, it: and he broke it: (S, K:) as also A^aja$~ahu↓. (K) ― -b3- He beat him, or struck him, with a staff or stick. (S, K.)

4 A^ajo$a3a
see 1, in two places.

ju$~apN *
(A, K, TA) and ja$a$N↓ (TA) Loudness, or vehemence, of voice or sound: (A, K, TA:) and a rough sound coming forth from the xayaA$iym [or air-passages in the nose], in which is a hoarseness. (K, TA.) You say, fiY Sahiyli Alfarasi ja$a$N↓ In the neighing of the horse is a rough sound: (TA:) which is one of the qualities approved in horses. (IDrd.) And fiY Sawoti Alqawosi ju$~apN Einoda Alr~amoYi In the sound of the bow is a roughness of twanging on the occasion of shooting. (AHn TA.)

ja$a$N *
: see ju$~apN, in two places.

ja$iy$N *
Wheat coarsely ground; as also majo$uw$N↓. (S.) ― -b2- And, [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] (TA,) as also ja$iy$apN↓, (S, K, TA,) What is coarsely ground, (S, K, TA,) of wheat &c., (S,) or of wheat and the like: (K, TA:) or the former, grain when bruised, brayed, or pounded, before it is cooked: and ↓the latter, such as is cooked: but ISd says that this distinction is not of valid authority. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, the former, i. q. sawiyqN [Meal of parched barley or wheat, coarsely ground, which is made into a kind of gruel]; (El-Fárisee, S, K;) and so ↓the latter: (A:) or ↓the latter is the n. un. (El-Fárisee.) You say, AisoqiniY ja$iy$apN↓ Give thou me to drink [some] swyq. (A.) Or swyq is not called j$y$p↓, but is called ja*iy*apN, q. v. (TA.) ― -b4- And the former, (Sh, K,) or ja$iy$apN↓, (TA in art. d$,) Wheat coarsely ground, and put into a cooking-pot, into which some flesh-meat is thrown, or some dates, and then cooked: (Sh, K:) also called da$iy$apN: (TA:) or a soup made of coarsely bruised wheat. (TA in art. d$.)

ja$iy$apN *
: see ja$iy$N, in seven places.

A^aja$~u *
Having a rough, (S, K,) or loud, or vehement, (A,) voice, or sound: (S, A, K:) applied to a man, and a horse, and thunder, (A, K,) &c. (K.) You say, rajulN A^aja$~u AlS~awoti A man having a [rough, or] loud, or vehement, voice. (A.) And farasN A^aja$~u, (A,) or A^aj~a$u AlSawoti, (S, TA,) A horse in whose neighing is a roughness. (TA.) And saHaAbN A^aja$~u, (As,) or A^aja$~u Alr~aEodi, (S,) Clouds that thunder vehemently. (As.) And qawosN ja$~aA='u, [j$~A=' being the fem. of Aj$~,] A bow having a rough twanging, (AHn, K,) when one shoots with it. (AHn.) ― -b2- AlA^aja$~u is also the name of One of the sounds of which musical modulations are formed, (Kh, K,) which are three in number; [app. meaning the treble, tenor, and bass, clefs; the last being that to which this
term is applied;] the sound thus called being from the head, (Kh,) issuing from the xayaA$iym [or air-passages in the nose], having in it a roughness and hoarseness, (Kh, K,) and followed by a gradual fall (taHad~ur) [of the voice] modulated in accordance to that same sound, and then followed by a sound [in my original biwa$oYK, but I think it probable that this is a mistranscription for biwaHoYK, or biwaHFY, or the like, for, though wa$oYN might perhaps, by straining a metaphor, be applied to denote a varied sound, its being understood in this sense seems to be forbidden by its being here added] like the first. (Kh, TA.) [This explanation is perhaps illustrated by the fact that the bass in the music of the Arabs is often formed of one prolonged note, falling and rising.] ― -b3- Also ja$~aA='u, [A^aroDN being understood,] A pebbly plain, fit for palm-trees. (K, TA.)

mija$~N *
, (S,) or mija$~apN↓, (A,) or both, (K,) A mill (S, K) with which ja$iy$ is ground: (S:) or a small mill with which one grinds coarsely. (A.)

mija$~apN *
: see what next precedes.

majo$uw$N *
: see ja$iy$N.

1 ja$aA^ato nafosuhu *
, (S, K,) aor.
ja$aAa
, (K,) inf. n. ju$uwo'N, (S, K, KL,) like quEuwdN, (TA,) and ja$aA='N, (KL, [or ja$aA^N, so Golius on the authority of the KL,]) [like jaA^a$ato nafosuhu, and jaA$ato,] His soul [or stomach] heaved, by reason of grief or fright: (S, K; and so in the O; but in one copy of the K, by reason of grief or joy: TA:) or [simply] heaved, or rose: (T in art. vwr:) and heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; (K;) i. q. xabuvato and laqisato: (Sh, TA:) and ja$aA^ato A_ilaY~a nafosiY My soul [or stomach] heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit, or became heavy, (xabovato,) in consequence of pain from something that it disliked. (ISh, TA.) ― -b2- ja$aA^a Eani AlT~aEaAmi He nauseated food, in consequence of indigestion. (TA.) ― -b3- ja$aA^ati Alganamu The sheep emitted a sound from their throats. (Lth, K.) ― -b4- ja$aA^ati AlA^aroDu (tropical:) The earth put forth all its plants, or herbage: like as they say, qaA='ati AlA^aroDu A^ukolahaA [lit. “ the earth vomited her victuals ”]. (TA.) ― -b5- ja$aA^ati Alr~iyaADu birub~aAhaA (tropical:) [The meadows, or gardens,] put forth [their good things]. (TA.) ― -b6- ja$aA^ati AlbilaAdu biA^aholihaA (tropical:) [The countries, or towns, &c.,] cast forth [their inhabitants]. (TA.) ― -b7- ja$aA^ati AlbiHaAru biA^amowaAjihaA (tropical:) [The seas] cast forth [their waves]. (TA.) ― -b8- Also ja$aA^a said of the sea, (tropical:) It rushed on, (TA,) grew dark, (K, TA,) and was tumultuous with its waves; (TA;) and [in the CK “ or ”] impended over one. (K, TA.) And in like manner said of the night, (tropical:) It came on suddenly, (TA,) grew dark; (K, TA;) and [in the CK “ or ”] impended over one. (K, TA.) ― -b9- ja$aA^ati AlwaHo$u (assumed tropical:) The wild animals made a single leap, or spring. (TA.) ― -b10- ja$aA^a Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The people, or company of men, went forth from one country, or town, to another. (S, K, TA.) It is said in a trad., ja$aA^ati Alr~uwma EalaY Eahodi Eumara (assumed tropical:) The Greeks rose, and advanced from their country [in the time of 'Omar]. (TA.)

2 ja$~aAa
see 5.

5 tj$~A^ *
, (S,) inf. n. taja$~uw^N; (S, Mgh, K; [in the CK, Alt~aja$~u is erroneously put for Alt~aja$~uw^u;]) or taja$~aY, inf. n. taja$~K; (Msb;) and j$~A^↓, (S,) inf. n. tajo$iy^apN; (S, K;) both signify alike; (S;) He eructed, or belched; i. e., emitted a sound accompanied with wind, from his mouth, on an occasion of satiation of the stomach, (Mgh, Msb,) intentionally: (Mgh:) or it (the stomach) emitted wind (K, TA) on an occasion of its impletion with food or drink. (TA.)

8 Ajt$A^ AlbilaAda *
, and Aijota$aA^a AlbilaAdu (assumed tropical:) [He found the country to disagree with him, and] the country disagreed with him. (S, K.)

ja$o'N *
A light bow: (S, K:) or a bow that makes a ringing sound: (Lth, TA:) or a light rod of the tree called naboE: (As, S:) pl. A^ajo$aA='u, (K,) anomalous, and asserted by IHsh to be rare, (TA,) and ja$aA=tN. (K: in the CK, ja$oA=tN.) ― -b2- sahomN ja$o'N A light arrow. (Yaakoob, TA.) ＝ -A2- A large number (IAar, K, TA) of men, and of cattle. (IAar, TA.)

ju$oA^apN *
: see ju$aA='N. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Daybreak: [or,] accord. to 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh, the blowing of the wind at daybreak. (TA.)

ju$aA^apN *
: see ju$aA='N, in two places.

qawosN ja$oA^aY *
A ringing bow. (TA. [See also ja$~aA='u, voce A^aja$~u, in art. j$.])

ju$aA='N *
A belch; i. e., a sound accompanied with wind, from the mouth, on an occasion of satiation of the stomach; (Mgh, Msb;) a subst. from 5; (As, S, Msb, K;) as also ju$aA^apN↓ (S, K) and ju$oA^apN↓: (K: but the first and last of these three words are omitted in some copies of the K:) or ↓the second of these three words, accord. to some, is a superlative epithet, signifying a great, or frequent, belcher. (MF.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) An invasion of the night, and of the sea. (K, TA.) The torrent and the night (Als~ayolu waAll~ayolu) are called AlA^aEomayaAni [the two blind things] because their invasion is vehement. (TA.)

1 ja$aba *
, aor.
ja$uba
; and ja$iba, aor.
ja$aba
; (K;) and ja$uba, aor.
ja$uba
, inf. n. ja$aAbapN; (TA;) said of wheat, or food, (TaEaAm,) It was gross, or coarse: (K, TA:) it was badly and coarsely ground: (TA:) or it was without seasoning, or condiment, or anything to render it savoury. (K.) ― -b2- And the first, It (a thing) was thick, gross, big, coarse, or rough. (TA.) ― -b3- And ja$uba, aor.
ja$uba
, inf. n. ju$uwbapN, He (a man, TA) was a foul, or bad, eater. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- ja$abahu He ground it coarsely; namely, wheat. (K, TA.) ― -b2- ja$aba A@ll~`hu $abaAbahu God caused his youth, or youthful vigour, to pass away: or rendered him vile and despicable (rad~aA^ahu waA^aqomaA^ahu): or may God cause &c. (K.)

12 Aijo$awo$ibuw *
accord. to some, or Aixo$awo$ibuwA accord. to others, occurs in a trad. of 'Omar; (TA in art. x$b;) [and J says, and so Az accord. to the TA,] the former, if used like the latter, is not improbably correct; but I have not heard it. (S.) [See art. x$b.]

ja$obN *
: see ja$ibN

ju$obN *
The rinds of pomegranates: (K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

ja$ibN *
(S, K) and ja$obN↓ and ja$iybN↓ and mijo$aAbN↓ (K) and majo$uwbN↓ (S, K,) applied to wheat, or food, Gross, or coarse: (S, K, TA:) badly and coarsely ground: (TA:) or without seasoning, or condiment, or anything to render it savoury: (K, TA:) j$b [probably ja$ibN] signifies also anything disagreeable in taste, and choking: (TA:) and gross, or coarse, and dry, or tough: (IAth, TA:) and what is dry, or tough, of herbage. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the first, A bulky and strong camel: (ISk, TA:) a thickboned horse. (Ham p. 207.)

ja$uwbN *
A rough, or coarse, (or, as some say, TA,) short woman. (K, TA.)

ja$iybN *
: see ja$ibu. ― -b2- Also Anything rough, gross or coarse, disagreeable to the taste, and choking. (K.) ― -b3- A thick, rough, or coarse, garment, or piece of cloth. (S.) ― -b4- A rough, or coarse, and old, worn-out, skin for water or milk. (TA.) ― -b5- Rude, uncivil, unkind, rough, speech or language. (TA.) ― -b6- And (applied to a man, TA) A foul, or bad, eater. (K, TA.)

mijo$abN *
Big, or bulky, and courageous, brave, or bold. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A2- [Also, accord. to Golius, as on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof, but in this case probably a mistranscription for mi$ojabN, A wooden thing upon which clothes are put.]

muja$~abN *
A man (Sh) coarse in his means of subsistence. (Sh, K.)

mijo$aAbN *
: see ja$ibN ― -b2- Thick, gross, big, coarse, or rough, (S, and Ham p. 207,) and short. (Ham ib.) ― -b3- mijo$aAbu Albadani Thick, gross, or big, in body. (T, TA.)

majo$uwbN *
: see ja$ibN.

1 ja$ara *
, aor.
ja$ura
, (As, A, Mgh,) inf. n. ja$orN; (As, S, K;) and j$~r↓, (A,) inf. n. tajo$iyrN; (K;) He took, or sent, forth his beasts to pasture, (As, S, Mgh, K,) not to return in the evening: (As, S Mgh:) [or] he pastured his beast near to the tents or houses: (A:) [or] ja$orN signifies also one's pasturing his horse before his tent or house, after their covering: (K:) or a people's taking forth their horses and pasturing them before their tents or houses. (L.) ― -b2- And ja$orN and tajo$iyrN↓ also signify The leaving or neglecting [a thing]:(K, TA:) and dismissing [it]. (TA.) ja$ara AlquroA=na, meaning He estranged himself from
the Kur-aacute;n, is said of him who has neglected the reading or reciting of it for two months. (L from a trad.) ＝ -A2- ja$ara AlmaAlu Eano A^aholihi The cattle went forth to the places of pasturage from their owners. (A.) ― -b2- ja$ara Alr~ajulu Eano A^aholihi (tropical:) The man journeyed away from his family, or wife. (A.) ― -b3- ja$ara AlS~uboHu (aor.
ja$ura
, S,) inf. n. ju$uwrN, (S, A, K,) (tropical:) The dawn broke, (S,) or rose, (K,) or came forth. (A.)

2 ja$~ara
see 1, in two places.

ja$orN *
: see ja$arN, in three places.

ja$arN *
Camels or sheep or goats pasturing in their place, not returning to their owners (As, S, K) at night: (K:) or [simply] not returning to their owners. (As, TA.) [See also muja$~arN.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A people who pass the night with the camels, (As, S, K,) in their place, not returning to their tents or houses: (As, S:) who go forth with their beasts to the place of pasturage, and remain in their place, not returning to the tents or houses: the doing this is not considered as travelling, and therefore is not a legal reason for shortening the ordinary prayers: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) and ja$orN↓ signifies the same. (TA, as on the authority of A 'Obeyed. [But perhaps this latter is a mistranscription for ju$~arN: see what follows.]) (tropical:) A man who is away (EazabN, K, TA) from his family, or wife, with his camels; (TA;) as also ja$iyrN↓: (K, TA:) and in like manner the former is applied to a company of men; and so ju$~arN [a pl. of jaA$irN↓, q. v.]: you say qawomN ja$arN and ju$~arN. (L, TA.) ＝ -A2- The herbs, or leguminous plants, of [the season, or rain, called] the rabiyE; (L, K;) as also ja$orN↓. (L.) And j$r [app. ja$arN or ja$orN↓] also signifies A pasture-land in which horses feed. (TA.)

ja$iyrN *
: see ja$arN ＝ -A2- Also A [quiver of the kind called] wafoDap; (S, K;) i. e., a kinaAnap; and so jafiyrN; accord. to ISd, a [quiver of the kind called] jaEobap, of skins, slit in the side in order that the wind may enter it and the feathers may therefore not be eaten: (TA:) or, accord. to Z, i. q. jiraAbN (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- And A large juwaAliq [or sack]: (S, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajo$irapN and [of mult.] ju$urN. (TA.)

ja$~aArN *
The owner (SaAHib) of a pasture-land in which horses feed. (K.) You say, "He is the ja$~aAr of our camels." (A, TA. [But it seems to be implied in the A that it signifies the same as jaA$irN as explained below.])

jaA$irN *
One who takes forth horses and camels to the pasture-land, and remains there: [see also ja$~aArN:] pl.ju$~aArN: (TA:) [and ju$~arN is another pl. of the same:] see ja$arN ― -b2- Also [the pl.] ju$~arN Camels, and asses, going whithersoever they will. (TA.)

jaA$iriy~apN *
(tropical:) A drink that is taken at daybreak: (S, A, K:) you say, AiSoTabaHonaA AljaA$iriy~apa We drank the morning-draught that is taken at daybreak: (S, A:) and it has no verb: (S:) or it is only of camels' milk: (K:) or it is correctly of general application: or is properly of wine; for this is what is most frequently mentioned: and it is also used as an epithet: thus you say $arobapN jaA$iriy~apN (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A certain kind of food: (K, TA:) or a kind of food eaten at daybreak. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The [last part of the night, called the] saHar: (K:) because near to daybreak. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Midday: (K:) because of the appearance and spreading of its light. (TA.)

muja$~arN *
[A beast] made to pass the night in the pasture, away from its owner, not brought back in the evening: (K, * TA: [see also ja$arN:]) or not pastured near the water: (IAar, TA:) or that is pastured near to the water. (El-Mundhiree, TA.) And xayolN muja$~arapN Horses pastured (S, K) biAlHimaY [in the place of pasturage that is prohibited to the public]. (S.)

1 ja$iEa *
, aor.
ja$aEa
, inf. n. ja$aEN, He was, or became, affected with the most vehement desire, eagerness, avidity, cupidity, or hankering, (S, O, K,) and, (O, K,) as explained by an Arab of the desert to As, (IDrd,) with the worst kind thereof, (IDrd, O, K,) for eating &c.: (TA:) or, as ex plained by another Arab of the desert to As, (IDrd,) he took his own share, and coveted the share of another: (IDrd, K:) and tj$~E↓ sig nifies the like; (S;) or i. q. taHar~aSa, q. v. (K.) ― -b2- ja$aEN also signifies The being impatient on account of separation from an associate. (TA.) ― -b3- And The being frightened, terrified, or afraid. (TA.)

5 taja$~aEa
see 1.

6 tajaA$aEaA AlmaA='a *
They straitened each other in pressing to the water, and [so I render taEaATa$aA] vied, each with the other, in endeavouring to satisfy their thirst; (K;) on the authority of an Arab of the desert. (TA.)

ja$iEN *
part. n. of ja$iEa, Affected with the most vehement desire, &c.: pl. ja$iEuwna, (S, K,) and ja$aAEaY and ju$aEaA='a and ji$aAEN are also pls. [of the same]. (TA.) ― -b2- Alja$iEu The lion. (TA.) ― -b3- rajulN ja$iEN ba$iEN, A man in whom are combined impatience and fright and a heavy, or a heaving, state of the soul. (TA.)

ja$iyEN *
One who assumes a false disposition, and that which is not in him. (TA.)

A^ajo$aEu *
[comparative and superlative of ja$iEN; More, and most, affected with most vehement desire, &c.]. (TA.)

1 ja$ima AlA^amora *
aor.
ja$ama
, inf. n. ja$omN (S, Msb, K) and ja$aAmapN, (Msb, K,) He took, or imposed, upon himself the affair, or he undertook it, as a task, or in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience; (S, Msb, K;) as also tj$~mhu↓, (S, Msb, * K,) and tjs~mhu: (Aboo-Turáb, TA:) or ↓the second and third signify he constrained himself to do it, or perform it: (Aboo-Mihjen, Aboo-Turáb, TA in art. jsm:) and ka*aA waka*aA tj$~m↓ He did such and such things against his will, and in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience. (TA.) [See also an ex. of tj$~m↓ in art. jsm;conj. 5, last sentence.] ja$imotu A_ilayoka Earaqa Alqirobapi is said to mean [I have imposed upon myself difficulty or trouble or inconvenience, in coming to thee,] so that I have journeyed, and become in want of the water of the water-skin in the journey: or the meaning is, I have suffered, and imposed upon myself, difficulty or trouble or inconvenience, so that I have sweated like the water-skin: or by the Earaq of the qirobap is meant its Ealaq, i. e., its miEolaAq, by which it is carried; and the phrase means A_ilayoka taja$~amotu↓ Hamola Alqirbapi [I have impose upon myself, in spite of difficulty &c., in coming to thee, the carrying of the water-skin]; alluding to journeying and its difficulties: (Har p. 511:) [and in like manner,] one says, laka Earaqa Alqirobapa taja$~amotu↓ (S in art. Erq.) The sportsman, when he has not taken any game, and has returned disappointed, says, maA ja$imotu A_ilayoka ZilofFA [app. meaning I have not had the trouble of bringing to thee so much as a hoof of a gazelle or the like]. (AZ, TA.) And maA ja$imotu Alyawoma TaEaAmFA i. e., I have not eaten, to-day, food, is said on the occasion of the disappointment of any one seeking a thing. (AZ, TA.)

2 j$~mhu AlA^amora *
(S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tajo$iymN; (S;) and Aj$mhu↓; (S, Msb, K;) He imposed upon him, or made him to undertake, the affair, as a task, or in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience; or he ordered, required, or constrained, him to do the thing, it being difficult or troublesome or inconvenient. (S, Msb, K.) Hence, (S, TA,) in a trad. of Zeyd Ibn-'Amr Ibn-Nufeyl, (TA,)
mahomaA tuja$~imoniY faA_in~iY jaA$imu↓
[Whatever thou impose upon me, in spite of difficulty &c., I undertake it, in spite of difficulty &c.]. (S, TA.)

4 A^ajo$ama
see 2.

5 taja$~ama
see 1, in six places. ― -b2- taja$~amotu Alr~amola I mounted, or ascended, the greater part of the sand: some say thus; and some say tajas~amotu (TA.) ― -b3- taja$~amotu fulaAnFA mino bayoni Alqawomi I directed my course, or aim, towards such a one, [and chose him, (like tajas~amotuhu q. v.,)] from among the people, or party. (Abu-n-Nadr, TA.)

ja$omN *
A state of destruction, perdition, or death. (AA, TA.) ― -b2- See also ju$amN.

ju$omN *
: see ju$amN ＝ -A2- Also Bad money: pl. ju$uwmN (IKh, TA.)

ja$amN *
: see ju$amN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also Fatness. (AA, K.)

ja$imN *
: see ja$iymN

ju$amN *
Weight, or heaviness; (S, K;) as also ja$amN↓ (K,) and ja$omN↓ accord. to the K, but correctly ju$omN↓, as in the A and L: (TA:) [and
and unpleasing, and a difficult or troublesome or an inconvenient, affair:] a subst. from taja$~ama ka*aA waka*aA. explained above: see 1. (TA.) You say, A^aloqaY fulaAnN EalaY~a ju$amahu, (S,) or ja$amahu↓, (TA,) Such a one threw upon me his weight, or heavi ness: (S, TA:) to which Z adds, or his difficult, or troublesome, or inconvenient, affair, that he had imposed upon himself, or that was imposed upon him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The jawof [i. e., the belly; or the chest; &c.]: or the breast, with the ribs that contain it: (K:) or the breast of a camel: (S, TA:) and the part [of the skin] of the camel's breast, and of the rest of the body thereof, with which the [kind of quiver called] qrn [i. e. qaranN] is covered. (TA.) You say, gat~ahu biju$amihi meaning He threw his breast upon him. (TA.)

ju$umN *
[app. pl. of ja$iymN↓, like as jududN is pl. of jadiydN] Fat men: (IAar, K:*) and tall, crafty or cunning, and wicked or malignant, men. (IAar, TA.)

ja$uwmN *
A man who takes, or imposes, upon him self, or who undertakes, affairs, with energy or vigour, or in an extraordinary degree, in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience. (Msb.)

ja$iymN *
(K.) or, as in the book of Kr. ja$imN↓, (TA,) Thick, gross, coarse, rough, rugged, rude, big, or bulky. (K.) See also ju$umN

jaA$imN *
A man taking, or imposing, upon himself, or undertaking, an affair, in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience. (Msb.) See 2.

Almujo$imu *
The lion. (K.)

majaA$imu *
: see 5 in art. jsm

jawo$anN *
and jawo$aniY~N: see art. jw$n

AjS: from kajo (Mgh, K, [in the CK kaJo]) or, as some say, GaJo; which are Persian: (TA:) in the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, qS~ [i. e.qiS~N or qaS~N]. (Lth, TA.) (S, TA [in the latter, in one place, probably by a mistake of a copyist, written jEbAp].) ― -b2- He in verted it, or him; he turned it, or him, upside down, or over, or inside out; syn. qalabahu. (K.) ― -b3- He collected it; (K;) mostly used in relation to that which is small in quantity, paltry, or inconsiderable. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jaEaba, (A, K,) and jaEaba jaEobapN, (A,) He made a quiver of the kind called jEbp. (A, K.)

and tjE~b↓ (K) and tajaEobaY↓ (S, K) He became prostrated, or thrown down upon the ground. (S, K.)

Q. Q. 2 tajaEobaY jEb tjEbY tjEby

jaEobapN jEb jEbh jEbp
A kinaAnap [or quiver] (A, K) for arrows (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) of the kind called nu$~aAb (S, A, Msb, K) and for those that are called nabol also: (Ham p. 154:) but some make a distinction between jaEobapN and kinaAnapN: the former, they say, is for n$~Ab; and the latter, for nbl: (Mz, MF:) accord. to IDrd, the knAnp is only for nbl, and is of leather: that which is of wood is called jafiyr: and that which is of two pieces [of wood] joined together is called qrn [i. e. qaranN]: (Ham ubi suprà:) accord. to ISh, the jEbp is round and wide, with a cover on the top, over its mouth: the wafoDap is smaller, and its upper and lower parts are of equal size; whereas the jEbp is wide in its upper part, and contracted in its lower part; wide in its upper part that the feathers of the arrows [having ample room] may not become detached; for the arrows are put in the quiver with the points downwards: each of these two kinds is made of two corresponding pieces of wood: (TA:) the pl. is jiEaAbN (S, A, Msb, K) and jaEabaAtN. (Msb.) You say, nakabuwA AljiEaAba wasakabuwA Aln~u$~aAba [They inverted, or inclined, the quivers, and poured forth the arrows]. (A, TA.) And maEahu jaEobapN fiyhaA banaAtu Almawoti [With him is a quiver in which are the daughters of death; i. e., deadly arrows]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also The largest of drinking-vessels. (MF, TA.)

juEobuwbN jEbwb
A man (S) short, and ugly, or contemptible; or ugly, and small in body: (S, K:) or weak, and destitute of good: or vile, or mean, and despicable: (K:) or a low, mean, or sordid, and weak man: pl. jaEaAbiybu. (TA.)

jiEaAbapN jEAbh jEAbp jEbp

mijoEabN mjEb
One who often prostrates, or throws down, others, (Sir~iyEN, [in some copies of the K, erroneously, SariyE,]) but is not himself prostrated, or thrown down. (K, TA.)

munojaEibN mnjEb
or mutajaE~ibN (accord. to different copies of the K) Dead, or dying; syn. may~itN. (K.)

1 jaEuda jEd
, aor.
jaEuda
, inf. n. juEuwdapN (S, A, Msb, K) and jaEaAdapN, (K,) said of hair, (S, A, Msb, K,) It was, or became, crisp, or curly, or twisted, and contracted; (Msb;) was, or became, the contr. of saboT, (K,) or of musotarosil: (Msb:) or was, or became, short: (Kr, K:) and jaEida, [aor.
jaEada
,] (Msb, TA,) inf. n. jaEadN, (TA,) signifies the same; (Msb, TA;) as also tjE~d↓. (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) It became contracted, and compacted in lumps; (L;) as also tjE~d↓; (L, K; *) said of earth, (K,) or of moist earth. (L.) [The inf. n.] juEuwdapN is also sometimes used in describing the state of the froth, or foam, of a camel's mouth, when it is accumulated. (S.[See jaEodN.]) ― -b3- Also, said of a cheek, inf. n. juEuwdapN, (assumed tropical:) It was rough, or coarse, and short; contr. of A^asula. (L.)

2 jE~dhu jEd jEdh jEdp
, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. tajoEiydN, (S, A, Msb,) He crisped, or curled, or twisted, and contracted, it; (Msb;) made it the contr. of saboT, (K,) or of musotarosil; (Msb:) or made it short: (K:) namely, hair. (S, A, Msb, K.)

5 tajaE~ada
see 1, in two places.

jaEodN jEd
, applied to hair, (S, A, Msb, K,) Crisp, or curly, or twisted, and contracted; (Msb;) contr. of saboTN (K,) or of musotarosilN: (Msb:) or short. (Kr, K.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, (S,) Having hair such as is termed jaEod: (S, Msb, K:) [or]
so jaEodu Al$~aEari: (A, TA:) fem. with p: (S, Msb, K:) pl. jiEaAdN. (A, Msb.) ― -b3- As an epithet of praise, it has two meanings; namely, (assumed tropical:) Compact in limbs, and strong in make; not flabby, nor of slack, or incongruous, make; (L;) or big, or bulky, and compact; (Ham p. 238;) or, as some say, light, or active: (TA:) and having crisp, or curly, not lank, hair; because lankness is the prevalent characteristic of the hair of the Greeks and Persians; and crispness, or curliness, is the prevalent characteristic of the hair of the Arabs: but very crisp, or frizzled, or woolly, hair, like that of the Zenj and the Nubians, is disapproved. (L.) ― -b4- [Hence,] (tropical:) Generous; bountiful; munificent; (T, S, A, K;) alluding to a man's being an Arab of generous disposition, because the Arabs are characterized by crisp, or curly, hair. (A.) As did not know jEd in this sense; but it occurs in many verses of the Ansár. (T, TA.) ― -b5- As an epithet of dispraise, it has also two meanings; namely, (assumed tropical:) Short, and incongruous in make: (L:) [contr. of saboTN:] ― -b6- and (tropical:) Niggardly; (As, T, S, L, K;) as also jaEodu Alyadayoni, (S, K,) and jaEodu AlA^anaAmilu, (S,) and jaEodu AlA^aSaAbiEu, (A,) or this signifies (assumed tropical:) having short fingers, (K,) and jaEodu AlbanaAni, and jaEodu Alkaf~i, (Har p. 96,) and jaEodu AljanaAni; (A;) contr. of [saboTu Alyadayoni, and] sbTu Alyadi and sbTu AlbanaAni [&c.]: (Har ubi suprà:) and mean; ungenerous; base: (L:) and jaEodu AlqafaA (tropical:) mean, or ignoble, in respect of rank, quality, reputation, or the like. (A, K.) ― -b7- A camel having much fur: (K:) or having crisp, or curly, and abundant, fur. (S.) [Hence,] A^abuw AljaEodi a surname of The camel. (L.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) Soft moist earth; as also vaEodN: (S:) or moist earth. (K.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) A mess of the kind called Hayos that is thick, (L, K,) not flowing; (L;) as also mujaE~adN↓. (L, K.) IAar cites the following words of a poet, accusing a woman of foul conduct:
wataxoliTu biAlmaA^oquwTi HayosFA mujaE~adFA↓
[And she mixes thick Hys with the food prepared with A^aqiT]; meaning, she confounds men together, and does not select him who is to have intercourse with her. (L.) ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) Froth, or foam, accumulated upon the fore part of the mouth of a camel. (S, * L.) And jaEodu All~ugaAmi (assumed tropical:) A camel having froth, or foam, accumulated upon the fore part of his mouth. (S, * L, K. *) ― -b11- (assumed tropical:) A cheek rough, or coarse, and short; not A^asiyl. (L, K.) And (assumed tropical:) A round face, with little miloH [or beauty], (K, TA,) or, as in some copies of the K, laHom [or flesh]. (TA.) And qadamN jaEodapN (tropical:) A short foot; (A, TA;) characteristic of low origin. (TA.) ― -b12- It is also applied, in the manner of an intensive epithet, to the plant called Sil~iyaAn; and in like manner, with p, to the plant called buhomaY. (TA.) ― -b13- naAqapN jaEodapN (assumed tropical:) A she-camel compact in make, and strong. (TA.)

A bad kind of dates; (Msb, K;) also metaphorically called AlfaA^orapi jaEoru↓ [the rat's, or mouse's, dung], because of the bad smell, and the diminutiveness, thereof: (Msb:) and you also say juEoruwrN: (TA:) or a species of the daqal, which is the worst kind of dates: (S:) or a species of the [kind of palm-tree called] daqal that bears small things [or dates] in which is no good. jaEAri jEAr
, (S, A, K,) like qaTaAmi, (K,) indecl., with kesr for its termination, because it deviates from its original form, which is jaAEirapN, and is of the fem. gender, and has the quality of an epithet in which that of a subst. is predominant, so that the thing to which it applies is known by it like as it is known by its proper name; and as it is prevented from being perfectly decl. by two causes, it must be indecl. by reason of three; as we also say with respect to HalaAqi, a proper name of death; (S;) The she-hyena; (S, A, K;) a name of that animal (S) because of the abundance of its dung; (S, A;) as also A^um~u jaEaAri, and jayoEarN↓, and A^um~u jaEowarK↓. (K.) Hence, A^aEoyavu mino jaEaAri [More mischievous than the she-hyena]: a prov. (A, TA.) And tiysiY jaEaAri (K) Be thou like the he-goat in stupidity, O she-hyena; a prov. applied to a stupid man: (A and TA in art. tys, q. v.:) or EiyviY jaEaAri [Do mischief, O she-hyena]; a prov. used in declaring a thing to be vain, or false. (K.) And
ruwEiY jaEaAri waA@noZuriY A^ayona Almafori
[for Almafir~u, Be afraid, O she-hyena, and look where is a place to which to flee]: (K, * TA:) or ruwgiY [i. e. turn aside, this way and that]: (S and TA in art. rwg:) a prov. applied to him who seeks to escape, and cannot: (TA:) or with reference to a coward, and his submissiveness. (K.) And quwmiY jaEaAri [Rise, O she-hyena]: said to a woman, in reviling her; likening her to a she-hyena. (ISk, TA.)

jiEaArN jEAr

(TA.)

(TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jaEorN.

A small river; a rivulet, streamlet, or brook; (IAar, S, K;) or one that is larger than a jadowalN: (K:) or, as in the Nawádir, a small river, larger than a jdwl: (TA:) or a river, IDrd, IJ, TA,) absolutely: (TA:) if small, it is a falaj: (IDrd, TA:) or (TA, but in the K “ and ”) a large, wide river: (Ibn-El-Ajdábee, K:) [if so,] bearing two contr. significations: (K:) or (in some copies of the K “ and ”) a full river. 1 jaEala jEl
, aor.
jaEala
, inf. n. jaEolN (S, Msb, K) and juEolN and jaEaAlapN and jiEaAlapN (K) and majoEalN, (S, TA,) He made a thing; syn. SanaEa; (Msb, K;) but having a more general signification than faEala and SanaEa and their equivalents [as will be shown by what follows]; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and so AjtEl↓: (K:) both these verbs signify the same. (S.) ― -b2- He made a thing of, or from, a thing; as in the saying [in the Kur xvi. 74 and xlii. 9], jaEala lakumo mino A^anofusikumo A^azowaAjFA [He hath made for you, of, or from, yourselves, wives]; and [in the Kur xvi. 83] wajaEala lakumo mina AljibaAli A^akonaAnFA [And He hath made for you, of the mountains, places of retreat; as caves, and excavated houses or chambers: so explained by Bd]. (TA.) ― -b3- He created; (K, TA;) brought into being, or existence; (TA;) as in the saying [in the Kur vi. 1], waJaEala AlZ~ulumaAti waAln~uwri [And hath created, or brought into being, the darknesses and the light]; (K, TA;) and [in the Kur xxi. 31] wajaEalonaA mina AlmaA='i kul~a $aYo'K HaY~K [And We have created of water, or the seminal fluid, everything living]; and [in the Kur xvi. 80, &c.,] wajaEala lakumu Als~amoEa wa AlA^aboSaAra waAlA^afoy^idapa [And He created for you the ears and the eyes and the hearts]. (TA.) ― -b4- He made, or prepared; as in the saying [in the Kur lxv. 2], yajoEalu lahu maxorajFA [He will make, or prepare, for him a way of escape, or safety]; and [in the Kur lxv. 4] yajoEalu lahu mino A^amorihi yusorFA [He will make, or prepare, for him an easy state of his circumstances; i. e., will make his circumstances, or case, easy to him]. (TA.) ― -b5- He made; meaning he made to be, or become; he constituted; he appointed; [in which sense it is doubly trans.;] (S, K;) as in the saying in the Kur [xix. 31], wajaEaloniY nabiy~FA [And He hath made me a prophet]; (S;) [and in the elliptical phrase, jaEalahu Ealayohi He made him to be superintendant, or the like, over it; set him, or appointed him, over it:] and in the phrase, jaEala AlqabiyHa HasanFA [He made that which was bad to be, or become, good]. (K.) ― -b6- He made a thing to be in a particular state or condition; as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 20], Al~a*i jaEala lakumu AlA^aroDa firaA$FA [Who hath made for you the earth to be as a bed]; and [in the Kur lxxi. 15] wajaEala Alqamara fiyhin~a nuwrFA [And hath made the moon, in them (the heavens), to be as a light]; and so, as some say, in the saying [in the Kur xliii. 2], A_in~aA jaEalonaAhu quroA=nFA Earabiy~FA [Verily we have made it an Arabic Kur-án]. (TA.) ― -b7- [He made a thing to be in an altered, or changed, state or condition; i. e.,] the verb signifies also the changing a thing from its state or condition; as in the saying [in the Kur xi. 84 and xv. 74], jaEalonaA EaAliyahaA saAfilahaA [We made their upper part to be their lower part]; (K;) and in the words of the Kur [lvi. 81], watajoEaluwna rizoqakumo A^an~akumo tuka*~ibuwna [And do ye make the thanks that ye should render for your sustenance to be that ye charge with falsehood the Giver thereof by attributing it to the stars called A^anowaA=' as expl. by Bd and Jel]. (TA.) ― -b8- He pronounced (Er-Rághib, K) a thing by a true judgment or decision, (Er-Rághib,) or as a legal ordinance; (K;) as in the saying (of the Legislator, TA), jaEala A@ll~`hu AlS~alawaAti AlmaforuwDaAti xamosFA [God hath pronounced the prayers that are made obligatory to be five] (K.) And He pronounce (Er-Rághib, K *) a thing by a false judgment or decision, (Er-Rághib,) or according to his own judgment, heretically; (K;) as in the saying [in the Kur xv. 91], Al~a*iyna jaEaluwA AlquroA=na EiDiyna [Who pronounced the Kur-án to be lies, or enchantment, &c.]. (Er-Rághib, K.) ― -b9- He called, or named, (S, Msb, K,) a thing; (Msb;) as in the saying [in the Kur xliii. 18], wajaEaluwA AlmalaAy^ikapa Al~a*iyna humo EibaAdu Alr~aHom`ni A_inaAvFA [And they have called the angels, who are the servants of the Compassionate, females]: (S, K:) or, as some say, the meaning is, have described them as, and pronounced them to be, females; like as one says, jaEala fulaAnN zayodFA A^aEolama Aln~aAsi [Such a one described Zeyd as, and pronounced him to be, the most learned of men]: or have held, or believed, them to be females; like as the verb signifies in the saying in the Kur [xvi. 59], wayajoEaluwna lil~`hi AlbanaAti [And they hold, or believe, God to have daughters: or this may be rendered and they attribute to God daughters]. (TA.) You say also, jaEalotu zayodFA A^axaAka, meaning I asserted Zeyd to be related to thee [as a brother; or I called Zeyd thy brother]. (K.) ― -b10- He thought; as in the saying, jaEala AlbaSorapa bagodaAda [He thought El-Basrah to be Baghdád]; (K;) and so in the saying, jaEalotuhu EabodFA fa$atamotuhu [I thought him to be a slave, and consequently I reviled him]. (Ham p. 31.) ― -b11- He made known, or plain, or perspicuous; as in the saying [in the Kur xliii. 2, of which one explanation has been given above], A_in~aA jaEalonaAhu quroA=nFA Earabiy~FA [Verily we have made it known, &c., as an Arabic Kur-án]: (K:) or the meaning is, we have revealed it [as such]. (TA.) ― -b12- He exalted, or ennobled; as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 137], jaEalonaAkumo A^um~apF wasaTFA [We have exalted you, or ennobled you, as a nation conforming to the just mean; or just, or equitable, or good]: (K:) [or it may be rendered, we have made you a nation &c.:] or, as some say, the meaning is, we have called you, or named you, a nation &c. (TA.) ― -b13- Also, inf. n. jaEolN, He put, or laid, a thing; or put it, or laid it, down. (K.) And jaEala baEoDahu fuwoqa baEoDK He put, or threw, one part of it upon another. (K.) ― -b14- He inserted a thing into a thing; as in the Kur [ii. 18], yajoEaluwna A^aSaAbiEahumo fiY A=*aAnihimo [They insert, or put, their fingers into their ears]. (TA.) ― -b15- He put into the heart, or mind; as in the Kur [lvii. 27], wajalonaA fiY quluwbi A@l~a*iyna A@t~abaEuwhu raA^ofapF waraHomapF [And we put into the hearts of those who followed him pity and com-
passion]. (TA.) ― -b16- [He appointed, or assigned, or stipulated to give, or gave, wages, pay, or a stipend, &c.]. You say, jaEalotu lahu juEolFA [I appointed him, &c., wages, pay, or a stipend]. (Msb.) And jaEala lahu ka*aA EalaY ka*aA He stipulated with him to give him such a thing for [doing] such a thing. (K.) And jaEala [alone] He gave wages, pay, or a stipend, to another to serve for him in war, i. e., in his stead. (Mgh.) And lahu A^ajoEalotu↓ I gave to him wages, pay, or a stipend. (S, * Mgh.) And juEolFA A^ajoEalahu↓ and lahu A^ajoEalahu↓, He gave to him wages, pay, or a stipend. (K, TA.) And it is said in a trad., jaEala liqawomihi miAy^apF mina AlA_ibili EalaY A^ano yusal~imuwA [He gave, or stipulated to give, to his people, or party, a hundred camels on the condition that they should surrender]. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- jaEala yafoEalu ka*aA He set about, began, commenced, took to, or betook himself to, doing such a thing; (K, * TA;) he became occupied in doing such a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- jaEala is also, sometimes, an intrans. verb included among the verbs of appropinquation (A^afoEaAlu AlmuqaArabapi); as in the saying,
waqado jaEalotu A_i*aA maA qumotu yuvoqiluniY
vawobiY faA^anohaDu nahoDa Al$~aAribi Alv~~amili
[And I was beginning to be, or at the point of being, in such a state that, when I rose, my garment heavily burdened me, so that I stood up as stands up the intoxicated drinker]. (K.) ＝ -A3- jaEila, (S, K,) aor.
jaEala
, (K,) inf. n. jaEalN; (S;) and AjEl↓; (K;) It (water) had in it many jiEolaAn, pl. of juEalN: (S, K:) or had in it dead jiEolaAn. (K.) ― -b2- And jaEila, (TK,) inf. n. jaEalN, (IAar, K, TK,) He (a boy, TK) was, or became, short and fat. (IAar, K. [In the explanation of AljaEalu in the CK, AlqaSiyru is erroneously put for AlqiSaru.]) ― -b3- And He (a man, TK) persisted; or persisted obstinately; or persisted in contention, or litigation; or contended, or litigated; jaEalN being syn. with lajaAjN. (IAar, K.)

3 jAElhu jAEl jAElh jAElp
, (A, K,) inf. n. mujaAEalapN and jiEaAlN, (TA,) He endeavoured to conciliate him by means of a bribe. (A, K. * [In the CK, ra$~Ahu is erroneously put for raA$aAhu.])

4 A^ajoEala
see jaEala, above, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see jaEila, above. ＝ -A3- AjEl Alqidora He put down the cooking-pot (S, K) from the fire (S) with the piece of rag called jiEaAl. (S, K,) ＝ -A4- A^ajoEalato and AstjElt↓ said of a bitch, (S, K,) and of other animals, (K,) of any beasts of prey, (S,) She desired, (S, K, Er-Rághib,) or loved, (K,) copulation: (S, K, Er-Rághib:) metonymically used in this sense. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

6 tjAElwA Al$~aYo'a *
They stipulated among themselves to give the thing as wages, pay, or stipend: (K:) from juEolN. (TA.) You say also, tjAEl Aln~aAsu bayonahumo Einoda AlbaEovi [The people stipulated among themselves to give wages, or pay, to such of them as should serve as substitutes, on the occasion of being ordered forth to war]. (TA.)

8 AjtEl AjtEl
: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also He took, or received, wages, pay, or a stipend. (Mgh, TA.)

10 A_isotajoEala
see 4.

jaEolN jEl
Short palm-trees: (S, K:) or shoots, or offsets, of palm-trees, cut off from the mothertrees, or plucked forth from the ground, and planted: or bad palm-trees: or palm-trees that rise beyond the reach of the hand: (K:) n. un. with p: (S: [in the K, not so correctly, pl. of jaEolapN:]) and palm-trees such as are called baEolN [q. v.]. (K.)

juEolN jEl
Wages; pay; a stipend; or a thing that is appointed, or stipulated, to be given to a man for work, or service; (S, Mgh, Msb, * K;) of more general import than A^ujorapN and vawaAbN; (TA;) as also jiEaAlapN↓ (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and (as some say, Msb) jaEaAlapN↓ (As, Mgh, Msb, K) and juEaAlapN↓ (Mgh, Msb, K) and jaEiylapN↓ (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jiEaAlN↓ (K) and jaEalN↓: (Har p. 134:) pl. juEulN (TA) and (of jEylp or jEAlp, Mgh) jaEaAy^ilu. (Mgh, TA.) Afterwards, (Mgh,) or jaEaAlapN↓ and jiEaAlapN↓ and juEaAlapN↓, (K, TA,) Wages, or pay, or the like, which one gives to a man who goes to war (Mgh, K, TA) as a substitute for the giver, (K, TA,) that he may aid himself thereby to serve in the war: (Mgh:) pl. of the last three words jaEaAy^ilu (TA.) And juEolN, (TA in art. r$w,) or jaEaAlapN↓, (K,) A bribe. (K, TA.) And jaEiylapN↓ Algaraqi What is given, or stipulated to be given, to him who dives for goods or for a man drowned. (TA.)

jiEolN jEl
and jaEilN↓ and mujoEilN↓ Water having in it many jiEolaAn, pl. of juEalN: or having in it dead jiEolaAn. (K.) And A^aroDN mujoEilapN↓ A land abounding with jiEolaAn. (K.)

jaEalN jEl
: see juEolN.

jaEilN jEl
: see jiEolN.

juEalN jEl
[The species of black beetle called cantharus;] a certain insect (duwayob~ap); (S, K;) a certain black insect, found in moist places, (TA,) that rolls along a little ball [of dung] called duHoruwjap [in which it deposits its eggs]: (S and K in art. dHrj:) [see also xunofasaA='u: it is strangely explained in the Msb as the HirobaA=', which is the male of the A^um~u Hubayon:] pl. jiEolaAnN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened thereto, (TA,) A black and ugly and small man: or one who is wont to persist, or to persist obstinately, or to persist in contention or litigation, or to contend or litigate: and (as some say, TA) i. q. raqiybN [a watcher, an observer, &c.]. (K, TA.)

jiEaAlN jEAl
A piece of rag with which a cooking-pot is put down (S, K) from the fire; (S;) as also jiEaAlapN↓ and juEaAlapN↓: (K:) pl. juEulN (S, TA) and jaEaAy^ilu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also juEolN.

jaEowalN jEwl
The young of the ostrich. (IDrd, K.)

jaEaAlapN jEAl jEAlh jEAlp
: see juEolN, in three places.

juEaAlapN jEAl jEAlh jEAlp
: see juEolN, for each in two places: ＝ -A2-

jiEaAlapN jEAl jEAlh jEAlp
: and jiEaAlN.

jaEiylapN jEylh jEylp
: see juEolN, in two places.

jaAEilN jAEl
[act. part. n. of jaEala] Giving [wages, pay, or a stipend: &c.]. (K.)

mujoEilN mjEl
applied to a bitch, (S, K,) and to any animal (S, K) or beast of prey, (S,) Desiring, (S,) or loving, (K,) copulation. (S, K. [See 4]) ＝ -A2- Also, fem. with p: see jiEolN, in two places.

mujotaEilN mjtEl
Taking, or receiving, [wages, pay, or a stipend.] (K.)

div1.superEntry:
jEms Q. accord. to the K, but Q. Q. accord. to Sgh, jaEomasa: see art. jEs.
juEomuwsN jEmws
: see art. jEs.
juEaAmisN jEAms
: see art. jEs.
mujaEomisN mjEms
: see art. jEs.

superEntry.entry:
1 jaf~a jf
, (S, Mgh, Msb,) sec. pers. jafafota, (K,) aor. yajif~u (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and yajaf~u, (S, K,) the latter aor. mentioned by AZ, but rejected by Ks; (S;) and sec. pers. jaffota, aor. yajaf~u, (Sgh, Msb, K,) of the dial. of Benoo-Asad; (Msb;) inf. n. jafaAfN and jufuwfN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which are assigned by J and Sgh to jaf~a aor. yajif~N; (TA;) It (a thing, Mgh, or a garment, S, Msb, K, and also said of other things, S) was, or became, dry; it dried, or dried up. (Mgh, Msb.) Hence the saying, mani A@Hotalama vum~a A^aSobaHa EalaY jafaAfK He who experiences an emission of semen in sleep, then rises in the morning with what is on his garment, of the semen, dry. (Mgh.) And jaf~a Aln~ahoru, an elliptical phrase, for jaf~a maA='u Aln~ahori [The water of the river dried up]. (Msb.) And fulaAnN laA yajif~u liboduhu Such a one does not remit, or become remiss, in his work, or labour: (TA:) or does not cease to go to and fro. (Har p. 589.) ― -b2- jaf~a, inf. n. jufuwfN, said of a man, He was, or became, silent; he did not speak. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- jafafotu Al$~aYo'a A_ilaY~a, aor. A^ajuf~u, inf. n. jaf~N, I collected the thing to me. (Nawádir of AZ, TA.) ― -b2- jaf~uwA A^amowaAlahumo They collected together their camels, and took them away. (Sgh, * K, * TA.)

2 jf~fhu jffh jffp
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. tajofiyfN (S, Msb, K) and tajofaAfN, (K,) He dried it. (Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- jf~f Alfarasa, (K,) inf. n. tajofiyfN, (S,) He clad, or attired, the horse with a tijofaAf. (S, K.)

5 tajaf~a3a
see R. Q. 2.

8 A_ijotafa3a
Ajtf~ maA fiY AlA_inaA='i He consumed what was in the vessel; (K;) i. e., drank up all of it; as also A$tf~. (TA.)

R. Q. 2 tajafojafa tjfjf
It (a garment, or piece of cloth), having been moist, dried so far as to retain
some moisture: (S, K:) if it has dried entirely, you say of it, qado qaf~a: (S:) the verb is originally tjf~f↓; the medial f being changed into j: it is like taba$oba$a, originally tb$~$. (Lth, S.)

jaf~N jf
: see jaf~apN.

juf~N jf
The spathe of the palm-tree; the envelope of the TaloE; (AA, A'Obeyd, S, K;) as also jub~N; (AA, TA;) or [in other words] the qiyqaA=' of the TlE; (K;) i. e., the envelope that is with the waliyE: (Lth, K:) or, as some say, the envelope of the TlE when it has become dry: (TA:) pl. jufuwfN. (A' Obeyd, TA.) [See jub~N.] ― -b2- A receptacle such as is termed wiEaA=' that is not to be tied round at its mouth. (K, TA.) ― -b3- An old, worn-out water-skin or milk-skin, of which half is cut off and made into a bucket: (S, K:) and sometimes it is made of the lower part of a palm-tree hollowed out: (Lth, S, K: *) or a thing that is hollowed out in (fiY [probably a mistranscription for min, i. e. of]) the trunks of palm-trees: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or a worn-out milk-skin or butter-skin: (IAar, TA:) or a water-skin, or milk-skin, of which part is cut off at the fore legs, and in which the beverage called nabiy* is prepared: (Kt, TA:) or the lower half of a water-skin or milk-skin, made into a bucket: (IDrd, TA:) or a thing of camel's skin, like a vessel, or like a bucket, in which the rainwater is taken, holding half the quantity of a water-skin or the like. (TA.) ― -b4- An old man; (K;) as being likened to an old, worn-out water-skin or milk-skin: mentioned in the L from ElHejeree, and by Sgh from Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.) ― -b5- Anything hollow, such as has something within it, like the nut, and the magodap [or fruit of the tanoDub, &c.: in the CK, the maEidap]. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.) ― -b6- The body, or substance, ($axoS,) of a thing. (TA.) ― -b7- An obstruction that one sees between him and the kibleh. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A2- huwa juf~u maAlK He is a good manager of cattle, (K,) acquainted with the art of pasturing them, and of collecting them at their proper time in the place of pasture. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also what next follows.

jaf~apN jf jfh jfp
(S, K) and juf~apN↓, (Sgh, K,) but the latter is rare, (Sgh,) and juf~N↓ (S, K) and jaf~N↓, (K,) A company of men or people; a collective body thereof: (Ks, S, K:) or a great number (K) thereof. (TA.) You say, duEiytu fiY jaf~api Aln~aAsi [I was summoned, or invited, among the collective body of people]. (S.) And jaAw^uwA jaf~pF waAHidapF (S, K) They came in one collective body. (K.) laA nafala fiY ganiymapK Hat~aY tuqosama jaf~apF, (S, Mgh,) or juf~apF↓, (K,) means [There shall be no gift of spoil] until it is divided altogether: (S, Mgh, K:) a saying of Ibn-'Abbás: (S, Mgh:) accord. to one reading, EalaY juf~atihi↓, i. e., [until it is divided] among the collective body of the army first. (K. [Golius (here copied by Freytag) appears to have read, laA taqulo fiY ganamK; and hence to have said, of jaf~apN, erroneously, " de pecore non dicitur nisi totus grex sit."])

juf~apN jf jfh jfp
: see what next precedes, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also A great dalow [or bucket]. (K.)

jufaAfN jfAf
What is dry of a thing that one has dried. (K.) You say, AiEozilo jufaAfahu mino raTobihi [Put thou apart what is dry thereof from what is fresh and moist thereof]. (TA.)

jafiyfN jfyf
Dry herbs or herbage: (S, K:) or dry leguminous plants or herbs, of the kind that are eaten without being cooked: (TA:) or of this kind and of such as are thick and inclining to bitterness; as also qafiyfN: (TA in art. qf:) or, as some say, mA Dmnt mn AlryH. (TA in the present art. [But what this means I know not; the verb being evidently mistranscribed.])

jufaAfapN jfAf jfAfh jfAfp
What has become scattered, or strewed, of dry herbage (Ha$iy$) and of [the kind of trefoil called] qat~, (S, K, TA,) and the like. (TA.)

tijofaAfN tjfAf
A thing, (S, Mgh, Msb,) i. e. a kind of armour, (IAth, K,) [a cataphract,] with which a horse is clad, (S, IAth, Mgh, Msb, K,) in war, in the manner of a coat of mail, (Mgh, Msb,) to defend him from being wounded; (IAth;) and sometimes worn by a man, to defend him in war: (K:) of the measure tifoEaAlN, (Mgh, Msb,) the t being augmentative, (Aboo-'Alee the Grammarian, S, IJ,) to render the word quasi-coordinate to the class of qiroTaAsN; (IJ;) from jaf~a, because of its hardness and toughness: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. tajaAfiyfu (S, Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a trad., A^aEid~a lilofaqori tijofaAfFA; and one says, Ailobaso lilofaqori tijofaAfFA; [both] meaning, Make thou preparation for poverty. (TA.)

mutajaf~ifN mtjff
Having a tijofaAf upon his horse. (Mgh.)

jafaA^a *
, (S, K,) aor.
jafaAa
, (K,) inf. n. jafo'N, (S,) It (a valley [flowing with water]) cast forth froth, or foam, (S, K,) and particles of rubbish or refuse; (S;) as also AjfA^↓; (K;) but this latter is said in the O to be of weak authority. (TA.) And jafaA^ati Alqidoru, and AjfA^t↓, The cooking-pot cast forth its froth, or foam, (S, K,) in boiling: (S:) or jfA^t bizabadihaA it cast forth its froth, or foam: (Ham p. 132:) originally jafat and Ajft, without '. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. jfw.) ＝ -A2- jafaA^a AlwaAdiY, (K,) or jafaA^a AlguvaA='a Eani AlwaAdiY, (IAar, O,) He (a man, IAar, O) swept off the scum and rubbish of the valley [after it had flowed, or while it was flowing, with water]. (IAar, O, K.) And jafaA^a Alqidora He cleared off the froth, or foam, of the cooking-pot. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also jafaA^a Alqidora, (S, Z in the Fáïk, TA,) inf. n. as above; (S, TA;) and A^ajofaA^ahaAs↓; (Z ubi suprà, TA;) but the former is that which is commonly known; (ISd, TA;) the latter is rare; (IAth, TA:) or the latter should not be said, though it occurs in a trad., (S, TA, *) accord. to one relation; (TA;) He turned the cooking-pot upsidedown, or inclined it, (S, Z ubi suprà, TA,) and poured out what was in it: (S:) or he emptied the cooking-pot, and turned it upside-down: (TA:) and jafaA^a Alburomapa fiY AlqaSoEapi He turned the cookingpot upside-down upon the bowl. (K.) ― -b3- jafaA^ahu, (S, K,) [like HafaA^ahu,] and jafaA^a bihi AlA^aroDa, (TA,) He threw him down, or prostrated him, on the ground: (S, K, TA;) namely, a man: (S:) and bihi AjfA^↓ [signifies the same; or] he threw him, or it, (K, TA,) on the ground. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 8.

4 A^ajofaAa
see 1, in four places.

8 AjtfA^ *
He pulled, or plucked, up, or out, or he uprooted, (S, K,) and threw down, or away, a thing, (S,) or plants, or herbs, such as are termed baqol, (K,) and trees; (TA;) [but see AHtfY;] as also jafaA^a↓, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above: (TA:) [or] both signify he cut a plant, or herb. (IAar, Nh.)

jufaA='N jfA='
What is cast forth [of froth, or foam, and particles of rubbish or refuse, (see 1,)] by a torrent: (ISk, S:) the froth, or foam, cast forth by a valley [flowing with water]; and by a cooking-pot, (K, TA,) in boiling. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened to the froth, or foam, of the cooking-pot, of which no use is made, (Fr, TA,) i. q. baATilN [meaning A thing that is worthless, useless, or unprofitable]. (Fr, K, TA.) It is said in the Kur [xiii. 18], faA^am~aA Alz~abadu faya*ohabu jufaA='F, meaning baATilFA [i. e. Now as to the froth, or scum, it passeth away as a thing that is worthless, or useless, or unprofitable], (Fr, S, Jel, TA,) and thrown away. (Jel.) You say also, *ahaba Alz~abadu jufaA='F, meaning [The froth, or scum, passed away] driven from its water. (TA.) ― -b3- jufaA='N mina Aln~aAsi, occurring in a trad., is explained by IAth as meaning The first, or foremost, of the men or people (saraEaAnuhumo): but Bkh and Muslim read (instead of jfA') A^axif~aA='u, pl. of xafiyfN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, [like jufaAyapN,] An empty ship. (O, K.)

1 jafara jfr jfrp
He, or it, became wide: (K:) or became inflated, or swollen. (A.) And jafara janobaAhu His (a kid's, S and Msb, or lamb's, Msb) sides became widened, or distended: (S, Msb:) and janobaAhu Ajfr↓ [and Anjfr↓ (K in art. hDm)] his (a horse's) sides became inflated, or swollen. (A.) ― -b2- He (a lamb, K, and a kid, TA) became what is termed jaforN; as also tjf~r↓ and Astjfr↓: (K:) and tjf~rt↓ and Astjfrt↓ she (a kid) became a jaforap. (ISh, TA.) And He (a boy) became what is termed jaforN; as also tjf~r↓ (TA) and Astjfr↓: (A:) and this last verb, he became large in the sides. (L.) ＝ -A2- jafara (S, A) Eani AlD~iraAbi, (S,) or Eani AlA_ibili, (A,) aor.
jafura
, (S,) inf. n. jufuwrN; (S, K;) and Ajtfr↓; and Ajfr↓, inf. n. A_ijofaArN; and jf~r↓, inf. n. tajofiyrN; (K;) He (a stallioncamel) ceased, (S, K,) or abstained, (A,) from covering, (S, A, K,) and avoided it; having indulged in it so much that he was wearied; (S;) and his seminal fluid became little: (TA:) you say of a ram, rabaDa, (S, A,) not jafara. (S.) And
jafara Eani AlmaroA^api, (IAar, TA,) and EanohaA Ajfr↓, (IAar, K,) and Ajtfr↓, and jf~r↓, (IAar, TA,) He (a man) abstained from the woman; (K;) he abstained from sexual intercourse with her. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- jafara mina AlmaraDi He recovered from the disease. (K, TA.)

2 jaf~ara
see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- jf~rhu AlA^amoru Eanohu The thing, or affair, cut him off from him, or it. (IAar, L.)

4 A^ajofara
see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- Ajfr also signifies He cut, abandoned, or forsook, (S, K,) another, (S,) or his companion, or friend, (K,) and left off visiting him. (S, K.) And A^ajofarotu maA kunotu fiyhi I left, or relinquished, that in which I was occupied. (S.) ＝ -A3- Also It (a thing, TA) was, or became, absent, or hidden, or concealed, (K, TA,) from one. (TA.)

5 tajaf~ara
see 1, in three places.

7 A_inojafara
see 1.

8 A_ijotafara
see 1, in two places.

10 A_isotajofara
see 1, in three places.

jaforN jfr jfrp
A lamb, or kid, whose sides have become widened, or distended: (Msb:) or a lamb, (IAmb, Msb, K,) and a kid, (K, * TA,) that has become large, and begun to pasture, (K, TA,) and whose sides have become widened, or distended: (TA:) or a lamb, (K,) or a kid, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, * TA,) that is four months old, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and whose sides have become widened, and that is weaned, (A'Obeyd, S,) and has taken to pasture: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or this is sometimes four months, and sometimes five months, after the birth: or a young lamb, and a kid, after it has been weaned, when six months old: (IAar, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajofaArN (K) and [of mult.] jifaArN (Msb, K) and jafarapN: (K) fem. with p: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or jaforapN signifies a female kid that has become satiated with leguminous herbs and with shrubs, and is independent of its mother: (ISh, TA:) IAmb applies it to a female lamb and a female kid; and this is correct, though some say that it is applied to the latter only. (TA.) ― -b2- A boy when his belly has become widened, (A,) or when his flesh has become swollen out, (K,) and he has begun to eat: (A, K:) fem. with p (K.)
