[See $aAdixN; and see also muTab~ixN.] ＝ -A2- A well, (Msb, K,) or a wide well, (S, A,) not cased, or walled round, within; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also jaforapN↓: (R, TA:) or, of which a portion is cased, or walled round, within, (K, TA,) and a portion is not: (TA:) the former of the masc. gender: pl. jifaArN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] fulaAnN munohadimu Aljafori (A, K *) [Such a one's well is in a state of demolition; meaning,] such a one has no judgment: (A:) or has no intelligence. (K.) And A_in~a jaforaka EalaY~a lahaArK [Verily thy well is falling in upon me; meaning] thy mischief is coming quickly upon me. (A, TA.) ― -b3- [The pl.] jafaArN also signifies [simply] Wells. (K.) ― -b4- And hence, (TA,) She-camels abounding with milk. (K, TA.)

jaforapN jfr jfrh jfrp
: see jaforN.

juforapN jfr jfrh jfrp
A round space in the ground: (S, K:) or a round and wide cavity in the ground: (L:) pl. jifaArN. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) The belly, or interior of the body: (S:) or the cavity of the chest: or what comprises the belly [in the TA the chest] and the two sides: (K:) or the place where the ribs curve; and so in a horse &c.: (TA:) the middle of a horse, (S, Msb, K,) and of a camel: and, as some say, the middle, and main part, of anything: and thus, the main part of the sea: (TA:) pl. jufarN and jifaArN, accord. to the K; but the latter is pl. of juforapN in the sense of "a round cavity." (TA.) ― -b3- Also [the pl.] jufarN signifies The holes that are dug in the ground for props. (TA.)

jafiyrN jfyr
A kind of quiver like the kinaAnap, but wider, (Lth, S, TA,) in which are put many arrows: (Lth, TA:) or a [quiver of the kind called] jaEobap [q. v.], of skins, in which is no wood: or of wood, in which are no skins; (K;) or in which is no skin; as in some good lexicons: (TA:) or of skins, and slit in its side, that the wind may enter it, and the feathers in consequence may not be eaten: (TA: [see also ja$iyrN:]) or the same as the jEbp and the knAnp: (El-Ahmar, TA:) or a quiver for nabol, wide, of wood. (Ham p. 358.) Hence, layosa fiY jafiyrihi gayoru zanodayoni [There is not in his quiver aught save two pieces of wood for producing fire]: a prov. applied to him in whom is no good. (Meyd.)

majofarN mjfr
: see majofarapN.

mujofarN mjfr
, applied to a horse, (S, Msb, K,) and with p applied to a she-camel, (S,) Large in the middle: (S, Msb, K:) and mujofaru Aljanobayoni a horse inflated, or swollen, in the sides. (A.)

majofarapN mjfrh mjfrp
(S, A, K) and majofarN↓ (Lh, K) An impediment to venery; (Lh, A'Obeyd, S, A, K;) and a cause of diminishing the seminal fluid: (A'Obeyd, TA:) applied to food: (Lh, K:) and such is fasting said to be; (A'Obeyd, S, K;) and the sun, (A, * TA,) i. e., sitting in the sun; and such, also, the sleeping between daybreak and sunrise, or in the first part of the day. (TA.)

1 jafala jfl
, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jafila
and
jafula
, inf. n. jafolN (Msb) and jufuwlN, (Msb, K,) He (a camel) took fright, or shied, and fled, or ran away at random; or became refractory, and went away at random; or ran away, or broke loose, and went hither and thither by reason of his sprightliness: and Ajfl↓ he (a bird) took fright, and flew away; or became scared away: (Msb:) or the former, he (an ostrich, K) hastened, or sped, (S, K,) in his pace, (TA,) and went away in the land, or country; as also Ajfl↓; (IDrd, K;) both, said of an ostrich, mean he spread his wings, running; (Ham p. 555;) or spread his wings, and ran quickly, or went away at random and swiftly: (TA:) or jafalati Aln~aEaAmapu means the ostrich fled: (Msb:) and Eanohu Ajfl↓, said of anything, he fled from it: (TA, Ham p. 555:) and jafaluwA, aor.
jafula
, inf. n. jafolN; (Msb;) and AjflwA↓ (S, Msb) and AnjflwA↓ and tjf~lwA↓; (Msb;) they (a company of men) fled quickly; (S, Msb;) or the second (K) and third (S, K) signify they became displaced, (S, K, TA,) and quickly defeated, (TA,) and went away; (S, K, TA;) or these two and the fourth, (TA,) or all the four, (Har p. 373,) they hastened in defeat and flight: (TA, and Har ubi suprà:) and jafalati Alr~iyHu, (K,) and Ajflt↓, (S, K,) the wind was swift (S, K, TA) in blowing. (TA.) ― -b2- jafala, inf. n. jufuwlN, (tropical:) It (hair) became shaggy, or dishevelled, and frouzy, or altered in smell, in consequence of its being seldom dressed; or dusty and matted, by reason of its being seldom anointed; (K, TA;) and became raised and spread. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jafala is also trans., signifying He made a bird to take fright, and fly away; or he scared it away: its quasi-pass. is Ajfl↓ [explained above]; the reverse of the rule commonly obtaining: (Msb:) or the former verb, as in the O; not the latter, as in the K; he made a male ostrich to hasten, or speed, in his pace, and to go away in the land, or country; or made him to spread his wings, and run quickly, or go away at random and swiftly: (TA:) and jf~l↓ he, or it, made an animal, or animals, to take fright, and flee, or run away at random; or scared away it, or them: (TA:) [and, app., he frightened; tajofiylN being also said in the TA to be syn. with taforiyEN, which, I think, is evidently a mistranscription for tafoziyEN.] You say, Alqan~aASu AlwaHo$a jf~l↓ [The sportsman scared away the wild animals]. (TA.) And Eano maraAkizihimo A^atawohumo fajaf~aluwhumo↓ [They came to them, and scared them, or frightened them, or made them to flee, away from their stations]. (TA.) And jafalati Alr~iyHu AlZ~aliyma The wind put in motion the male ostrich, and drove him away, or along: (K:) and [in like manner] Als~afiynapa [(assumed tropical:) the ship]. (TA.) And jafalati Alr~iyHu Als~aHaAba (tropical:) The wind smote the clouds, and put them into a state of commotion, (K, TA,) and made them to speed along. (TA.) And Alr~iyHu tajofilu AljahaAma (assumed tropical:) The wind carries away the rainless clouds. (Mgh. [See also 4.]) Whence, app., (Mgh,) jafala AlbaHoru samakFA (assumed tropical:) The sea cast fish upon the shore; (Lth, Mgh, K;) a verb like Daraba; occurring in a trad., in which it is erroneously said to be A^ajofala. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) aor.
jafila
, inf. n. jafolN, (TA,) He prostrated a man; threw him down upon the ground. (K.) You say, TaEanahu fajafalahu, meaning He thrust him, or pierced him, [with a spear or the like,] and displaced and prostrated him. (Mgh.) ― -b3- He threw goods one upon another. (IDrd, Msb, TA.) ― -b4- He, or it, overturned, or turned upside-down. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, aor.
jafila
, (K,) inf. n. jafolN, (TA,) He peeled, pared, stripped, or scraped off, a thing; (AZ, K, TA;) as, for instance, flesh from the bone, and fat from the skin; (AZ, TA;) and so jf~l↓, (K,) inf. n. tajofiylN: (TA:) he removed flesh from the bone: (K:) app. formed by transposition from jalafa. (TA.) ― -b6- Also, (Msb, K,) aor.
jafula
, (Msb,) or
jafila
, (K,) He swept away mud (Msb, K, TA) from the ground; (TA;) and so jf~l↓. (K.) [It seems that Golius found, in a copy of the K, Alt~ibona erroneously put for AlT~iyna;
and Haraqahu for jarafahu; for he has explained the former verb as meaning “ combussit stramen. ”]

2 jaf~ala
see 1, in five places.

4 A^ajofala
see 1, in six places. ― -b2- You say also, A^ajofalati Alr~iyHu biAlt~uraAbi (assumed tropical:) The wind carried away the dust; made it to fly away. (S.) And Ajfl Algayomu The clouds, or mist, became removed, or cleared off. (TA.)

5 tajaf~ala
see 1. ― -b2- You say of a cock, tjf~l, meaning nafa$a buraAy^ilahu [i. e., (assumed tropical:) He ruffled the feathers around his neck]. (Ibn-' Abbád, K, TA.)

7 A_inojafala
see 1. ― -b2- Anjfl also signifies (tropical:) It went away, or departed; said of the shade, (K, TA,) and of the night. (TA.) ― -b3- He, or it, became overturned, or turned upside-down. (TA.) ― -b4- Anjflti Al$~ajarapu The tree, blown upon by a violent wind, became uprooted. (TA.)

jafolN jfl
: see AjofiylN. It is an inf. n. used as an epithet; and means A people, or party, fleeing quickly; as also jafaAlapN↓. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A cloud that has poured forth its mater and gone away (S, K) quickly; (S;) because it is then lighter and quicker. (Har p. 373.) ― -b3- A ship; (K;) because the wind drives it along (tajofiluhaA): (TA:) pl. jufuwlN. (K.) ＝ -A2- Ants: black ants: (K:) large black ants: (TA:) a dial. var. of javolN. (K.)

waqaEato fiY Aln~aAsi jafolapN wqEt fy AlnAs jflh wqEt fy AlnAs jflp
[Fear fell upon the people;] the people feared. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jafolapN $ajarapN A leafy tree; a tree having many leaves. (K.) ＝ -A3- See also what next follows.

jufolapN jfl jflh jflp
(S, K) and jafolapN↓ (TA [there said in one place to be bAlftH, but this is most probably a mistranscription for bAlDm~,]) A fleece of wool: (S, K) [a word used in the sense of] a pass. part. n., like gurofap in the phrase Aigotarafa gurofapF. (S.)

daEawotuhumu AljafalaY dEwthm AljflY dEwthm Aljfly
, (AZ, S, Msb, * K, *) and AlA^ajofalaY↓, (AZ, S, K, *) which latter was unknown to As, (S,) I invited them to my feast, or food, (AZ, S, Msb, K, *) in common, (AZ, S, Msb,) without distinction, (Msb,) or with their company and commonalty. (K.) And duEiYa fulaAnN fiY Aln~aqaraY laA fiY AljafalaY, (Akh, S, Msb, *) and AlA^ajofalaY↓, Such a one was invited among the distinguished persons, not among the commonalty. (Akh, S.) And daEowapN jafalaY A general invitation; contr. of daEowapN naqaraY. (Msb.) And jaA='a Alqawomu, A^ajofalapF↓, and A^azofalapF, (Fr, S, K, *) The people came in a company; (Fr, S;) and biA^ajofalatihimo↓, and A^azofalatihimo, with their company. (Fr, S, K.) Accord. to some, (S,) A^ajofalaY↓ signifies A collection, or an assemblage, of any things; (S, K;) as also A^azofalaY: (S:) and juf~aAlapN↓, (S, Sgh, TA,) or jufaAlapN↓, (K,) a company, or an assembly, (S, Sgh, K,) of men, (S, TA,) going along quickly. (TA.)

jafolaAnu jflAn
, or jafolaAnN, [whether with or without tenween is not shown,] Fearful; wont, or apt, to take fright and flee, or run away at random. (TA.) [See also jaf~aAlN.]

jafaAlN jfAl
: see what next follows.

jufaAlN jfAl
What is cast forth by a torrent, (S, K, TA,) of rubbish and scum, or of rotten leaves mixed with scum; (TA;) as also jafaAlN↓, like saHaAbN; (TA;) and jufaAlapN↓. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- The froth of milk. (K.) ＝ -A2- Much (K) of anything: (TA:) or of wool; as also jafiylN↓: (K:) or much wool. (S.) The ewe is represented as saying, A^uwal~adu ruxaAlFA waA^ujaz~u jufaAlFA waA^uHolabu kuvabFA viqaAlFA walamo tara mivoliY maAlFA [I am delivered of lambs, and I am shorn of much wool, and I am milked of heavy bowlfuls, and thou hast not seen cattle the like of me]: by A^ujaz~u jufaAlFA is meant I am shorn [of much wool] at once; for nought of her wool falls to the ground until all of it is shorn. (S.) jfAl is applied, by Dhu-r-Rummeh, as an epithet to hair; [meaning Much, or abundant;] and it is not applied as an epithet to anything save what is much, or abundant. (S.) Ed-Dejjál [or Antichrist] is described, in a trad., as jufaAlu Al$~aEari Having much hair: (TA:) and Alr~aA^osi jaAfilu↓ [also] has this meaning. (Ham p. 469.)

jafuwlN jfwl
A wind (riyH) that smites the clouds, and puts them into a state of commotion; (K;) or that makes them to speed along: (TA:) a swift wind; (TA;) as also jaAfilapN↓ and mujofilN↓: (S, K:) pl. of the first, (i. e., of jfwl,) jufolN. (K.) ― -b2- Great, or large: so in the phrase jum~apN jafuwlN [A great, or large, quantity of hair extending beyond the ears]. (K.) ― -b3- An aged woman; (K, * TA;) as also A_ijofiylN↓: (K:) pl. of the former as above. (K.)

jafiylN jfyl
: see jufaAlN.

jafaAlapN jfAl jfAlh jfAlp
: see jafolN.

jufaAlapN jfAl jfAlh jfAlp
: see AljafalaY: ― -b2- and jufaAlN. ― -b3- Also AljufaAlapu, (K,) or jufaAlapu Alqidori, (S,) What one takes from the head [of the contents] of the cookingpot with the ladle. (S, K.)

jaf~aAlN jfAl
an intensive epithet from jafala in the first of the senses explained above; i.e., A camel that takes fright, or shies, and flees, &c., much, or often. (Msb.) [See also jafolaAnu.]

juf~aAlapN jfAl jfAlh jfAlp
: see AljafalaY.

jaAfilN jAfl
part. n. of jafala in the first of the senses explained above: (Msb:) [and in other senses.] ― -b2- Hastening, or speeding. (TA.) See jafuwlN. ― -b3- Disquieted, disturbed, agitated, or flurried. (S, K, TA.) ― -b4- See also jufaAlN.

jayofalN jyfl
a name of [The month] *uw AlqaEodapi, (K, TA,) in the time of paganism. (TA.)

A^ajofalapN *
: see AljafalaY, in two places.

A^ajofalaY *
: see AljafalaY, in three places.

A_ijofiylN Ajfyl
Cowardly, or a coward, (S, K, TA,) that is frightened at everything. (TA.) A heostrich (S, K) that takes fright, (K,) and flees from everything (S, K, TA) that he sees; (TA;) as also jafolN↓. (K.) ― -b2- A bow of which the arrow goes far. (K.) ― -b3- See also jafuwlN.

mujofilN mjfl
Turning away, or going back, or retreating; going away. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jafuwlN.

mijofalN mjfl
applied to a camel's hump, Heavy: [properly, an instrument of overturning:] applied as an epithet to a camel's hump that is so heavy as to overturn the animal when, after rolling on the ground, he desires to rise. (TA.)

1 jafana naAqapF jfn nAqh jfn nAqp
, (K,) inf. n. jafonN, (TA,) He slaughtered a she-camel, and gave her flesh for food (K, TA) to the people, (TA,) in bowls (jifaAn). (K, TA.)

2 jf~nwA jfnwA
They made bowls (jifaAn [probably meaning they prepared bowls of food: accord. to Freytag's Lex., jf~n means “ apposuit scutellam; but he does not name his authority]). (TA.) ＝ -A2- jf~n and tjf~n↓ It (a grape-vine) attained to the state of having an A^aSol [i. e., app., a stock]. (TA.)

5 tajaf~ana
see 2.

jafonN jfn
The eyelid; both the upper and the lower: (S, Msb, K:) of the mase. gender: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajofaAnN and A^ajofunN and [of mult.] jufuwnN. (K.) ― -b2- The upper surface, and the lower, of a cake of bread: both together being called jafonaA Alr~agiyfi. (Lh, TA.) ― -b3- The scabbard, or sheath, (gimod, S, K, or gilaAf, Msb,) of a sword: (S, Msb, K:) [or] the case, or receptacle, in which is [put] the sword together with its gmd and suspensory belt or cord: (S voce qiraAbN:) [but the former signification only is commonly known:] and [it is said that] jifonN↓ signifies the same; (K;) but this is doubted by IDrd: (M, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajofaAnN and [of mult.] jufuwnN. (Msb.) ― -b4- The A^aSol [app. here meaning stock] of a grape-vine: (K:) or a grape-vine itself, in the dial. of El-Yemen; (T, TA;) so called as being imagined to be the receptacle of the grapes: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or a species of grape: (ISd, K:) or the skin of the grape, in which is the juice: (IAar, TA:) or a climbing shoot of a grape-vine: (AHn, TA:) or the shoots of the grape-vine: (T, S, M, K:) n. un. with p: (T S, M:) or, accord. to IAar, jafonapN is syn. with krEp [app. a mistranscription for karomapN a single grape-vine]: or, accord. to some, as ISd says, the leaves of the grape-vine. (TA.) [Hence,] maA='u Aljafoni The juice of the vine; (A, TA;) wine: (TA:) [or it may originally mean tears; then, rain; and then, wine: for] wine is also called maA='u Als~aHaAbi: and jafonu AlmaA='i means the clouds. (TA.) ― -b5- A kind of tree, of sweet odour. (AHn, K.) ― -b6- A certain plant, of the kind called A^aHoraAr, that grows in a spreading manner, and, when it dries up, contracts; having grains like the Hulobap [or fenugreek]. (AHn, TA.)

jifonN jfn
: see jafonN.

jafonapN jfn jfnh jfnp
A [bowl of the kind called] qaSoEap: (K:) or like a qSEp: (S:) the largest kind of qSEp; (Ks, S in art. SHf, M;) next to which is the
qSEp [properly so called], which satisfies the hunger of ten [men]; then, the SaHofap, which satisfies five; then, the miy^okalap, which satisfies two men, and three; then, the SuHayofap, which satisfies one man: (Ks, S in art. SHf:) it is peculiarly applied to a receptacle for kinds of food: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. [of mult.] jafaAnN (S, Msb, K) and jifanN (Sb, TA) and (of pauc., TA) jafanaAtN (S, Msb, K.) [Hence,] kufiy^ato jafonatuhu [His bowl was turned upside-down; meaning] (tropical:) he was slain; a phrase similar to huriyqa rifoduhu. (A in art. rfd.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A small well; (K;) as being likened to the jfnp for food. (Er- Rághib, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A generous man: (K:) jafonapN gar~aA='u is an appellation applied to a generous man who entertains many guests and feeds many: (IAar, TA:) he is called jfnp because people are fed in the jfnp, and the epithet gr~A=' is added because of the whiteness of the camel's hump in the jfnp. (TA.) ― -b4- Also i. q. xamorapN [meaning Some wine, or a kind of wine: see also maA='u Aljafoni, voce jafonN]. (IAar, TA.)

1 jafaA jf jfA
, (K,) aor.
jafuwa
, (TA,) inf. n. jafaA='N; and tjAfY↓; It did not keep, or cleave, to its place. (K.) You say, jafaA janobuhu Eani AlfiraA$i, (Mgh,) and Eanohu tjAfY↓, (S, Mgh,) His side did not rest, or was restless, or uneasy, upon the bed; or shrank from it; (S, Mgh;) and heaved, or rose, from it: (Mgh:) or the former, his side did not keep, or cleave, to its place upon the bed: and the latter, it became withdrawn, or removed, from it. (TA.) And jafaA Als~aroju Eano Zahori Alfarasi, (S Msb, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (Msb;) and tjAfY↓; (S, Msb;) The saddle heaved, or rose, from the back of the horse: (S, Msb:) or did not keep, or cleave, to its place upon his back. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] it is said in a trad. of 'Omar, A_in~iY A^ajofuw Eano A^a$oyaA='a mina AlEilomi Verily I recoil, shrink, or am averse, from some matters of knowledge, or science, and ignore them, or neglect them. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also jafaA, (Msb, TA,) aor. as above, (Msb,) [and so the inf. n.,] said of a garment, or piece of cloth, It was thick, coarse, or rough: (Msb, TA:) and in like manner said of a reed-pen, it was thick, coarse, or rough, in its nib. (TA.) ― -b4- [And hence, (see jafaA='N, below, and jaAfK,) He was, or became, thick, gross, coarse, rough, or rude, of make: and, more commonly, coarse, rough, or rude, of nature or disposition, or in his intercourse and dealings with others; unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, or surly. (See also 10.)] It is said in a trad., mano badaA jafaA, i. e. [He who abides in the desert] becomes coarse, rough, or rude, of nature or disposition; [or unkind, hard, churlish, &c.;] by reason of mixing little with men. (TA.) ― -b5- jafaA Ealayohi ka*aA Such a thing was, or became, heavy, onerous, burdensome, or oppressive, to him. (K.) ＝ -A2- jafaA janobahu Eani AlfiraA$i: and jafaA Als~aroja: see 3. ― -b2- jafati Alqidoru zabadahaA The cooking-pot cast forth its froth, or foam; as also Ajft↓; (TA;) [like jafaA^at and AjfA^t;] originally without '. (Er- Rághib, TA.) And jafaA Als~ayolu The torrent drove away [things in its course]. (Msb.) ― -b3- jafaA Alr~ajula, aor. as above, He turned away from the man; avoided him; or shunned him: or he drove away the man; from jfA Als~ayolu, explained above: sometimes meaning, with hatred. (Msb.) And jafaAhu He withdrew, or removed, far, or to a distance, from him: whence the saying of Mohammad Ibn-Sookah, lam~aA qal~a maAliY jafaAniY A_ixowaAniY [When my property became little, my brethren withdrew far from me]. (TA) ― -b4- And jafaA maAlahu He did not keep, or cleave, or hold fast, to his property. (K.) ― -b5- And jafaAhu, (S, K,) aor.
jafuwa
, (S,) inf. n. jafaA='N (S, K) and jafowN, (K,) He treated him, or behaved towards him, coarsely, roughly, rudely, unkindly, hardly, churlishly, uncivilly, or surlily: (S, K:) you should not say jafayotu. (S.) The pass. part. n. is majofuw~N↓ and majofiY~N↓: (S, and K in art. jfY:) the latter formed in accordance with jufiYa, in which the w is changed into Y. (Fr, S.) ― -b6- He did to him what displeased, grieved, or vexed, him; did to him what he disliked, or hated; did evil to him. (TA.) So in the trad., mano Haj~a walamo yazuroniY faqado jafaA [He who performs the pilgrimage to Mekkeh and does not visit me, i.e. does not visit my tomb afterwards, either on his homeward journey or by journeying to ElMedeeneh for that special purpose, does what displeases me]. (TA.) ― -b7- jafati AlmaroA^upu waladahaA The woman neglected to take care of her child, or to pay frequent attention to it. (TA.)

2 tajofiyapN jf jfA tjfyh tjfyp
[inf. n. of jf~Y] signifies, in Persian, jfA' frmwdn [app. as meaning The ordering one to act, or to treat another, coarsely, roughly, rudely, &c.]. (KL. [Accord. to Golius, as on this authority, “ i. q. jafaA, sign. injuria affecit; duriter et inique tractavit: seu transit. ejus. ”])

3 jAfY janobahu Eani AlfiraA$i *
, and jafaAhu↓, He caused his side not to rest, or caused it to be restless, or uneasy, upon the bed; or caused it to shrink therefrom: and he heaved it, drew it up, or raised it, [making it to be separated by some space or interval] from the bed. (Mgh.) And hence, (Mgh,) jAfY EaDudayohi (Mgh, TA) Eano janobyohi (TA) He put, or set, his upper arms apart, or remote, from his sides. (Mgh, TA.) [Thus the Muslim is enjoined to do in prostrating himself in prayer.] And jAfY Als~aroja Eano Zahori Alfarasi, (S, * Msb,) and AjfAhu↓, (S, K,) and jafaAhu↓, (K, [said in the TA to be a mistake, but a similar usage of this verb has been mentioned above on the authority of the Mgh,]) He raised the saddle from the back of the horse: (S, Msb, K:) and in like manner, Alqataba Eano Zahori AlbaEiyri A^ajofayotu↓ [I raised the saddle from the back of the. camel]. (M, TA.)

4 AjfAhu A^jfAh A^jfY AjfAh AjfAp
He made, or caused, him, or it, to be, or become, distant, remote, far off, or aloof. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 3, in two places. ― -b3- AjfY AlmaA$iyapa He fatigued the cattle, [in some copies of the S, tabiEahaA is put for A^atoEabahaA,] and did not let them eat, (AZ, S, K, TA,) nor fed them previously, driving them vehemently. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A^ajofati Alqidoru: see 1. ― -b2- A^jofati AlA^aroDu The land became like the jufaA=', or rubbish and scum cast forth by the torrent of a valley, or by a cooking-pot, in respect of the departure of the good thereof. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

6 tjAfY jAfY tjAfY tjAfy
: see 1, in three places. [Said of a person prostrating himself, or lying down, it means He drew up his body from that on which he rested. And tjAfY Eanohu generally signifies He, or it, receded, withdrew, removed, or became remote or aloof or separated by some space or interval, from him, or it: and he drew away, shrank, or flinched, from him, or it.] It is said, of the difference between Al*~aboH and Alqatol, that the former is by cutting the external jugular veins; and the latter, biA_iyqaAEi AlfiEili fiY AlmaHal~i maEa Alt~ajaAfiY [By causing the act to take effect upon the place thereof while standing aloof]; meaning that the qaAtil strikes from a distance, not knowing whether he will hit the place or not. (Mgh.) And [hence] you say, tjAfY lahu Eano Haq~ihi (assumed tropical:) [He relinquished, i. e.] he gave, to him, his right, or due. (TA in art. xmS.) ― -b2- He inclined, or declined, or turned, from side to side: and from right to wrong. (Har p. 125.) [See 6 in art. dfw.]

8 AjtfAhu AjtfAh AjtfAp
He removed him, or it, from his, or its, place. (K.)

10 AstjfAhu AstjfAh AstjfAp
He esteemed it (namely, a bed, &c., K) jaAfK (S, K) i. e. thick, coarse, or rough. (TA.) ― -b2- He demanded, or required, of him that he should do what was displeasing, grievous, vexatious, or evil. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AstjfY He became coarse, rough, rude, unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, or surly. (KL. [See also 1.])

jafFA jfA
: see jafaA='N.

jafowapN jf jfw jfwh jfwp
A single act of coarse, rough, rude, unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, or surly, treatment, or behaviour. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jafaA='N, in three places.

jifowapN jf jfw jfwh jfwp
: see jafaA='N.

jafaA='N jfA='
is in make; [signifying Thickness, grossness, coarseness, roughness, or rudeness:] and in nature, or disposition; (TA;) signifying coarseness, roughness, or rudeness, (Mgh, Msb,) in one's intercourse and dealings with others; (Mgh;) unkindness, hardness, churlishness, incivility, or surliness; a predominant quality of the people of the desert; (Mgh, Msb;) from jafaA said of a garment, or piece of cloth; (Msb;) contr. of bir~N (S,) or of SilapN; (K;) as also jafFA↓, (K,) accord. to Lth; but Az says that he knew not any one who allowed this latter: (TA:) so, too, jifowapN↓ and jafowapN↓, in the sayings fiyhi jifowapN and jafowapN [In him is coarseness, roughness, or rudeness, &c.]: (K:) and fulaAnN ZaAhiru Aljifowapi Such a one is a person in whom coarseness, roughness, or rudeness, &c., is apparent: (S:) but accord. to Lth, jfwp [whether jafowapN or jafowapN is not shown] denotes a more constant quality than jafaA='N (TA.) You
say also, bihi jafowapN↓, meaning He is suffering coarseness, roughness, or rudeness, &c. (K.) And Alz~amani A^aSaAbatohu jafowapu↓ (tropical:) [The roughness, or rudeness, &c., of time, or fortune, smote him]; and jafawaAtuhu [its roughnesses, or rudenesses, &c.]. (TA.)

jufaA='N jfA='
The rubbish and scum cast forth by the torrent of a valley, and by a cooking-pot. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [See also art. jfA^.] ― -b2- And hence, as being likened to the jufaA=' of the torrent, (tropical:) The first, or foremost, of men, or people. (TA.) [But see art. jfA^.]

jaAfK jAf jAfy
[act. part. n. of 1:] applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (Mgh, Msb,) and to a bed, &c., (S, * K, TA,) Thick, coarse, or rough. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] applied to a man, (S, TA,) meaning Thick, gross, coarse, rough, or rude, of make; and coarse, rough, or rude, of nature or disposition; coarse, rough, rude, unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, or surly, in his treatment of, or behaviour towards, his companions: pl. jufaApN. (TA.) You say also, rajulN jaAfiY Alxiloqapi [A man thick, gross, coarse, rough, or rude, of make]: and jaAfiYAlxuluqi niggardly and incompliant; coarse, rough, or rude, (K, TA,) in his intercourse and dealings with others; oppressive when angry and irritated against his companion with whom he sits. (TA.) And jaAfK Eani AlmawoEiZapi [Obdurate against admonition]. (TA in art. jEZr.)

majofuw~N mjfw
: see 1.

majofiY~N mjfY mjfy
: see 1.

1 jal~~a jl
, aor. yajil~u, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. jalaAlapN, (S,) or jalaAlN, (K, [in the CK, erroneously, julAlFA is put for jalaAlFA,]) or both, (TA, [but see what follows,]) and jul~aY, (Ham p. 218, see this word below, under jalalN,) [in its primary sense, It was, or became, thick, gross, coarse, rough, rugged, rude, big, or bulky: (see jaliylN:) and then,] it, (a thing, Msb,) or he (a man, S) was, or became, great; (S, Msb, K, TA;) [said of a thing, meaning in size; and] said of a man, meaning in estimation, rank, or dignity: (S, TA:) or jalaAlapN signifies greatness of estimation or rank or dignity: but jalaAlN, supreme greatness thereof: (Er-Rághib, TA:) the latter is an attribute of God only; (As in Ham p. 607, Er-Rághib, TA;) except in few instances: (As ubi suprà:) or it means the greatness, or majesty, of God: (S, Msb:) or his absolute independence. (Bd in lv. 27.) [Eaz~a wa jal~a, referring to the name of God expressed or understood, is a phrase of frequent occurrence, meaning, To Him, or to Whom, belong might and majesty, or glory and greatness] ― -b2- yajilPu Eani AlA_iHaATapi bihi [He is too great to be comprehended within limits] and yajil~u A^ano yudoraka biAlHawaAs~i [He is too great to be perceived by the senses] are phrases used in speaking of God. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b3- The saying of El-Ahmar,
yaA jal~a maA baEudato Ealayoka bilaAdunaA
faA@boruqo biA^aroDika maA badaA laka waA@roEudi
[O, how greatly distant to thee is our country! therefore threaten in thy land as long as it seems fit to thee, and menace], means mA bEdt maA A^ajal~a↓ [&c.]. (S.) ― -b4- Also jal~a, (S, K,) aor.
jali3a
, inf. n. jalaAlapN and jalaAlN, (K,) said of a man, (S,) He became old, or advanced in age, (S, K,) and firm, or sound, in judgment. (K.) And jal~ato said of a she-camel, She was, or became, old, or advanced in age: (Abu-n-Nasr, S:) and so tjAl~t↓ said of a woman. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jal~ati AlhaAjinu Eani Alawladi [The girl married before she had arrived at puberty, or the beast covered before she was of fit age,] was too young [to bear offspring]: (S:) a prov. (TA.) [Thus the verb bears two contr. significations. See also haAjinN.] ＝ -A3- jal~a Alqawomu, (S, Msb, * K, *) Eani Albaladi, (S,) or Eano manaAzilihimo, (K,) aor.
jali3a
, (Msb, K,) or
jalu3a
[contr. to rule], (S, Sgh,) or both, accord. to Ibn-Málik and others, (TA,) inf. n. juluwlN, (S, K,) [and jalaA='N accord. to the K, but this is an inf. n. of jalaA], The people, or company of men, went forth, or emigrated, (S, Msb, K,) like jalaA, (S, K,) from a country, or town, (Msb,) [or from their places of abode,] to another country, or town. (S, Msb.) ＝ -A4- jal~uwA AlA^aqiTa, (K,) [aor., accord. to rule,
jalu3a
,] inf. n. jal~N, (TA,) They took the main part, or portion, of the [preparation of milk termed] AqT. (K.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- jalalota h`*aA EalaY nafosika Thou hast brought this as an injury (janayotahu) upon thyself. (K.) ＝ -A5- jal~a AlbaEara, (S, K,) aor.
jalu3a
, (S,) inf. n. jal~N (S, K) and jal~apN, (K,) He picked up, (S,) or collected with his hand, (K,) the camels', or similar, dung; (S, K;) and Ajtl~pu↓ signifies the same, (S,) or he picked it up for fuel. (K.) [See jal~apN.] ＝ -A6- See also 2.

2 jl~l jlY jll
, inf. n. tajoliylN, said of a thing, i. q. Eam~a [as meaning It included persons, or things, &c., in common, or generally, or universally, within the compass of its influence, or effects]. (S, TA.) So in the phrase saHaAbN yujal~ilu AlA^aroDa biAlmaTari [Clouds that include the land in common, or generally, or universally, within the compass of their rain; i. e., that rain upon the land throughout its general, or universal, extent]: (S, TA:) or, as in the A, thundering clouds, covering the land with rain. (TA.) And so in the phrase, jal~ala AlmaTaru AlA^aroDa The rain included the general, or universal, extent of the land within the compass of its fall; and covered the land so as not to leave anything uncovered. (IF, Msb.) ― -b2- And hence, [in a general sense,] He covered a thing. (Msb.) It [or he] ascended, rose, mounted, got, was, or became, upon, or over, a thing; (Ham p. 45;) as also tajl~l↓. (S, K.) ― -b3- He clad a horse (S, K) or beast (K) with a jul~ [or covering for protection from the cold]; (S, K;) as also jal~a↓. (K.)

4 Ajl~hu A^jAl A^jl A^jlY A^jlh Ajlh Ajlp jAl jlA jlY |jl |jlh |jlp
, (S, K,) inf. n. A_ijolaAlN, (TA,) [He made it jaliyl, i. e., thick, &c.: contr. of A^adaq~ahu: see Ham p. 546. ― -b2- And hence,] He magnified him; honoured him; (K, TA;) as also tjAl~hu↓: (TA:) he exalted him (TA) in rank, or station. (S.) It is said in a trad., A^ajil~uwA A@ll~`ha yagofiro lakumo, meaning [Magnify ye God, and He will forgive you: or] say ye, yaA *aA AljalaAli wa AlA_ikoraAmi [O Thou who art possessed of greatness, or majesty, and bounty], and believe in his greatness, or majesty: it is also recited otherwise, with H; (TA in the present art.;) i. e. A^aHil~uwA A@ll~`ha, meaning “Resign yourselves to God; ” or “ quit ye the danger and straitness of belief in a plurality of Gods, to avail yourselves of the freedom of El-Islám; ” (TA in art. Hl;) but the former recital is confirmed by another trad., namely, A^aliZ~uwA biyaA*aA AljalaAli wa AlA_ikoraAmi [see art. lZ]. (TA in the present art.) [Hence,] faEalotu mino A_ijolaAlika, and mn A^ajoli A_ijolaAlika: see jalalN. ― -b3- He gave him much. (S.) You say, maA A^ajal~aniy walaA A^adaq~aniY (S, TA) He gave me not much, nor gave he me little: (S:) or (assumed tropical:) he gave me not a camel, nor gave he me a sheep, or goat. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, El-Marrár ElFak'asee, describing his eye, (TA,)
bakato faA^adaq~ato fiY AlbukaY waA^ajal~ati
(assumed tropical:) It wept, and shed few tears, and shed many. (S, TA.) You say also, A^ajal~a farasahu firoqFA mino *urapK He gave his horse a large feed of millet. (TA.) ― -b4- He gave him a jaliylap, i. e., a she-camel that had brought forth once. (S, K.) You say, maA A^ajal~aniY walaA A^aHo$aAniY He gave me not a she-camel that had brought forth once, (S, K, *) nor gave he me a young, or small, camel. (S.) ＝ -A2- maA A^ajal~a: see 1. [You say, maA A^ajal~ahu How great, &c., is he, or it!] ＝ -A3- Ajl~ He was, or became, strong: ― -b2- and He was, or became, weak: thus bearing two contr. significations. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

5 tjll~`hu tjll`h tjll`p
He took the greater, main, principal, or chief, part of it; the main, gross, mass, or bulk, of it; (S, K;) as also Ajtl~hu↓ (K) and tjAl~hu↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, K. [In the CK, in the explanation of the second and third of these verbs, jilaAlahu is erroneously put for julaAlahu.]) ― -b2- See also 2. ― -b3- [Hence,] He sat upon him; namely, a horse. (K,) And tjl~l AlfaHolu Aln~aAqapa (S and K in art. dA^m) The stallion-camel mounted the she-camel. (TA in that art.)

6 tjAl~ A^jAl tjAl
i. q. taEaAZama (S, K) and taraf~aEa. (S.) You say, fulaAnN yatajaAl~u Eano *`lka (S, K *) Such a one exalts himself above that; holds himself above it; disdains it; or is disdainful of it; syn. yataraf~aEu Eanohu, (S,) or yataEaAZamu; (K;) as also ytjAl~ Ealayohi. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1. ＝ -A2- tjAl~hu: see 4: ― -b2- and 5.

8 A_ijotala3a
see 5: ＝ -A2- and see also 1.

R. Q. 1 jalojala jljl
[app. It sounded; or made a sound, or sounds; said of a little bell, such as is called julojul: said also of thunder: and it sounded vehemently; or made a vehement sound, or vehement sounds: and he threatened: (see jalojalapN, which seems to be the inf. n. of the verb in these senses:) and,] said of a horse, he neighed clearly; or had a clear neigh. (K.) ＝ -A2- jalojalahu,
(S,) inf. n. jalojalapN, (K,) He put it (a thing, S) in motion (S, K) with his hand. (S.) And jljl AlqidaAHa He (a player at the game called Almayosir) moved about [or shuffled] the gaming-arrows. (TA.) ― -b2- He mixed it. (K.) ― -b3- He twisted it vehemently, or strongly; namely, the string of a bow or the like. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

R. Q. 2 tajalojala jljl tjljl
It was, or became, in a state of motion; or was put in motion. (K.) ― -b2- It was, or became, agitated in the mind. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- He sank into the ground. (S, K.) It sank, or became depressed; syn. taDaEoDaEa. (K.) One says, tajalojalato qawaAEidu Albayoti The foundations of the house sank, or became depressed; syn. taDaEoDaEato. (S.)

jal~N jl
The sail of a ship: pl. juluwl~N. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also jul~N, in two places: ＝ -A3- and jil~N: ＝ -A4- and jaliylN. ― -b2- Also Contemptible, mean, or paltry: thus bearing two contr. significations. (K.)

jul~N jl
The greater, main, principal, or chief, part of a thing; the most thereof; the main, gross, mass, or bulk, of it; (S, Msb, K;) as also julaAlN↓. (K.) You say, A^axa*a jul~ahu (K, TA) and julaAlahu↓ (S, Sgh, K) [He took the greater part of it]. ＝ -A2- A horse-cloth, or covering (Msb, K,) of a horse or similar beast, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) for protection (Msb, K) from the cold; (Msb;) as also jal~N↓: (K:) [in Persian jalo:] pl. [of mult.] jilaAlN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] A^ajolaAlN, (Msb, K,) and A^ajil~apN is pl. of jilaAlN. (S, TA.) ― -b2- The cover of, or a thing with which one covers, a book, or volume; which latter is hence called majal~apN↓. (Er-Rághib in TA; but, in this sense, written without any vowel-sign.) ＝ -A3- The place of the pitching and constructing of a tent or house. (K.) ＝ -A4- Also, (S, K,) and jal~N↓, (K,) The rose, (AHn, S, K,) the white and the red and the yellow; (AHn, K;) plentiful in the countries of the Arabs, both cultivated and wild: (AHn, TA:) a Persian word, arabicized; (AHn, * S, Sgh;) from kulo: (Sgh, TA:) and the jasmine: n. un. with p. (K.) ＝ -A5- See also jil~N: ＝ -A6- and jalalN.

jil~N jl
: see jaliylN, in six places ＝ -A2- Also The stalks of seed-produce [or corn] when it has been reaped; (S, O, Mgh, K;) as also jul~N↓ and jal~N↓: (K:) when it has been removed to the place where the grain is trodden out, and has been trodden, and cut by means of the midowas, it is called tibonN. (AHn, Mgh.) And, by amplification, applied to The stalks remaining upon the field after the reaping. (Mgh in the present art. and in art. HSd.)

jal~apN jl jlh jlp
(S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jil~apN↓ and jul~apN↓, (K,) the second whereof is that which is most known [in the present day], and next the first [which seems to be the most chaste], (TA,) Camels', or sheep's, or goats', or similar, dung; syn. baEarN: (S, K:) or a single lump thereof: (Mgh, Msb, K:) or such as has not been broken. (K.) [Commonly applied in the present day to Such dung kneaded with chopped straw and formed into round flat cakes, which are dried in the sun, for fuel.] You say, A_in~a baniY fulaAnK wa quwduhumu Aljal~apu [Verily the sons of such a one, their fuel is the dung of camels or sheep &c.]. (S.) ― -b2- Also (metonymically, Mgh) applied to Human ordure. (Mgh, Msb.)

jul~apN jl jlh jlp
A large [receptacle made of palm-leaves woven together, such as is called] quf~ap, for dates; (K;) a receptacle (S, Mgh, Msb, K) for dates, (S, Mgh, Msb,) made of palm-leaves; (K;) [a thing made of palm-leaves woven together, generally used as a receptacle for dates, but also employed for other purposes, as, for instance, to lay upon the mouth of a watering-trough, where the water is poured in, by way of protection; see A_izaA='N:] pl. jilaAlN (Mgh, Msb, K) and julalN. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also jal~ahN.

jil~apN jl jlh jlp
: see jal~apN: ＝ -A2- and jaliylN; of which it is in most instances a pl.

jalalN jlY jll
A great, momentous, or formidable, thing, affair, matter, case, or event; as also jul~aY↓ (S, K, TA) and jul~aA='u↓: (TA:) or julaY↓ [as also jalalN and jul~aA='u↓] signifies a hard, difficult, severe, or distressing, and a great, momentous, or formidable, thing, or affair, &c.: (Msb:) pl. [of jalalN,] A^ajolaAlN; (TA;) and of julalN jul~aY↓; (S, K.) El-Hárith Ibn-Waaleh says,
qawomiY humu qataluwA A^umayoma A^axiY
faA_i*aA ramayotu yuSiybuniY sahomiY
falay^ino Eafawotu laA^aEofuwano jalalFA
walay^ino saTwotu laA^uwohinano EaZomiY
[My people, they have slain, O Umeymeh, (A^umayoma being apocopated, for A^umayomapu,) my brother; so, if I shoot, my arrow will strike me; and verily, if I forgive, I shall indeed forgive a great thing; but verily, if I assault, I shall indeed weaken my bone: see Ham p. 97]. (S.) And Beshámeh Ibn-Hazn says,
wamakorumapF waA_ino daEawota A_ilaY jul~aY↓
yawomFA saraApF kiraAma Aln~aAsi faA@doEiynaA
[And if thou invite to a great affair, and a generous act, any day, manly and noble persons, the generous of mankind, invite us]: (TA:) or jul~aY is here an inf. n. in the place of jalaAlN and jalaAlapN, like rujoEaY, &c. (Ham p. 218.) ― -b2- Also, i. e., jalalN, A small, (K,) an easy, or a mean, paltry, or contemptible, thing, affair, matter, case, or event: (S, K, TA:) thus bearing two contr. significations. (S, K.) Imra-el-Keys says, on the occasion of his father's having been slain,
A^alaA kul~u $aYo'K siwaAhu jalalo
bi qatoli baniY A^asadK rab~ahumN
meaning [By Benoo-Asad's slaying their lord: now surely everything beside it is] a mean, paltry, or small, matter. (S, * TA.) ― -b3- faEalotu *`lika mino jalalika I did that on account of thee, for thy sake, or because of thee; syn. mino A^ajolika; (S, K *) as also mn jul~ika↓, (K,) and mn jalaAlika↓, (S, K,) and mn tajil~atika↓, and mn A_ijolaAlika↓, and mn A^ajoli A_ijolaAlika↓. (K.) Jemeel says,
rasomu daArK waqafotu fiY Talaliho
kidotu A^aqoDiY AlgidApa mino jalalipo
meaning [The remains marking the site of a house, I paused at the relic thereof that was still standing: I almost died, in the early morning,] on account of it (mino A^ajolihi), or, as some say, because of its greatness in my eye. (S.) ＝ -A2- Accord. to Zj, jalalo is a particle syn. with naEamo. (Mughnee.)

jalaAlN jlAl
an inf. n. of jal~a. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] faEalotu *`lika mino jalaAlika: see jalalN.

julaAlN jlAl
: see jul~N, in two places: ― -b2- also, and its fem., with p, see jaliylN, in three places: ― -b3- and see julaAjilN.

jilaAlN jlAl
The deck, or part resembling a roof, of a ship: a sing. word. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [See jul~N and jul~apN, of each of which it is a pl.]

jaliylN jlyl
, in its primary acceptation, signifies Thick, gross, coarse, rough, rugged, rude, big, or bulky; applied to a material substance; (Er-Rághib, TA;) opposed to daqiyqN; (S, Er-Rághib, TA;) as also jil~N↓, (S,) opposed to diq~N: (S, K:) [and then,] great; (Msb, K;) as also jil~N↓ and jal~N↓ (K) and julaAlN↓, (S, K,) which is also explained as signifying large, big, bulky, or large in body, (K,) and jul~aAlN↓: fem. jaliylapN and julaAlapN↓: (K:) [also] great in respect of estimation, rank, or dignity: (S, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajil~apN and jil~apN and [of mult.] A^ajil~aA='u. (TA.) You say, maA lahu diq~N y^alaA jil~N↓, i. e., daqiyqN walaA jaliylN [He has neither slender, or fine, or small, nor thick, or gross, or coarse, &c., or great]. (S.) And $ajarN jil~N↓ [Large trees; or trees as] opposed to $ajarN diq~N [or shrubs, or bushes]. (Lth, Mgh in art. bql.) And Hulalu jil~K↓ Thick, or coarse, [garments, or dresses, of the kind called] Hulal; opposed to Hulalu diq~N: (Mgh in art. dq:) or the things termed jil~N, of commodities, are carpets, and [the garments called] A^akosiyap [pl. of kisaA='], and the like; (K;) contr. of diq~N; such as the [cloth called] Hilos, and the mat, and the like. (TA.) And julaAlapN↓ signifies A great she-camel; (S, K;) big-bodied. (TA.) You say also, TaHatapu TaHonFA jaliylFA [He ground it coarsely]. (S in art. j$.) Aljaliylu, meaning The great in dignity, is not applied peculiarly to God: when it is applied to Him, it is because of his creating the great things that are indicative of Him, or because He is too great to be comprehended within limits or to be perceived by the senses. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And qawomN jil~apN means A great people; lords, chiefs, or people of rank or quality; (K;) a good people; (TA;) a people of eminence, nobility, dignity, or high rank. (K.) ― -b2- Also Old, or advanced in age, and firm, or sound, in judgment:
pl. jil~apN: (K:) which pl., as meaning old, or advanced in age, is applied to camels, (S, Sgh, K,) as well as to men. (K.) Hence, in a trad., faA@EotaraDa lahumo A_iboliysu fiY Suwarpi $ayoxK jaliylK [And Iblees presented himself to them in the form of an old man advanced in age]. (TA.) jil~apN↓ in the sense last explained above, is also used as a sing., and is applied to the male and the female [of camels]: or signifies such as is termed vaniy~ap, [i. e., a she-camel that has entered her sixth year,] until she has become a baAzil [in her ninth year]: or a male camel that has become a vaniY~: or it is applied to a she-camel, and jil~N↓ to a he-camel. (K.) And [the fem.] jaliylapN↓ [used as a subst.] signifies A she-camel that has brought forth once: (S, O, K:) and [simply] a she-camel; as in the saying, maA lahu jaliylapN walaA daqiyqapN He has neither a she-camel nor a ewe, or she-goat: (S:) or camels. (JK and TA in art. dq [q. v., voce daqiyqN].) Also (i. e. jlylp↓) A great palm-tree having much fruit: pl. jaliylN; (K;) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.;] or, accord. to some copies of the K, the pl. is jilaAlN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. vumaAmN [Panicum, or panic grass]; (S, K;) a weak plant, with which the interstices of houses are stopped up: n. un. with p: (S:) or jaliylapN↓ signifies a species of vumaAm: (TA in art. vm:) pl. jalaAy^ilu. (S, K.)

jaliylapN jlyl jlylh jlylp
[used as a subst.]: see the latter part of the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

jul~aY jl jlY jly jlyy
: see jalalN, in four places.

jul~aA='u jlA='
: see jalalN, in two places.

jul~iY~N jl jlY jly jlyy
a rel. n. from jul; A seller of jilaAl [pl. of jul~N] for horses or similar beasts. (TA.)

jul~alN jlY jll
: see jaliylN

jal~aAlapN jlAl jlAlh jlAlp
(S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jaAl~apN↓ (Mgh, Msb) A cow that repeatedly seeks after filths [to eat them]; (S, K;) the milk of which is forbidden: (S:) a beast that eats jal~ap, meaning human ordure; (S, Mgh, Msb;) the flesh of which is forbidden: (Mgh:) pl. [of the former] jal~aAlaAtN; (Msb) and of the latter jawaAl~u; (Mgh, Msb;) the latter pl. occurring in a trad., in which some erroneously substitute for it jaw~aAlaAt. (Mgh.)

julojulN jljl
[A little bell, consisting of a hollow ball of copper or brass or other metal, perforated, and containing a loose solid ball;] a small jaras [or bell]; (Msb, K;) a thing that is hung to the neck of a horse or similar beast, or to the leg of a hawk: (Mgh:) pl. jalaAjilu. (S, Mgh, Msb.) You say, fulaAnN yuEal~iqu Aljulojula fiY Eunuqihi [Such a one hangs the little bell upon his neck;] meaning, (tropical:) such a one imperils, or endangers, himself. (TA.) Abu-n-Nejm says,
A_il~aA A@moraA^N yaEoqidu xayoTa Aljulojuli
[Except a man who ties the string of the little bell;] meaning, (tropical:) except a bold man, who imperils himself: AA says that it is a prov., meaning, except a man who makes himself notorious, so that no one precedes him except a courageous man who cares not for him, and who is stubborn and notorious. (TA.) ― -b2- See also julaAjilN.

jalojalapN jljl jljlh jljlp
[app. inf. n. of jalojala, q. v.;] The sound, or sounding, of a julojul, (S,) or of a jaras [or bell]; (TA;) and of thunder: (S, K:) and vehemence of sound: and a threatening (K, TA) from behind a thing covering or concealing. (TA.)

julojulaAnN jljl jljlAn
What is jaliyl [app. meaning great in estimation] of a thing. (Ibn-' Abbád, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The fruit of the kuzoburap [or coriander]: (S, Mgh, K:) and, (Mgh,) accord, to Abu-1-Ghowth, (S,) sesame, or sesamum, (S, Z, Mgh, TA,) in its husks, before it is reaped: (S:) or it signifies also the grain of sesame or sesamum. (K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The heart's core (Hab~apu Alqalobi). (S, Z, K, TA.) You say, A^aSabotu julojulaAna qalbihi (tropical:) [I hit his heart's core]. (S.) And Aisotaqar~a *`lika fiY julojulaAna qalobihi (tropical:) [That rested, or remained, in his heart's core]. (Z, TA.) And kalaAmN xaraja mino julojulaAni Alqalobi A_ilaY qimaEi AlA^u*uni (tropical:) [Speech that came forth from the core of the heart to the meatus of the ear]. (Z, TA.)

jalojaAlN jljAl
: see mujalojilN

julaAjilN jlAjl jljl
An ass that brays clearly; (S, K;) as also julaAlN↓; (El-Moheet, K) which is in like manner applied to a she-camel. (El-Moheet, TA.) ― -b2- A boy light in spirit; brisk, lively, or sprightly, in his work; (K;) as also julojulN↓ (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A2- A^abovavotuhu julaAjila nafosiY I revealed to him what was agitated in my mind. (Ibn-' Abbád, K, * TA.)

jaAl~N jAl
Going forth, or emigrating, from a country, or town, to another country, or town; (Msb;) [as also jaAlK; (see art. jlw;)] and so jaAl~apN, (S, Msb, K,) its pl., (Msb,) applied to a people, or company of men; (S, Msb, K;) originally applied to the Jews who were expelled from El-Hijáz; as also jaAliyapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, jaAl~apN↓, as a subst., meaning The poll-tax; (Msb;) as also jaAliyapN, (S and Msb in art jlw.) You say, AusotuEomila ifulaAnN EalaY AljaAl~ap [Such a one was employed as collector of the poll-tax]; like as you say, ElY AljaAliyapi. (S, Msb.) ＝ -A2- jaAl~apN as a fem. epithet used as a subst.: see jal~aAlapN.

jaAl~apN jAl jAlh jAlp
(as a subst.): see jaAl~N; of which it is also pl. and fem.

A^ajal~u *
[Thicker &c., and thickest &c.; see jaliylN: and] i. q. A^aEoZamu [more, and most, great &c.]: (S, TA:) fem. jul~aY. (Ham. p. 45.) With the article, [as a superlative epithet,] it is applied to God; (S, TA;) and so, by poetic license, AlA^ajolalu. (TA.)

tajil~apN A^jAl A^jl A^jlY jAl jlA jlY tjlh tjlp
a subst. [signifying The act of magnifying, or honouring]; (K, TA;) like takorimapN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] faEalotu *`lika mino tajil~atika, like mn A_ijolaAlika &c.: see jalalN

majal~apN mjlh mjlp
A SaHiyfap [or book, volume, writing, or written paper or the like;] in which is science: (S, K:) and any book, or writing, (A' Obeyd, S, K,) is thus called by the Arabs; (A 'Obeyd, S;) as, for instance, that of Lukmán, and one of poetry: (TA:) and so in the phrase used by En-Nábighah (Edh-Dhubyánee, TA) majal~atuhumo *aAtu AlA_il`hi [Their book is that of God]: or, as some recite it, he said maHal~atuhumo, with HA', meaning, their abode is one of pilgrimage and of sacred sites. (S, TA.) See jul~N ― -b2- [Hence,] Science; and the doctrine, or science, of practical law. (AA, TA.)

mujal~alN mjll
A horse clad with a jul~; as also majoluwlN↓; (TA;) which latter is likewise applied to a camel. (Ibn-Abbád, TA.)

saHaAbN mujal~ilN sHAb mjll
Clouds that include the land in common, or generally, or universally, within the compass of their rain; i. e., that rain upon the land throughout its general, or universal extent: (S, TA:) or thundering clouds, covering the land with rain: (A, TA:) or clouds in which are thunder and lightning. (As, TA in art. qSb.) [See also mujalojilN.]

majoluwlN mjlwl
: see mujal~alN. ＝ -A2- Also Water into which jal~ap [q. v.] has fallen. (TA.)

mujalojalN mjljl
A man very excellent, or elegant, in mind, manners, address, speech, person, or the like; in whom is no fault, or vice. (K.) ― -b2- A camel that has attained his full strength. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- A_ibilN mujalojalapN Camels having small bells, of the kind called julojulo, hung upon them. (K.)

mujalojilN mjljl
Clouds (saHaAbN) in which is the sound of thunder: (S, K: * [in the CK, in this instance, erroneously written mujalojalN:]) or sounding: (TA:) [see also mujal~ilN:] and in like manner jalojaAlN↓ applied to rain. (K, TA.) ― -b2- A strong chief: or [in the CK, "and,"] one whose voice, or fame, (Sawot,) reaches far: and bold, vehement in repelling or defending, eloquent, or able in speech, (K,) who subjects himself to peril, or danger. (TA.)

1 jalaba jlb
, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
jaliba
and
jaluba
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. jalobN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jalabN, (S, K,) He drove, (A, K,) or brought, conveyed, or transported, (Mgh,) a thing, (S, A, * Mgh, Msb, K, *) or things, such as camels, sheep, goats, horses, captives, or slaves, or any merchandise, (TA,) from one place to another, (A, K,) or from one country or town to another, for the purpose of traffic; (Mgh;) as also Ajtlb↓, (A, K, KL,) and Astjlb↓. (KL.) And jalabotu Al$~aYo'a A_ilay nafosiY and Aijotalabotuhu↓ signify the same; (S;) i. e. (assumed tropical:) I brought, drew, attracted, or procured, the thing to myself. (PS.) [Hence,] *aA mim~aA yajolibu AlA_ixowaAna (tropical:) [This is of the things that bring, draw, attract, or procure, brothers, or friends]. (A, TA.) And Ald~ahori jalabatuhu jawaAlibu↓ (tropical:) [The calamities of time, or of fortune, or of fate, brought, drew, or attracted, him, or it]. (A, TA.)
[Hence also, accord. to some,] laA jalaba wa laA janaba, a trad., explained as meaning, The owner of cattle shall not be required to drive them, or bring them, to the town, or country, in order that the collector may take from them the portion appointed for the poor-rate, but this shall be taken at the waters; and when the cattle are in the yards, they shall be left therein, and not brought forth to the place of pasture, for the collector to take that portion: or, as some say, wlA jnb means, nor shall one have a horse led by his side, in a race, in order that, when he draws near to the goal, he may tranfser himself to it, and so outstrip his fellow: and other explanations have been given: (Msb:) [accord. to some,] lA jlb here means, they shall not drive, or bring, their cattle to the collector of the portions appointed for the poor-rate in the place where he alights, but he shall himself come to their yards and take those portions: or [jlb here is from the verb jalaba in a sense which will be explained below, and] the trad. relates to horse-racing, and means, one shall not cause his horse to be followed by a man crying out at it and chiding it; nor shall he have a horse without a rider led by his own horse, in order that, when he draws near to the goal, he may transfer himself to it, and outstrip upon it: (Mgh:) or Aljalabu, which is forbidden, means the collector's not coming to the people at their waters to take the portions appointed for the poor-rate, but ordering them to drive, or bring, their cattle to him: or it relates to contending for a stake, or wager, and means the mounting a man upon one's horse, and, when he has drawn near to the goal, following his horse and crying out at it, in order that it may outstrip; which is a kind of fraud: (S:) or it is used in both these cases: (A 'Obeyd: [his explanations are virtually the same as those in the S:]) or the meaning of the trad. [so far as the former clause of it is concerned] is, that the contributions to the poor-rate shall not be driven, or brought, to the waters nor to the great towns, but shall be given in their places of pasture: or it means, [or rather Aljlb means,] the collector's alighting in a place, and then sending a person, or persons, to drive, or bring, to him the cattle from their places, that he may take the portion thereof appointed for the poor-rate: or it [relates to horse-racing, and] means the sending forth a horse in the racecourse, and a number of persons' congregating, and crying out at it, in order that it may be turned from its course: or a man's following his horse, and spurring on behind it, and chiding it, and crying out at it: (K, TA:) or the shaking a thing behind a horse that is backward in a race, that it may be urged on thereby, and outstrip: or one's riding a horse, and leading behind him another, to urge it on, in contending for a stake, or wager: or the crying out at a horse from behind, and urging it to outstrip. (TA. See also 1 in art. jnb.) ― -b2- jalaba lA^aholihi He gained or earned; sought or sought after or sought to gain [provisions &c.; generally meaning he purveyed]; and exercised art or cunning or skill, in the management of his affairs; for his family; as also Ajlb↓. (Lh, K.) ＝ -A2- jalabuwA, aor.
jaliba
and
jaluba
, (K,) [inf. n. jalabN, and perhaps jalabapN also;] and jl~bwA↓; (S, K;) and AjlbwA↓, (K,) inf. n. A_ijolaAbN; (Mgh;) [the second of which is the most common;] They raised cries, shouts, noises, a clamour, (S, Mgh, TA,) or confused cries or shouts or noises. (Mgh, K. *) And jalaba Ealay farasihi, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jaluba
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. jalabN, (S,) or jalobN, (Msb,) He chid, or urged on, his horse; as also jl~b↓ and Ajlb↓; (K;) the first, rare; the second and third, usual: (TA:) he cried out at his horse, (S, K,) from behind him, and urged him to outstrip [in a race], (S,) aor.
jaluba
and
jaliba
; (K; but this explanation is erased in the copy of the K in its author's handwriting, as being a repetition; and rightly, accord. to MF; though this requires consideration; TA;) as also Ajlb↓: (S:) he urged his horse to run, by striking, or goading, or by crying out, or the like; as also Ajlb↓: or, as some say, he led behind his horse that he was riding another horse to urge on the former, in contending [in a race] for a stake, or wager; as is shown in an explanation of the tradition cited above, laA jalaba walaA janaba. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xvii. 66], Ealayohimo bixayolika warajolika waA^ajolibo↓ And raise thou confused cries against them, (Mgh,) or cry out against them, with thy forces riding and on foot. (Bd. But see another explanation in what follows.) And it is said in a wellknown prov., jalabato jalobapF vum~a A^amosakato It, i. e. a cloud (saHaAbap), thundered, then refrained from raining: applied to a coward, who threatens, and then is silent: but accord. to some, it is with H in the place of j (MF. See art. Hlb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jalaba, aor.
jaliba
and
jaluba
; and Ajlb↓; He threatened with evil; (K, TA;) followed by an accus. (TA) [or, app., by EalaY before the object]: or (so in the TA, but in some copies of the K “ and, ”) he collected a company, a troop, or an army. (K, TA.) [It is said that] Ealayohimo waA^ajolibo↓, in the Kur [xvii. 66], means And collect thou against them [thy forces], and threaten them with evil. (TA. But see another explanation above.) And Ealayohi Ajlbw↓ signifies also They collected themselves together against him, (S, K, *) and aided one another; like AHlbwA. (S.) ― -b3- jalaba Ealayohi, aor.
jaluba
, inf. n. jalobN, He committed a crime against him; or an offence for which he should be punished. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- jalaba, aor.
jaliba
and
jaluba
, (S, K,) It (a wound) healed: (K:) or it (an ulcer, As, or a wound, S) became covered with a skin in healing: (As, S:) as also Ajlb↓. (S, L.) ― -b2- And It (blood) dried; became dry; as also Ajlb↓. (Lh, K.) ＝ -A4- jaliba, aor.
jalaba
, It [app. a company or troop] assembled, or became collected together. (K.)

2 jal~aba
see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- The inf. n. tajoliybN also signifies The act of bringing together: or collecting. (KL.)

3 jaAolaba
[jAlb is explained by Golius, as on the authority of the KL, as meaning He helped, or assisted: but this is a mistake for HAlb; for I find muHaAlabapN explained by yArY krdn in a copy of the KL, and the order of the words there shows that it is not a mistranscriptiou for mjAlbp.]

4 Ajlb A^jlb Ajlb jlb
: see 1, in eleven places, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also His camels brought forth males; (S, K;) because the males that they produce are driven, or brought, from one place to another, and sold; opposed to AHlb “ his camels brought forth females: ” (S:) and his camel brought forth a male. (TA.) A^ajolabota walaA A^aHolabota May thy camels bring forth males, and may they not bring forth females, is a form of imprecation against a man, implying a wish that he may lose the milk [that he would have otherwise]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- He aided, helped, or assisted, another. (S, K.) [So, too, AHlb.] ＝ -A4- He put an amulet into a julobap [which must therefore signify the piece of skin in which an amulet is enclosed, as well as an amulet enclosed in a piece of skin: see mujolibN]. (K.) ― -b2- Ajlb qatabahu, (S, K,) inf. n. A_ijolAbN, (T,) He covered his qtb [or camel's saddle] (S, K) with a julobap, i. e., (S,) with a piece of fresh, moist skin, which he left upon it until it became dry [and tight]: (S, K: *) or he covered the head of his qtb with a piece of kid's, or lamb's, skin, and left it to dry upon it. (T.)

5 tajal~aba
[tjl~b rendered by Golius Clamorem ac murmur excitavit, as on the authority of the K, I do not find in that lexicon nor in any other.]

7 Anjlb A^njlb Anjlb {njlb
It [a camel, sheep, goat, horse, captive, or slave, or a number of camels &c., or any merchandise, (see 1, first sentence,)] was driven [or brought] from one place to another [or from one country or town to another, for the purpose of traffic]. (K.)

8 Ajtlb A^jtlb Ajtlb {jtlb
: see 1, first and second sentences. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) He (a poet) took, or borrowed, from the poetry of another. (TA.) ― -b3- And He sought or demanded [a thing]. (Har p. 44.)

10 Astjlbhu A^stjlbh Astjlbh Astjlbp {stjlb {stjlbh
He sought, or demanded, or desired, that it [a camel, sheep, goat, horse, captive, or slave, or a number of camels &c., or any merchandise, (see 1, first sentence,)] should be driven [or brought] from one place to another [in which he was, or from one country or town to another, for sale]. (K.) ― -b2- See also 1, first sentence.

R. Q. 1 jalobabahu jlbbh jlbbp
, (K,) or jlbbhu jilobaAbFA, (TA,) inf. n. jalobabapN, the second b not being incorporated into the first because the word is quasi-coordinate to the class of daHorajapN, (S,) He put on him a garment of the kind called jilobaAb. (S, K.) Accord. to Kh, the first b in jlbb is [augmentative] like the w in jahowara and dahowara: accord. to Yoo, the second is [augmentative] like the Y in saloqaY and jaEobaY. (IJ, TA.)

R. Q. 2 tajalobaba tjlbb
, (K,) and tajalobabato, (A, Msb,) He, and she, put on a garment of the kind called jilobaAb; or clad himself, and herself, therewith. (A, Msb, K.) And tjlbb bivawobaha He covered himself with his garment. (Har p. 162.)

julobN jlb
: see jilobN ― -b2- Also The blackness of night; (K, TA;) and so jilobaAbN↓. (Har p. 480. [The latter evidently tropical in this sense, and perhaps the former also.])

jilobN jlb
(S, K) and julobN↓ (S, L) A camel's saddle of the kind called raHol, with what it
contains, or comprises: (K:) or its cover: (Th, K:) or its pieces of wood: (S:) or its curved pieces of wood: (TA:) or its wood, without [the thongs called] A^anosaAE and other apparatus. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, both words, Clouds, (K,) or thin clouds, (S,) in which is no water: (S, K:) or clouds appearing, or extending sideways, (muEotariDN,) [in the horizon,] like a mountain [or mountainrange]: (K, TA:) or a cloud like that which is termed EaAriDN [q. v.], but narrower, and more distant, and inclining to blackness: (AZ, TA in art. ErD:) pl. A^ajolaAbN. (TA.) [See also julobapN.]

jalabN jlb
A thing, or things, driven, or brought, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) from one country or town to another, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or from one place to another, (A, K,) for the purpose of traffic; (Mgh;) as horses, &c., (K,) camels, (TA,) sheep or goats, captives or slaves, (Lth, TA,) or any merchandise: (TA:) and so jalabapN↓, thus in the handwriting of the author of the K in his last copy of that work, and mentioned by more than one, (MF, [who adds that it is correct, but SM thinks it a mistake,]) and jaliybapN↓ and juluwbapN↓: (K:) [see this last, below:] pl. [of the first] A^ajolaAbN. (K.) Hence the prov., Aln~ufaADu yuqaT~iru Aljalaba The failure of provisions causes the camels, driven, or brought, from one place to another, to be disposed in files for sale. (TA.) ― -b2- [And, app., Male camels; like jaluwbapN; because they are driven, or brought, from one place to another, and sold; (see 4;) opposed to HalabN, q. v.] ― -b3- Also Persons who drive, or bring, camels and sheep or goats [&c.] from one place or country or town to another, for sale; and so [its pl.] A^ajolaAbN. (S.) [In the present day, jal~aAbN↓ signifies One who brings slaves from foreign countries, particularly from African countries, for sale.] ＝ -A2- Also, (S, A, K,) and jalabapN↓, (S, A, * Mgh, K,) [the former an inf. n., and so, perhaps, the latter, but often used as simple substs., the latter more commonly, meaning] Cries, shouts, noises, or clamour: (S, TA:) or a confusion, or mixture, (A, Mgh, K,) of cries or shouts or noises, (A, Mgh,) or of crying or shouting or noise. (K.) ― -b2- And the former, An assembly of men. (TA.)

julobapN jlb jlbh jlbp
The small piece of skin, (S,) or the crust, or scab, (A, K,) that forms over a wound (S, A, K) when it heals: (S, K:) pl. julabN. (A.) ― -b2- A piece of skin that is put upon the [kind of camel's saddle called] qatab. (S, K.) [See 4.] ― -b3- [A piece of skin in which an amulet is enclosed: see 4.] ― -b4- An amulet upon which is sewed a piece of skin: (K:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b5- A detached portion of cloud: (K:) [or] a cloud covering the sky. (IAar, TA.) [See also jilobN.] ― -b6- A piece of land differing from that which adjoins it; a patch of ground; syn. buqoEapN. (K.) One says, A_in~ahu lafiY julobapi SidoqK i. e. fY buqoEapi SidoqK [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily he is in a good station or position: see art. bqE]. (TA.) ― -b7- A detached portion of herbage or pasture. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Severity, or pressure, of time or fortune; (S, K;) like kulobapN: (S:) and hunger: (so in some copies of the K:) or vehemence of hunger: (so in other copies of the K:) or severity; adversity; difficulty; trouble: (TA:) and a hard, distressful, or calamitous, year. (K.)

jalabapN jlb jlbh jlbp
: see jalabN, in two places.

jilib~aAtN jlbAt
(S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and jilobaAbN↓; (K;) the latter mentioned as an ex. of form by Sb, and thought by Seer to be syn. with the former, but not explained by any one except the author of the K; masc. and fem.; (TA;) A [woman's outer wrapping garment called] miloHafap: (S:) or this is its primary signification; but it is metaphorically applied to other kinds of garments: (El-Khafájee, TA:) or a shirt, (K, TA,) absolutely: or one that envelopes the whole body: (TA:) and a wide garment for a woman, less than the mlHfp: or one with which a woman covers over her other garments, like the mlHfp: or the [kind of head-covering called], ximaAr: (K:) so in the M: (TA:) or a garment wider than the xmAr, but less than the ridaA=' (Mgh, L, Msb,) with which a woman covers her head and bosom: (L:) or a garment shorter, but wider, than the xmAr; the same as the miqonaEap: (En-Nadr, TA:) or a woman's head-covering: (TA:) or the [kind of wrapper called] A_izaAr: (IAar, TA:) or a garment with which the person is entirely enveloped, so that not even a hand is left exposed, (Har p. 162, and TA,) of the kind called mulaA='ap, worn by a woman: (TA:) or a garment, or other thing, that one uses as a covering: (IF, Msb:) pl. jalaAbiybu. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- See also julobN. ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Dominion, sovereignty, or rule [with which a person is invested]. (K.)

julobaAnN jlbAn
and julabaAnN: see julub~aAnN, in three places.

jilib~aAbN jlbAb
: see jilobaAbN.

jalab~aAnN jlbAn
: see the next paragraph, last sentence.

julub~aAnN jlbAn
, (K, TA, in the CK jul~abAn, and so in the TA in art. xrf,) and without teshdeed, (K,) [i. e.] julobaAnN↓, (S, Msb,) and, accord. to some, julabaAnN↓ also, (Msb,) not heard by AHn from the Arabs of the desert but with teshdeed, though many others pronounce it without tesh-deed, and pronounced in the latter manner, he says, it may be a dial. var.; (TA;) [a coll. gen. n.;] A certain plant; (K;) or a certain grain, or seed, of the kind called qaTaAniY~ [i. e. pulse]; (Msb;) the [grain, or seed, called] xul~ar, which is a thing resembling the maA$: (S:) or a dust-coloured, dusky hind of grain or seed, which is cooked; of the colour of the mA$, except in its being of a more dusky shade; but larger: (T, TA:) a certain kind of grain or seed, resembling the mA$, of the kind called qaTaAniY~, well known: (TA:) [a common kind of vetch, or pea, the common lathyrus, or blue chickling vetch, the lathyrus sativus of Linn., is called in Upper Egypt, and by some of the people of Lower Egypt also, jilobaAn:] n. un. with p. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also the first, (K,) and p↓, (TA,) and julobaAnN↓, (MF, on the authority of Ibn-ElJowzee,) [like jurub~aAnN and jurobaAnN or jirobaAnN,] A thing like a jiraAb [or sword-case], of skin, or leather, (K, TA,) in which is put the sword sheathed, and in which the rider puts his whip and implements &c., and which he hangs upon the A=xirap or the waAsiT [see these two words] of the camel's saddle; derived from julobapN meaning “ a piece of skin that is put upon a qatab: ” (TA:) or the case (qiraAb) of the sword-sheath, or scabbard: (K:) or jlb~Anu Als~ilAHi, occurring in a trad., signifies the case (qrAb) with its contents: or the sword and bow and the like, which require some trouble to draw forth and use in fight; not such a weapon as the lance. (L, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also the first, and jalab~aAnN↓, (K, TA,) or jilib~aAnN↓, (so in the CK,) A clamorous man; or one who makes a confused crying or shouting or noise. (K, TA.)

jilib~aAnN jlbAn
: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

julub~aAnapN jlbAn jlbAnh jlbAnp
and jilib~aAnapN: see jal~aAbapN.

julubonaAnapN jlbnAnh jlbnAnp
and jilibonaAnapN: see jal~aAbapN.

jaliybN jlyb
, applied to a male slave, (A, Mgh, K,) One who is brought from one place or country or town to another [for sale]: (S, K:) or one who is brought to the country of the Muslims [for sale]: (Mgh:) pl. jalobaY and julabA='u. (K.) It is also applied [in like manner] to a woman: pl. jalobaY and jalaAy^ibu. (Lh, K.)

jaluwbapN jlwbh jlwbp
A thing that is driven or brought from one place or country or town to another for sale; (T, S, TA;) such as an aged she-camel, and a he-camel, and a young she-camel such as is called qaluwS, and any other thing; but not applied to stallion-camels of generous race, that are used for procreation: pl. jalaAy^ibu: or the pl. signifies camels that are brought to a man sojourning at a water, who has not means of carriage; wherefore they put him [and his companions or goods &c.] thereon: (TA:) or jlwbp signifies male camels: [see also jalabN:] or camels that are laden with the goods or utensils &c. of the people: and it is used alike as pl. and sing. (K.) See jalabN, with which it is syn. (K.)

jaliybapN jlyb jlybh jlybp
: see jalabN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) An affected habit or disposition. (Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed, MF.)

jal~aAbN jlAb
: see jalabN.

jul~aAbN jlAb
Rose-water: an arabicized word, (K,) from the Persian [Gulo A=bo]. (TA.)

jal~aAbapN jlAb jlAbh jlAbp
and mujal~ibapN↓ and jilib~aAnapN↓ (K, TA) and julub~aAnapN↓ (CK) and jilibonaAnapN↓ and julubonaAnapN↓, (K, TA,) applied to a woman, Clamorous, noisy, very loquacious or garrulous, and of evil disposition: (K, TA:) or jlb~Anp signifies, thus applied, rude and coarse: (TA:) the l in this word is not a substitute for the r in jirib~aAnapN [which has a similar meaning]: for it is from Aljalabapu. (IJ, TA.)

jaAliabN jAlb
(A) and jaAlibapN↓ (L) and majolabapN↓ (Har p. 194 &c.) [all signify] (assumed tropical:) A cause of bringing or drawing or attracting or procuring of a thing: (Har p. 194, in explanation of the last:) thus majolabapu Ald~amoEi means (assumed tropical:) the cause of drawing tears:
(1d p. 15:) pl. of the second, jawaAlibu; as in the phrase jawaAlibu Alqadari (assumed tropical:) [the drawing, or procuring, causes of destiny]: (L, TA:) pl. of the third, majaAlibu. (Har p. 430.) You say, likul~i qaDaA='K jaAlibN walikul~i dar~K HaAlibN (tropical:) [For every decree of fate there is a drawing, or procuring, cause; and for every flow of milk there is a milker]. (A, TA.) And [hence] the pl. jawaAlibu signifies (assumed tropical:) Calamities, misfortunes, evil accidents, adversities, or difficulties. (TA.) See an ex. in the first paragraph, near the beginning. ― -b2- quruwHN jawaAlibu and jul~abN Wounds, or ulcers, healing, or becoming covered with skin in healing. (As, TA.)

jaAlibapN jAlb jAlbh jAlbp
: see the paragraph next preceding.

mujolibN mjlb
A person who puts an amulet into a case of skin: after which it is sewed upon [the headstall, or some other part of the trappings, of] a horse. (TA.)

majolabapN mjlbh mjlbp
: see jaAlibN.

mujal~ibN mjlb
, applied to thunder, (K,) and to rain, (TA,) Boisterous. (K, TA.) ― -b2- mujal~ibapN: see jal~aAbapN.

yanojalibN ynjlb {njlb
A xazarap [i. e. bead, or gem, or similar stone] (T, K, TA) used by the Arabs of the desert, (T, TA,) [or by the women of the desert, as a charm,] for captivating, or fascinating, men; (K, * TA;) or for bringing back after flight; (T, K;) or for procuring affection after hatred: (T, TA:) Az mentions it as a quadriliteral-radical word. (TA.) The Arab women used to say,
falaA yarumo walaA yagibo
A^ax~a*otuhu biAlyanojalibo
walaA yazilo Einoda AlT~anabo
[I have fascinated him with the yenjelib, and he shall not seek another, nor absent himself, nor cease to remain at the tent-rope]. (Lh, TA.)

1 jaliHa A^jlH jlH
, aor.
jalaHa
, inf. n. jalaHN, He (a man, S, L, &c.) was, or became, bald in the two sides of his head: (S, K:) or in the two sides of the fore part of his head: (Msb:) or in the fore part of his head: or a little more bald than he who is termed A^anozaEu. (L.) [See also jalaHN and A^ajolaHu.] ― -b2- jaliHati AlA^aroDu, inf. n. as above, The herbage of the land was eaten; as also juliHat. (TA.) And juliHati Al$~ajarapu The branches of the tree were eaten, and it became reduced to its stem, or root. (AHn, TA.) ＝ -A2- jalaHa AlmaAlu Al$~ajara, aor.
jalaHa
, (S, K,) inf. n. jaloHN; (S;) and jl~Hhu↓, inf. n. tajoliyHN; (TA;) The cattle ate the trees: or ate the upper parts thereof: (TA:) or fed upon the upper parts thereof, and peeled them. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- See also 3.

2 jal~aHa
see 1. ＝ -A2- tajoliyHN [the inf. n.] signifies also the acting, or advancing, boldly, (K,) or very boldly: (S:) or being bold to do evil or mischief; and showing open enmity or hostility: (A:) and acting with penetrating energy, vigour, or effectiveness, (S, K, TA,) in an affair: (TA:) and going, or journeying, vehemently: (TA:) and the assaulting, or attacking, (AZ, K, TA,) of a man, (AZ, TA,) and of an animal of prey. (K.) See also 3. You say, lat tujal~iHo EalayonaA yaA fulaAnu [Be not bold to do evil or mischief, or to show open enmity or hostility, to us, O such a one]. (A.) And fiY wajohihi tajoliyHN In his face is [apparent] boldness to do evil or mischief, and a show of open enmity or hostility. (A.) And jl~H EalaY Alqawomi He charged, or made an assault or attack, upon the people or party. (AZ, TA.) And jl~H tajoliyHa Al*~iy^obi [He assaulted with the assaulting of the wolf]. (A.) And jl~H EalayonaA He came upon us; or came down upon us and overcame us; or destroyed us; syn. A^ataY EalayonaA. (ISh, TA.) And jl~H fiY AlA^amori He went at random, heedlessly, without any certain aim or object, or without consideration, in the affair; or pursued a headlong, or rash, course therein. (TA.)

3 mujaAlaHapN mjAlHh mjAlHp
[the inf. n.] signifies the acting openly with another in an affair: (As, K:) and the showing open enmity or hostility with another. (S, K.) You say, jaAlaHotu Alr~ajula biAlA^amori I acted openly with the man in the affair. (S.) And jaAlaHaniY fulaAnN Such a one showed open enmity or hostility with me; as also jl~H EalaY~a↓. (A.) ― -b2- Also The contending with another for superiority in strength; syn. mu$aAd~apN (S) and mukaAlaHapN. (S, K.) You say, jaAlaHaniY fulaAnN wajalaHaniY↓ [app. meaning Such a one contended with me for superiority in strength, and overcame me therein]. (TA.) ― -b3- And i. q. mukaAbarapN [The contending with another for superiority in greatness; &c.]. (K.)

Q. Q. 1 jalomaHa jlmH
He shaved his head: (Fr, S, K:) the m is augmentative. (S.)

jalaHN A^jlH jlH
Baldness in the two sides of the head: (S, K:) or in the two sides of the fore part of the head: (Msb:) it is more than nazaEN, and less than SalaEN, (S, Msb,) which is less than jalahN: (Msb:) or baldness in the fore part of the head: or baldness that is a little more than what is termed nazaEN. (L.)

jalaHapN A^jlH jlHh jlHp
A part, or place, in which is baldness such as is termed jalaHN. (S, Msb.)

A^aroDN jilaHaA='apN *
Land that produces no herbage. (K.)

julaAHN jlAH
A torrent that carries away everything in its course. (S, K.)

jilowaAHN jlwAH
Wide (K, TA) and bare, or open, (TA,) land. (K, TA.)

jul~aHN A^jlH jlH
: see A^ajolaHu.

jaAliHapN jAlHh jAlHp
(TA) and jawaAliHu (S, K [the latter being pl. of the former]) What flies about in successive portions from the heads of reeds and papyrusplants (S, K, TA) and other plants, in the wind, (TA,) resembling cotton; (S, TA;) and spiders' webs so flying about. (TA.) And the latter, Flakes of snow falling quickly and continuously. (TA.)

A^ajolaHu *
A man bald in the two sides of his head: (S:) or in the two sides of the fore part of his head: (Msb:) or in the fore part of his head: (Mgh, L:) or a little more bald than he who is termed A^anozaEu: (L:) it signifies more than AnzE, and less than A^ajolaY and A^ajolahu: (Mgh:) when a man is bald in the sides of his forehead, he is termed AnzE; when the baldness is a little more, AjlH; when it extends to the half, or the like, AjlY; and then, Ajlh: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) the fem. is jaloHaA='u: and the pl. juloHN (L, Msb) and juloHaAnN. (L.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Having no horn; applied to a bull and a he-goat: (A:) and in this sense the fem. is applied to a ewe (T, M, Msb) or she-goat, (T, M, A, Msb,) and to a cow: (T, M, A:) and in like manner [the pl.] juloHN is applied to cows or bulls having no horns; (S, TA;) erroneously said in the K to be jul~aHN, like suk~arN. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A [woman's camel-vehicle of the kind called] hawodaj that has not a high head or top: (Ibn-Kulthoom, IJ, S, K:) or without a top: (T:) or one that is of a square form: (As, IJ:) pl. A^ajolaAHN↓, (S, IJ,) like as A^aEozaAlN is pl. of A^aEozalu; a very rare form of pl. of a sing. of the measure A^afoEalu. (IJ.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A flat roof not surrounded by a wall or anything else to prevent persons' falling from it. (IAth, K.) ― -b5- qaroyapN jaloHaA='u (tropical:) A town having no fortress: (A, TA:) pl. qurFY juloHN: the fortresses being likened to horns. (TA.) ― -b6- A^akamapN jaloHaA='u (assumed tropical:) [A hill] not having a pointed summit. (TA.) And haDobapN jaloHaA='u (assumed tropical:) [A] smooth [hill]. (A.) ― -b7- A^aroDN jaloHaA='u (assumed tropical:) A land in which are no trees. (TA.) ― -b8- yawomN A^ajolaHu (assumed tropical:) A hard, distressing, or calamitous, day; as also A^aSolaEu. (A, TA.)

A^ajolaAHN *
: see A^ajolaHu.

A_ijoliyHN AjlyH
A plant of which the upper parts have been eaten. (TA.)

mujal~aHN mjlH
Eaten: (S, K:) eaten until nothing of it is left: (S:) herbage so eaten. (TA.)

mujal~iHN mjlH
A man (S) who eats much; a great eater; voracious. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also mijolaAHN. ― -b3- sanapN mujal~iHapN A year of drought, barrenness, or death. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Insolent and audacious. (L.) You say, fulaAnN waqiHN mujal~iHN [Such a one is impudent, insolent, and audacious]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- A bold wolf. (TA.)

mijolaAHN mjlAH
A she-camel (S) that bears with hardiness a severe year, preserving her milk; (S, K;) as also mujal~iHapN↓. (L.) ― -b2- See also mujaAliHN.

majoluwHN mjlwH
A tree having the head, or upper part, eaten. (L.) ― -b2- A plant, or tree, that has been eaten and has grown again. (TA.)

mujaAliHN mjAlH
i. q. mukaAbirN [Contending with another for superiority in greatness; &c.: see its verb, 3]. (S.) ― -b2- The lion. (K.) ― -b3- A she-camel that yields
milk abundantly in winter: (S, K:) or that crops the twigs of the dry trees in winter, in a year of drought, and becomes fat upon them, and so preserves her milk: (IAar, TA:) pl. majaAliyHu↓: (S, K:) or this is pl. of mujaAliHN and mijolaAHN↓ as epithets applied to a palm-tree and a she-camel that cares not for the want of rain. (AHn, TA.) And mujaAlaHapN A she-camel that eats the samur and EurofuT, whether they have leaves upon them or not. (TA.)

majaAliyHu mjAlyH
: see mujaAliHN. ― -b2- Also Years of drought that carry off, or destroy, the cattle. (S, K.)

1 jaladahu jld jldh jldp
, (S, A, Mgh, &c.,) aor.
jalida
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jalodN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He hit, or hurt, his skin; (S, K;) like as you say, raA^asahu, and baTanahu: (S:) he beat his skin: (Mgh:) he beat him; namely, a criminal: (Msb:) he struck him with a whip, and with a sword: (TA:) he flogged him (A, K) with a whip, (K,) or with whips: (A:) jaladotu is sometimes written and pronounced jalad~u. (MF on the letter d.) You say, jaladahu AlHad~a, inf. n. as above, He inflicted upon him the flogging ordained by the law. (S, L.) ― -b2- jaladati AlHay~apu The serpent bit: (K:) or, accord. to some, one says of the serpent called A^asowadu, specially, yajolidu bi*anabihi [it strikes with its tail]. (TA.) ― -b3- jalada jaAriyatahu, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He lay with his young woman, or female slave. (K, TA.) [Hence,] jalada Eumayorapa [(assumed tropical:) i. q. nakaHa Alyada], a metonymical phrase: jalodu Eumayorapa meaning AlxaDoxaDapu, and AlAisotimonaA='u biAlyadi, also termed Alt~adoliylu, and AlAiEotimaAru: the similar act of a woman is termed AlA_iloTaAfu. (Har p. 572.) ― -b4- jalada bihi AlA^aroDa He smote the ground with him; (TA;) he threw him down prostrate on the ground. (A, TA.) And julida bihi He fell down (K, TA) upon the ground by reason of much sleepiness; as also julida bihi nuwomFA.
