(TA.) kunotu A^ata$ad~adu fayujoladu biY, in a trad., means [I used to exert my strength, or energy, but] sleep would overcome me so that I fell down. (L.) ― -b5- jaladahu EalaY AlA^amori (tropical:) He compelled him against his will to do the thing. (A, K.) ― -b6- yujoladu bikul~i xayorK (or, as related by AHát, yjl*, with *, TA) (tropical:) He is imagined to possess every good quality. (A, K.) But the saying of EshSháfi'ee kaAna mujaAlidN yujoladu means (assumed tropical:) Mujálid used to be pronounced a liar, (K, TA,) or suspected and accused of lying. (TA.) ＝ -A2- julidati AlA^aroDu, (S, L, Msb,) the verb being in the pass. form, (Msb,) or jalidat, (A, K,) a verb of the same form as fariHa; (K;) [or both may be correct, like Duribat and Daribat in the same sense;] and A^ajoladat↓; (K;) [but this last I believe to be a mistake for A^ujolidat, like A^uDoribat;] The land was, or became, affected or smitten, by hoar-frost, or rime. (S, A, L, Msb, K.) And jld Albaqolu [in the TA jalida] The herbs, or leguminous plants, were, or became, affected, or smitten, thereby. (L, TA.) And A^ujoliduwA↓ They (men) were, or became, affected, or smitten, thereby. (L, K.) ＝ -A3- jaluda, aor.
jaluda
, inf. n. jalaAdapN and juluwdapN and jaladN (or this last is a simple subst., L) and majoluwdN, (an inf. n. like maHoluwfN and maEoquwlN, (S, or from tajal~ada, M in art. Esr,) He (a man, S, L) was, or became, hardy, strong, sturdy, (S, * L, K, *) and enduring, or patient. (L.)

2 jl~d jld
, (IAar, T, S, Mgh,) inf. n. tajoliydN, (T, S, Mgh, K,) He skinned a camel (IAar, T, S, Mgh, K) that had been slaughtered: (S, K:) one seldom uses salaxa thus [in relation to a camel]. (S.) ― -b2- Also He covered a thing with skin; as, for instance, a pair of socks, or stockings: (Mgh:) and in like manner, [he bound] a book: (A, K: *) and he clad a young camel in the skin of another young camel: (L: [see jaladN:]) thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- [He ordered to be flogged. (Freytag's Lex.: but without any indication of an authority.)] ＝ -A3- [He, or it, rendered a man hardy, strong, sturdy, and enduring, or patient: so in the present day.]

3 jAldhu jAld jAldh jAldp
He contended with him in fight, whether the fight were with swords or not. (A in art. Trd.) You say, jAldhu biAls~ayofi, (L,) inf. n. mujaAladapN (S, A, L) and jilaAdN, (A, L,) He contended with him in fight with the sword. (S, * A, L.) And jaAladuwhumo biAls~uyuwfi They contended with them in fight with swords. (A.) And jAldwA biAls~uyuwfi, (K, TA,) and tjAldwA↓ (S, A, L, and so in the CK instead of jAldwA) bAlsywf, (S,) and AjtldwA↓, (S, A, L,) They contended, one with another, in fight with swords. (S, A, * L, K.) ― -b2- [See also HaADarahu.]

4 Ajldhu A_ilayohi Ajldh Alyh Ajldh Alyp
(assumed tropical:) He constrained, compelled, or necessitated, him to have recourse to, or betake himself to, him, or it: (so in some copies of the K:) or he made him to stand in need of, or to want, him, or it. (AA, L, and so in some copies of the K and in the TA.) ＝ -A2- A^ajoladati AlA^aroDu [or A^ujolidat]: and A^ujoliduwA: see 1.

5 tjl~d A^jld jld tjld
He affected hardiness, strength, sturdiness, and endurance, or patience; constrained himself to behave with hardiness, &c. (S, * A, * L, K. *) So in the phrase tjl~d lil$~aAmitiyna [He constrained himself to behave with hardiness, &c., to those who rejoiced at his misfortune]. (A, TA.) In the phrase tjl~d Eanohu [He constrained himself to endure with hardiness and patience the loss, or want, of him, or it], the verb is made trans. by means of En because it implies the meaning of taSab~ara. (L.) ― -b2- Also He feigned, or made a show of, hardiness, strength, sturdiness, and endurance, or patience. (L.)

6 tajaAolada
see 3.

8 A_ijotalada
see 3. ＝ -A2- Ajtld AlA_inaA='a, (AZ, TA,) or maAfiY AlA_inaA='i, (K,) He drank all that was in the vessel; (AZ, K, TA;) as also AHtld. (AZ, TA.)

jalodN jld
(sometimes pronounced jaDodN, S) and jaliydN↓, (applied to a man, S, A, Mgh,) Hardy, strong, sturdy, (S, * A, * L, K, *) and enduring, or patient: (L:) not baliyd [q. v.]: (Mgh:) pl. [of either] julodN, (S, L, K,) or juludN, (so in some copies of the K,) and juladaA='u and A^ajolaAdN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, L, K) and jilaAdN. (K.) And [the fem.] jalodapN A hardy and strong she-camel; strong to labour and to journey; that heeds not the cold: and also swift: pl. jalodaAtN: (L:) and a she-camel that yields a copious flow of milk: (Th, TA:) sing. of jilaAdN, (S,) which signifies she-camels abounding with milk; as also majaAliydu, (K,) pl. of mijolaAdN↓; (TA;) or she-camels having neither milk nor young: (K:) [see also jaladN:] or she-camels that yield the most greasy, or unctuous, sort of milk: and so the sing., jldp, applied to a ewe or a she-goat. (S.) jilaAdN (pl. of jalodapN, TA) is also applied to palm-trees, meaning Large, hard, hardy, or strong: (S, K, TA:) or such as are not affected by drought. (TA.) And tamorapN jalodapN signifies A tough-skinned, excellent, date; as also jilodapN↓: and a hard, compact, date. (L.)

jilodN jld
, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) the only form of the word mentioned by the generality of the lexicographers; (TA;) occurring at the end of a verse with kesr to the second as well as the first letter, jilidN↓, agreeably with a license allowed to a poet in such a case, to give to a quiescent letter in a rhyme the same vowel as that which the preceding letter has; (S;) and jaladN↓, (IAar, S, K,) like $ibohN and $abahN, and mivolN and mavalN; but this is said by ISk to be unknown; (S;) The skin of any animal; (K;) the integument of the body and limbs of an animal: (Az, Msb:) or the exterior of the ba$arapN [or upper skin] of an animal: (Msb: [but this is a strange explanation:]) pl. juluwdN (S, Msb, K) and (sometimes, Msb) A^ajolaAdN [a pl. of pauc.]. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- [The pl.] A^ajolaAdN signifies also, and tajaAliydu↓ likewise, The body and limbs (S, A, L) of a man; (S;) the whole person, or body and limbs, of a human being; (L, K;) and his self: (L:) so called because enclosed by the skin: pl. of the former, A^ajaAlidu. (L.) You say, maA A^a$obaha A^ajolaAdahu biA^ajolaAdi A^abiyhi How like are his person and body to the person and body of his father! (L.) And fulaAnN EaZiymu AlA^ajolaAdi and Alt~ajaAliydi↓ (A, L) Such a one is large and strong (L) in respect of the body and limbs. (A, L.) And rud~uwA AlA^ayomaAna EalaY A^ajolaAdihimo Repeat ye the oaths to the persons, themselves: occurring in a trad.: said on the occasion of a man's entering among others of whom an oath had been demanded. (L.) ― -b3- Aljilodu also signifies (assumed tropical:) The penis. (Fr, L, K: but in the CK, in this sense, it is written Aljalodu.) Agreeably with this explanation, its pl. juluwd is said by Fr to be used in the Kur xli. 20: (L:) or as meaning the pudenda: (L, K:) but ISd holds that this word there means the skins, with which, as in manual operations, acts of disobedience are performed. (L.)

jaladN jld
: see jilodN. ― -b2- Also The skin of a camel,
or other beast, with which another beast is clothed: (L:) the skin of a young camel, which (being stripped off, S) is put over the body of another young camel, in order that the mother of the skinned young one (smelling it, S) may conceive an affection for it [and suckle it]: (S, K:) or the skin of a young camel, which is stuffed with panic grass (vumaAm), (K, TA,) or some other plant, (TA,) and put before a she-camel, in order that she may be induced thereby to affect that which is not her young one [and so yield her milk], (K, TA,) or, to affect the young one of another. (L, TA.) ＝ -A2- A ewe or she-goat whose young one dies at the time of her bringing it forth; as also jaladapN↓: pl. [of the former] jilaAdN and [of the latter] jaladaAtN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, [as a coll. gen. n.,] Great she-camels, having neither young ones nor milk; n. un. with p: (S:) [see also jalodN:] or great camels, among which are no little ones; (K;) n. un. with p: (TA:) and (app. as a quasipl. n., TA) sheep or goats, and camels, having neither young ones nor milk; (K;) app. meaning having no little ones to which they give such: (Mohammad Ibn-El-Mukarram, TA:) or she-camels having no young ones with them, so that they endure patiently the heat and cold: (Fr, TA:) or she-camels having no milk, and the young ones of which have gone away from them; including what are called banaAtu All~abuwni, and such as are above these in age; and also such as are called maxaASN, and Ei$aArN, and HiyaAlN; but when they have given birth to their young, they cease to be termed jaladN, and are called Ei$aArN, and liqaAHN: the pl. is A^ajolaAdN and [pl. pl.] A^ajaAliydu. (Az, TA.) ＝ -A3- Hard ground; as also A^ajoladu↓: (S:) or hard and level ground; as also jaladapN↓: (K:) or level but rough ground; (L;) as also A^ajoladu↓: (TA:) pl. (of the former, TA) A^ajolaAdN and (of the latter, TA) A^ajaAlidu. (S, TA.) You also say A^aroDN jaladN, with fet-h to the l; (AHn, TA;) and jalodapN↓, with a quiescent l; (Lth, AHn, TA;) and ArD jaladapN↓ also; and makaAnN jaladN. (Lth, TA.) ＝ -A4- Also, as a subst. or an inf. n., (L, [see jaluda,]) Hardiness, strength, sturdiness, (S, * A, * L, K, *) and endurance, or patience. (T.)

jilidN jld
: see jilodN.

jalodapN jld jldh jldp
: see jaladN.

jilodapN jld jldh jldp
a more particular term than jilodN; (S, L;) signifying A piece, or portion, of skin. (L.) ― -b2- One says also jilodapu AlEayoni [app. meaning The eyelid]. (TA.) ― -b3- And qawomN mino jilodatinaA A people, or company of men, of ourselves, and of our kinsfolk. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jalodN.

jaladapN jld jldh jldp
: see jaladN, in three places.

jaliydN jlyd
A woman flogged with a whip; as also with p: pl. jalodaY and jalaAy^idu: (Lh, L:) the former pl. thought by ISd to be of the former sing.; and the latter, of the latter. (L.) ＝ -A2- Hoarfrost, or rime; i. e. dew that falls (S, A, K) from the sky (S) upon the ground (S, A, K) and congeals; (S, K;) also called DariybN and saqiyTN; (S;) like SaqiyEN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Congealed, or frozen, water; ice. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also jalodN.

julayodapN jlyd jlydh jlydp
[dim. of jilodapN] One of the TabaqaAt [coats, or tunics,] of the eye. (TA.)

juluwdiY~N jlwd jlwdY jlwdy jlwdyy
[A dealer in skins;] a rel. n. from juluwdN, pl. of jilodN. (TA.)

jal~aAdN jlAd
One whose office it is to flog others with a whip. (Mgh.) [In the present day, An executioner, in a general sense.]

A^ajoladu *
: see jaladN, in two places.

tajaAliydu tjAlyd
: see jilodN, in two places.

mijoladN mjld
A piece of skin which a wailing woman holds in her hand, and with which she slaps (S, K) her face (S) or her cheek: (K:) pl. majaAliydu; (Kr, K;) or, as ISd thinks, this is pl. of mijolaAdN↓ [as syn. with mijoladN], for mifoEalN and mifoEaAlN are often interchangeable as measures of words of this kind. (TA.)

mujal~adN mjld
Covered with skin: thus applied to a pair of socks, or stockings, meaning having skin put upon the upper and lower parts. (Mgh.) [A book, or portion of a book, bound: ― -b2- and hence, A volume: pl. mujal~adaAtN.] ― -b3- A bone covered only by the skin; having nothing remaining on it but the skin. (K.) ＝ -A2- A horse [rendered hardy and enduring;] that is not frightened by, (K,) or not impatient at, (S, and so in some copies of the K,) being beaten (S, K) with the whip. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A certain quantity of a burden, or load, of known measure and weight; (K;) six hundred pounds' weight. (IAar, TA in art. bhr.)

mujal~idN mjld
One who binds books, or covers them with skin. (K.)

mijolaAdN mjlAd
: see mijoladN: ＝ -A2- and see also jalodN.

majoluwdN mjlwd
[Having his skin hit, hurt, or beaten: flogged: &c.: see also jaliydN]. ＝ -A2- A^aroDN majoluwdapN Land affected, or smitten, by hoar-frost, or rime. (S, A, L, Msb, K.) ＝ -A3- majoluwdN is also an inf. n. of jaluda [q. v.]. (S, L, K.)

mujotaladN mjtld
A place of contending in fight with swords. (L from a trad.)

1 jalasa jls
, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
jalisa
, (A, K,) inf. n. juluwsN (S, A, Msb, K) and majolasN↓, (S, A, K,) He placed his seat, or posteriors, upon rugged [or rather elevated] ground, such as is termed jalosN: this is the primary signification: (TA:) [and hence,] He sat; i. q. qaEada [when the latter is used in its largest sense]: (Msb, and so S and L and A and K in art. qEd:) you say, jalasa mutarab~iEFA and qaEada mutarab~iEFA [He sat cross-legged]: (Msb:) accord. to El-Fárábee and others, contr. of qaAma; and thus it has a more common application than qaEada [when the latter is used in its most proper and restricted sense]: (Msb:) but qaEada also signifies the contr. of qaAma: ('Orweh Ibn-Zubeyr, L in art. qEd:) properly speaking, jalasa differs from qaEada; the former signifying he sat up; or sat after sleeping, or prostration, (Msb,) or after lying on his side; (B, TA;) and the latter, he sat down; or sat after standing: (Msb, B, TA: and see other authorities to the same effect in art. qEd:) for juluwsN is a change of place from low to high, and quEuwdN is a change of place from high to low: and one says, jalasa mut~akiy^FA, but not qaEada mut~akiy^FA, meaning [He sat] leaning, or reclining, upon one side: (Msb:) but both these verbs sometimes signify he was, or became: and thus, [it is said,] jalasa mutarab~iEFA and faEada mutarab~iEFA signify he was, or became, cross-legged: and jalasa bayona $uEabihaA AlA^arobaEi in like manner signifies he was, or became, [between her four limbs,] (El-Fárábee, Msb,) because the man, in this case, is resting upon his own four limbs. (Msb.) [jalasa maEahu and jalasa A_ilayohi, like xalaA mEh and xlA Alyh, signify the same; i. e. He sat with him: or the latter, he sat by him; like “ assedit ei. ”] An instance of the inf. n. majolasN is found in a trad., in which it is said, faA_i*aA A^atayotumo A_ilaY Almajolisi faA^aEoTuwA AlT~ariyqa Haq~ahu [But when ye come to sitting, perform ye the duties relating to the road]. (TA.) [The trad. commences thus: A_iy~aAkumo waAljuluwsa EalaY AlT~uruqaAti Beware ye of sitting on the roads: and then, after the words before cited, (in which, however, in my copy of the Jámi' es-Sagheer, instead of Almjls, I find AlmajaAlisi, which is pl. of Almajolisu,) it is added that the duties thus alluded to are the lowering of the eyes, the putting away or aside what is hurtful or annoying, the returning of salutations, the enjoining of that which is good, and the forbidding of that which is evil.] ― -b2- jalasati Alr~axamapu (tropical:) The aquiline vulture lay upon its breast on the ground; syn. javamat: a saying applied to him who is of the seceders. (A, TA.) [See also qaEada.] ― -b3- jalasa also signifies (assumed tropical:) It (a thing, as, for instance, a plant,) remained, or continued. (AHn, TA.) ― -b4- Also, (aor.
jalisa
, inf. n. jalosN, TA,) He came to Aljalos, (TA,) or [the high country called] Nejd: (T, S, A, TA:) and in like manner said of a cloud; it came to Nejd. (TA.)

3 jAlshu jAls jAlsh jAlsp
, inf. n. mujaAlasapN and jilaAsN, [He sat with him.] (TA.) You say, laA tujaAliso mano laA tujaAniso [Sit not with him with whom thou wilt not be congenial]. (A, TA.) And kariymu Aln~iHaAsi Tay~iybu AljilaAsi [Generous in origin, or disposition; pleasant to sit with;] is said of a man. (TA.)

4 Ajlshu A^jls A^jlsh Ajlsh Ajlsp
[He seated him; made him to sit: or he made him to sit up]: (S, K, TA:) he gave him place, or settled him, (mak~anahu,) in sitting. (TA.)

6 tjAslwA tjAslwA
[They sat together; one with another;] (S, A, TA;) fiY AlmajaAlisi [in the sittingplaces]. (S.)

10 Astjlshu Astjlsh Astjlsp
[He asked him, or desired him, to sit: or to sit up.]. You say, raA=niY qaAy^imFA faA@sotajolasaniY [He saw me standing, and he asked me, or desired me, to sit]: (A, TA:) but this is at variance with what we have mentioned in the beginning of the art., respecting the distinction [between jalasa and qaEada]. (TA.)

jalosN jls
Rugged ground or land: (S, K:) this is the primary signification. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also, app., Elevated ground or land:] a place elevated and hard: or, as some say, a tract of land extending widely. (Ham p. 688.) ― -b3- [And hence,] Aljalosu What is elevated above the gawor [or low country]: (TA:) applied especially to the country of Nejd. (T, S, M, K.) ＝ -A2- [Persons sitting: or sitting up:] a quasi-pl. n., accord. to Sb, or a pl., accord. to Akh, of jaAlisN↓: said to be used as sing. and pl. and fem. and masc.; but this assertion is of no account: (ISd, L:) or the people of a majolis: (Lh, ISd, L, K:) [juluwsN↓ is also a pl. of jaAlisN↓; like as bukiY~N, originally bukuwYN, is of baAki: or it is an inf. n. used as an epithet: see jaAvK:)] you say qawomN juluwsN [a company of men sitting: or sitting up]. (S.) [See also majolisN.] ― -b2- Also A woman who sits in the finaA=' [or court of the house], not quitting it: (K:) or she who is of noble rank (K, TA) among her people. (TA.)

jilosN jls
: see jaliysN, in two places.

jalosapN jlsh jlsp
A single sitting: or sitting up. (Msb.)

jilosapN jlsh jlsp
A mode or manner, (TA,) kind, (Msb,) or state, (S, A, Msb,) of sitting: or of sitting up. (S, * A, * Msb, K. *) You say, huwa Hasanu Aljilosapi [He has a good mode, &c., of sitting]. (A, Msb, K.)

julasapN jlsh jlsp
A man (S) who sits much; sedentary. (S, K.)

juluwsN jlws
: see jalosN.

jaliysN jlys
(S, A, Msb, K) and jil~iysN↓ (TA, as found in a copy of the K, [but this is an intensive form,]) and jilosN↓ (S, A, K) A companion with whom one sits: (A, Msb, K:) fem. of the first with p: (TA:) and pl. [of the same] julasaA='u (A, K) and [irreg., being by rule pl. of jaAlisN,] jul~aAsN. (K.) You say, huwa jilosiY↓ and jaliysiY [He is my companion with whom I sit]; like as you say, huwa xidoniY and xadiyniY. (S.)

jil~iysN jlys
: see jaliysN.

jaAlisN jAls
: see jalosN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A man, and a cloud, coming to [the high country called] Nejd. (TA.) You say, raA^ayotuhumo yaEoduwna jaAlisiyna I saw them running, coming to Nejd. (A, TA.)

majolasN mjls
: see 1: ― -b2- and see majolisN.

majolisN mjls
A sitting-place; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓with p; (Fr, Lh, Sgh, K;) similar to makaAnN and makaAnapN: (Sgh, TA:) [a place where persons sit together and converse; a sitting-room:] a thing upon which one sits: (MF:) some make a strange distinction between majolisN and majolasN↓, asserting the former to be applied to the chamber or house (bayot) [in which people sit]; and the latter, to a place of honour upon which it is forbidden to sit without permission; but the former is the only correct form of the two: (MF, TA:) pl. majaAlisu. (S, Msb.) You say, Aurozuno fiY majolisika and majolisatika↓ [Be thou grave] in thy sitting-place. (Fr, Sgh.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The people of a majolis; (Msb, TA;) elliptical, for A^aholu majolisK: (TA:) an assembly, or a company of men, sitting [together]: (Th, TA:) not well explained as being, with the article Al, syn. with Aln~aAsu: (TA:) persons sitting, or sitting up. (A, TA.) [See also jalosN.] You say, AinofaD~a Almajolisu (assumed tropical:) [The assembly of persons sitting together broke up]. (Msb.) And raA^ayotuhumo majolisFA I saw them sitting. (A, TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) An oration or a discourse, or an exhortation, (xuTobapN A^awo EiZapN,) delivered in a majolis; like maqaAmapN. (Mtr, in the Preface to Har.) ― -b4- It is also used in the same manner as HaDorap and janaAb: you say majolisu fulaAnK [meaning (assumed tropical:) The object of resort, with whom others sit and converse, such a one]; like HaDorapu fulaAnK. (Kull p. 146.) [See arts. HDr and jnb. But this usage I believe to be post-classical.] ― -b5- [Also (assumed tropical:) A stool; meaning, an evacuation. So in medical books.]

majolisapN mjls mjlsh mjlsp
: see majolisN, in two places.

jalosadN jlsd
and Aljalosadu: see art. jsd

1 jalafahu jlf jlfh jlfp
, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jalufa
, inf. n. jalofN, (S, Msb,) He peeled, pared, stripped, or scraped, it off; (S, Msb, K, TA;) namely, a thing; (TA;) as, for instance, (S, TA,) the mud, or clay, (S, Msb, TA,) from the head of a [jar of the kind called] dan~. (S, TA.) You say also, jalafa Zuforahu Eano A_iSobaEihi He stripped off his nail from his finger. (Lth, TA.) And accord. to some, jalofN signifies The scraping off, or stripping off, the skin with somewhat of the flesh: and the act of pulling, or drawing, out, or up, or off; or displacing. (TA.) ― -b2- Also i. q. jarafahu [He took away, carried away, or removed, the whole of it, or the greater part of it, or much of it; or he swept it away]: (K:) or, as some say, jalofN signifies a more intensive and more exterminating action than jarofN. (TA.) ― -b3- And He cut it off; (S;) or pulled it, or plucked it, out, or up; or eradicated, or uprooted, it; (K;) and exterminated it; (S, K;) as also Ajtlfhu↓. (K.) ― -b4- jalafahu biAls~ayofi He struck him with the sword: (K:) or he cut, or cut a piece from, or cut in pieces, his flesh [with the sword]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- julifa Aln~abaAtu The herbage was eaten to the uttermost. (TA.) ― -b6- julifa fiY maAlihi jalofapF He suffered the loss of somewhat of his property, or cattle. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jalifa, aor.
jalafa
, inf. n. jalafN and jalaAfapN, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, rude in disposition, or in make; coarse, or churlish. (K.)

2 jal~afatohu Als~inuwna jlfth Alsnwn
The years of drought, or barrenness, or dearth, destroyed his cattle. (S.) And jal~afato kaHolu, (S,) or kaHolN, (K,) The year of drought, or barrenness, or dearth, exterminated the cattle. (K.) And A^amowaAlahumo Ajtlfto↓ [It destroyed their cattle] is also said of a year of great drought, or barrenness, or dearth. (S.) And Ald~ahoru Ajtlfhu↓ Time, or fortune, or misfortune, destroyed his property, or cattle. (TA.)

4 Ajlf A^jlf Ajlf jlf
He (a man) removed the julaAf [or clay] from the head of the [jar called] xunobujap [i. q. dan~]. (IAar, K.)

8 A_ijotalafa
see 1; and see also 2, in two places.

jilofN jlf
A [jar of the kind called] dan~: (M, K:) or an empty dan~: (AO, S, Msb, K:) this is said (S, Msb) by AO (S) to be the primary signification of the word: (S, Msb:) or the lower part of a dan~ when it is broken: (ISd, Sgh, K:) and a [receptacle such as is called] Zarof, (AA, S, Hr, Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, Tarof,]) and wiEaA=', (AA, S, Msb, K,) of any kind, (AA, S, Msb,) such as a saddle-bag, or pair of saddlebags, and a sack, in which bread or other food is kept: (Hr, TA:) pl. [of mult.] juluwfN (S, M, Msb) and [of pauc.] A^ajolaAfN and A^ajolufN, which last is rare. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A [skin of the kind called] ziq~ without head and without legs. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- And A skinned animal, (AO, S,) or a skinned sheep or goat, (K,) of which the belly has been taken forth, (AO, S, K,) and the head and legs of which have been cut off; (K;) the body of a skinned sheep or goat, without head and without belly and without legs: or, as some say, a body of any kind without a head upon it: (L:) or a beast without fat, and without back [to bear], and without belly to conceive: (IAth, TA:) or the skin of a sheep or goat, and of a camel: (As, Msb:) pl. A^ajolaAfN (Sb, L) and sometimes A^ajolufN: (Sb, TA:) and [it is also said that] A^ajolaAfu Al$~aApi signifies the shinned sheep or goat that is without head and without legs and without belly. (S, Msb.) ― -b4- Hence, i. e., from AjlAf Al$Ap, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) Rude in disposition or in make; coarse, or churlish; (S, M, Msb, K;) as also jaliyfN↓; (K;) meaning that the person so termed is empty, without intellect: (M, TA:) applied to a DesertArab, (S,) or to an Arab: (so in a copy of the Msb:) or it is so applied as though meaning one with his skin; not having assumed the gentle and soft habits of the people of the towns or villages or cultivated lands; for when one does this, it is as though he pulled off his skin and clad himself with another: (Msb:) or (tropical:) stupid, foolish, or unsound in intellect; likened to a skinned sheep or goat because of the weakness of his intellect. (IAth, TA.) ― -b5- Also Thick, or coarse, dry bread: or bread not rendered savoury by anything eaten therewith: or the edge [of a cake] of bread. (K.) [See also jilofapN.] ＝ -A2- A male palm-tree, (Lth, K,) with the spadix of which the female palm-tree is fecundated: (Lth, TA:) pl. juluwfN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A certain well-known bird. (K.)

jalofapN jlf jlfh jlfp
[inf. n. of un. of julifa, q. v.]. ＝ -A2- See also jilofapN.

julofapN jlf jlfh jlfp
A part of a skin that is peeled, pared, stripped, or scraped, off. (L, K.)

jilofapN jlf jlfh jlfp
A broken piece of dry bread, (K, TA,) thick, or coarse, (TA,) and without anything to
render it savoury: (K, TA:) pl. jilafN. (TA.) [See jilofN, of which it may be regarded as the n. un.] ― -b2- A piece of anything: (Sgh, K:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b3- The portion of a reed for writing that is between its maboraY [or place where the paring is commenced] and its point; as also jalofapN↓. (K.)

julaAfN jlAf
Clay; such as is put upon the head of the [jar called] xunobujap. [See 4.] (IAar, K.)

jaliyfN jlyf
Peeled, pared, stripped, or scraped, off; as also majoluwfN↓. (K.) It is said by some that the last word in the following saying of Keys Ibn-El-Khateem,
hazolaY jaraAdi A^ajowaAfuhu julofu
kaA^an~a lab~aAtihaA tabad~adahaA
is pl. of the former in this sense: but accord. to ISk, [the meaning of the verse is, As though emaciated locusts without heads and without legs occupied the two sides, or the whole, of the part of her breast where the necklace lay; for he says that] the poet likens the ornaments upon her lab~ap to locusts without heads and without legs. (TA.) rijolN jaliyfapN [An excoriated leg]. (TA.) ― -b2- jaliyfapN [or sanapN jaliyfapN] A year that destroys the cattle; (S, * K;) as also jaAlifapN↓: (S, K:) any bane, or calamity, that destroys the cattle: pl. jalaAy^ifu and julufN and julofN. (TA.) You say, A^aSaAbatohumo jaliyfapN EaZiymapN A great destruction of their cattle befell them. (S, TA.) And sinuwna jalaAy^ifu and julufN and julofN Years that destroy the cattle. (K.) And jalaAy^ifu also signifies Torrents. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jilofN.

jaAlifN jAlf
[act. part. n. of jalafa]. ― -b2- jaAlifapN [or $aj~apN jaAlifapN] A wound of the head that peels off the skin with the flesh: (S, K:) or that peels off the skin but does not penetrate into the interior. (Msb.) And TaEonapN jaAlifapN A spear-wound, or the like, that does not penetrate into the interior; (S, K;) opposed to jaAy^ifapN. (S.) ― -b3- zamaAnN jaAy^ifN i. q. jaArifN [A time, or season, that sweeps away, or destroys, the cattle]. (TA.) See also jaliyfN.

mujal~afN mjlf
Having a portion, or portions, taken from its sides. (S, K.) ― -b2- Having somewhat thereof remaining. (S, K.) So explained by Abu-l-Ghowth as occurring in the saying of ElFarezdak,
waEaD~u zamaAna yaA A@bona marowaAna lamo yadaEo
mina AlmaAli A_il~aA musoHatFA A^awo mujal~afu
i. e., [And a biting of fortune, O Ibn-Marwán, left not, of the cattle, save] such as were destroyed, or they were such as had only a remnant remaining. (S.) ― -b3- A man (S) whose cattle have been destroyed by years of drought, or barrenness, or dearth. (S, K.) And qawomN mujotalafuwna↓ A people, or party, whose cattle have been destroyed by a year of drought or the like. (S, TA.)

majoluwfN mjlwf
: see jaliyfN. ― -b2- Also A skinned sheep or goat. (L.) ― -b3- xubozN majoluwfN Bread burnt by the oven, (K, TA,) so that its outer parts stick to it. (TA.)

qawomN mujotalafuwna qwm mjtlfwn
: see mujal~afN.

mutajal~ifN mtjlf
Lean, or emaciated; (K;) as also mutajar~ifN. (TA.)

jawaAliqu jwAlq
(S, M, MA, Mgh, K) and juwaAliqN (IAar, M, K) and jiwaAliqN (K) A sack; in Pers. juwaAlo; (MA, PS;) [not so well rendered in the KL by xurojiyno, which means a saddle-bag or a pair of saddle-bags, like the Arabic xurojN;] a certain kind of wiEaA='i [or receptacle], (S, M, K,) [for corn &c.,] well known: (M, K:) it has a loop, into which is inserted a stick, or piece of wood, called $iZaAZN, (S and K in art. $Z,) this being also inserted into the loop of another jwAlq, when they are bound upon the camel: (K * and TA in that art.:) or it has two loops, one of which is inserted into the other, (S and K voce qaTaba,) [and then the stick is put through,] on the occasion of putting it on a camel: (TA ibid.:) the word is arabicized; (M, TA;) said to be from kwAlh, (TA,) or kwAlk, (KL,) but correctly from JwAlh, which is Pers.: (TA:) the pl. is jawaAliqu (S, MA, Mgh, K) and jawaAliyqu, (Sb, S, MA, Mgh, K,) the latter occurring in poetry, (TA,) and juwaAliqaAtN (S, K) was sometimes used, (S,) but this is disallowed by Sb. (S, M.) The saying [of a rájiz], cited by Th,
A^uHib~u maAwiy~apa Hub~FA SaAdiqaA
Hub~a A^abiY AljuwaAliqi AljuwaAliqaA
[I love Máweeyeh with a true love; with the love of the owner (lit. father) of the sack for the sack;] means that the speaker had a vehement love for the food, or wheat, that was in his jwAlq. (M.) Another says,
yaA Hab~a*aA maA fiY AljawaAliyqi Als~uwdo
mino xu$okanaAni wasawiyqK maqonuwdo
[O, lovely is what is in the black sacks, of biscuit and meal of parched barley sweetened with sugarcandy!]. (S.)

1 jalamahu jlm jlmh jlmp
, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jalima
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jalomN, (S, Msb,) He cut it, or cut it off; (S, Msb, K;) [like jaramahu.] ― -b2- He shore it, or sheared it; namely, wool, (Msb, K,) and hair, with the jalamaAni, (Msb,) or jalam. (TA.) And jalamotu minohu I took [or clipped somewhat] from it; namely, wool; like jaramotu. (S in art. jrm.) And jalama Al$~aApa He shore, or sheared, the sheep or goat. (Har p. 190.) ― -b3- jalama Aljazuwra, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He took the flesh that was on the bones of the slaughtered camel; (S, K;) as also Ajtlmhu↓. (K.)

8 A_ijotalama
see what precedes.

jilomN jlm
The fat of the varob [or thin integument that covers the stomach and bowels or intestines] of a sheep or goat. (K.)

jalamN jlm
The instrument with which one shears (S, K, TA) wool and hair: (TA:) and jalamaAni signifies a pair thereof; a pair of shears: (S:) or jalamN and jalamaAni signify alike, i. q. miqoraADN; like as one says miqoraADN and miqoraADaAni, and qalamN and qalamaAni: and jalamaAnN↓ is also allowable, as a sing.; (Msb;) authorized by Ks; (TA;) and in like manner, qalamaAnN. (Msb. [But see miqoraADN.]) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The moon; (Az, K;) as also jayolamN↓: (K:) or the [new moon, or moon when it is termed] hilaAl: (K:) likened to the jalam [as meaning the blade of a pair of shears]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also, probably,] (assumed tropical:) A certain mark of camels, made with a hot iron. (Ibn-Habeeb, K.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] (assumed tropical:) The tick, or ticks. (K.) ― -b5- And, accord. to some, as being likened to these, because of their smallness, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The sheep of Mekkeh: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or certain sheep with long and hairless legs, found at Et-Táïf. (K.) And (assumed tropical:) The male of the gazelle, and of the sheep: pl. jilaAmN. (K.) And (assumed tropical:) A kid: (Kr, K:) pl. as above. (S, TA.)

jalomapN jlm jlmh jlmp
The whole of a thing; (S, K;) as also julomapN↓ and jalamapN↓. (K.) You say, A^axa*otu Al$~aYo'a bijalomatihi I took the thing wholly. (S.)

julomapN jlm jlmh jlmp
: see what next precedes.

jalamapN jlm jlmh jlmp
A skinned sheep or goat (S, K) without the intestines and without the legs, (S,) [or] when the shanks and the redundant parts have gone. (K.) And the whole flesh of a slaughtered camel. (S.) ― -b2- See also jalomapN.

jalamaAnN jlmAn
: see jalamN.

julaAmapN jlAmh jlAmp
Shorn wool. (K.)

jul~aAmN jlAm
Shorn he-goats. (K.)

jayolamN jylm
: see jalamN.

majoluwmN mjlwm
Cut, or cut off. (Msb.) ― -b2- A shorn sheep or goat. (K, * TA.)

mujotalamN mjtlm
A bone having the flesh cut off with the jalam (TA in art. knt.) Quasi

jalomaHa jlmH
: see Q. Q. 1. in art. jlH.

jalomadN jlmd
and julomuwdN↓ Rock: (S, K:) or a rock; or mass, or piece, of rock: (M:) or a round stone: (Mgh, Msb:) or [a stone] smaller than what is termed janodal, of such a size as that which is thrown with a ballista: (L:) or a great stone: (Har p. 95:) or the latter word, [a stone] like the head of a kid; or less, such as may be carried in the hand by grasping its side but over which the two hands will not meet, with which date-stones &c. are bruised, or brayed: (ISh:) [pl. of the former, jalaAmida; and of the latter, jalaAmiydu. Accord. to the Mgh and Msb, the m is an augmentative letter; but most of the lexicographers regard it as radical.] ― -b2- [Hence,] ra$aHa jalomaduhu, said of one known to be a niggard, meaning, (assumed tropical:) He gave something. (Har p. 95.) ― -b3- And A^aloqaY Ealayohi jalaAmiydahu (assumed tropical:) He threw his weight (viqalahu)
upon him. (K. [See AlqY Elyh mavaAqiylahu, voce mivoqaAlN.]) ― -b4- Also jalomadN, (L,) or jilomidN↓, (K,) A mass of rock rising out of shallow water. (IAar, L, K.) ― -b5- And the former, (assumed tropical:) A strong man; and so jalomadapN↓: (K:) or a man having a strong voice; and so julomudN↓. (L.) ＝ -A2- Also, jalomadN, Many camels: (S:) or camels composing a large herd: or camels advanced in years; as also julomuwdN↓: (K:) and sheep exceeding in number a hundred: (L, K:) you say DaA^onN jalomadN. (L.) ― -b2- And Oxen, or cows: (L:) and the same word, (K,) or jalomadapN↓, (AA, L,) a single ox or cow. (AA, L, K.)

julomadN jlmd
: see above.

jilomidN jlmd
: see above.

jalomadapN jlmd jlmdh jlmdp
applied to land (A^aroDN) Stony: (K:) and jalaAmidu is [its pl.,] like jaraAwilu. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jalomadN, in two places.

julomuwdN jlmwd
: see jalomadN, in two places.

jul~anaArN jlnAr
The flower of the pomegranate: an arabicized word, from GulonaAro, (K,) which is Persian, composed of Gulo “ a flower, ” and naAro “ a pomegranate. ” (MF.) It is said that whoever swallows three grains of it, of the smallest that may be, (K,) on the condition of his taking them with his mouth from the tree, before their opening, at sunrise, on a Wednesday, (Tedhkiret Dáwood, TA,) will not have ophthalmia in that year. (K.)

1 jaliha jl jlh jlp
, aor.
jalaha
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. jalahN, (Sudot;, * Msb, TA,) He was, or became, bald in the fore part of the head: (S, K:) or in the greater part of his head. (Msb.) [The latter seems to be the correct meaning: see jalahN below.] ― -b2- jalihato saAHatuhu His court, or yard, was, or became, vacant, or void. (JK.) ＝ -A2- jalaha, (S, K,) aor.
jalaha
, (K,) inf. n. jalohN, (TA,) He uncovered a thing; or removed it [from a thing that it covered or concealed]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- He raised the turban, while folding it, from the side of his forehead (Eano jabiynihi), (K, TA,) [like AijotalaY,] and from the fore part of his head. (TA.) ― -b3- He removed the pebbles from a place. (S, K.) ― -b4- He turned back a person from a difficult, or hard, thing or affair. (K.)

jalahN jl jlh jlp
, (JK, S,) or jalohapN↓, (K,) Baldness in the fore part of the head; (S, K;) which is the beginning of SalaEN; like jalaHN: (S:) or baldness of the greater part of the head; (Msb;) more than jalaHN, (JK,) and more than SalaEN, which is more than jalaHN. (Msb in art. jlH.)

jalohapN jlhh jlhp
: see jalahu. ＝ -A2- Also The part that faces one of the brows, or brinks, or edges, of a valley: (S:) or the side of a valley; (K, TA;) the bank, or border, thereof: (TA:) or elevated parts in the interior, or lower part, of a valley, rising above the water-course, so that, when the valley flows with water, the water does not reach them: (ISh, TA:) and, some say, the mouth of a valley: and some, a part of a valley uncovered by the torrents, and so made apparent: (TA:) and [the dual] jalohataAni, (JK, M, TA,) or jalohataA waAdK, (S,) the two sides, or borders, of a valley, (S, M, TA,) when there is in them hardness: (JK, M, TA:) occurring in a trad., or, as some relate it, jalohamataAni↓, with an augmentative m: (TA:) pl. jilaAhN. (S.) ― -b2- A great round rock. (JK, K.) ― -b3- A large [hill, or the like, such as is called] qaArapN; as also jalohamapN↓, with an augmentative m. (TA.) ― -b4- The place of alighting and abiding of a people, or company of men: (JK, K, TA:) and a yard, or wide space, in front, or extending from the sides, of their dwelling. (JK.) ― -b5- And A meadow in which water collects and stagnates: pl. as above. (JK.) ＝ -A3- Dates, (K, TA,) of which the stones have been picked out, (TA,) macerated and mashed with milk, (K, * TA,) then given to drink to women; (TA;) having a fattening property; (K, TA;) as also jaliyhapN↓. (K.)

jalohamapN jlhmh jlhmp
: see jalohapN, in two places.

jalahiy~apN jlhyh jlhyp
A mode of wearing the turban, in which the jabiyn [or side of the forehead] is uncovered, so that the part where the hair grows is seen. (JK, Sgh.)

jaliyhapN jlyhh jlyhp
A place from which the pebbles have been removed. (JK, S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also jalohapN, last sentence.

A^ajolahu *
Bald in the fore part of the head; (S;) i. q. A^ajolaHu: (TA:) or [it denotes more than the latter; meaning] bald in the greater part of the head: fem. jalohaA='u: pl. julohN. (Msb.) [See jalahN.] ― -b2- Large in the forehead, having the places of growth of the hair receding. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A bull having no horn; (Ks, JK, S, K;) like A^ajolaHu. (Ks, S.)

majoluwhN mjlwh mjlwp mjly
A tent, or house, or chamber, (bayotN,) in which is neither door nor curtain. (JK, K.)

julaAhiqN jlAhq
Bullets, syn. bunoduqN, (S, Msb, K,) or rounded things, (En-Nadr, TA,) made of clay, (En-Nadr, Msb, TA,) which one shoots [from a cross-bow]: (K:) n. un. with p: (En-Nadr, Msb, TA:) a Persian word, arabicized; (Msb;) in Persian julaho, meaning “ a ball of thread; ” pl. julahaA; applied also to “ a weaver; ” (S K;) i. e., jlhA is so applied. (TA.) Hence, qawosu AljulaAhiqi [The cross-bow for shooting bullets]. (S, Msb.)

superEntry.head: Quasi jlhm
superEntry.entry:
jalohamapN jlhmh jlhmp
: see art. jlh.

1 jalaA jl jlA
, (S, Mgh, Msb,) [aor.
jaluwa
,] inf. n. jalaA='N, (Msb,) It (a thing, and (assumed tropical:) an affair, or a case, Mgh, or (assumed tropical:) information, or tidings, Msb,) was, or became, clear, unobscured, exposed to view, displayed, laid open, disclosed, or uncovered, (Mgh, Msb,) llin~aAsi to men, or the people; (Msb;) as also tjl~Y↓, said of a thing: (S, Mgh, Msb:) it ((assumed tropical:) information, or tidings, S, Msb, or (assumed tropical:) an affair, or a case, Mgh,) was, or became, apparent, or plainly apparent, overt, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, plain, obvious, or evident, (S, Mgh, Msb,) liY to me, (S,) or liln~aAsi to men, or the people. (Msb.) One says, Al$~amosu tjl~t↓ The sun became unobscured, or exposed to view, and ceased to be eclipsed. (TA from a trad.) Er-Rághib says that waAln~ahaAri A_i*aA tajal~aY↓ is sometimes by the thing itself; as in the phrase [in the Kur xcii. 2], falam~aA tajal~aY rab~uhu lilojabali [By the day when it becometh clear, &c.]: and sometimes, by the case, and the action; as in the saying [in the Kur vii. 139], falam~aA tajal~aY rab~uhu lilojabali [And when his Lord became manifested to the mountain]: Zj says that the meaning in this instance is, appeared, and so say the Sunnees; El-Hasan says that the meaning is, tjl~Y biAln~uwri AlEaro$i [became manifested by light, the light of the empyrean]. (TA.) ― -b2- jalaA, [aor.
jaluwa
,] inf. n. jalaA='N (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jalowN; (K;) and AjlY↓; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) He, (a man, Msb,) or they, (a company of men, Mgh, Msb,) went forth, or emigrated, (S, Mgh, Msb,) Eani Albaladi from the country, or town, (S, Msb,) and Eano A^awoTaAnihimo from their homes: (S, Mgh:) [like jal~a:] or they (a company of men) dispersed themselves, or became dispersed, Eani AlmawoDiEi, and minohu, from the place: (K:) or jlA means, in consequence of fear: and AjlY↓, in consequence of drought: (AZ, K:) or manozilahumo A^ajolawoA↓ signifies they left their place of abode in consequence of fear; the verb in this case being trans. by itself: but if they have left for some other reason than fear, you say, Eano manozilihimo: (Msb:) accord. to IAar, jalaA signifies he fled, being driven away, from his home. (TA.) [See also 12.] ― -b3- jaliYa, aor.
jalawa
, inf. n. jalFA, He had that degree of baldness which is termed jalFA↓; (K;) i. e. baldness of the fore part of the head; (S, K;) like jalahN: (S:) or baldness of half of the head; (S, K;) which is the beginning of SalaEN: (S:) or baldness less than what is termed SalaEN. (K.) And jalA Aljabiyni, inf. n. jalFA, signifies the same as jaliYa [The part above the temple became bald]. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ＝ -A2- jalaAhu, [aor.
jaluwa
, inf. n., app., jilaA='N, or perhaps jalaA='N, but the former seems to be indicated by what follows;] (S, Mgh, Msb;) and jl~Ahu↓; (MA;) He made it, or rendered it, clear, or unobscured; exposed it to view, displayed it, laid it open, disclosed it, or uncovered it; (S, Mgh, MA;) namely, a thing: (S, Mgh:) he made it, or rendered it, apparent, or plainly apparent, overt, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, plain, obvious, or evident; (S, Mgh, Msb, MA;) namely, (assumed tropical:) an affair, (Mgh,) or (assumed tropical:) information, or tidings. (Msb.) You say, jalaA AlEaruwsa, inf. n. jilaA='N and jilowapN (S, Msb, K) and jalowapN (Msb, K) and julowapN; (K;) and AjtlAhA↓; (S, Msb, K;) He displayed the bride, EalaY baEolihaA to her husband: (K:) or he looked at the bride
displayed: (S:) and you say also, juliyato EalaY zawojihaA (TA) She mas shown to her husband, and he looked at her displayed: (Har p. 30:) and jalaAhaA zawojuhaA Her husband presented, or gave, to her a female slave (S, K) or some other thing at the time of her being displayed to him; as also jl~AhA↓: (K:) and jalati AlmaA$iTapu AlEaruwsa The female hairdresser adorned the bride [to display her to her husband]. (TA.) You also say, jalaA fulaAnN AlA^amora (tropical:) Such a one displayed, discovered, disclosed, revealed, or manifested, the affair, or case; as also jl~Ahu↓, and jalaA Eanohu: (K, * TA:) or jalaA fulaAnFA AlA^amori he displayed, discovered, &c., to such a one the affair, or case; as also jl~Ah↓ [i. e. jl~Ahu AlA^amora], and jalaA Eanohu [i. e. jlA Enh AlA^amora or jlA fulaAnFA Eani AlA^amori]. (So accord. to the CK and my MS. copy of the K. [The reading in the TA is, in my opinion, preferable to the latter.]) And Als~aAEapa Aall~`hu yujal~iY↓ (assumed tropical:) God will make manifest the hour, or time of the resurrection; or will make it to appear. (K in art. jlY: [but it belongs to the present art.:]) so in the Kur vii. 186. (TA.) And Eano nafosihi huwa yujal~iY↓ (assumed tropical:) He declares, or explains, his mind. (S.) ― -b2- jalawotu Als~ayofa, inf. n. jilaA='N, (S, Msb, K, [in the CK jalA', but it is]) with kesr, (S, Msb,) and jalowN, (K,) I removed, or cleared off, the rust from the sword; (Msb;) I polished, or furbished, the sword; (S, K;) and AlmiroA=pa the mirror; (K;) and the like; (TA;) [as, for instance,] AlfiD~apa the silver; and so jalayotuhaA. (K in art. jlY.) And jalawotu baSariY biAlkuHoli [I cleared my sight with collyrium]: (S:) [whence,] jalaA He applied collyrium to his eye or eyes. (IAar, TA.) And jalawotu ham~iY Ean~iY (tropical:) I removed my anxiety, or caused it to depart, from me: (S, K, * TA: *) and Eanohu Alham~a AjlY↓ (assumed tropical:) He removed, or cleared away, from him anxiety. (Lth, TA.) And jalaA A@ll~`hu Eanohu AlmaraDa (assumed tropical:) God removed from him the disease. (TA.) ― -b3- jalaAhumo, and AjlAhm↓, (S, Mgh,) or jalaAhu, and AjlAhu↓, (Msb, K,) and AjtlAhu↓, (K,) He, (a man, S, Msb, or the Sultán, Mgh,) or it, (drought, K,) caused them, or him, to go forth, or emigrate; or expelled them, or him; or drove them, or him, forth; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) [from their homes, or from his home.] And jalaA Aln~aHoli, inf. n. jilaA='N, or jalaA='N, (accord. to different copies of the K,) and jlwp [thus written without any syll. signs]; and AjtlAhA↓; (TA;) He smoked [out] the bees, in order to collect the honey; (K;) he drove away the bees by means of smoke. (TA.)

2 jl~Y jl jlY jly jlyy
: see 1, in six places. ＝ -A2- Also, inf. n. tajoliyapN and tajoliY~N, He (a hawk, or falcon,) raised his head, and looked, (K, TA,) seeing the prey: (TA:) or he (a hawk) closed his eyes, and then opened them, in order to see more clearly. (Ibn- Hamzeh, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] jl~Y bibaSarihi, inf. n. tajoliyapN, He cast his eyes (S, K) like the hawk looking at the prey. (S.) ＝ -A3- [jl~Y is also mentioned (in Har p. 161), on the authority of Mtr, as signifying He, or it, outstripped; from Almujal~iY meaning “ the first of the horses in a race; ” but as being not known in this sense on any other authority.]

3 jaAlayotuhu biAlA^amori *
, inf. n. mujaAlaApN, I acted openly with him in the affair; as also jaAlaHotuhu. (S.)

4 AjlY A^jl A^jlY A^jly A^jlyy AjlY Ajly jlA jlY |jl |jly |jlyy
as an intrans. v.: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- A^ajolawo Eani Alqatiyli They cleared themselves away, or removed, from the slain person. (S, Mgh, Msb, TA.) ― -b3- AjlY yaEoduw He hastened, running: (K:) or hastened somewhat, running: (TA:) or AjlY signifies he became distant, or remote, and hastened. (So accord. to some copies of the K, where we find waA^ajolaY baEuda wa A^asoraEa instead of wa A^ajolaY yaEoduw A^asoraEa.) ＝ -A2- As a trans. v.: see 1, in four places.

5 tjl~Y A^jl A^jlY jl jlA jlY tjlY tjly
: see 1, in three places: ― -b2- and see also 7. ＝ -A2- tjl~Y Al$~aYo'a He looked at the thing, (K in art. jlY,) standing upon a higher position. (TA.) [See also 8.]

6 tajaAlayonaA tjAlynA
Our states, or conditions, became disclosed to each other; the state, or condition, of each of us to the other. (S.)

7 AnjlY A^njl A^njly A^njlyy AnjlY Anjly {njlY
It became removed, or cleared away; said of anxiety, (S, K, * TA,) and of an affair [&c.]; as also tjl~Y↓. (K, * TA.) You say, AnjlY Eanohu Alham~u Anxiety became removed, or cleared away, from him, (S,) kamaA tanojaliY AlZ~ulomapu like as the darkness becomes removed, or cleared away. (TA.)

8 AjtlAhu AjtlAh AjtlAp {jtlAh {jtlY
He looked at him, or it. (K.) [See also 5.] Hence, AjtlY AlEaruwsa, explained above: see 1. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1 in two other places, last two sentences. ― -b3- Aijotalayotu AlEimaAmapa Eano raA^osiY I raised the turban, while folding it, from the side of my forehead (Eano jabiyniY): (S:) [like jalahotuhaA.] ＝ -A2- AjtlY It became polished, or furbished; said of a sword [&c.]. (TA.)

12 AjlwlY AjlwlY Ajlwly
He went forth, or emigrated, from one country, or town, to another. (IAar, K.) [See also 1.]

Aibonu jalaA Abn jlA
(tropical:) A man who is well known, celebrated, or notable; (Mgh;) of whom it is said, jalaA AlA^umuwra, i. e. he has made affairs clear, unobscured, or manifest; (S, Mgh;) or jalaA A^amoruhu, i. e. his case has become clear, unobscured, or manifest: (Mgh:) or one whose case is clear, apparent, plainly apparent, or manifest; (K, TA;) as also Aibonu A^ajolaY↓: (K:) applied to a man who is upon an elevated and conspicuous place; and applied by El-Hajjáj to himself, as meaning that he was one whom every one knew: (TA:) and also, (K,) for this reason, (TA,) the name of a certain man, (S, K,) well known, (K,) of the Benoo-Leyth, who was a person of great daring. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Soheym Ibn-Wetheel Er-Riyáhee, (TA,)
A^anaA A@bonu jalaA waTal~aAEu Alv~anaAyaA
mataY A^aDiEa AlEimaAmapa taEorifuwniY
[I am a man well known, celebrated, or notable, &c.; and he who rises to eminences, or who is accustomed to embark in, or surmount, lofty and difficult things: when I put down the turban, ye will know me]. (S, TA.) Sb says, (TA,) jlA in this case is a verb in the pret. tense: 'Eesà Ibn- 'Omar says that when a man is named qatala or Daraba or the like, the word is imperfectly decl.; and he adduces, in evidence, this verse: others say that jlA may be here without tenween because it is imitative of a phrase, as though the poet said, A^anaA A@bonu Al~a*iY yuqaAlu lahu jalaA AlA^umuwri: (S, TA:) accord. to IB, it is without tenween because it is a verb with its agent [implied in it]. (TA.) ― -b2- Accord. to some, it signifies (assumed tropical:) The daybreak, or dawn; (Har p. 498;) and so Aibonu A^ajolaY↓: (TA:) accord. to Hamzeh, (assumed tropical:) the beginning of day: and accord. to some, (assumed tropical:) the moon. (Har ubi suprà)

jalFA jl jlA
: see 1, voce jaliYa: ＝ -A2- and see jilaA='N.

jilFA jl jlA
: see jilaA='N.

jilowapN jlA jlY jlwh jlwp
A female slave, (S, K,) or some other thing, (K,) that is presented, or given, by the husband to his bride at the time of her being displayed to him. (S, * K.) One says, maA jilowatuhaA [What is her bridal present?]; and is answered, “ Such a thing. ” (S.)

jalaA='N jlA='
A thing, an affair, or a case, that is apparent, manifest, plain, or evident. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- And Acknowledgment, or confession: so in the saying of Zuheyr:
faA_in~a AlHaq~a maqoTaEuhu valaAvN
yamiynN A^awo nifaArN A^awo jalaA='N
[For verily the means of deciding the truth are three: an oath, and incongruity of circumstances, and acknowledgment, or confession]: (S:) but Az writes the last word jilaA='↓, with kesr to the j, as meaning an evidence, or a proof, and witnesses; from mujaAlaApN [inf. n. of 3, q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- A^aqamotu Einodahu jalaA='ayawomiY, (K, TA,) or jalaA='a yawomK, (so in some copies of the K,) [I remained with him, or at his abode,] during the whiteness of my, or a, day. (Zj, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

jilaA='N jlA='
: see the paragraph next preceding. ＝ -A2- Also, (S, Mgh, K,) written by El-Muhellebee jalaA='N↓, (TA,) and jalFA↓, which is more correct than the first, (Mgh,) or it is allowable, as also jilFA↓, the former of the last two mentioned on the authority of En-Nahhás, (TA,) Collyrium: (S, K:) or a particular kind thereof, (K, TA,) that clears the sight; (TA;) [i. e.] i. q. A_ivomidN [antimony, or an ore of antimony]; (Mgh, TA;) so called because it clears the sight. (Mgh.) ＝ -A3- maAjilaAw^uhu What is his honourable name, or surname, (S,) or his good surname, (K,) by which he is addressed? (S, K.)

jaliY~N jl jlY jly jlyy
Clear, unobscured, exposed to view, displayed, laid open, disclosed, or uncovered: apparent, or plainly apparent, overt, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, plain, obvious, or evident: (S, Msb, K, TA:) jaAlK thus used has not been heard. (Er-Rághib, TA.) It is applied as an epithet to information, or tidings, (Msb, TA,)
and to analogy, or rule. (TA.) ― -b2- EayonN jaliy~apN A seeing eye. (IB, TA.)

jaliy~apN jl jly jlyh jlyp
Sure information or tidings. (S.) ― -b2- A^axobaraniY Eano jaliy~apN AlA^amori He informed me of the true, or real, state of the affair, or case. (TA.)

dawaA='N jal~aA='N dwA=' jlA='
[A medicine that clears the complexion or skin]. (K voce fuw~apN, &c.)

jiliy~aAnN jly jlyAn
The act of rendering apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident: rendering clear, or unobscured; exposing to view, displaying, laying open, disclosing, or uncovering. (TA.)

jaAlK jAl
Going forth, or emigrating, from his country, or town: [like jaAl~N:] and so jaAliyapN, applied to a company of people; [as also jaAl~apN;] (Msb;) or to people who have gone forth, or emigrated, from their homes; (S;) and particularly to those tributaries, (Mgh, Msb,) namely, certain Jews, (Mgh,) whom 'Omar expelled from the country of the Arabs; (Mgh, Msb;) and afterwards, to such as have the poll-tax imposed upon them, of the people of the Bible, and of the Magians, though not having emigrated from their homes; (Mgh;) [i. e.] the free non-Muslim subjects of a Muslim government; because they were expelled by 'Omar from Arabia; (K;) the word being fem. because denoting a jamaAEap; (Mgh;) and its pl. is jawaAlK. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) jaAliyapN↓ [as a subst.] is applied to The poll-tax that is exacted from the persons last mentioned above; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also jaAl~apN: (S:) first, in this sense, applied to that which was exacted from the people expelled from Arabia by 'Omar. (Msb.) You say, AusotuEomila fulaAnN EalaY AljaAliyapi [Such a one was employed as collector of the poll-tax]. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also jaAy^ilN, in art. jwl.

jaAliyapN jAlyh jAlyp
(as a subst.): see what next precedes.

A^ajolaY *
Having that degree of baldness which is termed jalFA; i. e. baldness of the fore part of the head: or baldness of half of the head; (S, K;) which is the beginning of SalaEN: (S:) or baldness less than what is termed SalaEN: (K:) or baldness of half of the head, and the like: (A'Obeyd, TA:) fem. jalowaA='N. (K.) [See A^ajolaHu.] ― -b2- Beautiful, or handsome, in face, bald in the sides of the forehead. (K.) ― -b3- jabohapN jalowaA='u A wide forehead. (K.) ― -b4- samaA='N jalowaA='N (assumed tropical:) A cloudless sky: (Ks, S, K:) and layolapN jalowaA='u (assumed tropical:) a cloudless, bright, night. (TA.) ― -b5- Aibonu A^ajolaY: see Aibonu jalaA, in two places. ― -b6- Also (i. e. Abn AjlY) (assumed tropical:) The lion. (TA.) ＝ -A2- faEalotuhu mino A^ajolaAka, and A_ijolaAka↓, I did it on account of thee, for thy sake, or because of thee; syn. mino A^ajolika. (K.)

faEalotuhu mino A_ijolaAka fElth mn AjlAk
: see what next precedes.

majolFY mjlY mjly mjlyy
sing. of majaAlK, which signifies The fore parts of the head, which are the [first] places of baldness: (Fr, S:) or what is seen of the head when one fronts the face. (TA.)

mujolK mjl mjly
[act. part. n. of 4. Hence,] faA_im~aA HarobN mujoliyapN wa A_im~aA silomN muxoziyapN And either war that shall cause you to emigrate, or abasing peace. (TA.)

Almujol~iY AlmjlY Almjly mjly
The first of the horses in a race. (K in art. jlY.)

div1.superEntry: jlY Some words are mentioned in the K under this head belonging to art. jlw, q. v.

superEntry.entry:
1 jam~a jm
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
jami3a
, inf. n. jam~N, (Msb,) said of water, (S,) &c., (S, Msb,) It became much, or abundant; (S, Msb;) as also Astjm↓; said of a thing: (TA:) and, said of water, aor.
jamu3a
(S, K) and
jami3a
, (K,) the former of which is of the higher authority, (TA,) inf. n. jumuwmN, (S, Mgh, K,) it became much, or abundant, (S, Mgh, K,) in the well, (S,) and collected (S, K) after it had been drawn from; (S;) as also Astjm~↓. (K.) And jam~uwA They became many. (TA.) ― -b2- jam~ati Albiy^oru, (K,) aor.
jamu3a
and
jami3a
, inf. n. jumuwmN, (TA,) The water of the well returned by degrees, (K, TA,) and became much, or abundant, and collected; (TA;) and Astjm~t↓ signifies the same. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence, jam~ato mavaAbapN jaholihi, a tropical phrase, explained in art. vwb.] ― -b4- jam~a Alkayolu, inf. n. jumaAmN, with damm, The measure became full or filled. (KL. [But only the inf. n. is there mentioned: so that the verb may be jum~a, which see below.]) ― -b5- jam~a Alfarasu, (S, K,) aor.
jamu3a
and
jami3a
, (S, TA,) inf. n. jamaAmN (S, K) and jam~N; (S;) and Astjm~↓; (S;) The horse abstained from covering, (S, K,) so that his seminal fluid (maAw^uhu) collected. (K.) ― -b6- Also, (aor. of the former verb as above, TA, and inf. n. jam~N and jamaAmN, S, K,) The fatigue of the horse went away; (S;) [he recovered his strength after fatigue;] he recovered from his fatigue, being left unridden; (K, TA;) and so A^ajam~a↓ [of which see also the pass. form, below]. (M, K.) ― -b7- [And hence,] jam~a, [inf. n. jamaAmN, q. v. infrà,] He rested; said of a man [as well as of a horse]; (TA;) and so Astjm~↓. (Har p. 324.) ― -b8- Also, said of a bone, (K,) inf. n. jam~N, (TA,) It had much flesh; its flesh became much, or abundant. (K.) ― -b9- Also i. q. EalaA [He, or it, became high, &c.: perhaps said of water in a well]. (T, TA.) ― -b10- Also, inf. n. jumuwmN, He rose (AirotafaEa) in his pace, or going. (TA.) ― -b11- Also, (S, K,) inf. n. jam~N (TA) and jumuwmN, (S, TA,) said of an event, (K,) of the arrival of a person, (S,) It drew near; (S, K;) it came to pass: (S:) and Ajm~↓ signifies the same, (S, Msb, K,) said of an event, of separation from another, (S, TA,) and of an object of want: (TA:) AHm~, [q. v.,] with the unpointed H, in this sense, was not known to As. (TA.) ― -b12- And, said of the naSiY~, and the Sil~iyaAn, [two plants, inf. n. not mentioned,] It attained to the state of having a jum~ap [app. meaning tuft, or flower-bud]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jam~a Alkabo$i, (TA,) or jamimati Al$~aApu, [perhaps a mistranscription for jam~at,] aor.
jama3a
, (Msb,) inf. n. jamamN, (S, Msb, TA,) The ram, (TA,) or sheep or goat, (S, Msb,) was hornless. (S, Msb, TA.) ＝ -A3- jam~ahu, (K,) [aor.
jamu3a
, accord. to rule,] inf. n. jam~N, (TA,) He left it (namely, water [in a well],) to collect; as also Ajm~hu↓. (K.) And jum~ati Albiy^oru [The well was left for its water to collect]. (TA.) And Albiy^ora Astjm~↓ He left the well for some days until its water should collect: whence the metaphorical phrase, mavaAbapu safahihi kaAna yasotajim~u↓, [explained in art. vwb,] occurring in a trad. (Har p. 68.) ― -b2- Also He filled it (namely, a measure, S, such as is called mak~uwk, K) so that it had what is termed jumaAmN; and so Ajm~hu↓; (S, K;) and jm~mhu↓. (K.) And jum~a It was filled. (T, TA.) See also jam~N, last sentence.

2 jm~mt AlA^aroDu *
The jamiym [q. v.] of the land became full, or abundant. (ISh, TA.) ― -b2- jm~m [in the CK jamama] It (herbage) became such as is termed jamiym; as also tjm~m↓. (K, TA.) ― -b3- He made a jum~ap [q. v.] of his hair. (Z, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence but two.

4 Ajm~ A^jm A^jmp Ajm jm wjm
, as an intrans. verb: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- Ajm~hu: see 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- He left him unridden, so that he recovered from his fatigue; namely, a horse. (K.) And A^ujim~a He (a horse) was left unridden. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence, He rested him, or gave him rest.] You say, A^ajomimo nafosaka yawomFA A^awo yawomayoni [Rest thyself a day, or two days]. (S.) And hence, in a trad. respecting the safarojalap [or quince], tujim~u Alfuw^aAda, i. e. It rests the heart, and consolidates it, and completes its soundness and liveliness. (TA.) One says also, A_in~iY laA^asotajim~u↓ qalobiY bi$~aYo'K mina All~ahowi liA^aqowaY bihi EalaY AlHaq~i [Verily I relieve my heart with somewhat of diversion, in order that I may become strong thereby for that which is substantial, or solid, not vain or frivolous]. (S.) And Ajm~ AlA^aroDa He gave the land rest from tilling. (TA in art. bxE.) ― -b4- He gave him the jam~ap [or supply of water, that had collected after drawing,] of the well. (Th. TA.) ― -b5- A^ujim~a AlEinabu The grape-vine had all its branches that were above the ground cut off. (AHn, TA.)

5 tajam~a3a
see 2.

10 Astj~m A^stjm Astjm {stjm
, as an intrans. verb: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- It is said in a trad., mano yuHib~u A^ano yasotajim~a lahu Aln~aAsu qiyaAmFA faloyatabaw~aA^o maqoEadahu mina Aln~aAri, i. e. [Whoso loveth that men] should collect themselves to him, standing in his presence, and confining themselves to him, [let him take his sitting-place in the fire of Hell:] or, accord. as some relate it, ystxm~; see art. xm; (TA;) and, as some, yasotaxiyma. (TA in art. xym, q. v.) ― -b3- Astjm~t AlA^aroDu The land put forth its plants, or herbage, (K, TA,) so that it became like the [hair termed] jm~p [i. e. jum~ap]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- As a trans. verb: see 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two
places: ― -b2- and see 4. ― -b3- Ausotujim~ato jam~apu AlmaA='i [The supply of water that had collected after drawing] was drunk. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 jamojama jmjm
, (S, TA,) inf. n. jamojamapN, (K,) He spoke indistinctly, (S, K,) not from impotence, or, accord. to the T, from impotence; (TA;) and tajamojama↓ signifies the same. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Mgh, K,) with which majomajapN is syn., accord. to Ez-Zowzanee, (Mgh,) He concealed (Mgh, K, TA) speech, (Mgh,) or a thing, (K, TA,) in his bosom. (Mgh, K, TA.) You say, jmjm $ayoy^FA fiY Sadorihi He concealed a thing in his bosom; did not reveal it. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Kr, K,) He destroyed, or killed, (Kr, K, TA,) another or others. (TA.)

R. Q. 2 tajamojama jmjm tjmjm
: see R. Q. 1. ― -b2- Hence, tjmjm Eani AlA^amori (tropical:) [He held back from the thing, not daring to do it;] he did not dare to do the thing. (Ham p. 240.)

jam~N jm
, an inf. n. used as an epithet, (Msb,) Much, or many; (S, Msb, K;) as also jamiymN↓ accord. to the copies of the K, but correctly jamama↓, as in the L. (TA.) You say maAlN jam~N (Msb, TA) and jamama↓ (TA) Muck property, or many cattle. (Msb.) And it is said in the Kur [lxxxix. 21], wa yuHib~uwna AlmaAla Hub~FA jam~FA (S) And they love property with much love. (A'Obeyd, TA.) Aboo-Khirásh El-Hudhalee says,
A_ino tagofiri A@l~`lhuma tagofiro jam~aA
(TA) i. c. [If thou forgive, O God, Thou forgivest] much sin. (Mgh.) jam~` AlbuEaAqi, in a trad. respecting prayer for rain, means Copious, abundant, extensive rain. (TA in art. bEq.) ― -b2- The greater, or main, portion of the Zahiyrap [i. e. midday, or mid-day in summer, &c.]: and of water; as also jam~apN↓, (as in some copies of the K,) or jum~apN↓: (so in other copies of the K, and accord. to the TA: [the former app. the right: if it were the latter, the author of the K, accord. to a rule which he has seldom neglected, would have added biAlD~am~i; as SM has here done, unless his transcriber have thus written by mistake for biAlfatoHi:] or jam~N signifies the water, of a well, that has collected [after it has been drawn from]: and jam~apN↓, the place in which the water collects: (S:) and also, this last, the water itself: (TA: [i. e. the supply of water that has collected after drawing: see 4, last sentence but one; and see 10, last sentence:]) the pl. (of jam~apN S [or of this and of jam~N also]) is jimaAmN (S, K) and jumuwmN. (K.) ― -b3- biy^orN jam~apN: see jamuwmN. ― -b4- jaAw^uwA jam~FA gafiyrFA, and Aljam~a Algafiyra, &c.; see A^ajam~u, and art. gfr. ― -b5- jam~N also signifies People of the lowest, or basest, or meanest sort. (T, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The measuring to the head of the measure; [app. an inf. n., of which the verb is jam~a↓; see 1, last sentence but two; and so jamaAmN↓ and jumaAmN↓ and jimaAmN↓. (K.)

jam~apN jm jmh jmp
: see jam~N, in two places. ― -b2- Also The part, or place, of a ship, in which collects the water that leaks from its xuruwz [or seams: in the CK xuruwr]: (K:) a genuine Arabic word. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (S, K,) and jum~apN↓, (S, K, and Ham p. 746,) A company demanding a bloodwit (S, K) or an obligation that must be discharged, (TA, and Ham ubi suprà,) or peace; or coming for some other purpose: (Ham:) pl. jmm [probably jumamN, pl. of the latter, or perhaps of both; or it may be jimamN, as pl. of both]. (TA.) You say, jaA='a fiY jam~apK EaZiymapK and EZymp jum~apK↓ He came in a great company &c. (S, K.)

jum~apN jm jmh jmp
: see jam~N: ― -b2- and see also jam~apN, in two places. ― -b3- Also The collective mass of the hair of the head, or the head of hair, (mujotamaEa $aEori Alr~aA^osi S, Mgh, K,) when more in quantity than what is termed waforap: (S, Mgh:) or the collective mass of the hair (mujotamaEu Al$~aEori) when it hangs down from the head to the lobe of the ear, and to the two shoulder-joints, and more than that; what does not extend beyond the ears being termed wfrp: (TA:) or the collective mass (mujotamaEa) of the hair of the naASiyap [or anterior part of the head]: accord. to some, what reaches to the two shoulder-joints: (Msb:) in the M it is said to signify the hair; and in like manner in the Deewán el-Adab: but ISd adds that it is also said to mean hair more in quantity than that which is termed lim~ap: accord. to IAth, the hair of the head that falls upon the two shoulder-joints: in the Muhedhdhib, what extends beyond the ears: in the Mukaddameh of Z, what extends to the lobe of the ear: accord. to IDrd, much hair: (TA:) [see also lim~apN and waforapN:] pl. jumamN (Msb, TA) and jimaAmN: (TA:) dim. jumayomapN↓. (TA.) Hence, raA^aY lumoEapF fagasalahaA bijum~atihi, meaning [He saw a spot, and washed it] by a moistening of his jm~p: or with the water of his jm~p: the prefixed noun being suppressed. (Mgh.) ― -b4- Also [app. (assumed tropical:) A flower-bud;] the qbp [rendered by Golius “ nodosior pars ”] of a plant, from which the flower comes forth. (KL.) [See an ex. above, voce jam~a. If from jum~apN applied to hair, it would seem rather to mean A tuft.] ― -b5- One says also, Ha*afa jum~apu Aljawozapi vum~a A^akalahaA (tropical:) [app. meaning He threw away the husk of the walnut: then ate it]. (TA.)

jamamN jmm
: see jam~N, in two places: ― -b2- and see also jumaAmN.

jamaAmN jmAm
A state of resting; (Fr, S, Msb, K;) as also jamaAmapN↓: (TA:) particularly of a horse. (Fr, S, Msb.) [See jam~a, of which it is an inf. n.] ― -b2- See also jam~N, last sentence: and see what next follows.

jumaAmN jmAm
What has collected of the seminal fluid of a horse [after his resting from covering]; as also jimaAmN↓. (K.) ― -b2- Also, and jimaAmN↓ and jamaAmN↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) [but see what follows,] The quantity [of flour or the like] that rises above the head of the [measure termed] mak~uwk, (S, Mgh, K,) after the filling, (Mgh,) exceeding the TafaAf thereof; (S, Mgh, K;) as also jamamN↓: (K:) or the fill of a bowl, without a head: accord. to ISk, only said of flour and the like: one says, A^aEoTaAniY jmAma AlqadaHi daqiyqFA [He gave me the bowlful of flour]: but jmAm meaning the “ resting ” of a horse is with fet-h only: (Msb:) or, accord. to Fr, one says AlqadaHi AlmaA='F jimaAmN↓, with kesr, meaning the bowlful of water; and jumaAmu Almak~uwki daqiyqFA, with damm; and jamaAmN Alfarasi, with fet-h only; and one does not say jumaAmN, with damm, except in relation to flour and the like, meaning the quantity that rises above the head of the mk~wk, after the being filled: one says, A^aEoTiniY jumaAma Almak~uwki when one puts what the head of the mk~wk will bear, and gives it: (S, TA:) in the T, it is said that A^aEoTihi jmAma Almak~uwki means Give thou him [the quantity of] a mk~wk without a head: but [SM says,] I have seen in its margin written that the right meaning is, the quantity borne by the head of the mk~wk. (TA.) ― -b3- See also jam~N, last sentence.

jimaAmN jmAm
: see jumaAmN, in three places: ― -b2- and jam~N, last sentence: ＝ -A2- and see also jumojumapN. ＝ -A3- It is also a pl. of jam~apN (S) [and perhaps of jam~N likewise: (see this latter:)] and of jum~apN. (TA.)

biy^orN jamuwmN *
(S, K) and jam~apN↓ (K) A well of much water. (S, K.) ― -b2- farasN jamuwmN A horse that, after any run, runs again; (T, S, K;) applied to the female as well as the male: (T, TA:) a horse that goes much. (KL.)

jamiymN jmym
A plant, or herbage, that has grown somewhat, but not attained its full height: (S:) or much, or abundant, herbage: (K:) or herbage standing up and spreading: (AHn, K:) or that has grown up until it has become like the jum~ap of hair: (TA:) a plant, or herbage, when it first appears in the ground is termed baAriDN; then, jamiymN; then, busorapN; then, SamoEaA='u; and then, [when it is dry,] Ha$iy$N: (S in art. bsr:) pl. A^ajim~aA='u. (K.) And, with p, A [plant of the kind termed] naSiy~ap that has become half a month old, so that it fills the mouth. (K.) ― -b2- See also jam~N.

jamaAmapN jmAm jmAmh jmAmp
: see jamaAmN. ― -b2- Also The state of being satiated, or satisfied, with food, and with drink. (TA.)

jumayomapN jmymh jmymp
dim. of jum~apN, q. v. (TA.)

jum~aY jm jmY jmy jmyy
The bean, or beans; syn. baAqil~aY. (AHn, K.)

jum~iY jm jmY jmy jmyy
: see jum~aAniY~N.

jam~aAmN jmAm
: see what next follows.

jam~aAnN jm jmAn
A measure, (S,) such as is called mak~uwk, (K,) filled so as to have what is termed jumaAm; (S, K;) as also jam~aAmN↓: (K:) [fem. of the former jam~aY. Hence,] jumojumapN jam~aY [A] full [bowl]. (K. In the CK jamojamapN.)

jum~aAniY~N jm jmAn jmAnY jmAny
, with n, (S,) an irreg. rel. n., applied to a man, (Sb, S,) Having a long jum~ap: (S, K:) or having a great and long jum~ap: (Sb, TA:) but if you name a person jum~ap, the rel. n. formed from it is jum~iY~N↓ (Sb, S) only. (Sb, TA.)

jumojumN jmjm
: see what next follows.

jumojumapN jmjm jmjmh jmjmp
The skull; i. e. the bone that contains the brain: (S, Msb, K: *) or i. q. qiHofN [i. e. the bone above the brain, or a separate portion of the skull, or a distinct bone of the skull]: (K:) or the bones of the head; (IAar, Mgh, TA;) all of them; the uppermost of them being the haAmap; (IAar, TA;) or the hAmp is the jmjmp altogether; (ISh, TA;) and the qHf is said to be a piece of the jmjmp: (TA:) pl. jumojumN↓, (K,) [or this (in the CK, erroneously, jamojamN) is a coll. gen. n.,] and jamaAjimu [is the pl. properly so called, and that which is more commonly known]. (TA.) ― -b2- Sometimes it is used to signify A man; so that one says, xu*uwA mino kul~i jumojumapK dirohamFA [Take ye from every man, or head, a dirhem]; like as one says, mino kul~i raA^osK: (Msb:) and waDaEa AlA_imaAmu AlxaraAja EalaY AljamaAjimi EalaY kul~i jumojumapK ka*aA [The Imám imposed the tax, or land-tax, upon the heads; upon every head so much]. (Mgh.) ― -b3- A wooden bowl: (S, K:) a bowl of glass; as also qiHofN. (Az, TA.) ― -b4- A kind of measure for corn or the like. (K.) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) Chiefs, or lords, of the Arabs; because the jmjmp is the head, which is the most noble of the members: (TA:) also, (TA,) [the pl.] jamaAjimu has this meaning. (T, K, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) Any sons of a father that are persons of might, or power, and eminence, or nobility: (T, TA:) and [the pl.] jamaAjimu the tribes (qabaAy^il) of the Arabs which comprise buTuwn, and in relation to which persons are called; as Kelb Ibn-Webreh; for when you say kalobiY~N, you do not need to call the person in relation to any of the bTwn: (S:) or the tribes (qbAy^l) in relation to which the bTwn are called; as also jimaAmN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- A well that is dug in salt ground. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- Sixty head of camels. (IF, IB, TA.) ＝ -A4- jamaAjimu AlHaArivi The piece of wood at the head of which is the ploughshare. (TA.)

A^ajam~u *
[Greater, and greatest, in quantity, and in number, &c.: fem. jam~aA='u. Hence,] waAlwaHoYu A^ajam~u maA kaAna, in a trad. of Anas, means The revelation being the most that it used to be. (Sh, TA.) ― -b2- A bone having much flesh. (K.) You say also AimoraA^apN jam~aA='u AlEiZaAmi A woman having much flesh (K, TA) on the bones. (TA.) And AimoraA^apN jam~aA='u AlmaraAfiqi [A woman having much flesh on the elbows: or, as seems to be indicated by J, having no prominence of the elbows; and if so, from jam~aA='u applied to a ewe, in a sense explained in what follows]. (S.) ― -b3- jaAw^uwA Aljam~aA='a Algafiyra, (S, * Msb, K,) [and jam~aA='a gafiyrFA &c.,] and gafiyrFA jam~FA↓, (K,) [and Algafiyra Aljam~a↓, &c.,] They came all together, (S, * Msb, K,) high and low, none of them remaining behind, and they being many: (S, K, in art. gfr:) see art. gfr. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- Hornless, applied to a ram (Mgh, Msb, K) or he-goat; (Msb;) and so jam~aA='u applied to a ewe (S, Mgh, Msb) or she-goat: (S, Msb:) pl. jum~N. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (tropical:) A man having no spear (S, K, TA) in war or battle: (S, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) The pl. is also applied to horses, (S,) meaning (assumed tropical:) whose owners have no spears; the spears being regarded as the horses' horns. (Ham, p. 90.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A building having no [acroterial ornaments such as are termed] $uraf: (S:) and the pl., (assumed tropical:) Mosques having no $uraf (Mgh, TA) upon them, (TA,) [i. e.] upon their walls. (Mgh.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A flat house-top having no parapet, or surrounding wall. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Short; having no elevation. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A woman's anterior pudendum. (K.) ― -b7- And, as being likened thereto, or the reverse may be the case, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A bowl. (K.) ― -b8- Also, the fem., (assumed tropical:) Smooth. (IAar, K.) ― -b9- And hence, because of its smoothness, (IAar, TA,) (assumed tropical:) A helmet: (IAar, K:) to which the epithet gafiyrN [q. v.] is applied because it covers the head: but this meaning of “ a helmet ” was not known to ISd on any other authority than that of IAar. (TA.)

majam~N mjm
A place where water remains: or to which it reaches, and where it ends. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The breast, or bosom, or mind: (K, TA:) because it is the place in which are collected the knowledge &c. that it retains. (TA.) You say, huwa waAsiEu Almajam~i, i. e. raHobu Al*~iraAEi waAsiEu AlS~adori (tropical:) [He is possessed of ample power and might, and free from distress of mind or from narrowness of mind]. (IAar, K, TA.) And A_in~ahu laDay~iqu Almajam~i (tropical:) Verily he is contracted, or straitened, in mind by affairs, or events. (IAar, TA.)

majam~apN mjm mjmh mjmp
A thing in which resting is usually known to take place. (TA.)

mujam~amN mjmm
A boy (IDrd, TA) having a head of hair such as is termed a jum~ap. (IDrd, K, TA.)

mujam~imapN mjmmh mjmmp
A woman who makes her hair to form a jum~ap, to make herself like a man: the doing of which is forbidden. (TA.)

1 jamaHa jmH
, aor.
jamaHa
, inf. n. jimaAHN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and jumuwHN (S, A, Msb, K) and jamoHN, (K,) or this last has not been heard, (Mgh,) He (a horse) overcame his rider, or gained the mastery over him, (S, L, K,) running away with him: (L:) or broke loose, or ran away, (Msb,) and went at random, without any certain aim, so as not to be turned by anything: (Mgh, Msb:) or ran so as to have the mastery over his rider: (Ham p. 568:) and jamaHa biraAkibihi (A, Mgh, Msb) he overcame his rider, (A, Mgh,) and ran away so that he could not govern him: (A:) or became refractory, so that he overcame his rider: (Msb:) and sometimes, (Msb,) this verb also signifies he was quick, or swift, (A, Msb,) and brisk, lively, or sprightly; denoting in this case a quality that is approved; whereas in the senses before explained it denotes a quality that is disapproved: but in the last sense it is obsolete [unless tropically applied to a man]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He (said of anything [i. e. of a man or any animal]) went at random, or heedlessly, without consideration or certain aim, not obeying a guide to the right course. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) He (said of a man, S, L) hastened, or went quickly, (S, L, K,) A_ilayohi to him, or it, so that his course was not turned for anything. (L, TA.) wahumo yajomaHuwna, in the Kur [ix. 57], means (assumed tropical:) They hastening, or going quickly: (AO, S, L:) or hastening so that nothing turns them back, like the horse that is termed jamuwH: (Bd, Jel:) or running like horses that overcome their riders and run away so as to be ungovernable by them. (A.) And jamaHa fiY A_ivorihi, occurring in a trad., (assumed tropical:) He hastened after him, or it, so that nothing turned him back. (L.) ― -b3- jamaHati AlmaroA^apu (tropical:) The woman went forth from the place where she used to pass the night, in anger, without the permission of her husband. (Msb.) And jamaHato mino zawojihaA, so in the S and L &c., but in the K jamaHato zawojahaA, [which is evidently a mistake,] (TA,) (tropical:) She went forth from the house, or tent, of her husband, to her own family, before he divorced her; (S, L, K;) inf. n. jimaAHN. (L, TA.) And jamaHato A_ilaY A^aholihaA (tropical:) She went to her family without the permission of her husband. (A.) ― -b4- jamaHati Als~afiynapu (tropical:) The ship quitted her course, (A, TA,) and became ungovernable by the sailors; inf. n. jumuwHN. (TA.) ― -b5- jamaHati AlmafaAzapu biAlqawomi (tropical:) The desert led the people, or party, far away, by reason of its great extent. (A, TA.) ― -b6- jamaHa bihi muraAduhu (tropical:) The object of his desire baffled his efforts to attain it. (A, TA.)

jamoHapu jmHh jmHp
[A trick of overcoming the rider, and running away with him]. You say, daAb~apN samoHapN maA bihaA jamoHapN wa laA ramoHapN [A beast submissive, or easy, or gentle: there is not in her a trick of overcoming the rider, and running away with him, nor a trick of kicking]. (A.)

jamuwHN jmwH
(T, S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and jaAmiHN↓ (Mgh, Msb) A horse that overcomes his rider, or gains the mastery over him, (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) being refractory, (Msb,) and runs away with him, (L,) or runs away so that his rider cannot govern him, (A,) or goes away at random, without any certain aim, so as not to be turned by anything: (Mgh:) or that will not bend his head: (TA:) the former epithet, (T, Mgh, TA,) and the latter, (Mgh, Msb,) applied alike to the horse and the mare: (T, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and the former has two meanings; one denoting what is a fault, for which the horse may be returned; (T, Mgh, TA;) i. e., that habitually takes his own way, so that his rider cannot turn him from it; (T, TA;) or as explained before; (Mgh;) the other meaning being quick, or swift, and brisk, lively, and sprightly; and this does not imply a fault (T, Mgh, TA) for which he may be returned. (T, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Anything [i. e. a man or any animal] that goes at random, or heedlessly, without consideration or certain aim, not obeying a guide to the right course: (TA:) and the former epithet, (Msb, K,) or each of the two, (S, * A,) (tropical:) a man who follows his own natural desire, without consideration, not obeying a guide to the right course of conduct, (S, A, Msb, K,)
so that he cannot be turned back. (S, K.) And jum~aAHN↓ [is pl. of jaAmiHN↓, accord. to analogy, and] signifies (assumed tropical:) Men routed, defeated, or put to flight, in war. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- mafaAzapN jamuwHN (assumed tropical:) [A desert that leads one far away, by reason of its great extent: see 1, last sentence but one: likened to a horse that is termed jamuwH]: occurring in a poem of Dhu-r-Rummeh. (TA in art. nHb.)

jum~aAHN jmAH
An arrow, (S, K,) or a small arrow, (L,) without an iron point, having a round head, with which the art of shooting is learned (S, L, K) by a boy: (S, L:) or one with which boys play, putting upon its head a date or some clay, in order that it may not wound: (L:) or it signifies also a date put upon the head of a piece of wood, with which boys play: (K:) birds are shot at with it, and knocked down, without being killed, so that the shooter takes them: and it is also called jub~aAHN: (T, TA:) or a boy's arrow, upon the end of which he puts a lump of chewed dates of the size of the EifaAD [here meaning stopper] of a bottle, in order that it (the end) may go more directly, and be smooth; without feathers, and sometimes without a notch. (AHn, L.) ＝ -A2- Also That [kind of plant] at the extremities of which come forth what resemble ears of wheat, soft, (L, K,) like foxes' tails, or (L) resembling the heads of the HaliY~ and the Sil~iyaAn and the like: (L, K:) a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p: (L:) pl. jamaAmiyHu; and in poetry jamaAmiHu; (L, K;) the latter allowable only in cases of necessity. (L.) ＝ -A3- See also jamuwHN.

jaAmiHN jAmH
: see jamuwHN, in two places.

1 jamada jmd
, aor.
jamuda
, inf. n. jamodN and jumuwdN, said of water, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) &c., (Msb,) [i. e.,] of anything fluid, or liquid, (K,) It congealed; concreted; became solid, or contr. of fluid or liquid; froze; syn. qaAma; (S, M;) contr. of *aAba; (Msb, K;) as also jamuda. (L, K.) And said of blood, &c., (S, M,) It congealed, or concreted; syn. qAm: (M:) or became dry; dried. (S.) See also 2. ― -b2- Also, inf. n. jumuwdN, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, remained fixed, or stationary. (KL.) You say, maA zilotu A^aDoribuhu Hat~aY jamada (tropical:) [I ceased not to beat him until he became motionless].
