(A.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) [He, or it, was, or became, incapable of growth or increase; lifeless, or dead: see jaAmidN. ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence; inert; not sharp, penetrating, vigorous, or effective, in the performing of affairs; or soft, without strength or sturdiness, and without endurance: see, again, jaAmidN.] ― -b5- Also, inf. n. jumuwdN, (tropical:) said of a man's state or condition [as meaning, It was, or became, stagnant, or unimproving]. (A.) ― -b6- Also jamadato, aor.
jamuda
, inf. n. jumuwdN, (tropical:) She [a camel, &c.,] had little milk. (T, TA.) And jamadato Eayonuhu (tropical:) His eye shed few tears: a phrase alluding to hardness of the heart. (Msb.) ― -b7- Also jamada, (L, K,) aor.
jamuda
, (L,) [inf. n. jumuwdN;] and A^ajomada↓; (A, TA; [in a copy of the A, Anjmd, but this is doubtless a mistranscription; see mujomidN;]) (tropical:) He was, or became, niggardly, penurious, or avaricious; (L, A, K;) as also jamada kaf~uhu [or jamadato]; (Msb;) or jamadato yaduhu: (A:) and Ajmd↓ he possessed little good: (A, TA:) or jumuwdN signifies the refraining, or holding back, from beneficence. (Har p. 149.) ― -b8- jamada liY Ealayohi Haq~iY (tropical:) My right, or due, was, or became, incumbent, or obligatory, on him; or established against him; (A, K, * TA;) as also *aAba. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- jamadahu He cut it, or cut it off. (K.)

2 jm~d jmd
, inf. n. tajomiydN; (K;) or jamada↓; (so in the L;) It (water, and expressed juice, L) was about to congeal, concrete, become solid, or freeze; was at the point of congealing, &c.; expl. by HaAwala A^ano yajomuda. (L, K.) ＝ -A2- [And the former, It caused water &c. to congeal.]

4 Ajmd A^jmd Ajmd jmd
: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also, inf. n. A_ijomaAdN, He was entrusted with the management of affairs among a people or party [in the game called Almayosir: see mujomidN]. (T, TA.) ＝ -A2- A^ajomadotu Ealayohi Haq~iY (tropical:) I made my right, or due, incumbent, or obligatory, on him; or established it against him. (A, K, * TA.)

jamodN jmd
: see jaAmidN, in two places.

jumodN jmd
: see jumudN.

jamadN jmd
pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] of jaAmidN, q. v. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also Congealed, or frozen, water; ice: [see also jamodN, mentioned with jaAmidN:] and snow. (K.) ― -b3- See also what next follows.

jumudN jmd
and jumodN↓ Elevated ground; as also jamadN↓: (M, K:) or a hard, elevated place: (S, TA:) or jumudN signifies rugged ground: (TA:) or an elevated, rugged place: (As, TA:) or a small isolated mountain, not high, sometimes rugged and sometimes soft, and producing trees, only found in rugged land; so called because of its dryness; it is the smallest kind of A^akamap, round and small, not extending along the ground, rugged at the top, and producing herbs, or leguminous plants, as well as trees; differing from jumuwdN [q. v.]: (ISh, L, TA:) pl. [of mult.] jimaAdN (ISh, S, M, K) and [of pauc.] A^ajomaAdN. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- Also, the first, A stone: pl. jimaAdN. (Fr, TA.)

jamaAdN jmAd
(assumed tropical:) [A thing that does not grow, or increase; that is incapable of growth, or increase; an inorganic thing; as a mineral and the like:] an inanimate thing; a thing that has no soul: [an epithet used as a subst.; or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant:] pl. jamaAdaAtN. (Har p. 13.) [See also jaAmidN.] ― -b2- (tropical:) Land (A^aroDN) upon which rain has not fallen: (T, S, K:) or dry land, upon which no rain has fallen, and in which is nothing: (T, TA:) or land in which is no produce: (A:) or, as some say, rugged land: (L:) or sterile, barren, or unfruitful, land, in which is nothing; as also jahaAdN: pl. jumudN. (AA, L in art. jhd.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A year (sanapN) in which is no rain: (S, K:) or in which is no produce of the earth: (A:) and, in like manner, jaAmidapN↓ a year in which is no herbage, or pasture, no plenty, or fruitfulness, and no rain. (T, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A she-camel having no milk; (S, M, K;) and so a ewe or a she-goat: (L:) or having little milk: (T, TA:) and [accord. to some,] a slow she-camel; syn. baTiyoy^apN; (L, K;) but [this is app. a mistranscription for bakiyoy^apN “ having little milk, ” and] ISd says that the explanation bTyy^p does not please him. (TA.) ― -b5- See also jaAmidN, in two places. ＝ -A2- A kind of cloth or garment; as also jimaAdN↓. (K.)

jamaAdi jmAd
, like qaTaAmi, (K,) or jamaAdi lahu, (S, A, L,) said with reference to a niggard, (S, A, L, K,) in dispraise, (K,) as an imprecation, meaning (tropical:) May a stagnant, or an unimproving, state or condition (jumuwdu AlHaAli) be his lot [or his constant lot]: (A:) or may he not cease to be in a stagnant, or an unimproving, state or condition (laA zaAla jaAmida AlHaAli). (S, L.) jamaAdi is [a proper name,] indecl., with kesr for its termination, because it is transformed from the inf. n., namely, Aljumuwdu, like fajaAri, which means Alfajorapu: (S:) and the contr. of jamaAdi lahu is jamaAdi lahu, (S, * A,) which denotes praise. (S.) El-Mutalemmis says,
jamaAdi lahaA walaA taquwliY
lahaA A^abadFA A_i*aA *ukirato HamaAdi
i. e., Say thou jumuwdFA to her, [jumuwdFA,] and say not to her [ever, when she is mentioned,] HamodFA and $ukorFA. (S.)

jimaAdN jmAd
: see jamaAdN, last meaning.

jamuwdN jmwd
: see jaAmidN.

jumuwdN jmwd
[app. Elevated tracts,] softer, or more plain, than what is termed jumudN, and more intermixed with soft, or plain, tracts, sometimes in, or by, that [kind of high ground] which is termed quf~N, and sometimes in, or by, soft, or plain, tracts. (ISh, L, TA.)

jamiydu AlEayoni jmyd AlEyn
: see jaAmidN.

jumaAdaY jmAd jmAdY jmAdy
One of the names of the months, (Msb, K,) applied to two of the Arabian months, together called jumaAdayaAni, (TA,) and distinguished by the appellations of jumaAdaY AlA^uwlaY and jumaAdaY AlA=xirapu [the fifth and sixth months of the Arabian year]: (S, K:) it is of the measure fuEaAlaY, from Aljamodu; (S;) the two months to which it is applied being [said to be] so called because, when the months were named, these two fell in the season of the freezing of water: (ISd, L, Msb:) [but this derivation seems to have been invented when the two months thus named had fallen back, into, or beyond, the winter; for when they received this appellation, the former of them evidently commenced in March, and the latter ended in May; therefore I hold the opinion of M. Caussin de Perceval, that they were thus called because falling in a period when the earth had become dry and hard by reason of paucity of rain, from jamaAdN, an epithet applied to land upon which rain has not fallen, or from jumaAdaY, an
epithet applied to an eye that sheds few tears; which opinion is confirmed by the obvious derivations of the names of other months, SafarN and rabiyEN and ramaDaAnu and $aw~aAlN:] afterwards, when the lunar months superseded the solar, the same names were retained: (Msb:) [see zamanN, and Alhijorapu:] jmAdY is determinate, (K,) being a proper name, (TA,) and of the fem. gender: (Msb, K:) if you find it masc., it is because it is made to accord to Al$~ahoru: all the other names of the months are masc.: (Fr, IAmb, Msb:) the pl. is jumaAdayaAtN, (Fr, L, K,) agreeably with analogy; and if the form jimaAdN [a mistranscription for jamaAy^idu, like HabaAy^iru, pl. of HubaAraY,] were used, it would also be agreeable with analogy. (Fr, L.) The former of these two months is also called jumaAdaY xamosapK; and the latter, jumaAdaY sit~apK; (K;) which mean, respectively, Jumádà the fifth month and Jumádà the sixth month, from the commencement of the year. (TA.) Lebeed says, [describing a pair of wild asses,]
Hat~aY A_i*aA salaxaA jumaAdaY sit~apF
jazaA= faTaAla SiyaAmuhu waSiyaAmuhaA
[Until, when they both pass, and come to the end of, Jumádà, completing six months, they satisfy themselves with green pasture so as to be in no need of water, and his and her abstinence from water becomes of long continuance]: thus cited by Bundár; st~p being in the accus. case as a denotative of state, and by jmAdY being meant jmAdY AlA=xrp: or, accord. to IAar, the poet said st~pK, meaning the six months of winter, which are the months of dew; and Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee says the like. (MF.) AHn says that the Arabs applied the name of jmAdY to The whole of the winter; [see above;] whether the winter were at the same time as the months so called or not: and Aboo-Sa'eed says the like. (L.) ― -b2- See also jaAmidN.

layolapN jumaAdiy~apN lylp jmAdyh lylp jmAdyp
A wintry night. (Aboo-Sa'eed, L.) [See jumaAdaY.]

jam~aAdN jmAd
(tropical:) A sword such that he who is struck with it becomes motionless (yajomudu): (A, TA:) or a sharp, cutting, sword. (AA, K.)

jaAmidN jAmd
, applied to water, (Msb, K,) &c., (Msb,) [i. e.] anything fluid, or liquid, (K,) In a state of congelation, concretion, or solidity; freezing; as also jamodN↓; contr. of *aAy^ibN: (Msb, K:) you say maA='N jamodN [as well as maA='N jaAmidN]: (Msb:) or jamodN↓ signifies what is congealed, or frozen, of water [&c.]; ice; (S, A;) contr. of *awobN: (S:) [see also jamadN:] it is originally an inf. n.: (S, Msb, K:) [or it is an epithet from jamuda, like DaxomN from Daxuma:] and jamadN↓ is a pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of jaAmidN, (S, Msb, K,) like as xadamN is of xaAdimN: (S, Msb:) you say, qado kavura Aljamadu [The frozen waters have become many]. (S.) [Hence,] mux~apN jaAmidapN A hard piece of marrow. (L.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Remaining fixed, stationary, or motionless. (Bd and Jel in xxvii. 90.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A thing that does not grow, or increase; [incapable of growth, or increase; inanimate;] as stone, in contradistinction to a tree [and an animal]. (Kull.) [See also jamaAdN.] You say, laka jaAmidu h`*aA AlmaAli wa*aAy^ibuhu (A, L, K *) (tropical:) To thee belongs, or shall belong, what consists of gold and silver [or the like inanimate things], of this property, and what consists of live stock, thereof: (L, K:) or what consists of stones, thereof, and what consists of trees, thereof: or what is solid, thereof, and what is fluid, or liquid, thereof. (L.) ― -b4- [Hence its application in lexicology and grammar to (assumed tropical:) A noun that is not an inf. n. nor derived from an inf. n.; a noun having the quality of a real substantive (Aisomi EayonK), opposed to that which has the quality of an ideal substantive (Aisomu maEonFY): and (assumed tropical:) a verb that has but one tense and no inf. n., as layosa and niEoma &c., opposed (as is said in the TA voce qado) to mutaSar~ifN: it may be rendered (and so I have rendered it), in these cases, aplastic.] ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Lifeless; dead. (Kull p. 147.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) Stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence; inert; not sharp, penetrating, vigorous, or effective, in the performing of affairs; or soft, without strength or sturdiness, and without endurance. (TA.) ― -b7- It is also applied to a man's state, or condition: you say rajulN jaAmidu AlHaAli (assumed tropical:) [A man in a stagnant, or unimproving, state or condition]. (S, L.) ― -b8- And to the eye: you say EayonN jaAmidapN (assumed tropical:) An eye that sheds no tears; (Ks, K;) as also jumaAdaY↓, (Ks, K,) and jamuwdN↓; (S, K;) or this last signifies (tropical:) an eye that sheds few tears. (A.) And rajulN jaAmidu AlEayoni, (A, K,) and AlEyn jamiydu↓, and AlEyn jamaAdu↓, (A,) (tropical:) A man whose eye sheds few tears; (A;) or whose eye sheds no tears. (K.) ― -b9- See also jamaAdN. ― -b10- Also, (L,) and mujomidN↓, (M, A, K,) and Alkaf~i jamaAdu↓, (A, K,) (tropical:) Niggardly, penurious, or avaricious; (M, A, K;) niggardly of that which it is incumbent on him to give: (L:) and mujomidN↓, also, a man of little, or no, good; possessing little, or no, good. (K.) ＝ -A2- jawaAmidu, (as its pl., IAar, L,) Limits, or boundaries, or boundary-marks, between lands, (IAar, L, K, *) and between two dwellings. (L.)

mujomidN mjmd
: see jaAmidN, last sentence but one, in two places. ― -b2- The person who is entrusted with the management of affairs in a game of chance (qimaAr [here meaning the game called Almayosir]): (K:) [i. q. DariybN:] or the person entrusted with the management of affairs among a people or party, (T, K, TA,) who does not take part in the game called Almayosir, except that he shuffles the arrows (yaDoribu bihaA) for the players, and has them placed in his hands, and is confided in with respect to them, and compels him who has incurred an obligation to fulfil it: (L, TA:) or one who takes no part in the game called Almayosir, (who is called baramN,) but who sometimes shuffles, or deals forth, the arrows, (yufiyDu bihaA,) for the players; so in the following verse of Tarafeh:
waA^aSofara maDobuwHK naZarotu Hawiyrahu
EalaY Aln~aAri waA@sotawodaEotuhu kaf~a mujomidi
[And of many a yellow arrow, changed in colour by fire, I have awaited the sound over the fire, and I have deposited it in the hand of one taking no part in the game but only shuffling, or dealing forth, the arrows for the players]; meaning, I have awaited its sound, which was like an answer proceeding from it, when I straightened it and marked it, over the fire: (S:) [or, accord. to the EM (p. 105), where we find HiwaArahu in the place of Hawiyrahu, the meaning is, and of many a yellow arrow, &c., I have awaited the returning and gaining, while we were assembled at the fire, &c.:] or mjmd here means a man taking with both his hands so as not to let anything go forth from them: (AA, TA:) or, accord. to As, it here means a man entering upon Jumádà, which was in that [the poet's] time a month of cold: (S, K: *) or one whose arrow does not gain anything in the game called Almayosir: (L:) or a person in whom one confides, and who is tenacious of that which is in his hand or possession, and not to be deceived. (A 'Obeyd, TA.)

majomadapN mjmd mjmdh mjmdp
A place in which ice is kept. (MA.)

huwa mujaAmidiY hw mjAmdY hw mjAmdy
He is my neighbour, his house, or tent, adjoining mine. (K.)

1 jamVra
see 2, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also 4: ― -b2- and 5. ＝ -A3- Also jamarahu He gave him jamor [live, or burning, coals]. (K.) ＝ -A4- He put him aside, apart, away, or at a distance. (Th, K.) ― -b2- jamarti Al$~amosu Alqamari, aor.
jamura
, The sun concealed [or as it were put out] the moon [by its proximity thereto: see Aibonu jamiyrK]. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A5- jamara [said of the moon, It became concealed by its proximity to the sun: see an ex. voce jamiyrN: and see also 4]. ＝ -A6- Also, (K,) aor.
jamira
, (TA,) He (a horse) leaped while shackled; and so Ajmr↓. (K.)

2 jm~r jmr
, inf. n. tajomiyrN; (K;) and jamara↓; (Msb;) He collected together (Msb, K) a people, and anything. (Msb.) ― -b2- jam~arato $aEarahaA, inf. n. tajomiyrN; (S, A, K;) and jamaratohu↓, (Msb,) and A^ajomaratohu↓; (K;) She (a woman) collected together her hair, (S, A, Msb, K,) and tied it in knots, or made it knotted and crisp, (Eaqadatohu, S, A, Msb,) at the back of her neck; (S, A, Msb, K;) not letting it hang down loosely: (S:) or plaited it: (T, TA:) and jm~r $aEarahu he collected together his hair at the back of his head: (Mgh:) and raA^osahaA Ajmrt↓ she collected together the hair of her head, and plaited it: and $aEarahu Ajmr↓ he disposed his hair in *awaAy^ib [or locks hanging down loosely from the middle of the head to the back, or plaits hanging down]. (TA.) ― -b3- And jm~r It (a thing) necessitated a people to unite together. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, (inf. n. as above, S,) He (a commander, As, A) detained the army in the territory of the enemy, (S, K,) or on the frontier of the enemy's country, (A,) and did not bring them back (S, A, K) from the frontier: (S:) the doing of which is forbidden: (TA:) or he detained them long on the frontier of the enemy, and did not give them permission to return to their families: (As, TA:) or he collected them on the frontiers of the enemy, and kept them from returning to their families.
(TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4: ― -b2- and 5. ＝ -A3- jm~r Alv~awoba, (A, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (Mgh, Msb,) He fumigated the garment with perfume; (A, * Mgh, Msb;) as also Ajmrhu↓: (Mgh, Msb, K:) but the former is the more common. (Mgh.) And jm~r Almasojida, (Mgh, TA,) or Ajmrhu↓, accord. to different modes of writing the surname of a certain No'eym, i. e., Almujam~iru or Almujomiru, (TA,) [and accord. to different copies of the K,] He fumigated the mosque with perfume: (Mgh:) [or perhaps it may mean he strewed the ground of the mosque with pebbles; from jamorapN; like HaS~abahu, from HaSabapN or HaSobaA='u or HaSobapN.] ― -b2- And jm~r [for jm~r laHomFA] He put flesh-meat upon live coals [to roast]. (A.) ＝ -A4- Also, (A,) inf. n. as above, (S, A,) He (a pilgrim, A) threw the pebbles [in the valley of Minè]; (S;) and so Astjmr↓. (TA in art. tw.) Hence, yawomu Alt~ajomiyr [The day of the throwing of the pebbles, by the pilgrims, in the valley of Minè]. (A.) [See jamorapN.] ＝ -A5- jm~r Aln~axolapa, (inf. n. as above, A,) He cut off the heart, or pith, (jum~aAr,) of the palmtree. (S, A. K. *)

4 A^ajomarato $aEarahaA *
, and raA^osahaA; and Ajmr $aEarahu: see 2. ― -b2- Ajmr AlA^amoru baniY fulaAnK The thing, or affair, included the common mass, (K,) or the whole mass, (TA,) of the sons of such a one within the compass of its relation or relations, or its effect or effects, &c. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Ajmr Aln~axolu He computed by conjecture the quantity of the fruit upon the palm-trees, and then reckoned, and summed up the quantity so computed. (K.) He who does so is termed mujomirN↓. (TA.) ― -b4- Ajmr Alxayolu He prepared the horses for racing &c. by feeding them with food barely sufficient to sustain them, after they had become fat, (A^aDomarahaA,) and collected them together. (K.) ＝ -A2- Ajmr Alqawomu EalaY Al$~aYo'i, (S,) or ElY AlA^amori; (K;) and jm~r↓, (K,) inf. n. tajomiyrN; (TA;) and jamara↓, and Astjmr↓; (K;) The people, or party, agreed together to do the thing, (S, K,) and united for it. (K.) [See also 5.] ＝ -A3- Ajmr Alv~awoba, and Almasojida: see 2. ― -b2- Ajmr Aln~aAra, inf. n. mujomarN, He prepared the fire [app. in a mijomarap]. (S, * K.) ＝ -A4- Ajmr said of a camel, He had his foot rendered even, so that there was no line between its phalanges, (K, TA,) in consequence of its having been wounded by the pebbles, and become hard. (TA.) ＝ -A5- Also, said of a camel, (S,) and of a man, (TA,) He hastened, or was quick, in his pace, or going; (S, K;) and ran: (TA:) you should not say Ajmz. (S.) ― -b2- See also 1. ＝ -A6- A^ajomarati All~ayolapu The night had its moon concealed by its proximity to the sun. (K, * TA.) [See also 1.]

5 tjm~r jmr tjmr
It (a people, or party,) collected together; (A, Mgh, TA;) [and] so jamara↓; this verb being intrans. as well as trans.: (Msb: [see 2:]) and jm~r↓ it (a tribe) collected together, and became one band. (As, TA.) ― -b2- It (an army) became detained in the territory of the enemy, and was not brought back (S, K) from the frontier; (S;) as also Astjmr↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 10.

8 Ajtmr biAlmijomari Ajtmr bAlmjmr
, (K,) and Astjmr↓, (AHn, A, Mgh,) He fumigated, or perfumed, himself with aloes-wood [or the like]. (AHn, A, Mgh, K.)

10 Astjmr Astjmr
: see 4: ― -b2- and 5: ＝ -A2- and 8: ＝ -A3- and 2. ― -b2- Also, [and vulgarly tjm~r↓,] He performed the purification termed AisotinojaA=' with jimaAr, (Mgh, Msb, K,) i. e., with stones, (AZ, S, Msb,) or small stones. (Mgh, TA.)

jamorN jmr
: see what next follows, in two places.

jamorapN jmr jmrh jmrp
A live, or burning, coal; a piece of smokeless burning fire: (Msb:) or burning fire: (K:) [but the former is the correct explanation:] when cold, [before it is kindled,] it is called faHomN (TA) [or HaTabN &c.]: and when reduced to powder by burning, ramaAdN: (L in art. rmd:) from jam~ara “ he collected together: ” (Mgh:) pl. jamorN↓ (S, Msb, K) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.] and jamaraAtN and jimaArN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] fiY Aljamoru↓ kabidiY (tropical:) [Live coals are in my liver]. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] AljamaraAtu Alv~alaAvu (assumed tropical:) [The three live coals; meaning the first three degrees of heat]: the first is in the air; the second, in the earth, or dust; and the third, in the water: [or, accord. to the modern Egyptian almanacs, the first is in the air, and is cold, or cool; the second, in the water, and is lukewarm; and the third, in the earth, or dust, and is hot: the first falling exactly a zodiacal month before the vernal equinox; and each lasting seven days:] whence the saying, kaAna *`lika Einoda suquwTi Aljamorapi (assumed tropical:) [That was at the time of the falling of the live coal]; i. e., when the heat had acquired strength. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Any body of men that have united together, and become one band, and that do not form a confederacy with any others: (S:) or a body of men that congregate by themselves, because of their strength and their great valour; [said to be] from the same word signifying “ a live coal: ” (Msb:) or any people that endure patiently fighting with those who fight them, not forming a confederacy with any others, nor uniting themselves to any others: (Lth, TA:) or a tribe that does not unite itself to any other: (K:) or that comprises three hundred horsemen, (K,) or the like thereof: (TA:) or a tribe that fights with a company of tribes: (TA:) pl. jamaraAtN. (S, Msb, K.) You say, banuw fulaAnK jamorapN The sons of such a one are a people able to defend themselves, and strong. (TA.) jamaraAtu AlEarabi is an appellation especially applied to three tribes; namely, Benoo-Dabbeh Ibn-Udd, and Benu-l-Hárith Ibn-Kaab, and Benoo-Numeyr Ibn-' Ámir; (S, A, K;) the first of which became extinguished by confederating with Er-Ribáb, and the second by confederating with Medhhij; the third only remaining [a jmrp] because it formed no confederacy: (S:) or it is applied to 'Abs and El-Hárith and Dabbeh; all the offspring of a woman who dreamt that three live coals issued from her faroj. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also A thousand horsemen. (S, K.) One says jamorapN kaAljamorapi [A troop of a thousand horsemen like the live coal]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A3- A pebble: (S, K:) or a stone: (Msb:) or a small stone or pebble: pl. jimaArN (Mgh, Msb, Et-Towsheeh, TA) and jamaraAtN. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- Also sing. of jamaraAtN (S, Msb, K) and of jimaArN (TA) in the appellations jamaraAtu minFY (Msb) or jamaraAtu AlmanaAsiki (S, K) and jimaAru AlmanaAsiki, (TA,) which were three in number, (S, Msb, K,) called Aljamorapu AlA^uwlaY and Aljamorapu AlwusoTaY and jamorapu AlEaqabapi, (K,) at which jamaraAt (i. e. small pebbles, TA) were cast; (S, K;) each of these being a heap of pebbles, at Minè, and each two heaps [or rather each heap and that next to it] being about a bow-shot apart: (Msb:) accord. to Th, from jamarahu “ he put him aside, apart, away, or at a distance: ” or from A^ajomara “ he hastened; ” because Adam pelted Iblees in Minè, and he hastened away before him: (K, * TA:) or from tjm~rwA “ they collected together: ” (Mgh:) or from jamarahu “ he collected it together. ” (Msb.) ＝ -A4- See also jamiyrapN.

jamaArN jmAr
An assembly; an assemblage; a collection: (K:) a people assembled together. (TA.) ― -b2- Ead~a A_ibilahu jamaArFA He counted, or numbered, his camels in one herd, (As, TA,) by looking at their aggregate. (As, T voce naZiyrN, q. v.) ― -b3- jaAw^uwA jamaAraY↓, and with tenween, [i. e., app., jamaArFA, not, as might be thought at first sight, jamaArFY, a form which MF disapproves, though it is said in the TA that his disapproval requires consideration,] They came all together, or all of them. (K.)

jamiyrN jmyr
A place of assembly of a people. (S, K.) ― -b2- AibonaA jamiyrK The night and the day: (S, K:) so called because of the assembling [of people therein]; like as they are called AibonaA samiyrK because people held conversation therein: (S:) or the two nights during which the moon becomes concealed by its proximity to the sun. (TA.) And Aibonu jamiyrK, (IAar, S,) or Aibonu jumayorK↓, (Lh, Th,) The moon in the night when it is concealed by its proximity to the sun: (TA:) or the moon in the end of the [lunar] month; because the sun conceals it (tajomuruhu, i. e. tuwaAriyhi): (IAar, TA:) or the dark night: (S:) or the night in which the moon does not rise, either in the first part thereof or in the last: (TA:) or the last night of the [lunar] month. (Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid, TA.) You say, jaA='anaA faHomapa A@bonu jumayorK↓ [He came to us in the darkest part of the moonless night, or of the night in which the moon did not rise]. (Th, TA.) And laA A^afoEalu *`lika maA jamara A@bonu jumayorK↓ [I will not do that as long as the moon in the end of the lunar month becomes concealed by its proximity to the sun; i. e., I will never do it]. (Lh, TA.) ― -b3- jamiyru Al$~aEari What is collected together, of the hair, and tied in knots, or made knotted and crisp. (TA. [See 2.])

Aibonu jumayorK Abn jmyr
: see jamiyrN, in three places.

jamiyrapN jmyrh jmyrp
A plait of hair: (T, Msb, K:) and i. q. *uw^aAbapN [app. here meaning a plait of hair hanging down; or a lock of hair hanging down loosely from the middle of the head to the back]: (TA:) and jamorapN↓ a lock of hair: (TA:) pl. of the former jamaAy^iru. (T, Msb.)

jaAw^uwA jamaAraY *
: see jamaArN.

jum~aArN jmAr
(S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and jaAmuwrN↓ (K) [each a coll. gen. n.] The heart, or pith, [or cerebrum,] of the palm-tree, (S, A, Msb, K, TA,) that is in the summit of its head, which part is cut off, and its outer portion is stripped off from the pith within it, which is a white substance, like a piece of the hump of a camel, large and soft: it is eaten with honey: (TA:) from it come forth the fruit and the branches; and when it is cut off, the tree dies: (Msb:) the spathe comes forth from it, amid the part whence two branches divide: (TA:) the head of the palmtree; a soft, white substance: from jam~ara “ he collected together; ” for a similar reason termed kavarN: (Mgh:) n. un. jum~aArapN. (A, TA.) [See also qalobN.] You say, lahu saAqN kaAljum~aArapi He has a shank like a piece of the heart of the palm-tree. (A.) And Aljum~aAru fiY xalaAxilihin~a (tropical:) [Legs like the heart of the palm-tree are within their anklets]. (A.) Sakhr El-Hudhalee says, using a double trope, likening the fresh juicy stalks of the barodiY~ to the pith of the palm-tree, and then applying this expression to the legs of a woman,
A_i*aA EuTifato xalaAxuluhun~a gaS~abo
bijum~aAraAti barodiY~K xidaAli
(tropical:) [When their anklets are bent, (for the anklet of the Arab woman is formed of a piece of silver, or other metal, which is bent round so that the two ends nearly meet,) they are choked, or entirely filled up, with plump legs like the pith of the papyrus]. (A, TA.)

jaAmirN jAmr
: see mujam~irN.

jaAmuwrN jAmwr
: see jum~aArN. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A well-known appertenance of a ship or boat; [i. e., the head of the mast; a kind of truck, which is made of harder wood than the mast itself.] (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (tropical:) The head [absolutely]: but accord. to Kr, only the vulgar call it so. (TA.)

A^ajomaru *
occurs in a trad., where it is said, daxalotu Almasojida waAln~aAsu A^ajomaru maA kaAnuwA, meaning I entered the mosque when the people were in their most collected state. (TA.)

mujomarN mjmr
: see mijomarN: ― -b2- and see also mijomarapN, in two places. ― -b3- Also, (S, K,) and mujomirN↓, (K,) A hard solid hoof: (AA, S, K:) and a hard, strong, compact camel's foot: or one that has been wounded by the stones, and become hard. (TA.)

mujomirN mjmr
: see mujam~irN, in two places: ― -b2- and A^aJomara Aln~axola: ＝ -A2- and see also mujomarN.

mijomaro mjmr
: see mijomarapN. ― -b2- Also, (Mgh, Msb, K,) and mujomarN↓, (K,) Aloes-wood, (AHn, Mgh, Msb, K,) and the like, (Mgh,) or other substance, (Msb,) with which clothes are fumigated, (Mgh,) or with which one perfumes himself by burning it: (Msb:) pl. majaAmiru. (Mgh.)

mijomarapN mjmrh mjmrp
and mijomarN↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which latter is sometimes fem. [like the former], (K,) or fem. when by it is meant the fire (Aln~aAr), and masc. when meaning the place [of the fire], (TA,) and mujomarN↓, (K,) A vessel for fumigation; a censer; (Msb;) a vessel in which live coals are put, (S, K,) with incense, or some odoriferous substance for fumigation; (K;) a vessel in which aloes-wood is burned: it is disapproved, because generally of silver; but not so what is termed midoxanapN: (Mgh:) or mujomarN↓ signifies the thing for which the live coals are prepared: (S:) [and mijomarapN also signifies a blacksmith's fire-place: (K in art. kwr:)] pl. majaAmiru. (S.)

mujam~arN mjmr
Flesh-meat put upon live coals [to roast]. (A.)

mujam~irN mjmr
(S, Z) and mujomirN↓ (TA) One who collects together his hair, and ties it in knots, or makes it knotted and crisp, at the back of his neck, not letting it hang down loosely: (S:) or who plaits the hair of his head. (TA.) He who does so (while he is a muHorim, TA) is commanded to shave his head. (S and TA from a trad.) ＝ -A2- Also, both the former and jaAmirN↓, which is a possessive epithet, without a verb, One whose business is to fumigate garments [&c.] with perfume. (TA.)

1 jamaza jmz
, (S, A, &c.,) aor.
jamiza
, inf. n. jamozN (S, Msb, K) and jamazaY, (K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) said of a camel, (S, K,) and of a man, (A, K,) [He went at a gentle trot or run;] he went a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN, (S, A, Msb, K,) but not so quick as that termed HuDorN, (K,) or not so quick as a vehement HuDor; (TA;) he went the pace with which corpses are conveyed [to the tomb; which, according to the practice prescribed by Mohammad, is a quick pace]: (TA:) or simply, he went, or went along: (Msb:) and he ran; syn. EadaA: (Mgh, Msb:) and he went quickly. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) You say, jamaza biA@lojinaAzapi He went a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN [with the corpse upon its bier]. (A.) And jamaza Alr~ajulu fiY AlA^aroDa The man went away into, or in, the country or land. (Kr, K.)

2 jm~z jmz
, if used, He rode a camel such as is called jam~aAzN or jam~aAzapN. See the act. part. n., below.]

jamazaY jmzY jmzy
a subst. from jamaza; [signifying A gentle trot or run; a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN, but not so quick as that termed HuDorN, or not so quick as a vehement HuDor; &c.] (Msb.) You say, huwa yaEoduw AljamazaY, (A,) and Aln~aAqapu taEoduw AljamazaY, and in like manner Alfarasu, (Ks, S,) [He, and the she-camel, and the mare or horse, runs at the pace termed jamazaY.] ― -b2- See also jam~aAzN, in two places.

jam~aAzN jmAz
, applied to a he-camel, (S, K,) and jam~aAzapN, applied to a she-camel, (K,) That is ridden by the mujam~iz; (S;) that goes the pace described above, [voce jamazaY and] voce jamaza: (K, TA:) [the latter is also said in the TA to be mn A=laAt AlmHAml; but the correct reading seems to be mino A^uwlaAt AlmaHaAmili; and the meaning, of those that carry the vehicles called mHAml, pl. of maHomil.] ― -b2- HimaArN jam~aAzN An ass that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, quickly: (K:) and HimaArN jamazaY↓ a quick ass; (S, K;) or an ass that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, quickly, and is swift; (TA;) the latter word in this phrase used as a masc. and fem. epithet, though its final letter is a denotative of the fem. gender. (Ham p. 277. [See below; and see also HayadaY.]) Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee-'Áïdh (S, TA) El-Hudhalee (TA) says,
kaA^an~iY waraHoliY A_i*aA ruEotuhaA
jaAziy^K biAlr~imaAli EalaY jamazaY↓
[As though I and my she-camel's saddle, when I frightened her, were upon a swift wild ass satisfied with green pasture, so as to be in no need of water, in the sands]. (S, TA.) He likens his she-camel to a wild ass, to which he applies the epithet jmzY, that is, swift; meaning, EalaY HimaArK jamazaY. (TA.) As says that this is the only epithet of the measure faEalaY heard by him applied to a male; and that IAar cited the verse above to him saying Hay~idK biAld~iHaAli, meaning Eani Ald~iHaAli, [i. e., “ shying and turning aside from the hollows, narrow at the top but wide below, in the ground: ” but this is probably a reading of some in the place of HayadaY biAld~iHaAli, which ends the next verse, agreeably with what is said in the L in art. Hyd:] Az says that EalaY jamazaY may be explained as for EalaY EayorK *iY jamazaY, i. e., upon an ass having the mode of pace termed jamazaY; and naAqapN wakaraY has a similar meaning. (TA.) ― -b3- See also mujam~izN.

jum~ayozN jmyz
(S, K) and jum~ayozaY↓ (K) [The sycamorefig: and the sycamore fig-tree: ficus sycomorus; also called the Egyptian fig:] the male fig; (K, TA;) which is found in the Ghowr, or Ghór, [here meaning the Valley of the Jordan,] (TA,) and is sweet: (K, TA:) this is the yellow: the black makes the mouth bleed: (TA:) it is of various colours, or kinds, (A^alowaAn,) (K, * TA;) abundant in Syria and in Egypt: n. un. jum~ayozapN: (TA:) [a fruit] resembling the tiyn [or common fig]: (S:) AHn says, of the kinds of fig is the fig of the jum~ayoz, a sweet, moist fig, which has long fruit-stalks, and which is dried in the sun: and there is another species of the jm~yz, the fruit of which is like the fig in make, but its leaves are smaller than those of the fig, and its figs are yellow, of a small size, and black: it is found in the Ghowr, or Ghór, and is called the male fig: the yellow is sweet: the black makes the mouth bleed: and its fig has no stalk, but cleaves to the wood. ('Abd-el-Lateef, Account of Egypt: White's ed., entitled Abdollatiphi Historiæ Aegypti Compendium: p. 22. See also De Sacy's notes to his transl. of that work, pp. 82—86.) ― -b2- [Aljum~ayozapu also signifies (assumed tropical:) The pudendum muliebre: opposed to Alt~iynapu as meaning “ the anus. ”]

jum~ayozaY jmyz jmyzY jmyzy
: see jum~ayozN.

jum~ayoziY~N jmyz jmyzY jmyzy
A seller of jum~ayoz. (TA.)

mujam~izN mjmz
One who rides the camel called jam~aAz, (S, * TA,) or who rides the she-camel called jam~aAzap; (K, * TA;) as also jam~aAzN↓. (TA.)

1 jamasa jms
, (A, Msb, K,) aor.
jamusa
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. jumuwsN (S, Msb, K) and jamosN; (TA;) and jamusa, aor.
jamusa
; (TA;) It (grease, As, S, A, Msb, K, and clarified butter, and water, A, K, but jamada is more commonly said of the last, K, or jamasa is incorrect when said of water, As, TA) congealed. (As, S, A, Msb, K.)

jumosapN jmsh jmsp
A tough date: (IDrd, * M, K, * TA:) a date ripening (As, S, Z, K) altogether, (As, Z, K, TA,) but as yet hard, not mellow, or digestible, or easy of digestion: (As, S, Z, K:) pl. jumasN. (As, TA.) [See busorN.] ＝ -A2- Also A distinct number, or herd, of camels. (O, K.)

jaAmisN jAms
Grease, (A,) and clarified butter, (TA,) and water, (S,) or it is improperly applied to the last, (As, TA,) in a state of congelation. (S, A, Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- A plant that has lost its freshness, or juiciness, (AHn, K,) and become old, and hard, or tough. (AHn, TA.) ― -b3- SaxorapN jaAmisapN A tough rock, (TA,) firm in its place. (K, TA.) [In the TA is added muqo$aEir~apN: but this is evidently a mistranscription, for musotaqir~apN, which adds nothing to the explanation.]

jaAmuwsN jAmws
[The buffalo;] a kind of baqar; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) well known: (K:) n. un. with p: (K:) and pl. jawaAmiysu: (S, Msb, K:) an arabicized word, (T, S, K,) from the Persian; (T, S;) originally GaAwo miy$o. (T, K.)

1 jama$ahu *
, (S, A, K,) aor.
jami$a
and
jamu$a
, (TA,) inf. n. jamo$N, (S,) He shaved it, or removed its hair; (S, A, K;) namely, his pubes; (S;) or his head. (A, K.) And jama$atohu She shaved it; namely, her pudendum; or removed its hair: and it (nuwrap, q. v.) removed it; namely, hair. (A.)

jamuw$N *
, applied to nuwrap [q. v.], That removes hair; (S, K;) as also jamiy$N↓. (K.) ― -b2- Applied to a year (sanapN), (assumed tropical:) That shaves off, (S,) or nips, shrinks, shrivels, or blasts, [lit., burns, see A^aHoraqa,] (K,) the plants, or herbage. (S, K.)

jamiy$N *
, applied to the pubes, Shaven, or having its hair removed, (S, A, K, TA,) by means of nuwrap [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a place, (assumed tropical:) [Shorn of its plants, or herbage; or] having in it no plants, or herbage. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also jamuw$N.

1 jamaEa jmE
, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
jamaEa
, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. jamoEN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He collected; brought, or gathered, together; gathered up; assembled; congregated; mustered; drew together; or contracted; (Mgh, Er-Rághib, B, K; *) a thing; (Er-Rághib, Msb, B;) so that the several parts or portions became near together; (Er-Rághib, B;) or a thing in a scattered, or dispersed, state; (Fr, S;) and a number of men; (Fr;) as also jm~E↓; [or this has only an intensive signification;] and AjmE↓. (TA.) [See also the inf. n., jamoEN, below; and] see 2; and 10. ― -b2- [jamaEa bayonahumaA He brought them two together, into a state of union, after separation; and particularly, reconciled them; conciliated them: and he, or it, united, connected, or formed a connexion between, them two: see 3 (last sentence) in art. dnw.] ― -b3- jamaEa Ealayohi viyaAbahu He put on, or attired himself with, his clothes. (TA.) ― -b4- jamaEati AljaAriyapu The girl put on the diroE and the ximaAr and the miloHafap; (S, TA;) i. e., (tropical:) became a young woman; (S, K, TA;) became full-grown. (TA.) ― -b5- maA jamaEotu biA@moraA^apK qaT~u, and Eani A@moraA^apK, (assumed tropical:) I have never gone in to a woman; or I have never had a woman conducted to me as my bride. (Ks, K.) ― -b6- faA@jomaEuwA kayodakumo, and fajamaEa kayodahu: see 4. ― -b7- jamaEa A^amorahu: see 4. ― -b8- [jamaEa also signifies He composed, arranged, or settled, a thing, or an affair; as in the phrase jamaEa A@ll~`hu $amolahu: see art. $ml. ― -b9- Also It comprised, comprehended, or contained.] ― -b10- Also He pluralized a word; made it to have a plural, or plurals. (The Lexicons passim.)

2 jm~E jmE
, (Fr, Msb,) inf. n. tajomiyEN, (K,) He collected; brought, or gathered, together; gathered up; assembled; congregated; mustered; drew together; or contracted; [thus I render jamaEa, as explained above;] much; with much, or extraordinary, energy, or effectiveness, or the like; vigorously; or well. (Bd in civ. 2; Msb, K.) Thus in the Kur [civ. 2], Al~a*iY jam~aEa maAlFA waEad~adahu (S, * Bd) Who hath collected much wealth, and hath made it a provision for the casualties of fortune, or reckoned it time after time: (Bd:) [or who hath amassed, or accumulated, wealth, &c.:] or who hath gained, acquired, or earned, wealth, &c.; thus differing from jamaEa, explained above: but it is allowable to say maAlFA jamaEa↓, without teshdeed; (Fr;) and thus it is [generally] read in this passage of the Kur. (Bd.) See also 1. ― -b2- Ham~aEato, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) She (a hen) collected her eggs in her belly. (K, TA.) ― -b3- jam~aEuwA, (inf. n. as above, S,) They were present on the Friday, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or with the congregation [then collected], (Mgh,) and performed the prayers [with the congregation] on that day. (S, Mgh.) ― -b4- Hence the saying, A^aw~alu jumoEapK jum~iEato fiY AlA_isolaAmu baEoda Almadiynapi bijuw^aAviY [The first Friday that was observed by the performance of congregational prayer in the time of El-Islám, after the observance thereof in El-Medeeneh, was in Ju-áthà]. (TA.)

3 jAmEhu EalaY A^amori ka*aA *
, (S, K,) inf. n. mujaAmaEapN (TK) [and jimaAEN], He combined with him, (maEahu AjtmE↓, S, K, TA,) and aided him, (TA,) to do such a thing. (S, * K, * TA.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr, walaA jimaAEa lanaA fiymaA baEodu i. e. lanaA laAA@jotimaAEa↓ [which may mean Nor any combining, or nor any coming together, for us afterwards: see 8]. (TA.) ― -b2- jAmE A@moraA^atahu, (Msb,) inf. n. mujaAmaEapN (S, Msb, K) and jimaAEN, (Mgh, Msb,) (tropical:) He lay with his wife; compressed her. (S, * Mgh, * Msb, K. *) [The latter inf. n. is the more common as meaning Coïtus conjugalis, or the act of compressing]. ＝ -A2- AisotaA^ojara AlA^ajiyra mujaAmaEpF, and jimaAEFA, He hired the hireling for a certain pay every week. (Lh, * TA.)

4 AjmE A^jmE AjmE jmE
: see 1. A^ajomaEotu Al$~aYo'a signifies I put the thing together; such, for instance, as spoil, or plunder. (S.) You say, A^ajomaEotu Aln~ahobi, meaning I collected together from every quarter the camels taken as spoil from the people to whom they belonged, and drove them away: (AHeyth:) or A_ijomaAEN signifies [simply] the driving of camels together, or collectively. (K.) ― -b2- AlA_ijomaAEu also signifies The composing and settling a thing which has been discomposed [and unsettled]; as an opinion upon which one determines, resolves, or decides: (TA:) or jaEolu AlA^amori jamiyEFA baEoda tafar~uqihi, (AHeyth, K,) i. e. the determining, resolving, or deciding, upon an affair, so as to make it firmly settled, [after it had been unsettled in the mind, or] after considering what might be its issues, or results, and saying at one time, I will do thus, and at another time, I will do thus. (AHeyth.) You say, A^ajomaEotu AlA^amora, (Ks, S, Mgh, * Msb, K,) and EalaY AlA^amori, (Mgh, * Msb, K,) I determined, resolved, or decided, upon the affair; (Ks, S, Mgh, * Msb, K;) as though I collected myself, or my mind, for it; (TA;) as, for instance, a journeying, and a fasting, (Mgh, Msb,) and a going forth, and a tarrying or an abiding; (TA;) and in like manner, A^amorahu jamaEa↓ He determined, resolved, or decided, upon his affair; as, for instance, a fasting: (TA:) and A^ajomaEotu Alr~aA^oYi I determined, or settled, the opinion. (TA.) You say also, A^ajomiEo A^amoraka walaA tadaEohu munota$irFA [Determine thou, or decide, upon thine affair, and do not leave it unsettled]. (S.) The saying, in the Kur [x. 72], faA^ajomaEuwA A^amorakumo wa$urakaA='a kumo means Then determine ye, or resolve, or decide, upon your affair, (Fr, Ibn-'Arafeh, Bd,) and prepare for it, (Fr,) or AijoEaluwhu jamiyEFA, [which has the former of these meanings, as shown above,] (AHeyth,) and call ye your companions, (Fr, S, Bd, K,) $rkA'km being governed in the accus. case by the verb understood, (Bd, TA,) becanse the verb in the text is not used with $rkA' for its object, (S, K,) but only the unaugmented verb: (S:) or the meaning is then determine ye, with your companions, upon your affair; (Bd, K;) so says Aboo-Is-hák, adding that what Fr says is erroneous: (TA:) or then determine ye upon your affair and the affair of your companions, for waA^amora $urakaAy^ikumo. (Bd.) It is also said that the phrase, in the Kur [xx. 67], faA^ajomiEuwA kayodakumo means Therefore determine ye, or resolve, or decide, upon your artifice, or stratagem: (TA:) but some read kayodakumo faA@jomaEuwA↓, (Bd, TA,) meaning therefore combine ye all your artifice; leave nothing thereof unexerted; (TA;) and this latter reading is favoured by the phrase kayodahu fajamaE↓ [in verse 62 of the same ch.]. (Bd.) ― -b3- Also The agreeing, or uniting, in opinion. (K, * TA.) You say, A^ajomaEuwA EalaY AlA^amori meaning They agreed, or were of one mind or opinion, upon, or respecting, the affair; (Mgh, Msb;) [and so Ealayohi AjtmEwA↓;
and Elyh tjm~EwA↓.] ― -b4- Also The preparing [a thing], or making [it] ready; syn. AlA_iEodaAdu. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, AlAaEodaAdu.]) You say, A^ajomaEotu ka*aA I prepared, or made ready, such a thing. (TA.) And A^ajomiEuwA A^amorakumo Prepare ye for your affair. (Fr.) ― -b5- Also The binding the teats of a she-camel all together with the SiraAr, q. v. (K.) You say, AjmE biAln~aAqapi, (S, TA,) and AjmE Aln~aAqapi, (TA,) He so bound the teats of the she-camel; (S, TA;) and so A^akoma$a bihaA. (TA.) ― -b6- Also The drying [a thing]; drying [it] up; making [it] dry; syn. Alt~ajofiyfu waAlA_iybaAsu. (K TA. [In the CK, erroneously, Altaxofuyfu wAlAiyonAsu.]) Hence the saying of Aboo-Wejzeh Es-Saadee,
waA^ajomaEati AlhawaAjiru kul~a rajoEK
mina AlA^ajomaAdi waAld~amivi AlbavaA='i
i.e. [And the vehement mid-day-heats] dried up every pool left by a torrent [of the hard and elevated grounds and of the soft and even ground]. (TA.) ― -b7- AjmE AlmaTaru AlA^aroDi The rain made the whole of the land, both its soft tracts and its hard tracts, to flow: (K:) and in like manner you say, A^ajomaEati AlA^aroDu saAy^ilapF The land flowed in its soft tracts [as well as in its hard tracts; i. e., in every part]. (TA.) [See also 10.]

5 tajam~aEa
see 8, in three places: and see also 4, latter half.

7 AnjmE Eani Aln~aAsi AnjmE En AlnAs
[He withdrew himself from men]. (TA in art. qbD.)

8 AjtmE A^jtmE AjtmE {jtmE
It (a thing in a scattered or dispersed state, S, and a number of men, Msb, [and a number of things,]) became collected, brought together, gathered together, gathered up, assembled, congregated, mustered, drawn together, or contracted; or it collected, collected itself together, gathered itself together, came together, assembled, congregated, drew itself together, contracted itself; coalesced; combined; (K, TA;) so that the several parts or portions became near [or close] together; (TA;) as also AijodamaEa, (K,) with d [substituted for the t]; (TA;) and tjm~E↓ and AstjmE↓ signify the same: (Msb, K:) and tjm~EwA↓ signifies they became collected, &c., [from several places, or] hence and thence. (S, K:) [See also 10.] You say also, AjtmE maEahu (Mgh) and bihi (Msb) [meaning He was, or became, in company with him; came together with him; met with him; met him; had a meeting, or an interview, with him]. And AjtmE maEahu EalaY A^amori ka*aA: (S, K:) see 3, first sentence: and see the sentence there next following. And in like manner, EalaY tjm~EwA↓ fulaAnK They combined, conspired, or leagued, together against such a one. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. Dfr.) [See also AjtmEwA EalaY AlA^amori in 4, latter half.] You also say, AijotamaEati A=raAw^uhumo EalaY AlA^amori [Their opinions agreed together, or were in unison, upon, or respecting, the affair]. (Er-Rághib.) And AijotamaEato $araAy^iTu AlA_imaAmapi The conditions of the office of Imám occurred together [or were combined, or they coexisted, in such a case]; as also AisotajomaEato↓. (Msb: [but it is implied in the Mgh that the latter verb in this sense is not of established authority.]) [See a similar ex. voce ArtfE.] ― -b2- [He, or it, was, or became, compact in make or frame, compressed, contracted, or the like. ― -b3- And hence,] He (a man) attained to his full state of manly vigour, and his beard became fullgrown. (K, TA.) The verb is not thus used in speaking of a woman. (S, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] AjtmE fiY AlHaAjapi [He was quick and vigorous in executing the needful affair, or in accomplishing that which was wanted; as though he compacted his frame, and collected all his energy: see ma$aY mujotamiEFA, below: and see also 10]. (TA in art. km$.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] AijotamaEati Alqidoru The cooking-pot boiled. (Z, TA.) ― -b6- [Hence also, AjtmE said of a thing, or an affair, It was, or became, composed, arranged, or settled.]

10 A_isotajomaEa
AstjmE kul~a majomaEK↓ [He desired, or demanded, the collecting together of every body of soldiers; or he summoned together every body of soldiers]: said of him who demands, or summons, armies, or military forces. (S, TA.) [But this usage of the verb is perhaps post-classical: for Mtr says,] With respect to the saying of ElAbeewardee,
$aA=miy~apN tasotajomiEu Al$~awola Harojafu
[A north wind, cold and vehement, inviting to collect themselves together the she-camels whose milk has dried up, they having passed seven or eight months since bringing forth, or since pregnancy], it seems that he has compared this verb with the generality of others of the same class, [and so derived the meaning in which he has here used it,] or that he heard it [in that sense] from the people of the cities, or towns, or villages, and cultivated lands. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- AstjmE used intransitively is syn. with AjtmE, which see in two places, and tjm~E. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- AstjmE Als~ayolu The torrent collected itself together from every place. (S, Mgh, K.) ― -b3- AstjmE AlwaAdiY The valley flowed in every place thereof. (TA.) [See also 4, last signification.] ― -b4- AisotajomaEato lahu A^umuwruhu His affairs, or circumstances, all combined in a manner pleasing to him. (Mgh, K.) ― -b5- AstjmE Alfarasu jaroyFA (S, Mgh, K) The horse exerted all his force, or energy, in running: (K, TA:) the last word is here in the accus. case as a specificative. (Mgh.) You say also, AisotajomaEuwA lahumo, meaning They exerted [all] their strength, force, or energy, for fighting them: and hence, lakumo A_in~a Aln~aAsi qado jamaEuwA↓ [app. meaning Verily the men, or people, have exerted all their strength for fighting you]. (A, TA.) ― -b6- AstjmE Alqawomu The people, or company of men, all went away, not one of them remaining; like as one says of a valley flowing in every place thereof. (TA.) ― -b7- AstjmE Albaqolu The herbs, or leguminous plants, all dried up. (TA.)

jamoEN jmE
inf. n. of 1. (S, &c.) [Hence,] yawomu AljamoEi The day of resurrection [when all mankind will be collected together]. (IDrd, K.) ― -b2- Also, without the article Al, A name of El-Muzdelifeh [between 'Arafát and Minè]; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) determinate, like EarafaAtu: (TA:) so called because people collect themselves there; (S, Msb;) or because Adam there met with Eve (Mgh, Msb) after they had fallen [from Paradise]: (TA:) [or, app., a name of the tract from 'Arafát to Minè inclusive of these two places: and hence,] yawomu jamoEK the day of 'Arafeh [when the pilgrims halt at Mount 'Arafát]: and A^ay~aAmu jamoEK the days of Minè. (IDrd, K.) ― -b3- As an inf. n. used as a subst., properly so termed, (S, * Mgh, Msb,) it also signifies A collection; a number together; an assembly; a company, troop, congregated or collective body, party, or group; a mass; syn. jamaAEapN↓, (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) of men; (S, L, K;) as also majomaEN↓ (L, Msb, TA) and majomiEN↓ (Msb) and majomaEapN↓ (L, TA) and jamiyEN↓: (O, K:) but jamaAEapN↓ is also used as signifying a collection, a number together, or an assemblage, of other things than men; [of beasts, as camels, horses and the like, bulls and cows, and antelopes, gazelles, &c., i. e. a herd, troop, or drove; of dogs, i. e. a pack; of sheep and goats, i. e. a flock; of birds, i. e. a flock or bevy; of bees, and locusts, &c., i. e. a swarm;] and even of trees, and of plants; (L, TA;) it signifies a collection, or an assemblage, or aggregate, of any things, consisting of many and of few; (Msb;) [as also majomuwEN↓ and majomaEN↓;] a number, a plurality, and a multitude, of any things: (TA:) the pl. of jamoEN is jumuwEN. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b4- And particularly, An army; a military force; (TA;) as also jamiyEN↓. (S, K.) Whence the phrase, in a trad., lahu sahomN jamoEN, [or, more probably, sahomu jamoEK,] meaning For him or shall be, the like of an army's share of the spoil. (TA.) ― -b5- Also The plural of a thing [or word; i. e. a proper plural, according to the grammarians; and also applied by the lexicologists to a quasi-plural noun, which the grammarians distinguish by the terms Aisomu jamoEK and jamoEN lugawiY~N]; and so jimaAEN↓, (S, K,) and jamiyEN↓, except that this last is what is termed AisomN laAzimN [app. meaning a subst. which does not govern another as its complement in the gen. case like as jamoEN and jimaAEN do, being thus likened to what is termed fiEolN laAzimN, i. e. an intransitive verb; so that you say of AlxibaA='u, for instance, AljamiyEu AlA^axobiyapu the plural is AlAxbyp; for in this manner I always find it used when it has this signification, which is frequently the case in several of the older lexicons, and in some others; not jamiyEu AlxibaA='i AlA^axobiyapu]; (TA;) [whereas] you say, [jamoEu AlxibaA='i AlA^axobiyapu and] jimaAEu↓ AlxibaA='i AlA^axobiyapu, (S, K,) i. e. the jamoE [or plural] of AlxbA' is AlxibaA='i; (K) for AljimaAEu↓ is what comprises a number [of things]. (S, K.) See also this last word below. ― -b6- And see also the next paragraph, in three places. ― -b7- The worst sort of dates; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) because they are collected together and mixed, (Mgh, Msb,) from among the dates of fifty palm-trees: (Mgh:) and afterwards, by predominant usage,
[any] bad dates: (Mgh, * Msb:) or a certain kind of dates (K, TA) mixed together, of several sorts, not in request, and not mixed but for their badness: (TA:) or it signifies, (Mgh, K,) or signifies also, (S, Msb,) palm-trees (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K) of any kind, (As, Mgh, Msb,) growing from the date-stones, (S, K,) of which the name is unknown. (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b8- Red gum; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) [app. because collected and mixed with gum of lighter colour.] ― -b9- The milk of any camel having her udder bound with the SiraAr [q. v.]; ([i. e. the milk that collects in the udder so bound;] that of any camel not having her udder bound therewith is called fuwaAqN;) as also jamiyEN↓. (K.)

AljumoEu AljmE jmE
, (TA, and EM p. 102,) and jumoEu Alkaf~i, (S, Msb, K,) and Alkaf~i jimoEu↓, (Msb, K, and so in the margin of a copy of the S, as mentioned in the TA,) and Alkaf~i jamoEu↓, (Msb,) The fist; the hand clinched; (S, Msb, K;) the hand with the fingers put together and contracted in the palm: (TA, * and EM ubi suprà:) pl. A^ajomaAEN. (K.) You say, Darabotuhu bijumoEi kaf~iY I beat him, or struck him, with my fist. (S, Msb. *) And Darabuwhu biA^ajomaAEihimo They beat him, or struck him, with their [clinched] hands. (TA.) And jaA='a fulaAnN biquboDapK milo'K jumoEihi Such a one came with a quantity in his grasp as much as filled his clinched hand. (S, TA.) And jumoEu Alkaf~i signifies [also] The quantity that a hand grasps, of money &c. (Ham p. 778.) ― -b2- A^axa*otu fulaAnFA bijumoEi viyaAbihi, (S, Msb, *) and bijamoEi↓ viyaAbihi, (Msb,) i. e. [I took, or seized, such a one] by the part where his garments met together. (Msb.) ― -b3- A^amoruhumo bijumoEi, and bijimoEK↓, (tropical:) Their affair, or case, is concealed, (S, K,) undivulged by them, and unknown by any one [beside them]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- *ahaba Al$~ahoru bijumoEK, and bijimoEK↓, The month passed away wholly; all of it. (K, TA.) ― -b5- hiYa mino zawojihaA bijumoEK, (S, Mgh, K,) and bijimoEK↓, (S, K,) She is as yet undevirginated, or undeflowered, (S, Mgh, K,) by her husband. (S, Mgh.) And Tul~iqato bijumoEK, or bijimoEK↓, She was divorced being yet a virgin. (TA.) And maAtato bijumoEK, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and bijimoEK↓, (Ks, S, Msb, K,) and bijamoEK↓, (K,) She died a virgin: (Mgh, Msb, K:) or it signifies, (S, K,) or signifies also, (Mgh, Msb,) she died being with child; (AZ, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) whether suffering the pains of parturition or not: (AZ:) or heavy with child: (K:) occurring in the first sense, (Mgh, TA,) or, as some say, in the last, (TA,) in a trad., in which it is said that a woman who so dies is a martyr: (Mgh, TA:) it properly signifies she died with something comprised in her, not separated from her, whether it were a burden in the womb, or her maidenhead: (Sgh:) [the pl. is A^ajomaAEN; for] you say, maAtati Aln~isaA='u biA^ajomaAEK The women died [being virgins: or] being with child. (AZ.) You say also, naAqapN jumoEN A she-camel with young. (TA.) And AimoraA^apN jaAmiEN↓ A woman with child. (TA.)

jimoEN jmE
: see the next preceding paragraph, in six places.

jumaEN jmE
pl. of jamoEaA='u, fem. of A^ajomaEu [q. v.].

jumoEapN jmE jmEh jmEp
is [a subst.] from AlAijotimaAEu, like as [its contr.] furoqapN is [ a subst.] from AlAAifotiraAqu: (Mgh:) and signifies A state of union, agreement, congruity, or congregation: or sociableness, socialness, familiarity, companionableness, companionship, fellowship, friendship, and amity: syn. A^ulofapN: as in the saying, A^adaAma A@ll~`hu jumoEapa maA bayonakumaA [May God make permanent the state of union, &c., subsisting between you two]. (Aboo-Sa'eed, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh,) yawomu AljumoEapi, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) the original form, (TA,) of the dial. of 'Okeyl; (Msb, TA;) and yawomu AljumuEapi, (S, Msb, K,) the most chaste form, (TA,) of the dial. of El-Hijáz; (Msb, TA;) and yawomu AljumaEapi, (Msb, K,) of the dial. of Benoo-Temeem; (Msb, TA;) and, in consequence of frequency of usage, AljumaEapu alone; (Mgh;) A well-known day; (K;) [the day of the congregation; i. e. Friday;] formerly called (TA) the day of AlEaruwbap: (S, TA:) called ywm AljmEp because of the congregating of the people thereon: (Msb:) Th asserts that the first who named it thus was Kaab Ibn-Lu-eí; and he is related to have said that it was thus called because Kureysh used to gather themselves together to Kuseí, [on that day,] in [the building called] daAru Aln~adowapi: (TA:) accord. to the R, Kaab Ibn-Lu-eí was the first who collected a congregation on the day of AlErwbp, which was not called AljmEp save since the coming of El-Islám; [or it was not generally thus called before El-Islám; for it is added,] and he was the first who named it AljmEp; for Kureysh used to congregate to him on this day, and he used to preach to them, and to put them in mind of the mission of the apostle of God, informing them that he should be of his descendants, and bidding them to follow him and to believe in him: (TA:) or, as some say, it was thus called in the time of El-Islám because of their congregating [thereon] in the mosque: accord. to a trad., the Ansár named it thus, because of their congregating thereon: (TA:) or it was thus named because God collected thereon the materials of which Adam was created: (I 'Ab:) those who say AljumaEapu regard it as an epithet, meaning that this day collects men much; comparing it to humazapN and lumazapN and DuHakapN: (TA:) the pl. is jumaEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jumoEaAtN (Msb, K) and jumuEaAtN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jumaEaAtN; (Msb, K;) of which the last is pl. of jumaEapN, [as well as of jumoEapN, accord. to analogy,] but not so jumaEN (AHát) [nor either of the other pls. mentioned above]. ― -b3- In like manner you say SalaApN AljumoEapi [The prayer of Friday], and, in consequence of the frequency of usage, AljumoEapu alone. (Mgh.) ― -b4- AljumoEapu, with the m quiescent, is also a name for [The week; i. e.] the days of the week [collectively]; of which the Arabs are said, by IAar, to have reckoned the Sabbath (Als~abot [i. e. Saturday]) as the first, though they called Sunday the first of the days. (Msb.) ― -b5- jumoEapN is also syn. with majomuwEapN [meaning Things collected together; or a collection of things]; (K;) as in the phrase jumoEapN mino HaSFY [a collection of pebbles]. (TA.) ― -b6- You say also jumoEapN mino tamorK, meaning A handful of dates. (S, K.)

[
jamoEiY~N jmE jmEY jmEy
Of, or relating to, a plural.]

jumaEiY~N jmE jmEY jmEy
One who fasts on Friday by himself. (IAar, Th.)

jimaAEN jmAE
: see jamoEN as signifying “ a plural, ” in three places. [The primary signification seems to be the last there mentioned; where it is said,] AljimaAEu is What comprises a number [of things]: (S, K:) one says, Alxamoru jimaAEu AlA_ivomi (S, TA) [i. e. Wine is what comprises a number of sins: or] that in which sin is comprised, and known to be: the saying is a trad.: (TA:) or jimaAEu AlA_ivomi signifies the plurality (jamoE) of sins. (Msb.) Hence also the saying of El-Hasan El-Basree, Ait~aquwA h`*ihi AlA^ahowaA='a faA_in~a jimaAEahaA AlD~alaAlapu wamaEaAdahaA Aln~aAru [Beware ye of these natural desires; for what they involve is error, and the place to which they lead is the fire of Hell]. (TA: in the L, wmyEAdhA.) And it is said in a trad., Had~ivoniY bikalimapK takuwnu jimaAEFA i. e. Tell me a saying comprising [virtually] a plurality of sayings. (TA.) [See a similar phrase below, voce jaAmiEN.] ― -b2- [Hence also,] buromapN jimaAEN A stonecooking-pot of the largest size: (Ks, L:) or qidorN jimaAEN, and jaAmiEapN↓, (S, K, TA,) a cooking-pot that comprises a slaughtered camel; or, accord. to the A, that comprises a sheep or goat: (TA:) or a great cooking-pot; (S, K;) as also jaAmiEN↓: (Sgh, K:) pl. [most probably of this last] jumoEN [like as buzolN is pl. of baAzilN, &c.]. (K.) ― -b3- You say also, fulaAnN jimaAEN libaniY fulaAnK Such a one is an object of resort for his counsel and authority to the sons of such a one. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [See also 3.]

jamuwEN jmwE
: see jam~aAEN.

jamiyEN jmyE
In a state of collection, congregation, or union; being together; met together; [as also mujotamiEN↓;] contr. of mutafar~iqN. (S, K.) You say qawomN jamiyEN A people, or number of men, in a state of collection, &c.; being together; met together; syn. mujotamiEuwna↓: (TA:) and in like manner, A_ibilN jam~aAEapN↓ Camels in a state of collection; &c. (TA.) ― -b2- [All, or the whole, of any things or thing.] See A^ajomaEu, last sentence. ― -b3- [As an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] A tribe [or any number of men] in a state of collection, congregation, or union; being together; met together; syn. HaY~N mujotamiEN↓. (S, K.) See also jamoEN, in four places. ― -b4- A man compact, or compressed, or contracted, in make, or frame: (Alxaloqi mujotamiEu↓;) strong; who has not become decrepit nor infirm. (TA.) ― -b5- rajulN jamiyEN All~aA^omapi A man having his arms, or weapons, collected together. (TA.) ― -b6- rajulN jamiyEu Alr~aA^oYi, and mujotamiEuhu↓, A man of right, not disordered or unsettled, opinion, or judgment, or counsel. (TA.) ― -b7- jaEala
AlA^amora jamiyEFA baEoda tafar~uqihi (AHeyth, K) He determined, resolved, or decided, upon the affair, so as to make it firmly settled, [after it had been unsettled in his mind, or] after considering what might be its issues, or results, and saying at one time, I will do thus, and at another time, I will do thus. (AHeyth.)

jamaAEapN jmAE jmAEh jmAEp
: see jamoEN, in two places.

jam~aAEN jmAE
and mijomaEN↓ [are mentioned together, but not explained, in the TA: the former signifies, and probably, judging from analogy, the latter likewise, as also jamuwEN↓, One who collects much; or who collects many things]. ― -b2- A_ibilN jam~aAEapN: see jamiyEN

jum~aAEN jmAE
Anything of which the several component parts are collected, brought, gathered, or drawn, together. (IDrd, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] as an epithet, applied to a woman, it means Short. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] jum~aAEN Alv~uray~aA The cluster of the Pleiades: (IDrd:) or persons who collect together for the rain of the Pleiades, which is the rain called AlwasomiY~, looking for the fruitfulness and herbage resulting from it. (IAar.) ― -b4- And jum~aAEu Aln~aAsi A medley, or mixed or promiscuous multitude or collection, of men, or people, (S, Msb, K,) of various tribes; (S, K;) as also jum~aAEN alone: (TA:) or the latter, people scattered, or in a state of dispersion. (Ham p. 302.) ― -b5- jum~aAEN also signifies The place [either properly or tropically] which comprises the origin of anything; (K, TA;) the source of descent or extraction of people; and hence applied by I 'Ab to main tribes from which other tribes are derived; or, as some say, used by him as meaning various classes of men, such as are termed A^awozaAE and A^awo$aAb. (TA.) ― -b6- [And The main, or most essential, part of a thing. Thus,] jum~aAEu jasadi AlA_inosaAni means The head of the man. (TA.) ― -b7- jum~aAEu Alt~amori The contraction (tajam~uE) of the envelopes of the flowers of dates, in one place, upon [the germs of] the fruit, or produce, thereof. (TA.)

jaAmiEN jAmE
[act. part. n. of 1; Collecting; &c.] ― -b2- AljaAmiEu one of the names of God; meaning The Collector of the created beings for the day of reckoning: or, as some say, the Combiner of things of similar natures and of things of contrary natures, in existence. (IAth.) ― -b3- The belly; [because it collects what passes from the stomach;] of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, (Msb,) or Almasojidu AljaAmiEu, (S, K,) [The congregational mosque;] the mosque in which the [congregational] prayers of Friday are performed; because it collects the people for a certain time; (Msb;) and you may also say, masojidu AljaAmiEi, meaning masojidu Alyawomi AljaAmiEi, (S, K,) like as you say AlHaq~u Alyaqiynu and Haq~u Alyaqiyni, [the latter] as meaning Haq~u Al$~aYo'i Alyaqiyni; for it is not allowable to prefix a noun to another of the same meaning except with this kind of subaudition; or, accord. to Fr, the Arabs used to do so because of the difference of the two words themselves: (S:) or msjd AljAmE is a mistake: (K:) so says Lth; but all others allow it; for the Arabs prefix a subst. to another signifying the same thing, and also to its epithet, as in the phrases in the Kur diynu Alqay~imapi [ch. xcviii. v. 4] and waEoda AlS~idoqi [ch. xlvi. v. 15]: (Az, TA:) [pl. jawaAmiEu.] ― -b5- miSorN jaAmiEN [A great town comprising a large population; a comprehensive great town]. (Msb in art. mdn [where it is given as the explanation of madiynapN]; and K in art. qrY [where it is less properly given as the explanation of qaroyapN].) ― -b6- qidorN jaAmiEN and jaAmiEapN: see jimaAEN ― -b7- AimoraA^apN jAmiEN: see the paragraph commencing with AljumoEu; last signification. ― -b8- A^ataAnN jaAmiEN A she-ass pregnant when beginning to be so. (S, O, K.) ― -b9- jaAmiEapN↓ A [collar of the kind called] gul~; (S, K;) because it collects together the two hands to the neck: (S:) pl. jawaAmiEu. (TA.) ― -b10- A^amorN jaAmiEN An affair that collects people together: or, as Er-Rághib says, a momentous affair, on account of which people collect themselves together; as though the affair itself collected them. (TA.) [Similar to this is the saying,] AlS~alaApu jaAmiEapN likul~i Aln~aAsi Prayer is a collector of all people. (Msb.) ― -b11- It is said of Mohammad, (Msb,) kaAna yatakal~amu bijawaAmiEi Alkalimi He used to speak comprehensive but concise language; language conveying many meanings in few words. (Msb, K. [In the CK, Alklm is omitted.]) And hence the saying of 'Omar Ibn-'Abd-el-'Azeez, Eajibotu limano laAHana Aln~aAsa kayofa laA yaEorifu jawaAmiEa Alkalimi, meaning [I wonder at him who vies with men in endeavouring to show his superiority of intelligence,] how it is that he does not [know the way to] confine himself to conciseness, and abstain from superfluity, of speech. (TA.) In like manner, (TA,) it is said in a trad., A^uwtiytu jawaAmiEa Alkalimi, meaning I have had communicated to me the Kur-án, (K, TA,) in which many meanings are comprised in a few words. (TA.) AljawaAmiEu mina Ald~uEaA='i, also, signifies Prayers, or supplications, combining petitions for good and right objects of desire with praise of God and with the general prescribed observances proper to the case. (TA.) You say also, AlmaHaAmidi Hamidotu A@ll~`ha bimajaAmiEi↓ I praised God with words comprising various forms of praise. (Msb.) [See also jimaAEN.] ― -b12- rajulN jaAmiEN A man who combines such qualities that he is suited to hardship and to easiness of circumstances. (As. T in art. Adm.) And rajulN jaAmiEN liloxayori (T and M and K in art. Am) A man combining all kinds of good qualities. (TK in that art.) ― -b13- daAb~apN jaAmiEN A beast fit for the A_ikaAf and the saroj [i. e. for the saddle of either of the kinds thus called]. (Sgh, K.) ― -b14- jamalN jaAmiEN, and naAqapN jaAmiEapN, (K,) accord. to ISh, (TA,) A hecamel, and a she-camel, that fails of putting forth the tooth called nAb at the time expected; expl. by A^axolafaA buzuwlFA: but this is not said except after four years: (K:) so in the copies of the K; but correctly, accord. to the O and TS, this is not said after four years, [app. reckoned from the usual time of bzwl, for this is in the ninth year, or, sometimes, in the eighth,] without the exceptive particle. (TA.)

jaAmiEapN jAmE jAmEh jAmEp
used as a subst.: see the next preceding paragraph.

A^ajomaEu *
[Collecting, comprising, or containing, a greater, or the greatest, number or quantity; more, or most, comprehensive. Of its usage in a superlative sense, the following are exs.]. A_i*aA A^axa*a $aAhida zuwrK baEava bihi A_ilaY Als~uwqi A^ajomaEa maA kaAna [When he took a false witness, he sent him to the market when it comprised, or contained, the greatest number of people]: AjmE being here in the accus. case as a denotative of state with respect to the swq: and the reason why kAnt is not here said [instead of kAn] is that swq is sometimes masc. (Mgh.) And AifoEalo maA huwa A^ajomaEu liA^uSuwli AlA^aHokaAmi [Do thou that which is most comprehensive in relation to the principles of the ordinances applying to the case]. (Msb in art. HwT.) ＝ -A2- [As a simple epithet, Entire, complete, or whole: fem. jamoEaA='u. You say,] bahiymapN jamoEaA='u A beast free from defects, entire in all its limbs or members, without mutilation, and without cauterization; (TA;) a beast from the body of which nothing has gone. (S, K.) ― -b2- naAqapN jamoEaA='u [may sometimes have the like meaning: or,] accord. to IAar, (TA,) A she-camel extremely aged, (K, TA,) so that her teeth have become short, and almost gone. (TA.) ＝ -A3- It is also a sing. having the meaning of a pl., (S, K,) without any proper sing. of its own: (S:) its pl. is A^ajomaEuwna: and its fem. is jamoEaA='u: (S, K:) and the pl. of this last is jumaEu, though by rule it should be formed by the addition of A and t to the sing., like as the pl. of A^ajomaEu is formed by the addition of w and n; (S;) the original form from which jumaEu is changed being jamoEaAwaAtN; or it is jamaAEaY; it is not jumoEN, because A^ajomaEu is not an epithet, like as A^aHomaru is, of which the pl. is HumorN; (L;) for it is determinate, though of the measure of an epithet, which is indeterminate; (AAF;) and though it is in concordance with the noun which precedes it, like an epithet, it is shown to be not an epithet by its not having a broken pl.: (L:) it is a simple corroborative; (S, K;) and so are A^ajomaEuwna and jamoEaA='u and jumaEu; not used as an inchoative nor as an enunciative nor as the agent of a verb nor as the objective complement of a verb, like as are some other corroboratives, such as nafosuhu and Eayonuhu and kul~uhu. (S.) You say, A^axa*otu Haq~iY A^ajomaEa [I took my right, or due, all of it, or altogether]: and rA^ayotu Aln~isowapa jumaEa [I saw the women, all of them, or all together]: the last word in this and similar cases being imperfectly declinable, and determinate word: (Sudot;, TA:) and jaAw^uwA A^ajomaEuwna [They came, all of them, or all together]: and raA^ayotuhumo A^ajomaEiyna [I saw them, all of them, or all together]: and mararotu bihimo A^ajomaEiyna [I passed by them, all of them, or all together]. (Msb.) Fr mentions the phrases, A^aEojabaniY AlqaSoru A^ajomaEa [The palace pleased me, all of it, or altogether], and Ald~aAru jamoEaA='a [The house,
all of it, or altogether], with the accus. case, as denotative of state; but does not allow A^ajomaEuwna nor jumaEu to be used otherwise than as corroboratives: IDrst, however, allows A^ajomaEiyna to be used as a denotative of state; and this is correct; and accord. to both these ways is related the trad., faSal~uwA juluwsFA A^ajomaEiyna and A^ajomaEuwna [And pray ye sitting, all of you, or all together]; though some make AjmEyn [here] to be a corroborative of a pronoun understood in the accus. case, as though the speaker said, A^aEoniykumo A^ajomaEiyna [I mean you, all of you, or all together]: (K in art. btE:) or AjmEyn in this case is a corruption committed by the relaters in the first age; and he is in error who says that it is in the accus. case as a denotative of state, for corroboratives are determinate, and the denotative of state is literally or virtually indeterminate. (Msb.) [Respecting the usage of this corroborative together with others similar to it, see A^abotaEu.] You say also, jaAw^uwA biA^ajomaEihimo, and biA^ajomuEihimo, with damm to the m, [They came, all of them, or all together,] (S, Msb, K,) the latter mentioned by ISk. (Msb.) And you say, qabaDotu AlmaAla A^ajomaEahu [I took, or received, the property, all of it, or altogether]. (Msb.) And jamiyEN↓, also, is used as a corroborative: (S, Msb:) as in the saying jaAw^uwA jamiyEFA, meaning They came, all of them: (S:) and qabaDotu AlmaAla jamiyEahu, like A^ajomaEahu [explained above]: (Msb:) and jamiyEapF occurs as its fem.; but this is extr. (TA.)

majomaEN mjmE
and majomiEN, (S, Msb, K,) the latter anomalous, like ma$oriqN and magoribN &c., (TA,) A place of collecting, and the like: (S, Msb, * K:) [pl. majaAmiEu] [Hence,] majomaEu AlbaHorayoni, in the Kur [xviii. 59], means The place where the two seas meet. (Bd.) And in like manner, where it is said in a trad., fDaraba biyadihi majomaEa bayona EunuqiY wakatifiY, [in which maA seems to have been dropped by the copyist between mjmE and byn,] the meaning is, [And he struck with his hand] the place where my neck and my shoulder-blade meet. (TA.) [Hence also the phrase majaAmiEu AlmaHaAmidi, explained above: see jaAmiEN, near the end of the paragraph. And majaAmiEu AlA^umuwri, meaning The concurrences of affairs, or of circumstances, or of events.] ― -b2- A place in which people collect, assemble, or congregate: (Msb, * TA:) and [in like manner,] majomaEapN↓ signifies an assembly-room; a sitting room in which people assemble: (TA:) [pl. of both majaAmiEu.] You say, h`*aA AlkalaAmu A^awolaju fiY AlmasaAmiEi waA^ajowalu fiY AlmajaAmiEi [This language, or discourse, is more, or most, penetrating into the ears, and more, or most, circulating in the places of assembly]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also jamoEN, as syn. with jamaAEapN, in two places; and see 10, first sentence. ― -b4- [The whole of anything, considered as the place in which the several parts thereof are collected: see an instance voce xuf~N: and see also mujotamaEN.]

A^amorN mujomaEN *
, (S, K,) and mujomaEN Ealayohi, (TA,) An affair determined, resolved, or decided, upon: (S, K:) an affair agreed upon. (TA.) [The former signification applies to both of the abovementioned phrases: the latter signification, perhaps, only to the latter phrase.] ― -b2- xuTobapN mujomaEapN [A discourse in rhyming prose, or the like,] in which is no flaw, or defect. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.)

EaAmN mujomiEN EAm mjmE
A year of dearth, drought, sterility, or unfruitfulness: (Ks, K:) because it is an occasion of people's collecting together in the place where herbage, or plenty, is found. (Ks.) And falaApN mujomiEapN, (S, TA,) like muHosinapN; (TA;) [in Gol. Lex., erroneously, mujomaEapN;] and mujam~iEapN↓, like muHad~ivapN; (TA;) A desert in which people collect themselves together, not separating themselves, from fear of losing their way, or perishing, and the like; as though the desert itself collected them. (S, TA.) And A^aroDN mujomiEapN, like muHosinapN, A land of dearth, drought, sterility, or unfruitfulness, wherein the camels upon which people journey are not dispersed to pasture. (TA.)

mijomaEN mjmE
: see jam~aAEN.

majomaEapN mjmE mjmEh mjmEp
: see majomaEN: ― -b2- and jamoEN, as syn. with jamaAEapN. ＝ -A2- Also Sands collected together: (K:) pl. majaAmiEu. (TA.) And A vacant, or void, land, destitute of herbage or vegetable produce, and of water. (AA, K.)

falaApN mujam~iEapN flAp mjmEh flAp mjmEp
: see mujomiEN.

majomuwEN mjmwE
Collected; brought, or gathered, together; gathered up; assembled; congregated; mustered; drawn together; [or contracted;] (S, K, TA;) [from several places, or] hence and thence, although not made as one thing. (S, Sgh, L, K.) It is said in the Kur [xi. 105], *`lika yawomN majomuwEN lahu Aln~aAsi That is a day for which mankind shall be collected. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jamoEN.

mujotamaEN mjtmE
[A place in which a thing becomes collected, brought together, or the like; or in which things have become so; where they collect themselves, come together, or unite; or in which they are comprised, or contained; a place in which is a collection of things]. You say, AlbayoDapu mujotamaEu Alwaladi [The egg is that which comprises the young bird]. (Mgh in art. byD.) And mujotamaEu Almawoti signifies the same as HawoDu Almawoti, which see, in art. HwD. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- [Also The collective mass, or whole, of the hair of the head: (see jum~apN, in three places:) mujotamaEu $aEori Alr~aA^osi meaning the whole head of hair: see also majomaEN.]

mujotamiEN mjtmE
: see jamiyEN, in five places. ― -b2- A man who has attained to his full state of manly vigour, (S, Mgh, TA,) and whose beard has become fullgrown: (TA:) because at that time his powers have become collected, or because his beard is then full-grown. (Mgh.) [See the verb, 8. And see an ex. in a verse of Suheym Ibn-Wetheel cited in art. dwr, conj. 3.] ― -b3- A^aloqaAhu mujotamiEFA [He threw him down gathered together, or in a heap]. (S and Msb and K in art. kwr.) ― -b4- ma$aY mujotamiEFA He walked quickly, (K, TA,) with vehemence of motion, and strength of limbs, not languidly. (TA.)

mutajam~aEu AlbayodaA='i mtjmE AlbydA='
The main part of the desert; the part in which [as it were] it collects itself; syn. muEaZamuhaA wamuHotafaluhaA. (TA.)

1 jamala jml jmlp
, (K,) aor.
jamula
, inf. n. jamolN, (TA,) He collected [a thing, or things]. (K.) [See also 4.] ― -b2- Also, (S, Mgh, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, Mgh,) He melted fat; (S, Mgh, K;) and so Ajtml↓, and Ajml↓: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) this last was sometimes used: (S:) the best form is jamala: (Fr, TA:) accord. to Z, Ajtml↓ signifies he made the melted grease of fat to drip upon bread, putting it again over the fire. (TA. [See jamiylN.]) jamalaka A@ll~`hu, meaning May God melt thee like as fat is melted, is a form of imprecation mentioned in a trad., as used by a woman. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jamala Aljamala He put the he-camel apart from the she-camel that was fit to be covered. (TA.) ＝ -A3- jamula, aor.
jamula
; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and jamila, aor.
jamala
; (Msb;) inf. n. jamaAlN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) originally jamaAlapN; (Msb;) He was, or became, beautiful, goodly, comely, or pleasing, (S, M, Mgh, K,) in person, (M, K,) and good in action, or actions, or behaviour, (M, TA,) or also in moral character: (K:) or elegant, or pretty; i. e., delicately, or minutely, beautiful: (Sb, Msb:) or characterized by much goodness, beauty, goodliness, comeliness, or pleasingness, in his mind, or in his person, or in his actions or behaviour; and also, characterized by much goodness communicated from him to others. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [See jamaAlN, below; and see also jamiylN.]

2 jm~l jml jmlp
, (S, K,) inf. n. tajomiylN, (K,) He, or it, embellished, or adorned, another. (S, K.) Hence the saying, A_i*aA lamo yujam~iloka maAluka lamo yujodi Ealayoka jamaAluka [If thy wealth do not embellish thee, thy beauty of person, or of moral character, will not suffice thee]. (TA.) And you say, jam~ala A@ll~`hu Ealayohi, inf. n. as above, meaning, May God render him beautiful. (TA.) ＝ -A2- He gave a camel to be eaten. (K in art. brq$.) ＝ -A3- He detained an army long [on the frontier of the enemy]; (K, TA;) like jam~ara [q. v.]. (TA.)

3 jAmlhu jAmlh jAmlp
, (K,) inf. n. mujaAmalapN, (S, TA,) He coaxed him, or wheedled him, with comely behaviour or speech (biAljamiyli), not rendering him pure, or sincere, brotherly affection: (ISd, K:) or he associated with him in a good manner: (K:) or he treated him with comely behaviour. (S, TA.) One says, Ealayoka biAlmudaAraApi waAlmujaAmalapi [Keep thou to blandishment and coaxing, &c.]. (TA.)

4 Ajml A^jml Ajml jml
He collected a thing (Msb, K) without discrimination, or distinction, (Msb,) or from a state of separation, or dispersion. (K.) [See also 1.] And A^ujomila It was collected into an aggregate. (TA.) ― -b2- He reduced a calculation to its sum; summed it up: (S, K, TA:) and in like manner, he summed up a speech, or discourse, and then analyzed and explained it. (TA.) ― -b3-
See also 1. ＝ -A2- He made good and large [or liberal]: so in the phrase, Ajml AlS~aniyEapa (S, K) He made the benefit good and large [or liberal] (K) Einoda fulaAnK [to such a one]. (S.) ＝ -A3- [He acted with goodness, or was good and liberal: and he acted with moderation, or was moderate.
