You say,] Ajml fiY SaniyEihi [He was good and liberal, or, perhaps, moderate, in his benefit]. (S.) And Ajml fiY AlT~alabi He was moderate, not extravagant, in demanding, or desire. (Msb, * K, TA.) It is said in a trad., A^ajomiluwA fiY Talabi Alr~izoqi faA_in~a kul~FA muyas~arN limaA xuliqa lahu [Be ye moderate in demanding, or desiring, the means of subsistence, for every one is accommodated to that which is created for him]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Ajml Alqawomu The people, or company of men, had many camels; or their camels became many. (S.)

5 tjm~l A^jml jml tjml
He beautified, embellished, or adorned, himself. (K.) ― -b2- He affected what is jamiyl [or beautiful, goodly, comely, or pleasing, in person, or in action or actions or behaviour, or in moral character, &c.]. (S.) You say, tjm~l biA^akovara mim~aA Einodahu [He affected beautiful, goodly, comely, or pleasing, qualities, more than he possessed]. (TA in art. $bE.) ― -b3- He was, or became, patient; or restrained himself from impatience; or constrained himself to be patient: (Mgh, TA:) from jamaAlN meaning "patience." (Mgh.) Hence the saying,
waA_i*aA tuSiboka xaSaASapN fatajam~ali
And when poverty, or straitness, befalls thee, then be patient, or restrain thyself &c. (Mgh in art. xS.) ＝ -A2- He ate what is termed jamiyl, i. e., melted fat. (S, K. *)

8 Ajtml Ajtml
: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also He anointed himself with fat. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And He ate of a camel. (K in art. brq$.)

10 Astjml Astjml
He (a camel) became a jamal, (S, K,) i. e., such as is termed rabaAEK [or one in his seventh year], (S,) or such as is termed baAzilN [or one in his ninth year], or, accord. to Z, one that had covered. (TA.)

jamolN jml jmlp
: see jamalN.

jumolN jml jmlp
: see jumolapN and jum~alN; the latter in two places.

jamalN jml jmlp
(S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and jamolN↓, (K,) which latter is so rare that it is said by some to be used only in poetry, in cases of necessity, (MF,) but it is a correct dial. var., (TA,) a word of well-known meaning; (K;) i. e., [A he-camel; but commonly applied to the camel as a generic term; in like manner as jaAmilN is applied to the males and the females; but properly,] the male of the A_ibil; (TA;) the mate of the naAqap; (Fr, S, Mgh;) among camels, corresponding to rajulN among us; (Sh, Msb;) naAqapN corresponding to maroA^apN, and bakorN to gulaAmN, and bakorapN to jaAriyapN; (Sh, TA;) [in general] peculiarly applied to the male; (Msb;) exceptionally to the female, as in the saying $aribotu labana jamaliY, (K,) i. e., I drank the milk of my she-camel; but ISd doubts the correctness of this: (TA:) [as corresponding to rajulN among us, it signifies a full-grown hecamel:] or it signifies such as is termed rabaAEK [or one in his seventh year]: (S, ISd, K:) or such as is termed ja*aEN [or one in his fifth year]: (ISd, K:) or such as is termed baAzilN [or one in his ninth year]: (ISd, Mgh, Msb, K:) or such as is termed vaniY~N [or one in his sixth year]: (ISd, K:) or, accord. to Z, one that has covered: (TA:) [see also baEiyrN, and bakorN, and qaEuwdN:] pl. [of pauc.] A^ajomaAlN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which may be pl. of jamolN, (TA,) and A^ajomulN (Msb) and [of mult.] jimaAlN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jumolN (K) and jimaAlapN (Mgh, Msb, K) and [quasi-pl. n.] jumaAlapN and jamaAlapN and jaAmilN, (K,) which last is disallowed by some, as will be seen below, (TA,) and [pl. pl.] jimaAlaAtN, (S, Msb, K,) which is pl. of jimaAlN, (Msb, TA,) or it may be pl. of jimaAlapN, (TA,) and jumaAlaAtN [which see also voce jum~alN] and jamaAlaAtN (K) and jamaAy^ilu, (S, K,) pl. of jmAlp and jimAl, (Ham p. 527,) and A^ajaAmilu. (K.) One says of camels, when they are males, without any female among them, h`*ihi jimaAlapu baniY fulaAnK [These are the hecamels of the sons of such a one]. (ISk, S. [See also jumaAlapN.]) And they said also jimaAlaAni [meaning Two herds of camels, thus forming a dual from the pl. jimaAlN], like as they said liqaAHaAni. (ISd, in TA voce xayolN.) It is said in a prov., maAA@sotatara mano qaAda Aljamala [He does not conceal himself who leads the he-camel]. (TA.) And in another prov., Ait~axa*a All~ayola jamalFA (assumed tropical:) He journeyed all the night. (K, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 230.]) ― -b2- Aljamalu also signifies A certain fish (IAar, K) of the sea, (IAar, TA,) thirty cubits in length: (K:) or, as some say, jamalu AlbaHori is the name of a very great fish, also called the baAl, [i. e., the whale,] thirty cubits in length: accord. to some, this, (TA,) or jamalu AlmaA='i, (Mgh,) is what is called the kawosaj and kubaE (Mgh, TA) and luxom, [i. e., xiphias, or sword-fish,] which passes by nothing without cutting it. (TA.) [In the present day, jamalu AlbaHori is an appellation of The pelican.] ― -b3- Eayonu Aljamali, in the dial. of Egypt, i. q. Al$~aAh bal~uwT [The chestnut]. (TA.) ― -b4- jamalN signifies also (assumed tropical:) A woman's husband. (L in arts. Ax* and qyd. See 2 in each of those arts.) ― -b5- Also (tropical:) Palm-trees; (K;) as being likened to the he-camel in respect of their tallness and their bigness and their produce: in some of the copies of the K, Aln~aHolu is erroneously put for Aln~axolu. (TA.) ― -b6- See also jum~alN.

jumalN jml jmlp
: see jum~alN, in three places.

jumulN jml jmlp
A company, or congregated body, of men. (ISd, K.) ― -b2- See also jum~alN.

jumolapN jml jmlh jmlp
A strand of a thick rope: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] jumolN↓: or many strands of a rope, put together [to compose a cable: see jum~alN]. (TA, in two places in this art.) ― -b2- Hence, app., (TA,) The aggregate of a thing; (K;) the sum, whole, or total; (KL, PS;) it implies muchness, or numerousness, and means any aggregate unseparated: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. jumalN. (S.) [jumolapN mino maAlK generally means A large sum of money; and in a similar sense jumolapN is often used in relation to various things.] It is said in the Kur [xxv. 34], waqaAla A@l~a*iyna kafaruwA lawo laA nuz~ila Ealayohi A@loquroA=nu jumolapF waAHidapF, i. e., [And those who disbelieved said, Wherefore was not the Kur-án sent down, or revealed, to him] aggregated? (TA:) [or in one aggregate?] or at once? (Bd.) [Hence, biAljumolapi as meaning Upon the whole; to sum up.] ― -b3- And hence, in grammar, (TA,) [A proposition; a clause; a phrase; sometimes, a sentence;] a phrase composed of a subject and an attribute, [i. e., composed of an inchoative and an enunciative, (in which case it is termed jumolapN A@somiy~apN,) or of a verb and its agent, (in which case it is termed jumolapN fiEoliy~apN,)] (KT, TA,) [&c.,] whether affording a complete sense, as zayodN qaAy^imN [Zeyd is standing], or not, as A_ino yukorimoniY [If he treat me with honour]. (KT.)

jamolaA='u jmlA='
: see jamiylN.

jamaluwna jmlwn
A building, or structure, in the form of a camel's hump: (TA:) [a ridged roof: so in the present day: pl. jamaAliynu.]

jamaAlN jmAl jml
inf. n. of jamula: (S, Mgh, Msb:) [when used as a simple subst., meaning] Beauty, goodliness, comeliness, or pleasingness, syn. HusonN, (S, M, Mgh, * K,) in person, (M, K,) and goodness in action, or actions, or behaviour, (M, TA,) or also, in moral character: (K:) or elegance, or prettiness; i. e., delicacy, or minuteness, of beauty: (Sb, Msb:) or much goodness, or beauty or goodliness or comeliness, in the mind, or in the person, or in the actions or behaviour; and also, much goodness that is communicated from its possessor to another: (Er-Rághib, TA:) accord. to As, [when relating to the person,] HusonN is in the eyes; and jamaAlN, in the nose. (TA in art. Hsn.) [See also jamiylN.] One says, jamaAlaka A^ano laA tafoEala ka*aA, (ISd, K,) or A^ano tafoEala ka*aA, (IDrd, TA,) meaning, Keep to that which is most comely for thee to do, and do not thus. (IDrd, ISd, K. [But see what follows.]) ― -b2- Also Patience. (Mgh in art. xS.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
jamaAlaka A^ay~uhaA Alqalobu AlqariyHu
sataloqaY mano tuHib~u fatasotariyHu
(S, * TA, the former of which cites only the first hemistich, and the latter substitutes AljariyHu for its syn. AlqariyHu,) meaning, [Keep thy patience, O thou wounded heart: thou wilt find whom thou lovest, and be at rest: or] keep to thy patience, or thy constraint of thyself to be patient, and thy shrinking from what is foul, and be not impatient in an evil manner. (S, TA.)

jumaAlN jmAl jml
: see jamiylN: ＝ -A2- and jumaAlapN.

jamuwlN jmwl
A piece of fat melted. (IAar, TA.) [See also jamiylN.] ― -b2- A fat woman. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- A person, (K,) or woman, (M,) who melts fat. (M, K.)

jamiylN jmyl
Melted fat: (S, Mgh:) or melting fat: or fat that is melted and collected: (K, TA:) or fat that is melted, and, whenever it drips, made to drip upon bread, and then replaced over the fire [that it may drip again: see jamala]: (TA:) and jumaAlapN↓, also, signifies [the same; or] melted grease. (Mgh, * TA.) [See also jamuwlN.] ＝ -A2- Hence, accord. to Abu-l-'Alà, because, when a man becomes fat and in good condition, his jamaAl becomes apparent, (Ham p. 155,) as also jumaAlN↓ and jum~aAlN↓, (K,) or this last denotes a higher degree of beauty than jamiylN, (S, Sgh,) and has no broken pl., (TA,) and A^ajomalu↓, (TA,) Beautiful, goodly, comely, or pleasing, (S, M, Mgh, K,) in person, (M, K,) and good in action, or actions, or behaviour, (M, TA,) or also in moral character: (K:) [like the Greek καλὸς, the Latin pulcher, the French beau, &c.; and so HasanN:] or elegant, or pretty; i. e., delicately, or minutely, beautiful: (Msb:) [or characterized by much goodness, or beauty or goodliness or comeliness, in his mind, or in his person, or in his actions or behaviour; and also characterized by much goodness communicated from him to others: see jamaAlN:] pl. of the first jamaAlN: (TA:) fem. jamiylapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) applied to a woman; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also jamolaA='u↓, (Ks, S, K,) [said to be] an instance of [the measure] faEolaA='u having no [masc. of the measure] A^afoEalu; (TA;) [but see above;] or this is applied to any female as signifying perfect, or complete, in body. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) It is said in a trad., A_in~a A@ll~`ha jamiylN yuHib~u AljimaAla Verily God is comely in deeds, (TA,) or an Abundant Bestower of good things: He loveth those who are of the like character. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And you say, EaAmalahu baAljamiyli [He treated him with comely, or pleasing, behaviour]. (TA.) And maAsaHahu biAljamiyl [He coaxed him, or wheedled him, with comely, or pleasing, behaviour or speech]. (ISd, K. [See 3.]) ― -b2- A^abuw jamiylK [The kind of plants called] Albaqol; because they embellish by their presence, and render good, the seasoning of food; or because they take away the jamiyl, i. e., the grease of the flesh-meat, and dry up the food. (Har p. 227.)

jamaAlapN jmAl jmAlh jmAlp jml
: see the next paragraph.

jumaAlapa jmAl jmAlh jmAlp jml
: see jum~alN: ＝ -A2- and jamiylN. ＝ -A3- Also A herd, or distinct number, of camels; (K;) mentioned before as a pl. of jamalN [q. v.]: (TA:) or, of she-camels among which is no he-camel; as also jimaAlapN↓ and jamaAlapN↓; (K;) but this is contradictory to a saying of ISk [respecting jimaAlapN], mentioned above [voce jamalN; where all these three words are said to be pls. of jamalN]: (TA:) and also horses: pl. jumaAlN↓, which is extr. [as a pl.; though, in relation to jumaAlapN, it may be a coll. gen. n., forming its n. un. with p]. (AA, K.)

jimaAlapN jmAl jmAlh jmAlp jml
: see what next precedes.

jamiylapN jmyl jmylh jmylp
A number of gazelles together: and of pigeons. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.)

jumaAliY~N jmAl jmAlY jmAly jmAlyy jml
applied to a man, (S, Msb, K,) Large in make: (S, Msb:) or tall in body: (Msb:) or firm [in make], (K,) or big in limbs, complete in make, (TA,) like a he-camel. (K, TA.) And with p applied to a she-camel, (S, K,) Resembling a he-camel in greatness of make: (S:) or firm (K, TA) in make, (TA,) like a he-camel (K, TA) in greatness of make and in strength. (TA.)

jum~alN jml jmlp
(S, K, &c.) and jumalN↓ and jumolN↓ (K) and jumulN↓ and jamalN↓ (IJ, K) [A cable;] the rope of a ship, (S, K,) i. e., the thick rope thereof, (TA,) that is also called qalosN, (S, TA,) consisting of [a number of] ropes put together: (S:) and jumaAlapN↓ also signifies [the same; or] a thick rope, because consisting of many strands put together; pl. jumaAlaAtN; (Zj, TA;) which Mujáhid explains as meaning the ropes of bridges; but I 'Ab, as the ropes of ships, put together so as to be like the waists of men [in thickness]. (TA.) In all the forms mentioned above, except the last (jmAlp), the word is read in the phrase [in the Kur vii. 38], Hat~aY yalija Aljum~alu fiY sam~i AlxiyaATi [Until the cable shall enter into the eye of the needle]: (K, TA:) I 'Ab reads Aljum~alu, (S, TA,) and so do 'Alee and many others: jumolN↓ is pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of jumolapN, a strand of a thick rope; or, accord. to IJ, pl. of jamalN [q. v.]: the first is explained by Fr as meaning ropes put together; but Aboo-Tálib thinks that he meant jumalN↓, without tesh-deed. (TA.) ＝ -A2- HisaAbu Aljum~ali, (S K,) thought by IDrd to be not Arabic, (TA,) and Aljumali↓, (K,) but IDrd doubts its correctness, The calculation by means of the letters d j b A, &c. (TA.)

jam~aAlN jmAl jml
An owner, or an attendant, of a camel or camels: (KL, TA: * [see also jAmilN:]) and jam~aAlapN owners, or attendants, of camels; (S, K, TA;) similar to xay~aAlapN and Ham~aArapN; (S, TA;) as the former is to Ham~aArN. (TA.) [See an ex. of the latter in a verse cited voce A_i*aA.]

jum~aAlN jmAl jml
: see jamiylN.

jaAmilN jAml
[act. part. n. of jamala. ＝ -A2- And also part. n. of jamula]. The Arabs say, Aujomulo A_ino kunota jaAmilFA [Become beautiful, &c., if thou be becoming beautiful, &c.]: but when they mean the quality [alone], they say, A_in~ahu lajamiylN [Verily he is beautiful, &c.]. (Lh, TA.) ＝ -A3- A man possessing a jamal [or he-camel]. (TA. [See also jam~aAlN.]) ― -b2- A herd, or distinct number, of camels, (S, K, * TA,) males and females, (TA,) with their pastors and their owners: (S, K, TA: [also said in the K to be a pl. of jamalN: in the CK, AljAmiEu is erroneously put for AljaAmilu:]) or a word formed to denote a pl., meaning camels, (Ham pp. 122 and 490,) males and females; (Id p. 122;) derived from jamalN; (Id. p. 490;) like baAqirN (Id. ib. and TA) from baqarN, (Ham p. 490,) and kaAlibN [from kalobN]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A great tribe. (AHeyth, K.)

A^ajomalu *
[More, and most, jamiyl, or beautiful, &c.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also jamiylu.

mujomalN mjml
[pass. part. n. of 4, q. v. ― -b2- Also, applied to a phrase or the like,] properly, Including, or implying, a number of things, many and unexplained: (Er-Rághib, TA:) as used by the lawyers, [confused, or] requiring explanation. (TA.)

mujaAmilN mjAml
[act. part. n. of 3, q. v. ― -b2- Also] One who is unable to answer a question put to him by another person, and therefore neglects it, and bears malice against him for some time. (TA.)

jumaAnN jm jmAn
Beads made of silver, like pearls; (S;) things in the form of pearls, of silver; (K;) one of which is called jumaAnapN, (S, K,) pl. jumaAnaAtN: (Har p. 181:) or pearls (K, TA) themselves: (TA:) or the first is the proper meaning, and this is metaphorical: (EM p. 161:) [said to be] a Persian word, arabicized. (TA.) Also A kind of belt (safiyfap) woven of leather, in which are beads of every colour, worn by a woman as a wi$aAH [q. v.]: or silvered beads. (K.)

Q. 1 jamohara jmhr
, (T, A, K,) inf. n. jamoharapN, (A,) He collected together (T, A, K) a thing, (TA,) or earth, or dust, (T, A, TA,) one part upon another. (T, TA.) ― -b2- jmhr Alqabora, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He collected the earth, or dust, over the grave, (S, Msb, K,) not plastering it with clay, or mud, (S, K,) nor making it even, or level. (TA.) ― -b3- jmhr AlmataAEa He took the main part of the household-goods, or commodities: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to plants, or herbage. (Kitáb el- Addád, TA.) ― -b4- jmhr Ealayohi Alxabara, (Ks, S, K,) or lahu, (Lth, TA,) or A_ilayohi, (AZ, TA,) He acquainted him with a part of the news, or story, and concealed what he desired, or meant: (Ks, S, K:) or he acquainted him with a part of the news, or story, incorrectly, or not in the proper manner, and omitted what he desired, or meant: (Lth, TA:) or he acquainted him with a small portion thereof, omitting most of what was necessary for him to know, and relating it in a manner different from the proper way: (AZ, TA:) and accord. to the Kitáb el-Addád of Abu-t-Teiyib the Lexicologist, it seems to have a contr. signification; for he says that jamoharotu laka Alxabara means, I acquainted thee with the main part of the news, or story. (TA.)

Q. 2 tajamohara EalayonaA tjmhr ElynA
He held up his head with an assumption of superiority over us; domineered over us; or exalted himself above us. (TA.)

jamoharapN jmhr jmhrh jmhrp
[originally inf. n. of jamohara]: see the next paragraph.

jumohuwrN jmhwr
(not jamohuwrN, which is a form of the word mentioned by Et-Tilimsánee, MF) A quantity of sand rising above what is around it, (S, Msb, K,) and collected together; (S;) as also ↓with p; (L;) so called from its abundance and height: (Msb:) or a large quantity of sand, heaped up, and extensive: (Lth, TA:) and ↓with p, sand compacted together, and extending in an oblong form upon the surface of the earth. (TA.) ― -b2- The generality, or main part, of men, or people: (S, A, K:) and the eminent, elevated, or noble, of them: (TA:) and a great number of people:
(Msb:) pl. jamaAhiyru; (A, Msb;) which signifies also collective bodies of men. (TA.) You say, h`*aA qawolu Aljumohuwri This is the saying of the generality, or main part. (A.) ― -b3- The generality; the greater, main, or chief, part; the main body, main, gross, mass, or bulk; of anything; (K;) as also jamoharapN↓. (W 95.) ― -b4- Also, (K,) or jumohuwrapN↓, (TA,) A noble, or high-born, woman. (K, TA.)

jumohuwrapN jmhwr jmhwrh jmhwrp
: see jumohuwrN, in three places.

jumohuwriY~N jmhwr jmhwrY jmhwry
An intoxicating beverage: (AO, K:) or [beverage of the kind called] nabiy* made of grapes, that is three years old: (K:) or i. q. buxotajN; (TA;) which is expressed juice [of grapes] cooked (Mgh voce bxtj, and TA) so as to be reduced to one third, (Mgh,) such as is lawful to be drunk: (TA:) or the beverage called bxtj to which what has gone from it has been restored, and which is then cooked, and put into vessels, and becomes very potent: (AHn, and Mgh ubi suprà, and TA:) or juice of grapes cooked until half of it is gone and half remains: (KL:) called jmhwrY~ because used by most men. (TA.)

jumaAhirN jmAhr
Large, big, bulky, or corpulent. (TA.)

mujamoharapN mjmhrh mjmhrp
A she-camel compact in make; (K;) as though she were a jumohuwr of sand. (TA.)

1 jan~ahu 6
, (S, Mgh, K,) aor.
janu3a
, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. jan~N, (TA,) It veiled, concealed, hid, covered, or protected, him; (S, Mgh, K;) said of the night; (S, K;) as also jan~a Ealayohi, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
janu3a
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. junuwnN, (S,) or jan~N, (K,) or both; (TA;) so in the Kur vi. 76, meaning it veiled him, concealed him, or covered him, with its darkness; (Bd;) and Ajn~hu↓: (S, Msb, K:) or this last signifies he, or it, made, or prepared, for him, or gave him, that which should veil him, conceal him, &c.: accord. to Er-Rághib, the primary signification of jan~N is the veiling, or concealing, &c., from the sense. (TA.) And jun~a Eanohu means It (anything) was veiled, concealed, or hidden, from him. (K.) ― -b2- He concealed it; namely, a dead body; as also Ajn~hu↓: (S, TA:) or the latter, he wrapped it in grave-clothing: (K:) and he buried it. (TA.) And Al$~aYo'a fiY SadoriY A^ajonanotu↓ I concealed the thing in my bosom. (S.) And waladFA A^ajan~ato↓, (S,) or janiynFA, (K,) said of a woman, (S,) or a pregnant female, (K,) She concealed [or enveloped in her womb a child, or an embryo, or a fœtus]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jan~a, aor.
jani3a
, inf. n. jin~N, It (an embryo, or a fœtus,) was concealed in the womb. (K.) ― -b2- Also, [inf. n., probably, jin~N and junuwnN and janaAnN, explained below,] It (the night) was, or became, dark. (Golius on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof.) ＝ -A3- jun~a, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. junuwnN (S, K) and jin~apN (S) and jan~N; (K;) and Ausotujin~N↓, and tjn~n↓, and tjAn~↓; (K;) He (a man, S) was, or became, majonuwn [originally signifying possessed by a jin~iY~, or by jin~; possessed by a devil or demon; (see Bd li. 39;) and hence meaning bereft of reason; or mad, insane, unsound in mind or intellect, or wanting therein: the verbs may generally be rendered he was, or became, possessed; or mad, or insane]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- jun~a Al*~ubaAbu, (S, A, TA,) inf. n. junuwnN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The flies made much buzzing: (S:) or made a gladsome buzzing in a meadow. (A, TA.) ― -b3- jun~a Aln~abotu, inf. n. junuwnN, (tropical:) The herbage became tall, and tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and put forth its flowers or blossoms: (S, TA:) or became thick and tall and full-grown, and blossomed. (M, TA.) And jun~ati AlA^aroDu, (Fr, K,) inf. n. junuwnN, (K,) (tropical:) The land produced pleasing herbage or plants: (Fr, TA:) or put forth its flowers and blossoms; as also tjn~nt↓. (K, TA.)

2 jan~a3a
see 4.

4 A^ajona3a
see 1, in four places: ＝ -A2- and see 8. ＝ -A3- Also Ajn~hu He (God) caused him to be, or become, majonuwn [originally signifying possessed by a jin~iY~, or by jin~; and hence generally meaning bereft of reason; or mad, insane, unsound in mind or intellect, or wanting therein]. (S, Msb, K.) [And so, vulgarly, jn~nhu↓, whoever, or whatever, be the agent.] ― -b2- mA Ajn~hu [How mad, or insane, &c., is he!] is anomalous, (Th, S,) being formed from a verb of the pass. form, namely, jun~a; (Th, TA;) for of the maDoruwb one should not say, maA A^aDorabahu; nor of the masoluwl should one say, maA A^asal~ahu: (S:) Sb says that the verb of wonder is used in this case because it denotes want of intellect [which admits of degrees]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Ajn~ also signifies waqaEa fiY majan~apK [app. meaning He fell into, or upon, a place containing, or abounding with, jin~]. (TA.)

5 tajan~a3a
see 1, in two places. ― -b2- tjn~n Ealayohi, and tajaAnana↓, (S, K,) and tajaAn~a↓, (S,) He feigned himself majonuwn [i. e. possessed by a jin~iY~, or by jin~; and hence generally meaning bereft of reason; or mad, insane, &c.;] to him; (S, K;) not being really so. (TA.)

6 tajaAn~a * and tajaAnana
: see 1: ― -b2- and see also 5.

8 Ajtn~ jn jnh jnp
, (accord, to the S,) or Ajn~↓, (accord. to the K,) He was, or became, veiled, concealed, hidden, covered, or protected, or he veiled, concealed, hid, covered, or protected, himself, (S, K,) Eanohu from him, or it; (K;) as also Astjn↓. (S, K.) You say, bijun~apK Astjn↓ He was, or became, veiled, &c., or he veiled himself, &c., by a thing whereby he was veiled, &c. (S.)

10 A_isotajona3a
see 8, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also 1. ＝ -A3- AisotijonaAnN is also syn. with AisotiToraAbN; (S, K;) Astjn~hu meaning AstTrbhu, i. e. He excited him to mirth, joy, gladness, or sport. (TK.)

jin~N jn
The darkness of night; as also junuwnN↓ and janaAnu↓, (K, TA,) the last [written in the CK junAn, but it is] with fet-h: (TA:) or all signify its intense darkness: (TA:) or all, the confusedness of the darkness of night: (K:) [all, in these senses, are app. inf. ns.: (see 1:)] the last, janaAnN↓, also signifies night [itself]: (K:) or [so in copies of the K, accord. to the TA, but in the CK “ and, ”] the dense black darkness of night: (S, K:) and junuwnN↓, the veiling, or concealing, or protecting, darkness of night. (ISk, S.) ― -b2- Concealment: so in the phrase, laA jin~a bih`*aA AlA^amori There is no concealment with this thing. (K, * TA.) One of the Hudhalees says,
walaA jin~a biAlbagoDaA='i waAln~aZari Al$~azori
[And there is no concealment with vehement hatred and the looking with aversion]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [The genii; and sometimes the angels;] accord. to some, the spiritual beings that are concealed from the senses, or that conceal themselves from the senses; all of such beings; (Er-Rághib, TA;) the opposite of A_inosN; (S, Mgh, Msb, Er-Rághib, TA;) thus comprising the angels; all of these being jin~; (Er-Rághib, TA;) thus called because they are feared but not seen: (S:) or, accord. to others, certain of the spiritual beings; for the spiritual beings are of three kinds; the good being the angels; and the evil being the devils ($ayaATiyn); and the middle kind, among whom are good and evil, being the jin~; as is shown by the first twelve verses of ch. lxxii. of the Kur: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it here means intelligent invisible bodies, predominantly of the fiery, or of the aerial, quality: or a species of souls, or spirits, divested of bodies: or human souls separate from their bodies: (Bd:) or the jin~ are the angels [exclusively]; (K;) these being so called in the Time of Ignorance, because they were concealed, or because they concealed themselves, from the eyes: so, accord. to some, in the Kur [xviii. 48], where it is said that Iblees was of the jin~: and so, as some say, in the Kur [vi. 100], where it is said that they called the jin~ partners of God: (TA:) but some reject the explanation in the K, because the angels were created of light, and the jin~ of fire; and the former do not propagate their kind, nor are they to be described as males and females; contrary to the case of the jin~; wherefore it is generally said that in the phrase [in the Kur xviii. 48, above mentioned] A_il~aA A_iboliysa kaAna mina Aljin~i, what is excepted is disunited in kind from that from which the exception is made, or that Iblees had adopted the dispositions of the jin~: (MF, TA:) or, as some say, the jin~ were a species of the angels, who were the guardians of the earth and of the gardens of Paradise: (TA:) jin~apN↓, also, signifies the same as jin~N: (S, Msb, K:) so in the last verse of the Kur: (S:) in the Kur xxxvii. 158 meaning the angels, whom certain of the Arabs worshipped; (TA;) and whom they called the daughters of God: (Fr, TA:) a single individual of the jin~ is called jin~iY~N↓, [fem. with p:] (S, TA:) and jaAn~N↓, also, is syn. with jin~N: (Msb:) or AljaAnN means the father of the jin~; (S, Mgh, TA;) [i. e. any father of jin~; for] the pl. is jin~aAnN, like HiyTaAnN pl. of HaAy^iTN: (S, TA:) so says El-Hasan: it is said in the T, on the authority of
AA, that the jAn~ is, or are, of the jin~: (TA:) or jaAn~N is a quasi-pl. n. of jin~N; (M, K;) like jaAmilN and baAqirN: (M, TA:) so in the Kur lv. 56 and 74: in reading the passage in the Kur lv. 39, 'Amr Ibn- 'Obeyd pronounced it jaA^anN: (TA:) it is related that there were certain creatures called the jaAn~, who were upon the earth, and who acted corruptly therein, and shed blood, wherefore God sent angels who banished them from the earth; and it is said that these angels became the inhabitants of the earth after them. (Zj, TA.) baAta fulaAnN Dayofa jin~K [Such a one passed the night a guest of jn~] means, in a desolate place, in which was no one that might cheer him by his society or converse. (TA.) The saying of Moosà Ibn-Jábir,
famaA nafarato jin~iY walaA ful~a miboradiY
may mean And my companions, who were like the jin~, did not flee when I came to them and informed them, nor was my tongue, that is like the file, deprived of its sharp edge: or by his jn~ he means his familiar jn~, such as were asserted to aid poets when difficulties befell them; and by his mbrd, his tongue: (Ham p. 182 [where other explanations are proposed; but they are far-fetched]:) or by his jn~ he means his heart; and by his mbrd, his tongue. (S.) The Arabs liken a man who is sharp and effective in affairs to a jin~iY~ and a $ayoTaAn: and hence they said, nafarato jin~uhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He became weak and abject. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b2- The greater, main, or chief, part, or the main body, or bulk, of men, or of mankind; as also janaAnN↓; (K;) because he who enters among them becomes concealed by them: (TA:) or the latter means the general assemblage, or collective body, of men: (IAar, S, * TA:) or what veils, conceals, covers, or protects, one, of a thing. (AA, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) The flowers, or blossoms, of plants or herbage. (K, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The prime, or first part, of youth: (S, K, TA:) or the sharpness, or vigorousness, and briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, thereof. (TA.) You say, kaAna *`lik fiY jin~i $abaAbihi (tropical:) That was in the prime, or first part, of his youth. (S, TA.) And A^afoEalu *`lika AlA^amora bijin~i *`lika (tropical:) I will do that thing in the time of the first and fresh state of that. (S, TA.) jin~N may also signify (assumed tropical:) The madness, or insanity, of exultation, or of excessive exultation. (TA.) And one says, Ait~qi Aln~Aqapa faA_in~haA bijin~i DiraAmihaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) Fear thou the she-camel, for she is in her evil temper on the occasion of her bringing forth. (TA.) ― -b5- Also i. q. jd~ [app. jid~N, as meaning (assumed tropical:) Seriousness, or earnestness]; because it is a thing that is an accompaniment of thought, or reflection, and is concealed by the heart. (TA.)

jan~apN jn jnh jnp
A [garden, such as is called] busotaAn: (S, Mgh:) or a garden, or walled garden, (Hadiyqap, Msb, K,) of trees, or of palm-trees, (Msb,) or of palms and other trees: (K:) or only if containing palm-trees and grape-vines; otherwise, if containing trees, called Hdyqp: (Aboo-'Alee in the Tedhkireh, TA:) or any bstAn having trees by which the ground is concealed: and sometimes concealing trees: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and palm-trees: (S:) or tall palm-trees: (Mgh:) or shadowing trees; because of the tangling, or luxuriousness of their branches; as though concealing at once what is beneath them: then a bstAn; because of its dense and shadowing trees: (Bd in ii. 23:) or a bstAn of palms and other trees, dense, and shadowing by the tangling, or luxuriousness, and denseness, of their branches; as though it were originally the inf. n. of un. of jan~ahu, and meaning “ a single act of veiling ” or “ concealing ” &c.: (Ksh ib.:) then, with the article Al, [Paradise,] the abode of recompense; because of the jinaAn therein; (Ksh and Bd ib.;) or because the various delights prepared therein for mankind are concealed in the present state of existence: (Bd ib.:) [and] hence Aljan~aAtu [the gardens of Paradise], (so in a copy of the S,) or jan~aAtu EadonK [the gardens of continual abode]: (so in another copy of the S:) [for] the pl. of jan~apN is A^ajin~apN (Mgh, Msb, K) and jinayonap (Msb, TA) and jun~apN, but this last is strange. (MF, TA.) [Dim. junayonapN↓, vulgarly pronounced jinayonap, and applied to A garden; as though it were a little Paradise.]

jun~apN jn jnh jnp
A thing by which a person is veiled, concealed, hidden, covered, or protected: an arm, or armour, with which one protects himself: (S:) anything protective: (K:) or coats of mail, and any defensive, or protective, arm or armour: (TA:) pl. junanN. (S.) ― -b2- A piece of cloth which a woman wears, covering the fore and kind parts of her head, but not the middle of it, and covering the face, and the two sides of the bosom, (K,) or, accord. to the M, the ornaments [HuliY~ instead of janobaY] of the bosom, (TA,) and having two eyeholes, like the buroquE. (K.)

jin~apN jn jnh jnp
: see its syn. jin~N: ＝ -A2- and junuwnN.

jananN jn jnn jnnn
A grave; (S, K;) because it conceals the dead: (TA:) and so janiynN↓, of the measure faEylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- Grave-clothing; (K;) for the same reason. (TA.) ― -b3- A garment that conceals the body. (TA.) [See also janaAnN.] ＝ -A2- A dead body; (S, K;) because concealed in the grave; the word being of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, like nafaDN in the sense of manofuwDN. (TA.)

janunN jn jnn jnnn
: see junuwnN.

janaAnN jnAn jnp
: see jin~N, first sentence, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see the same in the latter part of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also A garment: (K:) or a garment that conceals one; as in the saying, maA EalaY~a janaAnN A_il~aA maA taraY [There is not upon me a garment that conceals me save what thou seest]. (S.) [See also jananN.] ― -b3- The Hariym [or surrounding adjuncts, or appertenances and conveniences,] (K, TA) of a house; because concealing the house. (TA.) ― -b4- The interior of a thing that one does not see; (K;) because concealed from the eye. (TA.) ― -b5- The heart; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) because concealed in the bosom; (T, M;) or because it holds things in memory: (M, TA:) or its ruwE [i. e. the heart's core, or the mind, or understanding, or intellect]; (K;) which is more deeply hidden: (TA:) and (sometimes, TA) the soul, or spirit; (IDrd, K;) because the body conceals it: (IDrd, TA:) pl. A^ajonaAnN. (IJ, K.) You say, maA yasotaqir~u janaAnuhu mina AlfazaEi [His heart does not rest in its place by reason of fright]. (TA.) ― -b6- A secret and bad action. (TA. [Before the word rendered “ secret ” is another epithet, which is illegible.])

junaAnN jnAn jnp
: see mijan~N: ＝ -A2- and what here next follows.

junuwnN jnwn
: see jin~N, first sentence, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, inf. n. of jun~a; (S, K;) [originally signifying A state of possession by a jin~iY~i, or by jin~; diabolical, or demoniacal, possession; and hence meaning] loss of reason; or madness, insanity, or unsoundness in mind or intellect; (Mgh;) or deficiency of intellect: (Sb, TA:) [it may generally be rendered possession, or insanity:] jununN↓ is a contraction thereof; (S, K;) or accord. to some, an original form: (MF, TA:) and jan~apN↓, also, (an inf. n. and a simple subst., S,) signifies the same as junuwnN: (S, Msb, K:) as also majan~apN↓, (S, K,) and junaAnN↓, but this last is vulgar. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Persistence in evil; and pursuance of a headlong, or rash, course. (Ham p. 14.)

janiynN jnY jnyn
Anything veiled, concealed, hidden, or covered: (K:) applied as an epithet even to rancour, or malice. (TA.) ― -b2- Buried; deposited in a grave. (IDrd, S.) ― -b3- An embryo; a fœtus; the child, or young, in the belly; (S Msb, K;) [i. e.,] in the womb: (Mgh:) pl. A^ajin~apN (S, Msb, K) and A^ajonunN. (ISd, K.) ― -b4- And the former of these pls., Waters choked up with earth. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jananN. ― -b2- Also The vulva. (TA.)

junaAnapN jnAnh jnAnp jnp
: see mijan~N.

janiynapN jnY jnyn jnynh jnynp
, accord. to the copies of the K, but in the M jin~iy~apN↓, (TA,) A [garment of the kind called] miToraf, (K, TA,) of a round form, (TA,) like the TayolasaAn, (K, TA,) worn by women: (TA:) in the T, said to be certain well-known garments. (TA.)

junayonapN jnY jnyn jnynh jnynp
: see jn~apN, last sentence.

jin~iY~N jn jnY jny
Of, or relating to, the jin~, or jin~ap. (K.) ― -b2- See jin~N. In the saying,
wayoHaki yaA jin~iY~a halo badaA laki
A^ano turojiEiY EaqoliY faqado A^anaY laki
[Mercy on thee! O Jinneeyeh, jin~iY~a being for jin~iy~apu,) doth it appear fit to thee that thou shouldst restore my reason? for the time hath come for thee to do so], a woman resembling a jin~iy~ap is meant, either because of her beauty, or in her changeableness. (TA.) ＝ -A2- The tallness, or length and height, of a camel's hump. (TA.)

jin~iy~apN jny jnyh jnyp
[fem. of jin~iY~N, q. v.] ＝ -A2- See also janiynapN

jinojinN jnjn
and janojanN and jinojinapN↓ (S, K) and jinojanapN↓ (K) and (as some say, TA) junojuwnN↓ (K) are sings. of janaAjinu, which signifies The bones of the breast: (S, K:) or the heads of the ribs of men and of others: (M, TA:) or the extremities of the ribs, next the sternum. (T, TA.)

janojanapN jnjnh jnjnp
: see what next precedes.

junojuwnN jnjwn
: see what next precedes.

jaAn~N jAn jAny
: see jin~N. ― -b2- Also A white serpent: (Lth, S, Msb:) or a small white serpent: (Mgh:) or a great serpent: (Zj, TA:) or a species of serpent (AA, M, K) having black-bordered eyes, (M, K,) inclining to yellow, (M, TA,) harmless, and abounding in houses: (M, K:) pl. jawaAn~u, (AA, TA,) or jin~aAnN. (TA.)

A^ajin~aka ka*aA *
i. q. mino A^ajoli A^an~aka [Because that thou art thus]; (S, K;) from which it is contracted by suppressing the l and A and transferring the kesreh of the l to the A (S.) A poet says,
A^ajin~aki EinodiY A^aHosanu Aln~aAsi kul~ihimo
[Because that thou art in my estimation the goodliest of all mankind]. (S.) The mino is omitted as in the phrase faEalotuhu A^ajolaka for mino A^ajolika. (Ks, TA.)

tajoniynN A^jn jn jnY tjnY tjnyn
[an inf. n. used as a simple subst.,] What is said by the jin~ [or genii]: or, accord. to Es-Sukkaree, strange, uncouth speech or language, difficult to be understood. (TA.)

mujan~N mAj mjn mjnn
: see majonuwnN.

mijan~N mAj mjn mjnn
A shield; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) because the owner conceals, or protects, himself with it; (Mgh, Msb;) as also mijan~apN↓ (Lh, K) and junaAnN↓ and junaAnapN↓: (K:) pl. majaAn~u. (S, Msb.) Sb held it to be of the measure fiEal~N, from mjn; but his opinion is opposed by the fact that the word is of the form which is significant of an instrument, by the doubling of the n, and by the syns. jnAn and jnAnp. (MF, TA.) It is said in a trad., that the hand [of a thief] shall not be cut off save for the value of a mijan~; which in the time of the Prophet was a deenár, or ten dirhems; for this is the lowest amount for which that punishment is to be inflicted. (Mgh.) You say, qalaba mijan~ahu [He turned his shield], meaning (tropical:) He dropped shame, and did what he pleased: or he became absolute master of his affair, or case. (K, TA.) And qalabotu lahu Zahora Almijan~i [I turned towards him the outer side of the shield], meaning (assumed tropical:) I became hostile to him after reconciliation. (Har p. 265.) ― -b2- Also A [woman's ornament such as is commonly called] wi$aAH (Az, K.)

majan~apN mAj mjn mjnh mjnnh mjnp
A place in which one is veiled, concealed, hidden, covered, or protected; or in which one veils, conceals, hides, covers, or protects, himself. (S.) ― -b2- A land having in it jin~: (S:) or abounding with jin~. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also junuwnN.

mijan~apN mAj mjn mjnh mjnnh mjnp
: see mijan~N.

majonuwnN mjnwn
[Possessed by jin~iY~, or by jin~, or by a devil, or demon; a demoniac: (see Bd li. 39:) and hence meaning bereft of reason; or mad, insane, unsound in mind or intellect, or wanting therein: (see junuwnN:) it may generally be rendered possessed; or mad, or insane:] part. n. of jun~a: (Msb:) or anomalously used as pass. part. n. of A^ajan~ahu: (S, * K, * TA:) one should not say mujan~N↓: (S, TA:) [pl. majaAniynu.] ― -b2- naxolapN majonuwnapN (tropical:) A tall palm-tree: (S, K, TA:) pl. majaAniynu. (S, TA.) And nabotN majonuwnN (tropical:) A plant, or herbage, that is tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, in part, and strong. (TA.) And A^aroDN majonuwnapN (assumed tropical:) Land producing much herbage, that has not been depastured. (TA. [See also what next follows.])

A^aroDN matajan~inapN *
(tropical:) Land having much herbage, so that it extends in every way. (K, TA.)

manojanuwnN mnjnwn
and manojaniynN: see art. mnjn

1 janaA^a Ealayohi *
, (As, S, L, K,) aor.
janaAa
, inf. n. junuwo'N, (As, K,) He bent down over, or fell prostrate upon, him, or it; (As, S, L, K;) namely, a man, (Th, L,) as one does in speaking to another [who is sitting], (Th,) or to shield or protect another from blows, (L,) and as a woman does over a child; (TA;) or a horse, said when a man has bent down to preserve himself [from an arrow &c.]; or a thing; (S;) as also janiY'a, aor.
janaAa
, inf. n. janaA^N; (K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, janA';]) as also AjnA^↓, (As, L, K,) likewise said of a man bending over another to shield or protect the latter; (L, TA;) and jAnA^↓, and tjAnA^↓, (S, K,) and AjtnA^↓ (TA.) ― -b2- janaA^a fiY Eadowihi He persevered, or was fatigued and slow, A^alaH~a, [which has these two different meanings,]) and bent down, in his running. (T, TA.) ＝ -A2- janiY'a, aor.
janaAa
, (Lth, K,) inf. n. janaA^N, (Lth, S,) said of a man, (S,) He had a bending forward of the upper part of his back over his breast: (Lth, K:) or was humpbacked: (S:) or he had a bent and humped back: but Lth denies that janaA^N signifies the being humpbacked. (TA.) [See also A^ajonaA^u.]

3 jaAonaAa
see 1.

4 A^ajonaAa
see 1.

6 tajaAonaAa
see 1.

8 A_ijotanaAa
see 1.

A^ujonaA^u *
, applied to a man, (S,) Having a bending forward of the upper part of the back over the breast: (Lth, K:) or humpbacked: (S:) or having a bent and humped back; but see what Lth says, voce janiY'a: (TA:) or i. q. A^adonaA^u and A^aqoEasu, meaning a man having a bending in his breast towards his back: (AA, TA:) accord. to As, applied to him who has been straight in the back and has then been affected with what is termed janaA^N: it is also applied to an ostrich: fem. janoA='u and janowaA='u (TA.) ― -b2- Also janoA='u A ewe, or a she-goat, having her horns bending backwards; (Esh-Sheybánee, K;) and so janowaA='u (TA in art. jnw.)

mujonaA^N *
A shield: (S, K:) so called because of its being humped, (K, TA, [in some copies of the former of which, for liA@HodiydaAbihi, we find laA Hadiydapa bihi, i. e. having no piece of iron in it,]) and on account of its bending form. (TA.)

mujonaA^apN *
A grave. (K.) [App. so called because the grave of an Arab of the desert generally has a small oblong humped mound raised over it.]

1 janabahu jnb jnbh jnbp
He broke his side: (S, K:) or he hit, or hurt, his side. (TA.) [The aor. of the verb in this sense is probably
januba
, and the inf. n., accord. to the TK, is janobN.] ― -b2- He led him by his side; (S, A, * Msb, K;) namely, a horse (S, A, Msb, TA) or the like, (S, A,) and a captive. (S, TA.) In this sense, its aor. is
januba
, (A, Msb, TA,) and the inf. n. janabN (S, A, Msb, K) and majonabN. (K.) Hence, TawoEu Aljanabi: see janabN.jinaAbN which is forbidden (S, A, TA) in a trad., [in which it is said, laA jalaba walaA janaba] (A, TA) relating to horse-racing and to [the collecting of] the poor-rate, (TA,) means [in the former case] A man's leading, by the side of a horse that he rides in a race, another horse, (S, A, K,) without a rider, (TA,) and when the horse that he rides has become languid and weak, (K,) or when he fears that he will not outstrip upon it, (S,) or when he draws near to the goal, (A,) transferring himself to the other, (S, A, K,) in order that he may outstrip: (A:) and in relation to the poorrate, it means the collector's alighting in the most remote of the places whence the portion appointed for the poor-rate is to be collected, and then ordering that the camels or the like [that constitute that portion] shall be led to him: or the going of the owner of the property to a distance, [or aside, or out of the way,] with his property, so that the collector is obliged to go to a distance in quest of it. (K. See more in art. jlb, first paragraph.) ― -b3- He placed, or put, at a distance, or he put, or sent, away, or far away, or far off, or he removed far away, alienated, or estranged, him, or it; (K;) as though he put him, or it, aside, or as though he walked aside; as also jAnbhu↓ (TA.) And He pushed, thrust, or drove, him, or it, away, aside, or to a distance. (K, * TA.) And janabahu Al$~aYo'a (S, K, *) or Al$~ar~a (Fr, Zj, Msb,) aor.
januba
; (S, Msb, K;) and jn~bhu↓, (Fr, Zj, S, A, Msb, K,) but this has an intensive signification; (Msb;) and Ajnbhu↓; (Fr, Zj, A, K;) He put aside, or away, or he warded off, from him, (S,) or he removed from him, (S, Msb, K,) or removed far from him, (Msb, K,) the thing, (S, K, *) or evil. (Fr, Zj, A, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [xiv. 38], waA@jonuboniY wabaniY~a A^ano naEobuda AlA^aSonaAma [And put Thou away from me and my sons our worshipping of idols], (S,) or, accord. to one reading, waA^ajoniboniY↓. (TA.) ― -b4- He yearned towards, longed for, or desired, him, or it. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- janaba bihi,
aor.
januba
, [He went aside, apart, out of the way, to a distance, or far away, with him, or it: or, like janabahu, in a sense explained above,] he placed, or put, at a distance, or he put, or sent, away, or far away, or far off, him, or it. (K, TA.) ― -b2- janaba fiY baniY fulaAnK, (S, K, *) aor.
januba
, inf. n. janaAbapN; (S;) and tjn~b↓; (so, app., in the TA;) He alighted, or descended and abode, or settled, as a stranger, among the sons of such a one. (S, K, * TA.) One says, niEoma Alqawomu humo lijaAri AljanaAbapi [Excellent are the people, they,] to the neighbour who is a stranger. (S. [See also junubN.]) And laA taHoriman~iY Eano janaAbapK Do not thou by any means refuse me because of being remote (S, A, TA) in respect of relationship. (A, TA.) [See also janaAbapN mentioned below as a subst.] ― -b3- janabati Alr~iyHu, (S, A, K,) aor.
januba
(TA,) inf. n. junuwbN; (K;) and Ajnbt↓; (TA;) The wind was, or became, such as is termed januwb [i. e. south, or southerly]; (K;) it blew in the direction of the wind thus called: (A, TA:) or the former, (S,) or janibat, (TA,) the wind changed, or veered, so as to become januwb (S, TA.) ― -b4- [And hence, (see januwbN,)] janaba A_ilayohi, (IAar, K,) or A_ilaY liqaAy^ihi, (TA,) aor.
januba
; (K;) and janiba, aor.
janaba
; (Th, K;) [inf. n., app., janobN, for the verb is said in the K to be like naSara and samiEa;] (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, disquieted by vehement desire to see him, or to meet him. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- janiba, aor.
janaba
, (S,) inf. n. janabN, (S, K,) He (a camel) limped, or halted, by reason of [pain in] his side: (S:) or he had an affection resembling ZaloE [i. e. limping, or halting], (K, TA,) but not the same as this: (TA:) and, (K,) or accord. to As, (S,) his lungs clave to his side by reason of vehement thirst: (S, K:) or, accord. to the Arabs of the desert, as ISk says, he became bent, or contorted, by reason of vehemence of thirst: (S:) and he (a camel) had a pain in his side from vehemence of thirst. (TA.) The epithet is janibN↓; which is applied by Dhu-r-Rummeh to an ass. (S, TA.) ― -b2- jnbt Ald~alowu [app. janibat] The bucket inclined to one side in consequence of the breaking of one or two of the thongs attacking it to the cross-bars. (L, TA.) ＝ -A4- janiba and januba and janaba are syn. with A^ajonaba in a sense explained below: see 4. ＝ -A5- juniba He had, or became affected by, the disease termed *aAtu Aljanobi [or pleurisy]: (S, Mgh, Msb:) he had a complaint of his side. (K.) ＝ -A6- junibuwA They were, or became, affected by the [south, or southerly, wind called] junuwb. (S, A, K.) And also, [in allusion to the fertilizing effect attributed to the wind so called,] They were, or became, affected by that wind in their cattle. (L, TA.)

2 jn~bhu jnb jnbh jnbp
: see 1: ― -b2- and see also 3. ＝ -A2- jnb~, inf. n. tajoniybN, He did not send the stallion-camel among his she-camels, nor the ram or he-goat among his ewes or she-goats. (K.) ― -b2- jn~b Alqawomu The milk of the people's camels became little: (S:) or the people's milk ceased; (K, TA;) or became little: or the people's camels had no milk: and jn~b said of a man, his camels had no milk, nor had his sheep or goats. (TA.) Hence, EaAmu tajoniybK [A year of little, or no, milk]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- jn~bt AlA^ibilu The camels, with the exception of one or two, brought forth no young. (AZ, TA.) The camels did not conceive, so as to have milk. (TA.) ＝ -A3- tajoniybN [as an inf. n. of which the verb, if it have one in any of the following senses, is jun~iba,] also signifies A bending, or curving, and tension [of the sinews] (tawotiyrN), of the hind leg of a horse; which is a quality approved: (S, K:) or, accord. to AO, a turning aside of his fore legs in raising them and putting them down: but accord. to As, it is in the kind legs, and taHoniybN is in the back-bone and in the fore legs. (TA.) [See also 2 in art Hnb; and see also mujan~abN.]

3 jAnbhu jAnb jAnbh jAnbp
, (A, K,) inf. n. mujaAnabapN and jinaAbN, (K,) He was, or became, at, or by, his side: (A, K:) and he walked, or went, by his side. (A.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. baA Eadahu; (A, K;) i. e. He was, or became, [distant, remote, far off, or aloof, from him; or] apart from him; or in a part, quarter, or tract, different from that in which he (the other) was; (TA;) thus bearing two contr. significations. (A, K.) jAnbhu and tjAnbhu↓ and tjn~buhu↓ and Ajtnbhu↓ all signify the same, (S, K,) i. e. He was, or became, distant, remote, far off, or aloof, or he went, or removed, or retired, or withdrew himself, to a distance, or far away, or far off, or he alienated, or estranged, himself, or he stood, or kept, aloof, from him, or it; he shunned, or avoided, him, or it; as also jin~bh↓ (K) [and minohu tjn~b↓]. You say, jaAnibi All~iy^aAma [Remove thyself far from the mean, or ignoble; stand, or keep, aloof from them; shun, or avoid, them]. (A.) And laj~a fiY jinaAbK qabiyHK He persisted in removing himself to a distance, or estranging himself, from his family. (S, A, K. [In two copies of the S, I find jnAb here written with fet-h to the j; but it is expressly said in the TA to be with kesr.]) ― -b2- See also 1.

4 Ajnbhu A^jnbh Ajnbh Ajnbp jnb
: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places. ＝ -A2- Ajnb, (S, IAth, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. A_ijonaAbN; (IAth, TA;) and janiba↓; (IB, K;) but the former is more common than the latter; and the latter, than the next here following; (IB, TA;) and januba↓ (S, Msb, K,) [inf. n. janaAbapN, agreeably with analogy;] and janaba↓, aor.
januba
; (L, TA;) and A^ujoniba, and Astjnb↓, (K,) and tjn~b↓; (L, TA;) He was, or became, in the state of one who is termed junub; (S, IAth, Mgh, L, Msb, K;) i. e., under the obligation of performing a total ablution, by reason of sexual intercourse and discharge of the semen. (IAth, TA.) laA yujonibu, said by I' Ab, of a man, and of a garment, and of the ground, (TA,) and of water, (Mgh, TA,) means (tropical:) He, or it, will not become polluted (Mgh, TA) by the touch of him who is junub so that one should need total ablution in consequence of the touching thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A3- AjnbwA They entered upon [a time in which blew] the [south, or southerly,] wind termed Aljunuwb. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- See also 1 in the latter half of the paragraph.

5 tajan~aba
see 1: ― -b2- and 3, in two places: ― -b3- and 4.

6 tajaAonaba
see 3.

8 A_ijotanaba
see 3.

10 A_isotajonaba
see 4.

janobN jnb
, a word of well-known meaning; (S;) The side, or half, or lateral half, syn. $iq~N, (A, K,) of a man &c.; as also jaAnibN↓ and janabapN↓: (K:) or the part of a man that is beneath the arm-pit, extending to the flank; as also jaAnibN↓, because it is the side of the person: (Msb:) pl. (of the first, Msb) junuwbN (Msb, K) and [of the same, a pl. of pauc.,] A^ajonaAbN (CK) and [of jaAnibN] jawaAnibu (Lh, ISd, K, but not in the CK) and [app. of janobN (like as layaAy^ilu is a pl. of layolN) or of janabapN (like as HawaAy^iju is pl. of HaAjapN which is originally HawajapN) or of both these] janAy^ibu↓ (M, K,) which is extr. (M, TA.) [Hence,] qaEadotu A_ilaY janobi fulaAnK and flAn AlY jaAnibi↓ [I sat by the side of such a one]: both meaning the same. (S.) And A_in~ahu lamunotafixu AljawaAnibi↓ [Verily he is inflated in the side]: jwAnb being here one of those words which are used in the sing. sense though in the pl. form. (Lh, TA.) And A^aEoTaAhu Aljanoba [lit. He gave him the side; meaning] he was, or became, submissive, manageable, easy, or tractable, to him. (A.) And jaAru Aljanobi He who cleaves to one, keeping by one's side. (K. [Differing from jaAru Aljunubi, q. v. infrà.]) And AlS~aAHibu biAljanobi [in the Kur iv. 40] The travelling-companion; the companion in a journey: (S, K:) or he who is near one; or by one's side: or the companion in every good affair: or the husband: or the wife. (TA.) And *aAtu Aljanobi, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) with which AljunaAbu↓ is syn., (K,) [and sometimes Aljanobu, as will be seen in what follows,] A well-known disease; (Mgh;) [the pleurisy; called by the first of these three appellations in the present day;] a severe disease, being an inflammatory tumour in the [pleura, or] membrane within the ribs: (Msb:) or an ulcer, or a purulent pustule, that comes within a man's side: (S, TA:) it is a severe disease in the side: accord. to El-Hejeree, it is in either side; and they assert that when it is in the left side, the patient perishes: accord. to ISh, the dubayolap; which is an ulcer that penetrates into the belly: or the ulcer (dubayolap and dum~al) that comes forth within the side, and discharges internally; the sufferer from which seldom recovers: he who suffers from it [and dies in consequence], or, as some say, he who is afflicted by a complaint of the side (absolutely) while warring in the cause of God, is reckoned a martyr: (TA:) [soldiers in a campaign are notoriously more subject to it than persons in most other circumstances; and it is app. for this reason that] it is termed daA='u AlS~anaAdiydi [the disease of the courageous chiefs]. (A, TA.) *uw Aljanobi, of which *aAtu Aljunobi is the fem., signifies Having a complaint of his side by reason of [the disease above mentioned, or what is termed] Ald~ubayolap. (TA. [See also majonuwbN.]) ― -b2- A poet says,
Aln~aAsu janobN waAlA^amiyru janobu
[The people are a side and the prince is a side]: (Akh, S, TA:) as though he reckoned the latter equal to all the people. (TA. [This is cited in the S and TA as though it were an ex. of jnb in the sense here next following: but it seems to be rather an ex. of this word in the sense first explained in the present paragraph.]) ― -b3- I. q. naAHiyapN [A side; meaning a lateral, or an outward or adjacent, part or portion, region, quarter, or tract; or a part, region, quarter, or tract, considered with respect to its collocation or juxtaposition or direction, or considered as belonging to a whole; a vicinage, or neighbourhood]; (S, K;) as also jaAnibN↓ (S, Msb, K) and janaAbN↓ and janobapN↓ (S, K) and janabapN↓ (S) and janaAbapN↓. (L, TA.) It is said that the primary signification of janobN is the part of the body mentioned in the beginning of this paragraph, and that its use in the sense of naAHyapN is metaphorical, as is the case of yamiynN and $imaAlN; but naAHiyapN is mentioned in the Msb as the primary signification of jaAnibN↓; (MF, TA;) though its primary signification accord. to the K and ISd seems to be that first mentioned. (TA.) You say, ma$awoA jaAnibayohi↓ and janaAbayohi↓ and janobatayohi↓ and janaAbatayohi↓ [They walked, or went on foot, on either side of him]. (A, TA. *) And mar~uwA yasiyruwna janaAbayohi↓ (S, L) and janobatayohi↓ and janaAbatayohi↓ (L, TA) They went along journeying on either side of him. (S, L.) And kun~aA Eanohumo janaA bayoni↓ and janaAbFA↓ We were apart from them [on two sides and on one side]. (TA.) And nazaluwA AlwaAdiY fiY janaAbaAti↓ [They alighted in the sides of the valley, or in the tracts beside the valley]. (A.) And fulaAnN laA yaTuwru bijanabatinaA↓ Such a one will not approach our quarter: (S:) thus accord. to AO; with fet-h to the n: IJ, however, says, people are wont to say, A^anaA fiY *araAka wajanabatika↓ [meaning I am under thy protection and in thy quarter]; but that the correct expression is janobatika↓, with the n quiescent. (IB, TA.) The Arabs also said, suhayolK AlHar~u jaAnibaYo↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) The heat is on either side of Suheyl [or Canopus: i. e., during the period next before, and that next after, the auroral rising of Canopus; which rising began, in central Arabia, at the commencement of the era of the Flight, about the 4th of August, O. S.]: this is the greatest heat. (TA.) One also says, A^aHaATuwA bihi mino jaAnibayohi↓ [meaning They surrounded him on all his sides; lit., on his two sides]; dividing the surrounding parts into two, but not meaning that any of these remained vacant. (Expos. of the exs. cited as testimonies by Sb, TA in art. Hwl.) ― -b4- Also, [and jaAnibN↓, which is thus used in the L in art. jnH, and by many authors,] A part, or portion, of a thing; (L;) the greater, or main, or chief, part or portion thereof; most thereof; (L, K;) or a great part or portion thereof; much thereof. (L.) Hence, [or perhaps from janobN in the second of the senses assigned to it above, conveying the idea of juxtaposition, and thus of comparison,] h`*aA qaliylN janobi mawad~atika [This is little in comparison with the magnitude of thy love; or simply, in comparison with thy love]. (TA.) ― -b5- yaA HasorataA EalaY maA far~aTotu fiY jnobi A@ll~`hi [in the Kur xxxix. 57] means fY jaAnibih↓, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [O my grief, or regret, for my negligence, or remissness,] in respect of that which is the right, or due, of God! (A, Bd, TA,) i. e., (Bd,) in respect of obedience to God! (Bd, Jel:) or, in respect of [the means of attaining] nearness to God! (Fr, TA;) or, nearness to God in Paradise! (IAar, TA:) or, in respect of the way of God, to which He hath called me! i. e., the profession of his unity, and the confession of the prophetic office of Mohammad. (Zj, TA.) The saying of the Arabs, Ait~aqi A@ll~`ha fiY janobihi walaA taqodaHo fiY saAqihi [may be rendered (assumed tropical:) Fear God in respect of his (thy brother's) right, or due, and impugn not his honour, or reputation: or] means, accord. to the copies of the K, laA taqotulohu [slay him not], or, as in the L, and in the original draught of the author [of the K] lA tagotalohu [slay him not clandestinely, or on an occasion of inadvertence], from Algiylapu, and throw him not into trouble, or trial: (TA:) or, accord. to some, fY jnbh means in detracting from his reputation, or reviling him. (K, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 240.]) A poet, cited by IAar, says,
xaliylaY~a kuf~aA waA@*okuraA A@ll~`ha fiY janobiY
(assumed tropical:) [O my two friends, refrain, and be mindful of God in respect of my reputation; (see also jaAnibN;)] meaning, in detracting from my reputation, or reviling me: or, accord. to MF, in my case. (TA.) And one says, maA faEalota fiY janobi HaAjatiY (assumed tropical:) What didst thou, or what hast thou done, in the case of the thing that I want? (L, TA.)

janabN jnb
: see janiybN. ＝ -A2- TawoEu Aljanabi: see jinaAbN. ＝ -A3- janabN also signifies Short; (K;) applied to a man. (TA.)

janibN jnb
: see janiba. ― -b2- It is also applied as an epithet to a wolf, because he pretends to halt, from guile, or cunning. (L, TA.) ― -b3- Also A man who goes aside, or to a distance, from the beaten way, for fear of guests' coming to him for entertainment. (K, TA.)

junubN jnb
, (El-Fárábee, S, A, Msb, K,) which is sometimes used in the sing. form as pl., and has no fem. form, (TA,) and jaAnibN↓ and A^ajonabiY~N↓, (El-Fárábee, S, Msb, K,) which is said by Az in art. rwH to be seldom or never used by the Arabs, but is mentioned by him in its proper art., (Msb,) and A^ajonabu↓, (Az, S, Msb, K,) are syn., (El-Fárábee, S, Msb, K,) signifying A stranger; (K;) as also janiybN↓: (S:) or a man who is distant, or remote: (Msb:) or distant, or remote, in respect of relationship: (Az and Msb in explanation of the third and fourth:) [or not a relation; as will be seen from what follows:] and jaAnibN↓ [as an act. part. n.] signifies one alighting, or descending and abiding, or settling, as a stranger, among a tribe: (S:) pl. of the first A^ajonaAbN, (A, TA,) and of the second jun~aAbN, (S, TA,) and of the fourth A^ajaAnibu. (Msb.) AljaAru Aljunubu [occurring in the Kur iv. 40] (T, S, A, Msb, K) and jaAru Aljunubi (TA) The person who is one's neighbour, but who belongs to another people; (T, S, A, Msb, K;) who is not of one's family nor of one's lineage; (A;) who is of another lineage than he of whom he is a neighbour; (T, TA;) who is not a relation: (MF:) or one who is distant, or remote, in an absolute sense: (TA:) or the person who is not a relation to another, and who comes to him, and asks him to protect him, and abides with him: such has the title to respect that belongs to him as neighbour of the other, and to his protection, and as relying upon his safeguard and promise. (TA in art. jwr. [Differing from jaAru Aljanobi, q. v. suprà.]) It is said in a trad., humo A^ajonaAbu Aln~aAsi They are the strangers of mankind, or of the people. (TA.) And in another trad., qaAla lijaAriy~pK halo mino mugaribapi Alxabaru xabarK qaAlato EalaY jaAnibK↓ [He said to a girl, Is there any news from abroad? She answered,] It is for a stranger coming from a journey [to give such news]. (TA.) And one says, huwa min~iY A^ajonabiY~N↓ [He is a person not related to me]. (A.) ― -b2- Also, ↓the same four words, (of which only the last is mentioned in this sense in the S,) That will not be led; intractable. (K.) ― -b3- junubN is also an epithet from AljanaAbapu; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) signifying A man under the obligation of performing a total ablution, by reason of sexual intercourse and discharge of the semen: (IAth, TA: [see 4:]) and is used alike as masc. and fem. (S, Mgh, Msb) and sing. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and dual (Msb, TA) and pl.; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) being regarded as quasi-coordinate to the class of inf. ns.; for the inf. n., when used as an epithet, must remain, in form, sing. and masc.: (MF in art. Eft:) or one may use the dual form junubaAni; (K;) and sometimes they used the pl. A^ajonaAbN (S, Msb, K *) and junubuwna, (S, Msb,) and the fem. pl. junubaAtN; (Msb;) but not junubapN, (K, TA,) applied to a female. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA tadoxulu AlmalaAy^ikapu biyotFA fiyhi junubN, meaning [The angels will not enter a house, or chamber, or tent, in which is] one who usually neglects the total ablution when under an obligation to perform it for the cause above mentioned. (IAth, TA.)

janobapN jnb jnbh jnbp
: see janobN, in four places: ― -b2- and see jaAnibN. ― -b3- Also Retirement, or secession, from others: (K, TA:) and in a trad., in which it is enjoined, used as meaning retirement from women; avoiding the sitting by them, and the approaching the place that they occupy. (TA.) You say, rajulN *uw janobapK A man of retirement. (TA.) And nazala janobapF He alighted, or descended and abode, or settled, in a place aside, or apart. (S, TA.) And qaEada janobapF He [sat apart, or] retired from others. (A, TA.) ― -b4- The state of being a stranger; as also janaAbapN↓. (K. [Both are there mentioned as simple substs.; but the latter is an inf. n.: see janaba fiY baniY fulaAnK; and what next follows it: and see also 4.]) Both also signify Remoteness in respect of relationship. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, janobapN, A piece of skin from the side of a camel, (S, L, K, *) of which is made a kind of milking vessel (Eulobap), (S, L,) larger than the miEolaq, but smaller than the jawobap. (L.) ＝ -A3- And Every kind of plant, (S,) or
every kind of tree in general, (K,) that produces [new leaves such as are termed] rabol in the season of the Sayof [which may mean either summer or spring]: (S, K:) or every kind of plant that produces leaves in that season without rain: (TA:) or a name given to many plants, all of them Euruwq [perhaps meaning resembling roots, i. e. straggling, or spreading like roots]; so called because less than large trees and higher than those that have no root-stock (A^aruwmap) in the earth; comprising the naSiY~ and Sil~iyaAn and HamaAT and makor and H*r [so in the TA, but I do not find it elsewhere, and think it may be a mistranscription for Hazor, of which Hazorap (the name of a certain sour tree) is probably the n. un.,] and dahomaA='; which are smaller than $ajar and superior to buquwl: all this has been heard from the Arabs: (T, TA:) or green and fresh Sl~yAn: (TA:) or what is [of a kind] between baqol and $ajar; (AHn, K, TA;) being [in the TA whmA, but this is evidently a mistake for wahiYa,] of the kind of which the root remains in the winter while the branches perish: (AHn, TA:) or herbage of which the root is deep in the earth; such as the naSiY~ and the Sil~iyaAn. (TA voce xaDirN.)

janabapN jnb jnbh jnbp
: see janobN, in four places: ― -b2- and see jaAnibN.

junabapN jnb jnbh jnbp
A thing from which one retires, or withdraws himself, to a distance, or far away, or far off; from which one stands, or keeps, aloof. (K.)

janaAbN jnAb
: see janobN, in five places. [Hence,] kun~aA Eanohumo janaAbayoni and janaAbFA We were remote, or retired, from them; or out of their way. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (S, A, Msb, K,) and jaAnibN↓, (Msb, * TA,) A court, or yard, or an open or a wide space in front of a house or extending from its sides: (S, A, K, TA:) and a place of alighting or abode; or a settlement, or place of settling: (A:) a mansion; an abode; a habitation; or a place to which a man betakes himself, or repairs, for lodging, covert, or refuge, in a city or town or village or other place of settled habitations; syn. raHolN: (K:) and a vicinage, neighbourhood, or tract adjacent to the place of abode or settlement, of a people or company of men: pl. A^ajonibapN. (S.) You say, A^anaA fiY janaAbi zayodK I am in the court, or yard, of Zeyd; and in his place of alighting or abode, or settlement. (A, TA.) And fulaAnN raHobu AljanaAbi, (A, TA,) and xaSiybu AljanaAbi, (S, A,) the former meaning Such a one is possessed of an ample raHol [or mansion, &c., as explained above]: (TA:) [and the latter, such a one is surrounded by a plentiful, or fruitful, tract:] or both mean (tropical:) such a one is generous or bountiful [or hospitable]. (A.) And falaAnN jadiybu AljanaAbi (S, TA) [meaning Such a one is environed by a tract affected with drought, or barrenness; as explained in the S in art. jdb: but generally used tropically, as meaning (assumed tropical:) such a one is ungenerous, illiberal, or inhospitable]. And A^axoSaba janaAbu Alqawomi [The neighbourhood of the people, or the tract surrounding them, became plentiful, or fruitful]. (S, TA.) And A^ajodaba binaA AljanaAbu [Our neighbourhood, or the tract surrounding us, became affected with drought, or barrenness]. (TA from a trad.) ― -b3- rajulN lay~inu AljanaAbi [perhaps a mistranscription for AljaAnibi] (tropical:) A man easy to deal with, compliant, or obsequious. (A.) ― -b4- [AljanaAbu is also a title often given by writers of letters and the like to any great man to whom others betake themselves, or repair, for protection; and sometimes to God; meaning (tropical:) The object of recourse; the refuge; the asylum: similar to AlHaDorapu, q. v., and used in the same manner, i. e., alone, and, without the article, prefixed to the name of the person to whom it is applied, or to a pronoun; but the latter is generally considered as implying greater respect than the former.]

AljunaAbu AljnAb jnAb
i. q. *aAtu Aljanobi: see janobu. (K.)

jinaAbN jnAb
A cord tied to the head and neck of a beast, by which he is led, or drawn. (KL.) [Hence,] farasN TawoEu AljanaAbi A horse easily led; or easy to be led; tractable; [obedient to the jnAb;] (S, A, K, TA;) as also TawoEu Aljanabi↓. (TA. [See 1, near the beginning.])

januwbN jnwb
, of the fem. gender, and, accord. to Sb, both a subst. and an epithet, [so that one says riyHN januwbN, as well as januwbN alone and riyHu Aljanuwbi,] (TA,) [The south wind: or a southerly wind:] the wind that is opposite to that called the $amaAl: (S, K:) [consequently, the wind that blows from the direction of the south pole, accord. to the S;] the wind that blows from the direction of the left hand of a person standing opposite to the kibleh [by which is here meant that corner of the Kaabeh in which is set the Black Stone; which corner is towards the east]: (Th, TA:) or the wind that blows from the quarter between the place where Canopus rises [S. 29? E. in central Arabia] and the place where the same star sets [S. 29? W. in the same latitude]: ('Omárah, TA:) or from the quarter between the place where Canopus rises and the place where the sun sets in winter [W. 26? S. in central Arabia]: (As, TA:) or it is a hot wind, that blows in every season; blowing from that part of the tract between the quarter whence blows the east wind (AlS~abaA) and that whence blows the west wind (Ald~abuwr) which is next to the place where Canopus rises: (T, TA:) or the wind that blows from the quarter between the place where Canopus rises and that where the Pleiades set [W. 26? N. in central Arabia]: (IAar, K:) [the points whence it usually blows seem to differ somewhat in different parts:] As says that the jnwb is attended by good, and by fecundating influence; and the $mAl by drying up [of the earth &c.]: (TA:) accord. to IAar, it is hot in every place, except in Nejd, where it is cold, or cool: (MF:) pl. janaAy^ibu (T, K) and [of pauc.] A^ajonubN. (T, TA.) ― -b2- One says, of two persons, when they are on terms of sincere friendship, riyHuhumaA januwbN (assumed tropical:) [Their wind is south, or southerly]; and when they are separated, $amalato riyHuhumaA (assumed tropical:) [Their wind has become north, or northerly]. (TA.)

janiybN jnyb
, applied to a horse and a captive, (TA,) Led by one's side; as also majonuwbN↓ and mujan~abN↓: (K:) or you say xayolN majan~abapN↓, meaning horses led by the side; the teshdeed denoting application to many objects: (S, TA:) pl. [of the first, and of janiybapN, q. v., or only of this last,] janaAy^ibu and [quasi-pl. n.] janabN↓. (K.) One walking by the side of another; (A;) [and] so jun~aAbN↓. (K.) ― -b2- Any animal or man that is obedient, tractable, or submissive. (S, TA.) You say, A^aSobaHa janiybahu He became compliant to him. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also junubN. ＝ -A3- Also, applied to a man, [app. Having a pain in the side; or having the pleurisy; like majonuwbN: and hence, or from janiba, q. v., irregularly formed,] as though walking on one side, bent or crooked, mutaEaq~ifFA: so in the L: in the M and K, on the authority of IAar, mutaEaq~ibFA [to which I am unable to assign an appropriate meaning, except its modern one of lagging behind]: so in the saying of a poet,
rabaA AljuwEu fiY A^awonayohi Hat~aY kaA^an~ahu
janiybN bihi A_in~a Aljaniyba janiybu
[Hunger increased in him (lit. in the two sides of his saddle-bags); so that he seemed as though he walked on one side, bent thereby; for he who has a pain in his side walks on one side, in that manner]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Also An excellent kind of dates, (K, TA,) well known; (TA;) one of the best kinds of dates. (Mgh in art. jmE, Msb.)

janaAbapN jnAb jnAbh jnAbp
: see janobN, in four places: and see jaAnibN. ＝ -A2- See also janobapN. ― -b2- Accord. to IAth, its primary signification is Distance: and hence it signifies The state of him who is under the obligation of performing a total ablution, by reason of sexual intercourse and discharge of the semen. (TA.) ― -b3- The sperma genitalis [itself]. (K. [But in a marginal note in my copy of that work I find this last signification rejected as erroneous.]) ＝ -A3- See also the next paragraph.

janiybapN jnybh jnybp
A led horse or mule or ass; (S, TA;) a horse that is led [by one's side], not ridden: (Msb:) pl. janaAy^ibu. (A, TA.) ― -b2- janiybataA AlbaEiyri The [two equal] loads on the two sides of the camel. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence, app.,] Ait~aqi A@ll~`ha Al~a*iY laA janybapa lahu (tropical:) Fear thou God, to whom there is no equal. (A, TA.) ― -b4- Also janiybupN, (S,) or janaAbapN↓, (K,) or both, (TA,) A she-camel that one gives [or lends] to people, (S, M, K,) with money, (M, TA,) in order that they may bring corn or other provision for him; (S, M, K;) also called EaliyqapN: pl. janaAy^ibu. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also, (Kr, M, K,) and xabiybapN, (M, TA,) The wool of a van~iY [or sheep in its third year]: (Kr, M, K:) it is better and cleaner than what is termed Eaqiyqap, which is the wool of a ja*aE [or sheep in or before its second year]. (TA.)

[
januwbiY~N jnwb jnwbY jnwby
Of, or relating to, the quarter of the wind termed the januwb; south, or southerly.]

janaAy^ibN *
as an extr. pl.: see janobN, first sentence.

jun~aAbN jnAb
: see janiybN.

jaAnibN jAnb
; pl. jawaAnibu: see janobN, in eleven places.
[Hence, laAna jaAnibuhu (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, gentle, easy to deal with, compliant, or obsequious. And rajulN lay~inu AljaAnibi (assumed tropical:) A man who is gentle, easy to deal with, compliant, or obsequious; contr. of galiyZu AljaAnibi; see art. glZ: and see janaAbN. And] tuzan~u biliyni AljaAnibi (assumed tropical:) [She is suspected of easiness, or compliance], (K in art. lms,) towards him who desires of her that he may lie with her. (TA in that art.) [Hence also,] jaAnibaA AlA^anofi (CK) and janaAbataA↓ and janobataA↓ and janabataA↓ (K) The two sides of the nose: (K:) or the two lines that surround the two sides of the nose of a doe-gazelle: (Sb, TA:) pl. [of the second, agreeably with analogy,] janaAy^ibu. (TA.) ― -b2- See also janaAbN. [It often signifies The vicinage or neighbourhood of a people &c.: and a region or quarter or tract of a people or country: like nAHyp. ― -b3- The bank of a river; and any bank, or steep acclivity. ― -b4- And A limit, bound, or boundary: see a tropical usage of its pl. (jawaAnibu) voce. HinowN. ― -b5- And EalaY jaAnibK means Beside, aside, or apart; and so jaAnibFA, and fiY jaAnibK. ― -b6- jaAnibN mino maAlK, in posi-classical writings, means A portion, and particularly a large portion, of property: and jaAnibN alone, in the same, a sum, and particularly a large sum, of money. ― -b7- The latter, also, in post-classical writings, signifies, like janobN, q. v., (assumed tropical:) A man's honour, or reputation, which should be preserved inviolate; so used in the K voce EiroDN, in an explanation of the latter word taken from IAth; i. q. naAmuwsN and HuromapN, as in the TK in that case.] ＝ -A2- Avoided and despised. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps, daEo ka*aA jaAnibFA Let thou, or leave thou, such a thing alone: see an ex. voce A^aw~N.] ― -b3- See also junubN, in four places. ― -b4- And see mujan~abN.

A^ajonabu *
: see junubN, in two places.

A^ajonabiY~N *
: see junubN, in three places ― -b2- You say also, huwa A^ajonabiY~N mino ka*aA, (A,) or Eino k*A, (TA,) (tropical:) He has no concern nor acquaintance with such a thing. (A, TA.)

majonabN mjnb
(S, AAF, K) and mijonabN↓ (AAF, K) Much (A'Obeyd, S, AAF, K) of good (A'Obeyd, K) and of evil. (K.) You say, A_in~a EinodanaA laxayorFA majonabFA Verily with us is much good, and $ar~FA majonabFA much evil. (S.) And TaEaAmN majonabN means Much [wheat or food]. (Sh, TA.)

mujonibN mjnb
: see what next follows.

mijonabN mjnb
A shield; (S, A, K;) because it wards off from its possessor what is displeasing to him; (A, TA;) also with damm to the m [app. mujonibN↓, act. part. n. of 4]. (K.) ― -b2- A thing by which a person or thing is veiled, concealed, or hidden; a veil, curtain, or covering; (K, TA;) for a house, or chamber, or tent. (TA.) ― -b3- A thing like a door, upon which the gatherer of honey stands; (K, TA;) he being let down [upon it] by means of ropes to [the place of] the honey [in the face of a rock or mountain]. (TA.) ― -b4- A thing ($abaHN [app. here meaning a wooden implement]) resembling a comb without teeth (K, TA) and thinedged in its lowest part, (TA,) with which earth is raised upon, or against, the A^aEoDaAd and fulojaAn [or raised borders of watering-troughs or the like, and streamlets for irrigation]. (K, TA. [In the CK, AlfilojAni is put for AlfulojAni.]) ― -b5- The extreme part of the territory of the foreigners towards that of the Arabs: (S, K:) and the nearest part of the territory of the Arabs to that of the foreigners. (S) ＝ -A2- See also majonabN.

mujan~abN mjnb
; and its fem., with p: see janiybN. ― -b2- Also, the former, (TA,) or jaAnibN↓, (K, [but this is said in the TA to be a mistake,]) A horse wide in the space between the two kind legs, (K, TA,) without what is termed fajajN [which is an awkward kind of straddling, with the hocks wide apart]: it is a quality approved. (TA. [See also 2; and see muHan~abN.])

mujan~ibN mjnb
A man whose sheep or goats [&c.] have few young ones; [and therefore, having little milk;] (TA in art. ysr;) contr. of muyasarN. (S and TA in that art. [See also 2.])

mujan~abapN mjnbh mjnbp
The van, or fore part, (K, TA,) of an army. (TA.)

Almujan~ibataAni AlmjnbtAn mjnbp
The right and left wings of an army: (K: [Golius has erroneously written mijonabataAni, and has given J as the authority instead of the K:]) or mujan~abapN signifies a portion of an army (katiybapN) that takes one of the two sides of a way: but the former meaning is the more correct. (IAar, TA.)

majonuwibN mjnwb
pass. part. n. of 1 [q. v.]. ― -b2- See also jniybN. ― -b3- Also Affected by the disease termed *aAtu Aljanobi [or pleurisy]: (S, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and said to mean also having a complaint of his side, absolutely. (TA.) ― -b4- And Affected by the [south, or southerly, wind called] januwb. (S, TA.) [And Affected by that wind in one's cattle: see 1, last sentence.] saHaAbapN majonuwbapN A cloud brought by the blowing of that wind. (S, A, K.) The saying of Aboo-Wejzeh,
majonuwbapu AlA^unosi ma$omuwlN mawaAEiduhaA
means Her familiarity passes away with the januwb [or south-wind], and her promises pass away with the $amaAl [or north wind]. (IAar, TA.)

jinovN jnv
i. q. A^aSolN [as meaning The stock, or stem, or the root, or base, or lowest part, of a tree or plant: and the stock, or origin, of a man]; (S, K;) a dial. var. of jinosN, or a word mispronounced: (S:) or, as some say, a root (of a tree) of which the A^aruwmap [i. e. root-stock] is erect in the ground: or the part of the saAq [i. e. stock, or stem,] of a tree that is in the ground, above the Euruwq [or roots properly so called]: (L, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajonaAvN and [of mult.] junuwvN. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN mino jinovika and jinosika, meaning mn A^aSolika [i. e. Such a one is of thy stock]. (S.) And A_in~ahu layarojiEu A_ilaY jinovi SidoqK [Verily he traces back his lineage to an excellent stock, or origin]. (TA.)

1 janaHa jnH jnHp
, (S, A, K, &c.,) aor.
janaHa
, (S, Msb, K,) agreeably with analogy, of the dial. of Temeem, and the most chaste form, (TA,) and
januHa
, (S, Msb, K,) of the dial. of Keys, (TA,) and
janiHa
, (K,) inf. n. junuwHN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He, or it, inclined, leant, or propended, (S, A, Mgh, L, K) A_ilayohi (L, Msb) and lahu (L) [to, or towards, it]; as also AjtnH↓, (S, Mgh, K,) and AjnH↓. (K [but, by the omission of a w after it, this is made in some copies of the K to relate to what there follows it].) It is said in the Kur [viii. 63], waA_ino janaHuwA lils~alomi faA@jonaHo lahaA (Mgh, L) And if they incline to peace, incline thou to it: slm being here made fem. because syn. with muSaAlaHap. (L.) You say, janaHuwA lils~alomi and A_ilayohi. (A.) ― -b2- He (a man) inclined, or leant, on one side; and leant upon his bow: as also AjtnH↓: and Ealayohi AjtnH↓ he leant upon him. (L.) And janaHato She (a camel lying on her breast) leant on one side. (AO, TA.) ― -b3- He (a man) set about a thing, to do it with his hands, his breast leaning over it. (T, TA.) ― -b4- janaHa EalaY mirofaqayohi, inf. n. junuwHN and janoHN, He (a man) rested himself upon his elbows, having set them upon the ground or upon a cushion. (ISh, TA.) ― -b5- janaHa A_ilayohimo and lahumo He [inclined to them; or] followed them and submitted to them; namely, a sect. (ISh, TA.) ― -b6- janaHati Al$~amosu liloguruwbi [The sun inclined to setting]. (A.) ― -b7- janaHa, (A, L, Msb,) aor.
janaHa
, (L, Msb,) inf. n. junuwHN, (S, L, K,) said of the night, (S, A, L, Msb, K) and of the evening, (A,) and of the darkness, (L,) It inclined to going, or to coming: (A:) or it came on, or approached. (S, L, Msb, K.) ― -b8- Also, with the same aor. and inf. n., said of a bird, It contracted its wings to descend, or alight, and approached like one falling, and repairing to a place of refuge. (L.) ― -b9- janaHato said of camels, They lowered the fore part of the neck [in running]: or they went quickly, or swiftly.
