(TA.) ― -b10- And, inf. n. junuwHN, said of a ship (safiynap), She came to shallow water, and stuck to the ground, (A, L,)so as to cease from motion. (L.) ＝ -A2- janaHa, inf. n. junuwHN, He (a man) gave with his [janaAH, or] hand. (TA.) ＝ -A3- janaHahu, (S, L,) aor.
janaHa
, inf. n. janoHN, (L,) He hit, or hurt, its janaAH [or wing]; (S, L;) i. e., the jnAH of the bird. (S.) And janaHa fulaAnFA He hit, or hurt, the arm (janaAH) of such a one. (K. [In some copies of the K, by the omission of a w, this signification is erroneously made to relate to AjnH: so in the copies used by MF and SM, who state that the right verb is janaHa]) ＝ -A4- juniHa, (S, K,) with damm, (S,) like EuniYa, (K,) inf. n. junuwHN, (TA,) He (a camel) had his jawaAniH [the ribs so called] broken by reason of the heaviness of his load: (S, K:) or
he (a camel) had the first of his ribs broken in the part next the breast. (TA.) ＝ -A5- [janaHa also signifies He regarded an act as a crime, or sin. Thus,] A_in~Y laA^ajonaHu A^ano A=kula minohu, in a trad. respecting the property of the orphan, means Verily I regard as a crime, or sin, (junaAH,) my eating, or devouring, [aught] thereof. (TA.)

2 jn~Hhu jnH jnHh jnHp
, inf. n. tajoniyHN, He furnished it with wings, or (assumed tropical:) the like: see mujan~aHN.]

4 AjnH A^jnH AjnH jnAH jnH
: see 1, first sentence. ＝ -A2- AjnHhu He made him, or it, to incline, lean, or propend. (S, K.)

5 tajan~aHa
see 8.

8 AjtnH AjtnH
: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- Also He (an old man) leant towards the ground, supporting himself with his hands upon his knees, by reason of his weakness. (Mgh.) And He (a man prostrating himself in prayer) rested upon his palms, putting his fore arms apart (from his sides, IAth), not laying them on the ground; (so that they became like the wings of a bird; IAth); as also tjn~H↓. (Sh, IAth, Mgh, K.) ― -b3- AijotinaAHN in a she-camel is The going quickly, or swiftly: (Sh, K:) or the going so that her hinder part as it were leans towards her fore part, by reason of her vehement pressing on, (ISh, K, *) by her pushing forward her kind legs towards her breast: (ISh:) and in a horse, the running with a uniform leaning on one side. (A, O, K.)

10 AstjnH AstjnH
It (the night) began. (L.)

junoHu All~ayoli jnH Allyl
(S, A, Msb, K) and jinoHuhu↓ (S, Msb, K) A part, or portion, of the night: (S, A, K:) or a great, or the greater, part thereof: or the first part thereof: or a part thereof, about the half: (L:) or the darkness thereof; and its confusedness. (Msb.) kaA^an~ahu junoHu layolK [As though it were a portion, &c., of a night] is said of a numerous army heavily encumbered. (L.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce A_in~a.]

jinoHN jnH jnHp
A side (S, Msb, K) of a road. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And The vicinage or neighbourhood, or the region or quarter or tract, and the shadow or shelter or protection, syn. naAHiyapN and kanafN, (S, K,) as also janaAHN↓, (K,) of a people, or party, or company of men: (S:) the latter word thus used is tropical. (TA.) You say, baAta bijinoHi Alqawomi He passed the night in the vicinage, &c., of the people. (S, TA.) And A^anaA fiY janaAHihi↓ (tropical:) I am in his shadow, shelter, or protection. (TA.) ― -b3- See also the next preceding paragraph.

janaAHN jnAH
The yad (S, K) [meaning wing] of a bird or flying thing; (S;) i. e., of a bird or flying thing, the limb that corresponds to the yd of a man: (Msb:) and also the yd [i. e. arm, sometimes also meaning hand, (see a signification of janaHa,)] of a man: (L, TA:) and (K) the upper arm, or arm from the shoulder to the elbow: (Zj, L, K:) each of these is so called because it is on one side of the body: (L:) and the armpit: (K:) pl. A^ajoniHapN (S, Msb, K) and A^ajonuHN: (IJ, K:) the sing., though masc., has the latter pl., which properly belongs to a fem. sing. [of this form], because jnAH is assimilated to riy$apN; (IJ;) [or rather, I think, to yadN, which is fem.;] but some assert jnAH to be both masc. and fem. (MF.) [Hence,] huwa maqoSuwSu AljanaAHi [He has the wing clipped; meaning] (tropical:) he is one who lacks strength or power or ability; he is impotent. (A, TA.) And xafaDa lahu janaAHahu (tropical:) [He abased himself to him: lit. he lowered to him his wing: but see an explanation of a similar phrase in the Kur, below]. (A.) And rakibuwA janaAHaYi AlT~aAy^iri, (Fr, L, K,) in [some of the copies of] the K, AlT~ariyqi, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) They quitted their homes, or accustomed places. (Fr, L, K.) And fulaAnN fiY janaAHaYo TaAy^irK Such a one is in a state of disquiet, and confounded, or perplexed, unable to see his right course. (L, A. *) And rakiba fulaAnN janaAHaYi Aln~aEaAmapi (tropical:) Such a one employed himself vigorously, labouriously, sedulously, or diligently, in an affair; (A, K;) managing well. (K.) And naHonu EalaY janaAHi Als~afari [lit. We are on the wing of travel; meaning] (tropical:) we are about to travel, or journey. (K, TA.) And janaAHu Alfarasi (assumed tropical:) A certain star [ γ] of Pegasus; one of the four bright stars, in Pegasus, which form a square; the other three being that at the extremity of the neck, called Eayonu Alfarasi, [i. e. a of Pegasus,] that called manokibu Alfarasi, [ β of Pegasus,] and the star [a of Andromeda] that belongs to both Pegasus and Andromeda. (Kzw.) [And janaAHu samakapK (assumed tropical:) The fin of a fish.] And janaAHaA naSolK (assumed tropical:) The two wings, or blades, of a spear-head or of an arrow-head. (L.) And janaAHu Alr~aHaY (assumed tropical:) The wing (naAEuwr) of the mill or mill-stone. (L.) And janaAHaA EasokarK (tropical:) The two wings of an army. (A, TA) And janaAHaA AlwaAdiY (tropical:) The two sides of the valley (A, L) down which the water runs, on the right and left. (L.) And variydapN lahaA janaAHaAni mino EuraAqK and biAlEuraAqi mujan~aHapN↓ (tropical:) [A mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth, having two sidegarnishes of bones with some meat remaining upon them]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also jinoHN, in two places. ― -b3- Also The side, syn. jaAnibN. (K.) So in the saying in the Kur [xvii. 25], waA@xofiDo lahumaA janaAHa Al*~ul~i, meaning waA^alino lahumaA jaAnibaka Al*~aliyla (tropical:) [And make soft to them [thy two parents) thy submissive side; i. e. treat them with gentleness and submissiveness: or the former words may be literally rendered lower to them the wing of submissiveness; meaning be submissive to them]. (Jel, TA.) ― -b4- And A part, or portion, of a thing; as also junaAHN↓. (K.)

junaAHN jnAH
A sin, a crime, or an act of disobedience: (AHeyth, S, A, IAth, L, Msb, K:) or an inclining thereto: (IAth, * L, TA:) and anxiety, and annoyance or molestation or hurt, which one is made to bear. (L, TA.) laA junaAHa Ealayokumo, in the Kur ii. 235, means, accord. to AHeyth, There shall be no sin, or crime, chargeable upon you: or, accord. to others, there shall be no straitening of you. (L.) ＝ -A2- See also janaAHN, last signification.

jaAniHN jAnH
Inclining, leaning, or propending: pl. A^ajonaAHN, like as A^a$ohaAdN is pl. of $aAhidN. (L, TA.)

jaAniHapN jAnH jAnHh jAnHp
sing. of jawaAniHu; (S, K;) which latter signifies The ribs of the breast: (A:) or the ribs that are beneath [those called] the taraAy^ib, of the part next the breast; (S, K;) like the DuluwE of the part next the back: (S:) or the anterior parts of those ribs; so called because they incline over the heart: or the short ribs that are in the anterior part of the breast: or, of a camel and a horse and the like, the ribs against which lies the shoulder-blade: and of a man, the ribs of the back which are called daA^oY, six in number, three on the right and three on the left. (L.)

majonaHapN mjnH mjnHh mjnHp
A piece of leather upon the fore part of the camel's saddle, upon which the rider leans with his hands, thus resting himself. (TA. [See 8.])

mujan~aHN mjnH
[Furnished with wings, or (assumed tropical:) the like]. ― -b2- [Hence,] variydapN mujan~aHapN biAlEuraAqi: see janaAHN. ― -b3- naAqapN mujan~aHapu Aljabiyni (assumed tropical:) A she-camel wide in the jbyn [app. here meaning the forehead]. (TA.)

2 jn~d junuwdFA jnd jnwdA
(S, A) He collected, or assembled, jnwd [i. e. armies, military forces, &c.]. (A.)

5 tjn~d jnd tjnd
He took or prepared, for himself, a junod [i. e. an army, a military force, &c.]. (A, TA.)

junodN jnd
[a coll. gen. n.] An army; a military force; a legion; a body of troops or soldiers; (L, K;) a collected body of men prepared for war: (Mgh:) auxiliaries: (S, L, Msb, K:) n. un. junodiY~N↓ [signifying a trooper; a soldier; an auxiliary]; like as ruwmiY~N is n. un. of ruwmN: (Msb:) pl. of the former, junuwdN (S, A, Mgh, Msb) and [pl. of pauc.] A^ajonaAdN. (Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a trad., AlA^arowaAHu junuwdN mujan~adapN↓ (S, A, L) Souls are troops collected together: meaning that they are created of two parties, each party agreeing together, and disagreeing with the other party, like two armies opposed, each to the other. (L.) ― -b2- Also Any kind, or species, of creatures, or created things, regarded as alone, by itself, or apart from others. (K, * TA.) It is said in a prov., A_in~a lil~hi junuwdFA minohaA AlEasalu Verily to God belong kinds, or species, of created things [by means of which He effects his purposes as by armies or auxiliaries], of which is honey: (Z, K:) first said by Mo'áwiyeh, when he heard that El-Ashtar had been given to drink some honey containing poison, in consequence of which he died: and used on the occasion of rejoicing at a misfortune that has befallen an enemy: it occurs in the history of El-Mes'oodee thus; A_in~a lil~hi junodFA fiY AlEasali. (MF.) ― -b3- Also, [as a term used in Syria, and afterwards by the Arabs from Syria in Spain,] A city [with its territory; i. e. a
province, or district]: (K:) or particularly a city of Syria [with its territory]: (AO, TA:) pl. A^ajonaAdN. (TA.) Syria consists of five AjnAd; namely, Dimashk [or Damascus], Hims [or Emessa], Kinnesreen, El-Urdunn [or the Jordan], and Filasteen or Falasteen [or Palestine]: (S, M, A:) they were thus called because the military forces were thence collected. (A.) [See mixolaAfN.]

junodiY~N jnd jndY jndy
: see junodN. ― -b2- Also Of, or relating to, a junod of Syria. (A.)

junodN mujan~adN jnd mjnd
An army, or a military force, collected. (TA.) See also junodN.

junodabN jndb
and junodubN and janodabN: see art. jdb.

janodara jndr
: see Q. Q. 1 in art. jdr.

Q. 1 janodala
[janodalahu He, or it, made him to cleave to the stones. Hence,] taribato yadaAhu wajunodilato [May his arms, or his hands, cleave to the dust, or earth, and the stones, by reason of poverty]. (M in art. trb.)

janodalN jndl
(S, K) and janodilN (K) Stones; (S in art. jdl;) used in the sense of [the pl.] janaAdilu: (Sb, TA:) n. un. janodalapN: (TA:) or what a man can lift, of stones: (K:) or, as some say, any stone: (TA:) or a mass of stone like a man's head. (T, TA.) [Hence, turobFA lahu wajanodalFA: see turaAbN.]

janadilN jndl
, (S in art. jdl,) or junadilN, (Kr, K,) A place in which are stones (Kr, S, K) collected together: (Kr, K:) but ISd doubts its correctness. (TA.) And A^aroDN junadilapN, (K,) and sometimes with fet-h, (Sgh, K,) i. e., to the j, [janadilapN,] (TK,) A land abounding with stones. (Sgh, K.)

junaAdilN jnAdl jndl
Strong and great. (K.)

1 janazahu jnz jnzh jnzp
, aor.
janiza
, (A, Msb, K,) and
januza
, (A,) inf. n. janozN, (TA,) He veiled, concealed, hid, or covered, it. (A, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- He collected it; or gathered it together or up; (K;) as also jn~zihu↓, inf. n. tajoniyzN. (Sgh, TA.) You say also, junaza Alr~ajulu, part. n. majonuwzN↓, The man was gathered up [app. as a corpse is gathered up in the grave-clothes]: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) he died. (Har p. 122.)

2 jn~zhu jnz jnzh jnzp
, inf. n. tajoniyzN: see 1. ― -b2- It is used by El-Hasan El-Basree as signifying He put it (namely a corpse) upon the bier. (K, * TA.)

jinaAzapN jnAz jnAzh jnAzp
and janaAzapN signify the same, (Mgh, Msb, K,) namely, A dead person; a corpse: (K:) but the former is the more chaste: (Msb:) or the former signifies the dead person; and the latter, the bier: (As, IAar, Msb, K:) or the former, the bier; and the latter, the dead person: (Mgh, Msb, K:) so accord. to Th, as related by Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid: (Msb:) or the former is said by the vulgar to mean the bier: (As, TA:) or the former signifies the bier with the dead person: (K:) or the dead person upon the bier: (S:) and the bier is not so called unless the dead person is upon it: (AAF:) when the dead person is not upon it, it is called sariyrN and naEo$N: (AAF, S:) but the vulgar say janaAzapN, with fet-h; (S;) which is not allowable: (Lth, As, Mgh, TA:) or janaAzapN [so in the TA] signifies the man: or the bier with the man: (En-Nadr, TA:) jnAzp is derived from janazahu, in the first of the senses assigned to it above: (A, Msb, TA:) so some assert: (IDrd, TA:) but ISd says, I know not whether this be correct: (TA:) or a janaAzap is so called because the clothes are gathered together when the man is upon the bier: ('Abd-Allah Ibn-El-Hasan, TA:) some say that it is Nabathean: (TA:) the pl. is janaAy^izu. (S.) The Arabs say, tarakotuhu jinaAzapF I left him a corpse, or dead. (As, TA.) And Duriba Alr~ajulu Hat~aY turika janaAzapF [so in the TA, The man was beaten until he was left a corpse]. (ISh, TA.) And rumiYa fiY jinaAzatihi, meaning, He died: (Lth, Mgh:) or he has been carried, or lifted, and put [into his bier]: this they say when they give information of the death of a man: (TA:) and they say also, TuEina fiY jinaAzatihi, meaning the same. (Lth, Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- Also jinaAzapN [or janaAzapN] (tropical:) A wine-skin [when emptied; as though it were a body without a soul]. (K.) A certain impudent man of the Arabs, 'Amr Ibn- Ki'ás, says,
wakunotu A_i*aA A^araY ziq~FA SariyEFA
yunaAHu EalaY janaAzatihi bakayotu
[And I used, when I saw a wine-skin laid prostrate, its corpse being wailed over, to weep, or accord. to Th, as is said in the TA in art. bkY, to sing]. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Anything oppressive and grievous, EalaY qawomK to a people. (Lth, K.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A sick person. (Sgh, K.)

janaAy^iziY~N *
, [from janaAy^izu, pl. of janaAzapN,] One who recites [or chants the profession of the faith &c.] before the dead [in a funeral-procession]. (TA.)

majonuwzN mjnwz
: see 1.

2 jn~shu bihi jnsh bh jnsh bp
, (TK,) inf. n. tajoniysN, from Aljinosu, (S, K,) [He made it homogeneous, or congenial, with it; or similar, or conformable, to it: expl. in the TK, not well, by $Aklh; but the inf. n., with tolerable correctness, by AykY $yy^Y brY brynh m$Akl qlmq. The usage of the term tajoniysN in rhetoric, to signify the use of two or more words completely or partly conformable, is post-classical, like jinaAsN, an inf. n. of jaAnasa.]

3 jAnshu jAns jAnsh jAnsp
, [inf. n. mujaAnasapN and jinaAsN,] It was, or became, homogeneous, or congenial, with it; or similar, or conformable, to it; syn. $aAkalahu: (Mgh, Msb:) AlmujaAnasapu is from Aljinosu. (S, TA.) You say, h`*aA yujaAnisu h`*aA This is homogeneous with this; syn. yu$aAkiluhu: (Mgh, Msb:) so says Kh. (Msb.) And kayofa yuw^aAnisuka mano laA yujaAnisuka [How will he be sociable with thee who will not be congenial with thee?]. (A.) And of a man who has not discrimination nor intelligence, one says, fulaAnN yujaAnisu AlbahaAy^ima walaA yujaAnisu Aln~aAsa [Such a one resembles the beasts, and does not resemble men]: (Mgh, Msb, * TA:) so says Kh. (Mgh.) But As says that this usage, (Mgh, Msb,) in the first and last of the above-mentioned phrases, (Msb,) is post-classical. (Mgh, Msb.) The usage of the term jinaAsN by rhetoricians [to signify the complete or partial conformity of two or more words] is post-classical [like tajoniysN]. (TA.)

6 tjAns Al$~ayoA=ni *
[The two things were, or became homogeneous, congenial, similar, or conformable,] is a phrase of the scholastic theologians, not [classical] Arabic. (TA.)

jinosN jns
[A genus, kind, or generical class, comprising under it several species, or sorts; or comprised under a superior genus, in relation to which it is a species, or sort;] a Darpb of a thing; (S;) or of anything; (Mgh, Msb;) any Darob of a thing; (A, K;) [as] of men, and of birds, and of the definitions of grammar and of the art of versification, and of things collectively; so accord. to the lexicologists; (ISd, TA;) a term of more common import than nawoE [which is a species, or sort]: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) thus animal is a jns and man is a nwE, (Mgh, Msb,) because the latter is of more particular import than the former, though it is a jns in relation to what is under it; but the scholastic theologians reverse the case, (Mgh,) for with them jns is of more particular import than nwE: (Kull p. 139:) thus also camels are a jns of beasts: (A, K:) pl. A^ajonaAsN [properly a pl. of pauc. but used also as one of mult.] (Mgh, Msb, K) and junuwsN. (IDrd, K.) You say, Aln~aAsu A^ajonaAsN waA^akovaruhumo A^anojaAsN [Men are of several kinds, and most of them are impure]. (A, TA.) And fulaAnN mino jinosika, meaning A^aSolika [i. e. Such a one is of thy stock]. (S in art. jnv.) ― -b2- [Hence, Aisomu jinosK A generic noun: and Aisomu jinosK jamoEiY~N a collective generic noun.] ― -b3- A^awoSaY lijinosihi signifies He left by will, of his property, to the children of his father, [or his kindred by the father's side,] exclusively of all relations of the mother: and so, liA^aholi bayotihi. (Mgh.) ― -b4- The assertion, in the K, that J's saying, on the authority of IDrd, that As used to say Aljinosu as meaning AlmujaAnasapu is a vulgarism, is erroneous, is a matter for consideration; for As said not this, but [what has been cited above, voce jaAnasahu, or] what will be found below, voce mujaAnisN. (TA.)

[
jinosiY~N jns jnsY jnsy jnsyy
Generic; generical.]

[
jinosiy~apN jns jnsy jnsyh jnsyp
Generical quality.]

[
mujaAnisN mjAns
Homogeneous; congenial; similar;
conformable; syn. mu$aAkilN. (K.) But IDrd asserts that As used to reject the saying of the vulgar, h`*aA mujaAnisu lih`*aA [This is homogeneous with this, &c.], and to say, It is post-classical. (S.) [See also 3.]

1 janafN jnf
(T, S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and junuwfN, (K,) the former being inf. n. of janifa and the latter of janafa, (TA,) The act of inclining, or declining (T, S, Mgh, K, TA) in speech and in all affairs: (TA:) and declining, or deviating, from the right course; acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically; (T, Msb, * K, TA;) like HayofN, which some erroneously assert to be the act of a judge only. (T, TA.) You say, janifa, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
janafa
, inf. n. janafN; (S, Msb;) [and app. janafa, aor.
janifa
, inf. n. junuwfN;] and Ajnf↓; (T, Msb, TA;) He inclined or declined [in speech and in any affair]: (T, S, TA:) and he declined, or deviated, from the right course; acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically; (T, Mgh, Msb, TA;) Ealayohi against him. (Mgh.) Hence, in the Kur [ii. 178], famano xaAfa mino muwSK janafFA (S, TA,) i. e. [And he who feareth, (or, as is said in the K in art. xwf, knoweth,) from, or on the part of, the testator,] an inclining [to a wrong course], or a declining [from the right course]: (TA:) or a manifest inclining or declining. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say, janifa fiY waSiy~atihi, aor.
janafa
; [He inclined, &c., in his testament;] and so Ajnf↓. (K.) And Ajnf↓ signifies He deviated from that which was right. (K.) And fiY Hukomihi Ajnf↓ [He declined from the right course, or acted wrongfully or unjustly, in his judgment]. (TA.) Or Ajnf↓ relates peculiarly to the case of a testament: and janifa signifies absolutely He declined, or deviated, from that which was right. (K.) And you say, janifa Eano Tariyqihi, aor.
janafa
; and janafa, aor.
janifa
; inf. n. janafN, (K, TA,) which is of the former verb, (TA,) and junuwfN, (K, TA,) which is of the latter verb; He turned away from his course, or way; deviated therefrom. (TA.) ― -b2- Or [app. a mistake for “and ”] janafN signifies Depression (duxuwlN and AinohiDaAmN) in one of the two sides of the breast, or chest, (Alz~awori,) with evenness of the other side: (K:) the verb is janifa: and the part. n. is janifN↓ and A^ajonafu↓, fem. [of the latter] janofaA='u. (TA.)

3 jnaAfN jnAf
[an inf. n. of which the verb (jAnf) is not mentioned]. You say, laj~a fiY jinaAfK qabiyHK He persisted in removing himself to a distance, or estranging himself, from his family; (Aboo-Sa'eed, K;) like jinaAbK qabiyHK. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.)

4 Ajnf Ajnf
He committed an act of inclining [to a wrong course], or declining [from the right course, or acting wrongfully or unjustly or injuriously or tyrannically]; like as you say, A^alaAma, meaning “he did a thing for which he should be blamed.” (S.) See also 1, in five places. ＝ -A2- Ajnfhu He found him to be one who deviated from the right way in his judgment; who acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, therein. (K.) tjAnf fiY mi$oyatihi In the text, the characters between ت and ن are unclear.
He carried himself in a proud and self-conceited manner, [affecting an inclining of the body from side to side,] in his gait. (TA.) [And He inclined on one side in his gait: said of one who is lame of one leg: see maHoruwqN.] ― -b2- tjAnf Eano Tariyqihi He affected a declining, or deviating, from his course, or way; he purposely declined, or deviated, therefrom; (K, * TA;) syn. tamaAyala. (K.) And in like manner, tjAnf A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i [He affected an inclining to the thing; intentionally inclined to it]. (TA.) You say, tjAnf liA_ivomK He inclined to a sin, (S, Mgh,) [or affected an inclining to it, (see the part. n., below,)] intending, or purposing, the commission of an act of disobedience. (Mgh.)

janafa jnf
is [an epithet] like danafa, applying to a sing. and a pl., [being] also an inf. n. [of janifa, q. v.]: Abu-l-'Iyál El-Hudhalee says,
A^al~aA daraA^ota AlxaSoma Hiyna raA^ayotuhumo
janafFA EalaY~a biA^alosunK waEuyuwni
[Wherefore didst not thou repel the adversaries, when thou sawest them inclining, or acting wrongfully, against me with tongues and eyes?]: or, accord. to one reading, junufFA [which is a pl. of jaAnifN↓]: (Skr p. 128:) [or, as some say,] janafFA is a pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] of jaAnifN↓, like as rawaHa is of raAy^iHN: or it may be for *awiy janafK. (TA.)

janifN jnf
: see A^ajonafu, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 1, last sentence.

junaAfiY~N jnAfY jnAfy
One who carries himself in a proud and self-conceited manner, (muxotaAl, [for which Golius, here copied by Freytag, appears to have read muHotaAl, with the unpointed H,]) with an inclining [of the body from side to side]: (Sh, K:) or one who affects an inclining [of the body from side to side] (yatajaAnafu) in his gait, and carries himself in a proud and self-conceited manner therein. (TA.)

jaAnifN jAnf
: see A^ajonafu; and see also janafN, in two places.

A^ajonafu *
[fem. janofaA='u] Inclining [to a wrong course], or declining [from the right course], or acting wrongfully or unjustly, [absolutely, as also janifN↓ and jaAnifN↓ and mijonafN↓, or peculiarly] in his testament. (K.) You say, SaAdafahu fiY Hukomihi janifFA↓ [He found him to be one who deviated from the right way in his judgment; who acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, therein]. (K.) And xaSomN mijonafN↓ An adversary who inclines [to a wrong course], or declines [from the right course]; (K;) who acts wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically. (TA.) ― -b2- Inclining; [or pendulous;] applied to a penis. (TA.) ― -b3- Having a bending back; (S, K;) applied to a man. (S.) ― -b4- See also 1, last sentence. ― -b5- Big, or large; applied to a bowl (qadaH). (TA.)

mijonafN mjnf
: see A^ajonafu, in two places.

gayora mutajaAnifK liA_ivomK gyr mtjAnf lAvm
, in the Kur [v. 5], means Not affecting an inclining to sin; intending, or purposing, it. (Msb, TA.)

1 janaquwA jnq jnqwA
, aor.
janiqa
, (IAar, K,) inf. n. janoqN; (IAar, TA;) and jn~qwA↓, inf. n. tajoniyqN; (AZ, K;) They cast stones of [or with] the manojaniyq: (K, * TA:) and majonaquwA↓, (K,) or majonaquwA manojaniyqFA [app. meaning they constructed a mnjnyq], (Lth, TA,) is said by such as hold the m to be radical; (K;) or it may be that the m is augmentative, and that the verb is [denominative,] similar to tamasokana from misokiynN. (TA.) ― -b2- janaquwnaA biAlmanojaniyqi They cast at us with the mnjnyq: mentioned by El-Fárisee on the authority of AZ. (M.) An Arab of the desert, in describing the wars of his people, said, taArapF nujonaqo waA^uxoraY nuro$aqo [One time we are cast at with the mnjnyq, and another we are shot at with arrows]: (S, * M:) also mentioned by El-Fárisee. (M.)

2 jn~qwA AlmajaAniyqa jnqwA AlmjAnyq
and majonaquwhaA↓ [app. They constructed the engines of the kind called mnjnyq]. (JK.) See also 1.

Q. Q. 1 majonaquwA mjnqwA
: see 1 and 2.

junuqN jnq
The stones of the mnjnyq. (M, TA.) [But] IAar says that jnq [app. junuqN] means The people who manage the mnjnyq. (TA.)

mujayniyqN mjynyq
dim. of manojaniyqN, q. v. (Sb, S.)

manojanuwqN mnjnwq
: see what next follows.

manojaniyqN mnjnyq
(S, M, Msb, K) and minojaniyqN (Msb, K) and manojanuwqN↓ (Lth, IAar, Msb, K) [A kind of balista;] an instrument [or engine of war] with which stones are cast (S, M, K, TA) at the enemy; made by binding [in some manner] very tall wooden poles, whereon is placed what is to be cast, which is then struck with a long pole, and so cast to a very distant place: [this imperfect description (the only one that I have found of this engine) seems to show that it was of a very simple and rude construction:] it is an ancient instrument, anterior to the invention [or use] of gunpowder and cannons by the Christians; and was used by Mohammad in the siege of Et-Táïf; but the first [of the Arabs] who used it in the time of paganism is said to have been Jedheemeh El-Abrash, of the Mulook et-Tawáïf: (TA:) pl. manojaniyqaAtN (S, Msb, K) and manojanuwqaAtN (Lth, TA) and majaAniyqu (Sb, S, Msb, K) and majaAniqu: (K:) dim. mujayoniyqN↓: (Sb, S:) it is fem., (Lth, S, Msb, K, *) preferably, (Lth, TA,) and in most instances; (Msb;) and hence it is also called AlA^unovaY; (M in art. Anv;) but sometimes it is masc.: (Msb, K:) and is arabicized, (S, Msb, K,) from the Persian (S, K) mano JiY niyko, i. e. “ How excellent am I! ” (S,) or mano Jiho niyko, i. e. “ I, how excellent am I! ” (K;) [Golius asserts it to be from the Greek μάγγανον but this is the original of manojanuwnN, which has a different meaning: its derivation, however, seems to have been unknown to the Arabs in general; for] some say that manojaniyqN is of
the measure mafoEaliylN, [so in copies of the S, but correctly manofaEiylN, as in the Msb and TA,] because of the phrase nujonaqu mar~apF [see 1]: (S, Msb: *) or, (Msb,) accord. to Sb, (S,) it is of the measure fanoEaliylN; (S, Msb;) because majaAniyqu is its pl. and the dim. is mujayniyqN; and because, if the m were augmentative as well as the n, there would be two augmentative letters at the beginning of the noun, and this may not be in substs. nor in epithets that are not conformable to augmented verbs; and if the n were made an essential part of the word, the noun would be a quadriliteral-radical, and augmentative letters are not prefixed to words of this class except nouns conformable to their verbs, like mudaHorajN: (S, TA:) but MF says that these disquisitions are unprofitable; for in his opinion, all the letters of the word are radical, since it is a foreign word. (TA.) manojaniyiqY~N [app. A maker of the kind of engine called mnjnyq; being mentioned as a surname:] a rel. n. from mnjnyq. (K.)

janokN jn jnk
[and junokN] A certain [musical] instrument, which is beaten like the Euwd [or lute; namely, the Persian harp; two specimens of which are figured in Note 26 to Chap. iii. of my translation of the “Thousand and One Nights”]; mentioned by El-Khafájee in the Shifá el-Ghaleel; and often spoken of: it is an arabicized word; (MF, TA;) from the Persian JanoG: and applied [also] to the df~, [duf~ or daf~, i. e., tambourine,] with which one plays. (TA.)

janokiY~N jnk jnkY jnky
[and junokiY~N] A player on the jnk above mentioned. (TA.)

janFA jn jnA
i. q. janaA^N [inf. n. of janiy^a, q. v.]. (Sgh, K.)

A^ajonaA *
, applied to a man, i. q. A^ajonaA^u, q. v. (Sgh, K.) And [its fem.] janowaA='u, i. q. janoA='u, (Sgh, K,) applied to a ewe, or a she-goat, meaning Having her horns bending backwards. (TA.)

1 janaY Alv~amarapa jny Alvmrh jny Alvmrp
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
janiYa
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. janFY, (S, TA,) or janoYN, (so accord. to one copy of the S, and written in the accus. case jnyA in the Ham p. 355,) and jinaAyapN, (Ham ib., but there without any vowel-signs,) He gathered, plucked, or took from the tree, the fruit; (Mgh, TA;) i. q. AjtnAhA↓ (S, Msb, K) and tjn~AhA↓: (K:) and in like manner one says of a thing similar to fruit. (TA.) One says also, janaAhaA lahu and janaAhu A_iy~aAhaA [He gathered it, plucked it, or took it from the tree, for him]. (A'Obeyd, K.) And janayotuka A^akomuw^FA [I gathered for thee truffles]. (TA.) And janaY *ahabFA He collected gold from its mine. (TA.) ― -b2- Aboo-Dhu-eyb uses this verb metaphorically, in the phrase janaY AlEulaY, meaning (tropical:) [He acquired] eminence, or nobility. (TA.) ― -b3- You also say, janaY Ealayohi, (S,) or EalaY qawomihi, (Msb,) inf. n. jinaAyapN, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) He committed, [against him, or] against his people, or party, a crime, or an offence for which he should be punished; (Msb;) as also jAnAhu↓ [or jAnY qawomihi]: (TK in art. jr:) [and (tropical:) he brought an injury upon him, or them:] and janaY Al*~anobi Ealayohi, aor.
janiYa
, inf. n. jinaAyapN, (K,) with kesr, (TA,) (tropical:) He committed the crime, offence, or injurious action, against him; syn. jar~ahu A_ilayohi: (K: [see art. jr:]) thus used, also, the verb is metaphorical, from janaY Alv~amarapa: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and so in the phrase, janaY $ar~FA, meaning (tropical:) He brought to pass an evil thing or action. (Mgh.) [See also jinaAyapN, below.] It is said in a trad., laA yajoniY jaAnK A_il~aA EalaY nafosihi (assumed tropical:) [An injurer shall not bring injury save on himself]; meaning that one shall not be prosecuted for an injurious action committed by another, of his relations or of others. (TA.) And a poet says,
jaAniyka mano yajoniY Ealayoka waqado
tuEodiy AlS~ijaAHa fatajorabu Aljurobu
[which may be rendered, (assumed tropical:) Thine injurer whom thou shouldst punish is he who brings an injury upon thee: but sometimes the mangy camels infect the sound ones so that these become mangy; and thus a criminal sometimes brings punishment upon his relations: for] A'Obeyd says that jAnyk mn yjnY Elyk is a prov. applied to the case of a man who is punished for an injurious action; because brothers [sometimes] bring injury upon a man [by occasioning his being punished for an injurious action which they have themselves committed], as the latter hemistich of the verse cited above indicates: but AHeyth says that this prov. means AljaAniY laka Alxayora mano yajoniY Ealayoka Al$~ar~a [The person bringing thee good is he who brings, or will bring, upon thee evil: perhaps intended as a caution; for the Arabs often suspect that a benefactor has some evil intention]: and he cites the following hemistich:
tuEodiy AlS~iHaAHa mabaAriku Aljurobi
[meaning Sometimes the places where the mangy camels lie down, and which afford benefit to other camels, infect the sound ones]. (TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 298.]) You say also, janayota h`*aA EalaY nafosika [Thou hast brought this as an injury upon thyself]. (K in art. jl.)

3 jAnY Ealayohi jAny Elyh jAny Elyp
, inf. n. mujaAnaApN, He accused him of a jinaAyap [or crime, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.

4 AjnY A^j A^jnY A^jny AjnY Ajny jnY jnyn |jn |jny |jnyy
said of a tree, (S, K,) or of a palmtree, (Msb,) It had ripe fruit: (S:) or it attained to the time for the gathering of its fruit: (Msb:) or it attained to maturity: (K:) or, said of a tree, it had fruit to be gathered and eaten: and, said of fruit, it became ripe: (TA:) and, said of grass, or herbage, it became abundant. (KL.) ― -b2- And Ajnti AlA^aroDu The land had much janFY, (S, Msb, K,) i. e. herbage, and truffles, and the like. (S.)

5 tajan~aYa
see 1. ― -b2- tjn~Y Ealayohi, (S, * K,) or tjn~Y Elyh *anobFA, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He accused him of a crime, an offence, or an injurious action, that he had not committed; (S, K;) i. e. he forged against him the charge of his having committed a crime, &c., he being guiltless [thereof]: (TA:) Aln~ajan~iY being like Alt~ajar~umu. (S.) You say also, yatajan~aY EalayonaA maA lamo najonihi [He accuses us of committing what we did not commit]. (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA in art. jrm.)

8 A_ijotanaYa
see 1. ― -b2- AijotanayonaA maA='i maTarK We came to rainwater, and drank it: (K:) a phrase mentioned with approval by IAar, but not explained by him: thought by ISd to have this meaning. (TA.)

janFY jn jnY jny
[in the CK janiY~N] Whatever is gathered, or plucked; as also janaApN↓: (K:) or whatever is gathered, or plucked, from trees, (S,) &c.; (so in a copy of the S;) as also janaApN↓: (S:) so that these two words are of the same class as Hiq~N and Hiq~apN: or the latter of them is a n. un.: (TA:) or the former signfies what is gathered from trees while fresh; (Msb;) as also janiY~N↓: (Msb:) or this last is an epithet applied to fruit, signifying just gathered or plucked; (S, K;) or gathered, or plucked, while fresh: (TA:) and majonFY↓, also, pl. majaAnK, signifies fruit gathered or plucked: (Har p. 369:) janFY also signifies fruit [ready to be gathered or plucked]; so in the Kur lv. 54: (Jel:) and is applied to fresh ripe dates: (Fr, K:) and grapes: (TA:) and truffles, and the like: (S:) and even cotton: (TA:) and herbage: (S:) and gold, (K,) which is collected from its mine: (TA:) and cowries, (K,) as though gathered from the sea: (TA:) and honey, (K,) when it is gathered: (TA:) pl. A^ajonaA='N (K) and A^ajonK, originally A^ajonuYN. (TA.) Hence the saying,
h`*aA janaAY wa xiyaAruhu fiyhi
A_i*okul~u jaAnK yaduhu A_ilaY fiyhi
[This is what I have gathered, and the best of it is in it; when every gatherer but myself has his hand to his mouth]: or, accord. to one reading, wa hijaAnuhu fiyhi (which has the same meaning, TA in art. hjn): a prov., ascribed by Ibn-El-Kelbee to 'Amr Ibn-' Adee El-Lakhmee, the son of the daughter of Jedheemeh: he says that Jedheemeh had ordered the people to gather for him truffles, and some of them ate the best that they found; but ' Amr brought to him the best that he found, and addressed to him these words: and 'Alee is related to have repeated them on an occasion of his entering the government-treasury; meaning that he had not defiled himself with anything of the tribute belonging to the Muslims, but had put it in its places. (TA.)

janaApN jAny jn jnAh jnAp jnY
: see janFY, in two places.

janiY~N jn jnY jny
: see janFY. Also Dates cut from the tree. (TA.)

jinaAyapN jnAyh jnAyp
, primarily, The act of gathering, plucking, or taking from a tree, fruit: [see 1:] ― -b2- then, (assumed tropical:) The bringing to pass an evil thing, or action: (Mgh, Kull p. 147:) ― -b3- then, (assumed tropical:) Evil, [itself]: ― -b4- then, (assumed tropical:) The doing a forbidden action: (Kull ib.:) specially used in this last sense; though it has a general application: (Mgh:) ― -b5- [as a simple subst., it generally signifies] A crime, an offence, or an injurious action, for which one should be punished:
(Msb:) or an action that a man commits requiring punishment or retaliation to be inflicted upon him in the present world and in the world to come: (TA:) or any forbidden injurious action: (Kull p. 134:) and in the language of the lawyers, especially a wounding: and an amputation, or a maiming: (Msb:) and janiy~apN↓ signifies the same as jinaAyapN: (Ham p. 241:) the pl. of jnAyp is jinaAyaAtN and janaAyaA; but the latter of these pls. is of rare occurrence. (Msb.)

janiy~apN jny jnyh jnyp
: see what next precedes. ＝ -A2- Also A [garment such as is called] ridaA=' (K, TA,) of a round form, (TA,) made of [the kind of cloth termed] xaz~. (K, TA.)

jaAnK jAn jAny
A gatherer of fruit [&c.]: ― -b2- and also (assumed tropical:) A committer of a jinaAyap [or crime, &c.]: (K, * TA:) pl. junaApN (S, K) and jun~aA='N (Sb, K) and [of pauc.] A^ajonaA='N, which last is extr., (S, K,) or doubtful. (S.) Hence the prov., A^ajonaAw^uhaA A^abonaAw^uhaA, explained in art. bnY. (S, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] AljaAniY (assumed tropical:) The wolf. (IAar, TA voce jaAbK, q. v.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. laq~aAHN; (IAar, Az, TA;) i. e. A fecundater of palm-trees. (Az, TA.)

AljawaAniY AljwAnY AljwAny jwAny
i. q. AljawaAnibu [pl. of AljaAnibu]; (K;) similar to Alv~aEaAliY and AlA^araAniY. (TA.)

majonFY mj mjn mjnY mjny mjnyy
: see janFY.

mujotanFY mAj mj mjtnY mjtny
A place of gathering, or plucking, fruits, &c. (TA.)

1 jahada jhd
, (S, A, L, &c.,) aor.
jahada
, (K,) inf. n. jahodN, (TA,) He strove, laboured, or toiled; exerted himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability; employed himself vigorously, strenuously, laboriously, diligently, studiously, sedulously, earnestly, or with energy; was diligent, or studious; took pains, or extraordinary pains; (S, A, L, K;) fiY ka*aA in such a thing; (S;) or fiY AlA^amori in the affair; (A;) as also Ajthd↓; (A, K;) and so jAhd↓, with respect to speech and actions: (L:) or jahada fiY AlA^amori, aor. and inf. n. as above, he did his utmost, or used his utmost power or efforts or endeavours or ability, in prosecuting the affair: (Msb:) and Ajthd↓ and tjAhd↓ he exerted unsparingly his power, or ability: (S, A, K:) or fiY AlA^amori Ajthd↓ he exerted unsparingly his power, or ability, in the prosecution of the affair, so as to effect his utmost. (Msb.) You say also, Aijohado jahadaka fiY h*aA AlA^amori (tropical:) Do thine utmost in this affair: (Fr, S, K: *) but not juhodaka. (Fr, S.) And raA^oyahu Ajthd↓ (tropical:) He took pains, or put himself to trouble or fatigue, to form a right judgment or opinion. (MA.) And raA^oyiY wanafosiY Hat~aY Aijotahadotu↓ balagotu majohuwdiY (assumed tropical:) I exerted my judgment and my mind so that I attained the utmost of my power, or ability. (T, L.) ― -b2- jahadabihi He tried, proved, or examined, him, (L, K,) Eani Alxayori wa gayorihi [respecting good qualities, &c.]. (L.) ＝ -A2- jahadahu, (Mgh, L, Msb,) aor.
jahada
, (Mgh, L,) inf. n. jahodN, (L, Msb,) It, (an affair, and a disease,) and he, (a man,) affected him severely; harassed, embarrassed, distressed, afflicted, troubled, inconvenienced, fatigued, or wearied, him: (Msb:) it (disease, L and K, and fatigue, and love, L) rendered him lean; emaciated him: (L, K:) he burdened him beyond his power; imposed upon him that which was beyond his power; as also Ajhdhu↓: (Mgh:) and, [as also Ajhdhu↓,] he importuned him, harassed him, or plied him hard, in asking, begging, or petitioning. (A.) [Hence,] juhida, said of a man, He was severely affected, harassed, embarrassed, distressed, afflicted, troubled, inconvenienced, fatigued, or wearied: (S, L:) or was grieved, or made sorry or unhappy. (L.) And A^aSaAbahumo quHuwTN mina AlmaTari fajuhiduwA jahodFA $adiydFA Drought befell them, and they consequently became severely distressed. (S.) And juhiduwA They were, or became, afflicted with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth. (L.) And rajulN yajohadu A^ano yaHomila silaAHahu mina AlD~aEofi, for yajohadu nafosahu, A man who imposes upon himself a difficulty, or trouble, or fatigue, or a difficult or severe task, or who strains, or strains himself, in the carrying of his weapons, or arms, by reason of weakness. (Mgh.) And jahada daAb~atahu and AjhdhA↓ He jaded, harassed, distressed, fatigued, or wearied, his beast; i. q. balaga jahodahaA↓: (K:) or he tasked, or plied, his beast beyond his power in journeying, or marching, or in respect of pace. (S, Msb.) And A^ajohadotuhu EalaY A^ano yafoEala ka*aA wa ka*aA [I importuned him, or harassed him, to do such and such things]. (L.) ― -b2- Also, (S, Msb,) aor. as above, (A,) and so the inf. n., (Msb,) (tropical:) He deprived it (namely, milk,) of its butter, (S, A, K,) entirely: (S, K:) or churned it so as to extract its butter and render it sweet and pleasant: or mixed it with water: (Msb:) or diluted it so that it consisted for the most part of water: and in like manner it is used in relation to broth. (A.) ― -b3- Hence, (Msb,) jahadahaA (assumed tropical:) He lay with her; or compressed her: (L, Msb, from a trad.:) or i. q. dafaEahaA, and HafazahaA [which has a similar meaning]. (L.) ― -b4- jahada AlT~aEaAmi (assumed tropical:) He desired the food eagerly; longed for it; (S, K;) as also Ajhdhu↓. (K.) And juhida AlT~aEaAmu and A^ujohida↓ (assumed tropical:) The food was eagerly desired, or longed for. (S.) ― -b5- Also (tropical:) He ate much of the food: (S, K:) he left nothing of it. (A.) You say also, h`*aA kalaA^N yajohaduhu AlmaAlu (assumed tropical:) This is herbage, or pasture, of which the cattle eat perseveringly. (AA, TA.) ＝ -A3- jahida It (a state of life) was, or became, hard, difficult, strait, or distressful. (S, K.)

3 jihaAdN jhAd
, inf. n. of jAhd, properly signifies The using, or exerting, one's utmost power, efforts, endeavours, or ability, in contending with an object of disapprobation; and this is of three kinds, namely, a visible enemy, the devil, and one's self; all of which are included in the term as used in the Kur xxii. 77. (Er-Rághib, TA.) See also 1, first sentence. You say, jAhd AlEaduw~a, (JK, A, Mgh,) inf. n. as above (JK, Mgh, K) and mujaAhadapN, (JK, K,) He fought with the enemy: (K:) or he encountered the enemy, imposing upon himself difficulty or distress or fatigue, or exerting his power or efforts or endeavours or ability, [or the utmost thereof,] to repel him, his enemy doing the like: and hence jAhd came to be used by the Muslims to signify generally he fought, warred, or waged war, against unbelievers and the like. (Mgh.) You say also, jAhd fiY sabiyli A@ll~`hi, inf. n. jihaAdN (S, Msb) and mujaAhadapN, (S,) [He fought, &c., in the way of God; i. e., in the cause of religion.]

4 Ajhd A^jhd Ajhd jhd
, as trans.: see 1, in six places. ― -b2- Also He made, or incited, another, to strive or labour or toil, to exert himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability, &c.; trans. of 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above. (JK.) ― -b3- A^ujohida He was thrown into a state of difficulty, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, or fatigue. (L.) ― -b4- Ajhd maAlahu He consumed, or wasted, and dispersed, his property: (K:) or gave it away, and dispersed it, altogether, here and there. (En-Nadr, TA.) ＝ -A2- As intrans., He (an enemy) strove, laboured, or exerted himself, in enmity, (K, TA,) EalayonaA against us. (TA.) ― -b2- He acted with energy, or with the utmost energy: so in the phrases saAra faA^ajohada He marched, or journeyed, and did so with energy, or with the utmost energy; and Halafa biA@ll~`hi faA^ajohada He swore by God, and did so with energy, &c.: in which cases one should not say fajahada. (Aboo-' Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, L.) ― -b3- He took the course prescribed by prudence, precaution, and sound judgment, fiY AlA^amori in the affair; syn. AiHotaATa. (L, K.) ― -b4- He became in a state of difficulty, embarrassment, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, or fatigue. (L.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) became mixed, or confused. (K.) ＝ -A3- He entered upon land such as is termed jahaAd: he went forth into the desert; and into the plain, or open country. (JK.) ― -b2- It rose up; rose into view; appeared. (JK.) You say, Ajhd liYa Alqawomu The people, or company of men, came within my sight, or view; syn. A^a$orafuwA. (AA, K.) And Ajhd fiyhi Al$~ayobu Hoariness appeared upon him, and became much: (TA:) or (tropical:) became much, and spread: (A:) or became much, and was quick in its progress, (K, TA,) and spread. (TA.) And A^ajohadato lahu AlA^aroDu The land became open to him. (L, K. *) And in like manner, Ajhd lh AlT~ariyqu, (L,) and AlHaq~u, (L, K, *) The road, and (assumed tropical:) the truth, became open, apparent, and manifest, to him. (L, K. *) And Ajhd laka AlA^amoru (assumed tropical:) The thing became, or has become, within thy power, or reach; (Aboo-Sa'eed, K;) and offered, or presented, itself to thee. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.)

6 tajaAohada
see 1.

8 A_ijotahada
see 1, in five places. ― -b2- AijotihaAdN as a conventional term means A lawyer's exerting the faculties [of the mind] to the utmost, for the purpose of forming an opinion in a case of law [respecting a doubtful and difficult point]: (KT:) the seeking to form a right opinion: (KL:) [investigation of the law, or the working out a solution of any difficulty in the law, by means of reason and comparison: and] the referring a case proposed to the judge, [respecting a doubtful and difficult
point,] from the method of analogy, to the Kur-Án and the Sunneh. (L, TA. *)

jahodN jhd
Power; ability; as also juhodN↓; (S, A, IAth, L, Msb, K;) the latter of the dial. of El- Hijáz, and the former of other dials.; (Msb;) and majohuwdN↓: (A:) jhd in the Kur ix. 80 is read both jahod and juhd↓: (S:) and jahodN signifies also labour, toil, exertion, effort, endeavour, energy, diligence, painstaking, or extraordinary painstaking: (L: [see jahada:]) or juhodN↓ has the signification first mentioned above, (Fr, S, IAth, Msb,) and jahodN, with fet-h, is from Aijohado jahodaka fiY h`*aA AlA^amori, (Fr, S,) or from jahada fiY AlA^amori, being an inf. n. from this verb, (Msb,) and signifies, [as also majohuwdN↓,] one's utmost; the utmost of one's power or ability or efforts or endeavours or energy. (Fr, S, IAth, Msb, K.) You say, ba*ala Aljahoda, (Msb in art. blg, &c.,) and Almajohuwda↓, (S, A,) or jahodahu, (Mgh,) [and majohuwdahu↓,] He exerted unsparingly his power or ability: (Mgh:) [or his utmost power or ability or efforts or endeavours or energy; as shown above.] And balaga jahodahu, (A, L,) and majohuwdahu↓, (A,) He accomplished the utmost of his power or ability; did his utmost. (A, L. [Like jahada jahodahu. See also balaga jahoda daAb~atihi, below.]) And juhayodaY↓ is syn. with jahodN; (K;) as in the saying, laA^abolugan~a juhayodaAYa fiY AlA^amori (JK, TK,) i. e. I will assuredly accomplish the utmost of my power, or ability, in the affair. (TK. [In a copy of the A, juhayodaAka; and so in the TA, I believe from that same copy.]) [So, too, is juhaAdaY↓; as in the saying,] juhaAdaAka A^ano tafoEala The utmost of thy power, or ability, and the utmost of thy case, is, or will be, thy doing [such a thing]; syn. quSaAraAka [q. v.], (JK, K,) and gaAyapu A^amorika. (TA.) Al~a*iyna A^aqosamuwA biA@ll~`hi jahoda A^ayomaAnihimo, in the Kur [v. 58, &c.], means Who swore by God with the most energetic of their oaths: (K, * Jel:) or the strongest, or most forcible, of their oaths; jhd being originally an inf. n., and in the accus. as a denotative of state with yajohaduwna understood before it, or as an inf. n. (Bd.) ― -b2- Also Difficulty, or grievousness; embarrassment, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, fatigue, or weariness; (S, A, IAth, Mgh, Msb, K;) so accord. to some who say that juhodN↓, with damm, has the first of the significations assigned to it above; (Msb;) as also majohuwdN↓: (Mgh:) a disease, or difficulty, that distresses or afflicts, a man; as also juhodN↓. (JK.) Hence, jahodu AlbalaA='i, (Msb,) i. e. A state of difficulty, or trouble, to which death is preferred: or largeness of one's family, or household, combined with poverty. (L, K. *) [Hence also,] balaga jahoda daAb~atihi, [i. e. balaga ma$aq~atahaA,] i. q. jahadahaA: see 1. (K.) ― -b3- Also Small provision, upon which a man possessing little property can live (JK, L) with difficulty. (L.) And jahodN Almuqil~i What a man who possesses little property can afford to give in payment of the poor-rate required by the law. (L, from a trad.)

juhodN jhd
: see jahodN, in five places. ＝ -A2- Also Milk mixed [with water: see majohuwdN]. (JK.)

jahaAdN jhAd
Hard land: (JK, S:) or land in which is no herbage: (TA:) or hard land in which is no herbage: (K:) or level, or even, land: or rugged land: also used as an epithet; so that you say A^aroDN jahaAdN: (TA:) or level, smooth land, in which is no hill: (JK:) or the most plain and even of land, whether it have produced herbage or not, not having any mountain or hill near it: and such is what is termed a SaHoraA=': (ISh, TA:) or an open tract of land: (Fr, TA:) or sterile, barren, or unfruitful, land, in which is nothing; as also jamaAdN: pl. juhudN. (AA, L.) ＝ -A2- Also The fruit of the A^araAk; (IAar, K;) and so jahaADN. (IAar, TA.)

maroEFY jahiydN mrEy jhyd
(tropical:) Pasture much eaten by cattle. (S, A, K.) And A^aroDN jahiydapu AlkalaA^i (tropical:) Land of which the herbage is much eaten by cattle. (A.)

juhaAdaY jhAd jhAdY jhAdy
: see jahodN.

juhayodaY jhyd jhydY jhydy
: see jahodN.

jaAhidN jAhd
[Striving, labouring, or toiling; &c.: see 1. Hence,] sayorunaA jaAhidN [Our journeying is laborious]. (TA in art. Axw.) And jahodN jaAhidN [Intense labour or exertion, or the like: or severe difficulty or distress &c.]: an intensive expression, (K, TA,) like $iEorN $aAEirN and layolN laAy^ilN. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Eagerly desiring [food]; longing for [it]: (JK, S:) pl. A^ajohaAdN. (JK.) ― -b3- garovaAnu jaAhidN (tropical:) Hungry and greedy, leaving no food. (A.)

mujohadN mjhd
A man thrown into a state of difficulty, embarrassment, distress, affliction, inconvenience, trouble, or fatigue. (L.)

huwa mujohadu laka hw mjhd lk
He is one who takes the course prescribed by prudence, precaution, or sound judgment, for thee; syn. muHotiyTN. (L.) And naSiyHN mujohidN A sincere, or faithful, and careful, adviser, or counsellor. (L.) ― -b2- rajulN mujohidN A man in a state of difficulty, embarrassment, distress, affliction, inconvenience, trouble or fatigue: possessing little property; poor. (L.) ― -b3- And A man whose beast is weak by reason of fatigue. (L.)

majohuwdN mjhwd
Severely affected, harassed, embarrassed, distressed, afflicted, troubled, inconvenienced, fatigued, or wearied: (S, Mgh, L:) distressed, or afflicted, by disease or difficulty: (JK:) afflicted with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth: (L:) and angry. (JK.) ― -b2- A hard, difficult, strait, or distressful, state of life. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Milk deprived of its butter (S, A) entirely: (S:) or mixed with water: (Msb:) or diluted so as to consist for the most part of water; and in like manner, broth: (A:) or churned so that its butter is extracted and it is rendered sweet and pleasant: and used as meaning eagerly desired, or longed for, and drunk without its occasioning disgust, by reason of its sweetness and pleasantness: (Msb:) or eagerly desired, or longed for; and so food in general: (JK, L:) or eagerly desired, or longed for, and drunk with perseverance, on account of its pleasantness and sweetness. (L.) ＝ -A2- See also jahodN, in six places.

1 jahara jhr
, (A, Msb, K,) aor.
jahara
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jahorN and jihaArN, (Er-Rághib, TA,) It (a thing, A, Msb) was, or became, plain, apparent, conspicuous, open, or public; syn. Zahara, (A, Msb,) and badaA, (TA,) and Ealana: (K:) or the radical signification is, it (a thing) was, or became, exceedingly plain to be perceived, either by the sense of sight or by that of hearing. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [Accord. to some, when relating to what is visible, it is tropical; and when relating to what is audible, proper: but if so, it seems to be so much used in the former sense as to be, in that sense, conventionally regarded as proper. See also jahorapN.] ＝ -A2- jahura, aor.
jahura
, [inf. n., app., jahaArapN and juhuwrapN,] He (a man, TA) was, or became, great, or bulky, (K, TA,) [and therefore a conspicuous object,] before the eyes of the beholder. (TA.) [And He was, or became, pleasing, or goodly, in aspect: see jahaArapN, below.] ― -b2- Also, (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. jahaArapN, (A, Msb,) It (the voice) rose [so as to be plainly heard]; was, or became, high, or loud. (A, Msb, * K.) ― -b3- Also, (S,) inf. n. jahaArapN, (TA,) He, (a man) was, or became, high, or loud, of voice. (S, TA.) ＝ -A3- jibir aor.
jahara
, (Msb,) inf. n. jaharN, (S, Msb,) He (a man) was unable to see in the sun. (S, Msb, TA.) And in like manner said of the eye. (K.) ＝ -A4- jaharahu, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. jahorN; (TA;) and jahara bihi; (A, Msb;) and Ajhrhu↓, (A, Msb, TA,) [and bihi Ajhr↓;] and jahowarahu↓; (TA;) He made it plain, apparent, conspicuous, open, or public. (A, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- jahara AlkalaAma, and jaharabihi; (K;) and Ajhrhu↓, inf. n. A_ijohaArN; (S;) and bihi Ajhr↓; (K;) and jahowara↓; (TA;) and jahara biAlqawoli, and biduEaAy^ihi, and biSalaAtihi, (TA,) and biqiraA='atihi, (Sgh, Msb, TA,) aor.
jahara
, inf. n. jahorN and jihaArN; (TA;) and bqr'A=th Ajhr↓; (Sgh, Msb, TA;) He uttered the speech, and the saying, and his supplication, and his prayer, and his recitation, with a plain, or an open, voice; openly; publicly: (S, Msb, K, TA:) or jahara bikalaAmihi, (A,) and biAlqawoli, and jahowara↓; (S;) and biqiraA='atihi; (A;) he uttered his speech, and the saying, and his recitation, with a raised, or loud, voice; aloud: (S, A:) and jahara AlS~awota he raised the voice [so as to make it plainly heard]. (K.) ― -b3- jahara biAlmaEaASiY, and Ajhr↓, and jAhr↓, he made known the acts of disobedience that he had committed, by talking of them: he who does so is termed biAlmuEaASiY mujaAhirN↓, and simply mujaAhirN. (TA.) And maA fiY Sadorihi Ajhr↓ He revealed what was in his bosom. (A.) And AlHadiyva baEoda maA hayonamahu jahowara↓ He revealed the story after he had concealed it. (A.) And Ajhr↓ AlA^amora He made the case, or affair, notorious. (TA.) ― -b4- Also jaharahu He discovered it (K, TA) ocularly. (TA.) ― -b5- He saw him (a man) without any veil (K, TA) intervening; (TA;) as also Ajthrhu↓: (K:) or he looked towards him, or regarded him. (K.) You say, maA fiY AlHaY~i A^aHadN
tajoharahu EayoniY There is not in the tribe any one whom my eye regards as worthy of notice or respect by reason of his greatness therein; syn. taA^oxu*uhu. (TA.) And Alqawomu fulaAnFA Ajthr↓ The people looked towards such a one without any veil intervening between them and him. (TA.) ― -b6- He treated him, or regarded him, with reverence, veneration, respect, or honour: (K:) or (TA) he regarded him as great in his eyes: (K, TA:) he saw him to be great in aspect, or appearance; (S;) as also Ajthrhu↓ (S, K) and Astjrhu↓: (A:) he was pleased with his beauty, and his form, or appearance, or state of apparel or the like; as also Ajthrhu↓: (Lh, * K:) or he pleased him by his beauty and form or appearance &c.: (A:) or it pleased him by its beauty; as also Ajthrhu↓. (TA.) ― -b7- He saw it (an army, S, A, K, and a people, TA) to be numerous in his eyes; as also Ajthrhu↓. (S A, K.) ＝ -A5- jahara Albiy^ora, (S, K,) aor.
jahara
, inf. n. jahorN, (TA,) He cleared out the well, (S, K,) and took forth from it the black fetid mud that it contained; as also AjtrhA↓: (S:) or both signify he entirely, or nearly, exhausted the well of its water: (K:) or the former, he reached the water of the well, (K, TA,) in digging: or so jahara alone: (TA:) and accord. to Akh, jaharotu Alr~akiy~apa signifies I cleared out the mud that the water covered in the well, so that the water appeared and became clear. (S.) 'Áïsheh said, describing her father, dufuna Alr~awaA='i Ajthr↓, lit., He cleared out the filled-up wells of abundant water so as to make the water well forth; alluding to his rectifying affairs that had become disordered. (TA from a trad.) ＝ -A6- jaharonaAhumo We came to them in the morning, at the time called AlS~abaAH, (S, A, K, TA,) when they were inadvertent. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- jahara AlA^aroDa He traversed the land (S, K) without knowledge. (S.) ＝ -A7- jahara Als~iqaA='a He shook the milk-skin to make butter, (Fr, S, K,) and took forth its butter. (Fr, TA.) ＝ -A8- jaharati Al$~amosu AlmusaAfira The sun dazzled the eye, and confused the sight, of the traveller; syn. A^asodarato Eayonahu. (K.)

3 jAhr jAhr
: see 1. ― -b2- [Its inf. n.] mujaAharapN signifies The fighting [with any one] face to face: and the showing open enmity, or hostility, with any one: and the reading, or reciting, a thing aloud: and the speaking loudly. (KL.) You say, jAhr biAlEadaAwapi, (Msb,) inf. n. mujaAharapN (S, Msb) and jihaArN, (Msb,) He showed open enmity or hostility, with another. (S, * Msb.) And jaAharotuhumo biAlA^amori I acted openly with them in the affair, or case; syn. EaAlanotuhumo bihi. (JK.) [And jAhrhu He treated him openly with enmity &c.] ― -b3- jaAharahumo biAlA^amori, (TA,) inf. n. mujaAharapN and jihaArN, (K,) [is explained as signifying] He vied with them, or strove to overcome or surpass them, in the affair, or case. (K, * TA.) [But gAlbhm, in the TA, and AlmugaAlabapu, in the K, are here evidently mistranscriptions for EaAlanahumo and AlmuEaAlanapu.]

4 A^ajohara
see 1, in eight places. ― -b2- Ajhr also signifies He begat sons goodly in stature (IAar, K) and in aspect, (IAar, TA,) or in cheeks: (K:) or, a squint-eyed son. (IAar, K.)

6 tajaAohara
[tajaAhurN signifies The showing oneself openly: and acting openly, or being open in one's conduct or converse, with others. You say,] tajaAharuwA biAlEadaAwapi They showed open enmity, or hostility, one with another; syn. tabaAdawoAbihaA. (S in art. bdw.) ＝ -A2- [And tjAhr He feigned himself unable to see in the sun: see the part. n., below.]

8 A_ijotahara
see 1, in eight places.

10 Astjhrhu Astjhrh Astjhrp
: see 1. ― -b2- Also He took it forth. (TA from a trad.)

Q. Q. 1 jahowara jhwr
: see 1, in four places.

jahorFA jhr jhrA
: see jahorapN, in two places.

juhorN jhr
: see jahaArapN, in six places.

jahirN jhr
: see jahiyrN, in two places.

jahorapN jhr jhrh jhrp
A thing that is plain, apparent, conspicuous, open, or public. (K.) You say, raA=hu jahorapF (S, A, &c.) He saw him, or it, [plainly,] without the intervention of any veil: (TA:) and rA=h jihaArFA↓ [signifies the same: or] he saw him, or it, with exceeding plainness: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the former signifies he saw him, or it, with his eyes, ocularly, or before his eyes, (S, A, Bd in ii. 52, Msb,) without anything intervening: (S:) so in the Kur. [ii. 52], Hat~aY naraY A@ll~`ha jahorapF: (S, Bd:) and [some say that] jahorapF is here originally an inf. n. of jaharotu in jaharotu biAlqiraA='api, [like jahorFA↓,] and metaphorically used in the sense of muEaAyanapF: it is in the accus. case as an inf. n.: or it is thus used as a denotative of state relating to the agent or the object: and some read jaharapF↓, as an inf. n. like galabap, or as pl. of jaAhirN, and as such it is a denotative of state: (Bd:) or jahorapF is here from jaharotu Alr~akiy~apa: (Akh, S:) accord. to Ibn-' Arafeh, it here signifies unconcealed from us: (TA:) and in the Kur. iv. 152, ocularly; not concealed from us by anything. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- You say also, kal~amahu jahorapF [and jahorFA↓ He spoke to him plainly, with an open voice, aloud, or publicly]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And laqiyahu nahaArFA jihaArFA↓ and jahaArFA↓ [He met him in the daytime, openly, or publicly]. (K.)

juhorapN jhr jhrh jhrp
[A blaze covering the face of a horse: or the quality of having such a blaze:] a subst. from A^ajoharu applied to a horse. (TA.) ― -b2- A cast in the eye. (AA, TA. [See also A^ajoharu.])

jaharapF jhr jhrh jhrp
: see jahorapN.

jahaArFA jhAr jhArA
and jihaArFA: see jahorapN, in three places.

jahowarN jhwr
: see jahiyrN. ― -b2- Also, and mujotaharN↓, An army seen to be numerous. (A.) ― -b3- And the former, Bold; daring: in the K, erroneously, jawoharN↓. (TA.)

jahiyrN jhyr
(in the TA, here, jahirN↓, but in another place, jahiyrN,) High, loud, or vehement, speech; (Msb, K, TA;) as also mujoharN↓ and jahowariY~N↓: (K:) and so applied to the voice; (Msb, TA;) as also jahowariY~N↓. (A, TA.) Also, and mujoharN↓ (TA) and jahowariY~N↓ (A, TA) and jahowarN↓ (A) and jahiyru AlS~awoti (S, A) and AlS~awoti jahowariY~u↓, (S,) A man having a high, loud, or strong voice. (S, A, TA.) ― -b2- A man (S, A) of pleasing, or goodly, aspect; (S, A, K;) as also jahirN↓: (K:) fem. of the former with p: (S:) beautiful: (K:) of goodly aspect, who pleases the beholder by his beauty: and a face of goodly, or beautiful, fairness: (TA:) and A^ajoharu↓ a man (TA) of goodly aspect, (K, TA,) and of goodly and perfect body. (AA, K, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or jahiyrN liloxayori and lilomaEoruwfi, (A,) Adapted to, or constituted for, goodness: (A, K:) because he who beholds him desires his beneficence: (TA:) pl. juharaA='u. (A, K.) ＝ -A2- Also Milk not mixed with water: (Fr, S, K:) or from which the butter has been taken forth. (TA.)

juhaArapN jhAr jhArh jhArp
[an inf. n. (see jahura)] Pleasingness, or goodliness, of aspect; (S, A, K;) as also juhuwrapN↓ (K) and juhorN↓: (TA:) [and a quality pleasing to behold: for] Abu-n-Nejm says,
waA^araY AlbayaADa EalaY Aln~isaA='i jahaArapF
[And I regard fairness in women as a quality pleasing to behold]: (S:) and juhorN↓ signifies the form, or appearance, or the like, and goodliness of aspect, of a man: (K:) or what pleases by its beauty, of the form or appearance or the like, of a man, and and goodliness of aspect: (S:) [and simply aspect, or outward appearance.] You say, banuwna *awuw jahaArpK Sons goodly in stature and in aspect: (IAar, TA:) or in stature and in cheeks: (K:) but the former is the more agreeable with authority. (TA.) And fulaAnK maA A^aHosana juhora↓ How goodly is the form, or appearance, or the like, and the beauty of aspect, of such a one! (S, A: *) [or simply, the aspect; for] you say also, maA A^asowaA^a juhorahu↓ [How evil is his aspect!]. (A.) And rajulN Hasanu AljahaArapi and Aljuhori↓ A man goodly in aspect. (TA.) And faEarafotu sir~ahu raA^ayotu juhorahu↓ [I saw his aspect, and so knew his mind]. (A.)

juhuwrapN jhwr jhwrh jhwrp
: see the next preceding paragraph.

fulaAnN Eafiyfu Als~ariyrapi wa Aljahiyrapi flAn Efyf Alsryrp w Aljhyrh flAn Efyf Alsryrp w Aljhyrp
[Such a one is chaste in secret conduct and in public behaviour]. (A.)

jahowariY~N jhwrY jhwry
: see jahiyrN, in four places.

jawoharN jwhr
a word of well-known meaning, (Msb,) [a coll. gen. n., Jewels; precious stones; gems; pearls: any kind of jewel, precious stone, or gem: and also applied (as in the T, M, Mgh, Msb, and K, voce tiborN, q. v.,) to native ore:] any stone from which is extracted, or elicited, anything by which one may profit: (K:) n. un. with p: (S:) [pl. jawaAhiru:] it is of the measure fawoEalu, (Msb,) and is from Aljahoru signifying a thing's “ becoming exceedingly plain to be perceived by the sense of sight: ” (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it is of Persian origin, (TA,) arabicized, (S, TA,) [from Gawoharo,] accord. to most persons. (TA.) ― -b2- jawoharu sayofK The diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, of a sword; syn. firinodN. (T and K voce firinodN.] ― -b3- jawoharu $aYo'K [The essence of a thing; or that whereby a thing is what it is; the substance of a thing: the constituent of a thing; the material part thereof;] that upon which the natural con-
stitution of a thing is as it were based; or of which its natural constitution is made to be; [or, as IbrD thinks to be meant in the K, the collective parts and materials of a thing, of which its natural constitution is moulded;] expl. by maAwuDiEato Ealayohi jibil~atuhu, (K,) or, as in some Lexicons, [as the JK and the Msb,] maA xuliqato Ealayohi jibil~atuhu [which is virtually the same]: (TA:) Aljawoharu and Al*~aAtu and AlmaAhiy~apu and AlHaqiyqapu are all syn. terms; and the first has other significations; but in the classical language it signifies AlA^aSolu, i. e., A^aSolu Almurak~abaAti [the original of compound things]; and not what subsists by itself. (Kull.) ― -b4- [Hence, Aljawoharu Alfarodu (assumed tropical:) The indivisible atom.] ― -b5- In the conventional language of scholastic theology, jawoharN signifies (tropical:) Substance, as opposed to accident; in which sense, some assert the word to be so much used as to be, in this sense, conventionally regarded as proper. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jahowarN.

jawohariY~N jwhr jwhrY jwhry jwhryy
A jeweller; a seller of jawohar [or jawaAhir]. (TA.) ― -b2- [In scholastic theology, (assumed tropical:) Of, or relating to, substance, as opposed to accident.]

A^ajoharu *
: see jahiyrN. ― -b2- Also A man having the eyeball, or globe of the eye, prominent and apparent, or large and prominent; syn. jaAHiZN: or resembling such as is termed jAHZ: fem. jahoraA='u. (TA.) And this latter, An eye having the ball, or globe, prominent and apparent, or large and prominent; syn. jaAHiZapN: (K:) or resembling what is thus termed. (TA.) ― -b3- Having a pretty cast in the eye: (AA, K:) fem. as above. (K.) ― -b4- That cannot see in the sun; (S, A, Msb, K;) applied to a man, (A, Msb,) and to a ram: (S:) fem. as above: (S, A, Msb, K:) or weak-sighted in the sun: (Lh, TA:) or that cannot see in the daytime; A^aEo$aY signifying “ that cannot see in the night: ” (TA:) and the fem., a woman who closes her eyes in the sun. (A.) ― -b5- A horse having a blaze that covers his face: fem. as above. (K.) ― -b6- Also the fem., Open, bare, land, not concealed by anything: (A:) or plain land, in which are no trees nor hills (K, TA) nor sands: (TA:) pl. jahoraAwaAtN. (A, TA.) ― -b7- And A company (S, K) consisting of the distinguished part (TA) of a people: (S:) the more, or most, excellent persons of a tribe. (K.) You say, [with reference to distinguished persons,] kayofa jahoraAw^ukumo How is your company? (S.)

mujoharN mjhr
. see majohuwrN: and see also jahiyrN, in two places.

mijoharN mjhr
(S, K) and mijohaArN↓ (K) A man accustomed to speak with a plain, or an open, voice; openly; or publicly. (S, K.)

mijohaArN mjhAr
: see what next precedes.

majohuwrN bihi mjhwr bh mjhwr bp
Notorious; applied to a thing: (TA:) and so mujotaharN↓ applied to a man: (A, TA:) and mujoharN↓ plain, apparent, or conspicuous; applied to a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- AlHuruwfu Almajohuwrapu [The letters that are pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only; the vocal letters;] the letters (nineteen in number, S) that are comprised in the saying Zil~u qaw~K rabaDN A_i*o gazaA junodu muTiyEN: (S, K:) opposed to Almahomuwsapu: (TA:) so called [accord. to some] because there is a full stress in the place where any one of them occurs, and the breath is prevented from passing with it until the stress is ended with the passage of the voice. (Sb, S.) ＝ -A2- maA='N majohuwrN Water which, having been buried in the earth, has been drawn until it has become sweet. (TA.) ― -b2- majohuwrapN A well (biy^orN) cleared out, and cleansed from the black fetid mud which it had contained. (S.) ― -b3- And Wells frequented [and in use], (K,) whether their water be sweet or salt. (TA.)

mujaAhirN mjAhr mjhr
: see, above, jahara biAlmaEaASiY.

mujotaharN mjthr
: see majohuwrN: and see also jahowarN.

mutajaAhirN mtjAhr
Feigning himself A^ajohar; as in the saying, cited by Th,
kaAln~aAZiri AlmutajaAhiri
[Like the looker that feigns himself unable to see in the sun]. (TA.)

1 jahaza EalaY AljariyHi jhz Ely AljryH
: see 4, in two places.

2 jh~z jhz
, inf. n. tajohiyzN, He fitted out, equipped, furnished, or supplied, a bride, and a traveller, and a corpse, (S, Msb, K,) and an army, (S,) with her, or his, or their, jahaAz [i. e. requisites, equipage, furniture, accoutrements, or apparatus]: (S, Msb. K:) he provided a warrior with a beast to ride, and with other requisites for his expedition: (TA:) he prepared him or it. (TA.) You say also, jhaz Ealayohi Alxayola [He fitted out the horsemen and sent them against him]. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also 4.

4 Ajhz EalaY AljariyHi Ajhz Ely AljryH
, (As, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_ijohuAzN; (Msb;) and Ealayoha jahaza↓, aor.
Hahaza
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jahozN; (TA;) He despatched, or he hastened and completed the slaughter of, the wounded man; (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) he made his slaughter sure, or certain: (JK, K:) and jh~z↓, with teshdeed, signifies the same, but denoting muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects, and intensiveness: (Msb:) or ElY AljryH jahaza↓ signifies he slew the wounded man. (IDrd, TA.) You should not say, A^ajazotu ElY AljryH, (S,) or A^ajaAza Elyh. (ISd, TA.)

5 tjh~z A^jhz jhz tjhz
He fitted out, equipped, furnished, or supplied, himself; or he or it became fitted out or equipped or furnished or supplied; with his or its jahaAz [or requisites, &c.]: (K:) he prepared himself. (S, K.) You say, tajah~azotu liA^amori ka*aA, (S, K, *) and AijohaAzazotu↓, (K,) I prepared myself for such a thing. (S, K.)

11 AijohaAzazotu liA^amorika*aA *
: see 5.

jahaAzN jhAz
, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) so accord. to the seven readers in the Kur xii. 59 and 70, (Az, Msb,) and jihaAzN↓, (S, Msb, K,) but the latter is rare, (Msb,) or bad, (Az, TA,) or an erroneous pronunciation of the people of El-Basrah, (Lth, TA,) The requisites, (Msb, K,) equipments, equipage, furniture, accoutrements, or apparatus, (Msb,) of a bride, [i. e. her paraphernalia,] and of a traveller, and of a corpse: (S, Msb, K:) provisions and other requisites for a traveller: (Har p. 104:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajohizapN, and pl. pl. A^ajohizaAtN. (S, K.) ― -b2- Accord. to some, Household goods or furniture and utensils: accord. to 'Alee Ibn- 'Eesà, excellent goods that are conveyed from country to country: and hence the jhAz of the bride: (Har p. 104:) or excellent goods that are conveyed as merchandise. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also the former, What is upon a camel that is used for riding [consisting of the saddle and its appertenances]. (K.) It is said in a prov., jahaAzihi Daraba fiY , with fet-h [to the j], (As, S, K,) i. e. He took fright and fled or went away at random, and did not return: (K:) or it is said of a thing that goes away and does not return: (As, S:) originally relating to a camel from whose back the saddle with its apparatus tumbles, falling between his legs, in consequence of which he takes fright and flees or runs away at random, so that he goes away into the land: (As, S, K:) Daraba signifies he went; (sAr; for which in the CK is put SAr;) and the meaning of the phrase is, he went stumbling upon his apparatus. (K.) In the T it is said, The Arabs say, Daraba AlbaEiyru fiY jahaAzihi, meaning The camel took fright and ran away at random, beating the ground with his feet so as to throw down the apparatus and load that were upon him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also the former, The pudendum of a woman. (S K, TA.)

jihaAzN jhAz
: see jahaAzN.

farasN jahiyzN frs jhyz
, (S, K,) or jahiyzu Al$~ad~i, (AO, TA,) A horse quick, or swift, in running: (AO, S:) or the former, a horse that is light, or active. (K.) ― -b2- mawotN jahiyzN, and mujohizN↓, A quick death. (K.)

mawotN mujohizN mwt mjhz
: see what next precedes.

mujah~azN mjhz
One for whom are prepared travellingprovisions and equipage, that he may perform the pilgrimage for another. (Mgh.)

mujah~izN mjhz
One who sends forth traders with excellent goods: or who travels with such goods. (Mgh.) Hence, app., the vulgar term mujaAhizN↓, meaning A rich merchant. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And mujah~izuwna Travelling-companions who assist one in the loading of the beasts. (Msb.)

mujaAhizN mjAhz
: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 jaha$a A_ilayohi *
, (S, K,) and jahi$a, (K,) which latter, accord. to IDrd, is the more common, (TA,) aor.
jaha$a
, inf. n. jaho$N (S, K) and juhuw$N and jaha$aAnN, (K,) He betook himself to him by reason of fright or fear, seeking protection, and being about, or ready, to weep; like as the child betakes himself to his mother by reason of fright or fear, (As, S, K,) and to his father, (As,) being about, or ready, to weep; (As, S;) as also A^ajoha$a↓. (AO, S, K.) ― -b2- jaha$ato nafosuhu, (S, A,) or jaha$ato A_ilayohi nafosuhu, inf. n. juhuw$N; (TA;) and A^ajoha$ato↓; (S, A, TA;) His soul heaved, (S, A,)
and he was about, or ready, to weep: (A:) or his soul heaved, and quitted him. (TA.) ― -b3- jaha$a lil$~awoqi waAlHuzoni He was ready, or about, to desire, and to mourn: (IDrd:) and biAlbukaA='i A^ajoha$a↓ He was ready, or about, to weep. (El-Umawee, K.) ― -b4- jaha$a mina Al$~aYp'i, (AA, K,) and jahi$a, (K,) aor.
jaha$a
, inf. n. jaha$aAnN, (AA, K,) He was frightened at the thing, or afraid of it: (AA, K:) or he fled from the thing.. (Sgh, K.) ― -b5- jaha$uwA faziEiyna They came quickly to me, frightened. (A.) ― -b6- yajoha$u mino A^aroDK A_ilaY A^aroDK He removes, and goes quickly, from land to land. (K.) ― -b7- jaha$a A_ilaY Alqawomi, inf. n. jaho$N, He came to the people, or company of men. (TA.)

4 A^ajoha$a
see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- Ajh$ fulaAnFA He hastened such a one. (Ibn-'Abbaád, K.)

jaho$apN *
A flow of tears (A, K, TA) falling one after another on the occasion of jaho$ [or the betaking oneself to another by reason of fright or fear, &c.]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A company of men; as also jaAhi$apN↓: (K:) or the latter signifies a party, and a multitude, of men. (TA.)

juhuw$N *
Quick; who removes, and goes quickly, from land to land. (K.)

jaAh$apN *
: see jaho$apN.

1 jahVDa
see 4, in two places.

3 jAhDhu jAhDh jAhDp
, (K,) inf. n. jihaADN, (TA,) He endeavoured to prevent him, or to turn him away [from a thing]; and strove to be before him; syn. maAnaEahu and EaAjalahu. (K.) Hence the saying, in a trad. of Mohammad Ibn-Meslemeh, relating his endeavouring to attack a man on the day of Ohod, fajaAhaDaniY Eanohu A^abuw sufoyaAna But Aboo-Sufyán endeavoured to turn me away from him (maAnaEaniY Eanohu), and put me away [from him]. (TA.)

4 A^ajohaDaniY *
He overcame me in contending for the thing; as also jahaDaniY↓. (S.) You say, AjhDhu Eani AlA^amori, He overcame him in contending for the thing, and made him to quit it, or put him away from it; as also Eanohu jahaDahu↓, aor.
jahaDa
. (A, K.) And qutila fulaAnN faA^ujohiDa Eanohu Alqawomu Such a one was slain, and the people were overcome so that he was taken from them. (S.) And SaAda AljaAriHapu AlS~ayoda faA^ajohaDonaAhu Eanohu The beast, or bird, of prey caught the game, and we removed him, and overcame him in contending for that which he had caught. (S, A, * Msb.) ― -b2- AjhD is also syn. with A^aEojala. (A, K.) Thus, sometimes, (S,) A^ajohaDotuhu Eano ka*aA, (S,) or Eani AlA^amori, (Mgh, TA,) signifies I hurried him so as to prevent him from doing such a thing, or the thing; (S, Mgh, TA;) and made him to quit it. (Mgh.) ― -b3- You say also, AjhDhu Eano makaAnihi He roused him, or made him to rise, from his place. (A, * TA.) And [elliptically] A^ajohaDonaA AlEaduw~a We roused the enemy, or made them to rise, from their places; and removed them therefrom, or made them to quit them. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- AjhDt She (a camel, AZ, As, S, A, K) cast her young one: (S, A:) or cast her young one with its fur grown, (As, K,) before it was perfect: (As:) or cast her young one before its form was apparent: (AZ:) or in an imperfect state: (TA:) or AjhDt waladahaA, inf. n. A_ijohaADN, she (a camel, and a woman,) cast her young one imperfect in form. (Msb.)

jihoDN jhD
: see jahiyDN, in two places.

jihaADN jhAD
[The act of a camel's, and of a woman's, casting an imperfect fœtus;] a subst. from AjhDt said of a camel and of a woman. (Msb.)

jahiyDN jhyD
, applied to the young one, or fœtus, of a camel, (S, A, Msb,) and of a woman, (Msb,) i. q. mujohaDN↓ [pass. part. n. of A^ajohaDato, q. v.]: (S, A, Msb: *) or, (K,) as also jihoDN↓, on the authority of Fr, being, as he says, like xidojN, in the K, erroneously, jahiDN, (TA,) an abortion: or a young one perfectly formed, and into which the spirit has been inspired, without its living: (K:) or jihoDN↓ signifies the young one of a camel that is cast before its form is apparent. (TA.)

mujohaDN mjhD
: see the next preceding paragraph.

mujohiDN mjhD
, applied to a she-camel, (S, Msb, K,) and to a woman, (Msb,) act. part. n. of A^ajohaDato [q. v.]; (S, Msb, K;) as also with majaAhiyDu: (Msb:) pl. mKjohaADN. (K.)

jhl jAhl jhl
A she-camel that is accustomed to cast her young (S, A) in an imperfect state. (TA.)

1 jahila jAhl jhl
; (S;) and jahilahu, (Sh, Msb, K,) and jahila bihi (JK) [and minohu (see jaAhilN)]; aor.
jaaaha
, (K,) inf. n. jaholN and jahaAlapN (S, Msb, K) and juhuwliy~ahN; (TA;) He was ignorant; (S;) he was characterized by jahol in any of the senses assigned to this word below: (TA:) and he was ignorant of it; he did not know it; (Sh, JK, Msb, K;) contr. of Ealimahu. (Msb, K.) You say, mivoliY laA yajohalu mivolaka The like of me will not be ignorant of the like of thee. (Sh, TA.) And jahila EalaY gayorihi He acted in an ignorant or a silly or foolish manner towards another: and wrongly. (Msb.) And jahila fulaAnN raA^oyahu [i. q. safiha raA^uyahu, He was ignorant, or silly, or foolish, in his opinion, or judgment]. (Sh, TA.) And jahila AlHaq~a He neglected the truth, or the right, or due; [or he ignored it;] syn. A^aDaAEahu. (Msb.) See also 6. ― -b2- jahilati Alqidoru (tropical:) The cooking-pot boiled vehemently; contr. of taHal~amat. (TA.)

2 jh~lhu jAhl jhl jhlh jhlp
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. tajohiylN, (S, K,) He attributed to him jahol [or ignorance, &c.]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And He caused him to fall into jahol. (TA.)

3 mujaAhalapN mjAhlh mjAhlp mjhl
The acting with levity, and in an ignorant or a silly or foolish manner, with any one. (KL.) [You say, jAhlhu, meaning He so acted with him.]

6 tjAhl tjAhl
He feigned, or made a false show of, jahol [or ignorance, &c.]. (S, K.) And jahila↓ Ealayohi He feigned ignorance [to him]. (K.)

10 Astjhlhu A^stjhlh Astjhlh Astjhlp {stjhl {stjhlh
He reckoned him, or esteemed him, jaAhil [or ignorant, &c.]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- He, or it, excited him to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness. (S, K.) ― -b3- Aisotjohalati Alr~iyHu AlguSona (tropical:) The wind put the branch into a state of commotion. (K, TA.)

jaholN jAhl jhl
an inf. n. of 1: Ignorance; contr. of EilomN: (S, Msb, * K: *) [and silliness, or foolishness: and wrong conduct: (see 1:)] it is of two kinds; namely, simple, which is the non-existence of knowledge of that which should be known; and compound, which is a decisive belief not agreeable with the fact, or reality: so accord. to Ibn-El-Kemál: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, it is of three kinds; namely, the mind's voidness of knowledge, which is the primary meaning; and the believing a thing to be different from what it is; and the doing a thing in a manner different from that in which it ought to be done: or, accord. to El-Harállee, the proceeding in dubious affairs without knowledge. (TA.) It is said in a prov., kafiY biAl$~ak~i juholFA [Doubt is sufficient ignorance]. (Msb.) And it is said in a trad., A_in~a mina AlEilomi jaholFA [Verily there is, among the kinds of knowledge, what is ignorance]: this is one's learning what is not requisite, and neglecting what is requisite; or a learned man's affecting, or pretending, a knowledge of that which he does not know. (TA.)

jahilaA^'u *
: see AljaAhiliy~apu.:jahuwlN see what next follows.

jaAhilN jAhl
and jahuwlN↓, [but the latter has an intensive signification,] Ignorant: (Msb, K:) and silly, or foolish, in conduct: and wrong in conduct: (Msb:) [characterized by jahol in any of the senses assigned to this word above:] pl. juh~aAlN (K, KL) and juholN and juhulN and juh~alN and juhalaA='u: (K:) see jaAhiliY~N.
