The former epithet is mostly used in dispraise: but sometimes not in dispraise; as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 274], yajosibuhumu AljaAhilu A^agoniyaA='a i. e., The ignorant of their [real] state [would reckon them possessed of competence]. (TA.) huwa jaAhilN minohu means hw jAhl bihi, (K, TA,) i. e., He is ignorant [of him, or it, or] of his, or its, state, or condition. (TA.) ― -b2- AljaAhilu The lion (K, TA) that is ignorant of the prey. (TA.) [In the CK, waAljaAhilu AlAasadu is a mistake for waAljaAhilu AlA^asadu.]

jayohalu jyhl
: see jayohalapN. ＝ -A2- Also Great as an epithet applied to a smooth rock (SafaApN). (K.)

jayohalapN jyhlh jyhlp
(IDrd, JK, K) and jayohalN↓ and mijohalN↓ (IDrd, K) and mijohalapN↓ (K) A piece of wood with which one stirs live, or burning, coals (jamor), (JK, K, TA,) or wine (xamor); (so in some copies of the K;) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

jaAhiliY~N jAhl jAhlY jAhly jAhlyy
[A pagan; a pagan Arab; one of those who are called collectively AljaAhily~apN↓; and
sometimes muxaDuramuwn↓, pl. of $aAhidN: and particularly, a pagan poet;] a poet of the first, or earliest, of the four classes which are ranked in chronological order; of the class which was succeeded next by the muxaDoramuwn. (Mz, 49th nwE.) [See also $aAhidN.]

AljaAhiliy~apN AljAhlyh AljAhlyp jAhly jAhlyp
: see what next precedes. ― -b2- [Also, or] AljaAhiliy~apu AljaholaA='u↓, (JK, S, K,) in which the latter word is a corroborative, (S, K,) as in layolapN layolaA='u &c., (S,) [The time, or state, of ignorance, or paganism; or of intense ignorance;] the time of the fatorap [or cessation of the mission of apostles, and of the effacement of the signs of their religion]. (JK.) One says, kaAna *`lika fiY AljaAhiliy~api AljaholaA='i [That was in the time, or state, of paganism, or of intense ignorance]. (S.)

majohalN mjhl
An affair, or an event, or a case, and a land, and a habit, a property, a quality, a practice, or an action, that induces a man to believe a thing to be different from what it is. (Er-Rághib, TA.) A desert (mafaAzapN) in which are no signs of the way. (S.) And A^aroDN majohalN A land in which are no signs of the way: (TA:) or in which one will not go aright (K, TA) unless by means of the [signs of the way called] A=raAm: (TA:) pl. majaAhilu, which is the contr. of maEaAlimu: (TA:) accord. to the K, it has neither dual nor pl.; but it has both, as 'Iyád and others have affirmed. (MF, TA.)

mijohalN mjhl
: see jayohalapN.

majohalapN mjhl mjhlh mjhlp
[A cause of, or an incitement to, ignorant, silly, foolish, or wrong, conduct;] a thing that incites one to Aljahol. (S, K.) Hence the saying, Alwaladu majohalapN [Children are a cause of silly, or foolish, conduct]. (S.)

mijohalapN mjhl mjhlh mjhlp
: see jayohalapN.

mijohaAlN mjhAl
(tropical:) A she-camel light, brisk, or agile, in her pace, or going. (TA.)

majohuwlN mjhwl
[Unknown]. You say, rakibotu AlmafaAzapN EalaY majohuwlihaA [I ventured upon traversing the desert notwithstanding its unknown character]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [A man of unknown origin. A book of unknown authorship. ― -b3- In grammar, The passive voice.] ― -b4- naAqapN majohuwlapN (tropical:) A she-camel that has never been milked: or that has no brand upon her: (K, TA:) and (tropical:) a she-camel that has never conceived. (Z, TA.)

musotajohilN mstjhl
Making himself like the jaAhil [or ignorant; feigning himself ignorant]: or reckoning, or esteeming, jaAhil. (Har p. 572.)

1 jahuma jhm
, aor.
jahuma
, inf. n. juhuwmapN (S, K) and jahaAmapN, (K,) He (a man) became frowning, or contracted, in face; or grinning in face, with a frowning, or contraction, or a stern, an austere, or a morose, look: (S:) or he was, or became, coarse, or rough, and contracted, and ugly, in face. (K.) ― -b2- Also, said of the pubes, It was coarse, rough, or big. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jahamahu, (S, K,) and jahimahu, aor.
jahama
, in both instances; (K;) and tjh~mhu↓, (S, K,) and lahu tjh~m↓; (JK, K;) He grinned, frowning, or looking sternly, austerely, or morosely, in his face: (S:) or he met him, or regarded him, with a displeasing, (JK, K, TA,) frowning, or grinning and frowning, (TA,) face: (JK, K, TA:) or tjh~m↓ signifies he showed a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, face. (TK in art. Ebs.) A poet says,
AljahuwmaA↓ wabalodapK tajah~amu↓
zajarotu fiyhaA EayohalFA rasuwmaA
(S, * TA,) i. e. [Many a region] that exhibits to the impotent that which he dislikes, [or that frowns upon the weak, or impotent, I have chidden therein a strong she-camel that leaves the marks of her footsteps upon the ground.] (S.) You say also, AlkiraAma Ald~ahoru yatajah~amu↓ (tropical:) [Fortune frowns upon the generous]. (TA.) And A^amaliY tajah~amaniY↓ (tropical:) [My object of hope frowned upon me] is said when one has not attained his object of hope. (TA.)

4 A^ajohamati Als~amaA='u *
The sky had clouds such as are termed jahaAm. (K.)

5 tajah~ama
see 1, in six places.

8 Ajthm A^j A^jthm Ajthm
He entered upon, (K,) or journeyed in, (A, TA,) the portion of the night termed juhomap. (A, K, TA.)

jahomN jhm
A coarse, or rough, and contracted, and ugly, face; as also jahimN↓; (K;) or, as in some of the lexicons, jahiymN↓. (TA.) And jahomu Alwajohi Frowning, or contracted, in face; or grinning in face, with a frowning, or contraction, or a stern, an austere, or a morose, look: (S, Mgh:) or coarse, or rough, in face: (JK, TA:) applied to a man: (JK, S, Mgh, TA:) and to a lion. (JK, TA.) And [hence,] Aljahomu The lion. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also jahuwmN.

jahimN jhm
: see jahomN.

jahomapN jhm jhmh jhmp
: see juhomapN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A big cooking-pot. (K.)

juhomapN jhm jhmh jhmp
and jahomapN↓, (JK, S, K,) both mentioned by Fr, (S,) A portion of the night: (JK:) the first of the last portions of the night, (JK, S, K, TA,) extending [app. from midnight] to near the period a little before daybreak: (TA:) or the remaining portion of the darkness of the last part of the night: (K:) or the former signifies, [or each,] the beginning of the night, extending to a fourth part: or, as some say, the middle of the night: (KL:) pl. of the former juhamN. (JK.) You say, maDaY mina All~ayoli juhomapN and jahomapN↓ [app. meaning A portion, or a portion at the commencement of the latter part, of the night passed]. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also the former, Eighty camels: or the like. (K.)

jahaAmN jhAm
Clouds in which is no water: (JK, S, K:) or that have poured forth their water (K, TA) with the wind. (TA.)

juhuwmN jhwm
, applied to a man, (JK, S,) Impotent; (JK, S, K;) weak; as also jahomN↓. (K.) See an ex. in the first paragraph.

jahiymN jhym
: see jahomN.

jahan~amu jhnm
[Hell; or Hell-fire;] (T, S, K, &c.;) a name of the fire with which God will punish, (T, S,) in the life to come, (T,) his [disobedient and unrepentant and unbelieving] servants; (S;) a proper name of the abode of punishment: (Bd, ii. 202:) a word rendered quasi-coordinate to the quinqueliteral-radical class by the doubling of the third letter: (S:) accord. to some, it is an Arabic word, applied to the fire of the world to come because of its depth; [see the last paragraph;] (T, TA;) or originally syn. with Aln~aAru [fire, or the fire]; (Bd in ii. 202;) and imperfectly decl. because determinate and of the fem. gender: (T, S:) accord. to others, it is an arabicized word, (T, S, Bd ubi suprà,) imperfectly decl. because determinate and of foreign origin; (T, TA;) some say, originally Persian; (S;) others, from the Hebrew khnAm, (TA,) [or as Golius says, ??? “ the Valley of Hinnom, ” where children were burned alive as sacrifices to the idol Moloch.] ― -b2- See also jihin~aAmN.

[
jahan~amiY~N jhnm jhnmY jhnmy
Of, or relating to, jahan~am, i. e. Hell, or Hell-fire.]

jihin~aAmN jhnAm
(S, K, Ham p. 817) and [jahin~aAmN and juhin~aAmN], with each of the three vowels (K, TA) to the j (TA,) [but accord. to the K it would rather seem to be jahan~aAmN and juhun~aAmN,] and jahan~amN↓, (K,) applied to a well (rakiy~apN, S, K, or biy^orN, Ham), Deep; (S, K, Ham;) in which he who falls into it perishes. (Ham.)

jaw~N jw
The air: (K:) or [the atmosphere; i. e.] what is between the heaven, or sky, and the earth; (S, Mgh;) the air [or the region] between the heaven, or sky, and the earth: pl. A^ajowaA='N. (TA.) fiY jaw~i Als~amaA='i, in the Kur [xvi. 81], means In the air between the heaven, or sky, and the earth: (Jel:) or in the middle of the sky: (Katádeh, TA:) or in the air that is remote from the earth. (Bd.) ― -b2- A low, or depressed, part of the ground; (M, K;) as also jaw~apN↓: (K:) or a wide part of a valley: (S, Msb:) pl. (in the latter sense, Msb, or in the former, K, TA) jiwaA='N (Msb, K) and [of pauc.] A^ajowiyapN. (TA.) It has the latter meaning in the saying of Tarafeh, [addressing a lark,]
xalaA laki Aljaw~u fabiyDiY waA@SofiriY
[The wide part of the valley has become vacant for thee; so lay thine eggs, and whistle]. (AA, S.) Az says, I entered, with an Arab of the desert, a [hollow place in which water collected, termed a] daHol, in El-Khalsà, and when we came to the water, he said, h`*aA jaw~N mina AlmaA'i laA yuwqafu EalaY A^aqoSaAhu [This is an abyss of water: one knows not the utmost extent of it]. (TA.) ― -b3- A vacant, void, or desolate, place, in which is no one to cheer by his company. (Ham p. 293.) ― -b4- The inside, or interior, of a house or tent; (K;) and of anything; of the dial. of Syria; also termed jaw~apN↓, (TA,) and jaw~aAniY~N↓; (K; [in the CK
A is erroneously put for n;]) in which last, the A and A^uriydu jaw~FA wayuriydu bar~FA are augmentatives for the purpose of corroboration. (TA.) ― -b5- [Hence,] jaw~apN I desire concealment, or secrecy, and he desires publicity. (A in art. br.)

jaw~apN jw jwh jwp
: see jaw~N, in two places.

jaw~aAniY~N jwAnY jwAny
: see jaw~N. Hence the saying of Selmán, mano A^aSolaHa jaw~aAniy~ahu A^aSolaHa A@ll~`hu bar~aAniy~ahu [explained in art. br]. (TA.) [It generally signifies Inner, inward, or interior; and secret, or private; opposed to bar~aAniY~N; and is now vulgarly pronounced juw~aAniYo.] It is a rel. n. [irregularly formed] from jaw~N signifying “ any low, or depressed, part of the ground. ” (T in art. br.)

1 yajuwo'u yj yjw'
is a dial. var. of yajiYo'u [aor. of jaA='a and meaning He comes, or will come]: (K:) mentioned by Sb, who gives as an ex. A^anaA A^ajuwow^uka waA^anobuw^uka [for AnA A^ajiyow^uka wA^anobaw^uka, I will come to thee and inform thee]. (TA.)

juwaAliqN jwAlq
and juwaAlaqN and jiwaAliqN: see art. jlq.

1 jaAbahu jAb jAbh jAbp
, (S, * TA,) aor. yajuwbu, (S, TA,) inf. n. jawobN (S, A, K, TA) and tajowaAbN, (Har p. 336,) He made a hole in it; or rent, or tore, it; (S, A, K, TA;) as also AjtAbhu↓: (K, * TA:) he made a hole through, or in, or into, it; perforated, pierced, or bored, it: (TA:) he cut it: (S, A, K, TA:) he cut it in like manner as one cuts a jayob [or an opening at the neck and bosom of a shirt &c.]: (L, TA:) he made, or cut, a hole in the middle of it; cut a piece out of the middle of it; hollowed it out; or excavated it. (TA.) You say, jAb AlS~axorapa He made a hole in the rock; (A, TA;) perforated, pierced, or bored, it. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [lxxxix. 8], wavamuwda Al~a*iyna jaAbuwA AlS~axora biAlwaAdi (Fr, S, TA) And Thamood, who made holes in the rocks, (Fr, TA,) or cut the rocks, (Bd, Jel,) [or hollowed them out,] and made them dwellings, in the valley, (Fr, Bd, Jel, TA,) i. e., in Wádi-l-Kurà. (Bd, Jel.) You say also, jAb AlqamiySa, (S, A, K,) aor. bajuwbu, [inf. n. jawobN;] (S, K, and Msb in art. jyb;) and aor. yajiybu, (S, K,) [inf. n., app., jiybN, originally jawobN; see a verse cited below, and a remark of Sh thereon;] and jw~bhu↓; (A, K;) He hollowed out, or cut out in a round form, the jayob of the shirt: (S, and Msb in art. jyb:) or he cut the jayob of the shirt: (A:) or he made a jayob to the shirt; (K;) as also jay~abahu, (S, and Msb in art. jyb,) inf. n. tajoyiybN. (S.) And jAb Alv~awoba He cut the garment, or piece of cloth; [or cut it out;] as also AjtAbhu↓. (A.) And jAb Aln~aEola, inf. n. jawobN, He cut out the sandal. (TA.) And jAb Alqaronu [i. e. jAb All~aHoma] The horn cut the flesh and came forth. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, also,] jAb, (S, A, Msb, TA,) aor. yajuwbu (S, Msb, TA) and yajiybu, (S, TA,) inf. n. jawobN; (TA;) and AjtAb↓; (S, A, TA;) (tropical:) He traversed, or crossed, (S, A, * Msb, TA,) or cut through by journeying, (TA,) a country, (S, TA,) or a land, (Msb,) and a desert, and the darkness: (A, * TA:) and jawobN signifies likewise the pouncing down of a bird. (TA.) A rájiz says,
baAtato tajiybu A^adoEaja AlZ~alaAmi
jiyba AlbiyaTori midoraEa AlhumaAmi
(assumed tropical:) [She passed the night cutting through the black darkness, like as the tailor cuts through the woollen tunic of the valiant chief, making the opening at the neck and bosom]: (S: [but in one copy, instead of jiyba, I here find jayoba; and in art. bTr, $aq~a:]) and Sh remarks that this [verb tjyb, or the inf. n. jyb,] is not from Aljayobu [meaning “ the opening at the neck and bosom ” of a shirt &c.], because its medial radical is w, and that of Aljyb is Y: (TA:) [i. e., jAb, aor. yjyb, is originally jawaba, aor. yajowibu.] One says also, of news, yajuwbu AlA^aroDa mino baladK A_ilaY baladK (assumed tropical:) [It traverses the earth from country to country, or the land from town to town]. (S, TA.) And of proverbs, tajuwbu AlbilaAda (assumed tropical:) They are current in the countries, or towns. (TA.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad., jiybati AlEarabu Ean~aA kamaA jiybati Alr~aHaA Eano quTobihaA (assumed tropical:) The Arabs were rent from us, like as the mill-stone is rent from its pivot; we being in the midst, and they around us. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jaAbati Ald~aEowapu: see A^ajowabu.

2 jw~b jwb
: see 1. ― -b2- Also, said of the light of the moon, (assumed tropical:) It illumined, and rendered clear, [by penetrating,] a dark night. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jw~b Ealayohi [from jawobN “ a shield ”] He shielded him. (TA: so accord. to an explanation of the act. part. n.)

3 jaAowaba
[jAwbhu, inf. n. mujaAwabapN, He returned him answer for answer, or answers for answers; held a dialogue, colloquy, conference, disputation, or debate, with him; bandied words with him.] See 6, in two places.

4 AjAbhu A^jAb A^jAbh A_jAbp AjAbh AjAbp jAbh
, (S, A, Msb, TA,) inf. n. A_ijaAbapN (S, Msb, K, * TA) and A_ijaAbN (K, * TA) and jaAbapN↓, (Kr, TA,) or this last is a simple subst., (AHeyth, S, TA,) like TaAEapN and TaAqapN, (S, A,) used in the place of an inf. n.; (AHeyth, TA;) and AstjAbhu↓ (A, K, TA) and Aisotajuwabahu↓ and lahu AistjAb↓; (K, TA;) [for] A_ijaAbapN and AisotijaAbapN↓ are syn.; (S, TA;) He answered him, replied to him, responded to him, (Msb, TA,) either affirmatively or negatively. (Msb.) And AjAb qawolahu He answered, or replied to, his saying. (Msb.) And AjAb Eano suw^aAlihi (S, TA) He answered, or replied to, his question. (TA.) And AjAb duEaA='ahu, (Msb, TA, *) and duEaA='ahu AstjAb↓, (S, A, TA,) and lahu AstjAb↓, (Msb,) and minohu AstjAb↓, (Har p. 307,) said of God, (S, A, Msb, TA,) [He answered his prayer;;] He accepted his prayer; (Msb;) He recompensed his prayer by gift and acceptance. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 182], A^ujiybu daEowpa Ald~aAEiY A_i*aA liY daEaAni faloyasotajiybuwA↓ [I answer the prayer of him who prayeth to me;] therefore let them answer me; (TA;) i. e., let them answer my call by obedience, (Jel,) when I call them to belief and obedience: (Bd:) accord. to Fr, what is here meant [by the last verb] is talobiyap [q. v. in art. lbY]: (TA:) [or let them give me their assent, or consent, to my call; or let them obey my call: for you say, AjAbhu A_ilaY $aYo'K and EalaY $aYo'K, (for the latter of which there is authority in this art. in the TA, but the former is more common,) and] lh AstjAb↓, He obeyed him, or complied with his desire, in doing a thing, [or consented to do it,] when summoned, or invited, to do it. (Msb.) ― -b2- AjAbt AlA^aroDu (assumed tropical:) The land produced plants, or herbage. (Ham p. 94.) ― -b3- damoEN yujiybu (assumed tropical:) Tears running, or flowing; as though called for and answering the call. (Har p. 71.) ＝ -A2- The forms A^ajowaba and A^ajowibo [as verbs of wonder] are not used: therefore you say, maA A^ajowada jawaAbahu and A^ajowido bijawaAbihi [How good is his answer, or reply!]; not maA A^ajowabahu nor A^ajowibo bihi: nor do you say, huwa A^ajowabu minoka [meaning He is better in answering, or replying, than thou: but see A^ajowabu, below]. (Sb, TA.)

6 tjAwbwA jAwb tjAwb tjAwbwA
i. q. baEoDuhumo baEoDFA jaAwaba↓ [They returned one another answer for answer, or answers for answers; they answered one another; replied, one to another; held a dialogue, colloquy, conference, disputation, or debate, together; bandied words, one with another]: (K:) mujaAwabapN↓ and tajaAwubN both signify i. q. taHaAwurN. (S, TA.) In like manner one says of turtle-doves, (A,) of pigeons, of braying camels, and of neighing horses. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] yatajaAwabu A^aw~alu kalaAmihi waA=xiruhu (tropical:) The first and the last parts of his speech correspond, or are consistent. (A, TA.)

7 AnjAb A^njAb A_njAb AnjAb {njAb
[It (a garment) became rent, or slit: see munojaAbN]. ― -b2- Said of a cloud, or a collection of clouds, It cleared away [so as to leave an open space]. (S, Msb.) It is said in a trad., waA@nojaAba Als~aHaAbu Eani Almadiynapi Hat~aY SaArakaAlA_i koliyli And the clouds became gathered and drawn together, and cleared away from the city [so that they became like a crown]. (TA.) ― -b3- [It (a place) was, or became, clear, open, or unobstructed.] See jawobapN ＝ -A2- AnjAbt She (a camel) stretched forth her neck, to be milked; (K;) as though she complied with the desire of her milker to be restrained [for that purpose]: but Fr says that he had not found a verb of this measure from A^ajaAba. (TA.)

8 AjtAb AjtAb
: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- He dug a well. (K.) And AjtAbt, said of a wild cow, She hollowed out, or excavated, a place to shelter herself from the rain. (TA.) ― -b3- He put on, i. e. clad himself with, (T, S, K,) a garment, (T,) or a shirt; (S, K;) he entered into a shirt: and in like manner, (assumed tropical:) the darkness. (TA.)

10 AstjAb 10 and Aisotajowaba
, inf. n. AisotijaAbapN: see 4, nine places.

jaAbN j*Ab
: see jaA^ubN, in art. jA^b

jawobN jwb
[an inf. n. (of 1, q. v.,) used in the sense of a pass. part. n. Hence,] a tribe is said to be jawobu A^abK as meaning Cut [as it were] from one
father; [sprung from the loins of one father;] occurring in a trad. (TA.) ― -b2- A fire-place; [so called because hollowed out;] syn. kaAnuwnN. (K.) ― -b3- A large dalow [or bucket; because of its hollow form]. (Kr, K.) ― -b4- A shield; (S, K;) as also jawobapN↓ (TA) and mijowabN↓: (K:) [see a verse cited voce yalabN:] pl. of the first A^ajowaAbN. (TA.) ― -b5- A garment like the baqiyrap: [so called because it has a slit in the middle, through which the head is put:] (S:) or a woman's shift. (K.) ― -b6- See also jawobapN ＝ -A2- [A kind, or sort.] You say, fulaAnN fiyhi jawobaAni mino xuluqK [In such a one are two kinds of temper, or disposition]; i. e., he does not remain in one temper, or disposition. (TA.) And Dhu-Rummeh says,
jawobayoni mino hamaAhimi AlA^agowaAli
meaning Thou hearest two kinds of the sounds, or voices, [or mutterings,] of the ghools. (TA.)

jayobN jyb
meaning The [part called] Tawoq of a shirt, (see art. jyb,) is, accord. to some, from the root jwb, because the middle of it is cut out: accord. to others, from the root jyb. (TA.)

jaAbapN jAb jAbh jAbp
is an inf. n. of A^ajaAba, (Kr, TA,) or a simple subst. (A Heyth, S, TA) used in the place of an inf. n. (A Heyth, TA. See 4.) Hence, A^asaA='a samoEFA faA^asaA='a jaAbapF [He heard ill, and therefore answered ill]: (S, A, K:) a prov., and therefore not to be rehearsed otherwise than in the original way, as above: [not to be altered by the substitution of A_ijaAbapN or A_ijaAbFA for jaAbapF:] its origin is said to have been this: Sahl [or Suheyl] Ibn-' Amr had an insane son; and a man said to him, A^ayona A^am~uka, i. e. “ Whither is thy tending? ” to which he (thinking that he said, A^ayona A^um~uka [“ Where is thy mother! ”],) answered, “ She is gone to buy flour: ” whereupon his father uttered the words of this prov. (TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 603.]) See also jawaAbN ＝ -A2- jaAbapu AlmidoraY is a dial. var. of jaA^obapu AlmdrY: (K: [see art. jA^b:]) accord. to AO and Sh, it is without ': accord. to the former, it means A doe-gazelle when her horn has come forth; and accord. to the latter, when her horn has cut the skin and come forth: (T, TA:) or it means having smooth horns; and if so, it has no [known] derivation. (TA.) [See also art. drY.]

jawobapN jwb jwbh jwbp
A depressed place amid the houses of a people, into which the rain-water flows: (TA:) a pit, an excavation, or a hollow, (T, K, TA,) round and wide: (T, TA:) a gap, or an opening, in the clouds; and in mountains: and a clear space (mawoDiEN yanojaAbu↓) in a [stony tract such as is called] Har~ap: (S:) a place (AHn, K) that is clear, (AHn,) plain and smooth, (AHn, K,) such as is termed daArapN, with few trees, like a round gaAy^T [or wide and depressed tract], (AHn,) in a tract that is hard, or hard and level, or level but rough, (AHn, K,) and such as is of large extent, not in sands nor in a mountain; so called because [for the most part] clear of trees: (AHn:) and an intervening space between houses; (K;) as also jawobN↓: (TA:) and a wide, or spacious, and smooth tract, between two lands: (K:) any wide gap, or opening: any gap, or opening, without buildings: (TA:) pl. juwabN (S, K) and jawobaAtN (TA.) ― -b2- The former of these pls. also signifies The pudenda of women; syn. furuwjN. (TA.) ― -b3- See also jawobN

jiybapN jyb jybh jybp
i. q. jawaAbN, q. v. (S, K.) So in the phrase, A_in~ahu laHasanu Aljiyabpi [Verily he is good in respect of answer or reply or response: or here it seems rather to signify, agreeably with analogy, the mode, or manner, of answering or replying or responding]. (S.)

jawaAbN jAbyp jwAb
An answer, a reply, or a response, (Msb, TA, *) to a letter, or writing, and to a saying, or question; and this is either affirmative or negative: (Msb:) [accord. to some, it is only after a question or demand; but this is not correct; for it is often a reply to an affirmation:] jiybapN↓ [q. v.] is syn. therewith; (S, K;) and so are jaAbapN↓ [q. v.] and majuwbapN↓: (K:) the pl. of jwAb is A^ajowibapN and jawaAbaAtN (Msb.) [Hence, in grammar, Harofu jawaAbK A responsive, or replicative, particle. And jawaAbu $aroTK An apodosis; the complement, or correlative, of a condition; as A^akoramotuka in the saying, A_ino jiy^otaniY A^akoramotuka; also called jazaA='u $aroTK, and jawaAbu jazaA='K. And jawaAbu qasamK The complement of an oath.] ― -b2- Also The sound of a bird pouncing down from the sky. (TA from a trad.)

jaw~aAbN jAbyp jwAb
[An excellent well-digger:] a surname given to Málik Ibn-Kaab El-Kilábee, (AO, ISk, S, K, *) because he dug not a well nor bored a rock without making it to yield water. (AO, ISk, S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A traverser of countries; one who travels much. (TA.) Hence, jaw~aAbu layolK saromadK (assumed tropical:) One who travels all the night without sleeping. (TA.) And jaw~aAbN jaA^~bN (assumed tropical:) One who traverses the countries and gains wealth. (TA.) And jaw~aAbu AlfalaApi (assumed tropical:) The guide of the desert. (TA.)

AljaAy^ibu AlEayoni *
The lion. (K.)

jaAy^ibapu xabarK *
(tropical:) News that traverses the earth, from country to country, or town to town: (S, A: *) or i. q. Tariyqap xaAriqap [app. a mistranscription for Tiriyfap xArqp, meaning recent news that traverses the land]. (K.) And [the pl.] jawaAy^ibu (assumed tropical:) Tidings from afar. (K.) And jawaAy^ibu AlA^amovaAli (assumed tropical:) Current proverbs; such as traverse the countries. (TA.)

A^ajowabu *
, [see 4,] in the following question, put to Mohammad, (TA,) A^aY~uAll~ayoli A^ajowabu daEowapF is either from jubotu AlA^aroDa (K, TA) “ I traversed the land, ” (TA,) and signifies (tropical:) More, or most, penetrating to the places whence the answer is imagined to proceed; (K, TA;) or [it signifies more, or most, quick in being answered,] from Ald~aEowapu jaAbati↓, of the measure faEulat, [i. e., originally jawubat,] “ the prayer became answered, ” which, however, is a verb not in use, like as faqiyrN and $adiydN are imagined to be derived from faqura and $aduda: (Z, TA:) or it signifies more, or most, quick of answer, [from A^ajaAba,] and is [anomalous, and] similar to A^aTowaEu [“ more obedient ”], from AlT~aAEapu, [i. e. from A^aTaAEa “ he obeyed, ”] (M, L, TA,) and to A^aEoTaY [“ more, or most, excellent in giving, ” from A^aEoTaY “ he gave ”], and lawaAqiHa [pl. of laAqiHapN a “ fecundating ” wind, (in the Kur xv. 22,) from A^aloqaHa “ he, or it, fecundated ”], (M, L, K, TA,) and the like; (M, L, TA;) and if so, the word is anomalous because a word of the measure A^afoEalu of this kind is not derived from a verb of more than three letters, except in certain cases of deviation from the constant course of speech: (L, TA:) the meaning is, (tropical:) What part of the night is that [in which prayer most quickly penetrates? or] in which prayer is most quick in being answered? (Mgh:) or what part of the night is that in which God is most quick in answering prayer? (L, TA.)

majuwbu mjwb
[pass. part. n. of 1, q. v.:] Anything cut in the middle, or of which the middle is cut out; as also mujaw~abN↓; (T, TA;) and the latter, anything hollowed out in the middle. (TA.)

mijowabN mjwb
An iron instrument with which one cuts [or perforates or hollows out]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- See also jawobN

Almujiybu Almjyb mjyb
one of the names of God; The Answerer of prayer; He who recompenses prayer and petition by gift and acceptance. (TA.)

majuwbapN mjwbh mjwbp
: see jawaAbN

mujaw~abN mjwb
: see majuwbN ― -b2- [Hence,] A^aroDN mujaw~abapN (assumed tropical:) A land of which one part has been rained upon (K, TA) and not another. (TA.)

mijowaAbN mjwAb
An instrument with which palm-sticks and canes &c. are bored by the maker of cages or crates or the like. (TA in art. vTb.)

mutajaAwibN mtjAwb
(tropical:) Speech, or language, of which the several parts correspond, or are consistent. (A, TA.)

munojaAbN mnjAb
A garment rent, or slit. (Ham p. 338.)

1 jaAHa jAH
, (S, A,) aor. yajuwHu, (S,) inf. n. jawoHN, (S, K,) He (a man, S) extirpated, or exterminated, (S, A, K,) a thing: (S:) He (God, S) destroyed (S, A, K) a man's property, or cattle, (S,) by what is termed jaAy^iHap: (S, A:) as also AjAH↓, (S, A,) inf. n. A_ijaAHapN; (K;) and AjtAH↓, (S,) inf. n. AijotiyaAHN. (K.) You say [also], jaAHiti AlA=fapu AlmaAla, i. e. AljaAy^iHapu, aor. tajuwHuhu, inf. n. as above; and AjAHthu↓; and AjtAHthu↓; The bane, or pest, or the like, destroyed the property, or cattle; as also jaAHatohu, aor. tajiyHuhu, inf. n. jiyaAHapN: (Msb:) and one says of anything, such as drought, or dearth, and civil war, or conflict and faction, &c., jAH AlmaAla and AjtAHhu↓, meaning it extirpated, or exterminated, the property, or cattle. (TA.) And jaAHatohumu AljaAy^iHapu, (S,) or Als~anapu, inf. n. jawoHN and jiyaAHN; and A^ajaAHatohumo↓; (TA;) and AijotaAHatohumo↓; (S, A, TA;) i. e. [The calamity, bane, pest, or the like, or drought, or dearth, destroyed or] extirpated [them, or] their property, or cattle.
(TA.) And AlEaduw~u maAlahu AjtAH↓ The enemy destroyed, or made an end of, his property, or cattle; syn. A^ataY Ealayohi. (TA.) ― -b2- Also jAH, aor. yajuwHu, inf. n. jawoHN, He destroyed the property, or cattle, of his relations. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A2- And, aor. yajuwHu, He deviated from the road, or beaten track. (IAar, K.)

4 A^ajowaHa
see 1, in three places.

8 A_ijotawaHa
see 1, in five places.

jawoHapN jwHh jwHp
: see jaAy^iHapN.

jaAy^iHN *
[act. part. n. of 1]. You say A=fapN jaAy^iHapN A destructive bane or pest or the like: (Msb:) and sanapN jaAy^iHapN a year of drought or dearth or sterility: (Mgh:) pl. jawaAy^iHu. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence,] The locust. (IAar, T in art. jHY.)

jaAy^iHapN *
[fem. of jaAy^iHN, q. v.: and hence, as a subst.,] A bane, a pest, (Msb,) a calamity, or the like, (S, Msb, K,) or a great calamity, (Mgh, TA,) that destroys, or extirpates, men's property, or cattle; (S, Mgh, Msb, * K, TA;) as drought, or dearth; or civil war, or conflict and faction, and the like: (S, TA:) drought, or dearth, that destroys, or extirpates, men's property, or cattle; as also jawoHapN↓: (Wásil, TA:) or a calamity that befalls a man, and destroys all his property, or cattle: (A'Obeyd, T:) or severe drought or dearth, that destroys, or extirpates, men's property, or cattle: (ISh:) sometimes it is the effect of large hail; and sometimes, of excessive cold or heat: (T:) or (accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee, Mgh, Msb) a blast, or blight, or calamity arising from the atmosphere, that destroys the fruits, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) or some thereof; (Mgh;) only relating to fruits: (TA:) pl. jawaAy^iHu. (A, Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a trad., A^amara biwaDoEi AljawaAy^iHi, which is an elliptical phrase, meaning He commanded to remit the poor-rate in respect of things affected by a blast, or blight, (Mgh, Msb,) namely, property, (Mgh,) or fruits, (Msb,) so affected; (Mgh, Msb;) i. e., that no portion thereof, (Mgh,) or of the remains thereof, (Msb,) should be taken for the poor-rate. (Mgh, Msb.)

mujaAHN mjAH
: see what next follows.

majuwHN mjwH
Property, or cattle, destroyed by a bane, or pest, or the like; as also majiyHN [belonging to art. jyH], and mujaAHN↓. (Msb.)

mijowaHN mjwH
[A person or thing] that destroys, or extirpates, everything. (K, TA.)

1 jaAda jAd
, aor. yajuwdu, inf. n. juwdapN and jawodapN, It (a thing, S, or a commodity, an article of household-goods, or the like, Msb, and a work, or performance, TA) was, or became, jay~id [i. e. good, goodly, approvable, or excellent; the verb being the contr. of raduw^a, as is implied in the A and K]: (S, A, Msb, K:) in this sense, accord. to some, of the class of qaAla; accord. to others, of the class of qaruba. (Msb.) [Also said of a man, meaning He was, or became, excellent, or egregious, in some quality; sometimes, though very rarely, in a quality that is disapproved.] ― -b2- And jAd, (S, A, Msb, K,) of the class of qAl, (Msb,) aor. as above, (S, Msb,) inf. n. juwdN, (S, A, Msb, K,) with damm, (S, Msb,) He was liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous: (K:) or he affected, or constrained himself, to be generous: (Msb:) or he gave without being asked, to preserve the receiver from the ignominy of asking: (MF:) or he gave what was meet to him to whom it was meet: (El-Karmánee, TA:) or he gave what was meet to him to whom it was meet, not for a compensation; so that it has a more special signification than A^aHosana. (MF.) You say, jAd bimaAlihi [He was liberal, &c., with his property]: (S:) or jAd biAlmaAli he affected, or constrained himself, to be generous with the property. (Msb.) ― -b3- Hence, (Msb,) jAd binafosihi, (S, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S, A,) inf. n. jawodN (TA) and juw^uwdN, (S, TA,) (tropical:) He gave up his spirit, (A, Msb, TA,) at death; (S, Msb;) like as one gives away his property; said of one in the agony of death: (TA:) and (tropical:) he gave away his life, in war. (Msb.) And you say also, jaAdato nafosuhu (assumed tropical:) [His soul, or spirit, resigned itself, or departed]. (Msb in art. nfs.) ― -b4- jAd AlmaTaru, inf. n. jawodN, The rain was, or became, copious, or abundant. (S.) And jaAdati Als~amaA='u, (A, Msb,) inf. n. jawodN, with fet-h, The sky rained. (Msb.) And jaAdati AlEayonu, inf. n. jawodN and juw^uwdN, The eye shed many, or abundant, tears. (Lh, K.) ― -b5- jAd said of a horse, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S,) inf. n. juwdapN (S, L, Msb, K) and jawodapN; (Msb, and some copies of the K;) and jwd↓, (A, L, K,) inf. n. tajowiydN; (TA;) and AjAd↓, (L,) and A^ajowada↓; (L, K;) He became fleet, or swift, and excellent, (L,) SaAra raAy^iEFA, (S, L, K, *) fiY Eadowihi in his running. (A, L, K.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce daAma, in art. dwm.] ― -b6- See also 4, in two places. ― -b7- jAd A_ilayohi He inclined to him, or it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jAdhu He overcame him in liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity. (K.) See 3. ― -b2- jaAdahumo, aor. yajuwdu, inf. n. jawodN, It (rain) rained, or descended, upon them copiously, or abundantly. (L.) And jiyduwA They were rained upon with a copious, or an abundant, rain. (L.) And jiydati AlA^aroDu, (S, L, K,) inf. n. jawodN; (As, TA;) and A^ujiydat↓; (K;) The earth, or land, was rained upon with a copious, or an abundant, rain: (S, L, K:) or, so that the moisture of the rain met that of the soil. (As, TA.) ― -b3- jiyda, (S, A, K,) aor. yujaAdu, (S, K,) inf. n. juwaAdN, (S, * K, * TA,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, S, A) thirsted, or became affected by thirst: (S, A, K:) or thirsted vehemently: (accord. to an explanation of juwaAdN in the K:) or was at the point of death, or destruction; (K;) as though destruction rained upon him. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] A_in~iY A^ujaAdu A_ilaYliqaAy^ika (tropical:) Verily I am affected with a longing desire to meet thee: (A:) or A_in~iY laA^ujaAdu A_ilayoka (K, TA [in the CK, erroneously, laAajAdu] (tropical:) Verily I am affected with a longing desire for thee, (K, TA,) i. e., to meet thee, (TA,) and am impelled towards thee: (K:) and yujaAduA_ilaY fulaAnapa (tropical:) He is affected with longing desire for such a female; like as you say yaZomaA^u. (A.) One says also, jAdhu AlahawY (tropical:) Love affected him with longing desire, ($aAqahu, L, K, in the CK $Aq~ahu,) and overcame him. (K.) ― -b5- [Also, app., jyda, aor. yujaAdu, inf. n. juwaAdN, (as in a sense explained above,) (assumed tropical:) He became affected, or overcome, or distressed, (see majuwdN,) by drowsiness, or slumber: for] juwaAdN is syn. with nuEaAsN: (L, TA:) and you say, jAdhu Aln~uEaAsu (assumed tropical:) Drowsiness, or slumber, overcame him; (L;) as though sleep rained upon him. (TA.)

2 jaw~ada
see 4: ― -b2- and see also 1.

3 jAwdhu jAwdh jAwdp
He vied with him, or contended with him for superiority, in liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity. (S, TA.) You say, jAwdhu fajaAdahu↓ He vied with him, or contended &c., in liberality, &c., and overcame him therein. (TA.)

4 AjAdhu A^jAd A^jAdh A_jAdp AjAdh AjAdp
He made it good, goodly, approvable, or excellent; (S, A, * K;) as also A^ajowadahu, (S, * K,) like as they said ATAl and ATwl, and AHAl and AHwl, and ATAb and ATyb, and AlAn and Alyn; (S;) and jw~dhu↓, (S, * A,) inf. n. tajowiydN. (S.) [Hence,] AjAdhu Aln~aqoda He gave him the cash, or ready money, good. (S, K.) And A^ajadotuka vawobFA I gave thee a garment, or piece of cloth, that was good, goodly, or excellent; or in a good state. (A, TA.) ― -b2- He gave him a dirhem, or piece of silver. (K.) ― -b3- A^ujiydati AlA^aroDu: see 1. ＝ -A2- He, or it, slew him, or killed him. (L.) ＝ -A3- AjAd, (inf. n. A_ijaAdapN, Msb,) He said, gave utterance to, uttered, or expressed, what was good, approvable, or excellent; he said, or did, well, or excellently; A^ataY biAljay~idi (L, Msb, K) mino qawoli A^awo fiEolK; (Msb;) as also A^ajowada; (L;) and jAd↓, inf. n. jawodapN. (L.) [You say, qaAla faA^ajaAda He said, and said well: and faEala faA^ajaAda He did, and did well.] And AjAd fiY Eamalihi, and Ajwd, He did well, or excellently, in his work. (L.) ― -b2- Said of a horse, and Ajwd likewise: see 1. ― -b3- Also He had with him a horse such as is termed jawaAd [i. e. fleet, or swift, and excellent]: (S:) or he became possessed of such a horse; (A, K;) as also Ajwd. (K.) ― -b4- A^ajaAdato She brought forth a child, or children, of liberal, bountiful, or generous, disposition. (A.) And AjAd biAlwaladi He begot the child, or children, of liberal, bountiful, or generous, disposition; (K;) and in like manner, bihi A^abawaAhu jAd↓ [His two parents so engendered him]. (TA.)

5 tjw~d jAd tjwd
He chose what was good, goodly, approvable, or excellent, among all things. (Ham p. 299.) He affected nicety, or refinement; he was, or became, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice and exact; or he chose what was excellent, or best, to be done; and exceeded the usual bounds; fiY SanoEatihi in his work of art, or his manufacture; syn. tanaw~aqa. (A, TA.) And tjw~d wabaAlaga fiY maToEamihi wamalobasihi [He was dainty, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice and exact; or he chose what was excellent, or best; and exceeded the usual bounds; in his food and his
apparel]; (JK and K in art. nwq;) he was studious of his diet and apparel, always eating exquisite food and wearing sumptuous clothing. (TK in that art.) ＝ -A2- tjw~dhu: see 10. tajaw~adotuhaA laka I chose, or selected, the best, or most excellent, (AlA^ajowada↓,) thereof for thee. (TA.)

6 tjAwdwA tjAwdwA
They considered [or tried] which of them had the best argument, or plea, or allegation: (K, TA:) so says Aboo-Sa'eed on the authority of an Arab of the desert. (TA.) And yatajaAwaduwna AlHadiyva They consider, or see, [or try,] which of them will be best in narration, or talk, or discourse. (A.) ― -b2- [Also They vied, or contended together for superiority, in liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity.]

10 AstjAdhu AstjAdh AstjAdp {stjAd {stjAdh
He reckoned it, or esteemed it, good, goodly, approvable, or excellent: (S:) or he found it to be so: (K:) or he desired, or sought, that it might be so, (A, K,) and chose it, or selected it; (A;) as also tjw~dhu↓. (A.) You say also, Aisotajowada raA^oyahu [He esteemed his judgment, or opinion, good: or found it to be so]. (TA in art. jzl.) ― -b2- He desired, or sought, or demanded, his liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity. (K.) ― -b3- He desired, or sought, that he (a horse) might be such as is termed jawaAd [i. e. fleet, or swift, and excellent]. (K.) ＝ -A2- AstjAd It came or happened, well. (KL.)

jawodN jwd
Copious, or abundant, rain; (S, L, K;) as also jaAy^idN↓: (S:) or rain that thoroughly irrigates everything: (M:) or rain that is not exceeded: (M, L, K:) accord. to some, who observe that the phrase, mentioned by Sb, A^axa*otanaA biAljawodiwafawoqhaA [Thou hast assailed us with a storm of reproach or the like not to be exceeded, and with that which is above it,] is one of hyperbole and reproach. (M, L.) It is an inf. n. thus used as an epithet [and therefore applicable without variation to a fem. as to a masc. n., and to a dual and a pl. as to a sing. n.]: (L:) and is also pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of jaAy^idN, (S, L, K,) like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN. (S, L.) You say maTarN jawodN [A copious, or an abundant, rain; &c.]: (L:) and saHaAbapN jawodN [A cloud yielding a copious, or an abundant, rain; &c.]: (IAar, L:) and haAjato lanaA samaA='N jawodN [A copious, or an abundant, rain, &c., became stirred up for us]: (S, K: *) and you also say, [contr. to the usage mentioned above, or as though jawodN were an epithet from jaAda, and this originally jawoda, like DaxomN from Daxuma, but used as a subst.,] maTorataAni jawodaAni [Two showers of rain, copious, or abundant, &c.]. (S, K.) tajaAwiydu↓, [app. signifying the same as jawodN used as a pl.,] occurring in the following verse of Sakhr El-Ghei,
yulaAEibu Alr~iyHa biAlEaSorayoni qaSoTaluhu
waAlwaAbiluwna watahotaAnu Alt~ajaAwiydi
[Its dust makes sport with the wind in the morning and evening, or night and day, and so do the violent showers of big drops, and the pouring of copious, or abundant, rains, &c.], (L, K, *) is a pl. having no sing.; (K;) or it may be so, like taEaAjiybu and taEaA$iybu and tabaA$iyru; or it may be pl. of tajowaAdN [an inf. n.]. (L.) You say also, AmaTari A^aSaAbatohu tajaAwiydu↓ [Copious showers of rain fell upon him, or it]. (A.) ― -b2- See also jawaAdN.

jawodapN jwdh jwdp
[an inf. n. of 1, (q. v.,) in two senses; as also juwdapN: and an inf. n. of un., signifying] A single affection of thirst; a thirsting. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also juwaAdN.

jaAdiY~N jAd jAdY jAdy jAdyy
Saffron. (S, K.)

jawaAdN jwAd
, used alike as masc. and fem., (S, K,) Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous: (S, * K:) or one who affects, or constrains himself, to be generous: (Msb:) or who gives without being asked, to preserve the receiver from the ignominy of asking: (MF:) or who gives what is meet to him to whom it is meet: (El-Karmánee, TA:) or who gives what is meet to him to whom it is meet, not for a compensation; so that it has a more special signification than muHosinN: (MF:) pl. [of pauc., masc.,] A^ajowaAdN and (of mult., TA) juwodN, (S, A, K,) like as qu*ulN is pl. of qa*aAlN, but the w is made quiescent because it is an unsound letter, (S,) [in some copies of the K juwudN,] and A^ajaAwidu, (S, K,) contr. to analogy, (TA,) or A^ajaAwiydu, [reg., as pl. of A^ajowaAdN,] (A,) and juwadaA='u (S, K) and juwadapN, (CK, [in some copies of the K omitted,]) or juwodapN, or juwudapN, [written in the latter manner in a MS. copy of the K,] with p added to the [proper] pl. form [juwodN or juwudN], accord. to the doctrine of Sb: (TA:) juwodN is used as a fem. pl., (S, Msb,) and is like nuworN pl. of nawaArN. (S.) ― -b2- Also, applied alike to the male and the female, (S,) A courser; a fleet, or swift, and excellent, horse; (L;) a horse fleet, or swift, in running; or excellent in running, or in the motion of his legs; as also jawodN↓: (Bd in xxxviii. 30:) or that outstrips others: (Jel ib.:) i. q. raAy^iEN: (S, L, K:) pl. jiyaAdN, (S, A, Bd, L, Msb, K,) which by rule should be jiwaAdN, like TiwaAlN, but this latter form has not been heard from the Arabs; (L;) or jiyaAdN is pl. of jawodN, or of jay~idN; (Bd ubi suprá;) and jawaAdN has also for its pl. A^ajoyaAdN, [a pl. of pauc., and irregular, or this is pl. of jay~dN, and therefore, though irregularly, retains the Y substituted for w] (S, L,) and A^ajowaAdN, [also a pl. of pauc., but agreeable with rule, or this is pl. of jawodN,] (L,) and A^ajaAwiydu (S, L) is pl. of A^ajowaAdN. (L.) Hence, A^aqobala jawaAdFA (assumed tropical:) He came on, or advanced, like a horse that is termed jwAd: and sirotu A_ilayohi jawaAdFA (assumed tropical:) I went to him, or it, like a horse that is so termed. (Mgh in art. g*.) You say also, EadaA EadowFA jawaAdFA He ran a long run. (A, TA.) And sironaA EuqobapF jawaAdFA, and Euqobatayoni jawaAdayoni, and EuqabFA jiyaAdFA (S, A) and A^ajowaAdFA, (A, TA,) We journeyed a long march or stage, and two long marches or stages, and long marches or stages. (S, A, TA.)

juwaAdN jwAd
[accord. to the TA inf. n. of jiyda, which see in two places,] (assumed tropical:) Thirst: (S, K:) or vehemence of thirst. (K.) ― -b2- Also, [accord. to the K jawodapN↓, but this is corrected in the TA,] (assumed tropical:) Drowsiness, or slumber. (TA.)

jaAy^idN *
: see jawodN.

jay~idN jyd
, originally of the measure fayoEilN, (S, Msb,) as the Basrees say, i. e. jayowidN, (Msb, TA,) the w being changed into Y because of its being meksoor and preceded by Y, and the augmentative Y being then incorporated into it; (TA;) or, as the Koofees say, of the measure fayoEalN, like EayoTalN &c., because there is found no sound word of the measure fayoEilN except SayoqilN, a woman's name, and the unsound is accorded to the sound; or, as others say, of the measure faEiylN, [and so I find in one copy of the S,] originally jawiydN, the kesreh of the w being, accord. to them, suppressed because difficult of pronunciation, and the quiescent w and Y thus coming together, [the latter receives the rejected kesreh, and] the w is changed into Y and incorporated into the [augmentative] Y; (Msb;) Good, goodly, approvable, or excellent; contr. of radi Yo; (A, K;) applied to a thing, (S,) or a commodity, an article of household-goods, or the like, (A, Msb,) and a work, or performance: (TA:) pl. jiyaAdN (S, A, Msb, K) and jiyaAdaAtN, (K,) the latter a pl. pl., [i. e. pl. of jiyaAdN,] (TA,) and jayaAy^idu, (S, K,) with hemz, [and, accord. to some,] contr. to analogy. (S.) [It is also applied to a man, meaning Excellent, or egregious, in some quality; sometimes, though very rarely, in a quality that is disapproved.]

A^ajowadu *
[Better, and best; more, and most, goodly or approvable or excellent]: see 5. ― -b2- [More, and most, liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous. Hence,] A^ajowadu mino HaAtimK [More liberal, &c., than Hátim]: a prov. (Meyd.) ― -b3- [More, and most, fleet, or swift, and excellent; relating to a horse. Hence,] A^ajowadu mina AljawaAdi Almubir~i [More fleet, &c., than the courser that surpasses others]: a prov. (Meyd.)

tajaAwydu tjAwyd
: see jawodN, in two places.

majuwdN mjwd
A field, or garden, rained upon: (A:) [or rained upon copiously, or abundantly.] And A^aroDN majowdapN Land rained upon with a copious, or an abundant, rain. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A man (S, A) affected with thirst: (S, A, K:) [or, with vehement thirst: (see juwaAdN:)] or at the point of death, or destruction. (K.) ― -b3- And [hence,] (tropical:) Affected with longing desire. (L.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) Overcome by drowsiness, or slumber: (TA:) or distressed by drowsiness, or slumber, &c. (Lh, L.)

mujiydN mjyd
: see mijowaAdN. ― -b2- Also A man possessing a horse such as is termed jawaAdi [i. e. fleet, or swift, and excellent]: pl. majaAwiydu [by rule pl. of mijowaAdN, q. v.]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- HatofN mujiydN (tropical:) Present death. (K, TA.)

mijowaAdN mjwAd
One who says, utters, or expresses, or who does, (K, TA,) much, or often, (TA,) what is good, goodly, approvable, or excellent; (K, TA;) as also mujiydN↓: (TA:) [or rather the latter is a simple, not an intensive, epithet:] the former is applied to a poet, (S, A, K,) as syn. with the latter, (K,) or as meaning who says, or utters, much, or often, what is good, or excellent:
(S:) and both are applied to a workman, or an artificer: pl. of the former majaAwiydu. (A.)

juw*aAbN *
: see art. j*b.

1 jaAra jAr jAry
, aor. yajuwru, (TA,) inf. n. jaworN, (S, A, K,) He declined, or deviated, from the right course; (S, A;) and so jArEani AlqaSodi: (A:) he wandered from the right way: (TA:) he pursued a wrong course: (K:) or he left the right way in journeying: and it (anything) declined. (TA.) You say also, jAr Eani AlT~iriyqi He declined, or deviated, from the road, or way. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- And jAr, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n., (Mgh, Msb, K,) He acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, (S, * Mgh, Msb, K,) Ealayohi against him, (S, TA,) fiY Hukomihi in his judgment, (Msb,) or fiY AlHukomi in judgment. (S, TA.) ― -b3- jArti AlA^aroDu (tropical:) The plants, or herbage, of the land grew tall: (A, TA:) and so jaA^arat. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 10.

2 jw~rhu jwr jwrh jwrp
, (S, A, K,) inf. n. tajowiyrN, (S,) He attributed, or imputed, to him, or charged him with, or accused him of, wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, conduct; (S, K;) contr. of Ead~alahu. (A.) ＝ -A2- He prostrated him (S, K) by a blow, (S,) or by a thrust of a spear or the like; from jAr “he, or it, declined;”; (A;) like kaw~arahu. (S.) ― -b2- He threw it down, (TA,) and overturned it; (K, TA;) namely, a building, and a tent, &c.: (TA:) he took it to pieces; namely, a tent. (A.)

3 jAwirhu jAwrh jAwrp
, inf. n. mujaAwarapN and jiwaArN (S, Msb, K) and juwaArN↓, (S, M, and some copies of the K,) or the last is a simple subst., (Msb,) and jawaArN↓, (M, and so in some copies of the K instead of juwaArN,) of which forms the second (jiwaArN) is more chaste than the third (S, TA) and than the fourth, as relating to the verb in the sense here following, though some disapprove of it, and assert the third and the fourth to be more chaste; (TA;) He became his jAr [or neighbour]; (K;) he lived in his neighbourhood, or near to him: (Msb, TA:) or he lived in a dwelling contiguous to his. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also jAwrhu, (TA,) inf. n. jiwaArN, (K,) and juwaArN↓ is said to be a quasi-inf. n., and more chaste than jiwaArN as relating to the verb in the sense here following; (TA;) He bound himself to him by a covenant to protect him. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And jAwr ban~Y fulaAnK, and fiY bnY flAn, inf. n. majaAwarapN and jiwaArN, He protected himself by a covenant with the sons of such a one; from mujaAwarapN signifying the “ living near. ” (TA.) ― -b4- And jAwr, inf. n. mujaAwarapN, i. q. AiEotakafa fiY masojidK [He confined himself in a mosque, or place of worship, during a period of days and nights, or at least during one whole day, fasting from daybreak to sunset, and occupying himself in prayer and religious meditation, without any interruption by affairs distracting the mind from devotion and not pressing]. (S, K.) But jAwr bimak~apa, and biAlmadiynapi, signifies absolutely He abode in Mekkeh, and El-Medeeneh; not necessarily implying conformity with the conditions of AiEotikaAf required by the law [though generally meaning for the purpose of study: and so in the neighbourhood of the great collegiate mosque called the Azhar, in Cairo: so that the term mujaAwirN↓ means a student of Mekkeh &c.]. (TA.)

4 AjArhu A^jAr A^jArh A^jArp A_jArp AjArh AjArp jArY
, (S, A, &c.,) inf. n. A_ijaArapN (Mgh, K) and jaArapN↓, (Kr, K,) [or the latter is rather a quasi-inf. n., like TaAEapN from A^aTaAEahu,] He protected him; granted him refuge; (K;) preserved, saved, rescued, or liberated, him; (S, A, Msb, K;) from (mino) wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, treatment; (S, K;) from punishment; (S, A;) or from what he feared: (Msb:) he aided him; succoured him; delivered him from evil: the A^a having a privative effect. (Mgh.) It is said of God, yujiyru walaA yujaAru Ealayohi He protects, but none is protected against him. (TA.) And in the Kur [lxxii. 22], qulo A_in~iY lano yujiyraniY mina A@ll~`hi A^aHadN Verily none will protect me against God. (TA.) ― -b2- AjAr AlmataAEa He put the household-goods, or commodities, into the repository, (K, TA,) and so preserved them from being lost. (TA.) ― -b3- It is said [of God] in a trad., yujiyru bayona AlbuHuwri He makes a division between the seas, and prevents one from mixing with another and encroaching upon it. (TA.)

5 tjw~r jAr tjwr
He became prostrated; (S;) he fell down; (K;) by reason of a blow. (S, TA.) ― -b2- It (a building, TA) became thrown down, or demolished. (K.) ― -b3- He (a man, TA) laid himself down on his side (K) upon his bed. (TA.)

6 tajaAwaruwA jAwr tjAwr tjAwrwA
and AijotawaruwA↓ (S, K) are syn., (S,) signifying They became mutual neighbours; they lived near together: (K, * TA:) the [radical] w in the latter verb remaining unaltered because this verb is syn. with one in which the w must preserve its original form on account of the quiescence of the preceding letter, namely, tjAwrwA, (S, TA,) and to show that it is syn. therewith: but AijotaAruwA also occurs. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also They bound themselves by a covenant to protect one another.]

8 A_ijotawara
see 6.

10 AstjAr AstjAr {stjAr
and jaAra↓, (K,) the latter like jaArN as syn. with musotajiyrN, (TA,) He sought, desired, or asked, to be protected; to be granted refuge; to be preserved, saved, rescued, or liberated. (K.) And AstjArhu He desired him, or asked him, to preserve, save, rescue, or deliver, him, (S, A, Msb,) mino fulaAnK from such a one. (S.) And AstjAr bihi He had recourse to him for refuge, protection, or preservation; he sought his protection. (TA.)

jaArN jAr jAry
A neighbour; one who lives near to another; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) one who lives in the next tent or house: (IAar, Th, T, Msb:) pl. [of mult.] jiyraAnN (Msb, K) [and jiwaArN (a pl. not of unfrequent occurrence, and mentioned by Freytag as used by El-Mutanebbee,)] and [of pauc.] jiyrapN and A^ajowaArN; (K;) like qaAEN, pl. qiyEaAnN and qiyEapN and A^aqowaAEN, the only similar instance: (TA:) fem. with p. (Mgh.) AljaAru *uw AlqurobaY [in the Kur iv. 40] is The relation, or kinsman, who is abiding in one's neighbourhood: or who is abiding in one town or district or the like while thou art in another, and who has that title to respect which belongs to nearness of relationship: (TA:) or the near neighbour: (Bd, Jel:) or the near relation: (Jel:) or he who is near, and connected, by relationship or religion. (Bd.) jaAru Aljanobi: and AljaAru Aljunubu and jaAru Aljunubi: see art. jnb. jaArN nif~iyjN A stranger [who has become one's neighbour]. (TA.) ― -b2- A person whom one protects from wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, treatment. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b3- One who seeks, or asks, protection (Msb, K) of another: jaAruka signifying he who seeks thy protection. (TA.) ― -b4- A protector; (A, Mgh, Msb, K;) one who protects another from that which he fears; (Msb;) one who grants refuge, or protects, or preserves. (AHeyth.) mino *`lika AlA^amori humo jaArapN↓ They are protectors from that thing, is a phrase mentioned by Th, respecting which ISd says, I know not how this is, unless the sing. be supposed to be originally jaAy^irN, so as to have a pl. of the measure faEalapN [as jaArapN is originally jawarapN]. (TA.) ― -b5- An aider, or assister. (IAar, Msb, K.) ― -b6- A confederate. (IAar, Msb, K.) ― -b7- A woman's husband. (Msb, K.) ― -b8- A man's wife; (Msb;) as also jaArapN↓: (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or the latter, the object of his love: (M:) and the latter also, a woman's fellow-wife; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) so called because the term Dar~apN is disliked, (Mgh, Msb,) as being of evil omen. (Mgh.) ― -b9- A partner who has not divided with his partner: so in the trad. AljaAru A^aHaq~u biSaqabihi [explained in art. Sqb]; as is shown by another trad. (Az, Msb.) ― -b10- A partner, or sharer, (Msb, K,) in immoveable property, such as land and houses, (Msb, TA,) and in merchandise, (K, TA,) whether he divide the property with the other or not, (Msb,) or whether he be partner in the whole or only in part. (TA.) ― -b11- One who divides with another. (IAar, K.) ― -b12- (tropical:) The froj [or pudendum] of a woman: and (tropical:) The anus; as also jaArapN↓. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b13- The part (IAar, K) of the sea-shore (IAar) that is near to the places where people have alighted and taken up their abode. (IAar, K.)

jaworN jwr jwrp
, an inf. n. used as an epithet, (TA,) i. q. jaAy^irN↓; (K, TA;) i. e. Declining, or deviating, from the right course: and acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: (TA:) pl. [of the latter], applied to men, jawarapN↓, (K,) in which the w remains unaltered contr. to rule, (TA,) and jaArapN↓, (A, K,) as in all the copies of the K, but some substitute for it, as a correction, juwarapN↓, [found in a copy of the A,] which, however, requires consideration, (TA,) and jaAy^iruwna. (K.) You say TariyqN jaworN A road, or way, deviating from the right course. (TA.) And huwa jaworN Eano TariyqinaA He is declining, or deviating, from our way. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, for *uw jawor, meaning Wronged, or unjustly treated, by the judge.
(Mgh from a trad.) ― -b3- Einodahu mina AlmaAli Aljaworu (tropical:) He possesses, of property, an extraordinary abundance. (A, TA.) See also jiwar~N.

jaArapN jAr jArh jArp
: see jaArN, in three places: ＝ -A2- and jaworN: ＝ -A3- and see also 4.

jawarapN jwr jwrh jwrp
and juwarapN: see jaworN.

A_in~ahu laHasanu Aljiyrapi Anh lHsn Aljyrh Anh lHsn Aljyrp
Verily he is good in respect of the mode, or manner, of jiwaAr [i. e. living as a neighbour, or binding himself by covenant to protect others]. (TA.)

jiwar~N jwr jwrp
A rain accompanied by vehement thunder: (K:) or by a vehement sound of thunder: (S:) or a copious rain; as also jaA^orN and juw^arN; (K in art. jA^r;) and, accord. to As, juw^aArN: (TA:) and an exceedingly great torrent. (TA. [In this last sense written in a copy of the A jaworN↓, and there said to be tropical.]) See jawaArN: and see also art. jr. ― -b2- You say also baAzilN jiwar~N (S) [app. meaning A camel nine years old that brays loudly: or] hard and strong: and baEiyrN jiwar~N a bulky camel. (TA.)

jawaArN jAryp jwAr
: see 3. ＝ -A2- Also The part of the exterior court or yard of a house that is coextensive with the house. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- Abundant and deep water. (K.) Whence jiwar~N↓ applied to rain. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Ships: a dial. var. of jawaArK; on the authority of Sá'id, (K,) surnamed Abu-l-'Alà: (TA:) said in the K to be strange; but similar instances are well known. (MF.)

juwaArN jAryp jwAr
: see 3, in two places. ― -b2- Also, and jiwaArN↓, or the latter is only an inf. n., The covenant between two parties by which either is bound to protect the other. (TA.)

jiwaArN jAryp jwAr
: see what next precedes. ＝ -A2- [Also a pl. of jaArN.]

jaAy^irN *
: see jaworN. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Wide and big; applied to a [bucket of the kind called] garob: and so, with p, applied to a [skin of the kind called] qirobap. (A, TA.)

mujaw~arN mjwr
[as meaning Thrown down, or overturned,] occurs in the following prov.:
yawomN biyawomi AlHafaDi Almujaw~ari
[A day for a day of the household-goods (or, accord. to the TA, the hair-cloth tent) thrown down, or overturned]: applied in the case of rejoicing at a calamity befalling another: a man had an aged paternal uncle, and used continually to go into the latter's tent, or house, and throw down his household-goods, one upon another; and when he himself grew old, sons of a brother of his did to him as he had done to his paternal uncle; wherefore he said thus, meaning, this is for what I did to my paternal uncle. (K.)

mujaAwirN mjAwr
: see 3, last sentence.

1 jaAza AlmawoDiEa
3 4
, (S, K,) or AlmakaAna, (A, Mgh, Msb,) aor. yajuwzu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. jawaAzN (S, Msb, K) and jawozN and juw^uwzN and majaAzN, (K,) He went, or passed, in, or along, the place, and left it behind; (Mgh, K;) [whether this be meant for one signification or two, does not appear; but in either case it is evident that one signification is he passed through, or over, or along, and beyond, the place; and this signification is of frequent occurrence;] as also jAz bihi; (K;) and AjAzhu↓; (Mgh;) and jAwzhu↓, (Mgh, K,) inf. n. jiwaAzN; (K, TA; in the CK jawaAzN;) and tjAwzhu↓; (Mgh;) lit., he traversed, or crossed, its jawoz, i. e., middle, and passed through it: (Mgh:) or he went, or passed, in, or along, the place; (As, S, A, Msb, TA;) as also jAz bihi, and jAwzhu↓, (TA,) and AjAzhu↓, (A,) and AjtAzhu↓: (S: [so it appears from its being said that AijotiyaAzN is syn. with suluwkN:]) and in like manner, AlT~ariyaqa the road: (TA:) AlmwDEa jAwz↓ and jAzhu signify the same: (TA:) or AjAzhu↓ (As, S, Msb, K) and jAwzhu↓ and tjAwzhu↓ (A) signify he left it behind him, (As, S, A, K,) and traversed, or crossed, it; (As, S, A, Msb;) and jAwzhu↓ and bihi jAwz↓ also signify he left it behind. (TA.) You say, juzotu xilaAla Ald~iyaAri, which is like jusotu [I passed amid, or among, the houses: (see the remarks on the letter z:) or I went to and fro amid, or among, the houses, in a hostile attack upon them: or went round about them]. (Ibn-Umm-Kásim, TA.) And juzotu bika*aA, i. e., bihi Aijotazotu↓ [I passed by, and beyond, such a thing]. (TA.) And jAz Ealayohi He passed by him, or it; syn. mar~a bihi, and Aimotar~a bihi and Ealayohi. (M and K in art. mr.) And jaAzahu He passed, or crossed, over it. (L.) jAz and AjAz↓ are syn. [in this last sense]. (TA.) You say, AlS~iraATi A^aEaAnaka A@ll~`hu EalaY A_ijaAzapi↓ (A, TA) May God aid thee [to pass, or cross, over, or] to pass along, and to leave behind thee, the Sirát. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the Sirát, faA^akuwnu A^anaA Ealayohi waA^um~atiY A^aw~ala mano yujiyzu↓ [And I, with my people, shall be the first who will pass over it]: yjyz being here syn. with yajuwzu. (TA.) ― -b2- juzotu Al$~aYo'a A_ilaY gayorihi: see 3. ― -b3- jAz Ald~irohamu fatajaw~azahu↓ [The piece of money passed, or was current, and he accepted it as current: in the TA written jAz Aldrhm ktjwzh, and without any syll. signs; but that the reading which I have adopted is right appears from what immediately follows:] a poet says,
wazuy~afu
[Pieces of money whereof there are current and bad]: and Lh mentions the saying, lamo A^ara Aln~afaqapa tajuwzu bimakaAnK kamaA tajuwzu bimak~apa [I have not seen money for expenses pass away in a place as it passes away in Mekkeh]: ISd says, He has not explained it, but I think that the meaning is tanofuqu. (TA.) ― -b4- jAz Al$~aYo'u, inf. n. jawaAzN, The thing was, or became, allowable; it passed for lawful: as though it kept the middle (jawoz) of the road. (TA.) You say, jaAza AlbayoEu, and Aln~ikaAHu, (A, Mgh,) and AlEaqodu wagayoruhu, (Msb,) [The sale, and the marriage, and the contract, or other thing, was, or became, allowable; or] passed as right, sound, valid, or good [in law:] (Msb:) or had effect. (Mgh.) [And jAz lahu A^ano yafoEala ka*aA It was allowable to him to do so. And yajuwzu A^ano yakuwna ka*aA It may be so; or such a thing may be.] ＝ -A2- jaAzahu in the sense of AjAzhu: see 4, second sentence, in two places.

2 jaw~aza
see 4, in nine places.

3 jAwzhu * and jAwz bihi
, inf. n. jiwaAzN: see 1, in six places. ― -b2- jAwz AlHad~a, and Alqadora, inf. n. mujaAwazapN; and so tjAwz↓, alone; He exceeded, or transgressed, the proper bound, or limit, or measure; acted extravagantly, exorbitantly, or immoderately: he, or it, was, or became, excessive, extravagant, exorbitant, or immoderate. (The Lexicons &c. passim.) ― -b3- jaAwazotu Al$~aYo'i A^ilaY gayorihi (S, Msb *) I passed from the thing [to another thing]; (Msb;) as also tajaAwazotuhu↓; (S, Msb;) i. q. juzotuhu↓. (S.) ― -b4- jAwz Eano *anobihi: see 6. ― -b5- [Hence, app.,] kaAna mino xuluqiY AljiwaAzu It was of my disposition to be easy, or facile, in selling and demanding. (TA from a trad.) ＝ -A2- jAwz bihi: see 4, in two places.

4 AjAz * and AjAzhu
: see 1, in six places. ＝ -A2- AjAzhu He made him to go, or pass along; as also jaAzahu↓: (TA:) he made him to pass through, or over, or along and beyond: (S, IF, Msb, K;) as also [bihi jAwz↓, as will be shown by an ex. below, and jw~zhu↓, and] jaAzahu↓, for which we find jAwzhu incorrectly substituted in the K. (TA.) A rájiz says,
xal~uwA AlT~ariyqa Eano A^abiY say~aAraho
Hat~aY yujiyza saAlimFA HimaAraho
[Leave ye the road to Aboo-Seiyárah until he make his ass to pass through, or over, safely]. (S.) And it is said in the Kur [vii. 134, and x. 90], bibaniY A_isoraAy^iyla AlbaHora wajaAwazonaA↓ [And we made the Children of Israel to pass through the sea]. (TA.) You say also lahumo A_ibilahumo jaw~aza↓, inf. n. tajowiyzN, He led for them their camels one by one until they passed. (K.) ― -b2- [He made it to pass, or be current; as also jw~zhu↓: as in the following phrases.] A^ajazotu EalaY A@somihi i. q. jaEalotuhu jaAy^izFA [I made his name to pass, or be current, by stamping money with it]: (ISk, S, TA:) and Darabotu [I coined, or minted, money in his name]. (ISd, TA.) And AlD~ar~aAbu Ald~araAhima jw~z↓, inf. n. tajowiyzN, [The coiner, or minter,] made the dirhems, or pieces of money, to pass, or be current. (Mgh.) ― -b3- He made it, or held it, to be allowable, or to pass for lawful; he allowed it, or permitted it; (S, K, TA;) as also jw~zhu↓: (S, TA:) syn. saw~aga: (S, K:) and syn. of A_ijaAzapN, [the inf. n. of the former verb,] A_i*onN. (K, TA: omitted in the CK.) You say, AjAz lahu maA SanaEa, (S, K, *) and lh jw~z↓, (S,) He made, or held, what he did to be allowable, &c. (S, K.) And AlEaqolu h`*aA mim~aA laA yujuw~izuhu↓ [This is of the things which reason will not allow]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- [He granted him the authority or degree of a licentiate in some one or more of the various departments of learning, for the instruction of others therein;] he
granted him a license with respect to the matters that he had related and heard [from other learned men, to teach the same]. (TA.) You say also, AjAz lifulaAnK jamiyEa masomuwEaAtihi mino ma$aAy^ixihi [He ters which he had heard from his sheykhs, to teach the same to others]. (TA.) The licentiate is termed mujaAzN↓: and the matters which he relates are termed mujaAzaAtN↓. (TA.) ― -b5- AjAz AlbayoEa, (A, Mgh, K,) and Aln~ikaAHa, (A, Mgh,) and AlEaqoda, (Msb,) He (the judge, A, Mgh) made the sale, (A, Mgh, K,) and the marriage, (A, Mgh,) and the contract, (Msb,) to have effect; he executed or performed it; (Mgh, Msb K;) lahu for him: (K:) he decreed it. (Mgh.) And [in like manner] AjAz raA^oyahu, and jw~zhu↓, He made his judgment, or opinion, to have effect; he executed or performed it. (K.) Hence the saying, in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr, qabola A^ano yujayzuwA EalaY~a, i. e., Before they slay me, and execute your order upon me. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A^ajaAzaniY (S, K *) (tropical:) He gave me water for, (S,) or he watered [for me], (K,) my land, or my beasts. (S, K.) And A_ibilahu jw~z↓, (K,) inf. n. tajowiyzN, (TA,) He watered his camels. (K.) And AjAz Alwafoda He gave to the party who came as envoys, or the like, the quantity of water sufficient to pass therewith from one watering-place to another. (TA.) And A^ajaAzahu maA='F yajuwzu bihi AlT~ariyqa (assumed tropical:) He gave him water wherewith to travel the road. (A.) And A^ajizoniY maA='F Give thou me some water that I may go my way, and pass from thee. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) AjAzhu bijaAy^izapK, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) and AjAzhu bijaAy^izapK saniy~apK, (S, A,) (assumed tropical:) He (the Sultán) gave him a gift, or present, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) and he gave him a gift, or present, of high estimation. (S, A. *) Or the origin of the expression was this: Katan the son of 'Owf, of the tribe of Benoo-Hilál-Ibn-'Ámir-Ibn-Saasa'ah, gave the government of Fáris to 'Abd-Allah Ibn- 'Abbás; and El-Ahnaf passing by him with his army on an expedition to Khurásán, he waited for them upon a bridge, and said, A^ajiyzuwhumo [Make ye them to pass over]; and he began to mention the lineage of each man and to give him according to his rank: (S:) or from the fact that a certain commander, having a river between him and an opposing force, said, mano jaAza h`*aA Aln~ahora falahu ka*aA [Whoso passeth this river shall have such a thing]; and whenever one passed over, he received a jaAy^izap. (TA.) You say also, A^ajaAzahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He gave him. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., A^ajiyzuwA Alwafoda binaHowi maA kunotu A^ujiyzuhumo bihi Give ye to the party who come as envoys, or the like, a similar jaAy^izap to that which I used to give them. (TA.)

5 tjw~z All~ayolu jAz AlmwDE
The darkness of the night cleared away. (A.) ＝ -A2- tjw~z fiY SalaAtihi He relaxed, or remitted, in his prayer; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) and so in other things; (A;) and abridged it; and was quick in it: said to be from Aljawozu “the act of traversing, and going, or passing along:” (TA:) or did less than was sufficient in it. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, tjw~z fiY A^axo*i Ald~araAhimi, (A, Mgh,) or tjw~z Ald~araAhima, (K,) He accepted the dirhems, or pieces of money, as current; did not reject them: (A, Mgh:) see 1: or he accepted them as they were, or notwithstanding what was in them: (Lth, TA:) or he accepted them notwithstanding what was intermixed with them, (K, TA,) [of bad money,] concealed therein, and notwithstanding their fewness. (TA.) In the phrase Alt~ajaw~uzu biduwni AlHaq~i [The accepting less than what was due], the inf. n. is made trans. by means of bi because it implies the meaning of Alr~iDaA [which is made trans. by the same means]. (Mgh.) tajaAwazo↓ also occurs in the sense of tajaw~azo in a trad. of Ibn-Rawáhah: h`*aA laka watajaAwazo fiY Alqasomi This is thine, or for thee, and be thou remiss, or not extreme, in, or with respect to, the division: and is allowable, though we have not heard it. (Mgh.) You say also, tajaw~aza fiY h`*aA AlA^amori maA lamo yatajaw~azo fiY gayorihi He bore patiently, or with silence and forgiveness, and with feigned neglect, or connivance, in this affair, or case, what he did not so bear in another. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- See also 6, in three places. ＝ -A3- tjw~z fiY kalaAmihi He made use of a trope, or tropes, in his speech. (S, K.) [See majaAzN, below.]

6 tjAwzhu jAwz tjAwz tjAwzh tjAwzp
: see 1, first sentence: and see also 3. ＝ -A2- tjAwz i. q. A^aforaTa, [i.e., jAwz AlHad~a, explained above,] fiyhi in it, or with respect to it. (K. See 3.) ― -b2- tjAwz Eanohu, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) and tjw~z↓; (S, A, Mgh;) and tjAwzEano *anobihi, (A, K,) and tjw~z↓, and jAwz↓; (K;) He (God, S, A, or a man, Msb) passed him by, or over, without punishing him; or forgave him; (S, A, Mgh, Msb;) namely, an evil-doer; (A, Mgh, Msb;) and He passed by, or over, without punishing, or forgave, his sin or offence. (A, K. *) You say, Aall~`hum~a tajaAwazo Ean~iY, and Ean~iY tajaw~azo↓, O God, pass me by, or over, without punishing me; or forgive me. (S, A.) tjAwz Eanohu, followed by a noun in the accus. case, also signifies He forgave him a thing. (L.) And the same alone, He feigned himself neglectful of it; he connived at it. (K.) ― -b3- [Also, this last phrase alone, He transcended it.] ― -b4- tajaAwazo fiY Alqasomi: see 5.

8 AjtAzhu A^jtAzh AjtAzh AjtAzp {jtAz {jtAzh
: and AjtAz bihi: see 1.

10 AstjAzhu AstjAzh AstjAzp {stjAz {stjAzh
He asked, or demanded, of him permission. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- He asked, or demanded, of him [the authority or degree of a licentiate; i. e.,] a license with respect to the matters that he had related and heard [from other learned men, to teach the same]. (TA.) [See 4.] ＝ -A2- (tropical:) He asked, or demanded, of him (S, K) water for, (S,) or to water [for him], (K,) his land, or his beasts. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- He approved it. (Har p. 326.)

jawozN jwz
The middle (S, K) of a thing, (K,) or of anything; (S;) [as, for instance,] of a desert, (A,) and of a camel, (TA,) and of the night: (A, TA:) and the main part of a thing, (K,) or of the night: (TA:) pl. A^ajowaAzN; (Sb, S, A;) beside which it has no other. (Sb.) ＝ -A2- [The walnut; or walnuts;] a well-known fruit, (K,) which is eaten: (Msb:) a Persian word, (S,) arabicized; (S, Msb, K;) originally Gawozo: (Mgh, Msb, K:) n. un. jawozapN: (S, TA:) pl. jawozaAtN: (S, K, TA: in the CK jawozaAnN:) the tree thereof abounds in the land of the Arabs, in the province of El-Yemen, where it bears fruit and is cultivated; and in the Sarawát (Als~arawaAt) are trees thereof, which are not cultivated: the wood thereof is characterized by hardness and strength. (AHn. TA.) ― -b2- jawozu baw~ay, (K,) or jawozu baw~aA, with the short alif, as heard from the physicians, in Persian Gawozi buwyaA, (Mgh, under the letter b,) [vulgarly called jawozu AlT~iybi, The nutmeg;] a certain medicine; (K;) it is of the size of the gall-nut (EafoS), easily broken, with a thin coat, (Mgh, TA,) having a pleasant odour, (Mgh,) or a pleasant and sharp odour; and the best kind is the red, with a black coat, and heavy: (TA:) it is good for the [affection of the face termed] laqowap, strengthens the stomach and heart, and removes cold. (Mgh.) ― -b3- jawozu maAvilK [The datura stramonium, or thorn-apple;] also a certain medicine; (K;) having the property of producing torpor; resembling the jawozu AlqaYo'i (see what follows); having upon it small, thick thorns; and its seed is like that of the A^utoruj~ [or citror.]. (TA.) ― -b4- jawozu Alq~Yo'i [Nux vomica;] also a certain medicine, (K,) having a power similar to that of the white xarobaq [or hellebore]. (TA.) ― -b5- jawozu Alhinodi [The cocoa-nut;] what is commonly called the naArajiyl. (TA.)

jawozapN jwz jwzh jwzp
: see jaAy^izapN, in four places. ＝ -A2- Also n. un. of jawozN [q. v.].

jiyzapN jyzh jyzp
: see jaAy^izapN.

AljawozaA='u AljwzA='
A certain constellation (najomN); (S;) a certain sign of the Zodiac; (K;) [namely, Gemini;] said to cross the jawoz (i. e. the middle, TA) of the sky; (S, TA;) for which reason it is [asserted to be] thus called. (TA.) ― -b2- Also i. q. Aljab~aAru [The constellation Orion]: (A and K in art. jbr:) it has three very bright stars disposed obliquely in the midst thereof, called by the Arabs Aln~aZomu, and niTaAqu AljawozaA='i, and faqaAru AljawozaA='i. (Har p. 456.)

jawaAzN jwAz
(assumed tropical:) The act of watering, or giving to drink: (S:) or a single watering of, or giving drink to, camels. (TA.) [See also jaAy^izapN.] A rájiz says,
yaA SaAHiba A@lomaA='i fadatoka nafosiY
Eaj~ilo jawaAziy waA^aqil~a HabosiY
[O master of the water (may my soul be thy ransom) hasten the watering of my camels, and make my detention little]. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The water with which beasts are watered, or with which seed-produce is watered: (AA, S, K:) [and] water which is given one that he may travel with it the road. (A, Mgh.) [See also jaAy^izapN.] ― -b3- Hence, (Mgh,) (assumed tropical:) The traveller's pass, (A, Mgh, K,) given him to prevent any one's offering opposition to him: (A, Mgh:) pl. A^ajowizapN. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- The office, or authority, of a guardian and affiancer. (TA.)

jaAy^izN *
[act. part. n. of jaAza, in all its senses]. ― -b2- Passing, or current, money. (Mgh.) See an ex. above, voce jaAza. [And hence,] jawaAy^izu AlA^a$oEaAri, and AlA^amovaAli, (K, TA,) for the former of which we find, in some copies of the K, Al$~iEori, which is incorrect, (TA,) Verses, or poems, and proverbs, current from country to country, or from town to town. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Applied to a contract, [and a sale and a marriage, Allowable; passing for lawful;] passing as right, sound, valid, or good [in law]; having effect. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- [The beam of a house, or chamber, upon which rest the EawaAriD, or rafters;] that upon which are placed the extremities of the pieces of wood in the roof of a house or chamber; (AO, TA;) the palm-trunk, (S,) or piece of wood, which passes across between two walls, (K,) called in Persian tiyor, (S, K,) which is the sahom of the house or chamber: (S:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajowizapN, (S, CK, TA,) in [some of] the copies of the K, incorrectly, A^jowuzN, (TA,) [and both these are given in the CK,] and [of mult.] juwzaAnN (S, K) and jiyzaAnN (CK, but omitted in my MS. copy of the K and in the TA,) and jawaAy^izu. (Seer, K.)

jaAy^izapN *
(assumed tropical:) A draught of water; (S, K;) as also jawozapN↓: (K:) or ↓the latter signifies a single watering, or giving of water to drink; (S, K; [see an ex. in art. A*n, conj. 2;]) or such as a man passes with from one person to another: and ↓both signify the quantity of water with which the traveller passes from one watering-place to another; as also jiyzapN↓. (TA.) It is said in a prov., vum~a yuw^u*~anu likul~i jaAbihK jawozapN↓, i. e., (assumed tropical:) For every one that comes to us for water is a single water-ing, or giving of water to drink; then he is repelled from the water: or, as in the M, then his ear is struck, to indicate to him that he has nothing more than that to receive from us. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (A, Mgh,) accord. to Aboo-Bekr, (TA,) [but see 4,] (assumed tropical:) A gift, or present: (Aboo-Bekr, S, Mgh, K:) pl. jawaAy^izu. (S, A, Mgh.) ― -b3- Hence also, (Mgh,) (tropical:) Kindness and courtesy: (K:) or kindnesses and courtesy shown to those who come to one as envoys or the like: (Mgh:) or provisions for a day and a night given to a guest at his departure after entertainment for three days. (Mgh, TA.) It is said in a trad., AlD~iyaAfapu valaAvapu A^ay~aAmK wajaAy^izatuhu yawomN walayolapN wamaA zaAda fahuwa SadaqapN, meaning, [The period of] the entertainment of a guest is three days, during the first of which the host shall take trouble to show him large kindness and courtesy, and on the second and third of which he shall offer him what he has at hand, not exceeding his usual custom; then he shall give him that wherewith to journey for the space of a day and a night; and what is after that shall be as an alms and an act of favour, which he may do if he please of neglect if he please. (TA.)

majaAzN mjAz mjAzy
A way, road, or path, (S, K, TA,) which one travels from one side [or end] to the other; (K, TA;) as also majaAzapN↓. (TA.) You say, jaEala fulaAnN *`lika AlA^amora majaAzFA A_ilaY HaAjatihi (assumed tropical:) Such a one made that thing a way to the attainment of his want. (S, TA.) nahorK majaAzapu↓ signifies A bridge. (A.) And majaAzapN↓ alone [also] signifies A road (TariyqapN) in a saboxap [or salt tract]. (K.) ― -b2- A privy, or place where one performs ablution; syn. mutabar~azN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A trope; a word, or phrase, used in a sense different from that which it was originally applied to denote, by reason of some analogy, or connexion, between the two senses; as, for instance, A^asadN, properly signifying “ a lion, ” applied to “ a courageous man; ” (KT, &c.;) what passes beyond the meaning to which it is originally applied; (TA;) [being of the measure mafoEalN in the sense of the measure faAEilN;] contr. of HaqiyqapN. (K.) [This is also called majaAzN lugawiY~N, and majaAzN lugapF; to distinguish it from what is termed majaAzN EurofiY~N, and majaAzN EurofFA, which is A word, or phrase, so little used in a particular proper sense as to be, in that sense, conventionally regarded as tropical; as, for instance, daAb~apN in the sense of “ a man, ” or “ a human being; ” it being commonly applied to “ a beast, ” and especially to “ a horse ” or “ a mule ” or “ an ass. ”] A Haqiyqap, when little used, becomes what is termed majaAzN EurofFA. (Mz, 24th nwE.) The majaAz is either what is termed AisotiEaArapN [i. e. a metaphor] (as A^asadN used as meaning “ a courageous man ”), or majaAzN murosalN [a loose trope] (as yadN used as meaning “ a benefit, ” “ benefaction, ” “ favour, ” or “ boon ”). (KT, &c.) [majaAzN also signifies A tropical meaning.]

mujaAzN mjAz mjAzy
: and mujaAzaAtN: see 4, in the middle of the paragraph.

mujiyzN mjyz
A commissioned agent of another; an executor appointed by a will; syn. wakiylN, and waSiY~; because he executes what he is ordered to do: so in the conventional language of the people of El-Koofeh: (Mgh:) or a slave who has received permission to traffic. (Mgh, K.) ― -b2- The guardian and affiancer [of a woman]; syn. waliY~N. (K.) You say, h`*ihi A@moraA^apN layosa lahaA mujiyzN [This is a woman who has no guardian and affiancer]: and Shureyh is related to have said, A_i*aA A^anokaHa A@lomujiyzaAni faAln~ikaAHu liloA^aw~ali [When the two guardians and affiancers give a woman in marriage, the marriage is the former's]. (TA.) ― -b3- The manager of the affairs of an orphan. (K.)

majaAzapN mjAz mjAzh mjAzp
: see majaAzN, in three places. ＝ -A2- A^aroDN majaAzapN (S, A) A land containing trees of the jawoz [or walnut]: (S:) or a land (in the K, makaAn [a place], which is wrong, TA) abounding with jawoz. (A, K.)

[
majaAziY~N mjAz mjAzY mjAzy mjAzyy
Tropical.]

mujataAzN mjtAz
Going, or passing along. (K.) ― -b2- One who travels, or penetrates, along a road. (K.) ― -b3- One who loves to hasten, or outstrip. (K, TA.)

1 jaAsa jAs
, aor. yajuwsu, (S, TA,) inf. n. jawosN, (A, K,) He sought for, or after, (Zj, S, A, K,) a thing, (Zj, A, K,) or news, or tidings, (S,) with the utmost of his endeavour. (Zj, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jaAsuwA xilaAla Ald~iyaAri, (S, A,) in the Kur [xvii. 5], (TA,) inf. n. as above, (S, A, K,) They went through the midst of the houses (taxal~aluwhaA), and sought for what was in them, as a man seeks for news, or tidings; as also AjtAswA↓: (S:) or they went to and fro among the houses, in a sudden attack: (A, K:) or the meaning in the Kur is, they slew you amid your houses; and HaAsuwA signifies the same; going and coming: (Fr, TA:) and, inf. n. as above, (K,) and jawasaAnN, (S, K,) they went round about (Zj, S, A, K) by night, (S,) among the houses, (Zj, A, K,) looking if any remained whom they had not slain, (Zj, TA,) or doing mischief: (A:) and AijotiyaAsN↓ signifies the same as jawasaAnN, (K, TA,) the going round about by night.
