(TA.) ― -b3- jiysa also signifies It (anything) was trodden: jawosN is said to be like dawosN: (TA:) and you say, jaA='a fulaAnN yajuwsu Aln~aAsa Such a one came stepping over the people; syn. yataxaT~aAhumo. (A, TA. *) And accord. to A' Obeyd, jusotuhu and Husotuhu both signify I came into it, and trod it; (xaAlaTotuhu wawaTiy^otuhu;) meaning, any place. (TA.) You say also, jaAsahumu AlA^asadu The lion trod upon them: or came into the midst of them, and did mischief among them. (TA; [in which the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is said to be jawosN and jawosaA='u: but the latter is probably a mistranscription for jawasaAnNu.])

8 A_ijotawasa
see 1, in two places.

jaw~aAsN jwAs
One who treads upon everything: or who comes into the midst of a people, and does mischief among them. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) The lion. (K, TA.) And in like manner it is applied to a man. (TA.)

jawosaqN jwsq
i. q. qaSorN [A palace: or a pavilion, or kind of building wholly or for the most. part isolated, sometimes on the top of a larger building, i. e., a belvedere, and sometimes projecting from a larger building, and generally consisting of one room if forming a part of a larger building]: (S, K, and Ham p. 823:) or a fortress; syn. HiSonN: (M, IB, TA:) or [a building] resembling a HiSon: (M:) an arabicized word, (Lth, JK, S, M,) from the Persian kuw$ok: (TA:) its primary meaning is a HiSon in a state of demolition; and a ruined qaSor: pl. jawaAsiqu and jawaAsiyqu; the latter formed by giving fulness of sound to the kesreh, or by poetic license. (Ham ubi suprà.) There were, in the Karáfeh, [the great burial-ground of the Egyptian metropolis,] numerous quSuwr, i. e., what are called jwAsq, having belvederes (manaAZir) and gardens: but most of the jwAsq were without gardens and without a well; being lofty belvederes: all of them were called quSuwr. (El-Makreezee's “ Khitat, ” ii. 453.)

jawo$N *
The breast; (S, A, K;) as also juw^o$uw$N (S) and jawo$N: (S, A:) and [particularly] that
of a man; as also juw$N↓: (K:) and the middle of a man. (K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The fore part (Sador) of the night; like jaro$N; (S;) and so juw$N↓: (TA:) or the middle thereof; (K;) as also jawozN: (AA:) and a great portion thereof: or of the latter part thereof: (K:) or a portion of the latter part thereof: (TA:) or from the time of a quarter to a third thereof. (T, TA.) You say, maDaY jawo$N mina All~ayoli (assumed tropical:) [A portion of the fore part, &c., of the night passed]. (S.)

juw$N *
: see above, in two places.

jawo$anN *
The breast: (IDrd, S, Mgh, K:) or the broad part of the middle of the breast: and the fore part of the body of a locust. (TA.) ― -b2- A coat of mail: (S, Mgh, K:) or mail with which the breast and the Hayozuwm [or parts adjoining the breast] are clad. (M, TA.) ― -b3- The middle of the night: (S, K:) and (so in the S, but in the K “ or ”) the fore part thereof: (S, K:) pl. jawaA$inu. (S.) You say, maDaY jawo$anN mina All~ayoli An early portion of the night passed: (S:) or [simply] a portion of the night. (M, TA.) It is a dial. var. of jawo$N, [in the first of the meanings explained above, and also as relating to the night,] although augmented. (TA.)

jawo$aniY~N *
A manufacturer of coats of mail. (K.)

1 jaAEa jAE
, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yajuwEu, (S,) inf. n. jawoEN, (Msb, K,) or juwEN, (S, so in two copies,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb, TA,) and majaAEapN, (S, K,) He was, or became, hungry; or empty in the belly; (TA;) contr. of $abiEa. (S, K, TA.) [See also juwEN below.] ― -b2- [Hence,] jaAEa A_ilayohi, (K,) or jaAEa A_ilaY liqaAy^ihi, (M, TA,) (tropical:) He desired, (M, K, *) and longed, (K,) [as though hungering,] to meet with him; like EaTi$a. (M, K. *) And jaAEa A_ilaY maAlihi (tropical:) He longed for his property. (AZ.)

2 jaw~aEa
see 4, in two places.

4 AjAEhu A^jAE A^jAEh A_jAEp AjAEh AjAEp
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_ijaAEapN; (Msb;) and jw~Ehu↓, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tajowiyEN; (Msb;) He constrained him to be hungry, or empty in the belly: (S, * K, TA:) or he debarred him from food and drink. (Msb.) It is said in a prov., A^ajiEo kalobaka yatobaEoka [Make thy dog to be hungry and he will follow thee]; (S, K;) meaning (assumed tropical:) constrain thou the ignoble to have recourse to thee, by want, in order that he may continue by thee; (K, * TA;) for if he be in no need of thee, he will leave thee: and for A^ajiEo, some say jaw~iEo↓. (TA.)

5 tjw~E jAE jwE tjwE
He made himself hungry, or empty in the belly, intentionally, or purposely. (S, K.) You say, tawaH~a$o lild~awaA='i and tajaw~aEo lild~awaA='i, [Make thyself hungry, or make thy stomach empty of food and beverage, (see art. wH$,) or] abstain thou from eating the full quantity of food, for the purpose of taking medicine. (TA.)

10 AstjAE AstjAE
He showed hunger. (KL, PS.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AisotijaAEapu AlEilomi (assumed tropical:) The being insatiable of knowledge. (TA.)

juwEN jwE
, a subst., (Msb, TA,) signifying Hunger; or emptiness of the belly; (TA;) contr. of $ibaEN; (S, K, TA;) as also majaAEapN↓, [properly an inf. n.,] and majowaEapN↓, (K, TA,) and majuwEapN↓. (TA.) You say, juwEFA lahu wanuwEFA [May God decree hunger to him]: accord. to Sb, an instance of inf. ns. in the accus. case by reason of a verb understood: it is a form of imprecation: and the latter noun may not be put before the former, because it is a corroborative to it: (TA:) or, accord. to some, nuwEN means “ thirst. ” (S, &c., in art. nwE.) And EaAmu majaAEapK↓ and majowaEapK↓ (S, K) and majuwEapK↓ (TA) A year in which is hunger, or emptiness of the belly: (K, TA:) and EaAmu AlmajaAEapi↓ and AlmajuwEapi↓ [the year of hunger, &c.]: (Msb:) pl. majaAy^iEu (K) and majaAwihu: as in the phrases A^aSaAbatohumu AlmajaAwiEu [Cases of hunger, &c., befell them] and waqaEuwAfiY AlmajaAwiEi [They fell into cases of hunger, &c.]. (TA.) And Alr~aDaAEapu mina AlmajaAEapi↓, meaning The sucking which occasions interdiction [of marriage with the woman whose milk is sucked and certain of her relations] is that consequent upon hunger which is stopped by the milk in the time of infancy of the child; not when the child's hunger is only to be stopped by solid food. (Mgh.) [See also 1 in art. rDE.] And it is said in a prov., samanu kalobK bijuwEi A^aholihi, i. e. [The dog's becoming fat is] by reason of [the hunger of his owners occasioned by] murrain befalling the camels; (K, * TA;) his owners falling into hunger and distress and leanness: (TA:) or klb was the name of a certain man, who was an object of fear, wherefore he was asked for a pledge, and he pledged his family: then obtaining possession of the camels, or cattle, of the people to whom he had pledged his family, he drove them away, and left his family: (K, TA:) some relate this prov. differently, saying [samina kalobN “ a dog, ” or “ Kelb, ” “ became fat, ” and] bibuw^osi A^aholihi [“ by reason of the distress of his owners, ” or “ his family ”]. (TA.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 615.]

jawoEapN jwE jwEh jwEp
A single temporary affection of hunger. (S, TA.) A state of destitution and hunger of a tribe. (TA.)

jawoEaAnu jwEAn
: see the next paragraph.

jaAy^iEN *
and jawoEaAnu↓, (Msb, K, TA,) but not jayoEaAnu, [as the vulgar say,] for this a mistake, (TA,) Hungry; or empty in the belly: (K, * TA:) or debarred from food and drink: (Msb:) the fem. [of the former] is jaAy^iEapN and [of the latter] jawoEaY: (Msb, K:) and the pl. [of the former] is juw~aEN (S, Msb, K) and juy~aEN, with the w changed into Y, (L,) and [of the latter, or perhaps of both,] jiyaAEN (S, K) and jaAEapN (K * in art. swE) and jayaAEaY [with the w changed into Y contr. to rule, if this be not a mistake for jiyaAEN, in which the w is changed into Y by rule]. (Msb.) You say jaAy^iEN naAy^iEN; the latter word being an imitative sequent; (TA;) or, accord. to some, signifying “ thirsty. ” (S, &c., in art. nwE.) ― -b2- rajulN jaAy^iEu Alqidori (tropical:) A man whose cookingpot is not full. (TA.) ― -b3- AimoraA^apN jaAy^iEapu Alwi$aAHi (tropical:) A woman slender in the [waist, or] belly. (K, * TA.) [See art. w$H.]

majaAEN mjAE
[The space in which one becomes hungry]. You say, huwa min~iY EalaY qadori majaAEi Al$~aboEaAni, i. e., EalaY qadori maA yajuwEu Al$~aboEaAnu [He, or it, is distant from me as far as the space in which he who is satiated with food becomes hungry]: (O, K: *) and in like manner, EalaY qadori maEoTa$i Alr~ay~aAni [as far as the space in which he who is satisfied with drink becomes thirsty]. (Z, TA.)

majaAEapN mjAEh mjAEp
: see juwEN, in four places.

majowaEapN mjwEh mjwEp
and majuwEapN: see juwEN, in five places.

musotajiyEN mstjyE
A man (S) who always shows himself, or is seen, to be hungry: (S, A, O, K:) or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, who is always eating one thing after another. (Sgh, L.)

1 jawafN A^jwf jwf
The being [hollow, or] wide and hollow within: (PS:) or the being empty, vacant, or void: an inf. n. of which the verb is of the class of taEiba [i. e. jaAfa, originally jawifa, like xaAfa, sec. pers. jifota, aor. yajaAfu]: (Msb:) the being wide, spacious, or ample: (K:) the inf. n., or source, whence $aYo'N A^ajowafu. (S.) [See also 10.] ＝ -A2- jaAfahu, [aor. yajuwfu,] inf. n. jawofN, It reached his jawof [or inside, or interior, &c.]. (TA.) It (medicine) entered his jawof. (TA. [See also 8.]) And jaAfatohu AljiraAHapu The wound reached his jawof. (Msb.) ― -b2- TaEanahu fajaAfahu, and AjAfhu↓, He pierced him and pierced his jawof: (Mgh, Msb:) and jw~fhu↓, inf. n. tajowiyfN, he pierced him in his jawof. (TA.) jufotuhu biAlT~aEonapi, and AlT~aEonapa A^ajafotuhu↓, I made the spear-wound, or the like, to reach his jawof. (Ks, A 'Obeyd, S, K.) jaAfa AlS~ayoda He made the arrow to enter the jawof of the object of the chase. (TA.)

2 tajowiyfN tjwyf
The making [a thing] hollow, or empty in the middle. (KL, PS.) You say, jw~fhu, inf. n. tajowiyfN, [He made it hollow; hollowed it out;] he made it to have a jawof. (Msb.) And of a thing that is mujaw~af, (S, K,) i. e. A^jowaf, (S,) you say, fiyhi tajowiyfN [In it is a hollowing out; meaning a hollow, in which sense tjwyf has a pl., namely, tajaAwiyfu]. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also 1.

4 A^ajowafa
see 1, in two places. ― -b2- AjAf AlbaAba (tropical:) He shut, or closed, the door. (S, K, TA.) Hence, in a trad., waA^ajiyfuwA AlA^abowaAa waA^aTofiy^uwA AlmaSaAbiyHa [And shut ye the doors, and extinguish the lamps]. (TA.)

5 tjw~f jwf tjwf
It was, or became, hollow, or empty within. (KL.) ＝ -A2- tjw~fhu: see 8. ― -b2- tajaw~afati AlxuwSapu
AlEarofaja The leaf was in the jawof [or inside] of the [plant called] Erfj, not having yet come forth. (S.)

8 AjtAfhu AjtAfh AjtAfp
He entered its jawof [or inside, or interior; he entered into the midst of it]; as also tjw~fhu↓. (S, K.) [See an ex. in a verse of Lebeed, voce A^aSolN: and see also 1.]

10 AstjAf 10 and Aisotajowafa
It (a thing) became wide, spacious, or ample. (S, K.) [See also 1, first sentence.] ＝ -A2- AstjAfhu He found it (a place) to be A^ajowaf [i. e. hollow, or empty within; or wide, spacious, or ample]. (O, L, K.)

jawofN A^jwf jwf
[A hollow; an interior empty, vacant, or void, space;] a vacancy: pl. A^ajowaAfN: this is the primary signification: then it was used in relation to a thing capable of being occupied and of being unoccupied; so as to be applied in the sense next following. (Msb.) ― -b2- The inside, or interior, (Msb, KL,) of a house [&c.]. (Msb.) ― -b3- [The midst, or middle, of a thing.] ― -b4- A low, or depressed, (S, K, TA,) and wide, (TA,) tract, or portion, of land, or ground: (S, K, TA:) what is wider than the $iEob; the [water-courses termed] tilaAE, and the valleys, flow into it; and it has jirafap [or abrupt, water-worn, banks]: sometimes it is wider than a valley, and deeper: and sometimes it is a plain, or soft, tract, that retains water: and sometimes it is completely round, so that it retains water: accord. to IAar, it signifies a valley: or, as some say, the interior (baTon) of a valley. (TA.) ― -b5- The belly, or abdomen, of a man: (S, K:) or, accord. to ISd, the interior of the belly: and the part upon which close the shoulder-blades and the upper arms and the ribs and the two flanks (AlS~uqolaAni): (TA:) the chest, or thorax; i. e., the part of the body that is separated from the baTon [or belly, or abdomen,] by the HijaAb [or diaphragm, or midriff]; containing the heart and its appertenances: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) pl. as above. (TA.) See also jaAy^ifN. It is one of the words that are not used adverbially except with prepositions. (Sb, TA.) It is said in a trad., laA tanosawuA Aljawofa wamaA waEaY [Forget not ye the jwf and what it hath collected]; meaning what enters into it, of food and beverage: but some say that Aljwf here means the belly and the faroj [or vulva, or pudendum muliebre], together, which are also called AlA^ajowafaAni↓: and some say that the meaning is, the heart and what it hath retained, and kept in memory, of the knowledge of God. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b6- AlA^ajowaAfu is also applied by the people of El-Ghowr (K) and of El-Yemen (TA) to The tents (fasaATiyT) of their Eum~aAl [or governors, or collectors of the poor-rates]. (K.) ― -b7- jawofu All~ayoli AlA=xiru, occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) The last third of the night: [or] the fifth of the sixths of the night: (K:) not the half, as some assert. (TA.)

jawofiY~N A^jwf jwf jwfY jwfy jwfyy
: see A^ajowafu.

juwfiY~N A^jwf jwf jwfY jwfy jwfyy
: see A^ajowafu. ＝ -A2- Also, and without tesh-deed, (S, K,) [app. meaning, when with the article Al, written and pronounced AljuwfiY,] in the accus. case juwfiyFA, by poetic license, (S,) A species of fish; and so juwaAfN↓. (S, K.)

juwfaAnN jwf jwfAn
The penis of an ass: (El-Muärrij, K:) and of a man. (TA.)

juwaAfN jwAf
: see juwfiY~N.

jaAy^ifN *
Reaching the jawof. (Msb.) [Hence,] TaEonapN jaAy^ifapN, (S, Mgh, K, &c.,) or jiraAHapN jaAy^ifapN, (Msb,) A spear-wound, or the like, that reaches the jawof↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) by which is here meant [the interior of the body or head, or], accord. to IAth, any vital part, as the belly and the brain: (TA:) and sometimes, that penetrates into the jwf: (A 'Obeyd, S, Mgh:) and that passes through also: (A 'Obeyd, S:) and said to be such as is in the pit between the collarbones, and in the pubes; but not in the neck, nor in the throat, nor in the thigh, nor in the leg: (Mgh:) not if it reaches the interior of the bone of the thigh: (Msb:) opposed to jaAlifapN. (S in art. jlf.) ― -b2- Hence, jaAy^ifapN is applied to (tropical:) A great fault or imperfection or vice. (TA from a trad.) ― -b3- taloEapN jaAy^ifapN A deep [water-course, &c.: see tlEh]: pl. jawaAy^ifu. (K, TA. [In the CK, qaSiyrapN is erroneously put for qaEiyrapN.]) ― -b4- jawaAy^ifu Aln~afosi The deep recesses of the jawofa [or chest] in the places where the soul has its seat; expl. by maA taqaE~ara mina Aljawofi fiY maqaAr~i Alr~uwHi. (L, K.) So in the phrase, used by El-Farezdak, warad~a Aln~afosa bayona AljawaAy^ifi [And he drove back the soul into the midst of the deep recesses of the chest]: (L, TA:) but some read byn Al$~araAsifi. (TA.) ― -b5- AljaAy^ifu [The cephalic vein;] a vein that runs along the upper arm to the [cartilage called] nagoD of the shoulder-blade; it is the faliyq. (TA.)

A^ajowafu *
Having a jawof; (TA;) [i. e.,] hollow, or empty within; (KL, PS;) having in it a tajowiyf [or hollowing out, meaning a hollow], (S,) and so mujaw~afN↓: (S, K: [but the latter is more properly rendered hollowed, or hollowed out:]) empty, vacant, or void: (Msb:) wide, spacious, or ample; (S, K;) as also musotajaAfN↓, (S, TA,) and juwfiY~N↓, with damm, (K,) thus correctly written, being a rel. n. altered from the original form, like suholiY~N and duhoriY~N, (Sgh, TA,) but meaning wide in the jawof [or belly, &c.], written by J [in the S] jawofiY~N↓, with fet-h: (TA:) great in the jawof; (TA;) as also majuwfN↓; (AO, S, K;) each applied to a man: (TA:) [fem. jawofaA='u:] pl. juwfN. (TA.) You say luw^oluw^N A^ajowafu, and mujaw~afN↓, [Hollow, and hollowed, pearls; or] both signify the same. (TA.) And qanaApN jawofaA='u An empty [or a hollow] cane, or reed: (K:) and in like manner, $ajarapN [a tree]; (S, K;) having a jawof. (S.) And dalowN jawofaA='u A wide, or an ample, bucket: (K:) and dilaA='N jawfN wide, or ample, buckets: (S:) and qidorN jawofaA='u a wide, capacious, cooking-pot. (Ham p. 719.) And AlA^ajowafu The lion that is great in the jawof [or belly, &c.]. (K.) And AlA^ajowafaAni The belly and the faroj [or vulva, or pudendum muliebre]; (S, K;) because of their width. (TA.) See also jawofN. Hence the trad., A_in~a A^axowafa maA A^axaAfu Ealayokumu AlA^ajowafaAni [Verily what I most fear for you are the belly and the vulva]. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A cowardly man; as also mijowafN↓, and mujaw~afN↓; the last explained in the K as meaning having no heart: pl. [of the first] juwfN. (TA.) ― -b3- A horse white in the jawof [or belly] as far as the part where the sides terminate, whatever be the colour of the rest of him; (AO, TA;) as also mijowafN↓. (TA.) [See also mujaw~afN.] ― -b4- In the conventional language of the science of inflection, (assumed tropical:) [A hollow word; i. e.] a word having an infirm letter for its medial radical; (K, TA;) as qaAla and baAEa. (TA.)

mujaAfN mjAf
(tropical:) A shut, or closed, door. (TA.)

majuwfN mj*wf
: see A^ajowafu.

mijowafN mjwf
: see A^ajowafu, in two places.

mujaw~afN mjwf
: see A^ajowafu, in three places. ― -b2- Also A beast whose balaq [q. v.] reaches up to his belly: (As, S, K:) or a horse whose balaq reaches to his sides is said to be mujaw~afN balaqFA. (AA, TA.) [See also A^ajowafu, last meaning but one.] ― -b3- And an epithet applied to the bird called Surad, because it is white in the belly. (Mgh and Msb in art. Srd.)

musotajaAfN mstjAf
: see A^ajowafu.

1 jaAla jAl
, (S, K, &c.,) aor. yajuwlu, (S,) inf. n. jawolN (S, K) and juwlN (K) and jawalaAnN (Az, S, ISd, Z, Sgh) and juw^uwlN (ISd, K) and jiylaAlN, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) in some copies of the K jiylaAn; (TA;) and in like manner, AjtAl↓ and AnjAl↓; (S, K;) He went round or about, or or round about; as also jw~l↓, inf. n. tajowaAlN: (K:) or jw~l signifies he went round, or about, or round about, much, or often; agreeably with what Sb says of the measure tafoEaAlN; but accord. to the O, tajowaAlN is an inf. n. of jAl. (TA.) You say, jAl fiY AlbilaAdi He went about, or round about, in the countries, or districts, not remaining fixed, or settled: (Msb:) and AlbilaAda jw~l↓, (T, TA,) or jw~l fiY AlbilaAdi, (S,) inf. n. tajowiylN, (T, TA,) or tajowaAlN, (S,) he went about, or round about, much, or often, in the countries, or districts. (T, S, TA.) And jAl fiY AlmayodaAni, aor. as above, inf. n. jawolapN and jawalaAnN, He (a horse) traversed the sides, or lateral parts or tracts, of the horse-course; which are termed A^ajowaAlN, pl. of juwlN. (Msb.) And jAl fiY AlHarobi, inf. n. jawolapN, He wheeled round, or about, in battle. (K.) And far~a lilojawalaAni vum~a EaAda liloqitaAli [He fled, to wheel round, or about, and then returned to the fight]. (Msb in art. kr.) And jAluwA, (Msb,) or tajaAwaluwA↓, (S, K,) means jAl baEoDuhumo EalaY baEoDK, (S, Msb,
K,) i. e., They assailed, or assaulted, one another, (TA,) fiY AlHarobi [in battle]; (S, Msb, K;) [and so, app., jaAwaluwA↓, inf. n. mujaAwalapN:] and kaAnato bayonahumo mujaAwalaAtN↓ (S, K *) There were between them mutual [assailings, or assaults, and] defendings. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) And jAl Alqawomu, inf. n. jawolapN, The company of men were routed, defeated, or put to flight, (Ainoka$afuwA,) and then returned to the fight, or charged, or assaulted. (K.) And A^aSaAba Almusolimiyna jawolapN Defeat befell the Muslims: a metonymy; used only in relation to the favourites of God; from AljawalaAnu. (Mgh.) ― -b2- jAlwuA fiY AlD~alaAlapi, (Sgh, TA,) or A_ilaY AlD~alaAlapi, (A, TA,) (assumed tropical:) They became excited to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness, and carried away, and driven, (Sgh, TA,) or they became fascinated, and turned away, (A, TA,) by the influence of devils, (A, Sgh, TA,) from their religion, (Sgh, TA,) or from the right course, (A, TA,) to error. (A, Sgh, TA.) ― -b3- jAl Alt~uraAbu, (ISd, K,) inf. n. jawolN, (TA,) The dust went away, and rose; as also AnjAl↓: (ISd, K:) or the latter signifies became removed, or cleared away [by the wind]; syn. Ainoka$aTa. (T, TA.) ― -b4- yajuwlu fiY SadoriY A^ano A^afoEalahu (tropical:) [It is revolved in my bosom, or mind, that I should do it]. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 4, in two places. ＝ -A2- jAl Al$~aYo'a, (K,) inf. n. jawolN, (TA,) He chose, or selected, the thing. (K.) You say, julotu h`*aA mino h`*aA I chose, or selected, this from this. (AA, S.) And manohumo jawolFA Aijotalotu↓ I chose, or selected, from them [a choice portion]; (S, K, * TA;) and separated some of them from others. (TA.) And mino maAlihi jawolFA AjtAl↓, and jawaAlapF, He chose, or selected, from his property, or cattle, a choice portion. (TA.)

2 jaw~ala
see 1, in two places.

3 jaAwaluwA jAwlwA
, inf. n. mujaAwalapN: and kaAnato bayonahumo mujaAwalaAtN: see 1.

4 AHAlhu AHAlh AHAlp A^HAl A^HAlh A_HAlp
, (Msb, K,) and AjAl bihi, (K,) inf. n. A_ijaAlapN, (S,) He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to go, move, or turn round, or about, or round about; to circle, or revolve; (S, Msb, K;) as also bihi jAl↓. (Zj, K.) One says in the game called Almayosir, [see this word,] A^ajili Als~ihaAma [Turn thou round about, i. e., shuffle, the arrows in the ribaAbap]. (S, TA.) And AjAl Als~ihaAma bayona Alqawomi He moved about the arrows, [i. e., shuffled them in the ribaAbap,] (Az, ISd, TA,) and then distributed them among the people, or party. (Az, TA.) And AjAl sayofahu He brandished, flourished, or played with, his sword, turning it round about. (Msb.) And baAlt~uraAbi Alr~iyHu tajuwlu↓, (Lth, TA,) and biAlHaSaY, (K, TA,) [The wind makes the dust, and the pebbles, to turn round about, to circle, or to revolve.] ― -b2- A^ajaAluwA Alr~aA^oYa fiymaA bayonahumo (tropical:) They turned about, or revolved, [in their minds, the idea, or opinion, respecting the matter that was between them.] (TA.) And AjAlwA Alfikari (assumed tropical:) [They turned about, or revolved, thoughts, ideas, schemes, or contrivances, in their minds]. (Jel in ix. 48.) ― -b3- [AjAl xamosahu fiY wiEaAy^ihi, in the 7th Makámeh of Har, (p. 76 of the sec. ed.,) is explained in a MS. of that work as meaning Adxl, (De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., p. 185,) i. e., He inserted: but the proper meaning is, he turned about, or round about, his five fingers in his bag.] ― -b4- A^ajilo jaAy^ilataka↓ (tropical:) Accomplish, or finish, the affair in which thou art engaged. (M, K, TA.)

6 tajaAowala
see 1.

7 A_inojawala
see 1, in two places.

8 A_ijotawala
see 1, first sentence. ＝ -A2- AjtAlhumo He turned them from their course. (K.) He (the devil) caused them to leave, or forsake, the right way. (T, TA.) AijotaAlatohumu Al$~ayaATiynu Eano diynihimo The devils excited them to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness, so that they turned away from their religion, to error; i. e., they carried them away and drove them [from their religion]. (Sgh, TA.) [See also 10.] ＝ -A3- See also 1, last two sentences.

10 AisotajaAlatohumu Al$~ayaATiynu *
The devils turned them from the right course, to error; fascinated them so that they turned with them. (A, TA.) And AstjAlhu Al$~aYo'u The thing excited him to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness. (TA.) [See also 8.] ― -b2- AstjAlti Alxayolu maA mar~ato bihi The horses removed, or displaced, that by which they passed. (O, TA.) ― -b3- Ausotujiyla Alr~abaAbu The rbAb [or white clouds] were driven together after a state of dispersion, and became ready to rain: (M, TA:) or it means jaA='atohu Alr~iyHu faA@sotajaAlatohu, i. e., the wind came to them, and removed them, or displaced them, and dissundered them, and drove them away. (TA.) ― -b4- AisotajalonaA AljahaAma (tropical:) We saw the rainless clouds going about, or round about, in the horizon, (A, TA,) or in the sky. (TA.)

jaAlN jAl
: see juwlN, in five places: ― -b2- and mijowalN.

jaAlK jAl
: see jaAy^ilN.

jawolN jwl
: see jawolaAnN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A large army, or military force, or troop of horse: (Sgh, K:) pl. juwlN. (Sgh, TA.) A herd of camels: and a troop of xayol [meaning horses or horsemen]: as also juwlN↓ in both these senses: (K:) or the latter, which is also explained in the K as signifying a herd of camels, and a flock of ostriches and of sheep or goats, is pl. of the former: (TA:) or the former signifies thirty [horses or horsemen]: or forty: (K:) or less: or more: (TA:) or the choice, or best, of camels: and [in like manner] jawaAlapN↓ signifies the choice and best; as in the saying, A^axa*a jawaAlapa maAlihi [He took the choice and best of his cattle, or property]. (K. [See also 1, last two sentences: and see jawalaAn.]) And Many great sheep or goats. (K.) ― -b2- Also A male mountain-goat that is old, or advanced in age: (M, K:) pl. A^ajowaAlN. (M, TA.)

juwlN jwl
The wall [that surrounds the interior] of a well: accord. to A 'Obeyd, every side of a well, from its top to its bottom: and jaAlN↓ signifies the same: (S:) or the former, the side, or lateral part, (M, Msb, K,) of a well, and of a grave, and of the sea, and of a mountain; as also jaAlN↓ (M, K) and jiylN↓: (K, TA; in the CK jayol:) or the surrounding parts [or sides] of a grave: (M, TA:) and AlwaAdiY jaAlaA↓ the two sides of the water of the valley: and AlbaHori jaAlaA↓ the two shores of the sea, or great river: (T, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajowaAlN, (Az, S, Msb, K,) pl. of juwlN and jaAlN, (TA,) and [of mult.] jiwaAlN and jiwaAlapN; (so in copies of the K, and in the M, but in some copies of the K juwaAlN and juwaAlapN;) and A^ajaAwilu is pl. of A^ajowaAlN. (TA.) Also, as in the T and the Moheet, (TA,) The portion of rock that is at the bottom of the water, (K, TA.) upon which is the casing of the well; so that if it quit its place, the well falls to ruin: this is [said to be] the primary meaning of the word: and hence the saying, h`*aA maA='N laA yudoraku juwluhu [This is water of which the rock beneath it is not to be reached]. (TA.) ― -b2- [And from this word as signifying the casing of a well, or the portion of rock above mentioned,] (tropical:) Intelligence; (S, K, TA;) judgment, and intelligence, or full intelligence, or intelligence to which one has recourse; (T, TA;) understanding of the heart; (TA;) and resolution, or fixed purpose of mind; (S, M;) and prudence: (T, TA:) AlEazomu in the K is erroneously put for AlHazomu. (TA.) You say, of a man, maAlahu juwlN (tropical:) He has not intelligence and judgment, or fixed purpose of mind, to withhold him, or protect him; like the jwl of a well; (S, M, * TA; *) because a well, when cased with stone or the like, is stronger. (TA.) And rajulN lahu zaborN wajuwlN (tropical:) A man having judgment and intelligence, or full intelligence, or intelligence to which recourse is had; whose jwl does not become demolished: and in like manner, huwa mazobuwrN maAfawqa Aljuwli minohu waSulobN maAtaHota Alz~abori mina Aljuwli: and in the contr. case, layosa lifulaAnK juwlN (tropical:) Such a one has not intelligence nor prudence; i. e., his jwl is demolished, therefore one is not sure that the zbr [that rests upon it] may not also fall: and layosa lahu juwlN, and jaAlN↓, (tropical:) He has not prudence. (T, TA.) ― -b3- faEalotuhu mino juwlihi I did it on account, or for the sake, or because, of him, or it. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jawolN: ＝ -A3- and jawolaAnN.

jiylN jyl
: see juwlN.

jawolaAnN jwlAn
Dust; as also jawolN↓ and juwlN↓, (K,) both mentioned by Az, (TA,) and jayolaAnN↓, (K,) mentioned by ISd: [or] all signify dust which the wind makes to turn about or round about, to circle, or to revolve, upon, or from, the surface of the earth. (TA.) And Small pebbles which the wind makes to turn about or round about, to circle, or to revolve; (K, TA;) as also jawolN↓ and jayolaAnN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jawolaAnu: see A^ajowalu.

jawalaAnu Alhumuwmi jwlAn Alhmwm
(tropical:) The first, or beginning, [lit. the revolving, (see 1,)] of anxieties. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, jawolAnu.]) You say, fiY qalobihi jawalaAnu Alhumuwmi (tropical:) In his heart are revolving anxieties. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- jawalaAnu AlmaAli The small, or young, and bad, of cattle: (Fr, S, K:) so in the M and O; but in a copy of the M, written jawolAn; which is app. a mistake. (TA.) Accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, The choice, or
best, of cattle: the contr. of what is said by Fr. (TA. [See also jawolN.])

jayolaAnN jyl jylAn
: see jawolaAnN, in two places. ＝ -A2- jyolaAnu: see A^ajowalu.

jawolaAniY~N jwl jwlAn jwlAnY jwlAny
: see A^ajowalu. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A man whose benefits are common to the near and the distant; (K, TA;) whose benefits go round to every one. (Sgh, TA.)

jayolaAniY~N jylAnY jylAny
: see A^ajowalu.

jawiylN jwyl
What the winds sweep away (AHn, M, K) and round about, (AHn, M,) of fragments of plants and of the fallen leaves of trees; (AHn, M, K;) as also jaAy^ilN↓. (M, TA.)

jawaAlapN jwAl jwAlh jwAlp
: see jawolN.

jawaAy^ilu A^amorK *
(assumed tropical:) The turns (dawaAy^ir) of an affair, or event. (TA.)

jaw~aAlN jAlyp jwAl
One who goes about, or round about, much, or often, in the countries, or districts, (Msb,) TA,) not remaining fixed, or settled; (Msb;) as also jaw~aAlapN↓ [but in a more intensive sense, meaning who does so very much, or very often]. (TA.) ― -b2- A horse having a flexible head: (TA:) and A^ajowaliY~N↓ a swift horse, that turns about howsoever one turns him. (K, * TA.)

jaw~aAlapN jwAl jwAlh jwAlp
: see the next preceding paragraph.

jaAy^ilN *
: see jawiylN. ― -b2- Also Rainless clouds going round about. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And, applied to a [woman's ornament of the kind termed] wi$aAH, and to a camel's belly-girth, Loose; not tight; unsteady; as also jaAlK↓. (T, TA.) [Hence,] AimoraA^apN jaAy^ilapu Alwi$aAHayoni (tropical:) A woman slender in the waist. (Z, TA.)

jaAy^ilapN *
An affair in which one is engaged. (M, K.) See 4, last sentence.

A^ajowalu *
[More, and most, wont to go round, or about, or round about; to circle, or revolve;] is from the first of the verbs in this art.: and hence the prov., A^ajowalu mino quTorubK [More wont to go about, or round about, or more restless, than a qTrb; a certain animalcule, or insect, that is constantly moving about: see art. qTrb]. (Har p. 661.) ― -b2- Also, [as meaning (assumed tropical:) More, and most, circulating,] applied to language, or discourse. (TA in art. jmE.) [See an ex. voce majomaEN.] ― -b3- yawomN A^ajowalu, and jayolaAniY~N↓, and jawolaAniY~N↓, (Lh, M, K,) and jawolaAnu↓, and jayolaAnu↓, (M, K,) A day of much dust (T, M, K) and wind: (T, TA:) from jawolN signifying “ dust.” (TA.)

A^ajowaliY~N *
: see jaw~aAlN.

majaAlN mjAl mjAly
A place in which one goes round, or about, or round about: (TA:) [a field of battle: a circus:] a place of exercise for horses. (Har p. 16.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, lamo yaboqa majaAlN fiY AlA^amori (tropical:) [There remained not any scope in the affair, or case]. (TA.)

mijowalN mjwl
A certain garment for women, (M, K,) doubled, and sewed together at one of its two sides, and having an opening made to it at the neck and bosom; in which a woman goes about: (M, TA:) or for a young girl; (K;) the diroE being for a woman: (TA:) a small garment in which a girl goes about: (S:) or a garment which a girl wears before she is made to keep herself behind, or within, the curtain, and in which she goes about: (Z, TA:) accord. to IAar, i. q. SudorapN. (TA.) Imra-el-Keys says,
A_ilaY mivolihaAyaronuw AlHaliymu SabaAbapF
A_i*aA maA A@sobakar~ato bayona diroEK wamijowali
[At the like of her the staid would fixedly gaze with tenderness of desire, when she has become of erect and justly-proportioned stature, between such as wears a woman's shirt and such as wears a young girl's garment]. (S, * TA.) ― -b2- A woman's anklet. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- An amulet, a phylactery, or charm of the kind termed Euw*ap. (IAar, K.) ― -b4- A crescent of silver in the middle of the necklace termed qilaAdap. (IAar, K.) ― -b5- Silver [itself]. (Th, K.) ― -b6- A good, or sound, diroham [or silver coin]. (IAar, K.) ― -b7- A shield; (S, O, K;) sometimes used in this sense; (S, O;) as also jaAlN↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ― -b8- A large wooden bowl. (IAar, TA.) ― -b9- A white vawob [or piece of cloth] that is put upon the hand of him to whom the players at the game called Almayosir commit the arrows [to be shuffled and distributed, in order that he may not be able to distinguish them by the feel,] when they have collected themselves. (ISd, K, * TA.) [For the same purpose, a piece of thin skin was also used: see ribaAbapN.] ＝ -A2- A pool of water left by a torrent; because the water goes round about in it. (IF, TA.) ＝ -A3- A wild ass. (IAar, K.)

musotajaAlN mstjAl
[pass. part. n. of 10, Turned from the right course, &c.:] excited to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness: (TA:) being bereft of his reason, or intellect. (AA, TA.)

jaAmN jAm
A vessel, (K,) or faAvuwr [i. e. a basin, or a table, or a tray used as a table], (IAar, TA,) of silver: (IAar, K, TA:) or a white dish or tray, of glass or of silver: (Mgh:) or a vessel (Zarof) of glass: (Har p. 200:) [a Persian word, i. e. jaAmo, arabicized; or] a genuine Arabic word: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajow^umN, with ', (IAar, K,) and A^ajowaAmN, and (as some say, IAar, TA, [of mult.,]) juwmN, (K,) with damm, (TA, in the CK jawomN,) and [of pauc. or mult.] jaAmaAtN: (IAar, K:) but IB says that jaAmN is pl. of jaAmapN↓, as is also jaAmaAtN: [instead of which he should rather have said that jAm is a coll. gen. n. of which the n. un. is jAmp, (though this requires consideration, as the former is commonly used as a sing.,) and that the pl. of the latter is jAmAt:] that its dim. is juwayomapN↓: and that it, i. e. jAm, is of the fem. gender. (TA.)

jaAmapN j*Am j*Amh j*Amp
: see above.

juwayomapN jwymh jwymp
: see above.

1 jaAna jAn jAny
, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, jAn~a,]) inf. n. jawonN, (TA,) It (the face) became black. (K.)

jawonN jwn
White: and black: (S, Msb, K:) thus bearing two contr. significations: (S:) and juwniY~N↓, also, has the latter signification: (IAth, TA in art. Hwt:) or jawonN signifies black tinged over with red: (T, M, TA:) and black intermixed with red; the colour of the qaTaA: (T, TA:) and also red: (K:) or of a pure red colour: (TA:) and, applied to a horse and a camel, of the colour termed A^adoham, (S, K,) intensely black: (S:) every camel, and every wild ass, seen from a distance, is of this colour: fem. with p: (T, TA:) and, applied to a plant, or herbage, green, (K,) or intensely green, (TA,) inclining to blackness: (K, TA:) pl. juwnN; (S, TA;) like as SutomN is of SatomN, (S,) and wurodN of warodN. (M, TA.) You say also, Al$~amosu jawonapN The sun is characterized by what is termed juwnapN: (S:) or is intensely glistening and clear. (Az, TA.) [See also jawonapN below.] See also juwniY~N. Accord. to ISk, A^abuw Aljawoni means The white man: opposed to A^abuwAlbayoDaA='i meaning the negro. (TA in art. byD.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Day: (AO, S, K:) pl. as above. (K.) So in the saying,
gay~ara yaA binota AlHulayosi lawoniY
mar~u All~ayaAliY waA@xotilaAfu Aljuwoni
[The passing of the nights, and the alternating of the day, have changed, O daughter of El-Holeys, my colour]. (AO, S.) ― -b3- And, accord. to certain of the lawyers, metaphorically, (tropical:) The light: and the darkness. (Msb.) ― -b4- And accord. to IAar, (assumed tropical:) The frq [app. faraq, meaning day-break]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AljawonaAni The two extremities of the bow. (Fr, Az, K.)

jawonapN jwn jwnh jwnp
The sun; (K;) [i. e.] the sun's disc; because it becomes black [or of a blackish colour tinged with red] at setting; (S;) or it may be because of its whiteness and clearness; but it is said to be only applied to the sun when it is setting; opposed to gazaAlapN; as observed by MF: (TA:) [see also jawonN:] the sun is also called jawonaA='u↓, (K,) because of its becoming black [or of a blackish colour tinged with red] at setting. (TA.) ― -b2- A [jar such as is called] xaAbiyap: (IAar, TA:) or a xAbyp smeared with tar, or pitch. (S.) [See an ex. in a verse of Lebeed cited in art. dkn.] See also juwnapN. ― -b3- And A bucket (dalow) that has become black. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- And i. q. faHomapN [which may here mean either A piece of charcoal, or the blackness of night or the like]. (IAar, K.) ― -b5- And i. q. A^aHomaru [perhaps as a subst., meaning A red thing]. (K.) ― -b6- See also jawniY~N.

juwnapN jwn jwnh jwnp
The quality [i. e. colour], in horses, denoted by [the epithet] jawonN; like gubospN and duhomapN; (S;) in horses, i. q. jawonapN: (K:) and in the sun, also, the quality denoted by jawonapN [as fem. of jawonN, q. v.]: and blackness; as in the saying, laA A^afoEaluhu Hat~aY taboyaD~a juwnapu AlqaAri [I will not
do it until the blackness of pitch, or tar, become white]: but if you say AlqaAri jawonapu↓, the meaning is the xaAbiyp [smeared with tar, or pitch]. (S.) ＝ -A2- A small basket (sulayolap), (K,) or safaT, (K in art. jA^n,) of a round form, (TA,) that is with the sellers of perfumes, (S, K,) used for containing their perfumes: (K in art. jA^n:) called in Persian $iy$aho daAnN [a receptacle for bottles or the like]: (KL:) originally with ': (K:) or sometimes pronounced with ': (S:) El-Fárisee approved the suppression of the ': (M, TA:) pl. juwanN. (S, M, K.) [See also raboEapN.] ＝ -A3- A small mountain. (K.)

jawonaA='u jwnA='
: see jawonapN. ― -b2- Also A cooking-pot; (K;) because it is black. (TA.) ― -b3- And A she-camel such as is termed dahomaA='u [of an intense, or a dark, gray colour, without any admixture of white]; from jaAna said of the face. (K.)

juwniY~N jwn jwnY jwny
: see jawonN. ― -b2- Also A species of the kind of bird called qaTFA, (S, K,) black in the belly and wings, larger than the [species called] kudoriY~, one of the former species being equal to two of the latter: (S, TA:) or, accord. to ISk, the qTA compose two species; one called juwniY~N and kudoriY~N; and the other, gaTaATN; and the former is dusky, or dingy, or of a hue inclining to black and dust-colour, (A^akodar,) in the back, black in the inner side of the wing, yellow in the throat, short in the legs, having in the tail two feathers longer than the rest of the tail: (T, TA:) or, as some say, the kudoriy~ap and juwniy~ap are one of the two species of the qTA, and the other is the gTAT; and the former are short in the legs, yellow in the necks, black in the primary feathers of the wings, of a white hue tinged with red (Suhob) in the tertials: (TA voce gTAT, q. v.:) [but see kudoriY~N: the jwnY~ is described by De Sacy, on the authority of the book entitled dr~p AlmntqAp mn EjAy^b AlmxlwqAt wgrAy^b AlmwjwdAt, thus: “ le djouni a les barbes internes des ailes et les pennes primaires noires; il a la gorge blanche, ornée de deux colliers, l'un jaune et l'autre noir; son dos est d'un gris cendré, moucheté, mêlé d'un peu de jaune: on appelle cette espèce djouni, parce que sa voix ne rend pas un son clair et sonore, mais qu'elle fait entendre seulement une sorte de gargouillement dans le gosier: ” (Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., ii. 369:)] it is stated in the handwriting of As, on the authority of the Arabs, that jwnY~, applied to the qTA, is with '; app. meaning that it was pronounced juw^uniY~N: (M, TA:) a single bird of this species is termed juwniy~apN: (S:) and you say also qaTaApN jawonapN↓, with fet-h: (TA:) [but juwniY~N seems to be also used as a n. un., like ruwmiY~N: for it is said that] juwnN is pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of juwnY~N, like as tamorN is of tamorapN. (Ham p. 605.)

1 jaAhahu biAlmakoruwhi jAhh bAlmkrwh jAhh bAlmkrwp
, (S,) or bimakoruwhK, (K,) [aor. yajuwhu,] inf. n. jawohN, (S,) i. q. jabahahu bihi [He met him, or encountered him, with, or he said to him, or did to him, or he accused him, to his face, of, that which was, or a thing that was, disliked, or hated]. (S, K.) And [in like manner,] jAhhu bi$ar~K He encountered him with evil [speech or conduct]; or confronted him therewith: whence laA jihota, i. e. Mayest thou not be encountered with evil; said in chiding a he-camel: see jaAhi below. (TA.) A woman of Ghatafán, being chidden by her son, and being asked why she did not reply against him, said, A^axaAfu A^ano yajuwhaniY biA^akovara mino h`*aA, meaning I fear that he would encounter me with more than this. (JK.)

2 jw~h jw jwh jwp
and AjAh↓ are rendered by Golius Ad dignitatem evexit: spectabilem reddidit: as on the authority of the S: but in my copies of the S the two verbs are Awjh and wj~h; and belong to art. wjh, though mentioned in the present art.]

4 A^ajowaha
see 2.]

5 tjw~h jwy tjwh tjwp
He magnified himself; or was, or became, proud, haughty, or disdainful: or he affected rank, station, or dignity, not possessing it. (TA.)

jaAhN jAh jAp
Rank, station, or dignity, (S, K, TA, and JK in art. wjh,) with, or in the estimation of, the Sultán; (JK, TA;) as also jaAhapN↓, (K,) on the authority of Lh, (TA, as from the K, [but not in my copies,]) or, accord. to Sgh, of Ks.: the former word [probably arabicized from the Persian jaAho; but] said to be formed by transposition from wajohN; this being first changed to jawohN; then, to jawahN; and then, to jaAhN: or, accord. to Lh, it is not from wajohN, but from juhot [app. juhotu, first pers. sing. of jaAha, q. v.]; though he does not explain what is juhot. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN *uw jaAhK [Such a one is possessed of rank, station, or dignity]. (S.) And lifulaAnK jaAhN fiyhimo To such a one belongs rank, station, or dignity, among them. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) The dim. of jaAhN [or of jaAhapN] is juwayohapN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jaAhi, indecl., with kesr for its termination; and, accord. to As, sometimes, jaAhK, with tenween; (S;) or jaAhi jaAhi, (JK, K,) and jaAhK jaAhK, and jaAho jaAho, (Lh, K,) and juwh juwh↓, or jawoh jawoh, (accord. to different copies of the K, but) indecl., with kesr for the termination, [i. e. juwhi juwhi, or jawohi jawohi,] mentioned in the M, (TA,) and jaAhi laA jihota↓, (IDrd, TA, [see 1,]) ejaculations used for chiding a he-camel, not a she-camel: (As, JK, IDrd, S, K:) or one says to a she-camel, EaAjK and jaAhK. (A 'Obeyd, TA in art. Ewj: [or perhaps there is an omission here: I think it more likely that what A 'Obeyd said was that one says to a she-camel EaAjK, and to a he-camel jaAhK.])

juwhN jw jwh jwp
The face, or countenance: syn. wajohN; as also jiyhN: (Lh, K:) the latter with kesr: (TA:) so in the saying, naZara bijuwhi sawo'K and bijiyhi sawo'K [He looked with an evil face or countenance]. (Lh, K.) ＝ -A2- juwhi juwhi, or jawohi jawohi: see the next preceding paragraph.

jaAhapN jAh jAhh jAhp
: see jaAhN.

juwayohapN jwyhh jwyhp
: see jaAhN.

tujaAha tjAh tjAp
and tijaAha and tajaAha: see art. wjh.

jawoharN jwhr
: see art. jhr.

jawohariY~N jwhr jwhrY jwhry jwhryy
: see art. jhr.

1 jawiYa jw jwY jwy
, (S, K,) aor.
jawaYa
, (TA,) inf. n. jawFY, (K,) He (a man, S) was, or became, affected with what is termed jawFY↓, (S, K,) meaning ardour: and violence of amorous desire; or of grief, or sorrow: (S:) or inward love: (M, K:) and grief, or sorrow: (K, and so in a copy of the S:) and ardour: and violence of love: or of grief, or sorrow: (K:) [see Hub~N:] ― -b2- and also as meaning consumption; or an ulcer in the lungs: and long continuance, or oppressiveness, of disease: and a disease in the chest: (K:) or any inward disease during which one does not find food to be wholesome: (TA:) part. n. jawK↓; (S, K;) fem. jawiyapN. (TA.) ― -b3- You say also, jawiyato nafosiY, meaning I found the country, or town, to disagree with me. (S.) And jawiyato nafosuhu minohu and Eanohu [He found it to disagree with him: a meaning indicated, but not expressed]. (K.) See also 8. ― -b4- And jawiyati AlA^aroDu The land stank. (TA.)

8 AjtwAhu AjtwAh AjtwAp {jtwAh {jtwY
He disliked residing in it, namely, a country, or town, even if in the enjoyment of ease and plenty: (S:) or he disliked it, (K, TA,) and found it to disagree with him; (TA;) as also jawiyahu↓: (K, TA:) or he disliked it, namely, a city, and found it to be insalubrious: or, as AZ says, he disliked it, namely, a country, even if it agreed with him in respect of his body: and he says, in his Nawádir, that AijotiwaA='N signifies the yearning towards, or longing for, home, and disliking a place, even if in the enjoyment of ease and plenty: and disliking it without yearning towards, or longing for, home: and also the not finding the food nor the beverage in a land to be wholesome: but not when one likes the residing in it but its food and beverage do not agree with him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And AjtwY His heart was burnt by the fire of enmity. (Ham p. 219.)

jawFY jw jwY jwy
: see 1: ― -b2- and see what next follows, in two places.

jawK jw
part. n. of 1, q. v.; (S, K;) and jawFY↓ signifies the same, being an inf. n. used as an epithet. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) the former, (S, K,) as also ↓the latter, (K, and so in a copy of the S,) signifies Stinking water; (K;) or water that has become altered and stinking. (S, TA.) ― -b3- A^aroDN jawiyapN and jawiy~apN↓ A land that disagrees with one. (K.)

jawiY~N jw jwY jwy
Contracted in the bosom, (K, TA,) by reason of disease therein, (TA,) so that his tongue cannot explain for him, (K,) or so that his tongue can hardly, or not at all, explain for him. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aroDN jawiy~apN: see jawK.

3 jaAyaAhu jAyAh jAyAp
, inf. n. mujaAyaApN, He faced him, fronted him, was opposite to him, or was over against him: a dial. var. of jaAyaA^ahu. (IAar, K.) You say also, mar~a biY mujaAyaApF He passed by me being in front, or opposite. (TA.)

1 jaA='a jA='
, aor. yajiYo'u, inf. n. majiYo'N (S, Msb, K, &c., [the most common form, but] deviating from the general rule [respecting inf. ns. of this class], for the inf. n. of a verb of the form faEala having its aor. of the form yafoEilu is [accord. to the general rule, if commencing with an augmentative m,] mafoEalN, though some words, beside majiYo'N, deviate from this rule by being of the measure mafoEilN, [for majiYo'N is originally majoyiy^N,] as maEiy$N and makiylN and maSiyrN and masiyrN and maHiydN and mamiylN and maqiylN and maziydN and maEiylN and mabiyEN and maHiySN and maHiyDN, S, * TA) and jayoy^apN (S, K, of the form of an inf. n. of un., but used as an inf. n. in an absolute sense, like rajofapN and raHomapN, S, TA) and jaYo'N, (K,) He, or it, came; or was, or became, present; syn. A^ataY; (S, K;) or HaDara, said of a man [&c.]; (Msb;) or HaSala [meaning it came, came to pass, happened, took place, betided, befell, or occurred; it resulted; it ensued; &c.]; and it is used in relation to ideal, as well as real, substantives; so that A_i*aA jaA='a naSoru A@ll~`hi [When the assistance of God shall come (in the Kur ex. 1)] is [not a figurative but] a proper phrase. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Sb mentions, on the authority of certain of the Arabs, huwa yajiyka [for hw yajiyow^uka He comes, or will come, to thee], with the hemzeh suppressed: (TA:) and he also mentions yajuwo'u as a dial. var. of yajiYo'u. (Id. in art. jwA^, q. v.) [As shown above,] jaA='a is used intransitively and transitively. (Msb, MF.) say, jaA='a zayodN Zeyd came; or was, or became, present. (Msb.) And jiy^otu majiyoy^FA HasanFA [I came with a good coming; or in a good manner]. (S.) And jiy^otu zayodFA I came to Zeyd. (Msb.) And sometimes one says, jiy^otu A_ilayohi meaning I went [as well as I came] to him, or it. (Msb.) And jiy^otu mina Albaladi [I came from the town, or country]: and mina Alqawomi, meaning mino Einodi Alqawomi [from the presence of the people, or company of men]. (Msb.) And jaA='a Algayovu The rain [came, or] descended. (Msb.) And jaA='a A^amoru Als~uloTaAni The order, or command, of the Sultán came, or arrived. (Msb.) And jiy^otu bihi (S, Msb, K) and A^ajaA^otuhu↓, both signifying the same, (S, K,) [I came with him, or it;] I brought him, or it, with me. (Msb.) And AlHamodu ll~`hi Al~a*iY jaA='a bika [Praise be to God who brought thee]; and AlHamodu ll~`hi A_i*o jiy^ota [Praise be to God because, or that, thou camest, or hast come]; but not AlHamodu ll~`hi Al~a*iY jiy^ota: (S, TA:) and [in like manner] you say, AlHamodu ll~`hi A_i*o kaAna ka*aA; but not AlHamodu ll~`hi Al~a*iY kaAna ka*aA unless you say bihi or minohu or Eanohu [after Al*Y]. (ISk, TA.) [Hence, jaA='a biwaladK He begot a child, or children; like A^ataY biwaladK. And jaA='to bihi She brought him forth; gave birth to him; like A^atato bihi. And jaA='a bimaEonFY It (a word) conveyed, or imported, a meaning.] ― -b2- [jaA='a bi$aYo'K also signifies He brought to pass, did, executed, performed, or effected, a thing: and he said, gave utterance to, or uttered, a thing: like A^ataY bihi in both these senses.] And jaA='a ka*aA He did thus, or such a thing. (TA.) Hence, [in the Kur xix. 28,] laqado jiy^oti $ayoy^FA fariy~FA (TA) [Verily, O Mary, thou hast done] a thing hitherto unknown; a thing deemed strange. (Bd. [See another ex. voce A_imorN, likewise from the Kur.]) And jiy^otu $ayoy^FA HasanFA I did a good thing. (Msb.) And jaA='a biAlbadiyEi He produced a new saying, or new poetry, not after the similitude of anything preceding. (TA in art. bdE.) And jaA='a jaroyFA baEoda jaroYK (K in art. tA^m) or [more commonly] jA' bijaroYK baEoda jaroYK (M in that art.) [He (a horse) performed, or fetched, run after run]. ― -b3- jaA=' is also syn. with SaAra, like A^ataY; as in the saying, jaA='a AlbinaA='u muHokamFA The building became, or came to be, firm, strong, or compact. (Kull p. 11.) [And hence the phrase,] maA jaA='ato HaAjataka, (M, K,) thus in all the copies of the K, with the noun in the accus. case; i. e. What became, or has become, thy want? syn. maA SaArato; (M, K;) or What was thy want? syn. maA kaAnato: (Er-Radee, TA:) mA being here an interrogative, and the [implied] pronoun [in the verb] being made fem. because its predicate is fem.: but some say HaAjatuka, in the nom. case, [as it is in the CK, meaning What did, or has, thy want become?] regarding HAjtk as the subject of jA't, and mA as the predicate of this verb. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 3.

3 mujaAyaA^apN *
[inf. n. of jaAyaA^a] signifies The act of facing, or fronting; being opposite, or over against: (IAar, K:) and the act of coinciding; as also jiyaA='N. (AZ, K.) You say of a man, jaAyaA^aniY mino qurobK He faced me, fronted me, was opposite to me, or was over against me, at a short distance. (TA.) And mar~a biY mujaAyaA^apF He passed by me being in front, or opposite. (TA.) And jaAyaA^otu fulaAnFA I coincided with such a one in his coming. (TA.) And lawo jaAwazota h`*aA AlmakaAna lajaAyaA^ota Algayova Hadst thou passed beyond this place, thou hadst met with rain, or coincided with rain in its coming. (TA.) ― -b2- jaAA=niY fajiy^otuhu↓, [so in copies of the S, and in copies of the K, as from the S, but in the TA, as from the S, jaA='aA^aniY, and said to be with two hemzehs, though this is evidently wrong,] aor. A^ajiyow^uhu, the former verb of the measure faAEalaniY, (S,) is [said to be] a mistake for jaAyaA^aniY fjy^th, since the former verb has an infirm letter [Y] for its medial radical and ' for its final, not the reverse, (Sgh, K,) [therefore] what J says is not allowable unless it be an instance of transposition; (IB, TA;) but what is given by F [and Sgh as the correct form] is that which is accord. to rule, and what J says is that which has been heard from the Arabs, as ISd has pointed out; (TA;) [and rule is not to be regarded when it is contr. to classical usage;] the meaning is, He vied with me, or strove to surpass me, in frequency of coming, and I surpassed him therein. (S, K.)

4 A^ajaA'ahu *
He made him, or it, to come. (Kull p. 11.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^ajaA^otuhu i. q. jiy^otu bihi: see 1. (S, K.) ― -b3- A^ajaA^otuhu A_ilayohi I compelled him, constrained him, or necessitated him, to have recourse, or betake himself, to it; (Fr, S, K;) or made him to want it, or be in need of it: (S:) in the dial. of Temeem, A^a$aA^otuhu. (TA in art. $yA^.) It is said in a prov., $ar~N maA yujiyow^uka A_ilaY mux~api EuroquwbK [It is an evil thing that compels thee to have recourse to the marrow of a hock]; for, as As says, the Erqwb contains no marrow, and only he who cannot obtain any [other] thing is made to want it. (S.) And it is said in the Kur xix. 23, faA^ajaA='ahaA AlmaxaADu A_ilaY ji*oEi Aln~axolapi And the motion of the child in her womb compelled her to betake herself to the trunk of the palm-tree. (Bd.)

jiyoy^apN *
[A coming;] a subst. from jaA='a, (S, K,) of the measure fiEolapN, with kesr to the j. (S.)

jay^iy^N *
and jaA^~='N: see what next follows.

jay~aA='N jyA='
, (K,) mentioned by Sb as an extr. word, (TA,) [but regularly formed, of the measure faE~aAlN,] and jaA^~='N↓, also written jaA^~aA'N, (K,) with the Y changed into hemzeh, (TA,) and jay^iy^N↓, (K,) [originally jayiy^N, of the measure faEilN, denoting intensiveness, in the CK written jaAyiy^N,] mentioned by IJ as anomalous, A frequent comer. (TA.) One says, A_in~ahu lajay~aA='N bixayorK Verily he is a frequent bringer of good. (TA.)

[
jaA='K jA='
, originally jaAyiy^N, then jaAy^iy^N, then jaAy^iYN, and then jaA='K, Coming; act. part. n. of 1.]

1 jaAba jAb jAby
, aor. yajiybu: see 1 in art. jwb, in two places.

2 jy~b jyb
, inf. n. tajoyiybN: see 1 in art. jwb.

jayobN jyb
The Tawoq [or opening at the neck and bosom] (K) of a shirt (S, K) and the like; (K;) as, for instance, of a coat of mail: (TA:) or the opening of a shirt at the uppermost part of the breast: (Msb, MF:) or the opening in a garment for the head to be put through: or such an opening as a sleeve and a Tawoq: (MF:) pl. [of mult.] juyuwbN, (Msb, K,) also pronounced jiyuwbN, (TA,) [like biyuwtN for buyuwtN,] and [of pauc.] A^ajoyaAbN: (Msb:) this is said to be its proper art., (K, TA,) not jwb, because its pl. is juyuwbN. (TA.) [The Arabs often carry things within the bosom of the shirt &c.; and hence the word is now applied by them to A pocket.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The heart; the bosom. (K.) So in the saying, huwa naASiHu Aljayobi (assumed tropical:) [He is pure, or sincere, of heart or bosom]: (K:) or trusty, trustworthy, or faithful. (S. [See also art. nSH.]) A poet says,
waxa$~anota SadorFA jayobuhu laka naASiHu
(assumed tropical:) [And thou hast exasperated a bosom the heart of which was faithful to thee]. (TA.) You say also, huwa danisu Aljayobi (assumed tropical:) [He is a person of foul heart]. (A in art. dns.) And radaEa jayobahu Eanohu (assumed tropical:) He cleared his heart, or bosom, of it. (K in art. rdE q. v.) ― -b3- jayobu AlA^aroDi (assumed tropical:) The place of entrance of the land, or country: (K:) pl. juyuwbN. (TA.)

jiybapN jyb jybh jybp
: see art. jwb.

yaAquwtN mujay~abN yAqwt mjyb
Hollowed [sapphires]: occurring in a trad. describing the banks of the river of Paradise: but accord. to one reading, it is luw^oluw^N mujaw~abN; accord. to another, mujay~abN or majaw~afN; and accord. to another, mujay~abN or mujaw~abN. (TA.)

1 jaAHati AlA=fapu AlmaAla jAHt AlA=fp AlmAl
, aor. tajiyHuhu, inf. n. jiyaAHapN, [perhaps a mistranscription for jaAy^iHapN,] i. q. jaAHatohu of which the aor. is tajuwHuhu: see art. jwH. (Msb.) And jaAHahumu A@ll~`hu, inf. n. jayoHN and jaAy^iHapN, the latter an inf. n. like EaAfiyapN, God afflicted them with a calamity. (TA.)

majiyHN mjyH
i. q. majuwHN: see art. jwH. (Msb.)

1 jayida jyd
, (Lh, L,) or jaAda, of the same class as taEiba, aor. yajaAdu, (Msb,) inf. n. jayadN, (Lh, S, A, L, Msb, K,) He had a long neck: (A, Msb, K:) or a long and beautiful neck: (S, L:) or a slender and long neck. (L, K.)

jiydN jyd
, of the measure fiEolN, (Sb, Akh,) or it may be originally of the measure fuEolN, (Sb, TA,) The neck: (S, L, Msb, K:) said by Sh to be used only in praise; and EunuqN, in dispraise; the use of the former in the Kur exi. being ironical; (TA;) but accord. to Esh-Shiháb, the contr. is often the case: (MF:) generally applied to that of a woman: (L:) or the part of the neck upon which the necklace lies: or its fore part: (L, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^ajoyaAdN (S, L, Msb, K) and [of mult.] juyuwdN. (L, K.) lay~inapu AlA^ajoyaAdi means A female soft in respect of the neck; as though the term jiydN applied to each distinct part of the neck, and the pl. denoted the whole neck. (L.)

jayodaAnapN jydAnh jydAnp
: see A^ajoyadu.

jay~idN jyd
: see art. jwd.

A^ajoyadu *
Having a long neck: (A, Msb, K:) or having a long and beautiful neck: (S, L:) or having a slender and long neck: (L, K:) or it is not applied to a man: (T, TA:) fem. jayodaA='u, (S, L, Msb, K,) with which jayodaAnapN↓ is syn.; (K;) or this signifies having a beautiful neck: (L:) pl. juwdN [originally juyodN]. (S, A, K.) And EunuqN A^ajoyadu A long and beautiful, or slender and long, neck. (L.)

2 jy~r jyr
He plastered a watering-trough or tank with jay~aAr. (TA.)

jayori jyr
, with kesr to the r, (S, Mughnee, K, &c.,) like A^amosi; (Mughnee;) and jayora, like A^ayona; and sometimes jayorK; (Mughnee, K;) or this, where it occurs, is for jayori A_in~a, and is properly written jayorino, A_in~a in the sense of naEamo being a corroborative of jayori, and its hemzeh and sheddeh and final vowel being here suppressed: (Mughnee:) a form of oath, (S, K,) or put in the place of an oath, (IAmb, TA,) meaning Verily, or truly; syn. Haq~FA: (S, K:) or a responsive particle, (Mughnee,) meaning yes; syn. naEamo [which is most approved as responsive to an interrogation], (Mughnee, K,) or A^ajalo [which is most approved as responsive to an affirmation]; (Sharh et-Tesheel, K;) not a noun in the sense of Haq~FA, for were it so it would be an inf. n.; nor in the sense of A^abadFA, for were it so it would be an adv. n. of time; and if it were a noun it would be decl., and would admit the article Al, and would not have A_in~a for a corroborative, nor have laA opposed to it, as it has in the saying,
A_i*aA taquwlu laA A@bonapu AlEujayori
taSoduqu laA A_i*aA taquwlu jayori
[When the daughter of El-'Ojeyr says lA, she speaks truly: not when she says jyr]: (Mughnee:) or it is a verbal noun, meaning I know; syn. A^aEorifu; as is mentioned by Ibn-Abi-r-Rabeea, and by Er-Radee on the authority of 'Abd-El- Káhir. (MF.) You say, jayori laA A=tiyka Verily, or truly, [&c.,] I will not come to thee. (S.) And jayori laA A^afoEalu *`lika Verily, or truly, [&c.,] I will not do that. (K, * TA.) And laA jayori laA A^afoEalu No, verily, or truly, [&c.,] I will not do [that]. (K.)

jiyrN jyr
Gypsum; syn. jiS~N. (IAar, TA.) [In modern Arabic, Lime: see also what next follows.]

jay~aArN jyAr
Quick lime, and the mixtures thereof, with which are plastered watering-troughs or tanks, and baths; syn. SaAruwjN: (S, K:) quick lime and gypsum mixed with ashes: (IAar TA:) or quick lime alone. (TA. [See also jiyrN.]) ＝ -A2- [A limeburner: so in the present day: see A^atuwnN.] ＝ -A3- Heat in the chest, by reason of rage or hunger; as also jaAy^irN↓: (S, K:) or cough, or the like. (Ham p. 56.) It is app. of the measure faE~aAlN; or it may be of the measure fayoEaAlN; or fawoEaAlN [originally jawoyaArN]. (IJ, TA.) ― -b2- Strength, or vehemence. (TA.)

jaAy^irN *
: see jay~aArN.

mujay~arN mjyr
A watering-trough or tank made small: or made deep: or plastered with gypsum. (K.)

1 jaA$a *
, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yajiy$u, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. jayo$N (Msb, K) and jaya$aAnN (T, K) and juyuw$N, (K,) said of a cooking-pot (T, S, A, Msb, K) &c., (T, A, K,) It boiled, or estuated: (T, S, A, Msb, K:) or began to do so, not yet boiling or estuating; this latter being said by some to be the correct meaning. (Ib, L, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (the sea) estuated (A, * K, TA) with the waves, (A, TA,) so that it was unnavigable. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (a valley) flowed with much water, its water, or waves, rising high. (S, K. *) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) It (a water-spout, or pipe,) poured forth water: (TA:) and [in like manner] you say of the eye, jaA$ato, meaning, (assumed tropical:) it flowed, or overflowed, with tears. (K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He (a horse) reared, and became excited. (TA.) ― -b6- jaA$ato nafosuhu, (S, K,) or jaA$ato A_ilayohi nafosuhu, (A,) (tropical:) His soul [or stomach] heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. gavato; (S, K, TA;) or faArato; (T in art. vwr; see vaArato nafosuhu in that art.;) as though what was in his belly rose to his fauces: (TA:) or his soul [as it were] turned round, [i. e., he became giddy,] with the tendency to vomit: (S, K:) as also tjy~$t↓; (K;) which occurs in the former of these senses in a trad.: (TA:) and jaA$ato nafosuhu also signifies his soul [or stomach] heaved, by reason of grief or fright; (K;) [as also jaA^a$ato;] or when this last signification is meant, you say ja$aA^ato: (S:) and his (a coward's) soul purposed flight: or was frightened: as also jaA^a$ato, in either of these two senses: (TA:) and jaA$ato A_ilayohi Aln~afosu his heart quitted its place by reason of fear. (EM p. 79.) ― -b7- jaA$a Sadoruhu (tropical:) His bosom boiled with wrath, or rage. (TA.) You say also, Sadoruhu yajiy$u EalaY~a biAlgil~i (tropical:) [His bosom boils against me with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; or with latent rancour, &c.]. (A.) ― -b8- jaA$a Alham~u fiY AlS~adori Anxiety boiled in the bosom: and in like manner, jaA$ati AlguS~apu fiY AlS~adori (assumed tropical:) [Choking wrath or rage boiled in the bosom]. (T, TA.) ― -b9- jaA$at AlHarobu bayonahumo (A, L) (tropical:) War, or the war, [boiled, or raged, or] began to boil [or rage,] between them. (L, TA.) ― -b10- In the following words of a poet, cited by IAar,
qaAmato tabad~aY laka fiY jayo$aAnihaA
(assumed tropical:) [She arose, showing herself to thee] in her strength and youth, [tabad~aY being for tatabad~aY,] jy$An, [the inf. n.,] meaning as rendered above, is with sukoon [to the Y] by poetic license. (ISd, TA.)

2 jy~$ *
, [from jayo$N,] He collected, or assembled, armies, or military forces. (S.) And jy~$ jayo$FA [He collected, or assembled, an army, or a military force]. (A.)

5 tjy~$t nafosuhu *
: see 1. ＝ -A2- [tjy~$wA, from jayo$N, They became collected, or assembled, as an army, or a military force: or they formed themselves into an army, or a military force.]

10 AstjA$ *
, [from jayo$N,] He demanded, or summoned, armies, or military forces, mino maHal~i ka*aA from such a place. (A.) And AstjA$hu He demanded of him an army, or a military force. (S.)

jaA$N *
: see jaA^o$N, in art. jA^$, in two places; and see AljaAy^i$apu, below.

jayo$N *
An army; a military force: (A, K:) or a body of men in war: (TA:) or men going to war or for some other purpose: (T, K, TA:) pl. juyuw$N. (S, A Msb, K.)

jayo$apN *
A single rising, or heaving, or the like: pl. jayo$aAtN: hence the phrase jayo$aAtu AlA^abaATiyli [app. meaning The risings of false or vain things in the mind, or the like]. (TA.)

mirojalN jay~aA$N *
[A cooking-pot boiling, or boiling much]. (A.) ― -b2- farasN jiy~aA$N (assumed tropical:) A horse that rears and is excited when thou puttest him in motion with thy heel. (K * TA.)

AljaAy^i$apu *
The soul; syn. Aln~afosu; (K;) [as also AljaA^o$u, sometimes written AljaA$u↓, without ';] mentioned by some in art. jA^$. (TA.) Quasi

jayaAEaY jwEAn jyAEY jyAEy
and juy~aEN: see jaAy^iEN, in art. jwE.

, aor. tajiyfu; (K;) and jy~ft↓, (S, * K,) inf. n. tajoyiyfN; (S;) and AjtAft↓, (K,) [and tjy~ft↓, Golius, as from the K, but not found by me in any copy thereof,] and AnjAft↓; (TA;) The dead body stank, or became stinking. (S, * K, TA.)

jiyfapN jyfh jyfp
[A carcass, or corpse, i. e.] a dead body [of a beast or a man], that has become stinking; (S, Mgh, K;) or, as some say, in a general sense; [whether stinking or not:] (TA:) or, of beasts and cattle, an animal that has died a natural death, or been killed otherwise than in the manner prescribed by the law, and has become stinking: (Msb:) [and the corpse of a man: (see jay~aAfN:)] pl. [of mult.] jiyafN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] A^ajoyaAfN. (S K.) [Hence,] jiyfapu layolK quTorubu nahaArK One who sleeps all the night, and labours all the day. (TA from a trad. [See also art. qTrb.]) IDrd mentions this word in art. jwf, holding the Y to be originally w. (TA.)

jay~aAfN jyAf
A rifler, or ransacker, of graves; (K, TA;) because he removes the [grave-] clothes from the corpses, and takes them; or, as some say, because of the stinking nature of his act. (TA.)

jiylN jyl
A nation, people, race, tribe, or family of mankind; (S, Msb, K;) such as the Turks, and the Greeks, (S. TA,) and the Chinese: (TA:) pl. A^ajoyaAlN (M, Msb, TA) and jiylaAnN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And A generation of men. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also juwlN.
